Index

前言

PREFACE

 

《如何阅读一本书》于 1940 年初首次出版。令我惊讶的是，我承认，令我高兴的是，它立即成为畅销书，并在全国畅销书排行榜上保持了一年多的时间. 自 1940 年以来，它以精装本和平装本的形式继续广泛发行，并被翻译成其他语言——法语、瑞典语、德语、西班牙语和意大利语。那么，为什么要为当代读者重铸和重写这本书呢？

How to Read a Book was first published in the early months of 1940. To my surprise and, I confess, to my delight, it immediately became a best seller and remained at the top of the nationwide best-seller list for more than a year. Since 1940, it has continued to be widely circulated in numerous printings, both hardcover and paperback, and it has been translated into other languages—French, Swedish, German, Spanish, and Italian. Why, then, attempt to recast and rewrite the book for the present generation of readers?

这样做的原因在于过去三十年我们的社会和学科本身都发生了变化。今天，更多高中毕业的青年男女进入大学并完成四年学业；尽管广播和电视很受欢迎，甚至因为广播和电视的普及，但仍有很大比例的人口识字。人们的兴趣已经从阅读小说转向阅读非小说类作品。该国的教育工作者已经认识到，从最基本的意义上讲，教年轻人阅读是我们最重要的教育问题。卫生、教育和福利部最近的一位部长指定 70 年代为“阅读十年”，并投入了联邦资金支持各种努力，以改善熟练掌握这项基本技能，其中许多努力在儿童开始阅读艺术的水平上取得了一些成功。此外，大量成年人被速读课程的光辉承诺所吸引——承诺提高他们对阅读内容的理解以及阅读速度。

The reasons for doing so lie in changes that have taken place both in our society in the last thirty years and in the subject itself. Today many more of the young men and women who complete high school enter and complete four years of college; a much larger proportion of the population has become literate in spite of or even because of the popularity of radio and television. There has been a shift of interest from the reading of fiction to the reading of nonfiction. The educators of the country have acknowledged that teaching the young to read, in the most elementary sense of that word, is our paramount educational problem. A recent Secretary of the Department of Health, Education, and Welfare, designating the seventies as the Decade of Reading, has dedicated federal funds in support of a wide variety of efforts to improve proficiency in this basic skill, and many of those efforts have scored some success at the level at which children are initiated into the art of reading. In addition, adults in large numbers have been captivated by the glittering promises made by speed-reading courses—promises to increase their comprehension of what they read as well as their speed in reading it.

然而，有些事情在过去三十年里并没有改变。一个常数是，要实现阅读的所有目的，必须具备以不同的（适当的）速度阅读不同内容的能力，而不是以尽可能快的速度阅读所有内容。正如帕斯卡三百年前所说，“当我们阅读太快或太慢时，我们什么都不懂。” 由于速读已经成为一种全民时尚，新版的《如何阅读一本书》针对这个问题提出了变速阅读作为解决方案，目的是读得更好，总是更好，但有时更慢，有时更快.

However, certain things have not changed in the last thirty years. One constant is that, to achieve all the purposes of reading, the desideratum must be the ability to read different things at different—appropriate—speeds, not everything at the greatest possible speed. As Pascal observed three hundred years ago, “When we read too fast or too slowly, we understand nothing.” Since speed-reading has become a national fad, this new edition of How to Read a Book deals with the problem and proposes variable-speed-reading as the solution, the aim being to read better, always better, but sometimes slower, sometimes faster.

不幸的是，另一件没有改变的事情是未能对初级水平以外的阅读进行指导。我们大部分的教育智慧、金钱和努力都花在了前六年级的阅读教学上。除此之外，几乎没有提供正式培训来使学生获得更高和截然不同的技能水平。1939 年哥伦比亚大学师范学院的 James Mursell 教授为大西洋月刊撰写了一篇题为“学校的失败”的文章时，情况确实如此。他当时所说的，在我现在要引用的两段中，仍然是正确的。

Another thing that has not changed, unfortunately, is the failure to carry instruction in reading beyond the elementary level. Most of our educational ingenuity, money, and effort is spent on reading instruction in the first six grades. Beyond that, little formal training is provided to carry students to higher and quite distinct levels of skill. That was true in 1939 when Professor James Mursell of Columbia University’s Teachers College wrote an article for the Atlantic Monthly entitled “The Failure of the Schools.” What he said then, in two paragraphs that I am now going to quote, is still true.

学校里的学生是否学会有效地阅读他们的母语？是和不是。一直到五六年级，阅读总体上得到了有效的教授和良好的学习。到那个水平，我们发现一个稳定和普遍的改善，但超过它，曲线变平到死水平。这并不是因为一个人到了六年级就达到了他自然的效率极限，因为事实一再表明，通过特殊的辅导，大得多的孩子和成年人都可以取得巨大的进步。这也不意味着大多数六年级学生的阅读能力对所有人来说都足够好实用目的。很多学生在高中时表现不佳，因为他们完全没有能力从印刷的页面中获取意义。他们可以改进；他们需要改进；但他们没有。

Do pupils in school learn to read their mother tongue effectively? Yes and no. Up to the fifth and sixth grade, reading, on the whole, is effectively taught and well learned. To that level we find a steady and general improvement, but beyond it the curves flatten out to a dead level. This is not because a person arrives at his natural limit of efficiency when he reaches the sixth grade, for it has been shown again and again that with special tuition much older children, and also adults, can make enormous improvement. Nor does it mean that most sixth-graders read well enough for all practical purposes. A great many pupils do poorly in high school because of sheer ineptitude in getting meaning from the printed page. They can improve; they need to improve; but they don’t.

普通的高中毕业生阅读了大量书籍，如果他继续上大学，他会阅读更多；但他很可能是一个贫穷无能的读者。（请注意，这是对普通学生而言的，而不是作为特殊治疗对象的人。）他可以跟随一篇简单的小说并享受它。但是让他面对一篇写得严密的阐述，一个谨慎而简洁的论点，或者一个需要批判性考虑的段落，他会不知所措。例如，已经表明，普通的高中生在指出一段文章的中心思想，或者在论证或阐述中强调和从属的程度方面出奇地无能。就所有意图和目的而言，他一直是六年级的读者，直到进入大学。

The average high-school graduate has done a great deal of reading, and if he goes on to college he will do a great deal more; but he is likely to be a poor and incompetent reader. (Note that this holds true of the average student, not the person who is a subject for special remedial treatment.) He can follow a simple piece of fiction and enjoy it. But put him up against a closely written exposition, a carefully and economically stated argument, or a passage requiring critical consideration, and he is at a loss. It has been shown, for instance, that the average high-school student is amazingly inept at indicating the central thought of a passage, or the levels of emphasis and subordination in an argument or exposition. To all intents and purposes he remains a sixth-grade reader till well along in college.

如果需要如何阅读一本书三十年前，正如本书第一版的受欢迎程度所表明的那样，今天的需求要大得多。但是，满足这种更大的需求并不是唯一的，也不是重写这本书的主要动机。对学习阅读问题的新见解；对复杂的阅读艺术进行更全面、更有条理的分析；将基本规则灵活应用到不同类型的阅读中，实际上适用于各种阅读材料；发现和制定新的阅读规则；以及阅读金字塔的概念，底部宽阔，顶部逐渐变细——所有这些东西，在我三十年前写的书中没有得到充分处理或根本没有处理，

If there was a need for How to Read a Book thirty years ago, as the reception of the first edition of the book would certainly seem to indicate, the need is much greater today. But responding to that greater need is not the only, nor, for that matter, the main motive in rewriting the book. New insights into the problems of learning how to read; a much more comprehensive and better-ordered analysis of the complex art of reading; the flexible application of the basic rules to different types of reading, in fact to every variety of reading matter; the discovery and formulation of new rules of reading; and the conception of a pyramid of books to read, broad at the bottom and tapering at the top—all these things, not treated adequately or not treated at all in the book that I wrote thirty years ago, called for exposition and demanded the thorough rewriting that has now been done and is here being published.

《如何阅读一本书》出版后的第二年，以《如何阅读两本书》为题出现了对它的拙劣模仿；IA Richards 教授写了一篇题为《如何阅读一页》的严肃论文。我提到这两个续集是为了指出这两个标题所暗示的阅读问题，无论是诙谐的还是严肃的，在这次重写中都得到了充分的处理，尤其是如何阅读一些相互关联的相关书籍并阅读它们的问题以这样一种方式，他们必须清楚地掌握关于一个共同主题的互补和冲突的事情。

The year after How to Read a Book was published, a parody of it appeared under the title How to Read Two Books; and Professor I. A. Richards wrote a serious treatise entitled How to Read a Page. I mention both these sequels in order to point out that the problems of reading suggested by both of these titles, the jocular as well as the serious one, are fully treated in this rewriting, especially the problem of how to read a number of related books in relation to one another and read them in such a way that the complementary and conflicting things they have to say about a common subject are clearly grasped.

在重写《如何阅读一本书》的原因中，我已经强调了关于阅读艺术要说的事情，以及关于在这门艺术中获得更高水平技能的需要要提出的要点，这些在本书的原始版本中没有触及或展开。任何想知道添加了多少内容的人都可以通过将当前目录与原始版本的目录进行比较来快速做到这一点。四个部分中，只有第二部分阐述了分析阅读的规则，与原文的内容非常相似，甚至有很大的改写。第一部分的介绍区分了四个层次的阅读——初级阅读、检查阅读、分析阅读和主题阅读——是本书结构和内容的基本和控制性变化。第三部分阐述了接触不同类型阅读材料的不同方法——实践和理论书籍、想象文学（抒情诗、史诗、小说、戏剧）、历史、科学和数学、社会科学和哲学，以及参考书、时事新闻，甚至广告——是最广泛的补充。最后，第四部分对主题阅读的讨论是全新的。

Among the reasons for rewriting How to Read a Book, I have stressed the things to be said about the art of reading and the points to be made about the need for acquiring higher levels of skill in this art, which were not touched on or developed in the original version of the book. Anyone who wishes to discover how much has been added can do so quickly by comparing the present Table of Contents with that of the original version. Of the four parts, only Part Two, expounding the rules of Analytical Reading, closely parallels the content of the original, and even that has been largely recast. The introduction in Part One of the distinction of four levels of reading—elementary, inspectional, analytical, and syntopical —is the basic and controlling change in the book’s organization and content. The exposition in Part Three of the different ways to approach different kinds of reading materials—practical and theoretical books, imaginative literature (lyric poetry, epics, novels, plays), history, science and mathematics, social science, and philosophy, as well as reference books, current journalism, and even advertising—is the most extensive addition that has been made. Finally, the discussion of Syntopical Reading in Part Four is wholly new.

在更新、重铸和重写本书的工作中，查尔斯·范·多伦 (Charles Van Doren) 加入了我的行列，多年来，他一直是我在哲学研究所的助理。我们合作过其他书籍，特别是 1969 年由 Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc. 出版的 20 卷美国年鉴。也许与我们作为合著者参与的当前合作项目更相关的是什么？是在在过去的八年里，查尔斯·范多伦和我密切合作，在芝加哥、旧金山和阿斯彭组织了关于好书的讨论小组，并主持了高管研讨会。在这些经历的过程中，我们获得了许多新的见解，这些见解已用于重写本书。

In the work of updating, recasting, and rewriting this book, I have been joined by Charles Van Doren, who for many years now has been my associate at the Institute for Philosophical Research. We have worked together on other books, notably the twenty-volume Annals of America, published by Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc., in 1969. What is, perhaps, more relevant to the present cooperative venture in which we have been engaged as co-authors is that during the last eight years Charles Van Doren and I have worked closely together in conducting discussion groups on great books and in moderating executive seminars in Chicago, San Francisco, and Aspen. In the course of these experiences, we acquired many of the new insights that have gone into the rewriting of this book.

感谢范多伦先生为我们的共同努力所做的贡献；他和我一起希望对我们从我们的朋友 Arthur LH Rubin 那里得到的所有建设性批评、指导和帮助表示最深切的感谢，他说服我们介绍了许多重要的变化，这些变化使本书有别于它的前身，并且我们希望它成为一本更好、更有用的书。

I am grateful to Mr. Van Doren for the contribution he has made to our joint effort; and he and I together wish to express our deepest gratitude for all the constructive criticism, guidance, and help that we have received from our friend Arthur L. H. Rubin, who persuaded us to introduce many of the important changes that distinguish this book from its predecessor and make it, we hope, a better and more useful book.

M ORTIMER J. A DLER

MORTIMER J. ADLER

博卡格兰德

1972 年 3 月 26 日

Boca GrandeMarch 26, 1972

如何

阅读一本书

_

HOWTOREAD A BOOK

 

第一部分

PART ONE

 

阅读的维度

The Dimensions of Reading

 

1

阅读的活动和艺术

1THE ACTIVITY AND ART OF READING

 

这是一本面向读者和那些希望成为读者的人的书。特别是，它适用于书籍的读者。更具体地说，它是为那些读书的主要目的是为了增加理解力的人准备的。

This is a book for readers and for those who wish to become readers. Particularly, it is for readers of books. Even more particularly, it is for those whose main purpose in reading books is to gain increased understanding.

我们所说的“读者”是指那些仍然习惯于从书面文字中获取大量关于世界的信息和对世界的理解的人，就像过去几乎所有有文化和聪明的人一样。当然不是全部。即使在收音机和电视出现之前的日子里，一定数量的信息和理解也是通过口头语言和观察获得的。但对于聪明和好奇的人来说，这永远不够。他们知道他们也必须读书，而且他们确实读书了。

By “readers” we mean people who are still accustomed, as almost every literate and intelligent person used to be, to gain a large share of their information about and their understanding of the world from the written word. Not all of it, of course; even in the days before radio and television, a certain amount of information and understanding was acquired through spoken words and through observation. But for intelligent and curious people that was never enough. They knew that they had to read too, and they did read.

现在有些人觉得读书不像以前那么必要了。广播，尤其是电视已经取代了印刷品曾经发挥的许多功能，就像摄影取代了绘画和其他图形艺术曾经发挥的作用一样。诚然，电视可以很好地发挥其中的一些功能。例如，新闻事件的视觉传播具有巨大的影响力。在我们从事其他事情（例如，驾驶汽车）时，无线电为我们提供信息的能力非常了不起，并且可以节省大量时间。但可能会受到严重质疑现代通信媒体的出现是否大大增强了我们对我们生活的世界的理解。

There is some feeling nowadays that reading is not as necessary as it once was. Radio and especially television have taken over many of the functions once served by print, just as photography has taken over functions once served by painting and other graphic arts. Admittedly, television serves some of these functions extremely well; the visual communication of news events, for example, has enormous impact. The ability of radio to give us information while we are engaged in doing other things—for instance, driving a car—is remarkable, and a great saving of time. But it may be seriously questioned whether the advent of modern communications media has much enhanced our understanding of the world in which we live.

或许我们对世界的了解比以往更多，只要知识是理解的先决条件，那就再好不过了。但知识并不像通常认为的那样是理解的先决条件。我们不必为了理解某事而了解它的一切；太多的事实往往与太少的事实一样难以理解。从某种意义上说，我们现代人被事实淹没而损害了理解。

Perhaps we know more about the world than we used to, and insofar as knowledge is prerequisite to understanding, that is all to the good. But knowledge is not as much a prerequisite to understanding as is commonly supposed. We do not have to know everything about something in order to understand it; too many facts are often as much of an obstacle to understanding as too few. There is a sense in which we moderns are inundated with facts to the detriment of understanding.

造成这种情况的原因之一是我们所提到的媒体的设计使思考显得不必要（尽管这只是表象）。知识分子的立场和观点的包装是当今一些最优秀的头脑最活跃的企业之一。电视的观众、广播的听众、杂志的读者，都会看到一整套复杂的元素——从巧妙的修辞到精心挑选的数据和统计——让他们很容易“下定决心” ”以最小的难度和努力。但包装通常做得非常有效，以至于观众、听众或读者根本无法自己下定决心。相反，他将打包的意见插入他的脑海，有点像将磁带插入磁带播放器。然后他按下一个按钮，并在合适的时候“回放”意见。他的表现令人满意，无需思考。

One of the reasons for this situation is that the very media we have mentioned are so designed as to make thinking seem unnecessary (though this is only an appearance). The packaging of intellectual positions and views is one of the most active enterprises of some of the best minds of our day. The viewer of television, the listener to radio, the reader of magazines, is presented with a whole complex of elements—all the way from ingenious rhetoric to carefully selected data and statistics—to make it easy for him to “make up his own mind” with the minimum of difficulty and effort. But the packaging is often done so effectively that the viewer, listener, or reader does not make up his own mind at all. Instead, he inserts a packaged opinion into his mind, somewhat like inserting a cassette into a cassette player. He then pushes a button and “plays back” the opinion whenever it seems appropriate to do so. He has performed acceptably without having had to think.

主动阅读

Active Reading

 

正如我们在开头所说的，我们将在这些页面中主要关注阅读技能的发展；但是，如果遵循和实践阅读规则，可以培养这种技能，也可以应用于印刷材料一般而言，适用于任何类型的阅读材料——报纸、杂志、小册子、文章、小册子，甚至广告。

As we said at the beginning, we will be principally concerned in these pages with the development of skill in reading books; but the rules of reading that, if followed and practiced, develop such skill can be applied also to printed material in general, to any type of reading matter—to newspapers, magazines, pamphlets, articles, tracts, even advertisements.

由于任何形式的阅读都是一项活动，因此所有阅读都必须在某种程度上是积极的。完全被动阅读是不可能的；我们不能在眼睛不动、头脑昏昏欲睡的情况下阅读。因此，当我们比较主动阅读和被动阅读时，我们的目的首先是要提醒人们注意阅读可以或多或少是主动的，其次是要指出阅读越主动越好。一位读者比另一位读者更好，因为他能够在阅读中进行更大范围的活动并付出更多的努力。如果他对自己和他面前的文本要求更多，他会更好。

Since reading of any sort is an activity, all reading must to some degree be active. Completely passive reading is impossible; we cannot read with our eyes immobilized and our minds asleep. Hence when we contrast active with passive reading, our purpose is, first, to call attention to the fact that reading can be more or less active, and second, to point out that the more active the reading the better. One reader is better than another in proportion as he is capable of a greater range of activity in reading and exerts more effort. He is better if he demands more of himself and of the text before him.

虽然严格来说，阅读和阅读不可能是绝对被动的，但很多人认为，与写作和口语这样明显主动的活动相比，阅读和听力完全是被动的。作者或演讲者必须付出一些努力，但读者或听众无需做任何工作。阅读和聆听被认为是从积极参与给予或发送信息的人那里接收信息。这里的错误是假设接收通信就像接收来自法院的打击或遗产或判决。相反，读者或听众更像是棒球比赛中的接球手。

Though, strictly speaking, there can be no absolutely passive reading, many people think that, as compared with writing and speaking, which are obviously active undertakings, reading and listening are entirely passive. The writer or speaker must put out some effort, but no work need be done by the reader or listener. Reading and listening are thought of as receiving communication from someone who is actively engaged in giving or sending it. The mistake here is to suppose that receiving communication is like receiving a blow or a legacy or a judgment from the court. On the contrary, the reader or listener is much more like the catcher in a game of baseball.

接球与投球或击球一样是一项活动。投手或击球手是发球者，因为他的活动引发了球的运动。接球手或守场员在他的活动终止它的意义上是接球手。两者都是活跃的，尽管活动不同。如果有什么是被动的，那就是球。运动或停止的是惰性的东西，而球员是活跃的，移动到投球、击球或接球。与写作和阅读的类比几乎是完美的。写入和读取的东西，如球，是开始和终止过程的两个活动共有的被动对象。

Catching the ball is just as much an activity as pitching or hitting it. The pitcher or batter is the sender in the sense that his activity initiates the motion of the ball. The catcher or fielder is the receiver in the sense that his activity terminates it. Both are active, though the activities are different. If anything is passive, it is the ball. It is the inert thing that is put in motion or stopped, whereas the players are active, moving to pitch, hit, or catch. The analogy with writing and reading is almost perfect. The thing that is written and read, like the ball, is the passive object common to the two activities that begin and terminate the process.

我们可以将这个类比更进一步。捕捉的艺术是接住各种投球的技巧——快球和弧线球、变速球和指节球。同样，阅读的艺术是尽可能捕捉各种交流的技巧。

We can take this analogy a step further. The art of catching is the skill of catching every kind of pitch—fast balls and curves, changeups and knucklers. Similarly, the art of reading is the skill of catching every sort of communication as well as possible.

值得注意的是，投手和接球手只有在合作的情况下才能取得成功。作者与读者的关系也是如此。作者并不是不想被抓住，尽管有时看起来是这样。成功的交流发生在任何情况下，即作者想要收到的东西找到了读者所拥有的方式。作者的技巧和读者的技巧汇聚在一个共同的目标上。

It is noteworthy that the pitcher and catcher are successful only to the extent that they cooperate. The relation of writer and reader is similar. The writer isn’t trying not to be caught, although it sometimes seems so. Successful communication occurs in any case where what the writer wanted to have received finds its way into the reader’s possession. The writer’s skill and the reader’s skill converge upon a common end.

诚然，作家各不相同，就像投手一样。一些作家具有出色的“控制力”；他们确切地知道他们想要传达什么，并且准确无误地传达。在其他条件相同的情况下，他们比没有“控制”的“狂野”作家更容易“抓住”。

Admittedly, writers vary, just as pitchers do. Some writers have excellent “control”; they know exactly what they want to convey, and they convey it precisely and accurately. Other things being equal, they are easier to “catch” than a “wild” writer without “control.”

这个类比在一个方面是站不住脚的。球是一个简单的单位。它要么被完全捕获，要么没有被捕获。然而，一篇文章是一个复杂的对象。它可以或多或少地被完整地接受，从作者意图的极少部分到全部。读者“捕捉到”的数量通常取决于他在这个过程中投入的活动量，以及他执行所涉及的不同心理活动的技巧。

There is one respect in which the analogy breaks down. The ball is a simple unit. It is either completely caught or not. A piece of writing, however, is a complex object. It can be received more or less completely, all the way from very little of what the writer intended to the whole of it. The amount the reader “catches” will usually depend on the amount of activity he puts into the process, as well as upon the skill with which he executes the different mental acts involved.

积极阅读意味着什么？我们将在本书中多次回到这个问题。目前，可以这么说，如果要阅读同样的东西，一个人比另一个人读得更好，首先是更积极地阅读它，其次是更熟练地执行所涉及的每一个动作。这两件事是相关的。阅读是一项复杂的活动，就像写作一样。它由大量独立的行为组成，所有这些行为都必须在良好的阅读中进行。能够执行更多操作的人能够更好地阅读。

What does active reading entail? We will return to this question many times in this book. For the moment, it suffices to say that, given the same thing to read, one person reads it better than another, first, by reading it more actively, and second, by performing each of the acts involved more skillfully. These two things are related. Reading is a complex activity, just as writing is. It consists of a large number of separate acts, all of which must be performed in a good reading. The person who can perform more of them is better able to read.

阅读的目标：阅读获取信息和阅读理解

The Goals of Reading: Reading for Information and Reading for Understanding

 

你有想法。现在让我们假设您也有一本书想读。这本书由某人为了与您交流某些内容而编写的语言组成。你能否成功阅读它取决于你对作者想要传达的一切的接受程度。

You have a mind. Now let us suppose that you also have a book that you want to read. The book consists of language written by someone for the sake of communicating something to you. Your success in reading it is determined by the extent to which you receive everything the writer intended to communicate.

当然，这太简单了。原因是你的思想和书之间可能存在两种关系，而不只是一种。这两种关系可以通过阅读本书时获得的两种不同体验来体现。

That, of course, is too simple. The reason is that there are two possible relations between your mind and the book, not just one. These two relations are exemplified by two different experiences that you can have in reading your book.

有书；这是你的想法。当你翻阅这些页面时，你要么完全理解作者要说的一切，要么不理解。如果你这样做，你可能获得了信息，但你不可能增加你的理解。如果这本书从头到尾对你来说是完全可以理解的，那么作者和你就是同一个模具中的两个思想。页面上的符号仅表示您在相遇之前的共同理解。

There is the book; and here is your mind. As you go through the pages, either you understand perfectly everything the author has to say or you do not. If you do, you may have gained information, but you could not have increased your understanding. If the book is completely intelligible to you from start to finish, then the author and you are as two minds in the same mold. The symbols on the page merely express the common understanding you had before you met.

让我们采取第二种选择。你没有完全理解这本书。让我们甚至假设——不幸的是，这并不总是正确的——你了解得足够多，以至于知道你并不了解这一切。您知道这本书要说的比您理解的要多，因此它包含可以增加您的理解力的内容。

Let us take our second alternative. You do not understand the book perfectly. Let us even assume—what unhappily is not always true—that you understand enough to know that you do not understand it all. You know the book has more to say than you understand and hence that it contains something that can increase your understanding.

那你怎么办呢？你可以把这本书拿给你认为比你读得更好的人，让他解释让你感到困扰的部分。（“他”可能是一个活生生的人或另一本书——一本评论或教科书。）或者你可能认为你头上的事情不值得操心大概，那你懂的够多了。无论哪种情况，您都没有完成本书要求的阅读工作。

What do you do then? You can take the book to someone else who, you think, can read better than you, and have him explain the parts that trouble you. (“He” may be a living person or another book—a commentary or textbook.) Or you may decide that what is over your head is not worth bothering about, that you understand enough. In either case, you are not doing the job of reading that the book requires.

这只能通过一种方式完成。在没有任何形式的外部帮助的情况下，您可以继续写这本书。除了你自己的头脑的力量，你对你面前的符号进行操作，从而逐渐将自己从一种了解较少的状态提升到一种了解较多的状态。这种提升，通过在一本书上工作来实现，是高度熟练的阅读，一种挑战你的理解的书值得的阅读。

That is done in only one way. Without external help of any sort, you go to work on the book. With nothing but the power of your own mind, you operate on the symbols before you in such a way that you gradually lift yourself from a state of understanding less to one of understanding more. Such elevation, accomplished by the mind working on a book, is highly skilled reading, the kind of reading that a book which challenges your understanding deserves.

因此，我们可以粗略地定义我们所说的阅读艺术的含义如下：在没有任何外界帮助的情况下，除了可读材料的符号之外，头脑没有任何可操作的过程，*通过自身运营的力量提升自身。头脑从了解较少到了解较多。导致这种情况发生的熟练操作是构成阅读艺术的各种行为。

Thus we can roughly define what we mean by the art of reading as follows: the process whereby a mind, with nothing to operate on but the symbols of the readable matter, and with no help from outside,* elevates itself by the power of its own operations. The mind passes from understanding less to understanding more. The skilled operations that cause this to happen are the various acts that constitute the art of reading.

通过自己在阅读中的智力努力，从了解较少到了解更多，就像靠自己的力量来提升自己一样。确实有这种感觉。这是一项重大的努力。显然，这是一种比以前更积极的阅读方式，不仅需要更多样的活动，而且需要更多的技巧来完成所需的各种动作。同样明显的是，通常被认为更难阅读的东西，因此只适合更好的读者，是那些更可能值得和需要这种阅读的东西。

To pass from understanding less to understanding more by your own intellectual effort in reading is something like pulling yourself up by your bootstraps. It certainly feels that way. It is a major exertion. Obviously, it is a more active kind of reading than you have done before, entailing not only more varied activity but also much more skill in the performance of the various acts required. Obviously, too, the things that are usually regarded as more difficult to read, and hence as only for the better reader, are those that are more likely to deserve and demand this kind of reading.

为了信息而阅读和为了理解而阅读之间的区别比这更深。让我们试着多谈谈它。我们将不得不考虑阅读的两个目标，因为以一种方式可读的内容与以另一种方式必须阅读的内容之间的界限往往是模糊的。的程度为了使阅读的这两个目标有所区别，我们可以在两种不同的意义上使用“阅读”一词。

The distinction between reading for information and reading for understanding is deeper than this. Let us try to say more about it. We will have to consider both goals of reading because the line between what is readable in one way and what must be read in the other is often hazy. To the extent that we can keep these two goals of reading distinct, we can employ the word “reading” in two distinct senses.

第一种意义是我们说自己正在阅读报纸、杂志或任何其他根据我们的技能和才能可以立即完全理解的东西。这些东西可能会增加我们的信息存储量，但它们不能提高我们的理解力，因为在我们开始之前我们的理解力与它们相同。否则，如果我们既警觉又诚实，就会感到困惑和困惑所带来的震惊。

The first sense is the one in which we speak of ourselves as reading newspapers, magazines, or anything else that, according to our skill and talents, is at once thoroughly intelligible to us. Such things may increase our store of information, but they cannot improve our understanding, for our understanding was equal to them before we started. Otherwise, we would have felt the shock of puzzlement and perplexity that comes from getting in over our depth—that is, if we were both alert and honest.

第二种意义是一个人试图阅读起初他并不完全理解的东西。这里要阅读的东西最初比读者更好或更高。作者正在传达一些可以增加读者理解的东西。不平等之间的这种交流必须是可能的，否则一个人永远无法通过口头或书面向另一个人学习。这里的“学习”是指理解更多，而不是记住更多与您已经拥有的其他信息具有相同程度的可理解性的信息。

The second sense is the one in which a person tries to read something that at first he does not completely understand. Here the thing to be read is initially better or higher than the reader. The writer is communicating something that can increase the reader’s understanding. Such communication between unequals must be possible, or else one person could never learn from another, either through speech or writing. Here by “learning” is meant understanding more, not remembering more information that has the same degree of intelligibility as other information you already possess.

如果新事实与你已经知道的是同一类，那么在阅读过程中获取新信息显然没有智力上的困难。一个了解美国历史的某些事实并从某种角度理解它们的人可以很容易地从第一种意义上通过阅读获得更多这样的事实并从同样的角度理解它们。但是假设他正在阅读一部历史，它不仅试图给他一些更多的事实，而且还试图对所有的一切提出一个新的、也许更具启发性的启示。他知道的事实。假设这里的理解能力比他开始阅读之前更高。如果他能设法获得更好的理解，他就是在第二种意义上阅读。他确实通过他的活动提升了自己，虽然是间接的，当然，这种提升是由于作家教他一些东西而成为可能的。

There is clearly no difficulty of an intellectual sort about gaining new information in the course of reading if the new facts are of the same sort as those you already know. A person who knows some of the facts of American history and understands them in a certain light can readily acquire by reading, in the first sense, more such facts and understand them in the same light. But suppose he is reading a history that seeks not merely to give him some more facts but also to throw a new and perhaps more revealing light on all the facts he knows. Suppose there is greater understanding available here than he possessed before he started to read. If he can manage to acquire that greater understanding, he is reading in the second sense. He has indeed elevated himself by his activity, though indirectly, of course, the elevation was made possible by the writer who had something to teach him.

这种阅读——为理解而阅读——发生的条件是什么？那里有两个。首先，在认识上存在初步的不平等。作者必须在理解上“优于”读者，他的书必须以可读的形式传达他拥有而潜在读者缺乏的见解。其次，读者必须能够在某种程度上克服这种不平等，也许很少完全克服，但总是接近与作者的平等。在接近平等的范围内，沟通的清晰度得以实现。

What are the conditions under which this kind of reading —reading for understanding—takes place? There are two. First, there is initial inequality in understanding. The writer must be “superior” to the reader in understanding, and his book must convey in readable form the insights he possesses and his potential readers lack. Second, the reader must be able to overcome this inequality in some degree, seldom perhaps fully, but always approaching equality with the writer. To the extent that equality is approached, clarity of communication is achieved.

简而言之，我们只能向我们的“更好的人”学习。我们必须知道他们是谁以及如何向他们学习。拥有这种知识的人就拥有我们在本书中特别关注的那种意义上的阅读艺术。每个能阅读的人都可能有一定的阅读能力。但是我们所有人，无一例外，都可以通过努力将其应用到更有价值的材料中，从而学会更好地阅读并逐渐收获更多。

In short, we can learn only from our “betters.” We must know who they are and how to learn from them. The person who has this sort of knowledge possesses the art of reading in the sense with which we are especially concerned in this book. Everyone who can read at all probably has some ability to read in this way. But all of us, without exception, can learn to read better and gradually gain more by our efforts through applying them to more rewarding materials.

我们不想给人这样的印象，即导致信息增加的事实和导致理解增加的见解总是很容易区分的。我们承认，有时仅是对事实的叙述本身就可以带来更好的理解。我们在这里要强调的一点是，本书讲的是阅读的艺术，目的是为了增加理解。幸运的是，如果你学会这样做，阅读信息通常会自行解决。

We do not want to give the impression that facts, leading to increased information, and insights, leading to increased understanding, are always easy to distinguish. And we would admit that sometimes a mere recital of facts can itself lead to greater understanding. The point we want to emphasize here is that this book is about the art of reading for the sake of increased understanding. Fortunately, if you learn to do that, reading for information will usually take care of itself.

当然，除了获取信息和理解之外，阅读还有一个目的，那就是娱乐。不过，这本书不会太关注娱乐性的阅读。它是要求最低的一种阅读，需要最少的努力。此外，没有规则。凡是会读书的人，只要愿意，都可以读书消遣。

Of course, there is still another goal of reading, besides gaining information and understanding, and that is entertainment. However, this book will not be much concerned with reading for entertainment. It is the least demanding kind of reading, and it requires the least amount of effort. Furthermore, there are no rules for it. Everyone who knows how to read at all can read for entertainment if he wants to.

事实上，任何可以为了理解或信息而阅读的书也可能是为了娱乐而阅读的，就像一本能够增加我们理解力的书也可以纯粹为了它所包含的信息而阅读一样。（这个命题不能被推翻：并不是每本书都可以为了娱乐而阅读也可以为了理解而阅读。）我们也不想敦促你永远不要为了娱乐而读一本好书。关键是，如果你想读一本好书来理解，我们相信我们可以帮助你。因此，我们的主题是阅读好书的艺术，而理解是您的目标。

In fact, any book that can be read for understanding or information can probably be read for entertainment as well, just as a book that is capable of increasing our understanding can also be read purely for the information it contains. (This proposition cannot be reversed: it is not true that every book that can be read for entertainment can also be read for understanding.) Nor do we wish to urge you never to read a good book for entertainment. The point is, if you wish to read a good book for understanding, we believe we can help you. Our subject, then, is the art of reading good books when understanding is the aim you have in view.

阅读即学习：通过指导学习和通过发现学习的区别

Reading as Learning: The Difference Between Learning by Instruction and Learning by Discovery

 

获取更多信息就是学习，了解您以前不了解的内容也是如此。但是这两种学习之间有一个重要的区别。

Getting more information is learning, and so is coming to understand what you did not understand before. But there is an important difference between these two kinds of learning.

被告知就是简单地知道事情是这样的。此外，要开悟就是要了解它的全部内容：为什么会这样，它与其他事实有什么联系，在哪些方面相同，在哪些方面不同等等。

To be informed is to know simply that something is the case. To be enlightened is to know, in addition, what it is all about: why it is the case, what its connections are with other facts, in what respects it is the same, in what respects it is different, and so forth.

就能够记住某事和能够解释它之间的差异而言，这种区别很常见。如果你记得某个作者说过的话，你就从阅读他的作品中学到了一些东西。如果他说的是真的，你甚至对这个世界有所了解。但是，无论是关于书本的事实还是关于世界的事实，如果你只锻炼了记忆力，那么你除了信息之外一无所获。你还没有开悟。只有当你除了知道作者所说的内容之外，还知道他的意思和他为什么这么说时，才能实现启蒙。

This distinction is familiar in terms of the differences between being able to remember something and being able to explain it. if you remember what an author says, you have learned something from reading him. If what he says is true, you have even learned something about the world. But whether it is a fact about the book or a fact about the world that you have learned, you have gained nothing but information if you have exercised only your memory. You have not been enlightened. Enlightenment is achieved only when, in addition to knowing what an author says, you know what he means and why he says it.

当然，您应该能够记住作者所说的内容并了解他的意思。被告知是开悟的先决条件。然而，关键不在于被告知。

It is true, of course, that you should be able to remember what the author said as well as know what he meant. Being informed is prerequisite to being enlightened. The point, however, is not to stop at being informed.

蒙田谈到“先于学习的初学者的无知知识，以及随之而来的博士般的无知。” 首先是那些不知道 ABC 的人的无知，根本无法阅读。二是误读多书之人的无知。正如亚历山大蒲柏正确地称呼他们一样，他们是书本笨蛋，无知地阅读。总是有识字的无知者，他们阅读的范围太广，但阅读的并不好。希腊人给这种学问和愚蠢的混合体取了一个名字，这个名字可以用在所有年龄段的书呆子但不识字的人身上。他们都是大二学生。

Montaigne speaks of “an abecedarian ignorance that precedes knowledge, and a doctoral ignorance that comes after it.” The first is the ignorance of those who, not knowing their ABC’s, cannot read at all. The second is the ignorance of those who have misread many books. They are, as Alexander Pope rightly calls them, bookful blockheads, ignorantly read. There have always been literate ignoramuses who have read too widely and not well. The Greeks had a name for such a mixture of learning and folly which might be applied to the bookish but poorly read of all ages. They are all sophomores.

为了避免这种错误——假设被广泛阅读和被广泛阅读是一回事的错误——我们必须考虑学习类型的某种区别。这种区别对整个阅读业务及其与教育的关系具有重要意义。

To avoid this error—the error of assuming that to be widely read and to be well-read are the same thing—we must consider a certain distinction in types of learning. This distinction has a significant bearing on the whole business of reading and its relation to education generally.

在教育史上，人们经常区分通过指导学习和通过发现学习。当一个人通过演讲或写作来教导另一个人时，就会发生教导。然而，我们可以在不被教导的情况下获得知识。如果情况不是这样，并且每个老师都必须被教导他反过来教给别人的东西，那么知识的获取就没有开始。因此，必须有发现——通过研究、调查或反思而不是被教导来学习某些东西的过程。

In the history of education, men have often distinguished between learning by instruction and learning by discovery. Instruction occurs when one person teaches another through speech or writing. We can, however, gain knowledge without being taught. If this were not the case, and every teacher had to be taught what he in turn teaches others, there would be no beginning in the acquisition of knowledge. Hence, there must be discovery—the process of learning something by research, by investigation, or by reflection, without being taught.

发现之于指导，就像没有老师的学习之于有师傅的帮助一样。在这两种情况下，学习活动都在学习者身上进行。如果认为发现是主动学习而指导是被动的，那就错了。没有消极的学习，就像没有消极的阅读一样。

Discovery stands to instruction as learning without a teacher stands to learning through the help of one. In both cases, the activity of learning goes on in the one who learns. It would be a mistake to suppose that discovery is active learning and instruction passive. There is no inactive learning, just as there is no inactive reading.

事实上，这是如此真实，以至于明确区分的更好方法是将指令称为“辅助发现”。无需深入研究心理学家所设想的学习理论，教学显然是一门非常特殊的艺术，仅与其他两种艺术——农业和医学——共享一个极其重要的特征。一个医生可能会为他的病人做很多事情，但归根到底是病人自己必须康复——健康成长。农夫为他的植物或动物做了很多事情，但归根结底，它们必须长得更大、更优秀。同样，虽然老师可以在很多方面帮助他的学生，但必须由学生自己来学习。如果要学习，知识必须在他的头脑中增长。

This is so true, in fact, that a better way to make the distinction clear is to call instruction “aided discovery.” Without going into learning theory as psychologists conceive it, it is obvious that teaching is a very special art, sharing with only two other arts—agriculture and medicine—an exceptionally important characteristic. A doctor may do many things for his patient, but in the final analysis it is the patient himself who must get well—grow in health. The farmer does many things for his plants or animals, but in the final analysis it is they that must grow in size and excellence. Similarly, although the teacher may help his student in many ways, it is the student himself who must do the learning. Knowledge must grow in his mind if learning is to take place.

通过指导学习和通过发现学习之间的区别——或者，正如我们更愿意说的，辅助发现和非辅助发现之间的区别——主要是学习者所使用的材料的不同。当他接受指导时——在老师的帮助下发现——学习者根据传达给他的东西采取行动。他对话语、书面或口头进行操作。他通过阅读或聆听来学习。请注意阅读和听力之间的密切关系。如果我们忽略这两种接受交流方式之间的细微差别，我们可以说阅读和听力是同一门艺术——被教导的艺术。然而，当学习者在没有任何老师帮助的情况下继续学习时，学习的操作是针对自然或世界而不是话语进行的。这种学习的规则构成了独立发现的艺术。如果我们宽泛地使用“阅读”这个词，我们可以说发现——严格来说，独立的发现——是阅读自然或世界的艺术，就像指导（被教导或辅助发现）是阅读书籍的艺术一样，包括听，从话语中学习。

The difference between learning by instruction and learning by discovery—or, as we would prefer to say, between aided and unaided discovery—is primarily a difference in the materials on which the learner works. When he is being instructed —discovering with the help of a teacher—the learner acts on something communicated to him. He performs operations on discourse, written or oral. He learns by acts of reading or listening. Note here the close relation between reading and listening. If we ignore the minor differences between these two ways of receiving communication, we can say that reading and listening are the same art—the art of being taught. When, however, the learner proceeds without the help of any sort of teacher, the operations of learning are performed on nature or the world rather than on discourse. The rules of such learning constitute the art of unaided discovery. If we use the word “reading” loosely, we can say that discovery—strictly, unaided discovery—is the art of reading nature or the world, as instruction (being taught, or aided discovery) is the art of reading books or, to include listening, of learning from discourse.

思考呢？如果我们所说的“思考”是指用我们的头脑来获得知识或理解，如果通过发现学习和通过指导学习穷尽了获得知识的方式，那么在这两种活动中都必须进行思考。我们必须在阅读和听力的过程中思考，就像我们必须在研究的过程中思考一样。自然地，思维的种类是不同的——正如两种学习方式的不同一样。

What about thinking? If by “thinking” we mean the use of our minds to gain knowledge or understanding, and if learning by discovery and learning by instruction exhaust the ways of gaining knowledge, then thinking must take place during both of these two activities. We must think in the course of reading and listening, just as we must think in the course of research. Naturally, the kinds of thinking are different—as different as the two ways of learning are.

许多人认为思考与研究和独立发现的关系比与学习的关系更密切，原因是他们认为阅读和听力相对轻松。一个人在阅读信息或娱乐时比在着手发现某事时思考得更少，这可能是真的。这些是不太活跃的阅读方式。但对于更积极的阅读——努力去理解，情况并非如此。没有做过这种阅读的人会说它可以不假思索地完成。

The reason why many people regard thinking as more closely associated with research and unaided discovery than with being taught is that they suppose reading and listening to be relatively effortless. It is probably true that one does less thinking when one reads for information or entertainment than when one is undertaking to discover something. Those are the less active sorts of reading. But it is not true of the more active reading—the effort to understand. No one who has done this sort of reading would say it can be done thoughtlessly.

思考只是学习活动的一部分。还必须运用自己的感官和想象力。一个人必须观察、记住和想象地构建无法观察到的东西。还有一种倾向是强调这些活动在独立发现过程中的作用，而忘记或最小化它们在通过阅读或听力进行教学的过程中的地位。例如，许多人认为虽然诗人在写诗时必须运用他的想象力，但他们在阅读这首诗时却不必运用他们的想象力。简而言之，阅读的艺术包括所有与独立发现的艺术相同的技能：敏锐的观察力、随时可用的记忆力、丰富的想象力，当然还有经过分析和反思训练的智力。这样做的原因是，从这个意义上说，阅读就是发现，

Thinking is only one part of the activity of learning. One must also use one’s senses and imagination. One must observe, and remember, and construct imaginatively what cannot be observed. There is, again, a tendency to stress the role of these activities in the process of unaided discovery and to forget or minimize their place in the process of being taught through reading or listening. For example, many people assume that though a poet must use his imagination in writing a poem, they do not have to use their imagination in reading it. The art of reading, in short, includes all of the same skills that are involved in the art of unaided discovery: keenness of observation, readily available memory, range of imagination, and, of course, an intellect trained in analysis and reflection. The reason for this is that reading in this sense is discovery, too—although with help instead of without it.

现任和缺席教师

Present and Absent Teachers

 

我们一直在进行，好像阅读和听力都可以被视为向老师学习。在某种程度上这是真的。两者都是受教的方式，而对于这两种方式，一个人必须精通受教的艺术。例如，听讲座在很多方面就像读书一样；听一首诗就像读一首诗。本书制定的许多规则都适用于此类体验。然而，我们有充分的理由将重点放在阅读上，而让听力成为次要的关注点。原因在于，聆听是向在场的老师——一位在世的老师——学习，而阅读是向不在场的老师学习。

We have been proceeding as if reading and listening could both be treated as learning from teachers. To some extent that is true. Both are ways of being instructed, and for both one must be skilled in the art of being taught. Listening to a course of lectures, for example, is in many respects like reading a book; and listening to a poem is like reading it. Many of the rules to be formulated in this book apply to such experiences. Yet there is good reason to place primary emphasis on reading, and let listening become a secondary concern. The reason is that listening is learning from a teacher who is present—a living teacher—while reading is learning from one who is absent.

如果你问一位在世的老师一个问题，他可能会回答你。如果你对他说的话感到困惑，你可以通过问他他的意思来省去思考的麻烦。然而，如果你向一本书提出问题，你必须自己回答。在这方面，一本书就像自然或世界。当你质疑它时，它只会在你自己进行思考和分析的范围内回答你。

If you ask a living teacher a question, he will probably answer you. If you are puzzled by what he says, you can save yourself the trouble of thinking by asking him what he means. If, however, you ask a book a question, you must answer it yourself. In this respect a book is like nature or the world. When you question it, it answers you only to the extent that you do the work of thinking and analysis yourself.

当然，这并不意味着如果在世的老师回答了你的问题，你就没有进一步的工作了。仅当问题只是事实之一时才会如此。但如果你正在寻求解释，你就必须理解它，否则什么都没有向你解释。然而，有了活生生的老师，你会在理解他的方向上得到提升，因为当你只需要老师在书中的话时，你就不是这样了。

This does not mean, of course, that if the living teacher answers your question, you have no further work. That is so only if the question is simply one of fact. But if you are seeking an explanation, you have to understand it or nothing has been explained to you. Nevertheless, with the living teacher available to you, you are given a lift in the direction of understanding him, as you are not when the teacher’s words in a book are all you have to go by.

在校学生经常在老师的帮助和指导下阅读较难的书籍。但是对于我们这些不在学校的人来说，实际上对于我们这些试图阅读不需要或分配的书籍的人来说，我们的继续教育主要取决于书本，没有老师的帮助就可以阅读。因此，如果我们打算继续学习和发现，我们就必须知道如何让书本教好我们。这确实是本书的主要目标。

Students in school often read difficult books with the help and guidance of teachers. But for those of us who are not in school, and indeed also for those of us who are when we try to read books that are not required or assigned, our continuing education depends mainly on books alone, read without a teacher’s help. Therefore if we are disposed to go on learning and discovering, we must know how to make books teach us well. That, indeed, is the primary goal of this book.

2

阅读水平

2THE LEVELS OF READING

 

在前一章中，我们做了一些区分，这些区分对接下来的内容很重要。读者寻求的目标——无论是娱乐、信息还是理解——决定了他的阅读方式。他阅读的有效性取决于他在阅读中投入的努力和技巧。总的来说，规则是：越努力越好，至少对于那些最初超出我们作为读者的能力范围，因此能够将我们从理解较少的状态提升到理解较多的状态的书籍来说是这样。最后，指导和发现（或辅助发现和非辅助发现）之间的区别很重要，因为我们大多数人在大多数时候都必须在没有任何人帮助的情况下阅读。阅读，就像独立发现一样，是向不在场的老师学习。只有知道怎么做，我们才能成功地做到这一点。

In the preceding chapter, we made some distinctions that will be important in what follows. The goal a reader seeks—be it entertainment, information or understanding—determines the way he reads. The effectiveness with which he reads is determined by the amount of effort and skill he puts into his reading. In general, the rule is: the more effort the better, at least in the case of books that are initially beyond our powers as readers and are therefore capable of raising us from a condition of understanding less to one of understanding more. Finally, the distinction between instruction and discovery (or between aided and unaided discovery) is important because most of us, most of the time, have to read without anyone to help us. Reading, like unaided discovery, is learning from an absent teacher. We can only do that successfully if we know how.

尽管这些区别很重要，但与我们将在本章中提出的要点相比，它们就显得微不足道了。这些都与阅读水平有关。在阅读技能发生任何有效提高之前，必须了解级别之间的差异。

But important as these distinctions are, they are relatively insignificant compared to the points we are going to make in this chapter. These all have to do with the levels of reading. The differences between the levels must be understood before any effective improvement in reading skills can occur.

阅读有四个层次。它们在这里被称为层次而不是种类，因为种类严格来说是彼此不同的，而层次的特征是较高的包含较低的。阅读水平也是如此，它是累积的。第一关不输第二个，第二个在第三个，第三个在第四个。事实上，第四个也是最高层次的阅读包括了所有其他的阅读。它只是超越了他们。

There are four levels of reading. They are here called levels rather than kinds because kinds, strictly speaking, are distinct from one another, whereas it is characteristic of levels that higher ones include lower ones. So it is with the levels of reading, which are cumulative. The first level is not lost in the second, the second in the third, the third in the fourth. In fact, the fourth and highest level of reading includes all the others. It simply goes beyond them.

第一级阅读我们称之为初级阅读。其他名称可能是初级阅读、基本阅读或初步阅读；这些术语中的任何一个都可以表明，当一个人掌握了这一水平时，他就从不识字过渡到至少是初级识字。掌握这一层次，就是学习阅读艺术的基础，接受阅读的基本训练，初步掌握阅读技巧。然而，我们更喜欢初级阅读这个名字，因为这种阅读水平通常是在小学学习的。

The first level of reading we will call Elementary Reading. Other names might be rudimentary reading, basic reading or initial reading; any one of these terms serves to suggest that as one masters this level one passes from nonliteracy to at least beginning literacy. In mastering this level, one learns the rudiments of the art of reading, receives basic training in reading, and acquires initial reading skills. We prefer the name elementary reading, however, because this level of reading is ordinarily learned in elementary school.

孩子第一次接触阅读就是在这个层次上。他的问题（以及我们开始阅读时的问题）是识别页面上的单个单词。孩子看到白底黑字的集合（如果他在黑板上读书，可能会看到黑底白字）；标记上写的是，“猫坐在帽子上。” 一年级学生此时并不真正关心猫是否真的坐在帽子上，或者这对猫、帽子和世界意味着什么。他只关心作者所使用的语言。

The child’s first encounter with reading is at this level. His problem then (and ours when we began to read) is to recognize the individual words on the page. The child sees a collection of black marks on a white ground (or perhaps white marks on a black ground, if he is reading from a blackboard); what the marks say is, “The cat sat on the hat.” The first grader is not really concerned at this point with whether cats do sit on hats, or with what this implies about cats, hats, and the world. He is merely concerned with language as it is employed by the writer.

在这个阅读层次上，向读者提出的问题是“这句话说了什么？” 当然，这可以被认为是一个复杂而困难的问题。然而，我们在这里的意思是最简单的意思。

At this level of reading, the question asked of the reader is “What does the sentence say?” That could be conceived as a complex and difficult question, of course. We mean it here, however, in its simplest sense.

几乎所有读过这本书的人都获得了初级阅读技能。然而，无论我们作为读者的能力如何，我们都会继续遇到这种阅读水平的问题。例如，每当我们想读一些用我们不太了解的外语写成的东西时，就会发生这种情况。那么我们首先要做的就是识别实际的单词。只有在分别认识它们之后，我们才能开始尝试理解它们，努力理解它们的含义。

The attainment of the skills of elementary reading occurred some time ago for almost all who read this book. Nevertheless, we continue to experience the problems of this level of reading, no matter how capable we may be as readers. This happens, for example, whenever we come upon something we want to read that is written in a foreign language that we do not know very well. Then our first effort must be to identify the actual words. Only after recognizing them individually can we begin to try to understand them, to struggle with perceiving what they mean.

即使在阅读用自己的语言编写的材料时，许多读者在这个阅读水平上仍然会遇到各种困难。这些困难大部分是机械性的，其中一些可以追溯到早期的阅读教学。克服这些困难通常能让我们阅读得更快；因此，大多数速读课程都集中在这个级别。我们将在下一章更多地讨论基础阅读；在第 4 章，我们将讨论速读。

Even when they are reading material written in their own language, many readers continue to have various kinds of difficulties at this level of reading. Most of these difficulties are mechanical, and some of them can be traced back to early instruction in reading. Overcoming these difficulties usually allows us to read faster; hence, most speed reading courses concentrate on this level. We will have more to say about elementary reading in the next chapter; and in Chapter 4, we will discuss speed reading.

第二层次的阅读我们称之为检视阅读。它的特点是特别强调时间。在此级别阅读时，允许学生在设定的时间内完成指定的阅读量。例如，他可能有十五分钟的时间阅读这本书——甚至是两倍长的书。

The second level of reading we will call Inspectional Reading. It is characterized by its special emphasis on time. When reading at this level, the student is allowed a set time to complete an assigned amount of reading. He might be allowed fifteen minutes to read this book, for instance—or even a book twice as long.

因此，描述这种阅读水平的另一种方式是说它的目标是在给定时间内充分利用一本书——通常是相对较短的时间，而且总是（根据定义）太短而无法阅读书中一切皆可得。

Hence, another way to describe this level of reading is to say that its aim is to get the most out of a book within a given time—usually a relatively short time, and always (by definition) too short a time to get out of the book everything that can be gotten.

此级别的另一个名称可能是略读或预读。但是，我们并不是指那种以随意或随机浏览一本书为特征的略读。检视阅读是系统地略读的艺术。

Still another name for this level might be skimming or pre-reading. However, we do not mean the kind of skimming that is characterized by casual or random browsing through a book. Inspectional reading is the art of skimming systematically.

在这个水平上阅读时，你的目标是检查书的表面，学习表面所能教给你的一切。这通常很划算。

When reading at this level, your aim is to examine the surface of the book, to learn everything that the surface alone can teach you. That is often a good deal.

而在第一级提出的问题是“这句话说的是什么？” 这个级别通常问的问题是“这本书是关于什么的？” 这是一个表面问题；其他类似性质的是“这本书的结构是什么？” 或“它的组成部分是什么？”

Whereas the question that is asked at the first level is “What does the sentence say?” the question typically asked at this level is “What is the book about?” That is a surface question; others of a similar nature are “What is the structure of the book?” or “What are its parts?”

完成一本书的检视阅读后，无论你需要在多短的时间内完成，你也应该能够回答这样的问题：“这是什么样的书——小说、历史、科学论文？ ”

Upon completing an inspectional reading of a book, no matter how short the time you had to do it in, you should also be able to answer the question, “What kind of book is it—a novel, a history, a scientific treatise?”

第 4 章专门介绍这一级别的阅读，因此我们不会在这里进一步讨论。然而，我们确实要强调，大多数人，甚至许多非常优秀的读者，都没有意识到检查性阅读的价值。他们从第一页开始读一本书，然后慢慢读完，甚至不看目录。因此，他们在努力理解这本书的同时，还面临着对这本书有肤浅了解的任务。这加剧了困难。

Chapter 4 is devoted to an account of this level of reading, so we will not discuss it further here. We do want to stress, however, that most people, even many quite good readers, are unaware of the value of inspectional reading. They start a book on page one and plow steadily through it, without even reading the table of contents. They are thus faced with the task of achieving a superficial knowledge of the book at the same time that they are trying to understand it. That compounds the difficulty.

第三层次的阅读我们称之为分析阅读。它比目前讨论的两种阅读水平中的任何一种都更复杂、更系统。根据阅读文本的难度，它或多或少地对读者提出了沉重的要求。

The third level of reading we will call Analytical Reading. It is both a more complex and a more systematic activity than either of the two levels of reading discussed so far. Depending on the difficulty of the text to be read, it makes more or less heavy demands on the reader.

分析阅读是透彻的阅读、完整的阅读或良好的阅读——你能做的最好的阅读。如果说检视阅读是有限时间内最好、最完整的阅读，那么分析阅读就是无限时间内最好、最完整的阅读。

Analytical reading is thorough reading, complete reading, or good reading—the best reading you can do. If inspectional reading is the best and most complete reading that is possible given a limited time, then analytical reading is the best and most complete reading that is possible given unlimited time.

分析型读者必须针对他正在阅读的内容提出许多有条理的问题。我们不想在这里陈述这些问题，因为这本书主要是关于这个级别的阅读：第二部分给出了它的规则并告诉你如何去做。我们确实想在这里强调，分析阅读总是非常活跃的。在这个阅读层次上，读者抓住一本书——这个比喻很贴切——然后努力阅读，直到这本书成为他自己的。弗朗西斯·培根曾说过：“有些书要细细品味，有些要吞咽，少数要咀嚼和消化。” 分析地阅读一本书就是咀嚼和消化它。

The analytical reader must ask many, and organized, questions of what he is reading. We do not want to state these questions here, since this book is mainly about reading at this level: Part Two gives its rules and tells you how to do it. We do want to emphasize here that analytical reading is always intensely active. On this level of reading, the reader grasps a book—the metaphor is apt—and works at it until the book becomes his own. Francis Bacon once remarked that “some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested.” Reading a book analytically is chewing and digesting it.

我们还想强调，如果您阅读的目的只是获取信息或娱乐，那么分析性阅读几乎没有必要。分析阅读主要是为了理解。相反，除非你至少具备一些分析阅读的技能，否则几乎不可能借助一本书将你的思想从一种理解较少的状态转变为一种理解较多的状态。

We also want to stress that analytical reading is hardly ever necessary if your goal in reading is simply information or entertainment. Analytical reading is preeminently for the sake of understanding. Conversely, bringing your mind with the aid of a book from a condition of understanding less to one of understanding more is almost impossible unless you have at least some skill in analytical reading.

第四种也是最高层次的阅读，我们称之为主题阅读。它是所有阅读中最复杂、最系统的阅读类型。它对读者提出了很高的要求，即使他正在阅读的材料本身相对简单和简单。

The fourth and highest level of reading we will call Syntopical Reading. It is the most complex and systematic type of reading of all. It makes very heavy demands on the reader, even if the materials he is reading are themselves relatively easy and unsophisticated.

这个级别的另一个名称可能是比较阅读。当按主题阅读时，读者会阅读多本书，而不仅仅是一本书，并将它们与彼此相关联，并与它们都围绕的主题相关联。但仅仅比较文本是不够的。主题阅读涉及更多。在所读书籍的帮助下，主题式读者能够对可能不在任何书籍中的主题进行分析。因此，很明显，主题式阅读是最积极、最费力的阅读方式。

Another name for this level might be comparative reading. When reading syntopically, the reader reads many books, not just one, and places them in relation to one another and to a subject about which they all revolve. But mere comparison of texts is not enough. Syntopical reading involves more. With the help of the books read, the syntopical reader is able to construct an analysis of the subject that may not be in any of the books. It is obvious, therefore, that syntopical reading is the most active and effortful kind of reading.

我们将在第四部分讨论主题阅读。暂时可以说主题式阅读不是一门简单的艺术，而且它的规则并不广为人知。尽管如此，主题阅读可能是所有阅读活动中最有价值的。好处是如此之大，值得学习如何去做。

We will discuss syntopical reading in Part Four. Let it suffice for the moment to say that syntopical reading is not an easy art, and that the rules for it are not widely known. Nevertheless, syntopical reading is probably the most rewarding of all reading activities. The benefits are so great that it is well worth the trouble of learning how to do it.

3

第一级阅读：初级阅读

3THE FIRST LEVEL OF READING: ELEMENTARY READING

 

我们的时代是一个对阅读充满兴趣和关注的时代。政府官员宣称 1970 年代将是“阅读的十年”。畅销书告诉我们为什么约翰尼能读书或不能读书。初始阅读教学各个领域的研究和实验都在以不断加快的速度进行。

Ours is a time of great interest in and concern about reading. Public officials have declared that the 1970’s will be “the decade of reading.” Best-selling books tell us why Johnny can or can’t read. Research and experimentation in all fields of initial reading instruction proceed at an ever-increasing pace.

三种历史趋势或运动汇聚在我们的时代，产生了这种发酵。首先是美国继续努力教育其所有公民，这当然意味着至少要让他们都识字。美国人几乎从国家存在之初就支持这项努力，它是我们民主生活方式的基石之一，已经取得了显著成果。美国比其他任何地方都更早普及识字，这反过来又帮助我们成为当今高度发达的工业社会。但也存在巨大的问题。它们可以总结为这样的观察，即教育一小部分积极性很高的孩子，他们中的大多数是有文化的父母的孩子，

Three historical trends or movements have converged upon our time to produce this ferment. The first is the continuing effort of the United States to educate all of its citizens, which means, of course, at a minimum, to make them all literate. This effort, which Americans have supported almost from the beginning of the national existence and which is one of the cornerstones of our democratic way of life, has had remarkable results. Near-universal literacy was obtained in the United States earlier than anywhere else, and this in turn has helped us to become the highly developed industrial society that we are at the present day. But there have been enormous problems, too. They can be summed up in the observation that teaching a small percentage of highly motivated children, most of them the children of literate parents, to read —as was the case a century ago—is a far cry from teaching every child to read, no matter how little motivated he may be, or how deprived his background.

第二个历史趋势是阅读教学本身。直到 1870 年，阅读教学与希腊和罗马学校的教学方式几乎没有什么变化。至少在美国，所谓的 ABC 方法在整个 19 世纪的大部分时间里都占主导地位。孩子们被教导单独读出字母表中的字母——因此这种方法得名——然后将它们组合成音节，先是一次两个字母，然后是三个和四个，不管这样构成的音节是否有意义。因此，为了掌握语言，练习了ab、ac、ad、ib、ic等音节。当一个孩子可以说出所有确定数量的组合时，就可以说他知道他的 ABC。

The second historical trend is in the teaching of reading itself. As late as 1870, reading instruction was little changed from what it had been in Greek and Roman schools. In America, at least, the so-called ABC method was dominant throughout most of the nineteenth century. Children were taught to sound out the letters of the alphabet individually—hence the name of this method—and to combine them in syllables, first two letters at a time and then three and four, whether the syllables so constructed were meaningful or not. Thus, syllables such as ab, ac, ad, ib, ic were practiced for the sake of mastery of the language. When a child could name all of a determined number of combinations, he was said to know his ABC’s.

这种综合阅读教学方法在上世纪中叶受到严厉批评，并提出了两种替代方法。一种是合成 ABC 方法的变体，称为语音方法。在这里，这个词是通过它的发音而不是它的字母名称来识别的。为了表示单个字母（尤其是元音）发出的不同声音，进化出了复杂而巧妙的印刷系统。如果你五十岁或以上，你很可能学会了使用语音方法的某种变体来阅读。

This synthetic method of teaching reading came under heavy criticism around the middle of the last century, and two alternatives to it were proposed. One was a variant on the synthetic ABC method, known as the phonic method. Here the word was recognized by its sounds rather than by its letter-names. Complicated and ingenious systems of printing were evolved for the purpose of representing the different sounds made by a single letter, especially the vowels. If you are fifty or over, it is probable that you learned to read using some variant of the phonic method.

一种完全不同的方法，分析的而不是综合的，起源于德国，大约在 1840 年后由 Horace Mann 和其他教育家提倡。这涉及教授视觉在注意字母名称或字母发音之前识别整个单词。这种所谓的视觉法后来得到扩展，首先介绍代表思想单位的整个句子，学生随后才学会识别组成词，最后才是组成字母。这种方法在 1920 年代和 30 年代特别流行，这一时期的特点还在于重点从口头阅读转向默读。结果发现，口头阅读的能力并不一定意味着默读的能力，如果以默读为目标，口头阅读教学并不总是足够的。因此，几乎完全强调快速、全面的默读是大约从 1920 年到 1925 年的一个特点。然而，最近，钟摆又回到了自然拼读上，它确实从未完全离开课程。

A wholly different approach, analytical rather than synthetic, originated in Germany and was advocated by Horace Mann and other educators after about 1840. This involved teaching the visual recognition of whole words before giving any attention to letter-names or letter-sounds. This so-called sight method was later extended so that whole sentences, representing units of thought, were introduced first, with the pupils only later learning to recognize the constituent words and then, finally, the constituent letters. This method was especially popular during the 1920’s and 30’s, which period was also characterized by the shift in emphasis from oral reading to silent reading. It was found that ability to read orally did not necessarily mean ability to read silently and that instruction in oral reading was not always adequate if silent reading was the goal. Thus, an almost exclusive emphasis on rapid, comprehensive silent reading was a feature of the years from about 1920 to 1925. More recently, however, the pendulum has swung back again toward phonics, which indeed had never entirely left the curriculum.

所有这些不同的小学阅读教学方法对一些学生来说是成功的，对另一些学生来说是不成功的。在过去的两三年里，最受关注的或许是失败案例。第三种历史趋势在这里发挥作用。批评学校是美国的传统；一个多世纪以来，家长、自封的专家和教育工作者自己都在攻击和控诉教育系统。学校教育的任何方面都没有比阅读教学受到更严厉的批评。当前的书籍有着悠久的历史，每一项创新都伴随着一群怀疑的人，而且，人们觉得，无法说服的观察者。

All of these different methods of teaching elementary reading were successful for some pupils, unsuccessful for others. In the last two or three decades, it has perhaps been the failures that have attracted the most attention. And here the third historical trend comes into play. It is traditional in America to criticize the schools; for more than a century, parents, self-styled experts, and educators themselves have attacked and indicted the educational system. No aspect of schooling has been more severely criticized than reading instruction. The current books have a long ancestry, and every innovation carries in its train a posse of suspicious and, one feels, unpersuadable observers.

批评者可能是对的，也可能是不对的，但无论如何，随着对所有公民进行教育的持续努力进入了一个新阶段，导致高中和大学人口不断增长，这些问题变得更加紧迫。阅读能力不佳的年轻男女在追求美国梦时会受到阻碍，但如果他不在学校，这在很大程度上仍然是个人问题。然而，如果他留在学校或上大学，这也是他的老师和同学们关心的问题。

The critics may or may not be right, but in any event the problems have taken on a new urgency as the continuing effort to educate all citizens has entered a new phase, resulting in ever-growing high school and college populations. A young man or woman who cannot read very well is hindered in his pursuit of the American dream, but that remains largely a personal matter if he is not in school. If he remains in school or goes to college, however, it is a matter of concern for his teachers as well, and for his fellow students.

因此，研究人员目前非常活跃，他们的工作催生了许多新的阅读教学方法。更重要的新课程包括所谓的折衷方法、个性化阅读方法、语言体验方法、基于语言学原理的各种方法，以及或多或少基于某种程序化教学的其他方法。此外，还采用了诸如初始教学字母表 (ita) 之类的新媒介，有时这些媒介也涉及新方法。还有其他设备和程序是“完全沉浸法”、“外语学校”方法”，这种方法被称为“看-说”、“看-说”、“看-说”或“文字法”。毫无疑问，现在正在以不同于所有这些的方法和途径进行实验。现在判断这些是否是长期寻求的治疗所有阅读疾病的灵丹妙药可能还为时过早。

Hence, researchers are very active at the present time, and their work has resulted in numerous new approaches to reading instruction. Among the more important new programs are the so-called eclectic approach, the individualized reading approach, the language-experience approach, the various approaches based on linguistic principles, and others based more or less closely on some kind of programmed instruction. In addition, new mediums such as the Initial Teaching Alphabet (i.t.a.) have been employed, and sometimes these involve new methods as well. Still other devices and programs are the “total immersion method,” the “foreign-language-school method,” and the method known variously as the “see-say,” “look-say,” “look-and-say,” or “word method.” Doubtless experiments are now being undertaken in methods and approaches that differ from all of these. It is perhaps too early to tell whether any of these is the long-sought panacea for all reading ills.

学习阅读的阶段

Stages of Learning to Read

 

最近研究的一个有用发现是对阅读学习阶段的分析。现在人们普遍认为，在孩子向所谓的成熟阅读能力发展的过程中，至少有四个或多或少清晰可辨的阶段。第一阶段称为“阅读准备”。有人指出，这在出生时就开始了，并正常持续到大约六七岁。

One useful finding of recent research is the analysis of stages in learning to read. It is now widely accepted that there are at least four more or less clearly distinguishable stages in the child’s progress toward what is called mature reading ability. The first stage is known by the term “reading readiness.” This begins, it has been pointed out, at birth, and continues normally until the age of about six or seven.

阅读准备包括几种不同类型的学习阅读准备。身体准备包括良好的视力和听力。智力准备涉及最低水平的视觉感知，以便孩子可以接受并记住整个单词以及组合形成它的字母。语言准备包括能够清楚地说话和按正确顺序使用几个句子的能力。个人准备包括与其他孩子一起工作、保持注意力、听从指示等的能力。

Reading readiness includes several different kinds of preparation for learning to read. Physical readiness involves good vision and hearing. Intellectual readiness involves a minimum level of visual perception such that the child can take in and remember an entire word and the letters that combine to form it. Language readiness involves the ability to speak clearly and to use several sentences in correct order. Personal readiness involves the ability to work with other children, to sustain attention, to follow directions, and the like.

一般阅读准备情况是通过测试来评估的，也由通常善于辨别学生何时准备好学习阅读的教师进行评估。重要的是要记住，仓促行事通常会弄巧成拙。还没有准备好阅读的孩子如果试图教他，就会感到沮丧，他可能会将对这种经历的厌恶带入他以后的学校生涯，甚至进入成年生活。在阅读准备阶段之后延迟开始阅读教学并没有那么严重，尽管父母可能担心他们的孩子“落后”或没有“跟上”同龄人。

General reading readiness is assessed by tests and is also estimated by teachers who are often skillful at discerning just when a pupil is ready to learn to read. The important thing to remember is that jumping the gun is usually self-defeating. The child who is not yet ready to read is frustrated if attempts are made to teach him, and he may carry over his dislike for the experience into his later school career and even into adult life. Delaying the beginning of reading instruction beyond the reading readiness stage is not nearly so serious, despite the feelings of parents who may fear that their child is “backward” or is not “keeping up” with his peers.

在第二阶段，孩子们学习阅读非常简单的材料。至少在美国，他们通常从学习一些常见单词开始，到第一年结束时通常会掌握大约三百到四百个单词。此时介绍基本技能，例如上下文或意义线索的使用以及单词的开头声音。到这个阶段结束时，学生们应该能够独立而热情地阅读简单的书籍。

In the second stage, children learn to read very simple materials. They usually begin, at least in the United States, by learning a few sight words, and typically manage to master perhaps three hundred to four hundred words by the end of the first year. Basic skills are introduced at this time, such as the use of context or meaning clues and the beginning sounds of words. By the end of this period pupils are expected to be reading simple books independently and with enthusiasm.

顺便值得一提的是，在这个阶段发生了一些非常神秘，几乎是神奇的事情。在孩子成长过程中的某个时刻，当他面对一页纸上的一系列符号时，会发现它们毫无意义。不久之后——也许只有两三个星期之后——他发现了它们的意义；他知道他们说“猫坐在帽子上”。尽管哲学家和心理学家在两年半的时间里努力研究这一现象，但没有人真正知道这是如何发生的。意义从何而来？一个法国孩子怎么会在符号“Le chat s'asseyait sur le chapeau”中找到相同的含义？事实上，这种对符号意义的发现可能是任何人所做出的最惊人的智力壮举——而且大多数人在七岁之前就做到了！

It is incidentally worth observing that something quite mysterious, almost magical, occurs during this stage. At one moment in the course of his development the child, when faced with a series of symbols on a page, finds them quite meaningless. Not much later—perhaps only two or three weeks later-he has discovered meaning in them; he knows that they say “The cat sat on the hat.” How this happens no one really knows, despite the efforts of philosophers and psychologists over two and a half millennia to study the phenomenon. Where does meaning come from? How is it that a French child would find the same meaning in the symbols “Le chat s’asseyait sur le chapeau”? Indeed, this discovery of meaning in symbols may be the most astounding intellectual feat that any human being ever performs—and most humans perform it before they are seven years old!

第三阶段的特点是词汇构建的快速进步以及通过上下文线索“解锁”生词含义的技能不断提高。此外，这个阶段的孩子学习阅读的目的不同，内容也不同，例如科学、社会研究、语言艺术等。他们了解到，阅读除了是一个人在学校做的事情之外，也是一个人可以自己做的事情，可以是为了乐趣、满足好奇心，甚至是为了“扩大自己的视野”。

The third stage is characterized by rapid progress in vocabulary building and by increasing skill in “unlocking” the meaning of unfamiliar words through context clues. In addition, children at this stage learn to read for different purposes and in different areas of content, such as science, social studies, language arts, and the like. They learn that reading, besides being something one does at school, is also something one can do on one’s own, for fun, to satisfy curiosity, or even to “expand one’s horizons.”

最后，第四阶段的特点是对先前获得的技能进行细化和增强。最重要的是，学生开始能够吸收他的阅读经验——也就是说，将概念从一篇文章转移到另一篇文章，并比较不同作者对这方面的观点。同一个主题。这是阅读的成熟阶段，应该由十几岁的年轻人达到。理想情况下，他们应该在余生中继续以此为基础。

Finally, the fourth stage is characterized by the refinement and enhancement of the skills previously acquired. Above all, the student begins to be able to assimilate his reading experiences—that is, to carry over concepts from one piece of writing to another, and to compare the views of different writers on the same subject. This, the mature stage of reading, should be reached by young persons in their early teens. Ideally, they should continue to build on it for the rest of their lives.

对于许多家长和大多数教育工作者来说，他们往往甚至达不到这一点是显而易见的。失败的原因有很多，从家庭环境中的各种剥夺——经济、社会和/或智力（包括父母文盲）——到各种个人问题（包括对“制度”的全面反抗） ”）。但是失败的原因之一并不经常被注意到。非常强调阅读准备和用于教孩子阅读基础的方法意味着其他更高水平的阅读往往被忽视。考虑到在第一级发现的问题的紧迫性和程度，这是完全可以理解的。尽管如此，除非努力解决美国人的整体阅读缺陷，否则无法找到有效的补救措施。各级阅读。

That they often do not even reach it is apparent to many parents and to most educators. The reasons for the failure are many, ranging all the way from various kinds of deprivations in the home environment—economic, social, and/or intellectual (including parental illiteracy)—to personal problems of all kinds (including total revolt against “the system”). But one cause of the failure is not often noted. The very emphasis on reading readiness and on the methods employed to teach children the rudiments of reading has meant that the other, the higher, levels of reading have tended to be slighted. This is quite understandable, considering the urgency and extent of the problems found on this first level. Nevertheless, effective remedies for the overall reading deficiencies of Americans cannot be found unless efforts are made on all levels of reading.

阶段和级别

Stages and Levels

 

我们已经描述了阅读的四个层次，我们还概述了以初级方式学习阅读的四个阶段。这些阶段和层次之间的关系是什么？

We have described four levels of reading, and we have also outlined four stages of learning to read in an elementary fashion. What is the relation between these stages and levels?

最重要的是要认识到这里概述的四个阶段都是第一级阅读的所有阶段，如前一章所述。它们是初级阅读的阶段，因此可以按照小学课程的方式进行一些有用的划分。初级阅读的第一阶段——阅读准备——对应于学前和幼儿园的经历。第二阶段——单词掌握——对应于典型儿童一年级的经验（尽管许多非常正常的儿童在这个意义上并不“典型”），结果孩子获得了我们所谓的第二阶段阅读技能，或一年级的阅读能力或一年级的识字能力。这基本阅读的第三阶段——词汇增长和上下文的利用——通常（但不是普遍的，即使是正常儿童）在小学四年级结束时获得，并导致所谓的四年级，或功能性、识字能力——根据一个通用定义，能够相当轻松地阅读交通标志或图片说明，填写更简单的政府表格等。初级阅读的第四个也是最后一个阶段大约在学生离开或从小学或初中毕业时达到。它有时被称为八年级、九年级或十年级识字。这个孩子是一个“成熟”的读者，因为他现在几乎可以阅读任何东西，但仍然是一种相对简单的方式。用最简单的话来说，

It is of paramount importance to recognize that the four stages outlined here are all stages of the first level of reading, as outlined in the previous chapter. They are stages, that is, of elementary reading, which thus can be usefully divided somewhat in the manner of the elementary school curriculum. The first stage of elementary reading—reading readiness—corresponds to pre-school and kindergarten experiences. The second stage—word mastery—corresponds to the first grade experience of the typical child (although many quite normal children are not “typical” in this sense), with the result that the child attains what we can call second-stage reading skills, or first grade ability in reading or first grade literacy. The third stage of elementary reading—vocabulary growth and the utilization of context—is typically (but not universally, even for normal children) acquired at about the end of the fourth grade of elementary school, and results in what is variously called fourth grade, or functional, literacy—the ability, according to one common definition, to read traffic signs or picture captions fairly easily, to fill out the simpler government forms, and the like. The fourth and final stage of elementary reading is attained at about the time the pupil leaves or graduates from elementary school or junior high school. It is sometimes called eighth grade, ninth grade, or tenth grade literacy. The child is a “mature” reader in the sense that he is now capable of reading almost anything, but still in a relatively unsophisticated manner. In the simplest terms, he is mature enough to do high school work.

然而，他还不是我们要在本书中使用该术语的意义上的“成熟”读者。他已经掌握了第一层次的阅读，仅此而已；他可以自己阅读，并准备学习更多关于阅读的知识。但他还不知道如何阅读超过初级水平的内容。

However, he is not yet a “mature” reader in the sense in which we want to employ the term in this book. He has mastered the first level of reading, that is all; he can read on his own and is prepared to learn more about reading. But he does not yet know how to read beyond the elementary level.

我们之所以提到所有这些，是因为它与本书的信息密切相关。我们假设——我们必须假设——你，我们的读者，已经达到了九年级的识字水平，你已经掌握了初级阅读水平，这意味着你已经成功地通过了所描述的四个阶段。如果你仔细想想，你就会意识到我们不能假设更少。没有人能从一本如何做的书中学到东西，除非他能阅读它；一本声称教人阅读的书尤其如此，它的读者必须能够在某种意义上阅读。

We mention all this because it is highly germane to the message of this book. We assume—we must assume—that you, our reader, have attained ninth grade literacy, that you have mastered the elementary level of reading, which means that you have passed successfully through the four stages described. If you think about it, you realize that we could not assume less. No one can learn from a how-to-do-it book until he can read it; and it is particularly true of a book purporting to teach one to read that its readers must be able to read in some sense of the term.

辅助和非辅助发现之间的区别在这里发挥作用。通常，初级阅读的四个阶段是在在世教师的帮助下完成的。当然，孩子们的能力各不相同；有些人比其他人需要更多帮助。但是老师通常会在场回答问题并解决小学阶段出现的困难学年。只有当他掌握了初级阅读的所有四个阶段时，孩子才准备好进入更高层次的阅读。只有这样，他才能独立阅读并自学。只有这样他才能开始成为一个真正优秀的读者。

The difference between aided and unaided discovery comes into play here. Typically, the four stages of elementary reading are attained with the help of living teachers. Children differ in their abilities, of course; some need more help than others. But a teacher is usually present to answer questions and smooth over difficulties that arise during the elementary school years. Only when he has mastered all of the four stages of elementary reading is the child prepared to move on to the higher levels of reading. Only then can he read independently and learn on his own. Only then can he begin to become a really good reader.

更高水平的阅读和高等教育

Higher Levels of Reading and Higher Education

 

传统上，美国的高中很少为学生提供阅读指导，而大学则没有。这种情况近年来发生了变化。两代人之前，当高中入学人数在相对较短的时间内大幅增加时，教育工作者开始意识到，不能再假设进入学生就可以有效阅读。因此提供了补习性阅读指导，有时多达 75% 或更多的学生。在过去的十年里，同样的情况也发生在大学层面。因此，在 1971 年秋季进入纽约城市大学的大约 40,000 名新生中，超过一半，即超过 20,000 名年轻人必须接受某种阅读补救培训。

Traditionally, the high schools of America have provided little reading instruction for their students, and the colleges have provided none. That situation has changed in recent years. Two generations ago, when high school enrollments increased greatly within a relatively short period, educators began to realize that it could no longer be assumed that entering students could read effectively. Remedial reading instruction was therefore provided, sometimes for as many as 75% or more students. Within the last decade, the same situation has occurred at the college level. Thus, of approximately 40,000 freshmen entering the City University of New York in the fall of 1971, upwards of half, or more than 20,000 young people, had to be given some kind of remedial training in reading.

然而，这并不意味着至今许多美国大学都提供小学以外的阅读指导。事实上，几乎没有一个提供它。补习阅读指导不是更高层次的阅读指导。它只是为了让学生在阅读方面达到他们在小学毕业时应该达到的成熟水平。直到今天，大多数高等院校要么不知道如何指导学生进行初级以上的阅读，要么缺乏这样做的设施和人员。

That does not mean, however, that reading instruction beyond the elementary level is offered in many U.S. colleges to this day. In fact, it is offered in almost none of them. Remedial reading instruction is not instruction in the higher levels of reading. It serves only to bring students up to a level of maturity in reading that they should have attained by the time they graduated from elementary school. To this day, most institutions of higher learning either do not know how to instruct students in reading beyond the elementary level, or lack the facilities and personnel to do so.

尽管许多四年制大学和社区大学最近开设了速读课程、“有效”阅读课程或“能力”课程，但我们还是这么说。读。总的来说（虽然也有例外），这些课程是补救性的。它们旨在克服低年级学校的各种失败。它们的目的不是为了让学生超越第一层次，也不是为了向他介绍本书主要主题的阅读种类和层次。

We say this despite the fact that a number of four-year and community colleges have recently instituted courses in speed reading, or in “effective” reading, or “competence” in reading. On the whole (though there are exceptions), these courses are remedial. They are designed to overcome various kinds of failures of the lower schools. They are not designed to take the student beyond the first level or to introduce him to the kinds and levels of reading that are the main subject of this book.

当然，事实并非如此。一所好的文科高中，如果它什么都不做的话，应该培养出有能力进行分析阅读的毕业生。一所好的大学，如果它什么都不做的话，应该培养出称职的主题读者。大学学位应该代表一般的阅读能力，这样毕业生就可以为普通读者阅读任何类型的材料，并且能够对几乎任何主题进行独立研究（因为这就是主题阅读，除其他外，你可以做到这一点） ). 然而，在学生达到这种阅读能力水平之前，通常需要三四年的研究生学习，而且他们并不总是能达到这种水平。

This, of course, should not be the case. A good liberal arts high school, if it does nothing else, ought to produce graduates who are competent analytical readers. A good college, if it does nothing else, ought to produce competent syntopical readers. A college degree ought to represent general competence in reading such that a graduate could read any kind of material for general readers and be able to undertake independent research on almost any subject (for that is what syntopical reading, among other things, enables you to do). Often, however, three or four years of graduate study are required before students attain this level of reading ability, and they do not always attain it even then.

一个人不应该为了学习如何阅读而在研究生院度过四年。四年的研究生学习，加上十二年的预科教育和四年的大学教育——加起来就是整整二十年的学校教育。学习阅读不应该花那么长时间。如果确实如此，那就大错特错了。

One should not have to spend four years in graduate school in order to learn how to read. Four years of graduate school, in addition to twelve years of preparatory education and four years of college—that adds up to twenty full years of schooling. It should not take that long to learn to read. Something is very wrong if it does.

有什么问题可以改正。许多高中和大学都可以根据本书中描述的课程开设课程。我们要提出的建议没有什么神秘的，甚至没有什么新鲜的。这主要是常识。

What is wrong can be corrected. Courses could be instituted in many high schools and colleges that are based on the program described in this book. There is nothing arcane or even really new about what we have to propose. It is largely common sense.

阅读与教育的民主理想

Reading and the Democratic Ideal of Education

 

我们不想看起来只是吹毛求疵的批评家。我们知道，成千上万的新生脚步踏在楼梯上发出的雷鸣声让人难以听见，无论信息。只要这些新生中有很大一部分，甚至是大多数，在小学阶段都不能有效阅读，我们就意识到，首先要面对的任务就是教他们以最低、最大的公分母阅读，词义。

We do not want to seem to be mere carping critics. We know that the thunder of thousands of freshmen feet upon the stairs makes it hard to hear, no matter how reasonable the message. And as long as a large proportion, even a majority, of these new students cannot read effectively at the elementary level, we are aware that the first task to be faced must be to teach them to read in the lowest, the largest common-denominator, sense of the term.

目前，我们也不会想要任何其他方式。我们公开表示，无限的教育机会——或者，实际上，仅受个人愿望、能力和需要限制的教育机会——是社会可以为其成员提供的最有价值的服务。我们还不知道如何提供这种机会，但这并不是放弃尝试的理由。

Nor, for the moment, would we want it any other way. We are on record as holding that unlimited educational opportunity—or, speaking practically, educational opportunity that is limited only by individual desire, ability, and need—is the most valuable service that society can provide for its members. That we do not yet know how to provide that kind of opportunity is no reason to give up the attempt.

但我们也必须认识到——学生、教师和外行——即使我们完成了摆在我们面前的任务，我们也不会完成全部任务。我们必须不仅仅是一个实用文人的国家。我们必须成为一个真正有能力的读者的国家，认识到能力这个词所暗示的一切。没有什么会满足即将到来的世界的需要。

But we must also realize—students, teachers, and laymen alike—that even when we have accomplished the task that lies before us, we will not have accomplished the whole task. We must be more than a nation of functional literates. We must become a nation of truly competent readers, recognizing all that the word competent implies. Nothing less will satisfy the needs of the world that is coming.

4

第二层次阅读：检视阅读

4THE SECOND LEVEL OF READING: INSPECTIONAL READING

 

检视阅读是真正水平的阅读。它与之前的水平（基础阅读）和自然顺序之后的水平（分析阅读）截然不同。但是，正如我们在第 2 章中提到的，阅读水平是累积的。因此，基础阅读包含在检视阅读中，正如检视阅读包含在分析阅读中，而分析阅读包含在主题阅读中一样。

Inspectional reading is a true level of reading. It is quite distinct from the level that precedes it (elementary reading) and from the one that follows it in natural sequence (analytical reading). But, as we noted in Chapter 2, the levels of reading are cumulative. Thus, elementary reading is contained in inspectional reading, as, indeed, inspectional reading is contained in analytical reading, and analytical reading in syntopical reading.

实际上，这意味着除非你能在初级水平上有效阅读，否则你不能在检查水平上阅读。您必须能够或多或少地稳定地阅读作者的文章，而不必停下来查找许多单词的含义，也不会在语法和句法上绊倒。你必须能够理解大部分的句子和段落，尽管不一定是所有句子和段落中最好的理解。

Practically, this means that you cannot read on the inspectional level unless you can read effectively on the elementary level. You must be able to read an author’s text more or less steadily, without having to stop to look up the meaning of many words, and without stumbling over the grammar and syntax. You must be able to make sense of a majority of the sentences and paragraphs, although not necessarily the best sense of all of them.

那么，检视阅读包括哪些内容呢？你打算怎么做？

What, then, is involved in inspectional reading? How do you go about doing it?

首先要认识到的是，有两种类型的检查阅读。它们是单一技能的各个方面，但建议初学者将它们视为两个不同的步骤或活动。有经验的读者学会了同时执行这两个步骤，但目前我们将它们视为完全不同的。

The first thing to realize is that there are two types of inspectional reading. They are aspects of a single skill, but the beginning reader is well-advised to consider them as two different steps or activities. The experienced reader learns to perform both steps simultaneously, but for the moment we will treat them as if they were quite distinct.

检视阅读 I：系统略读或预读

Inspectional Reading I: Systematic Skimming or Pre-reading

 

让我们回到我们之前提到的基本情况。有一本书或其他读物，这是你的思想。你做的第一件事是什么？
