Let us return to the basic situation to which we have referred before. There is a book or other reading matter, and here is your mind. What is the first thing that you do?

让我们在这种情况下假设另外两个因素，这些因素非常普遍。首先，你不知道你是否想读这本书。你不知道它是否值得分析阅读。但你怀疑它确实如此，或者至少它包含信息和见解，如果你能挖掘出来，这些信息和见解对你来说很有价值。

Let us assume two further elements in the situation, elements that are quite common. First, you do not know whether you want to read the book. You do not know whether it deserves an analytical reading. But you suspect that it does, or at least that it contains both information and insights that would be valuable to you if you could dig them out.

其次，让我们假设——这是很常见的情况——你只有有限的时间来找出所有这些。

Second, let us assume—and this is very often the case-that you have only a limited time in which to find all this out.

在这种情况下，你必须做的是浏览这本书，或者像有些人喜欢说的那样，预读它。略读或预读是检视阅读的第一个子层次。你的主要目标是发现这本书是否需要更仔细的阅读。其次，略读可以告诉你很多关于这本书的其他事情，即使你决定不再仔细阅读它也是如此。

In this case, what you must do is skim the book, or, as some prefer to say, pre-read it. Skimming or pre-reading is the first sublevel of inspectional reading. Your main aim is to discover whether the book requires a more careful reading. Secondly, skimming can tell you lots of other things about the book, even if you decide not to read it again with more care.

以这种方式快速浏览一本书是一个脱粒过程，可以帮助您从营养的真正内核中分离出谷壳。你可能会发现，你暂时浏览的内容就是这本书对你的全部价值。它可能永远不会更值钱。但你至少会知道作者的主要论点是什么，以及他写了什么样的书，这样你花在翻书上的时间就不会浪费了。

Giving a book this kind of quick once-over is a threshing process that helps you to separate the chaff from the real kernels of nourishment. You may discover that what you get from skimming is all the book is worth to you for the time being. It may never be worth more. But you will know at least what the author’s main contention is, as well as what kind of book he has written, so the time you have spent looking through the book will not have been wasted.

略读的习惯不应该花费太多时间来养成。这里有一些关于如何做的建议。

The habit of skimming should not take much time to acquire. Here are some suggestions about how to do it.

1.查看扉页，如果书有，请查看序言。快速阅读每一个。特别注意字幕或本书的范围或目标或作者对其主题的特殊角度的其他说明。在完成这一步之前，您应该对主题有一个很好的了解，并且，如果您愿意，您可以暂停片刻，将这本书放在您脑海中的适当类别中。这本书属于哪个已经包含其他书籍的文件夹？

1. LOOK AT THE TITLE PAGE AND, IF THE BOOK HAS ONE, AT ITS PREFACE. Read each quickly. Note especially the subtitles or other indications of the scope or aim of the book or of the author’s special angle on his subject. Before completing this step you should have a good idea of the subject, and, if you wish, you may pause for a moment to place the book in the appropriate category in your mind. What pigeonhole that already contains other books does this one belong in?

2.研究目录以大致了解本书的结构；像旅行前的路线图一样使用它。令人惊讶的是，有多少人从来不看一本书的目录，除非他们想在其中查找一些东西。事实上，许多作者在创建目录时花费了大量时间，但令人遗憾的是，他们的努力往往是白费的。

2. STUDY THE TABLE OF CONTENTS to obtain a general sense of the book’s structure; use it as you would a road map before taking a trip. It is astonishing how many people never even glance at a book’s table of contents unless they wish to look something up in it. In fact, many authors spend a considerable amount of time in creating the table of contents, and it is sad to think their efforts are often wasted.

曾经是一种常见的做法，尤其是在说明性作品中，但有时甚至在小说和诗歌中，也会写出非常完整的目录，将章节或部分分解成许多指示所涵盖主题的副标题。例如，弥尔顿为《失乐园》的每一本书都写了或多或少冗长的标题，或者他称之为“论据” 。吉本出版了他的罗马帝国衰亡史每章都有一个广泛的分析目录。这样的摘要不再常见，尽管偶尔您仍然会遇到分析目录。这种做法减少的原因之一可能是人们不再像以前那样阅读目录。此外，出版商已经开始觉得，一个不那么暴露的目录比一个完全坦率和开放的目录更具吸引力。他们觉得，读者会被一本章节标题或多或少神秘的书所吸引——他们会想阅读这本书以了解这些章节的内容。尽管如此，目录还是很有价值的，在继续阅读本书的其余部分之前，您应该仔细阅读它。

It used to be a common practice, especially in expository works, but sometimes even in novels and poems, to write very full tables of contents, with the chapters or parts broken down into many subtitles indicative of the topics covered. Milton, for example, wrote more or less lengthy headings, or “Arguments,” as he called them, for each book of Paradise Lost. Gibbon published his Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire with an extensive analytical table of contents for each chapter. Such summaries are no longer common, although occasionally you do still come across an analytical table of contents. One reason for the decline of the practice may be that people are not so likely to read tables of contents as they once were. Also, publishers have come to feel that a less revealing table of contents is more seductive than a completely frank and open one. Readers, they feel, will be attracted to a book with more or less mysterious chapter titles—they will want to read the book to find out what the chapters are about. Even so, a table of contents can be valuable, and you should read it carefully before going on to the rest of the book.

此时，如果您还没有阅读本书，您可能会翻回本书的目录。我们试图使它尽可能地完整和信息丰富。检查它应该让您对我们正在尝试做的事情有一个很好的了解。

At this point, you might turn back to the table of contents of this book, if you have not already read it. We tried to make it as full and informative as we could. Examining it should give you a good idea of what we are trying to do.

3.如果书中有索引，请查看索引——大多数说明性著作都有。快速估计涵盖的主题范围以及参考的书籍和作者的种类。当您看到列出的术语似乎很重要时，请至少查看引用的一些段落。（我们将在第二部分对关键术语进行更多讨论。在这里，您必须根据从第 1 步和第 2 步获得的对本书的总体感觉来判断它们的重要性。）您阅读的段落可能包含症结——本书的关键点——或新的出发点，这是作者方法和态度的关键。

3. CHECK THE INDEX if the book has one—most expository works do. Make a quick estimate of the range of topics covered and of the kinds of books and authors referred to. When you see terms listed that seem crucial, look up at least some of the passages cited. (We will have much more to say about crucial terms in Part Two. Here you must make your judgment of their importance on the basis of your general sense of the book, as obtained from steps 1 and 2.) The passages you read may contain the crux—the point on which the book hinges—or the new departure which is the key to the author’s approach and attitude.

与目录的情况一样，此时您可以查看本书的索引。您将认识到一些已经讨论过的术语是至关重要的。例如，您能否通过它们下面的参考文献数量来识别其他似乎也很重要的内容？

As in the case of the table of contents, you might at this point check the index of this book. You will recognize as crucial some terms that have already been discussed. Can you identify, for example, by the number of references under them, any others that also seem important?

4. 如果这本书是一本带防尘套的新书，请阅读出版商的简介。有些人的印象是，宣传语不过是吹嘘而已。但这通常是不正确的，尤其是在说明性作品的情况下。许多这些书的导语都是作者自己写的，诚然是在出版商公共关系部门的帮助下。作者尝试尽可能准确地总结书中的要点的情况并不少见。这些努力不应被忽视。当然，如果宣传语不过是吹吹这本书，一般一眼就能发现。但这本身可以告诉你一些关于这项工作的事情。也许这本书没有说任何重要的事情——这就是为什么广告语也没有说什么的原因。

4. If the book is a new one with a dust jacket, READ THE PUBLISHER’S BLURB. Some people have the impression that the blurb is never anything but sheer puffery. But this is quite often not true, especially in the case of expository works. The blurbs of many of these books are written by the authors themselves, admittedly with the help of the publisher’s public relations department. It is not uncommon for authors to try to summarize as accurately as they can the main points in their book. These efforts should not go unnoticed. Of course, if the blurb is nothing but a puff for the book, you will ordinarily be able to discover this at a glance. But that in itself can tell you something about the work. Perhaps the book does not say anything of importance—and that is why the blurb does not say anything, either.

完成这前四个步骤后，您可能已经对这本书有了足够的信息，可以知道您想要更仔细地阅读它，或者您根本不想或根本不需要阅读它。无论哪种情况，您都可以暂时搁置。如果你不这样做，你现在准备好浏览这本书，正确地说。

Upon completing these first four steps you may already have enough information about the book to know that you want to read it more carefully, or that you do not want or need to read it at all. In either case, you may put it aside for the moment. If you do not do so, you are now ready to skim the book, properly speaking.

5. 根据您对本书内容的一般性且仍然相当模糊的了解，现在查看似乎对其论点至关重要的章节。如果这些章节的开头或结尾页有总结性陈述（通常如此），请仔细阅读这些陈述。

5. From your general and still rather vague knowledge of the book’s contents, LOOK NOW AT THE CHAPTERS THAT SEEM TO BE PIVOTAL TO ITS ARGUMENT. If these chapters have summary statements in their opening or closing pages, as they often do, read these statements carefully.

6. 最后，翻页，在这里和那里蘸一下，阅读一两段，有时是连续几页，永远不要超过这个。以这种方式翻阅这本书，总是寻找主要争论的迹象，倾听事情的基本脉搏。最重要的是，不要忘记阅读最后两三页，或者，如果这是结语，请阅读本书主要部分的最后几页。很少有作者能够抵制诱惑，在这些页面中总结他们认为关于他们的工作的新的和重要的内容。你不想错过这一点，尽管有时作者自己的判断可能是错误的。

6. Finally, TURN THE PAGES, DIPPING IN HERE AND THERE, READING A PARAGRAPH OR TWO, SOMETIMES SEVERAL PAGES IN SEQUENCE, NEVER MORE THAN THAT. Thumb through the book in this way, always looking for signs of the main contention, listening for the basic pulsebeat of the matter. Above all, do not fail to read the last two or three pages, or, if these are an epilogue, the last few pages of the main part of the book. Few authors are able to resist the temptation to sum up what they think is new and important about their work in these pages. You do not want to miss this, even though, as sometimes happens, the author himself may be wrong in his judgment.

你现在已经系统地浏览了这本书；你已经给了它第一种检查性阅读。在花不超过几分钟（最多一个小时）阅读这本书之后，此时你应该对这本书有了很多了解。特别是，你应该知道这本书是否包含你仍想挖掘的内容，或者它是否不值得你花更多的时间和精力。您还应该能够比以前更准确地将这本书放在您的心理卡片目录中，以便在需要时进一步参考。

You have now skimmed the book systematically; you have given it the first type of inspectional reading. You should know a good deal about the book at this point, after having spent no more than a few minutes, at most an hour, with it. In particular, you should know whether the book contains matter that you still want to dig out, or whether it deserves no more of your time and attention. You should also be able to place the book even more accurately than before in your mental card catalogue, for further reference if the occasion should ever arise.

顺便说一句，这是一种非常积极的阅读方式。不保持警觉，不让一个人的所有机能都清醒和工作，就不可能对任何一本书进行检查性阅读。有多少次你在一本好书的几页上做白日梦，醒来时才意识到你对自己所走过的地面一无所知？如果您遵循此处概述的步骤，即不会发生这种情况——也就是说，如果您有一个遵循一般线索的系统。

Incidentally, this is a very active sort of reading. It is impossible to give any book an inspectional reading without being alert, without having all of one’s faculties awake and working. How many times have you daydreamed through several pages of a good book only to wake up to the realization that you have no idea of the ground you have gone over? That cannot happen if you follow the steps outlined here—that is, if you have a system for following a general thread.

把自己想象成一个寻找线索的侦探本书的总体主题或想法，警惕任何可以使其更清晰的内容。听取我们提出的建议将帮助您保持这种态度。你会惊讶地发现你节省了多少时间，高兴地看到你掌握了多少，并欣慰地发现这一切比你想象的要容易得多。

Think of yourself as a detective looking for clues to a book’s general theme or idea, alert for anything that will make it clearer. Heeding the suggestions we have made will help you sustain this attitude. You will be surprised to find out how much time you will save, pleased to see how much more you will grasp, and relieved to discover how much easier it all can be than you supposed.

检视阅读二：粗略阅读

Inspectional Reading II: Superficial Reading

 

本节的标题是故意挑衅的。“肤浅”一词通常带有负面含义。然而，我们非常认真地使用这个词。

The title of this section is intentionally provocative. The word “superficial” ordinarily has a negative connotation. We are quite serious, however, in using the term.

每个人都有过这样的经历，在一本开篇就寄予厚望的启蒙书上苦苦挣扎，却无果而终。很自然地得出结论，首先尝试阅读它是一个错误。但这不是错误。相反，这是因为对一本困难的书的第一次阅读期望过高。以正确的方式接近，没有一本面向普通读者的书，无论多么困难，都不会成为绝望的原因。

Everyone has had the experience of struggling fruitlessly with a difficult book that was begun with high hopes of enlightenment. It is natural enough to conclude that it was a mistake to try to read it in the first place. But that was not the mistake. Rather it was in expecting too much from the first going over of a difficult book. Approached in the right way, no book intended for the general reader, no matter how difficult, need be a cause for despair.

什么是正确的方法？答案在于一个重要而有用的阅读规则，但通常被忽视了。这条规则很简单：第一次读一本困难的书时，通读一遍，不要停下来查找或思考你不明白的地方。

What is the right approach? The answer lies in an important and helpful rule of reading that is generally overlooked. That rule is simply this: In tackling a difficult book for the first time, read it through without ever stopping to look-up or ponder the things you do not understand right away.

注意你能理解的东西，不要被你不能立即掌握的东西阻止。继续阅读你难以理解的地方，你很快就会明白你所理解的东西。专注于这些。继续这样下去。通读这本书，不要被你忽略的段落、脚注、评论和参考文献吓倒和沮丧。如果你让自己停滞不前，如果你让自己被这些绊脚石中的任何一个绊倒，你就会迷路。大多数情况下，坚持下去是解不开的。在第二次阅读时你将有更好的机会理解它，但这需要你至少通读一遍这本书。

Pay attention to what you can understand and do not be stopped by what you cannot immediately grasp. Go right on reading past the point where you have difficulties in understanding, and you will soon come to things you do understand. Concentrate on these. Keep on in this way. Read the book through, undeterred and undismayed by the paragraphs, footnotes, comments, and references that escape you. If you let yourself get stalled, if you allow yourself to be tripped up by any one of these stumbling blocks, you are lost. In most cases, you will not be able to puzzle the thing out by sticking to it. You will have a much better chance of understanding it on a second reading, but that requires you to have read the book through at least once.

通过通读本书你所理解的——即使只有百分之五十或更少——将在你以后付出额外的努力回到你第一次阅读时经过的地方时帮助你。即使你再也回不去，理解一本真正难懂的书的一半也比完全不理解要好得多，如果你允许自己被你遇到的第一个困难的段落所打断，就会出现这种情况。

What you understand by reading the book through to the end—even if it is only fifty percent or less—will help you when you make the additional effort later to go back to the places you passed by on your first reading. And even if you never go back, understanding half of a really tough book is much better than not understanding it at all, which will be the case if you allow yourself to be stopped by the first difficult passage you come to.

我们大多数人都被教导要注意我们不理解的事情。当我们遇到一个不熟悉的词时，我们被告知要查字典。当我们遇到我们不理解的典故或陈述时，我们被告知要去看百科全书或其他参考书。我们被告知要查阅脚注、学术评论或其他二手资料以获得帮助。但这些事情做得太早，只会阻碍我们的阅读，而不是帮助我们阅读。

Most of us were taught to pay attention to the things we did not understand. We were told to go to a dictionary when we met an unfamiliar word. We were told to go to an encyclopedia or some other reference work when we were confronted with allusions or statements we did not comprehend. We were told to consult footnotes, scholarly commentaries, or other secondary sources to get help. But when these things are done prematurely, they only impede our reading, instead of helping it.

例如，阅读莎士比亚的巨大乐趣被一代又一代的高中生宠坏了，他们被迫逐个场景地阅读《凯撒大帝》、《皆大欢喜》或《哈姆雷特》 ，查找所有奇怪的单词词汇表和研究所有的学术脚注。结果，他们从未真正读过莎士比亚的戏剧。当他们到达终点时，他们已经忘记了起点，也看不到整体。与其被迫采取这种迂腐的方法，不如鼓励他们一次性阅读剧本，并讨论他们从第一次快速阅读中得到了什么。只有到那时，他们才会准备好仔细、仔细地研究戏剧，因为那时他们就会对它有足够的了解，从而学到更多。

The tremendous pleasure that can come from reading Shakespeare, for instance, was spoiled for generations of high school students who were forced to go through Julius Caesar, As You Like It, or Hamlet, scene by scene, looking up all the strange words in a glossary and studying all the scholarly footnotes. As a result, they never really read a Shakespearean play. By the time they reached the end, they had forgotten the beginning and lost sight of the whole. Instead of being forced to take this pedantic approach, they should have been encouraged to read the play at one sitting and discuss what they got out of that first quick reading. Only then would they have been ready to study the play carefully and closely because then they would have understood enough of it to learn more.

该规则同样适用于说明性作品。在这里，的确，规则正确性的最好证明——给出一本书的第一次粗略阅读——是当你不去读它时会发生的事情。以经济学的基础著作为例，比如亚当·斯密的经典著作《国富论》。（我们选择这本书作为示例，因为它不仅仅是一本教科书或该领域专家的作品。它是一本面向一般人的书读者。）如果你坚持在继续阅读下一页之前理解每一页上的所有内容，你将不会走得太远。在你努力掌握细节的过程中，你会错过斯密非常清楚地阐述的关于工资、租金、利润和利息等因素的重要观点，这些因素会影响事物的成本，市场在决定价格中的作用，垄断的罪恶，自由贸易的理由。你会只见树木不见森林。你在任何层面上都不会读得很好。

The rule applies with equal force to expository works. Here, indeed, the best proof of the soundness of the rule—give a book a first superficial reading—is what happens when you do not follow it. Take a basic work in economics, for example, such as Adam Smith’s classic The Wealth of Nations. (We choose this book as an example because it is more than a textbook or a work for specialists in the field. It is a book for the general reader.) If you insist on understanding everything on every page before you go on to the next, you will not get very far. In your effort to master the fine points, you will miss the big points that Smith makes so clearly about the factors of wages, rents, profits, and interest that enter into the cost of things, the role of the market in determining prices, the evils of monopoly, the reasons for free trade. You will miss the forest for the trees. You will not be reading well on any level.

关于阅读速度

On Reading Speeds

 

我们在第 2 章中将检视阅读描述为在有限的时间内充分利用一本书的艺术。在本章进一步描述它时，我们并没有改变这个定义。检视阅读的两个步骤都很快。有能力的审阅者会很快完成这两个任务，不管他试图阅读的书有多长或多难。

We described inspectional reading in Chapter 2 as the art of getting the most out of a book in a limited time. In describing it further in the present chapter, we have in no way changed that definition. The two steps involved in inspectional reading are both taken rapidly. The competent inspectional reader will accomplish them both quickly, no matter how long or difficult the book he is trying to read.

然而，这个可行的定义不可避免地提出了一个问题，速读呢？阅读水平与当今提供的许多学术和商业速读课程之间的关系是什么？

That working definition, however, inevitably raises the question, What about speed reading? What is the relation between the levels of reading and the many speed reading courses, both academic and commercial, that are offered at the present day?

我们已经提出，此类课程基本上是补救性的——也就是说，它们主要（如果不是唯一的话）提供初级阅读方面的指导。但还需要说更多。

We have already suggested that such courses are basically remedial—that is, that they provide instruction mainly, if not exclusively, in reading on the elementary level. But more needs to be said.

让我们立即理解，我们完全赞成大多数人应该能够比他们阅读得更快的命题。很多时候，有些东西我们必须阅读真的不值得花很多时间阅读；如果我们不能快速阅读它们，那将是对时间的极大浪费。的确，很多人读某些东西太慢，他们应该读得更快。但是很多人也有些东西读得太快了，他们应该把那些东西读得慢一点。因此，一个好的速读课程应该教你以多种不同的速度阅读，而不仅仅是一种比你现在能做到的任何速度都快的速度。它应该能让你根据材料的性质和复杂性来改变你的阅读速度。

Let it be understood at once that we are wholly in favor of the proposition that most people ought to be able to read faster than they do. Too often, there are things we have to read that are not really worth spending a lot of time reading; if we cannot read them quickly, it will be a terrible waste of time. It is true enough that many people read some things too slowly, and that they ought to read them faster. But many people also read some things too fast, and they ought to read those things more slowly. A good speed reading course should therefore teach you to read at many different speeds, not just one speed that is faster than anything you can manage now. It should enable you to vary your rate of reading in accordance with the nature and complexity of the material.

我们的观点真的很简单。许多书几乎不值得略读；有些应该快速阅读；还有一些应该以允许完全理解的速度阅读，通常很慢。一本只值得快速阅读的书，慢慢阅读是一种浪费；速读技巧可以帮助你解决这个问题。但这只是一个阅读问题。阻碍理解一本难懂的书的障碍通常不是生理上的或心理上的，也许从来不是主要的。它们的出现是因为读者在接近一本困难但有益的书时根本不知道该怎么做。他不知道阅读的规则；他不知道如何调动他的智力资源来完成这项任务。无论他阅读多快，如果他经常这样做，他也不会过得更好，

Our point is really very simple. Many books are hardly worth even skimming; some should be read quickly; and a few should be read at a rate, usually quite slow, that allows for complete comprehension. It is wasteful to read a book slowly that deserves only a fast reading; speed reading skills can help you solve that problem. But this is only one reading problem. The obstacles that stand in the way of comprehension of a difficult book are not ordinarily, and perhaps never primarily, physiological or psychological. They arise because the reader simply does not know what to do when approaching a difficult —and rewarding—book. He does not know the rules of reading; he does not know how to marshal his intellectual resources for the task. No matter how quickly he reads, he will be no better off if, as is too often true, he does not know what he is looking for and does not know when he has found it.

那么，关于阅读速度，理想的不仅是能够阅读得更快，而且能够以不同的速度阅读——并且知道不同的速度何时是合适的。检视阅读完成得很快，但这不仅是因为你读得更快，尽管事实上你是这样做的；这也是因为当你对一本书进行检查性阅读时，你读的书较少，而且你以不同的方式阅读它，带着不同的目标。分析阅读通常比检查阅读慢得多，但即使你对一本书进行分析阅读，你也不应该以同样的速度阅读所有的书。每一本书，无论有多难，包含可以而且应该快速阅读的间隙材料；每本好书都包含一些难点，应该慢慢读。

With regard to rates of reading, then, the ideal is not merely to be able to read faster, but to be able to read at different speeds— and to know when the different speeds are appropriate. Inspectional reading is accomplished quickly, but that is not only because you read faster, although in fact you do; it is also because you read less of a book when you give it an inspectional reading, and because you read it in a different way, with different goals in mind. Analytical reading is ordinarily much slower than inspectional reading, but even when you are giving a book an analytical reading, you should not read all of it at the same rate of speed. Every book, no matter how difficult, contains interstitial material that can be and should be read quickly; and every good book also contains matter that is difficult and should be read very slowly.

固定和回归

Fixations and Regressions

 

速读课程充分利用了这一发现——我们已经知道半个世纪或更长时间了——大多数人在第一次学习阅读后会继续发声多年。此外，眼球运动影片显示，年轻或未受过训练的读者在阅读每一行时，眼睛会“注视”多达五六次。（眼睛在移动时是盲目的；它只有在停止时才能看到。）因此，一次读取单个单词或最多两个单词或三个单词的短语，跳过一行。更糟糕的是，不称职的读者的眼睛经常每两三行就会退缩一次——也就是说，他们会回到之前读过的短语或句子。

Speed reading courses properly make much of the discovery—we have known it for half a century or more—that most people continue to sub-vocalize for years after they are first taught to read. Films of eye movements, furthermore, show that the eyes of young or untrained readers “fixate” as many as five or six times in the course of each line that is read. (The eye is blind while it moves; it can only see when it stops.) Thus single words or at the most two-word or three-word phrases are being read at a time, in jumps across the line. Even worse than that, the eyes of incompetent readers regress as often as once every two or three lines—that is, they return to phrases or sentences previously read.

所有这些习惯都是浪费，显然会降低阅读速度。它们很浪费，因为与眼睛不同，头脑不需要一次只“阅读”一个单词或短语。头脑，这种令人惊叹的工具，可以“一眼”抓住一个句子甚至一个段落——如果只有眼睛能为它提供它需要的信息的话。因此，首要任务——所有速读课程都承认这一点——是纠正让许多读者放慢速度的固着和退步。幸运的是，这可以很容易地完成。一旦完成，学生可以按照他的思维让他快速阅读，而不是像他的眼睛让他慢。

All of these habits are wasteful and obviously cut down reading speed. They are wasteful because the mind, unlike the eye, does not need to “read” only a word or short phrase at a time. The mind, that astounding instrument, can grasp a sentence or even a paragraph at a “glance”—if only the eyes will provide it with the information it needs. Thus the primary task—recognized as such by all speed reading courses—is to correct the fixations and regressions that slow so many readers down. Fortunately, this can be done quite easily. Once it is done, the student can read as fast as his mind will let him, not as slow as his eyes make him.

有多种设备可以打破眼睛注视，其中一些设备复杂且昂贵。然而，通常没有必要使用任何比您自己的手更复杂的设备，您可以训练自己跟随它在页面上越来越快地移动。你可以自己做。将拇指和前两个手指放在一起。将这个“指针”扫过一行字，速度要快于眼睛移动的舒适度。强迫自己跟上你的手。随着手的移动，您很快就能读出单词。继续练习，并不断提高手的移动速度，不知不觉中，您的阅读速度就会提高一倍或三倍。

There are various devices for breaking the eye fixations, some of them complicated and expensive. Usually, however, it is not necessary to employ any device more sophisticated than your own hand, which you can train yourself to follow as it moves more and more quickly across and down the page. You can do this yourself. Place your thumb and first two fingers together. Sweep this “pointer” across a line of type, a little faster than it is comfortable for your eyes to move. Force yourself to keep up with your hand. You will very soon be able to read the words as you follow your hand. Keep practicing this, and keep increasing the speed at which your hand moves, and before you know it you will have doubled or trebled your reading speed.

理解力问题

The Problem of Comprehension

 

但是，如果你显着提高阅读速度，你究竟有什么收获呢？的确，你节省了时间——但理解力呢？这是否也增加了，或者在此过程中受到了影响？

But what exactly have you gained if you increase your reading speed significantly? It is true that you have saved time —but what about comprehension? Has that also increased, or has it suffered in the process?

据我们所知，没有一种速读课程不声称能够提高您的理解力和阅读速度。总的来说，这些说法可能有一定的基础。用作计时器的手（或其他设备）不仅可以提高您的阅读速度，还可以提高您对阅读内容的注意力。只要你跟着你的手走，就很难入睡、做白日梦、让你的思绪漫游。到目前为止，一切都很好。专注是我们所说的阅读活动的另一个名称。好的读者会积极地、全神贯注地阅读。

There is no speed reading course that we know of that does not claim to be able to increase your comprehension along with your reading speed. And on the whole, there is probably some foundation for these claims. The hand (or some other device) used as a timer tends not only to increase your reading rate, but also to improve your concentration on what you are reading. As long as you are following your hand it is harder to fall asleep, to daydream, to let your mind wander. So far, so good. Concentration is another name for what we have called activity in reading. The good reader reads actively, with concentration.

但是，当正确理解时，仅靠专注并不能真正对理解产生太大影响。理解不仅仅是能够回答有关文本的简单事实问题。事实上，这种有限的理解不过是回答关于一本书或其他阅读材料的问题的基本能力：“它说什么？” 许多进一步的问题，如果回答正确，意味着更高的理解水平，在速读课程中很少被问到，也很少给出如何回答这些问题的指导。

But concentration alone does not really have much of an effect on comprehension, when that is properly understood. Comprehension involves much more than merely being able to answer simple questions of fact about a text. This limited kind of comprehension, in fact, is nothing but the elementary ability to answer the question about a book or other reading material: “What does it say?” The many further questions that, when correctly answered, imply higher levels of comprehension are seldom asked in speed reading courses, and instruction in how to answer them is seldom given.

为了更清楚地说明这一点，让我们举一个阅读的例子。让我们以《独立宣言》为例。您可能有它的副本。拿下来看看。打印时占用不到三页。你应该多快阅读它？

To make this clearer, let us take an example of something to read. Let us take the Declaration of Independence. You probably have a copy of it available. Take it down and look at it. It occupies less than three pages when printed. How fast should you read it?

宣言第二段以一句话结尾：“为了证明这一点，让事实被提交给一个坦诚的世界。” 下面两页的“事实”，顺便说一句，其中一些非常可疑，可以快速阅读。对杰斐逊所引用的事实的大致了解是没有必要的，当然，除非你是一位关注他写作所处的历史环境的学者。即使是最后一段，以签名者“相互保证我们的生命、我们的财富和我们的神圣荣誉”这一名副其实的声明结尾，也可以快速阅读。这是一种修辞上的繁荣，它应得的只是修辞总是应得的。但《独立宣言》的前两段需要的不仅仅是快速阅读。

The second paragraph of the Declaration ends with the sentence: “To prove this, let facts be submitted to a candid world.” The following two pages of “facts,” some of which, incidentally, are quite dubious, can be read quickly. It is not necessary to gain more than a general idea of the kind of facts that Jefferson is citing, unless, of course, you are a scholar concerned with the historical circumstances in which he wrote. Even the last paragraph, ending with the justly celebrated statement that the signers “mutually pledge to each other our lives, our fortunes, and our sacred honour,” can be read quickly. This is a rhetorical flourish, and it deserves what mere rhetoric always deserves. But the first two paragraphs of the Declaration of Independence require more than a first rapid reading.

我们怀疑是否有人能够以超过每分钟 20 个单词的速度阅读前两段。的确，著名的第二段中的个别词——如“不可剥夺”、“权利”、“自由”、“幸福”、“同意”、“正义权力”——值得仔细思考、疑惑和仔细考虑。正确阅读《宣言》的前两段可能需要数天、数周甚至数年才能完全理解。

We doubt that there is anyone who can read those first two paragraphs at a rate much faster than 20 words a minute. Indeed, individual words in the famous second paragraph-words like “inalienable,” “rights,” “liberty,” “happiness,” “consent,” “just powers”—are worth dwelling over, puzzling about, considering at length. Properly read, for full comprehension, those first two paragraphs of the Declaration might require days, or weeks, or even years.

那么速读的问题就是理解的问题。实际上，这归结为在初级以外的层次上定义理解。在大多数情况下，速读课程不会尝试这样做。因此，值得强调的是，本书力求提高的正是阅读理解能力。如果不分析地阅读一本书，你就无法理解它；正如我们所指出的，分析阅读主要是为了理解（或理解）。

The problem of speed reading, then, is the problem of comprehension. Practically, this comes down to defining comprehension at levels beyond the elementary. Speed reading courses, for the most part, do not attempt this. It is worth emphasizing, therefore, that it is precisely comprehension in reading that this book seeks to improve. You cannot comprehend a book without reading it analytically; analytical reading, as we have noted, is undertaken primarily for the sake of comprehension (or understanding).

检视阅读总结

Summary of Inspectional Reading

 

几句话总结一下这一章。没有一个正确的阅读速度。以各种速度阅读并知道每种速度何时合适的能力是理想的。阅读速度快是一项可疑的成就；只有当你必须阅读的东西不值得阅读时，它才有价值。一个更好的公式是：每本书的阅读速度都不应超过其应有的速度，并且速度不应超过您可以满意和理解地阅读它的速度。无论如何，他们阅读的速度，无论快慢，都只是大多数人阅读问题的一小部分。

A few words in summary of this chapter. There is no single right speed at which you should read; the ability to read at various speeds and to know when each speed is appropriate is the ideal. Great speed in reading is a dubious achievement; it is of value only if what you have to read is not really worth reading. A better formula is this: Every book should be read no more slowly than it deserves, and no more quickly than you can read it with satisfaction and comprehension. In any event, the speed at which they read, be it fast or slow, is but a fractional part of most people’s problem with reading.

略读或预读一本书总是一个好主意；当您不知道手头的这本书是否值得仔细阅读时（通常是这种情况），这是必要的。你会通过浏览它来发现它。通常，即使您打算仔细阅读一本书，也需要略读一下，以了解其形式和结构。

Skimming or pre-reading a book is always a good idea; it is necessary when you do not know, as is often the case, whether the book you have in hand is worth reading carefully. You will find that out by skimming it. It is generally desirable to skim even a book that you intend to read carefully, to get some idea of its form and structure.

最后，不要试图在第一次读完一本难懂的书时就理解每一个字或每一页。这是最重要的规则；这是检视阅读的精髓。不要害怕成为或看起来是肤浅的。通读最难的书。然后，您将准备好第二次阅读它。

Finally, do not try to understand every word or page of a difficult book the first time through. This is the most important rule of all; it is the essence of inspectional reading. Do not be afraid to be, or to seem to be, superficial. Race through even the hardest book. You will then be prepared to read it well the second time.

我们现在已经完成了对阅读的第二个层次——检视阅读的初步讨论。当我们来到第四部分时，我们将回到这个主题，在那里我们将展示检视阅读在主题阅读中的重要作用，主题阅读是第四种也是最高层次的阅读。

We have now completed our initial discussion of the second level of reading—inspectional reading. We will return to the subject when we come to Part Four, where we will show what an important role inspectional reading plays in syntopical reading, the fourth and highest level of reading.

然而，在我们讨论本书第二部分描述的第三个阅读层次——分析阅读——时，你应该记住，检视阅读在那个层次上也起着重要的作用。检查阅读的两个阶段都可以被认为是读者在分析阅读时所采取的步骤的预期。检查阅读的第一阶段——我们称之为系统略读的阶段——用于让分析型读者准备好回答该级别第一阶段必须提出的问题。换句话说，系统略读预示着对一本书结构的理解。而第二阶段的检视阅读——我们称之为浅读的阶段——服务于读者进入第二阶段分析层面的阅读。浅读是理解一本书内容的第一步。

However, you should keep in mind during our discussion of the third level of reading—analytical reading—which is described in the second part of this book, that inspectional reading serves an important function at that level, too. The two stages of inspectional reading can both be thought of as anticipations of steps that the reader takes when he reads analytically. The first stage of inspectional reading—the stage we have called systematic skimming—serves to prepare the analytical reader to answer the questions that must be asked during the first stage of that level. Systematic skimming, in other words, anticipates the comprehension of a book’s structure. And the second stage of inspectional reading—the stage we have called superficial reading—serves the reader when he comes to the second stage of reading at the analytical level. Superficial reading is the first necessary step in the interpretation of a book’s contents.

在继续解释分析阅读之前，我们想暂停一下，再次考虑阅读作为一项活动的本质。活跃或要求苛刻的读者必须执行某些操作才能读好。我们将在下一章讨论它们。

Before going on to explain analytical reading, we want to pause for a moment to consider again the nature of reading as an activity. There are certain actions the active or demanding reader must perform in order to read well. We will discuss them in the next chapter.

5

如何成为一个苛刻的读者

5HOW TO BE A DEMANDING READER

 

阅读自己入睡的规则比阅读时保持清醒的规则更容易遵守。找个舒服的姿势上床，确保光线不至于造成轻微的眼睛疲劳，选择一本要么非常难，要么非常无聊的书——总之，一本你根本不在乎读不读的书——几分钟后你就会睡着了。擅长读书放松的人，不必等到夜幕降临。图书馆里一把舒适的椅子随时都可以。

The rules for reading yourself to sleep are easier to follow than are the rules for staying awake while reading. Get into bed in a comfortable position, make sure the light is inadequate enough to cause a slight eyestrain, choose a book that is either terribly difficult or terribly boring—in any event, one that you do not really care whether you read or not—and you will be asleep in a few minutes. Those who are experts in relaxing with a book do not have to wait for nightfall. A comfortable chair in the library will do any time.

不幸的是，保持清醒的规则并不在于反其道而行之。在舒适的椅子上什至在床上阅读时都可以保持清醒，众所周知，人们在太暗的光线下阅读到很晚会使眼睛疲劳。是什么让著名的烛光读者保持清醒？有一件事是肯定的——这对他们产生了影响，非常大的影响，无论他们是否阅读手头的书。

Unfortunately, the rules for keeping awake do not consist in doing just the opposite. It is possible to keep awake while reading in a comfortable chair or even in bed, and people have been known to strain their eyes by reading late in light too dim. What kept the famous candlelight readers awake? One thing certainly—it made a difference to them, a great difference, whether or not they read the book they had in hand.

您能否保持清醒在很大程度上取决于您的阅读目标。如果你阅读的目的是从中获益——在思想或精神上以某种方式成长——你就必须保持清醒。这意味着尽可能积极地阅读。它意味着付出努力——一种你期望得到回报的努力。

Whether you manage to keep awake or not depends in large part on your goal in reading. If your aim in reading is to profit from it—to grow somehow in mind or spirit—you have to keep awake. That means reading as actively as possible. It means making an effort—an effort for which you expect to be repaid.

好书，无论是小说还是非小说，都值得这样阅读。用一本好书作为镇静剂是一种明显的浪费。睡着了，或者，同样的，让你的思绪在你计划投入阅读以获利的时间里走神——也就是说，主要是为了理解——显然会打败你自己的目的。

Good books, fiction or nonfiction, deserve such reading. To use a good book as a sedative is conspicuous waste. To fall asleep or, what is the same, to let your mind wander during the hours you planned to devote to reading for profit—that is, primarily for understanding—is clearly to defeat your own ends.

但可悲的事实是，许多能够区分利润和愉悦的人——一方面是理解，另一方面是娱乐或仅仅是满足好奇心——却无法执行他们的阅读计划。即使他们知道哪些书给出了哪些，他们也会失败。原因是他们不知道如何要求读者，如何让他们的注意力集中在他们正在做的事情上，让他们完成没有利润就无法赚取的工作。

But the sad fact is that many people who can distinguish between profit and pleasure—between understanding, on the one hand, and entertainment or the mere satisfaction of curiosity, on the other hand—nevertheless fail to carry out their reading plans. They fail even if they know which books give which. The reason is that they do not know how to be demanding readers, how to keep their mind on what they are doing by making it do the work without which no profit can be earned.

主动阅读的本质：读者提出的四个基本问题

The Essence of Active Reading: The Four Basic Questions a Reader Asks

 

我们已经在本书中广泛讨论了主动阅读。我们说过主动阅读是更好的阅读，我们也注意到检视阅读总是主动的。这是一项需要付出努力，而不是毫不费力的事业。但是，我们还没有通过陈述积极阅读的一个简单处方来触及问题的核心。它是：边读边问问题——你自己必须在阅读过程中尝试回答的问题。

We have already discussed active reading extensively in this book. We have said that active reading is better reading, and we have noted that inspectional reading is always active. It is an effortful, not an effortless, undertaking. But we have not yet gone to the heart of the matter by stating the one simple prescription for active reading. It is: Ask questions while you read—questions that you yourself must try to answer in the course of reading.

任何问题？不。初级以上任何级别的阅读艺术都在于养成以正确的顺序提出正确的问题的习惯。关于任何一本书，你必须问四个主要问题。*

Any questions? No. The art of reading on any level above the elementary consists in the habit of asking the right questions in the right order. There are four main questions you must ask about any book.*

1.整本书讲的是什么？你必须尝试发现这本书的主题，以及作者如何通过将其细分为基本的从属主题或主题，以有序的方式发展该主题。

1. WHAT IS THE BOOK ABOUT AS A WHOLE? You must try to discover the leading theme of the book, and how the author develops this theme in an orderly way by subdividing it into its essential subordinate themes or topics.

2.详细说明了什么，如何说明？你必须尝试发现构成作者特定信息的主要思想、断言和论点。

2. WHAT IS BEING SAID IN DETAIL, AND HOW? You must try to discover the main ideas, assertions, and arguments that constitute the author’s particular message.

3. 这本书是全部还是部分真实的？在回答前两个问题之前，您无法回答这个问题。你必须先知道对方在说什么，然后才能决定它是真是假。然而，当你读懂一本书时，如果你认真阅读，你就有义务做出自己的决定。知道作者的心思是不够的。

3. Is THE BOOK TRUE, IN WHOLE OR PART? You cannot answer this question until you have answered the first two. You have to know what is being said before you can decide whether it is true or not. When you understand a book, however, you are obligated, if you are reading seriously, to make up your own mind. Knowing the author’s mind is not enough.

4.它是什么？如果这本书给了你信息，你必须问问它的意义。为什么作者认为了解这些事情很重要？了解他们对你很重要吗？如果这本书不仅告诉了你，而且启发了你，那么有必要通过询问接下来还有什么，进一步暗示或建议什么来寻求进一步的启发。

4. WHAT OF IT? If the book has given you information, you must ask about its significance. Why does the author think it is important to know these things? Is it important to you to know them? And if the book has not only informed you, but also enlightened you, it is necessary to seek further enlightenment by asking what else follows, what is further implied or suggested.

我们将在本书的其余部分详细讨论这四个问题。换句话说，它们成为第二部分主要关注的阅读基本规则。他们在这里以问题的形式陈述是有充分理由的。阅读超出初级水平的任何级别的书，本质上都是您努力提出问题（并尽您最大的能力回答问题）。永远不应忘记这一点。这就是为什么要求苛刻的读者和要求不高的读者之间存在世界上所有差异的原因。后者不问问题——也得不到答案。

We will return to these four questions at length in the rest of this book. Stated another way, they become the basic rules of reading with which Part Two is mainly concerned. They are stated here in question form for a very good reason. Reading a book on any level beyond the elementary is essentially an effort on your part to ask it questions (and to answer them to the best of your ability). That should never be forgotten. And that is why there is all the difference in the world between the demanding and the undemanding reader. The latter asks no questions—and gets no answers.

上述四个问题总结了读者的全部义务。它们适用于任何值得一读的东西——一本书、一篇文章甚至一则广告。检视阅读往往能为前两个问题提供比后两个问题更准确的答案，但它仍然有帮助同者也。除非你对最后这些问题有答案——除非你对这本书的全部或部分真相及其意义有所了解，如果只是在你自己的事物体系中，那么对一本书的分析性阅读就不算圆满。最后一个问题——它是什么？——可能是主题阅读中最重要的一个问题。当然，在尝试最后一个问题之前，您必须先回答前三个问题。

The four questions stated above summarize the whole obligation of a reader. They apply to anything worth reading —a book or an article or even an advertisement. Inspectional reading tends to provide more accurate answers to the first two questions than to the last two, but it nevertheless helps with those also. An analytical reading of a book has not been accomplished satisfactorily until you have answers to those last questions—until you have some idea of the book’s truth, in whole or part, and of its significance, if only in your own scheme of things. The last question—What of it?—is probably the most important one in syntopical reading. Naturally, you will have to answer the first three questions before attempting the final one.

知道这四个问题是什么是不够的。你一定要记得在阅读时问他们。这样做的习惯是要求苛刻的读者的标志。不仅如此，您还必须知道如何准确准确地回答他们。训练有素的能力就是阅读的艺术。

Knowing what the four questions are is not enough. You must remember to ask them as you read. The habit of doing that is the mark of a demanding reader. More than that, you must know how to answer them precisely and accurately. The trained ability to do that is the art of reading.

人们为好书而入睡，不是因为他们不愿意努力，而是因为他们不知道如何努力。好书在你头上；如果他们不这样做，他们就不会对你有好处。除非你能达到它们并将自己提升到它们的水平，否则你头上的书会让你感到疲倦。让您感到疲倦的不是拉伸，而是因为您缺乏有效拉伸的技巧而导致拉伸失败的挫败感。要继续积极阅读，你不仅要有这样做的意愿，还要有技巧——一种使你能够通过掌握乍看之下似乎无法超越的东西来提升自己的艺术。

People go to sleep over good books not because they are unwilling to make the effort, but because they do not know how to make it. Good books are over your head; they would not be good for you if they were not. And books that are over your head weary you unless you can reach up to them and pull yourself up to their level. It is not the stretching that tires you, but the frustration of stretching unsuccessfully because you lack the skill to stretch effectively. To keep on reading actively, you must have not only the will to do so, but also the skill—the art that enables you to elevate yourself by mastering what at first sight seems to be beyond you.

如何制作自己的书

How to Make a Book Your Own

 

如果你有边看书边提问的习惯，你会比不这样做时更善于阅读。但是，正如我们已经指出的，仅仅提出问题是不够的。你必须尝试回答他们。虽然从理论上讲，这只能在您的脑海中完成，但用手中的铅笔来完成要容易得多。当你阅读时，铅笔就会成为你警觉的标志。

If you have the habit of asking a book questions as you read, you are a better reader than if you do not. But, as we have indicated, merely asking questions is not enough. You have to try to answer them. And although that could be done, theoretically, in your mind only, it is much easier to do it with a pencil in your hand. The pencil then becomes the sign of your alertness while you read.

俗话说，你必须“阅读之间行”以充分利用任何东西。阅读规则是一种正式的表达方式。但我们也想说服您“在字里行间写下”。除非你这样做，否则你不可能进行最有效的阅读。

It is an old saying that you have to “read between the lines” to get the most out of anything. The rules of reading are a formal way of saying this. But we want to persuade you to “write between the lines,” too. Unless you do, you are not likely to do the most efficient kind of reading.

当你购买一本书时，你就在其中确立了财产权，就像你购买衣服或家具并付款时所做的那样。但购买行为实际上只是拥有一本书的前奏。只有当你把它变成你自己的一部分时，你才能完全拥有一本书，而让你自己成为其中一部分的最好方法——这也是一样的——就是在里面写作。

When you buy a book, you establish a property right in it, just as you do in clothes or furniture when you buy and pay for them. But the act of purchase is actually only the prelude to possession in the case of a book. Full ownership of a book only comes when you have made it a part of yourself, and the best way to make yourself a part of it—which comes to the same thing—is by writing in it.

为什么标记一本书对于阅读它是不可或缺的？首先，它让你保持清醒——不仅是有意识的，而且是完全清醒的。其次，阅读，如果它是主动的，就是思考，而思考倾向于用文字、口头或书面形式来表达自己。说他知道自己在想什么但不能表达出来的人通常不知道他在想什么。第三，写下你的反应有助于你记住作者的想法。

Why is marking a book indispensable to reading it? First, it keeps you awake—not merely conscious, but wide awake. Second, reading, if it is active, is thinking, and thinking tends to express itself in words, spoken or written. The person who says he knows what he thinks but cannot express it usually does not know what he thinks. Third, writing your reactions down helps you to remember the thoughts of the author.

阅读一本书应该是你和作者之间的对话。大概他比你更了解这个主题；如果没有，您可能不应该为他的书而烦恼。但是理解是双向的。学习者必须质疑自己并质疑老师。一旦他听懂了老师的话，他甚至不得不愿意与老师争论。标记一本书实际上是表达您与作者的分歧或同意。这是你能给予他的最高尊重。

Reading a book should be a conversation between you and the author. Presumably he knows more about the subject than you do; if not, you probably should not be bothering with his book. But understanding is a two-way operation; the learner has to question himself and question the teacher. He even has to be willing to argue with the teacher, once he understands what the teacher is saying. Marking a book is literally an expression of your differences or your agreements with the author. It is the highest respect you can pay him.

有各种各样的设备可以智能而富有成效地标记一本书。以下是一些可以使用的设备：

There are all kinds of devices for marking a book intelligently and fruitfully. Here are some devices that can be used:

1.下划线——要点；重要或有力的陈述。

1. UNDERLINING—of major points; of important or forceful statements.

2.竖线在页边——强调已经划线的陈述或指向一段太长而不能划线的段落。

2. VERTICAL LINES AT THE MARGIN—to emphasize a statement already underlined or to point to a passage too long to be underlined.

3.星号、星号或页边空白处的其他装饰物——谨慎使用，强调本书中十个或十几个最重要的陈述或段落。您可能需要将每页的一角折叠起来，或者在页面之间放一张纸条。在任何一种情况下，您都可以随时将书从书架上取下来，打开指定的页面，刷新您的回忆。

3. STAR, ASTERISK, OR OTHER DOODAD AT THE MARGIN—to be used sparingly, to emphasize the ten or dozen most important statements or passages in the book. You may want to fold a corner of each page on which you make such marks or place a slip of paper between the pages. In either case, you will be able to take the book off the shelf at any time and, by opening it to the indicated page, refresh your recollection.

4.空白处的数字——表明作者在论证过程中提出的一系列观点。

4. NUMBERS IN THE MARGIN—to indicate a sequence of points made by the author in developing an argument.

5.页边空白处的其他页数——指出作者在书中其他地方提出了相同的观点，或与此处标记的观点相关或矛盾的观点；将思想集中在一本书中，尽管它们可能被许多页隔开，但它们是一体的。许多读者使用符号“Cf”来表示其他页码；它的意思是“比较”或“参考”。

5. NUMBERS OF OTHER PAGES IN THE MARGIN—to indicate where else in the book the author makes the same points, or points relevant to or in contradiction of those here marked; to tie up the ideas in a book, which, though they may be separated by many pages, belong together. Many readers use the symbol “Cf” to indicate the other page numbers; it means “compare” or “refer to.”

6.圈出关键词或短语——这与加下划线的功能大致相同。

6. CIRCLING OF KEY WORDS OR PHRASES—This serves much the same function as underlining.

7.在页边空白处、页首或页底写字——记录一段文章在你脑海中提出的问题（也许还有答案）；将复杂的讨论简化为简单的陈述；通过本书记录主要观点的顺序。书后的尾页可用于按出现顺序为作者的观点制作个人索引。

7. WRITING IN THE MARGIN, OR AT THE TOP OR BOTTOM OF THE PAGE—to record questions (and perhaps answers) which a passage raises in your mind; to reduce a complicated discussion to a simple statement; to record the sequence of major points right through the book. The endpapers at the back of the book can be used to make a personal index of the author’s points in the order of their appearance.

对于顽固的书签，前端的尾页通常是最重要的。有些人将它们保留为精美的藏书票。但这仅表示他们对这本书的财务所有权。最好保留前端文件以记录您的想法。读完这本书并在封底纸上制作好个人索引后，翻到前面，试着勾勒出这本书的大纲，而不是逐页或逐点（您已经在后面完成了），但作为一个集成结构，具有基本轮廓和零件顺序。该大纲将衡量您对作品的理解程度；与藏书票不同，它将表达您对这本书的知识所有权。

To inveterate book-markers, the front endpapers are often the most important. Some people reserve them for a fancy bookplate. But that expresses only their financial ownership of the book. The front endpapers are better reserved for a record of your thinking. After finishing the book and making your personal index on the back endpapers, turn to the front and try to outline the book, not page by page or point by point (you have already done that at the back), but as an integrated structure, with a basic outline and an order of parts. That outline will be the measure of your understanding of the work; unlike a bookplate, it will express your intellectual ownership of the book.

三种笔记法

The Three Kinds of Note-making

 

您将在书中以及关于它们的笔记中做三种截然不同的笔记。您制作哪种取决于您的阅读水平。

There are three quite different kinds of notes that you will make in your books as well as about them. Which kind you make depends upon the level at which you are reading.

当你对一本书进行检查性阅读时，你可能没有太多时间在其中做笔记；正如我们所观察到的，检视阅读总是有时间限制的。然而，当你在这个层次上阅读一本书时，你是在问一些关于这本书的重要问题，当你的答案在你脑海中浮现时，最好记录下你的答案，即使这并不总是可能的。

When you give a book an inspectional reading, you may not have much time to make notes in it; inspectional reading, as we have observed, is always limited as to time. Nevertheless, you are asking important questions about a book when you read it at this level, and it would be desirable, even if it is not always possible, to record your answers when they are fresh in your mind.

检视阅读回答的问题是：第一，这本书是什么书？第二，它整体上讲的是什么？第三，作品的结构顺序是什么，作者据以发展他对该一般主题的概念或理解？你可以而且很可能应该对你对这些问题的回答做笔记，特别是如果你知道可能需要几天或几个月的时间才能回到这本书进行分析阅读。做此类注释的最佳位置是在目录页上，或者可能在标题页上，这些在我们上面概述的方案中是未使用的。

The questions answered by inspectional reading are: first, what kind of book is it? second, what is it about as a whole? and third, what is the structural order of the work whereby the author develops his conception or understanding of that general subject matter? You may and probably should make notes concerning your answers to these questions, especially if you know that it may be days or months before you will be able to return to the book to give it an analytical reading. The best place to make such notes is on the contents page, or perhaps on the title page, which are otherwise unused in the scheme we have outlined above.

要认识到的一点是，这些注释主要涉及本书的结构，而不是其内容——至少不是细节。因此，我们称这种笔记为结构性的。

The point to recognize is that these notes primarily concern the structure of the book, and not its substance—at least not in detail. We therefore call this kind of note-making structural.

在检视阅读的过程中，尤其是阅读一本又长又难的书，你可能会获得一些洞察力作者关于他的主题的想法。然而，通常你不会；当然，在您更仔细地阅读本书之前，您应该推迟对陈述的准确性或真实性做出任何判断。然后，在分析阅读期间，您需要回答有关本书的真实性和意义的问题。因此，你在这个阅读层次上做的笔记不是结构性的而是概念性的。它们关系到作者的概念，也关系到你自己的概念，因为它们在你阅读本书时得到了加深或扩展。

In the course of an inspectional reading, especially of a long and difficult book, you may attain some insights into the author’s ideas about his subject matter. Often, however, you will not; and certainly you should put off making any judgment of the accuracy or truth of the statements until you have read the book more carefully. Then, during an analytical reading, you will need to give answers to questions about the truth and significance of the book. The notes you make at this level of reading are, therefore, not structural but conceptual. They concern the author’s concepts, and also your own, as they have been deepened or broadened by your reading of the book.

结构笔记和概念笔记之间有明显的区别。当你对几本书进行主题阅读时——当你在一个主题上阅读不止一本书时，你会做什么样的笔记？同样，此类注释往往是概念性的；页面上的注释不仅可以将您引向该书中的其他页面，还可以引向其他书中的页面。

There is an obvious difference between structural and conceptual note-making. What kind of notes do you make when you are giving several books a syntopical reading—when you are reading more than one book on a single subject? Again, such notes will tend to be conceptual; and the notes on a page may refer you not only to other pages in that book, but also to pages in other books.

然而，甚至还不止于此，真正的专家读者在按主题阅读几本书时可以做到这一点。那就是对讨论的形式做笔记——所有作者都参与的讨论，即使他们不知道。出于将在第四部分中变得清楚的原因，我们更愿意将这些注释称为辩证的。由于它们涉及多本书，而不仅仅是一本书，因此通常必须在单独的一张（或多张）纸上制作。这里隐含了概念的结构——关于单个主题的陈述和问题的顺序。我们将在第 20 章回到这种记笔记的方式。

There is a step beyond even that, however, and a truly expert reader can take it when he is reading several books syntopically. That is to make notes about the shape of the discussion—the discussion that is engaged in by all of the authors, even if unbeknownst to them. For reasons that will become clear in Part Four, we prefer to call such notes dialectical. Since they are made concerning several books, not just one, they often have to be made on a separate sheet (or sheets) of paper. Here, a structure of concepts is implied—an order of statements and questions about a single subject matter. We will return to this kind of note-making in Chapter 20.

养成阅读的习惯

Forming the Habit of Reading

 

任何艺术或技能都是那些养成了按照其规则操作的习惯的人所拥有的。这是任何领域的艺术家或工匠不同于那些缺乏技能的人的方式。

Any art or skill is possessed by those who have formed the habit of operating according to its rules. This is the way the artist or crafsman in any field differs from those who lack his skill.

现在没有其他方法养成操作习惯而不是通过操作。这就是所谓的边做边学的意思。养成习惯前后活动的区别在于便利程度和准备程度。经过练习，你可以比刚开始时做得更好。这就是熟能生巧的意思。起初你做的非常不完美，你逐渐会以本能表现所具有的那种近乎自动的完美来做。你做某事就好像你是天生的，就好像这项活动对你来说就像走路或吃饭一样自然。这就是习惯是第二天性的意思。

Now there is no other way of forming a habit of operation than by operating. That is what it means to say one learns to do by doing. The difference between your activity before and after you have formed a habit is a difference in facility and readiness. After practice, you can do the same thing much better than when you started. That is what it means to say practice makes perfect. What you do very imperfectly at first, you gradually come to do with the kind of almost automatic perfection that an instinctive performance has. You do something as if you were born to it, as if the activity were as natural to you as walking or eating. That is what it means to say that habit is second nature.

了解一门艺术的规则并不等同于拥有习惯。当我们说一个人在任何方面都很熟练时，并不是说他知道做某事或做某事的规则，而是说他拥有做某事或做某事的习惯。当然，或多或少明确地了解规则确实是获得技能的一个条件。你不能遵守你不知道的规则。如果不遵守规则，你也无法养成艺术习惯——任何手艺或技能。艺术作为可以教授的东西，由操作中要遵循的规则组成。作为学习和拥有的东西的艺术包括按照规则操作所产生的习惯。

Knowing the rules of an art is not the same as having the habit. When we speak of a man as skilled in any way, we do not mean that he knows the rules of making or doing something, but that he possesses the habit of making or doing it. Of course, it is true that knowing the rules, more or less explicitly, is a condition of getting the skill. You cannot follow rules you do not know. Nor can you acquire an artistic habit-any craft or skill—without following rules. The art as something that can be taught consists of rules to be followed in operation. The art as something learned and possessed consists of the habit that results from operating according to the rules.

顺便说一句，并不是每个人都明白成为一名艺术家就在于按规则行事。人们指着一位极具原创性的画家或雕塑家说，“他不遵守规则。他正在做一些完全原创的事情，一些以前从未做过的事情，一些没有规则的事情。” 但他们看不到艺术家遵循的是什么规则。严格来说，绘画或雕塑的创作没有最终的、牢不可破的规则。但是，准备帆布、混合颜料和涂抹它们，以及塑造粘土或焊接钢材，都是有规则的。画家或雕塑家必须遵守这些规则，否则他不可能做出他所创造的东西。不管他的最终作品多么原创，无论它看起来多么不遵守“规则”传统上所理解的艺术，他必须熟练地制作它。这就是我们在这里谈论的艺术——技能或技艺。

Incidentally, not everyone understands that being an artist consists in operating according to rules. People point to a highly original painter or sculptor and say, “He isn’t following rules. He’s doing something entirely original, something that has never been done before, something for which there are no rules.” But they fail to see what rules it is that the artist follows. There are no final, unbreakable rules, strictly speaking, for making a painting or sculpture. But there are rules for preparing canvas and mixing paints and applying them, and for moulding clay or welding steel. Those rules the painter or sculptor must have followed, or else he could not have made the thing he has made. No matter how original his final production, no matter how little it seems to obey the “rules” of art as they have traditionally been understood, he must be skilled to produce it. And this is the art—the skill or craft—that we are talking about here.

从多种规则到一种习惯

From Many Rules to One Habit

 

读书就像滑雪。如果做得好，如果由专家来完成，阅读和滑雪都是优雅、和谐的活动。当由初学者完成时，两者都很笨拙、令人沮丧且缓慢。

Reading is like skiing. When done well, when done by an expert, both reading and skiing are graceful, harmonious activities. When done by a beginner, both are awkward, frustrating, and slow.

学习滑雪是成年人可能经历的最屈辱的经历之一（这是从年轻开始的原因之一）。毕竟一个大人已经走了很久了；他知道他的脚在哪里；他知道如何将一只脚放在另一只脚前面以到达某个地方。但是，一旦他把滑雪板放在脚上，就好像他必须重新学习走路一样。他滑了又滑，摔倒了，爬起来有困难，滑雪板被弄弯了，又摔倒了，总的来说看起来——感觉上像个傻瓜。

Learning to ski is one of the most humiliating experiences an adult can undergo (that is one reason to start young). After all, an adult has been walking for a long time; he knows where his feet are; he knows how to put one foot in front of the other in order to get somewhere. But as soon as he puts skis on his feet, it is as though he had to learn to walk all over again. He slips and slides, falls down, has trouble getting up, gets his skis crossed, tumbles again, and generally looks—and feels-like a fool.

即使是最好的教练，起初似乎也无济于事。教师轻而易举地执行他说很简单但学生暗自认为不可能的动作，这几乎是一种侮辱。你怎么能记住老师说的所有你必须记住的东西呢？弯曲你的膝盖。往山下看。保持你的体重在下坡滑雪。保持背部挺直，但仍然向前倾。告诫似乎没完没了——你怎么能考虑到所有这些并仍然滑雪呢？

Even the best instructor seems at first to be no help. The ease with which the instructor performs actions that he says are simple but that the student secretly believes are impossible is almost insulting. How can you remember everything the instructor says you have to remember? Bend your knees. Look down the hill. Keep your weight on the downhill ski. Keep your back straight, but nevertheless lean forward. The admonitions seem endless—how can you think about all that and still ski?

当然，关于滑雪的要点是，你不应该考虑单独的动作，这些动作一起完成一个平滑的转弯或一系列相互关联的转弯——相反，你应该只是看着前方的山坡，预料到颠簸和颠簸。其他滑雪者，享受着冷风拂过脸颊的感觉，当你加速下山时，你对身体流畅的优雅感到高兴地微笑。换句话说，你必须学会忘记单独的行为，以便很好地执行所有这些行为，甚至是其中的任何一个。但是为了忘记它们作为单独的行为，你必须首先将它们作为单独的行为来学习。只有这样你才能把它们放在一起成为一名优秀的滑雪者。

The point about skiing, of course, is that you should not be thinking about the separate acts that, together, make a smooth turn or series of linked turns—instead, you should merely be looking ahead of you down the hill, anticipating bumps and other skiers, enjoying the feel of the cold wind on your cheeks, smiling with pleasure at the fluid grace of your body as you speed down the mountain. In other words, you must learn to forget the separate acts in order to perform all of them, and indeed any of them, well. But in order to forget them as separate acts, you have to learn them first as separate acts. Only then can you put them together to become a good skier.

读书也是一样。可能你也已经阅读了很长时间，重新开始学习可能会很丢人。但是，就像滑雪一样，阅读也一样，你不能将许多不同的行为结合成一个复杂、和谐的表现，直到你成为每一个行为的专家。你不能将工作的不同部分压缩，使它们相互碰撞并紧密融合。每一个单独的动作都需要你在做的时候全神贯注。分别练习各个部分后，您不仅可以更轻松、更轻松地完成每个部分，还可以逐渐将它们组合成一个流畅的整体。

It is the same with reading. Probably you have been reading for a long time, too, and starting to learn all over again can be humiliating. But it is just as true of reading as it is of skiing that you cannot coalesce a lot of different acts into one complex, harmonious performance until you become expert at each of them. You cannot telescope the different parts of the job so that they run into one another and fuse intimately. Each separate act requires your full attention while you are doing it. After you have practiced the parts separately, you can not only do each with greater facility and less attention but can also gradually put them together into a smoothly running whole.

所有这些都是关于学习复杂技能的常识。我们在这里这么说只是因为我们想让你意识到学习阅读至少和学习滑雪、打字或打网球一样复杂。如果你能回忆起你在任何其他学习经历中的耐心，你就会更能容忍那些很快会列举一长串阅读规则的老师。

All of this is common knowledge about learning a complex skill. We say it here merely because we want you to realize that learning to read is at least as complex as learning to ski or to typewrite or to play tennis. If you can recall your patience in any other learning experience you have had, you will be more tolerant of instructors who will shortly enumerate a long list of rules for reading.

有过获得一项复杂技能的经验的人知道，他不必害怕在学习新事物开始时出现的一系列规则。他知道他不必担心他必须分别精通的所有单独行为将如何协同工作。

The person who has had one experience in acquiring a complex skill knows that he need not fear the array of rules that present themselves at the beginning of something new to be learned. He knows that he does not have to worry about how all the separate acts in which he must become separately proficient are going to work together.

规则的多样性表明要养成的一个习惯的复杂性，而不是多个不同的习惯。当每个部分到达自动执行阶段时，这些部分合并并伸缩。当所有的从属动作都能或多或少地自动完成时，你就已经形成了整个表演的习惯。然后你可以考虑解决您以前从未滑雪过的专业跑步，或者阅读您曾经认为对您来说太难的书。开始时，学习者注意自己和他在单独动作中的技能。当动作在整个表演的技巧中失去了它们的独立性时，学习者终于可以将注意力集中在他所获得的技巧使他能够达到的目标上。

The multiplicity of the rules indicates the complexity of the one habit to be formed, not a plurality of distinct habits. The parts coalesce and telescope as each reaches the stage of automatic execution. When all the subordinate acts can be done more or less automatically, you have formed the habit of the whole performance. Then you can think about tackling an expert run you have never skied before, or reading a book that you once thought was too difficult for you. At the beginning, the learner pays attention to himself and his skill in the separate acts. When the acts have lost their separateness in the skill of the whole performance, the learner can at last pay attention to the goal that the technique he has acquired enables him to reach.

我们希望我们在这些页面中所说的内容鼓励了您。学好阅读很难。阅读，尤其是分析阅读，不仅是一项非常复杂的活动——比滑雪复杂得多；它也更像是一种心理活动。刚开始滑雪的人必须想到他以后可以忘记并几乎自动执行的身体动作。想到和意识到身体行为相对容易。像刚开始分析的读者必须做的那样，思考心理活动要困难得多；从某种意义上说，他是在考虑自己的想法。我们大多数人都不习惯这样做。然而，它是可以做到的，而且做到这一点的人会情不自禁地学会更好地阅读。

We hope we have encouraged you by the things we have said in these pages. It is hard to learn to read well. Not only is reading, especially analytical reading, a very complex activity—much more complex than skiing; it is also much more of a mental activity. The beginning skier must think of physical acts that he can later forget and perform almost automatically. It is relatively easy to think of and be conscious of physical acts. It is much harder to think of mental acts, as the beginning analytical reader must do; in a sense, he is thinking about his own thoughts. Most of us are unaccustomed to doing this. Nevertheless, it can be done, and a person who does it cannot help learning to read much better.

第二部分

PART TWO

 

阅读第三层次：分析阅读

The Third Level of Reading: Analytical Reading

 

6

收藏一本书

6PIGEONHOLING A BOOK

 

我们在本书开头说过，它提供的阅读指导适用于任何你必须阅读或想要阅读的内容。然而，在阐述分析阅读的规则时，正如我们将在第二部分所做的那样，我们似乎忽略了这一事实。我们通常（如果不是总是）指的是整本书的阅读。为什么会这样？

We said at the beginning of this book that the instruction in reading that it provides applies to anything you have to or want to read. However, in expounding the rules of analytical reading, as we will do in Part Two, we may seem to be ignoring that fact. We will usually, if not always, refer to the reading of whole books. Why is this so?

答案很简单。阅读一整本书，尤其是一本又长又难的书，是任何读者都可能面临的最严峻的问题。读短篇小说几乎总是比读小说容易；阅读一篇文章几乎总是比阅读同一主题的书更容易。如果你能读史诗或小说，你就可以读歌词或短篇小说；如果你能阅读说明性书籍——历史、哲学著作、科学论文——你就可以阅读同一领域的文章或摘要。

The answer is simple. Reading a whole book, and especially a long and difficult one, poses the severest problems any reader can face. Reading a short story is almost always easier than reading a novel; reading an article is almost always easier than reading a book on the same subject. If you can read an epic poem or a novel, you can read a lyric or a short story; if you can read an expository book—a history, a philosophical work, a scientific treatise—you can read an article or abstract in the same field.

因此，我们所说的关于读书的一切都适用于阅读所指出种类的其他材料。你要明白，当我们提到读书时，所阐述的规则也指的是较少但更容易理解的材料。有时这些规则并不以完全相同的方式适用于后者，或者它们适用于整本书的程度。尽管如此，您总是很容易调整它们以使其适用。

Hence everything that we will say about reading books applies to reading other materials of the kinds indicated. You are to understand, when we refer to the reading of books, that the rules expounded refer to lesser and more easily understood materials, too. Sometimes the rules do not apply to the latter in quite the same way, or to the extent that they apply to whole books. Nevertheless, it will always be easy for you to adapt them so that they are applicable.

书籍分类的重要性

The Importance of Classifying Books

 

分析阅读的第一条规则可以表述如下： 规则1.你必须知道你正在阅读的是什么类型的书，并且你应该尽可能早地知道这一点，最好是在你开始阅读之前。

The first rule of analytical reading can be expressed as follows: RULE 1. YOU MUST KNOW WHAT KIND OF BOOK YOU ARE READING, AND YOU SHOULD KNOW THIS AS EARLY IN THE PROCESS AS POSSIBLE, PREFERABLY BEFORE YOU BEGIN TO READ.

例如，你必须知道你是在读小说——小说、戏剧、史诗、抒情诗——还是某种说明性作品。几乎每个读者在看到小说时都知道它是一部小说。至少看起来是这样——但这并不总是那么容易。Portnoy 的抱怨是小说还是精神分析研究？裸体午餐是小说还是反对吸毒的小册子，类似于过去为了读者改善而讲述酒精恐怖的书籍？《乱世佳人》是南北战争之前和期间的浪漫史还是南方历史？做大街和愤怒的葡萄属于文学文学的范畴，还是两者都是社会学研究，一个专注于城市体验，另一个专注于农村生活？

You must know, for instance, whether you are reading fiction—a novel, a play, an epic, a lyric—or whether it is an expository work of some sort. Almost every reader knows a work of fiction when he sees it. Or so it seems—and yet this is not always easy. Is Portnoy’s Complaint a novel or a psychoanalytical study? Is Naked Lunch a fiction or a tract against drug abuse, similar to the books that used to recount the horrors of alcohol for the betterment of readers? Is Gone with the Wind a romance or a history of the South before and during the Civil War? Do Main Street and The Grapes of Wrath belong in the category of belles-lettres or are both of them sociological studies, the one concentrating on urban experiences, the other on agrarian life?

当然，所有这些都是小说。所有这些都出现在畅销书排行榜的小说方面。然而，这些问题并不荒谬。仅凭书名，很难区分《缅因街》和《米德尔敦》哪一部是虚构的，哪一部是社会科学。一些当代小说中有如此多的社会科学，而社会学中有如此多的虚构，很难将它们区分开来。但也有另一种科学——例如物理学和化学——在诸如仙女座变种或罗伯特·海因莱因或亚瑟·C·克拉克的小说中。还有像《宇宙》和《爱因斯坦博士》这样的书，虽然显然不是小说，但它几乎和小说一样“可读”，而且可能比威廉·福克纳 (William Faulkner) 的某些小说更具可读性。

All of these, of course, are novels; all of them appeared on the fiction side of the best-seller lists. Yet the questions are not absurd. Just by their titles, it would be hard to tell in the case of Main Street and Middletown which was fiction and which was social science. There is so much social science in some contemporary novels, and so much fiction in much of sociology, that it is hard to keep them apart. But there is another kind of science, too—physics and chemistry, for instance—in books like The Andromeda Strain or the novels of Robert Heinlein or Arthur C. Clarke. And a book like The Universe and Dr. Einstein, while clearly not fiction, is almost as “readable” as a novel, and probably more readable than some of the novels of, say, William Faulkner.

说明性书籍主要是传达知识，“知识”的解释很广。任何主要由观点、理论、假设或推测组成的书籍，或多或少明确地声称它们在某种意义上是真实的，在知识的这种意义上传达知识，是一部说明性作品。与小说一样，大多数人在看到说明性作品时都知道它。然而，这里的问题不是区分非虚构类作品和虚构类作品，而是要认识到说明性书籍的种类繁多。这不仅是了解哪些书主要具有指导意义的问题，而且还需要知道哪些书以特定方式具有指导意义。一部历史和一部哲学著作所提供的信息或启示的种类是不同的。一本关于物理学的书和一本关于道德的书所处理的问题是不一样的，作者在解决这些不同问题时所采用的方法也不一样。

An expository book is one that conveys knowledge primarily, “knowledge” being construed broadly. Any book that consists primarily of opinions, theories, hypotheses, or speculations, for which the claim is made more or less explicitly that they are true in some sense, conveys knowledge in this meaning of knowledge and is an expository work. As with fiction, most people know an expository work when they see it. Here, however, the problem is not to distinguish nonfiction from fiction, but to recognize that there are various kinds of expository books. It is not merely a question of knowing which books are primarily instructive, but also which are instructive in a particular way. The kinds of information or enlightenment that a history and a philosophical work afford are not the same. The problems dealt with by a book on physics and one on morals are not the same, nor are the methods the writers employ in solving such different problems.

因此，分析阅读的第一条规则虽然适用于所有书籍，但尤其适用于非虚构的说明性作品。你如何着手遵守规则，尤其是它的最后一条？

Thus this first rule of analytical reading, though it is applicable to all books, applies particularly to nonfictional, expository works. How do you go about following the rule, particularly its last clause?

正如我们已经建议的那样，你首先要检查这本书——检查性阅读。你读了标题、副标题、目录，你至少看了一眼序言或作者的介绍和索引。如果这本书有防尘套，您可以查看出版商的简介。这些是作者挥舞的信号旗，让您知道风向。如果你不停下来、不看、不听，那不是他的错。

As we have already suggested, you do so by first inspecting the book—giving it an inspectional reading. You read the title, the subtitle, the table of contents, and you at least glance at the preface or introduction by the author and at the index. If the book has a dust jacket, you look at the publisher’s blurb. These are the signal flags the author waves to let you know which way the wind is blowing. It is not his fault if you will not stop, look, and listen.

你可以从书名中学到什么

What You Can Learn from the Title of a Book

 

不注意信号的读者数量比您预期的要多。我们在学生身上一次又一次地有过这样的经历。我们问过他们一本书是关于什么的。我们已经要求他们以最笼统的方式告诉我们这是一本什么样的书。这是开始讨论一本书的好方法，几乎​​是必不可少的方法。然而，这个问题通常很难得到任何类型的答案。

The numbers of readers who pay no attention to the signals is larger than you might expect. We have had this experience again and again with students. We have asked them what a book was about. We have asked them, in the most general terms, to tell us what sort of book it was. This is a good way, almost an indispensable way, to begin a discussion of a book. Nevertheless, it is often hard to get any kind of answer to the question.

让我们举几个例子来说明这种混淆这可能会发生。1859年，达尔文出版了一本非常有名的书。一个世纪后，整个英语世界都庆祝了这本书的出版。它被无休止地讨论，其影响由博学的和不那么博学的评论员评估。这本书是关于进化论的，书名里有“物种”两个字。标题是什么？

Let us take a couple of examples of the kind of confusion that can occur. In 1859, Darwin published a very famous book. A century later the entire English-speaking world celebrated the publication of the book. It was discussed endlessly, and its influence was assessed by learned and not-so-learned commentators. The book was about the theory of evolution, and the word “species” was in the title. What was the title?

可能你说的是物种起源，在这种情况下你是对的。但你可能没有这么说过。你可能会说书名是《物种起源》。最近，我们问了大约 25 位博览群书的人，达尔文的书的书名是什么，超过一半的人说是《物种起源》。错误的原因很明显；他们从未读过这本书，以为它与人类物种的发展有关。事实上，它与达尔文在后来的一本书《人类的起源》中提到的主题几乎没有关系。物种起源正如它的标题所说的那样——即主要由于自然选择的原则，自然界中大量的植物和动物物种从最初数量少得多的物种中增殖出来。我们提到这个常见错误是因为许多人认为他们知道书名，尽管实际上很少有人仔细阅读过书名并思考过它的含义。

Probably you said The Origin of Species, in which case you were correct. But you might not have said that. You might have said that the title was The Origin of the Species. Recently, we asked some twenty-five reasonably well-read persons what the title of Darwin’s book was and more than half said The Origin of the Species. The reason for the mistake is obvious; they supposed, never having read the book, that it had something to do with the development of the human species. In fact, it has little or nothing to do with that subject, which Darwin covered in a later book, The Descent of Man. The Origin of Species is about what its title says it is about—namely the proliferation in the natural world of a vast number of species of plants and animals from an originally much smaller number of species, owing mainly to the principle of natural selection. We mention this common error because many think they know the title of the book, although few have actually ever read the title carefully and thought about what it means.

这是另一个例子。在这种情况下，我们不会要求您记住标题，而是考虑它的含义。吉本 (Gibbon) 写了一本关于罗马帝国的著名长篇巨著。他将其命名为《罗马帝国的衰亡》。几乎所有拿起这本书的人都认得这个书名；大多数人，即使手里没有这本书，也知道书名。事实上，“衰落”一词已成为众所周知的说法。然而，当我们问同样的 25 位博览群书的人，为什么第一章被称为“安东尼时代帝国的疆域和军事力量”时，他们却毫无头绪。他们没有看到，如果整本书的标题是《衰落与衰落》，那么它可能会假设故事将从罗马帝国的鼎盛时期开始，一直持续到最后。不知不觉中，他们把“decline and fall”翻译成了“rise and fall”。他们感到困惑，因为没有讨论罗马共和国，罗马共和国在安东尼时代之前结束了一个半世纪。如果他们仔细阅读了书名，他们可能会认为安东尼时代是帝国的巅峰时期，即使他们之前并不知道这一点。换句话说，阅读标题可以让他们在开始阅读之前就了解这本书的基本信息；但他们没能做到这一点，因为大多数人即使读了一本不熟悉的书也做不到。

Here is another example. In this case we will not ask you to remember the title, but to think about what it means. Gibbon wrote a famous, and famously long, book about the Roman Empire. He called it The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire. Almost everybody who takes up the book recognizes that title; and most people, even without the book in their hand, know the title. Indeed, the phrase “decline and fall” has become proverbial. Nevertheless, when we asked the same twenty-five well-read people why the first chapter is called “The Extent and Military Force of the Empire in the Age of the Antonines,” they had no idea. They did not see that if the book as a whole was titled Decline and Fall, then it might be assumed that the narrative would begin with the high point of the Roman Empire, and continue through to the end. Unconsciously, they had translated “decline and fall” into “rise and fall.” They were puzzled because there was no discussion of the Roman Republic, which ended a century and a half before the Age of the Antonines. If they had read the title carefully they could have assumed that the Age of the Antonines was the high point of the Empire, even if they had not known it before. Reading the title, in other words, could have given them essential information about the book before they started to read it; but they had failed to do that, as most people fail to do even with an unfamiliar book.

许多读者忽略标题和序言的原因之一是他们认为对正在阅读的书进行分类并不重要。他们不遵循分析阅读的第一条规则。如果他们尝试遵循它，他们将感谢作者帮助他们。显然，作者认为让读者知道他所收到的书的种类很重要。这就是为什么他不厌其烦地在序言中把它说清楚，而且通常试图让他的标题——或者至少是他的副标题——具有描述性。因此，爱因斯坦和因费尔德在他们的《物理学的进化》序言中，告诉读者他们希望他知道“一本科学书籍，即使很受欢迎，也不能像小说一样阅读。” 他们还构建了一个分析目录，以提前告知读者他们治疗的细节。无论如何，列在前面的章节标题是为了强调主标题的重要性。

One reason why titles and prefaces are ignored by many readers is that they do not think it important to classify the book they are reading. They do not follow this first rule of analytical reading. If they tried to follow it, they would be grateful to the author for helping them. Obviously, the author thinks it is important for the reader to know the kind of book he is being given. That is why he goes to the trouble of making it plain in the preface, and usually tries to make his title—or at least his subtitle—descriptive. Thus, Einstein and Infeld, in their preface to The Evolution of Physics, tell the reader that they expect him to know “that a scientific book, even though popular, must not be read in the same way as a novel.” They also construct an analytical table of contents to advise the reader in advance of the details of their treatment. In any event, the chapter headings listed in the front serve the purpose of amplifying the significance of the main title.

忽略所有这些事情的读者如果对这个问题感到困惑，这只能怪他自己，这是什么样的书？他会变得更加困惑。如果他不能回答那个问题，如果他从不问自己，他将无法回答关于这本书的许多其他问题。

The reader who ignores all these things has only himself to blame if he is puzzled by the question, What kind of book is this? He is going to become more perplexed. If he cannot answer that question, and if he never asks it of himself, he is going to be unable to answer a lot of other questions about the book.

阅读标题很重要，但这还不够。世界上最清晰的标题，最露骨的封面，不会帮助你对一本书进行分类，除非你已经在脑海中有了大致的分类线。

Important as reading titles is, it is not enough. The clearest titles in the world, the most explicit front matter, will not help you to classify a book unless you have the broad lines of classification already in your mind.

如果你不知道心理学和几何学都是科学，你就不会知道欧几里得的《几何原本》和威廉·詹姆斯的《心理学原理》是同一类书籍的意义——顺便说一句，如果你不知道“几何元素” ”和“原则”在这两个标题中的含义大致相同（尽管不是笼统的），除非您知道科学有不同的种类，否则您将无法进一步区分它们的不同。类似地，就亚里士多德的政治学和亚当·斯密的国富论而言，只有知道什么是实际问题以及实际问题有哪些不同种类，才能说出这些书有何相同之处和不同之处。

You will not know the sense in which Euclid’s Elements of Geometry and William James’ Principles of Psychology are books of the same sort if you do not know that psychology and geometry are both sciences—and, incidentally, if you do not know that “elements” and “principles” mean much the same thing in these two titles (though not in general), nor will you further be able to distinguish them as different unless you know there are different kinds of science. Similarly, in the case of Aristotle’s Politics and Adam Smith’s The Wealth of Nations, you can tell how these books are alike and different only if you know what a practical problem is, and what different kinds of practical problems there are.

标题有时会使书籍的分组变得容易。任何人都知道，欧几里德的《几何原本》 、笛卡尔的《几何学》和希尔伯特的《几何学基础》是三本数学书籍，或多或少在主题上密切相关。这并非总是如此。奥古斯丁的《上帝之城》、霍布斯的《利维坦》和卢梭的《社会契约论》可能不太容易从书名中看出它们是政治论着，但仔细阅读它们的章节标题会发现这三本书的共同问题。

Titles sometimes make the grouping of books easy. Anyone would know that Euclid’s Elements, Descartes’ Geometry, and Hilbert’s Foundations of Geometry are three mathematical books, more or less closely related in subject matter. This is not always the case. It might not be so easy to tell from the titles that Augustine’s The City of God, Hobbes’ Leviathan, and Rousseau’s Social Contract are political treatises, although a careful perusal of their chapter headings would reveal the problems that are common to these three books.

然而，再次将书籍归为同类是不够的；要遵循这条阅读的第一条规则，您必须知道那是什么。标题不会告诉你，其他所有的封面内容也不会告诉你，有时甚至整本书本身也不会告诉你，除非你有一些类别可以用来智能地对书籍进行分类。换句话说，如果你想明智地遵守这条规则，就必须让它更容易理解一点。只有通过区分并创建有意义且经得起时间考验的类别，才能使它易于理解。

Again, however, to group books as being of the same kind is not enough; to follow this first rule of reading you must know what that kind is. The title will not tell you, nor all the rest of the front matter, nor even the whole book itself sometimes, unless you have some categories you can apply to classify books intelligently. In other words, this rule has to be made a little more intelligible if you are to follow it intelligently. It can only be made intelligible by drawing distinctions and thus creating categories that make sense and will stand up to the test of time.

我们已经讨论了书籍的粗略分类。我们说过，主要区别一方面是虚构作品，另一方面是传达知识或说明性作品另一方面，有效。在说明性著作中，我们可以进一步区分历史与哲学，以及科学与数学。

We have already discussed a rough classification of books. The main distinction, we said, was between works of fiction, on the one hand, and works conveying knowledge, or expository works, on the other hand. Among expository works, we can further distinguish history from philosophy, and both from science and mathematics.

现在这一切都很好。这是一个类别相当明确的分类方案，如果大多数人考虑一下，他们可能会将大多数书籍归入正确的类别。但并非所有类别的所有书籍。

Now this is all very well as far as it goes. This is a classification scheme with fairly perspicuous categories, and most people could probably place most books in the right category if they thought about it. But not all books in all categories.

问题是我们至今还没有分类原则。随着我们继续讨论更高层次的阅读，我们将更多地谈论这些原则。目前，我们想将自己局限于一个基本区别，一个全面适用于所有说明性作品的区别。这是理论作品和实践作品之间的区别。

The trouble is that as yet we have no principles of classification. We will have more to say about these principles as we proceed in our discussion of the higher levels of reading. For the moment, we want to confine ourselves to one basic distinction, a distinction that applies across the board to all expository works. It is the distinction between theoretical and practical works.

实用与理论书籍

Practical vs. Theoretical Books

 

每个人都使用“理论”和“实践”这两个词，但并不是每个人都知道它们的意思，也许最不了解所有不信任所有理论家的头脑冷静的实际人士，尤其是当他们在政府中时。对这些人来说，“理论的”意味着有远见的甚至是神秘的；“实用”意味着有用的东西，可以立即获得现金回报的东西。这其中有一个真实的元素。实用性与以某种方式立即或长期起作用的东西有关。理论涉及要看到或理解的东西。如果我们对这里所掌握的粗略真相进行润色，我们就会发现知识和行动之间的区别是作家可能想到的两个目的。

Everyone uses the words “theoretical” and “practical,” but not everyone knows what they mean, perhaps least of all the hardheaded practical man who distrusts all theorists, especially if they are in the government. For such persons, “theoretical” means visionary or even mystical; “practical” means something that works, something that has an immediate cash return. There is an element of truth in this. The practical has to do with what works in some way, at once or in the long run. The theoretical concerns something to be seen or understood. If we polish the rough truth that is here being grasped, we come to the distinction between knowledge and action as the two ends a writer may have in mind.

但是，你可能会说，在处理说明性书籍时，我们不是在处理传达知识的书籍吗？行动如何进入其中？答案当然是明智的行动取决于知识。知识有多种用途，不仅可以用于控制自然和发明有用的机器或仪器，还可以用于指导人类行为并规范人们在各个技能领域的操作。我们在这里想到的是纯科学和应用科学之间的区别，或者，有时表达得非常不准确，科学和技术之间的区别。

But, you may say, in dealing with expository books, are we not dealing with books that convey knowledge? How does action come into it? The answer, of course, is that intelligent action depends on knowledge. Knowledge can be used in many ways, not only for controlling nature and inventing useful machines or instruments but also for directing human conduct and regulating man’s operations in various fields of skill. What we have in mind here is exemplified by the distinction between pure and applied science, or, as it is sometimes very inaccurately expressed, between science and technology.

有些书和一些老师只对他们必须交流的知识本身感兴趣。这并不意味着他们否认它的实用性，或者他们坚持认为知识只是为了它自己的缘故才是好的。他们只是将自己局限于一种交流或教导，而将另一种留给其他人。这些其他人的兴趣超越了知识本身。他们关心知识可以帮助解决的人类生活问题。他们也传播知识，但总是着眼于并强调知识的应用。

Some books and some teachers are interested only in the knowledge itself that they have to communicate. This does not mean that they deny its utility, or that they insist that knowledge is good only for its own sake. They simply limit themselves to one kind of communication or teaching, and leave the other kind to other men. These others have an interest beyond knowledge for its own sake. They are concerned with the problems of human life that knowledge can help to solve. They communicate knowledge, too, but always with a view to and an emphasis upon its application.

要使知识具有实用性，我们必须将其转化为操作规则。如果我们想到达某个地方，我们必须从知道情况如何转变为知道如何处理它。这可以概括为知道那个和知道如何做之间的区别。理论书告诉你事情是这样的。实用书籍教你如何做你想做或认为你应该做的事情。

To make knowledge practical we must convert it into rules of operation. We must pass from knowing what is the case to knowing what to do about it if we wish to get somewhere. This can be summarized in the distinction between knowing that and knowing how. Theoretical books teach you that something is the case. Practical books teach you how to do something you want to do or think you should do.

这本书是实用的，而不是理论的。任何指南都是一本实用的书。任何告诉您应该做什么或如何做的书都是实用的。因此，您会看到，实用书籍类别包括所有要学习的艺术说明、任何领域的所有实践手册，如工程、医学或烹饪，以及所有方便归类为道德的论文，如经济书籍，道德或政治问题。我们稍后会解释为什么这最后一组书，恰当地称为“规范”书，构成了一个非常特殊的实用书籍类别。

This book is practical, not theoretical. Any guidebook is a practical book. Any book that tells you either what you should do or how to do it is practical. Thus you see that the class of practical books includes all expositions of arts to be learned, all manuals of practice in any field, such as engineering or medicine or cooking, and all treatises that are conveniently classified as moral, such as books on economic, ethical, or political problems. We will later explain why this last group of books, properly called “normative,” constitutes a very special category of practical books.

可能没有人会质疑我们对要学习的艺术、手册或规则手册、实用作品的呼唤。但是，我们提到的那个“务实”的人可能会反对这样一种观念，即一本伦理学书籍或一本经济学书籍是实用的。他可能会说这样一本书不实用，因为它不真实或行不通。

Probably no one would question our calling expositions of arts to be learned and manuals or rule books, practical works. But the “practical” man to whom we have referred might object to the notion that a book on ethics, say, or one on economics, was practical. He might say that such a book was not practical because it was not true or would not work.

其实这无关紧要，虽然一本不真实的经济学书是一本烂书。严格来说，任何伦理工作都是在教导我们如何过好自己的生活，告诉我们什么该做，什么不该做，常常告诉我们做与不做的奖惩。因此，无论我们是否同意其结论，任何此类工作都是实用的。（一些现代社会学研究仅仅报告了人的实际行为，而没有对其进行评判。这些既不是伦理学书籍也不是实用书籍。它们是理论著作——科学著作。）

In fact, this is irrelevant to the point, although a book about economics that is not true is a bad book. Strictly speaking, any ethical work teaches us how to live our lives, tells us what we should do and not do, and often informs us of the rewards and punishments attached to doing and not doing it. Thus, whether or not we agree with its conclusions, any such work is practical. (Some modern sociological studies merely report the actual behavior of men, without judging it. These are neither ethical nor practical books. They are theoretical works—works of science.)

经济学方面的工作也是如此。除了对经济行为的报告、数学或统计研究，这些研究是理论而非实践，这些著作通常教我们如何组织我们的经济生活，无论是作为个人还是作为社会或国家，告诉我们应该做什么和不做什么，并告知我们如果我们不做我们应该做的，所涉及的处罚。同样，我们可能不同意，但我们的分歧不会使本书不切实际。

Similarly with a work on economics.
