Apart from reportorial, mathematical, or statistical studies of economic behavior, which are theoretical rather than practical, such works usually teach us how to organize our economic life, either as individuals or as societies or states, tell us what we should do and not do, and also inform us of the penalties involved if we do not do what we should. Again, we may disagree, but our disagreement does not make the book unpractical.

伊曼纽尔·康德写了两部著名的哲学著作，一部叫做《纯粹理性批判》 ，另一部叫做《实践理性批判》。第一个是关于它是什么以及我们如何知道它——不是如何知道它，而是我们实际上如何知道它——以及什么可以知道什么不能知道。这是一本卓越的理论书籍。实践理性批判是关于人们应该如何行事以及什么构成了美德或正确的行为。这本书非常强调责任是所有正确行为的基础，而这种强调似乎让许多现代读者感到厌恶。他们甚至可能会说，认为责任不再是一个有用的伦理概念是“不切实际的”。当然，他们的意思是，在他们看来，康德的基本方法是错误的。但这并不意味着他的书在我们这里所使用的意义上就不是一部实用的作品。

Immanuel Kant wrote two famous philosophical works, one called The Critique of Pure Reason, the other, The Critique of Practical Reason. The first is about what is and how we know it—not how to know it, but how we in fact do know it—as well as about what can and cannot be known. It is a theoretical book par excellence. The Critique of Practical Reason is about how men should conduct themselves and about what constitutes virtuous or right conduct. This book places great emphasis on duty as the basis of all right action, and that emphasis may seem repellent to many modern readers. They may even say it is “impractical” to believe that duty is any longer a useful ethical concept. What they mean, of course, is that Kant is wrong, in their opinion, in his basic approach. But that does not mean that his book is any less a practical work in the sense we are employing here.

除了手册和道德论文（广义上的）之外，还应该提到另一种实用写作的例子。演说——政治演说或道德劝告——肯定会试图告诉你应该做什么或如何做应该感受到一些东西。任何实际写任何东西的人不仅会试图给你建议，还会试图说服你听从他的建议。因此，在每一篇道德论文中都有演讲或劝告的成分。它也出现在试图教授一门艺术的书中，比如这本书。因此，除了尝试教您更好地阅读之外，我们已经并将继续尝试说服您努力这样做。

Apart from manuals and moral treatises (in the broad sense) one other instance of practical writing should be mentioned. An oration—a political speech or moral exhortation—certainly tries to tell you what you should do or how you should feel about something. Anyone who writes practically about anything not only tries to advise you but also tries to persuade you to follow his advice. Hence there is an element of oratory or exhortation in every moral treatise. It is also present in books that try to teach an art, such as this one. Thus, in addition to trying to teach you to read better, we have tried, and will continue to try, to persuade you to make the effort to do so.

虽然每一本实用的书都有些雄辩和劝告，但这并不意味着雄辩和劝告就与实用相得益彰。政治演讲与政治论文、经济宣传与经济问题分析之间存在差异。《共产党宣言》是一篇演讲稿，但马克思的《资本论》远不止于此。

Although every practical book is somewhat oratorical and hortatory, it does not follow that oratory and exhortation are coextensive with the practical. There is a difference between a political harangue and a treatise on politics, between economic propaganda and an analysis of economic problems. The Communist Manifesto is a piece of oratory, but Marx’s Capital is much more than that.

有时你可以从书名看出一本书是实用的。如果标题包含诸如“艺术的”或“如何做”之类的短语，您可以立即发现它。如果书名名称是您知道的实用领域，例如伦理学或政治学、工程或商业，在许多情况下还有经济学、法律或医学，您可以很容易地对这本书进行分类。

Sometimes you can detect that a book is practical by its title. If the title contains such phrases as “the art of” or “how to,” you can spot it at once. If the title names fields that you know are practical, such as ethics or politics, engineering or business, and in many cases economics, law, or medicine, you can classify the book fairly readily.

标题可以告诉你更多。约翰·洛克写了两本标题相似的书：《关于人类理解的论文》和《关于公民政府的起源、范围和终结的论文》。其中哪些是理论性的，哪些是实践性的？

Titles can tell you even more than that. John Locke wrote two books with similar titles: An Essay Concerning Human Understanding and A Treatise Concerning the Origin, Extent, and End of Civil Government. Which of these is theoretical, which practical?

仅从标题我们就可以得出结论，第一个是理论性的，因为任何理解分析都是理论性的，而第二个是实践性的，因为政府问题本身就是实践性的。但人们可以超越这一点，使用我们已经描述过的检查阅读技巧。洛克为这本关于理解的书写了序言。他在那里表达了他的意图，即探究“人类知识的起源、确定性和广度”。措辞类似于关于政府的书的标题，但有一个重要的区别。洛克是在一种情况下与知识的确定性或有效性有关，在另一种情况下与政府的目的或目的有关。关于某事的有效性的问题是理论上的，而对任何事情的目的提出问题，它服务的目的，是实际的。

From the titles alone we may conclude that the first is theoretical, because any analysis of understanding would be theoretical, and that the second is practical, because problems of government are themselves practical. But one could go beyond that, employing the techniques of inspectional reading that we have described. Locke wrote an introduction to the book on understanding. There he expressed his intention as being to inquire into the “origin, certainty, and extent of human knowledge.” The phrasing resembles the title of the book on government, but with one important difference. Locke was concerned with the certainty or validity of knowledge in the one case, and with the end or purpose of government in the other. Questions about the validity of something are theoretical, whereas to raise questions about the end of anything, the purpose it serves, is practical.

在描述检视阅读的艺术时，我们指出，您通常不应在读完一本书的前言和索引后就停下来。您应该阅读书中看似具有摘要性质的段落。您还应该阅读本书的开头和结尾及其主要部分。

In describing the art of inspectional reading, we noted that you should not ordinarily stop after reading the front matter of a book and perhaps its index. You should read passages in the book that appear to be of a summary nature. You should also read the beginning and end of the book and of its major parts.

当无法根据书名和其他前言对一本书进行分类时（有时是这种情况），这就变得很有必要了。在这种情况下，您必须依赖于文本主体中的符号。通过注意单词并牢记基本类别，您应该能够在不阅读很远的情况下对一本书进行分类。

This becomes necessary when, as is sometimes the case, it is impossible to classify a book from its title and other front matter. In that case, you have to depend on signs to be found in the main body of the text. By paying attention to the words and keeping the basic categories in mind, you should be able to classify a book without reading very far.

一本实用的书很快就会因为频繁出现“应该”和“应该”、“好”和“坏”、“目的”和“方法”等词而暴露其特征。实用书籍中的典型陈述是说应该做（或做）某事；或者这是做（或做）某事的正确方法；或者，作为要寻求的目的或要选择的手段，一件事比另一件事更好。相比之下，一本理论书总是说“是”，而不是“应该”或“应该”。它试图表明某事是真实的，这些就是事实；并不是说如果不是这样事情会更好，这里是让事情变得更好的方法。

A practical book will soon betray its character by the frequent occurrence of such words as “should” and “ought,” “good” and “bad,” “ends” and “means.” The characteristic statement in a practical book is one that says that something should be done (or made); or that this is the right way of doing (or making) something; or that one thing is better than another as an end to be sought, or a means to be chosen. In contrast, a theoretical book keeps saying “is,” not “should” or “ought.” It tries to show that something is true, that these are the facts; not that things would be better if they were otherwise, and here is the way to make them better.

在转向理论书籍之前，让我们提醒您不要假设问题就像判断您喝的是咖啡还是牛奶一样简单。我们只是提出了一些迹象，您可以据此开始进行区分。你越了解理论和实践之间的区别所涉及的一切，你就能越好地使用这些符号。

Before turning to theoretical books, let us caution you against supposing that the problem is as simple as telling whether you are drinking coffee or milk. We have merely suggested some signs whereby you can begin to make discriminations. The better you understand everything that is involved in the distinction between the theoretical and the practical, the better you will be able to use the signs.

一方面，你必须学会​​不信任他们。你必须对书籍进行分类持怀疑态度。我们已经注意到，虽然经济学主要而且通常是实践性的问题，但仍然存在纯理论性的经济学书籍。同样，虽然理解主要是而且通常是理论问题，但有些书（其中大部分都很糟糕）声称可以教你“如何思考”。你还会发现不知道理论和实践之间区别的作者，就像有些小说家不知道小说和社会学之间的区别一样。你会发现部分属于一种类型，部分属于另一种类型的书籍，例如斯宾诺莎的《伦理学》。尽管如此，作为读者，发现作者处理问题的方式仍然对您有利。

For one thing, you will have to learn to mistrust them. You have to be suspicious in classifying books. We have noted that although economics is primarily and usually a practical matter, there are nevertheless books on economics that are purely theoretical. Similarly, although understanding is primarily and usually a theoretical matter, there are books (most of them are terrible) that purport to teach you “how to think.” You will also find authors who do not know the difference between theory and practice, just as there are novelists who do not know the difference between fiction and sociology. You will find books that are partly of one sort and partly of another, such as Spinoza’s Ethics. It remains, nevertheless, to your advantage as a reader to detect the way an author approaches his problem.

理论书籍种类

Kinds of Theoretical Books

 

理论书籍的传统细分将它们分为历史、科学和哲学。每个人都粗略地知道这里的区别。只有当你试图提炼明显的东西，并使区别更加精确时，你才会遇到困难。目前，让我们尝试避开这种危险，让粗略的近似值就足够了。

The traditional subdivision of theoretical books classifies them as history, science, and philosophy. Everybody knows the differences here in a rough way. It is only when you try to refine the obvious, and give the distinctions greater precision, that you get into difficulties. For the moment, let us try to skirt that danger and let rough approximations suffice.

就历史而言，标题通常可以解决问题。如果“历史”一词没有出现在标题中，其余的前言很可能会告诉我们这是一本关于过去发生的事情的书——当然不一定是遥远的过去，因为它可能昨天才发生。历史的本质是叙述。历史是关于特定事件或事物的知识，这些事件或事物不仅存在于过去，而且随着时间的推移发生了一系列变化。历史学家叙述这些事件，并经常用对事件重要性的评论或洞察来修饰他的叙述。

In the case of history, the title usually does the trick. If the word “history” does not appear in the title, the rest of the front matter is likely to inform us that this is a book about something that happened in the past—not necessarily in the far past, of course, because it may have happened only yesterday. The essence of history is narration. History is knowledge of particular events or things that not only existed in the past but also underwent a series of changes in the course of time. The historian narrates these happenings and often colors his narrative with comment on, or insight into, the significance of the events.

历史是时间主题的。Chronos是希腊语中的时间，topos是希腊语中的地点。历史总是处理在特定时间存在的事物或发生的事件日期和特定地点。“chronotopic”这个词可以让你想起这一点。

History is chronotopic. Chronos is the Greek word for time, topos the Greek word for place. History always deals with things that existed or events that occurred on a particular date and in a particular place. The word “chronotopic” can remind you of that.

科学并不关心过去本身。它处理在任何时间或地点都可能发生的事情。科学家寻求规律或概括。他想找出事情在大多数情况下或在所有情况下是如何发生的，而不是像历史学家那样，在过去的特定时间和地点发现某些特定的事情是如何发生的。

Science is not concerned with the past as such. It treats of matters than can happen at any time or place. The scientist seeks laws or generalizations. He wants to find out how things happen for the most part or in every case, not, as the historian does, how some particular things happened at a given time and place in the past.

科学著作的标题通常不像历史书的标题那样暴露。有时会出现“科学”一词，但更多时候会出现主题名称，例如心理学或地质学或物理学。然后我们必须知道该主题是否像地质学那样属于科学家，或者像形而上学那样属于哲学家。麻烦来自于不太清楚的案例，例如物理学和心理学，科学家和哲学家在不同时期都声称这些案例。“哲学”和“科学”这两个词甚至有问题，因为它们被广泛使用。亚里士多德将他的物理学著作称为科学论文，尽管按照目前的用法，我们应该将其视为哲学著作；牛顿将他的伟大著作命名为自然哲学的数学原理，虽然对我们来说它是科学的杰作之一。

The title of a scientific work is usually less revealing than the title of a history book. The word “science” sometimes appears, but more often the name of the subject matter appears, such as psychology or geology or physics. Then we must know whether that subject matter belongs to the scientist, as geology clearly does, or to the philosopher, as metaphysics clearly does. The trouble comes with the cases that are not so clear, such as physics and psychology, which have been claimed, at various times, by both scientists and philosophers. There is even trouble with the very words “philosophy” and “science,” for they have been variously used. Aristotle called his book on Physics a scientific treatise, although according to current usage we should regard it as philosophical; and Newton titled his great work Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy, though for us it is one of the masterpieces of science.

哲学像科学而不像历史，因为它寻求普遍真理而不是对特定事件的描述，无论是在不久的过去还是在遥远的过去。但哲学家提出的问题与科学家不同，他回答问题的方法也不同。

Philosophy is like science and unlike history in that it seeks general truths rather than an account of particular events, either in the near or distant past. But the philosopher does not ask the same questions as the scientist, nor does he employ the same kind of method to answer them.

既然标题和主题名称不太可能帮助我们确定一本书是哲学的还是科学的，我们怎么知道呢？我们认为有一个标准始终有效，尽管您可能需要阅读一定数量的书才能应用它。如果一本理论书强调的东西超出了你正常、日常、日常经验的范围，那么它就是一本科学著作。如果不是，那就是哲学。

Since titles and subject-matter names are not likely to help us determine whether a book is philosophical or scientific, how can we tell? There is one criterion that we think always works, although you may have to read a certain amount of the book before you can apply it. If a theoretical book emphasizes things that lie outside the scope of your normal, routine, daily experience, it is a scientific work. If not, it is philosophical.

这种区别可能令人惊讶。让我们举例说明。（记住它只适用于要么是科学要么是哲学的书，而不适用于两者都不是的书。）伽利略的两门新科学要求你想象，或者在实验室里为自己重复某些倾斜平面的实验。牛顿的光学指的是在带有棱镜、镜子和特别控制的光线的暗室中的体验。作者所说的特殊经历，可能不是他在实验室里得到的。达尔文在《物种起源》中报道的事实他在多年的实地工作过程中观察到。这些事实可以并且已经被其他做出类似努力的观察员重新检查过。但它们不是可以根据普通人的日常经验来核实的事实。

The distinction may be surprising. Let us illustrate it. (Remember that it applies only to books that are either science or philosophy, not to books that are neither.) Galileo’s Two New Sciences requires you to imagine, or to repeat for yourself in a laboratory, certain experiments with inclined planes. Newton’s Opticks refers to experiences in dark rooms with prisms, mirrors, and specially controlled rays of light. The special experience to which the author refers may not have been obtained by him in a laboratory. The facts that Darwin reported in The Origin of Species he observed in the course of many years of work in the field. They are facts that can be and have been rechecked by other observers making a similar effort. But they are not facts that can be checked in terms of the ordinary daily experience of the average man.

相比之下，一本哲学书不求助于普通人经验之外的任何事实或观察。哲学家让读者参考他自己的正常和普遍的经验，以验证或支持作者所说的任何事情。因此，洛克的《人类理解论》是心理学的哲学著作，而弗洛伊德的许多著作都是科学的。洛克根据我们所有人对自己心理过程的体验来阐述每一点。弗洛伊德只有通过报告他在精神分析师办公室的临床条件下观察到的情况，才能阐明他的许多观点。

In contrast, a philosophical book appeals to no facts or observations that lie outside the experience of the ordinary man. A philosopher refers the reader to his own normal and common experience for the verification or support of anything the writer has to say. Thus, Locke’s Essay Concerning Human Understanding is a philosophical work in psychology, whereas many of Freud’s writings are scientific. Locke makes every point in terms of the experience all of us have of our own mental processes. Freud can make many of his points only by reporting what he observed under the clinical conditions of the psychoanalyst’s office.

另一位伟大的心理学家威廉·詹姆斯上了一个有趣的中间课程。他报告了许多只有细心、训练有素的观察者才能知道的特殊经历的例子，但他也经常要求读者根据自己的经历来判断所说的是否属实。因此，詹姆斯的《心理学原理》既是科学著作，也是哲学著作，尽管它主要是科学著作。

William James, another great psychologist, took an interesting middle course. He reports many examples of the special experience that only the careful, trained observer can know about, but he also frequently asks the reader to judge whether what is being said is not true from his own experience. Thus James’ Principles of Psychology is both a scientific and a philosophical work, although it is primarily scientific.

当我们说科学是实验性的或依赖于详尽的观察研究时，这里提出的区别得到普遍认可，而哲学仅仅是纸上谈兵的思考。对比不应令人反感。有一些问题，其中一些非常重要，知道如何根据人类的共同经验思考这些问题的人坐在扶手椅上就可以解决这个问题。还有其他问题，再多的最佳扶手椅思维也无法解决。解决这些问题所需要的是某种调查——实验室中的实验或实地研究——将经验扩展到正常的日常工作之外。需要特殊经验。

The distinction proposed here is popularly recognized when we say that science is experimental or depends upon elaborate observational researches, whereas philosophy is merely armchair thinking. The contrast should not be invidious. There are certain problems, some of them very important, that can be solved in an armchair by a man who knows how to think about them in the light of common, human experience. There are other problems that no amount of the best armchair thinking can solve. What is needed to solve them is investigation of some sort—experiments in the laboratory or research in the field—extending experience beyond the normal, everyday routine. Special experience is required.

这并不意味着哲学家是纯粹的思想家，而科学家只是观察者。两者都必须观察和思考，但他们考虑的是不同类型的观察结果。不管他们可能得出了他们想要证明的结论，他们以不同的方式证明它们，科学家通过指出他的特殊经验的结果，哲学家通过指出所有人共有的经验。

This does not mean that the philosopher is a pure thinker and the scientist merely an observer. Both have to observe and think, but they think about different sorts of observations. And however they may have arrived at the conclusions that they want to prove, they prove them in different ways, the scientist by pointing to the results of his special experiences, the philosopher by pointing to experiences that are common to all.

这种方法上的差异总是在哲学和科学书籍中表现出来，这就是你如何分辨你正在阅读哪种书的方式。如果你注意到被称为理解所说内容的条件的那种体验，你就会知道这本书是科学的还是哲学的。

This difference in method always reveals itself in philosophical and scientific books, and that is how you can tell which sort of book you are reading. If you note the sort of experience that is being referred to as a condition of understanding what is being said, you will know whether the book is scientific or philosophical.

了解这一点很重要，因为除了他们所依赖的不同种类的经验之外，科学家和哲学家的思考方式并不完全相同。他们争论的方式不同。你必须能够找到构成这些不同类型论证的术语和命题——这里我们有点超前了。

It is important to know this because, apart from the different kinds of experiences that they depend on, scientists and philosophers do not think in exactly the same way. Their styles in arguing are different. You must be able to find the terms and propositions—here we are getting a little ahead of ourselves—that constitute these different sorts of argumentation.

历史也是如此。历史陈述不同于科学和哲学陈述。历史学家以不同的方式争论，以不同的方式解释事实。此外，典型的历史书在形式上是叙述性的。叙事就是叙事，无论是事实还是虚构。历史学家必须诗意地写作，这意味着他必须遵守讲好故事的规则。不管洛克的《人类理解论》或牛顿的《原理》有什么其他的优点，都不是一个好故事。

The same is true of history. Historical statements are different from scientific and philosophical ones. A historian argues differently and interprets facts differently. Furthermore, the typical history book is narrative in form. A narrative is a narrative, whether it be fact or fiction. The historian must write poetically, which means he must obey the rules for telling a good story. Whatever other excellences Locke’s Essay on Human Understanding or Newton’s Principia may have, neither is a good story.

你可能会反对我们做的太多了书籍分类，至少在阅读之前。真的那么重要吗？

You may object that we are making too much of the classification of books, at least before one has read them. Is it really all that important?

我们也许可以通过提请您注意一个显而易见的事实来解决异议。如果你走进一间老师正在讲课或以其他方式指导学生的教室，你很快就能分辨出这堂课是历史、科学还是哲学。老师讲课的方式、他使用的措辞、他采用的论证类型、他提出的问题类型以及他期望学生做出的反应类型，都会暴露他的归属感到一个或另一个部门。如果你想聪明地倾听发生的事情，知道这一点会对你产生影响。

We may be able to meet the objections by calling your attention to one obvious fact. If you walked into a classroom in which a teacher was lecturing or otherwise instructing students, you could tell very soon whether the class was one in history, science, or philosophy. There would be something in the way the teacher proceeded, the kind of words he used, the type of arguments he employed, the sort of problems he proposed, and the kind of responses he expected from his students, that would give him away as belonging to one department or another. And it would make a difference to you to know this, if you were going to try to listen intelligently to what went on.

总之，不同学科的教学方法是不同的。任何老师都知道这一点。由于方法和主题的不同，哲学家通常更容易教他的同事以前没有教过的学生，而科学家则更喜欢他的同事已经准备好的学生。等等等等。

In short, the methods of teaching different kinds of subject matter are different. Any teacher knows this. Because of the difference in method and subject matter, the philosopher usually finds it easier to teach students who have not been previously taught by his colleagues, whereas the scientist prefers the student whom his colleagues have already prepared. And so forth and so on.

现在，正如不同领域的教学艺术存在差异一样，被教授的艺术也存在相互差异。学生的活动必须以某种方式响应教师的活动。书与读者的关系，如同教师与学生的关系。因此，由于书籍所传达的知识种类不同，因此它们会以不同的方式指导我们；而且，如果我们要遵循它们，我们必须学会以适当的方式阅读每一种。

Now, just as there is a difference in the art of teaching in different fields, so there is a reciprocal difference in the art of being taught. The activity of the student must somehow be responsive to the activity of the instructor. The relation between books and their readers is the same as that between teachers and their students. Hence, as books differ in the kinds of knowledge they have to communicate, they proceed to instruct us differently; and, if we are to follow them, we must learn to read each kind in an appropriate manner.

7

X 光检查一本书

7X-RAYING A BOOK

 

每本书的封面之间都隐藏着骨架。作为一名分析型读者，你的工作就是找到它。

Every book has a skeleton hidden between its covers. Your job as an analytical reader is to find it.

一本书来到你面前，光秃秃的骨头上有肉，肉上有衣服。都是盛装打扮。你不必脱掉它的衣服或撕掉它四肢的肉来获得柔软表面下的坚固结构。但是你必须用 X 光的眼光来阅读这本书，因为它是你理解任何一本书的重要组成部分，以掌握其结构。

A book comes to you with flesh on its bare bones and clothes over its flesh. It is all dressed up. You do not have to undress it or tear the flesh off its limbs to get at the firm structure that underlies the soft surface. But you must read the book with X-ray eyes, for it is an essential part of your apprehension of any book to grasp its structure.

认识到需要查看一本书的结构会导致发现阅读任何一本书的第二条和第三条规则。我们说“任何书”。这些规则既适用于诗歌，也适用于科学，适用于任何类型的说明性作品。当然，它们的应用会有所不同，这取决于使用它们的书的种类。小说的统一性不同于政治论文的统一性；零件也不相同，或以相同的方式排序。但是，每一本值得一读的书都毫无例外地具有整体性和组织性。一本没有的书会一团糟。这将是相对不可读的，因为坏书实际上是这样。

Recognition of the need to see the structure of a book leads to the discovery of the second and third rules for reading any book. We say “any book.” These rules apply to poetry as well as to science, and to any kind of expository work. Their application will be different, of course, according to the kind of book they are used on. The unity of a novel is not the same as the unity of a treatise on politics; nor are the parts of the same sort, or ordered in the same way. But every book without exception that is worth reading at all has a unity and an organization of parts. A book that did not would be a mess. It would be relatively unreadable, as bad books actually are.

我们将尽可能简单地说明这两个规则。然后我们将解释和说明它们。

We will state these two rules as simply as possible. Then we will explain and illustrate them.

分析阅读的第二条规则可以表述如下： 规则2.用 A陈述整本书的整体性一句话，或至多几句话（一小段）。

The second rule of analytical reading can be expressed as follows: RULE 2. STATE THE UNITY OF THE WHOLE BOOK IN A SINGLE SENTENCE, OR AT MOST A FEW SENTENCES (A SHORT PARAGRAPH).

这意味着你必须尽可能简短地说出整本书的内容。说整本书讲的是什么，并不等于说这本书是什么样的书。（规则 1 涵盖了这一点。）“关于”一词在这里可能会产生误导。从某种意义上说，一本书是关于某种类型的主题，它以某种方式处理。如果你知道这一点，你就知道这是一本什么样的书。但是还有另一种更口语化的“关于”。我们问一个人他在做什么，他在做什么。所以我们可以想知道作者在做什么，他想做什么。从这个意义上说，找出一本书是关于什么的，就是发现它的主题或要点。

This means that you must say what the whole book is about as briefly as possible. To say what the whole book is about is not the same as saying what kind of book it is. (That was covered by Rule 1.) The word “about” may be misleading here. In one sense, a book is about a certain type of subject matter, which it treats in a certain way. If you know this, you know what kind of book it is. But there is another, more colloquial sense of “about.” We ask a person what he is about, what he is up to. So we can wonder what an author is up to, what he is trying to do. To find out what a book is about in this sense is to discover its theme or main point.

一本书是一件艺术品。（再一次，我们想警告你不要对“艺术”有过于狭隘的概念。我们在这里不是指，或者我们不仅仅是指“美术”。一本书是具有一定制作技能的人的产物. 他是书籍的制造者，他为了我们的利益在这里制作了一本书。）作为一本书和一件艺术品，它有多好，它就具有更近乎完美、更普遍的统一性。音乐和绘画如此，小说和戏剧如此；传达知识的书籍也是如此。

A book is a work of art. (Again, we want to warn you against too narrow a conception of “art.” We do not mean, or we do not only mean, “fine art” here. A book is the product of someone who has a certain skill in making. He is a maker of books and he has made one here for our benefit.) In proportion as it is good, as a book and as a work of art, it has a more nearly perfect, a more pervasive unity. This is true of music and paintings, of novels and plays; it is no less true of books that convey knowledge.

但仅仅含糊地承认这个事实是不够的。你必须理解确定性的统一性。只有一种方法可以知道您已经成功。你必须能够用几句话告诉自己或其他人什么是团结。（如果需要太多的话，你看到的不是统一而是多样性。） 不要满足于无法表达的“感受统一”。说“我知道它是什么，但我就是不能说”的读者可能连自己都骗不了。

But it is not enough to acknowledge this fact vaguely. You must apprehend the unity with definiteness. There is only one way to know that you have succeeded. You must be able to tell yourself or anybody else what the unity is, and in a few words. (If it requires too many words, you have not seen the unity but a multiplicity.) Do not be satisfied with “feeling the unity” that you cannot express. The reader who says, “I know what it is, but I just can’t say it,” probably does not even fool himself.

第三条规则可以表述如下： 规则3.列出本书的主要部分，并说明这些部分是如何组织成一个整体的，通过彼此有序和整体的统一。

The third rule can be expressed as follows: RULE 3. SET FORTH THE MAJOR PARTS OF THE BOOK, AND SHOW HOW THESE ARE ORGANIZED INTO A WHOLE, BY BEING ORDERED TO ONE ANOTHER AND TO THE UNITY OF THE WHOLE.

这条规则的原因应该是显而易见的。如果一个作品艺术是绝对简单的，当然，它没有任何部分。但事实并非如此。人类所知道的任何可感知的物理事物都不是这种绝对简单的，任何人类生产也不是。它们都是复杂的统一体。如果你只知道它是怎样的，你就没有掌握一个复杂的统一体。你还必须知道它有多少，不是由许多独立的东西组成的多，而是有组织的多。如果各个部分没有有机的联系，那么它们所组成的整体就不是一个整体。严格来说，根本没有整体，只有一个集合。

The reason for this rule should be obvious. If a work of art were absolutely simple, it would, of course, have no parts. But that is never the case. None of the sensible, physical things man knows is simple in this absolute way, nor is any human production. They are all complex unities. You have not grasped a complex unity if all you know about it is how it is one. You must also know how it is many, not a many that consists of a lot of separate things, but an organized many. If the parts were not organically related, the whole that they composed would not be one. Strictly speaking, there would be no whole at all but merely a collection.

一方面是一堆砖头，另一方面是它们可以构成的单栋房屋之间存在差异。单独的房子和房子的集合是有区别的。一本书就像一座房子。它是一座豪宅，房间很多，房间高低不一，大小不一，形状各异，景色各异，用途各异。房间是独立的，部分。每个都有自己的结构和内部装饰。但它们并不是绝对独立和分开的。它们由门和拱门、走廊和楼梯以及建筑师所说的“交通模式”连接起来。因为它们是相互联系的，所以每个人执行的部分功能都会为整个房子的实用性做出贡献。不然房子就住不下去了。

There is a difference between a heap of bricks, on the one hand, and the single house they can constitute, on the other. There is a difference between a single house and a collection of houses. A book is like a single house. It is a mansion having many rooms, rooms on different levels, of different sizes and shapes, with different outlooks, with different uses. The rooms are independent, in part. Each has its own structure and interior decoration. But they are not absolutely independent and separate. They are connected by doors and arches, by corridors and stairways, by what architects call a “traffic pattern.” Because they are connected, the partial function that each performs contributes its share to the usefulness of the whole house. Otherwise the house would not be livable.

这个类比几乎是完美的。一本好书，就像一座好房子，是各部分排列有序的。每个主要部分都有一定的独立性。正如我们将要看到的，它可能有自己的内部结构，并且可能以不同于其他部分的方式进行装饰。但它也必须与其他部分相连——也就是说，在功能上与它们相关——否则它就不会对整体的可理解性做出贡献。

The analogy is almost perfect. A good book, like a good house, is an orderly arrangement of parts. Each major part has a certain amount of independence. As we will see, it may have an interior structure of its own, and it may be decorated in a different way from other parts. But it must also be connected with the other parts—that is, related to them functionally—for otherwise it would not contribute its share to the intelligibility of the whole.

正如房屋或多或少宜居，书籍或多或少可读。最具可读性的书是作者的建筑成就。最好的书是那些结构最容易理解的书。尽管它们通常比较差的书更复杂，但它们的复杂性更高也更加简单，因为它们的部分组织得更好，更统一。

As houses are more or less livable, so books are more or less readable. The most readable book is an architectural achievement on the part of the author. The best books are those that have the most intelligible structure. Though they are usually more complex than poorer books, their greater complexity is also a greater simplicity, because their parts are better organized, more unified.

这就是为什么最好的书也是最易读的原因之一。小作品读起来确实比较麻烦。然而，要读好它们——也就是说，尽可能读懂它们——你必须设法在其中找到一些计划。如果他们的作者自己能更清楚地看到计划，他们会成为更好的书。但如果它们完全结合在一起，如果它们在某种程度上是一个复杂的统一体而不仅仅是集合，那么就必须有一个计划，你必须找到它。

That is one of the reasons why the best books are also the most readable. Lesser works are really more bothersome to read. Yet to read them well—that is, as well as they can be read—you must try to find some plan in them. They would have been better books if their authors had themselves seen the plan a little more clearly. But if they hang together at all, if they are a complex unity to any degree and not mere collections, there must be a plan and you must find it.

情节和计划：陈述一本书的统一性

Of Plots and Plans: Stating the Unity of a Book

 

现在让我们回到第二条规则，它要求你陈述一本书的整体性。对规则的一些说明可能会指导您将其付诸实践。

Let us return now to the second rule, which requires you to state the unity of a book. A few illustrations of the rule in operation may guide you in putting it into practice.

让我们从一个著名的案例开始。你可能在学校读过荷马的奥德赛。如果没有，您一定知道奥德修斯或罗马人对他的称呼尤利西斯的故事，这个男人花了十年时间才从特洛伊围城中回来，却发现他忠实的妻子佩内洛普自己也被追求者围困。正如荷马所讲述的那样，这是一个精心制作的故事，充满了激动人心的陆地和海洋冒险，充满了各种各样的情节和许多复杂的情节。但它也有一个单一的行动统一体，一个将一切联系在一起的主线情节。

Let us begin with a famous case. You probably read Homer’s Odyssey in school. If not, you must know the story of Odysseus, or Ulysses, as the Romans call him, the man who took ten years to return from the siege of Troy only to find his faithful wife Penelope herself besieged by suitors. It is an elaborate story as Homer tells it, full of exciting adventures on land and sea, replete with episodes of all sorts and many complications of plot. But it also has a single unity of action, a main thread of plot that ties everything together.

亚里士多德在他的《诗学》中坚持认为这是每一个好故事、小说或戏剧的标志。为了支持他的观点，他展示了如何用几句话来概括奥德赛的统一性。

Aristotle, in his Poetics, insists that this is the mark of every good story, novel, or play. To support his point, he shows how the unity of the Odyssey can be summarized in a few sentences.

某男多年不在家；他被波塞冬嫉妒地注视着，孤零零地离开了。与此同时，他的家也陷入了困境；追求者正在浪费他的财产并密谋反对他的儿子。最后，他本人在暴风雨中来了；他让某些人认识了他；他亲手攻击求婚者，并在消灭求婚者时保全了自己。

A certain man is absent from home for many years; he is jealously watched by Poseidon, and left desolate. Meanwhile his home is in a wretched plight; suitors are wasting his substance and plotting against his son. At length, tempest-tossed, he himself arrives; he makes certain persons acquainted with him; he attacks the suitors with his own hand, and is himself preserved while he destroys them.

“这，”亚里士多德说，“是情节的精髓；剩下的就是插曲了。”

“This,” says Aristotle, “is the essence of the plot; the rest is episode.”

这样你知道了情节之后，通过它把整个叙述统一起来，你就可以把各个部分放在适当的位置了。你可能会发现用你读过的一些小说来尝试这个是一个很好的练习。在一些好的作品上尝试一下，例如菲尔丁的汤姆琼斯或陀思妥耶夫斯基的罪与罚或乔伊斯的现代尤利西斯。汤姆琼斯的情节，例如，可以简化为熟悉的公式：男孩遇到女孩，男孩失去女孩，男孩得到女孩。这确实是每部浪漫故事的情节。认识到这一点，就是了解世界上只有少数情节是什么意思。具有相同基本情节的好故事和坏故事之间的区别在于作者如何处理它，他如何打扮裸露的骨头。

After you know the plot in this way, and through it the unity of the whole narrative, you can put the parts into their proper places. You might find it a good exercise to try this with some novels you have read. Try it on some good ones, such as Fielding’s Tom Jones or Dostoevsky’s Crime and Punishment or Joyce’s modern Ulysses. The plot of Tom Jones, for instance, can be reduced to the familiar formula: Boy meets girl, boy loses girl, boy gets girl. That, indeed, is the plot of every romance. To recognize this is to learn what it means to say that there are only a small number of plots in the world. The difference between good and bad stories having the same essential plot lies in what the author does with it, how he dresses up the bare bones.

您不必总是自己找出一本书的统一性。作者经常帮助你。有时，标题就是您必须阅读的全部内容。在 18 世纪，作家们习惯于精心编写标题，告诉读者整本书的内容。这是杰里米·科利尔 (Jeremy Collier) 的书名，他是一位英国神学家，他攻击了他认为是淫秽的东西——我们可以说色情，也许是——比现在的习俗更博学的复辟戏剧：英国人的不道德和亵渎的简短看法舞台，连同这种争论的古老感。从这里你可以猜到，科利尔列举了许多公然滥用道德的例子，并且他通过引用古人的文本来支持他的抗议，这些古人认为，就像柏拉图那样，舞台腐蚀了年轻人，或者像早期教父所做的那样，戏剧是肉体和魔鬼的诱惑。

You do not always have to find out the unity of a book all by yourself. The author often helps you. Sometimes, the title is all you have to read. In the eighteenth century, writers had the habit of composing elaborate titles that told the reader what the whole book was about. Here is a title by Jeremy Collier, an English divine who attacked what he considered to be the obscenity—we would say pornography, perhaps—of Restoration drama much more learnedly than is customary nowadays: A Short View of the Immorality and Profaneness of the English Stage, together with the Sense of Antiquity upon this Argument. You can guess from this that Collier recites many flagrant instances of the abuse of morals and that he supports his protest by quoting texts from those ancients who argued, as Plato did, that the stage corrupts youth, or, as the early Church fathers did, that plays are seductions of the flesh and the devil.

有时作者会告诉你他的计划在他的作品中的统一性前言。在这方面，说明性书籍与小说截然不同。科学或哲学作家没有理由让你悬而未决。事实上，他给你留下的悬念越少，你就越有可能坚持读完他的作品。就像报纸文章一样，说明性书籍可能会在第一段中进行自我总结。

Sometimes the author tells you the unity of his plan in his preface. In this respect, expository books differ radically from fiction. A scientific or philosophical writer has no reason to keep you in suspense. In fact, the less suspense he keeps you in, the more likely you are to sustain the effort of reading him through. Like a newspaper article, an expository book may summarize itself in its first paragraph.

如果作者愿意提供帮助，请不要过于骄傲地接受，但也不要完全依赖他在前言中所说的内容。作者精心设计的计划，就像老鼠和其他人的计划一样，经常会出错。以作者给你的说明书为指导，但永远记住，找到统一性的义务最终属于读者，就像拥有统一性的义务属于作者一样。只有通读整本书，你才能诚实地履行这一义务。

Do not be too proud to accept the author’s help if he proffers it, but do not rely too completely on what he says in the preface, either. The best-laid plans of authors, like those of mice and other men, often go awry. Be guided by the prospectus the author gives you, but always remember that the obligation of finding the unity belongs finally to the reader, as much as the obligation of having one belongs to the writer. You can discharge that obligation honestly only by reading the whole book.

希罗多德 (Herodotus) 的希腊人和波斯人之间的战争史的介绍性段落提供了对整体的极好总结。它运行：

The introductory paragraph of Herodotus’ history of the war between the Greeks and the Persians provides an excellent summary of the whole. It runs:

这些是希罗多德 (Herodotus) 对哈利卡纳苏斯 (Halicarnassus) 的研究，他发表了这些研究，希望借此保护人们对人类所做的事不朽的记忆，并防止希腊人和野蛮人的伟大而奇妙的行为失去应有的价值荣耀; 并记录他们不和的理由是什么。

These are the researches of Herodotus- of Halicarnassus, which he publishes, in the hope of thereby preserving from decay the remembrance of what men have done, and of preventing the great and wonderful actions of the Greeks and the Barbarians from losing their due meed of glory; and withal to put on record what were their grounds of feud.

这对作为读者的你来说是一个好的开始。它简洁地告诉你整本书的内容。

That is a good beginning for you as a reader. It tells you succinctly what the whole book is about.

但你最好不要停在那里。在您通读了希罗多德历史的九个部分之后，您可能会发现有必要详细说明该陈述以公平对待整体。你可能想提到波斯国王——居鲁士、大流士和薛西斯；战争中的希腊英雄——主要是地米斯托克利；以及重大事件——渡过赫勒斯滂海峡和决定性的战役，尤其是温泉关和萨拉米斯战役。

But you had better not stop there. After you have read the nine parts of Herodotus’ history through, you will probably find it necessary to elaborate on that statement to do justice to the whole. You might want to mention the Persian kings-Cyrus, Darius, and Xerxes; the Greek heroes of the war—primarily Themistocles; and the major events—the crossing of the Hellespont and the decisive battles, notably Thermopylae and Salamis.

所有其余的迷人细节，希罗多德为他的高潮做好充分的准备，可以从您的情节摘要中删除。请注意，在这里，历史的统一性是单一的情节线索，很像小说。就统一性而言，这种阅读规则在历史和小说中引出了同样的答案。

All the rest of the fascinating details, with which Herodotus richly prepares you for his climax, can be left out of your summary of the plot. Note, here, that the unity of a history is a single thread of plot, very much as in fiction. So far as unity is concerned, this rule of reading elicits the same kind of answer in history and in fiction.

再举几个例子就足够了。让我们先看一本实用的书。亚里士多德伦理学的统一性可以这样表述：

A few more illustrations may suffice. Let us take a practical book first. The unity of Aristotle’s Ethics can be stated thus:

这是对人类幸福的本质的探究和对幸福可能获得或失去的条件的分析，并指出人们在行为和思想上必须做什么才能变得幸福或避免不幸，主要强调培养美德，包括道德和智力，尽管其他物品也被认为是幸福所必需的，例如财富、健康、朋友和一个公正的社会。

This is an inquiry into the nature of human happiness and an analysis of the conditions under which happiness may be gained or lost, with an indication of what men must do in their conduct and thinking in order to become happy or to avoid unhappiness, the principal emphasis being placed on the cultivation of the virtues, both moral and intellectual, although other goods are also recognized as necessary for happiness, such as wealth, health, friends, and a just society in which to live.

另一本实用的书是亚当·斯密的《国富论》。在这里，作者在一开始就对“作品的计划”做出了自己的陈述，这对读者很有帮助。但这需要好几页。单位可以更简要地表述如下：

Another practical book is Adam Smith’s The Wealth of Nations. Here the reader is aided by the author’s own statement of “the plan of the work” at the very beginning. But that takes several pages. The unity can be more briefly stated as follows:

这是对任何建立在劳动分工基础上的经济体的国民财富来源的探究，考虑到支付劳动的工资、返还资本的利润和欠地主的租金之间的关系，作为分工的主要因素。商品价格。它讨论了资本可以或多或少获得收益的各种方式，并将货币的来源和使用与资本的积累和使用联系起来。它考察了不同国家和不同条件下富裕的发展，比较了几种政治经济学体系，并论证了自由贸易的好处。

This is an inquiry into the source of national wealth in any economy that is built on a division of labor, considering the relation of the wages paid labor, the profits returned to capital, and the rent owed the landowner, as the prime factors in the price of commodities. It discusses the various ways in which capital can be more or less gainfully employed, and relates the origin and use of money to the accumulation and employment of capital. Examining the development of opulence in different nations and under different conditions, it compares the several systems of political economy, and argues for the beneficence of free trade.

如果读者以这种方式理解《国富论》的统一性，并为马克思的《资本论》做类似的工作，他将很容易看到过去两个世纪最有影响力的两本书之间的关系。

If a reader grasped the unity of The Wealth of Nations in this way, and did a similar job for Marx’s Das Kapital, he would be well on the way toward seeing the relation between two of the most influential books of the past two centuries.

达尔文的《物种起源》为我们提供了科学理论书籍统一性的一个很好的例子。这是它的声明：

Darwin’s The Origin of Species provides us with a good example of the unity of a theoretical book in science. Here is a statement of it:

这是对无数世代过程中生物变异的描述，以及这种变异导致动植物新分类的方式；它既处理家养动物的变异性，也处理自然条件下的变异性，展示生存斗争和自然选择等因素如何运作以产生和维持这种群体；它认为物种不是固定不变的群体，而只是从较不明显的状态过渡到更显着和永久状态的变种，地壳中发现的已灭绝动物的证据以及比较胚胎学和解剖学的证据支持了这一论点.

This is an account of the variation of living things during the course of countless generations and the way in which this results in new groupings of plants and animals; it treats both of the variability of domesticated animals and of variability under natural conditions, showing how such factors as the struggle for existence and natural selection operate to bring about and sustain such groupings; it argues that species are not fixed and immutable groups, but that they are merely varieties in transition from a less to a more marked and permanent status, supporting this argument by evidences from extinct animals found in the earth’s crust, and from comparative embryology and anatomy.

这看起来似乎是一大口，但对于 19 世纪的许多读者来说，这本书的篇幅更大，部分原因是他们没有费心去找出它真正讲的是什么。

That may seem like a big mouthful, but the book was an even bigger one for a great many readers in the nineteenth century, partly because they did not go to the trouble of finding out what it was really about.

最后，让我们把洛克的《人类理解论》作为哲学理论著作来看待。你可能还记得我们观察到洛克自己总结他的工作时说这是“对人类知识的起源、确定性和广度的探究，以及信仰、意见和同意的基础和程度”。我们不会对作者如此出色的计划陈述争论不休，除了添加两个从属条件以公正地对待文章的第一部分和第三部分：我们会补充说，它将表明，没有先天的想法，但所有人类知识都是从经验中获得的；语言将作为表达思想的媒介进行讨论，它的正确使用和最常见的滥用将被指出。

Finally, let us take Locke’s Essay Concerning Human Understanding as a theoretical book in philosophy. You may recall our observing that Locke himself summarized his work by saying that it was “an inquiry into the origin, certainty and extent of human knowledge, together with the grounds and degrees of belief, opinion and assent.” We would not quarrel with so excellent a statement of plan by the author, except to add two subordinate qualifications to do justice to the first and third parts of the essay: it will be shown, we would add, that there are no innate ideas, but that all human knowledge is acquired from experience; and language will be discussed as a medium for the expression of thought, its proper use and most familiar abuses to be indicated.

在我们继续之前，我们希望您注意两件事。第一个是你多久可以期望作者，尤其是一位好作者，帮助你陈述他的书的计划。尽管如此，如果你问，大多数读者都会完全不知所措他们简要说明整本书的内容。部分原因是由于普遍无法说简洁的英语句子。部分原因是在阅读时忽视了这条规则。但这也表明，许多读者很少关注作者的介绍性文字，就像他们通常关注他的标题一样。

There are two things we want you to note before we proceed. The first is how frequently you can expect the author, especially a good one, to help you to state the plan of his book. Despite that fact, most readers are at a total loss if you ask them to say briefly what the whole book is about. Partly this is owing to the widespread inability to speak concise English sentences. Partly it is owing to neglect of this rule in reading. But it also indicates that many readers pay as little attention to the author’s introductory words as they ordinarily do to his title.

第二点是谨慎的话。不要把我们给你的样本摘要当成它们在每种情况下都是本书整体性的最终和绝对表述。单位可以有不同的表述。没有一种正确的方法可以做到这一点。当然，一种说法优于另一种说法，与它的简短、准确和全面成正比。但是完全不同的陈述可能同样好，也可能同样坏。

The second point is a word of caution. Do not take the sample summaries we have given you as if they were, in each case, a final and absolute formulation of the book’s unity. A unity can be variously stated. There is no one right way to do it. One statement is better than another, of course, in proportion as it is brief, accurate, and comprehensive. But quite different statements may be equally good, or equally bad.

有时我们在这里陈述一本书的整体性与作者的表达完全不同，并且没有向他道歉。您可能与我们有类似的不同。毕竟，一本书对每个读者来说都是不同的。如果这种差异以读者陈述其统一性的方式表达出来，那就不足为奇了。然而，这并不意味着一切都会发生。尽管读者不同，但这本书是一样的，可以客观地检查任何人对它所做的陈述的准确性和保真度。

We have here sometimes stated the unity of a book quite differently from the author’s expression of it, and without apologies to him. You may differ similarly from us. After all, a book is something different to each reader. It would not be surprising if that difference expressed itself in the way the reader stated its unity. This does not mean, however, that anything goes. Though readers are different, the book is the same, and there can be an objective check upon the accuracy and fidelity of the statements anyone makes about it.

掌握多样性：一本书的大纲艺术

Mastering the Multiplicity: The Art of Outlining a Book

 

现在让我们转向另一个结构规则，这个规则要求我们按顺序和关系列出全书的主要部分。第三条规则与第二条规则密切相关。说得好，是指组成整体的主要部分；如果不以某种方式看到它的部分，你就无法理解一个整体。但同样真实的是，除非你掌握其部分的组织，否则你无法全面了解整体。

Let us turn now to the other structural rule, the rule that requires us to set forth the major parts of the book in their order and relation. This third rule is closely related to the second. A well-stated unity indicates the major parts that compose the whole; you cannot comprehend a whole without somehow seeing its parts. But it is also true that unless you grasp the organization of its parts, you cannot know the whole comprehensively.

那么，为什么在这里制定两条规则而不是一条呢？它主要是方便的问题。分两步比一步更容易掌握一个复杂而统一的结构。第二条规则将你的注意力引向一本书的统一性，第三条规则将你的注意力引向一本书的复杂性。分开还有一个原因。当你掌握一本书的整体性时，可能会看到一本书的主要部分。但是这些零件本身通常很复杂，并且具有您必须看到的内部结构。因此，第三条规则涉及的不仅仅是部分的列举。这意味着勾勒出它们的轮廓，也就是说，将部分视为从属的整体，每个部分都有其自身的统一性和复杂性。

Why, then, make two rules here instead of one? It is primarily a matter of convenience. It is easier to grasp a complex and unified structure in two steps than in one. The second rule directs your attention toward the unity, the third toward the complexity, of a book. There is another reason for the separation. The major parts of a book may be seen at the moment when you grasp its unity. But these parts are themselves usually complex and have an interior structure you must see. Hence the third rule involves more than just an enumeration of the parts. It means outlining them, that is, treating the parts as if they were subordinate wholes, each with a unity and complexity of its own.

可以根据这第三条规则规定一个公式。它将以一般方式指导您。根据第二条规则，我们不得不说：整本书都是关于某某某某的。完成后，我们可以按照以下步骤遵守第三条规则：（1）作者分五个主要部分完成了这个计划，其中第一部分是关于某某，第二部分是关于某某，第三部分是关于这个的，第四部分是关于那个的，第五部分是关于另一件事的。(2) 这些主要部分的第一部分分为三个部分，其中第一部分考虑 X，第二部分考虑 Y，第三部分考虑 Z。 (3) 在第一部分的第一部分，作者提出了四点，其中第一个是A，第二个是B，第三个是C，第四个是D。依此类推。

A formula can be stated for operating according to this third rule. It will guide you in a general way. According to the second rule, we had to say: The whole book is about so and so and such and such. That done, we might obey the third rule by proceeding as follows: (1) The author accomplished this plan in five major parts, of which the first part is about so and so, the second part is about such and such, the third part is about this, the fourth part about that, and the fifth part about still another thing. (2) The first of these major parts is divided into three sections, of which the first considers X, the second considers Y, and the third considers Z. (3) In the first section of the first part, the author makes four points, of which the first is A, the second B, the third C, and the fourth D. And so on and so forth.

你可能反对这么多概述。以这种方式阅读一本书将花费一生。但当然这只是一个公式。这条规则看起来好像需要你做大量的工作。事实上，优秀的读者习惯性地做这种事情，因此很容易也很自然。他可能不会全部写出来。他甚至可能在阅读的时候都没有把它全部口头表达清楚。但如果他被要求说明这本书的结构，他会做一些近似于我们所描述的公式的事情。

You may object to this much outlining. It would take a lifetime to read a book that way. But of course this is only a formula. The rule looks as if it required an impossible amount of work from you. In fact, the good reader does this sort of thing habitually, and hence easily and naturally. He may not write it all out. He may not even at the time of reading have made it all verbally explicit. But if he were called upon to give an account of the structure of the book, he would do something that approximated the formula we have described.

“近似”这个词应该可以减轻你的焦虑。一个好的规则总是描述理想的性能。但是一个人可以精通一门艺术而不是理想的艺术家。如果他只是近似规则，他可以成为一个好的练习者。我们在这里为理想情况陈述了规则。如果您对要求的内容做出非常粗略的近似，您应该会感到满意。

The word “approximation” should relieve your anxiety. A good rule always describes the ideal performance. But a person can be skilled in an art without being the ideal artist. He can be a good practitioner if he merely approximates the rule. We have stated the rule here for the ideal case. You should be satisfied if you make a very rough approximation to what is required.

即使您变得更加熟练，您也不会希望以同样的努力程度来阅读每本书。你不会发现在某些书上耗尽你所有的技能是无利可图的。即使是最优秀的读者也只会尝试对相对较少的几本书做出相当接近该规则要求的近似值。大多数情况下，他们对本书结构的粗略概念感到满意。近似的程度因书的性质和阅读目的而异。不管这种可变性如何，规则保持不变。你必须知道如何遵循它，无论你是严格遵循它还是粗略地遵循它。

Even when you become more skilled, you will not want to read every book with the same degree of effort. You will not find it profitable to expend all your skill on some books. Even the best readers try to make a fairly close approximation to the requirements of this rule for only a relatively few books. For the most part, they are satisfied with a rough notion of the book’s structure. The degree of approximation varies with the character of the book and your purpose in reading it. Regardless of this variability, the rule remains the same. You must know how to follow it, whether you follow it closely or only in a rough fashion.

您应该明白，对您可以接近规则的程度的限制不仅仅是时间和精力的限制。你是一个有限的、终有一死的生物；但是一本书也是有限的，即使不是凡人，至少在人类创造的所有事物的方式上都是有缺陷的。没有一本书值得拥有完美的大纲，因为没有一本书是完美的。它只到此为止，您也必须如此。毕竟，这条规则并不要求你把作者没有放在那里的东西放到书中。你的大纲是关于书本身的，而不是书的主题。也许一个主题的大纲可以无限期地扩展，但你的书的大纲不能，它只是或多或少地给出了主题的确定性处理。因此，你不应该觉得我们只是在敦促你偷懒遵守这条规则。

You should understand that the limitations on the degree to which you can approximate the rule are not only ones of time and effort. You are a finite, mortal creature; but a book is also finite and, if not mortal, at least defective in the way all things made by man are. No book deserves a perfect outline because no book is perfect. It goes only so far, and so must you. This rule, after all, does not call for your putting things into the book that the author did not put there. Your outline is of the book itself, not the subject matter that the book is about. Perhaps the outline of a subject matter could be extended indefinitely, but not your outline of the book, which gives the subject matter only more or less definitive treatment. Hence you should not feel that we are urging you merely to be lazy about following this rule. You could not follow it out to the bitter end even if you wanted to.

公式中规定各部分的顺序和关系的令人生畏的方面可能会通过一些规则运行中的说明而有所减轻。不幸的是，说明这条规则比说明统一性的另一条规则更难。毕竟，一个统一可以用一句话来表述或两个，最多一小段。但是，对于一本庞大而复杂的书，要对各个部分、它们的各个部分以及它们的各个部分细化到可理解和值得识别的最小结构单元进行仔细和充分的概述，将需要很多页才能写出来。

The forbidding aspect of the formula for setting forth the order and relation of the parts may be somewhat lessened by a few illustrations of the rule in operation. Unfortunately, it is more difficult to illustrate this rule than the other one about stating the unity. A unity, after all, can be stated in a sentence or two, at most a short paragraph. But in the case of a large and complex book, a careful and adequate outline of the parts, and their parts, and their parts down to the least structural unit that is comprehensible and worthwhile identifying, would take a great many pages to write out.

理论上，轮廓可以比原来的更长。一些伟大的中世纪对亚里士多德作品的评论比他们评论的作品还要长。当然，它们包括的不仅仅是大纲，因为它们承诺逐句解释作者。某些现代评论也是如此，例如康德的《纯粹理性批判》中的伟大评论。莎士比亚戏剧的集译本包括详尽的大纲和其他内容，长度是原版的好几倍——也许是十倍。如果你想看到所遵循的规则尽可能接近完美，你可以查看此类评论。例如，阿奎那在他的评论的每一部分开始时，都以优美的轮廓概述了亚里士多德在其著作的特定部分中提出的观点；他总是明确地说出那个部分是如何适应整体结构的，尤其是与前后部分相关的部分。

Theoretically, the outline could be longer than the original. Some of the great medieval commentaries on the works of Aristotle are longer than the works they comment on. They include, of course, more than an outline, for they undertake to interpret the author sentence by sentence. The same is true of certain modern commentaries, such as the great ones on Kant’s Critique of Pure Reason. And a variorum edition of a Shakespeare play, which includes an exhaustive outline as well as other things, is many times as long—perhaps ten times as long —as the original. You might look into a commentary of this sort if you want to see the rule followed as close to perfection as man can do. Aquinas, for instance, begins each section of his commentary with a beautiful outline of the points that Aristotle has made in a particular part of his work; and he always says explicitly how that part fits the structure of the whole, especially in relation to the parts that come before and after.

让我们看一些比亚里士多德的论文更简单的东西。亚里士多德可能是最紧凑的散文作家。你会认为他的一部作品的大纲会是广泛而困难的。让我们也同意，为了示例的缘故，如果我们有大量可用页面，我们将不会将流程进行到相对完美的程度。

Let us take something easier than a treatise of Aristotle. Aristotle is probably the most compact of prose writers; you would expect that an outline of one of his works would be extensive and difficult. Let us also agree that, for the sake of the example, we will not carry the process out to the relative perfection that would be possible if we had a great number of pages available.

美国宪法是一份有趣、实用的文件，也是一篇条理分明的文章。如果你检查它，你应该不难找到它的主要部分。它们被非常清楚地指示出来，尽管你必须做一些思考才能做出主要的划分。以下是该文件的建议大纲：

The United States Constitution is an interesting, practical document, and a very well-organized piece of writing. If you examine it, you should have no difficulty in finding its major parts. They are pretty clearly indicated, though you have to do some thinking to make the main divisions. Here is a suggested outline of the document:

 

第一：序言，阐明宪法的目的；

FIRST: The Preamble, setting forth the purpose(s) of the Constitution;

第二条：第一条，涉及政府立法部门；

SECOND: The first Article, dealing with the legislative department of the government;

第三条：第二条，涉及政府行政部门；

THIRD: The second Article, dealing with the executive department of the government;

F OURTH：第三条，关于政府司法部门；

FOURTH: The third Article, dealing with the judicial department of the government;

第五条：第四条，处理州政府与联邦政府的关系；

FIFTH: The fourth Article, dealing with the relationship between the state governments and the federal government;

第六条：第五条、第六条和第七条，涉及宪法修正案、宪法作为国家最高法律的地位及其批准条款；

SIXTH: The fifth, sixth, and seventh Articles, dealing with the amendment of the Constitution, its status as the supreme law of the land, and provisions for its ratifications;

第七条：前十项修正案，构成权利法案；

SEVENTH: The first ten amendments, constituting the Bill of Rights;

E IGHTH : 迄今为止的其余修正案。

EIGHTH: The remaining amendments up to the present day.

这些是主要部门。现在让我们概述其中一个，第二条，构成宪法的第一条。与大多数其他文章一样，它分为多个部分。这是一个建议的大纲。

Those are the major divisions. Now let us outline one of them, the Second, comprising the Constitution’s first Article. Like most of the other Articles, it is divided into Sections. Here is a suggested outline.

 

II, 1: 第一节，在美国国会中建立立法权，分为参议院和众议院两个机构；

II, 1: Section I, establishing legislative powers in a Congress of the United States, divided into two bodies, a Senate and a House of Representatives;

II, 2：第 2 节和第 3 节，分别描述了众议院和参议院的组成以及议员的资格。此外，声明众议院拥有弹劾的唯一权力，而参议院拥有弹劾审判的唯一权力；

II, 2: Sections 2 and 3, respectively describing the composition of the House and Senate and stating the qualifications of members. In addition, it is stated that the House has the sole power of impeachment, while the Senate has the sole power of trying impeachments;

II, 3: 第 4 节和第 5 节，涉及国会两个分支机构的成员选举以及各自的内部组织和事务；

II, 3: Sections 4 and 5, having to do with the election of members of both branches of Congress and with the internal organization and affairs of each;

II, 4: 第 6 节，说明两个分支机构成员的津贴和报酬，并说明对成员的公务员就业的一项限制；

II, 4: Section 6, stating the perquisites and emoluments of members of both branches, and stating one limitation on civil employment of members;

II, 5: 第7节，界定政府立法部门与行政部门之间的关系，并说明总统的否决权；

II, 5: Section 7, defining the relationship between the legislative and executive departments of the government and describing the President’s veto power;

II, 6: 第 8 节，阐明国会的权力；II, 7: 第 9 节，说明对第 8 节中概述的权力的一些限制；

II, 6: Section 8, stating the powers of Congress; II, 7: Section 9, stating some limitations on the powers outlined in Section 8;

II, 8：第 10 节，说明对各州权力的限制以及它们必须将某些权力交给国会的程度。

II, 8: Section 10, stating limitations on the powers of the states and the extent to which they must give over certain powers to the Congress.

然后我们可以继续为所有其他主要部门制定类似的大纲，并在完成之后，返回依次为各节制定大纲。其中一些，例如第一条第 8 节，将需要确定许多不同的主题和子主题。

We could then proceed to make a similar outline of all the other major divisions, and, after completing that, return to outline the Sections in turn. Some of these, for example Section 8 in Article I, would require the identification of many different topics and subtopics.

当然，这只是完成这项工作的一种方式。还有很多其他的。例如，前三条可以归为一个主要部分；或者，不是对修正案进行两次分工，而是可以引入更多的主要分工，根据修正案所处理的问题对修正案进行分组。我们建议，您尝试自己将宪法划分为主要部分。比我们走得更远，并尝试说明零件的零件。你可能已经读过很多次宪法，但如果你以前没有应用过这条规则，你会发现它在文件中揭示了很多你从未见过的东西。

Of course, this is only one way of doing the job. There are many others. The first three Articles could be grouped together in one major division, for instance; or instead of two divisions with respect to the amendments, more major divisions could be introduced, grouping the amendments according to the problems they dealt with. We suggest that, you try your hand at making your own division of the Constitution into its main parts. Go even further than we did, and try to state the parts of the parts as well. You may have read the Constitution many times, but if you have not applied this rule before, you will find that it reveals much in the document that you never saw.

这是另一个例子，同样非常简短。我们已经说明了亚里士多德伦理学的统一性。现在让我们尝试对其结构进行一次近似。整体分为以下几个主要部分：第一，将幸福视为生命的目的，并将其与所有其他实用的事物联系起来进行讨论；第二，处理自愿行为的性质及其与好习惯和坏习惯形成的关系；第三，讨论道德和智力上的各种美德和恶习；第四，处理非善非恶的道德状态；第五，对待友情；第六篇也是最后一篇，讨论快乐，并完成从第一篇开始的关于人类幸福的叙述。

Here is one more example, again very brief. We have already stated the unity of Aristotle’s Ethics. Now let us attempt a first approximation of its structure. The whole is divided into the following main parts: A first, treating of happiness as the end of life, and discussing it in relation to all other practicable goods; a second, treating of the nature of voluntary action, and its relation to the formation of good and bad habits; a third, discussing the various virtues and vices, both moral and intellectual; a fourth, dealing with moral states that are neither virtuous nor vicious; a fifth, treating of friendship; and a sixth and last, discussing pleasure, and completing the account of human happiness begun in the first.

这些划分显然不对应于十伦理学书籍。因此，第一部分在第一本书中完成；第二部分贯穿第二册和第三册的前半部分；第三部分从第三册的其余部分延伸到第六册的末尾；对快乐的讨论发生在第七卷的末尾，并在第十卷的开头再次出现。

These divisions obviously do not correspond to the ten books of the Ethics. Thus, the first part is accomplished in the first book; the second part runs through Book II and the first half of Book III; the third part extends from the rest of Book III through the end of Book VI; the discussion of pleasure occurs at the end of Book VII and again at the beginning of Book X.

我们提到这一点是为了告诉你，你不需要按照章节划分来遵循一本书的表面结构。当然，该结构可能比您制定的大纲更好，但也可能更糟；无论如何，重点是制定自己的大纲。作者为了写出好书而做出了自己的贡献。你必须自己做才能读好。如果他是一个完美的作家而你是一个完美的读者，那么这两者就是一样的。随着你们中的任何一个偏离完美，各种差异将不可避免地产生。

We mention this to show you that you need not follow the apparent structure of a book as indicated by its chapter divisions. That structure may, of course, be better than the outline you develop, but it may also be worse; in any event, the point is to make your own outline. The author made his in order to write a good book. You must make yours in order to read it well. If he were a perfect writer and you a perfect reader, it would follow that the two would be the same. In proportion as either of you falls away from perfection, all sorts of discrepancies will inevitably result.

这并不意味着您应该忽略作者所做的章节标题和章节划分；我们在分析宪法时并没有忽视它们，尽管我们也没有盲目地遵循它们。它们旨在帮助您，就像标题和序言一样。但你必须将它们用作你自己活动的指南，而不是被动地依赖它们。很少有作者能完美地执行他们的计划，但一本好书中的计划往往比第一眼看到的要多。表面可能是骗人的。您必须查看它的下方才能发现真正的结构。

This does not mean that you should ignore chapter headings and sectional divisions made by the author; we did not ignore them in our analysis of the Constitution, although we did not slavishly follow them, either. They are intended to help you, just as titles and prefaces are. But you must use them as guides for your own activity, and not rely on them passively. There are few authors who execute their plan perfectly, but there is often more plan in a good book than meets the eye at first. The surface can be deceiving. You must look beneath it to discover the real structure.

发现真正的结构有多重要？我们认为非常重要。另一种说法是，如果不遵守规则 3（陈述构成该统一体的各个部分的要求），就无法有效地遵循规则 2（陈述一本书的整体性的要求）。粗略地浏览一本书，您可能能够用两三句话对它的整体性进行充分的陈述。但你不会真正知道它是否足够。读过这本书的其他人可能知道这一点，并对你的努力给予高分。但对你来说，从从你的角度来看，这只是一个很好的猜测，一个幸运的命中。这就是为什么第三条规则作为第二条规则的补充是绝对必要的。

How important is it to discover that real structure? We think very important. Another way of saying this is to say that Rule 2—the requirement that you state the unity of a book—cannot be effectively followed without obeying Rule 3—the requirement that you state the parts that make up that unity. You might, from a cursory glance at a book, be able to come up with an adequate statement of its unity in two or three sentences. But you would not really know that it was adequate. Someone else, who had read the book better, might know this, and award you high marks for your efforts. But for you, from your point of view, it would have been merely a good guess, a lucky hit. This is why the third rule is absolutely necessary as a complement to the second one.

一个非常简单的例子将说明我们的意思。刚开始说话的两岁孩子可能会说“二加二等于四”。客观上，这是一个真实的陈述；但是我们从中得出结论说这个孩子懂很多数学是错误的。事实上，孩子可能不知道这句话是什么意思，因此，尽管这句话本身就足够了，但我们不得不说孩子仍然需要在这方面进行训练。同样，您对一本书的主题或要点的猜测可能是正确的，但您仍然需要通过练习来展示您是如何以及为什么这样陈述的。因此，要求您概述一本书的各个部分，并展示它们如何举例说明和发展主题，这支持了您对本书整体性的陈述。

A very simple example will show what we mean. A two-year-old child, just having begun to talk, might say that “two plus two is four.” Objectively, this is a true statement; but we would be wrong to conclude from it that the child knew much mathematics. In fact, the child probably would not know what the statement meant, and so, although the statement by itself was adequate, we would have to say that the child still needed training in the subject. Similarly, you might be right in your guess about a book’s main theme or point, but you still need to go through the exercise of showing how and why you stated it as you did. The requirement that you outline the parts of a book, and show how they exemplify and develop the main theme, is thus supportive of your statement of the book’s unity.

阅读和写作的互惠艺术

The Reciprocal Arts of Reading and Writing

 

总的来说，我们一直在讨论的两条阅读规则看起来好像也是写作规则。当然是。写作和阅读是相互的，教学和被教学也是如此。如果作者和教师不组织他们的交流，如果他们不统一他们并整理他们的部分，那么指导读者或听众寻找统一性并揭示整体结构就没有意义。

In general, the two rules of reading that we have been discussing look as if they were rules of writing also. Of course they are. Writing and reading are reciprocal, as are teaching and being taught. If authors and teachers did not organize their communications, if they failed to unify them and order their parts, there would be no point in directing readers or listeners to search for the unity and uncover the structure of the whole.

然而，尽管规则是互惠的，但它们并没有以相同的方式得到遵守。读者试图揭开书中隐藏的骨架。作者从骨架开始，试图掩盖它。他的目的是艺术地隐藏骨架，或者换句话说，在裸露的骨头上放肉。如果他是个好作家，他不会把一具微不足道的骨架埋在一堆脂肪下；另一方面，肉也不能太薄，以免露出骨头。如果肉厚足够了，如果避免松弛，关节就会有缺陷，零件的运动就会暴露关节。

Nevertheless, although the rules are reciprocal, they are not followed in the same way. The reader tries to uncover the skeleton that the book conceals. The author starts with the skeleton and tries to cover it up. His aim is to conceal the skeleton artistically or, in other words, to put flesh on the bare bones. If he is a good writer, he does not bury a puny skeleton under a mass of fat; on the other hand, neither should the flesh be too thin, so that the bones show through. If the flesh is thick enough, and if flabbiness is avoided, the joints will be defectible and the motion of the parts will reveal the articulation.

为什么会这样？为什么一本试图以有序的方式呈现知识体系的说明性书籍不应该仅仅是主题的轮廓？原因不仅是大多数读者看不懂大纲，而且这样一本书会让自尊的读者感到厌恶，他们认为如果他能完成他的工作，作者就应该完成他的工作。不仅如此。一本书的血肉和骨架一样都是它的一部分。书籍如此，动物和人类也是如此。肉体——拼写出来的轮廓，正如我们有时所说的“读出”——增加了一个重要的维度。就动物而言，它增加了生命。正因为如此，实际上从大纲开始写这本书，无论多么详细，都会赋予作品一种原本不会拥有的生命力。

Why is this so? Why should not an expository book, one that attempts to present a body of knowledge in an ordered way, be merely an outline of the subject? The reason is not only that most readers cannot read outlines, and that such a book would be repellent to a self-respecting reader who thought that if he could do his job, the author ought to do his. There is more to it than that. The flesh of a book is as much a part of it as the skeleton. This is as true of books as it is of animals and human beings. The flesh—the outline spelled out, “read out,” as we sometimes say—adds an essential dimension. It adds life, in the case of the animal. Just so, actually writing the book from an outline, no matter how detailed, gives the work a kind of life that it would not otherwise have had.

我们可以通过回忆一篇文章应该具有统一性、清晰性和连贯性的老式格言来总结所有这一切。这确实是优秀写作的基本准则。我们在本章中讨论的两条规则与遵循该格言的写作有关。如果文字具有统一性，我们必须找到它。如果文章清晰连贯，我们必须通过找到部分的区别和顺序来欣赏它。清楚的是其轮廓的清晰度。连贯的东西在各部分的有序排列中联系在一起。

We can summarize all of this by recalling the old-fashioned maxim that a piece of writing should have unity, clarity, and coherence. That is, indeed, a basic maxim of good writing. The two rules we have been discussing in this chapter relate to writing that follows that maxim. If the writing has unity, we must find it. If the writing has clarity and coherence, we must appreciate it by finding the distinction and the order of the parts. What is clear is so by the distinctness of its outlines. What is coherent hangs together in an orderly disposition of parts.

因此，这两条规则可以用来区分制作精良的书籍和劣质书籍。如果在你获得足够的技巧之后，你再多的努力也无法理解一本书的整体性，如果你也不能辨别它的各个部分以及它们之间的关系，那么很可能这本书是一个坏的，不管它的名声如何。你不应该太快做出这个判断；也许错在你而不是书。然而，你也不应该失败并总是认为错误在你身上。事实上，无论你作为读者有什么失败，错误通常出在书中，对于大多数书来说——绝大多数——从作者没有按照这些规则写作的意义上说，这些书做得很差。

These two rules, therefore, can be used to distinguish well made books from badly made ones. If, after you have attained sufficient skill, no amount of effort on your part results in your apprehension of the unity of a book, and if you are also not able to discern its parts and their relation to one another, then very likely the book is a bad one, whatever its reputation. You should not be too quick to make this judgment; perhaps the fault is in you instead of the book. However, neither should you fail ever to make it and always assume that the fault is in you. In fact, whatever your own failings as a reader, the fault is usually in the book, for most books—the very great majority —are badly made books in the sense that their authors did not write them according to these rules.

我们可以补充说，这两条规则也可以用于阅读说明性书籍的任何重要部分，以及整个。如果所选择的部分本身是一个相对独立、复杂的整体，那么要想读懂它，就必须辨别出它的整体性和复杂性。在这里，传达知识的书籍与诗歌作品、戏剧和小说之间存在显着差异。前者的部分可以比后者的部分更加自主。说他已经“阅读足够多以理解这个想法”的小说的人并不知道他在说什么。他不可能是正确的，因为如果这部小说有任何好处，那么这个想法是整体的，并且不能缺少阅读整体。但是你可以了解亚里士多德的伦理学或达尔文的物种起源仔细阅读某些部分，尽管在这种情况下您无法遵守规则 3。

These two rules can also, we might add, be used in reading any substantial part of an expository book, as well as the whole. If the part chosen is itself a relatively independent, complex unity, its unity and complexity must be discerned for it to be well read. Here there is a significant difference between books conveying knowledge and poetical works, plays, and novels. The parts of the former can be much more autonomous than the parts of the latter. The person who says of a novel that he has “read enough to get the idea” does not know what he is talking about. He cannot be correct, for if the novel is any good at all, the idea is in the whole and cannot be found short of reading the whole. But you can get the idea of Aristotle’s Ethics or Darwin’s Origin of Species by reading some parts carefully, although you would not, in that case, be able to observe Rule 3.

发现作者的意图

Discovering the Author’s Intentions

 

我们要在本章中讨论另外一个阅读规则。可以简述一下。它几乎不需要解释，也不需要插图。如果您应用了第二条和第三条规则，它实际上会以另一种形式重复您已经完成的操作。但它是一种有用的重复，因为它把整体和部分放在另一个角度。

There is one more rule of reading that we want to discuss in this chapter. It can be stated briefly. It needs little explanation and no illustration. It really repeats in another form what you have already done if you have applied the second and third rules. But it is a useful repetition because it throws the whole and its parts into another light.

第四条规则可以这样表述： 规则4.找出作者的问题所在。一本书的作者从一个问题或一组问题开始。这本书表面上包含一个或多个答案。

This fourth rule can be stated thus: RULE 4. FIND OUT WHAT THE AUTHOR’S PROBLEMS WERE. The author of a book starts with a question or a set of questions. The book ostensibly contains the answer or answers.

作者可能会也可能不会告诉你问题是什么，并给你答案，这是他工作的成果。不管他有没有，特别是如果他没有，作为读者，你的任务就是尽可能准确地提出问题。你应该能够说明主要的本书试图回答的问题，如果主要问题很复杂并且有很多部分，您应该能够陈述从属问题。你不仅应该对所涉及的所有问题有相当充分的掌握，而且应该能够将问题按可理解的顺序排列。哪些是主要的，哪些是次要的？如果要稍后回答其他问题，则必须首先回答哪些问题？

The writer may or may not tell you what the questions were as well as give you the answers that are the fruits of his work. Whether he does or does not, and especially if he does not, it is your task as a reader to formulate the questions as precisely as you can. You should be able to state the main question that the book tries to answer, and you should be able to state the subordinate questions if the main question is complex and has many parts. You should not only have a fairly adequate grasp of all the questions involved but should also be able to put the questions in an intelligible order. Which are primary and which secondary? Which questions must be answered first, if others are to be answered later?

从某种意义上说，您可以看到这条规则是如何重复您在陈述统一性和寻找其组成部分方面已经完成的工作。但是，它实际上可以帮助您完成这项工作。换句话说，遵循第四条规则与遵守其他两条规则相结合是一个有用的程序。

You can see how this rule duplicates, in a sense, work you have already done in stating the unity and finding its parts. It may, however, actually help you to do that work. In other words, following the fourth rule is a useful procedure in conjunction with obeying the other two.

而且由于该规则比其他两个更陌生，因此它可能对您处理一本困难的书更有帮助。然而，我们要强调的是，我们并不是要你陷入批评者所说的故意谬误。认为你可以从作者所写的书中发现作者的想法是错误的。这尤其适用于文学作品；例如，试图根据哈姆雷特的证据对莎士比亚进行心理分析是一个严重的错误。然而，即使是诗歌作品，尝试说出作者想做的事情通常也是非常有帮助的。对于说明性作品，该规则具有明显的优点。然而，大多数读者，无论在其他方面多么熟练，也常常无法观察到它。结果，他们对一本书的要点或主题的构想可能极度缺乏，当然他们的结构大纲也会混乱。他们看不到一本书的统一性，因为他们看不到为什么它有这样的统一性；他们对这本书的骨架结构的理解将缺乏对它所服务的目的的理解。

And since the rule is a little more unfamiliar than the other two, it may be even more helpful to you in tackling a difficult book. We want to emphasize, however, that we do not mean for you to fall into what is called by critics the intentional fallacy. That is the fallacy of thinking you can discover what was in an author’s mind from the book he has written. This applies particularly to literary works; it is a grave error, for example, to try to psychoanalyze Shakespeare from the evidence of Hamlet. Nevertheless, even with a poetical work, it is often extremely helpful to try to say what the author was trying to do. In the case of expository works, the rule has obvious merit. And yet most readers, no matter how skilled in other respects, very often fail to observe it. As a result, their conception of a book’s main point or theme may be extremely deficient, and of course their outline of its structure will be chaotic. They will fail to see the unity of a book because they do not see why it has the unity it has; and their apprehension of the book’s skeletal structure will lack comprehension of the end that it serves.

如果你知道任何人可以就任何事情提出的问题类型，你就会变得善于发现作者的问题。它们可以简单地表述为：某物存在吗？这是什么东西？是什么导致它存在，或者它在什么条件下可以存在，或者它为什么存在？它有什么作用？它存在的后果是什么？什么是它的特征，它的典型特征？它与其他类似或不同类型的事物有什么关系？它的行为如何？这些都是理论问题。应该追求什么目的？应该选择什么方法来达到既定的目的？一个人必须做什么才能达到某个目标，顺序是什么？在这种情况下，什么是正确的，或者更好而不是更坏的事情？在什么条件下做这个比做那个更好？这些都是实际问题。

If you know the kinds of questions anyone can ask about anything, you will become adept in detecting an author’s problems. They can be formulated briefly: Does something exist? What kind of thing is it? What caused it to exist, or under what conditions can it exist, or why does it exist? What purpose does it serve? What are the consequences of its existence? What are its characteristic properties, its typical traits? What are its relations to other things of a similar sort, or of a different sort? How does it behave? These are all theoretical questions. What ends should be sought? What means should be chosen to a given end? What things must one do to gain a certain objective, and in what order? Under these conditions, what is the right thing to do, or the better rather than the worse? Under what conditions would it be better to do this rather than that? These are all practical questions.

这份问题清单远非详尽无遗，但它确实代表了在追求理论或实践知识时最常被问到的问题类型。它可以帮助您发现一本书试图解决的问题。这些问题在应用于富有想象力的文学作品时必须进行调整，它们也将是有用的。

This list of questions is far from being exhaustive, but it does represent the types of most frequently asked questions in the pursuit of theoretical or practical knowledge. It may help you discover the problems a book has tried to solve. The questions have to be adapted when applied to works of imaginative literature, and there too they will be useful.

第一阶段分析阅读

The First Stage of Analytical Reading

 

我们现在已经陈述并解释了阅读的前四个规则。它们是分析阅读的规则，但如果您在阅读一本书之前仔细检查它，那将有助于您应用它们。

We have now stated and explained the first four rules of reading. They are rules of analytical reading, although if you inspect a book well before reading it, that will help you to apply them.

在这一点上，重要的是要认识到这前四个规则是相互关联的，并形成一组具有单一目标的规则。它们一起为应用它们的读者提供了书籍结构的知识。当你将它们应用到一本书上，或者应用到你正在阅读的任何相当冗长和困难的东西时，你将完成分析阅读的第一阶段。

It is important at this point to recognize that these first four rules are connected and form a group of rules having a single aim. Together, they provide the reader who applies them with a knowledge of a book’s structure. When you have applied them to a book, or indeed to anything fairly lengthy and difficult that you may be reading, you will have accomplished the first stage of reading it analytically.

你不应该按照时间顺序来理解“阶段”这个词，除非可能是在你作为分析阅读者开始练习的时候。也就是说，不必为了应用前四个规则而通读一本书，然后为了应用其他规则而一遍又一遍地阅读它。熟练的读者一次完成所有这些阶段。然而，您必须意识到，了解一本书的结构确实构成了分析阅读它的一个阶段。

You should not take the term “stage” in a chronological sense, unless perhaps at the very beginning of your exercise as an analytical reader. That is, it is not necessary to read a book through in order to apply the first four rules, then to read it again and again in order to apply the other rules. The practiced reader accomplishes all of these stages at once. Nevertheless, you must realize that knowing a book’s structure does constitute a stage toward reading it analytically.

换句话说，应用前四个规则可以帮助你回答关于一本书的第一个基本问题。你会记得第一个问题是：整本书讲的是什么？你还会记得我们说过，这意味着发现本书的主要主题，以及作者如何通过将其细分为基本的从属主题或主题来有序地发展这个主题。显然，应用前四个阅读规则将提供你回答这个问题所需知道的大部分内容——尽管应该指出的是，当你继续应用其他规则并回答第一个问题时，你的答案会更准确。其他问题。

Another way to say this is that applying these first four rules helps you to answer the first basic question about a book. You will recall that that first question is: What is the book about as a whole? You will also recall that we said that this means discovering the leading theme of the book, and how the author develops this theme in an orderly way by subdividing it into its essential subordinate themes or topics. Clearly, applying the first four rules of reading will provide most of what you need to know in order to answer this question—although it should be pointed out that your answer will improve in accuracy as you proceed to apply the other rules and to answer the other questions.

既然我们现在已经描述了分析阅读的第一阶段，让我们暂停一下，在适当的标题下按顺序写下前四个规则，以供复习。

Since we have now described the first stage of analytical reading, let us pause a moment to write out the first four rules in order, under the appropriate heading, for review.

分析阅读的第一阶段，或寻找一本书的内容的规则

The First Stage of Analytical Reading, or Rules for Finding What a Book Is About

 

1.按种类和题材对书进行分类。

1. Classify the book according to kind and subject matter.

2. 尽可能简洁地陈述整本书的内容。

2. State what the whole book is about with the utmost brevity.

3. 按顺序和关系列举主要部分，并像概述整体一样概述这些部分。

3. Enumerate its major parts in their order and relation, and outline these parts as you have outlined the whole.

4. 定义作者试图解决的一个或多个问题。

4. Define the problem or problems the author is trying to solve.

8

与作者达成协议

8COMING TO TERMS WITH AN AUTHOR

 

当你应用了上一章末尾列出的四个规则时，分析阅读的第一阶段就完成了，这四个规则一起让你知道一本书是关于什么的，并勾勒出它的结构。您现在已准备好进入下一阶段，该阶段也包含四个阅读规则。我们将其中的第一个简称为达成协议。

The first stage of analytical reading has been accomplished when you have applied the four rules listed at the end of the last chapter, which together allow you to tell what a book is about and to outline its structure. You are now ready to go on to the next stage, which also comprises four rules of reading. The first of these we call, for short, coming to terms.

达成协议通常是任何成功的商业谈判的最后一步。剩下的就是在虚线上签名。但在一本书的分析阅读中，达成共识是超越大纲的第一步。除非读者与作者达成协议，否则知识不会从一个人传递到另一个人。因为术语是可交流知识的基本要素。

Coming to terms is usually the last step in any successful business negotiation. All that remains is to sign on the dotted line. But in the analytical reading of a book, coming to terms is the first step beyond the outline. Unless the reader comes to terms with the author, the communication of knowledge from one to the other does not take place. For a term is the basic element of communicable knowledge.

词语与术语

Words vs. Terms

 

一个术语不是一个词——至少，不仅仅是一个没有进一步限定的词。如果一个术语和一个词完全一样，你只需要在一本书中找到重要的词来理解它。但是一个词可以有多种含义，尤其是一个重要的词。如果作者以一种含义使用一个词，而读者以另一种含义阅读它，他们之间有话要说，但他们还没有达成协议。如果沟通中存在未解决的歧义，就没有沟通，或者充其量只能是不完整的沟通。

A term is not a word— at least, not just a word without further qualifications. If a term and a word were exactly the same, you would only have to find the important words in a book in order to come to terms with it. But a word can have many meanings, especially an important word. If the author uses a word in one meaning, and the reader reads it in another, words have passed between them, but they have not come to terms. Where there is unresolved ambiguity in communication, there is no communication, or at best communication must be incomplete.

看一下“沟通”这个词。它的词根与“共同”一词有关。我们说社区是一群有共同点的人。沟通是一个人与另一个人（或与动物或机器）分享某些东西的努力：他的知识、他的决定、他的情感。只有当它产生共同的东西时，它才会成功，例如两方共享的信息或知识项。

Just look at the word “communication” for a moment. Its root is related to the word “common.” We speak of a community as a group of people who have something in common. Communication is an effort on the part of one person to share something with another person (or with an animal or a machine): his knowledge, his decisions, his sentiments. It succeeds only when it results in a common something, such as an item of information or knowledge that two parties share.

当知识交流中存在歧义时，所有共同点就是一个人说或写的词和另一个人听或读的词。只要歧义持续存在，作者和读者之间就没有共同的意义。因此，要顺利完成沟通，双方就必须用同样的词、同样的意思——简言之，达成协议。当这种情况发生时，沟通就发生了，只有一个想法的两个思想的奇迹。

When there is ambiguity in the communication of knowledge, all that is in common are the words that one person speaks or writes and another hears or reads. So long as ambiguity persists, there is no meaning in common between writer and reader. For the communication to be successfully completed, therefore, it is necessary for the two parties to use the same words with the same meanings— in short, to come to terms. When that happens, communication happens, the miracle of two minds with but a single thought.

术语可以定义为明确的词。这不太准确，因为严格来说没有明确的词。我们应该说的是，术语是明确使用的词。字典里满是单词。它们几乎都是模棱两可的，因为它们有很多含义。但是一个有多种含义的词一次可以在一种意义上使用。当作者和读者以某种方式设法在一段时间内使用一个给定的词且只有一个含义时，那么，在明确使用的那段时间里，他们就达成了协议。

A term can be defined as an unambiguous word. That is not quite accurate, for strictly there are no unambiguous words. What we should have said is that a term is a word used unambiguously. The dictionary is full of words. They are almost all ambiguous in the sense that they have many meanings. But a word that has several meanings can be used in one sense at a time. When writer and reader somehow manage for a time to use a given word with one and only one meaning, then, during that time of unambiguous usage, they have come to terms.

你无法在字典中找到术语，尽管制造它们的材料就在那里。术语只发生在通信过程中。当作者试图避免歧义，而读者通过尝试理解他的用词来帮助他时，它们就会出现。当然，这方面的成功有很多种。妥协是作家和读者所追求的理想应该努力。由于这是写作和阅读艺术的主要成就之一，我们可以将术语视为为了交流知识而熟练使用单词。

You cannot find terms in dictionaries, though the materials for making them are there. Terms occur only in the process of communication. They occur when a writer tries to avoid ambiguity and a reader helps him by trying to follow his use of words. There are, of course, many degrees of success in this. Coming to terms is the ideal toward which writer and reader should strive. Since this is one of the primary achievements of the art of writing and reading, we can think of terms as a skilled use of words for the sake of communicating knowledge.

在这一点上，很明显我们只是在谈论说明文作家和说明文书籍。诗歌和小说不像说明性作品那样关注词语的明确使用——在我们一直使用的词的广义上传达知识的作品。甚至可以说，最好的诗歌是最含糊不清的诗歌，而且可以公正地说，任何一位优秀的诗人有时都会在他的作品中故意含糊不清。这是关于诗歌的一个重要见解，我们将在稍后返回。这显然是文学艺术的诗意和说明或科学领域之间的主要区别之一。

At this point it is probably clear that we are speaking exclusively of expository writers and expository books. Poetry and fiction are not nearly so concerned with the unambiguous use of words as expository works—works that convey knowledge in the broad sense of the word that we have been employing. It can even be argued that the best poetry is that which is the most richly ambiguous, and it has been said with justice that any good poet is sometimes intentionally ambiguous in his writing. This is an important insight about poetry to which we will return later. It is obviously one of the primary differences between the poetical and the expository or scientific realms of literary art.

我们现在准备陈述阅读的第五条规则（说明性作品）。粗略地说，就是：你必须找出一本书中的重要词语，并弄清楚作者是如何使用它们的。但我们可以使它更精确和优雅：规则5.找到重要的词并通过它们与作者达成协议。请注意，该规则有两个部分。第一部分是定位重要的词，即产生影响的词。第二部分是准确地确定这些词的含义。

We are now ready to state the fifth rule of reading (an expository work). Stated roughly, it is this: You must spot the important words in a book and figure out how the author is using them. But we can make that a little more precise and elegant: RULE 5. FIND THE IMPORTANT WORDS AND THROUGH THEM COME TO TERMS WITH THE AUTHOR. Note that the rule has two parts. The first part is to locate the important words, the words that make a difference. The second part is to determine the meaning of these words, as used, with precision.

这是分析阅读第二阶段的第一条规则，其目的不是概述一本书的结构，而是解释其内容或信息。这一阶段的其他规则，将在下一章讨论，在一个重要方面与本阶段相似。他们还要求你采取两个步骤：一步处理语言本身，一步超越语言，进入语言背后的思想。

This is the first rule for the second stage of analytical reading, the aim of which is not the outlining of a book’s structure but the interpretation of its contents or message. The other rules for this stage, to be discussed in the next chapter, are like this one in an important respect. They also require you to take two steps: a step dealing with the language as such, and a step beyond the language to the thought that lies behind it.

如果语言是一种纯粹而完美的思维媒介，那么这些步骤就不会分开。如果每个词都只有一个意思，如果词不能被歧义使用，如果，简而言之，每个词都是一个理想的术语，那么语言将是一种透明的中等的。读者会通过作者的文字直接看到他的思想内容。如果是这样的话，这第二阶段的分析阅读就完全没有必要了。不需要口译。

If language were a pure and perfect medium for thought, these steps would not be separate. If every word had only one meaning, if words could not be used ambiguously, if, in short, each word was an ideal term, language would be a diaphanous medium. The reader would see straight through the writer’s words to the content of his mind. If that were the case, there would be no need at all for this second stage of analytical reading. Interpretation would be unnecessary.
