但当然，事实远非如此。像哲学家莱布尼茨和他的一些追随者试图做的那样，哭泣是没有用的，为理想语言编造不可能的方案也是没有用的。事实上，如果他们成功了，就不会再有诗歌了。因此，在说明性作品中，唯一要做的就是充分利用语言的本来面目，而做到这一点的唯一方法就是在你想要传达或接受知识时尽可能熟练地使用语言.

But of course that is far from the case. There is no use crying about it, no use making up impossible schemes for an ideal language, as the philosopher Leibniz and some of his followers have tried to do. Indeed, if they succeeded, there would be no more poetry. The only thing to do, therefore, in -expository works, is to make the best of language as it is, and the only way to do that is to use language as skillfully as possible when you want to convey, or to receive, knowledge.

由于语言作为传达知识的媒介是不完美的，它也起到了交流障碍的作用。解释性阅读的规则旨在克服这一障碍。我们可以期望一位优秀的作家尽最大努力通过语言不可避免地设置的障碍来接触我们，但我们不能期望他独自完成这项工作。我们必须半途而废。我们，作为读者，必须尝试从我们这边的障碍中穿过。通过语言达成共识的可能性取决于读者和作者合作的意愿。正如除非有被教导的互惠活动，否则教学将无济于事，因此，任何作者，无论他的写作技巧如何，都无法在没有读者的互惠技能。如果不是这样，无论付出多少努力，写作和阅读的不同技巧都不会将思想聚集在一起，就像从山的对面挖隧道穿过的人永远不会相遇，除非他们根据相同的工程原理。

Because language is imperfect as a medium for conveying knowledge, it also functions as an obstacle to communication. The rules of interpretive reading are directed to overcoming that obstacle. We can expect a good writer to do his best to reach us through the barrier language inevitably sets up, but we cannot expect him to do the job all by himself. We must meet him halfway. We, as readers, must try to tunnel through from our side of the barrier. The likelihood of a meeting of minds through language depends on the willingness of both reader and writer to work together. Just as teaching will not avail unless there is a reciprocal activity of being taught, so no author, regardless of his skill in writing, can achieve communication without a reciprocal skill on the part of readers. If that were not so, the diverse skills of writing and reading would not bring minds together, however much effort was expended, any more than the men who tunnel through from opposite sides of a mountain would ever meet unless they made their calculations according to the same principles of engineering.

正如我们所指出的，解释性阅读的每条规则都涉及两个步骤。从技术角度来说，我们可以说这些规则具有语法和逻辑方面的意义。语法方面是处理单词的方面。逻辑步骤处理它们的含义，或者更准确地说，处理术语。就沟通而言，这两个步骤缺一不可。如果不假思索地使用语言，就没有任何交流。没有语言就无法交流思想或知识。作为艺术，语法和逻辑关注语言与思想的关系，以及思想与语言的关系。这就是为什么阅读和写作技能是通过这些艺术获得的。

As we have pointed out, each of the rules of interpretive reading involves two steps. To get technical for a moment, we may say that these rules have a grammatical and a logical aspect. The grammatical aspect is the one that deals with words. The logical step deals with their meanings or, more precisely, with terms. So far as communication is concerned, both steps are indispensable. If language is used without thought, nothing is being communicated. And thought or knowledge cannot be communicated without language. As arts, grammar and logic are concerned with language in relation to thought and thought in relation to language. That is why skill in both reading and writing is gained through these arts.

这种语言和思想的事务——尤其是单词和术语之间的区别——是如此重要，以至于我们将冒着重复的风险来确保要点得到理解。要点是一个词可以承载多个词，一个词可以由多个词来表达。让我们以以下方式示意性地说明这一点。在我们的讨论过程中，“阅读”一词有多种含义。让我们考虑其中的三种含义：“阅读”一词的意思可能是 (1) 阅读是为了娱乐，(2) 阅读是为了获取信息，以及 (3) 阅读是为了理解。

This business of language and thought—especially the distinction between words and terms—is so important that we are going to risk being repetitious to be sure the main point is understood. The main point is that one word can be the vehicle for many terms, and one term can be expressed by many words. Let us illustrate this schematically in the following manner. The word “reading” has been used in many senses in the course of our discussion. Let us take three of these senses: By the word “reading” we may mean (1) reading to be entertained, (2) reading to get information, and (3) reading to achieve understanding.

现在让我们用字母 X 来表示“阅读”这个词，用字母a、b和c来表示这三种含义。在这个方案中用Xa、Xb和Xc表示的不是三个词，因为X始终保持不变。但它们是三个术语，当然，条件是，作为读者的你和作为作者的我们知道什么时候X是在一种意义上而不是另一种意义上使用的。如果我们在给定的地方写Xa，而你读Xb，我们在写，你在读同一个词，但方式不同。歧义会阻止或至少阻碍沟通。只有当您像我们一样思考这个词时，我们之间才会有一个想法。我们的思想不能在 X 中相遇，而只能在Xa或Xb或Xc中相遇。这样我们就达成了协议。

Now let us symbolize the word “reading” by the letter X, and the three meanings by the letters a, b, and c. What is symbolized in this scheme by Xa, Xb, and Xc, are not three words, for X remains the same throughout. But they are three terms, on the condition, of course, that you, as reader, and we, as writers know when X is being used in one sense and not another. If we write Xa in a given place, and you read Xb, we are writing and you are reading the same word, but not in the same way. The ambiguity prevents or at least impedes communication. Only when you think the word as we think it, do we have one thought between us. Our minds cannot meet in X, but only in Xa or Xb or Xc. Thus we come to terms.

寻找关键词

Finding the Key Words

 

我们现在准备充实要求读者接受的规则。他是怎么做到的？他如何找到一本书中的重要或关键词？

We are now prepared to put flesh on the rule that requires the reader to come to terms. How does he go about doing it? How does he find the important or key words in a book?

你可以确定一件事。并非作者使用的所有词语都很重要。比这更好的是，你可以确定他的大部分话都不是。只有他以特殊方式使用的那些词对他以及对我们读者来说都是重要的。当然，这不是绝对的问题，而是程度的问题。文字可能或多或少重要。我们唯一关心的是书中的某些词比其他词更重要。一个极端是作者使用的词语就像街上众所周知的人所做的那样。既然作者在日常的话语中是像大家一样使用这些词的，那么读者应该没有问题。他熟悉它们的歧义，并且已经习惯了它们在这种情况或那种情况下出现的含义变化。

You can be sure of one thing. Not all the words an author uses are important. Better than that, you can be sure that most of his words are not. Only those words that he uses in a special way are important for him, and for us as readers. This is not an absolute matter, of course, but one of degree. Words may be more or less important. Our only concern is with the fact that some words in a book are more important than others. At one extreme are the words that the author uses as the proverbial man in the street does. Since the author is using these words as everyone does in ordinary discourse, the reader should have no trouble with them. He is familiar with their ambiguity and he has grown accustomed to the variation in their meanings as they occur in this context or that.

例如，“阅读”这个词出现在 AS Eddington 的书《物理世界的本质》中。他谈到“指针读数”，即科学仪器上刻度盘和仪表的读数。他在其中一种普通意义上使用“阅读”这个词。这对他来说不是一个技术词。他可以依靠普通用法向读者传达他的意思。即使他在书中的其他地方以不同的意义使用了“阅读”这个词——比如说，在一个短语中，比如“阅读自然”——他也可以确信读者会注意到这个词的另一个意思的转变普通的意思。做不到这一点的读者无法与他的朋友交谈或继续他的日常事务。

For example, the word “reading” occurs in A. S. Eddington’s book, The Nature of the Physical World. He speaks of “pointer-readings,” the readings of dials and gauges on scientific instruments. He is using the word “reading” in one of its ordinary senses. It is not for him a technical word. He can rely on ordinary usage to convey what he means to the reader. Even if he used the word “reading” in a different sense somewhere else in the book—in a phrase, let us say, such as “reading nature”—he could be confident that the reader would note the shift to another of the word’s ordinary meanings. The reader who could not do this could not talk to his friends or carry on his daily business.

但是爱丁顿不能这么轻松地使用“原因”这个词。这可能是一个普通话，但他在讨论因果理论时是在一个绝对特殊的意义上使用它。如何理解这个词会产生不同，他和读者都必须为此操心。出于同样的原因，“阅读”这个词在这本书中很重要。我们不能仅仅以普通的方式使用它。

But Eddington is not able to use the word “cause” so lightheartedly. That may be a word of common speech, but he is using it in a definitely special sense when he discusses the theory of causation. How that word is to be understood makes a difference that both he and the reader must bother about. For the same reason, the word “reading” is important in this book. We cannot get along with merely using it in an ordinary way.

作者使用大多数词语，就像人们通常在谈话中所做的那样，具有一系列含义，并相信上下文可以表明变化。了解这一事实有助于检测更重要的词。然而，我们不能忘记，在不同的时间和地点，相同的词在日常使用中并不是同样熟悉的项目。当代作家会使用大多数今天常用的词，你会知道这些词是什么，因为你今天还活着。但是在阅读过去写的书时，可能更难发现作者使用的词语，就像大多数人在他写作的时间和地点所做的那样。一些作者故意使用古词或词的古义这一事实使事情变得更加复杂，外语书籍的翻译也是如此。

An author uses most words as men ordinarily do in conversation, with a range of meanings, and trusting to the context to indicate the shifts. Knowing this fact is some help in detecting the more important words. We must not forget, however, that at different times and places the same words are not equally familiar items in daily usage. Contemporary writers will employ most words as they are ordinarily used today, and you will know which words these are because you are alive today. But in reading books written in the past, it may be more difficult to detect the words the author is using as most people did at the time and place he was writing. The fact that some authors intentionally employ archaic words, or archaic senses of words, complicates the matter further, as does the translation of books from foreign languages.

尽管如此，任何一本书中的大多数单词都可以像在与朋友交谈时使用的那样阅读，这仍然是事实。翻开这本书的任意一页，数一数我们以这种方式使用的单词：所有的介词、连词和冠词，以及几乎所有的动词、名词、副词和形容词。到目前为止，在本章中，只有几个重要的词：“单词”、“术语”、“歧义”、“交流”，也许还有一两个。其中，“术语”显然是最重要的；所有其他的都是重要的。

Nevertheless, it remains true that most of the words in any book can be read just as one would use them in talking to one’s friends. Take any page of this book and count the words we are using in that way: all the prepositions, conjunctions, and articles, and almost all of the verbs, nouns, adverbs, and adjectives. In this chapter so far, there have been only a few important words: “word,” “term,” ambiguity,” “communication,” and perhaps one or two more. Of these, “term” is clearly the most important; all the others are important in relation to it.

如果不努力理解出现关键词的段落，你就无法找到关键词。这种情况有些自相矛盾。如果你确实理解了这段话，你当然会知道其中哪些词是最重要的。如果你没有完全理解这篇文章，那可能是因为你不知道作者使用某些词的方式。如果你把困扰你的词标记出来，你可能会击中作者特别使用的那些词。这很可能是因为你应该不会对作者以普通方式使用的词语有任何问题。

You cannot locate the key words without making an effort to understand the passage in which they occur. This situation is somewhat paradoxical. If you do understand the passage, you will, of course, know which words in it are the most important. If you do not fully understand the passage, it is probably because you do not know the way the author is using certain words. If you mark the words that trouble you, you may hit the very ones the author is using specially. That this is likely to be so follows from the fact that you should have no trouble with the words the author uses in an ordinary way.

因此，从你作为读者的角度来看，最重要的词是那些给你带来麻烦的词。很可能这些词对作者也很重要。然而，他们可能不是。

From your point of view as a reader, therefore, the most important words are those that give you trouble. It is likely that these words are important for the author as well. However, they may not be.

也可能是对作者不打扰你，正是因为你了解他们。在这种情况下，您已经与作者达成协议。只有当你无法达成协议时，你才会继续努力。

It is also possible that words that are important for the author do not bother you, and precisely because you understand them. In that case, you have already come to terms with the author. Only where you fail to come to terms have you work still to do.

技术词汇和特殊词汇

Technical Words and Special Vocabularies

 

到目前为止，我们一直在通过消除普通词来进行消极处理。你会发现一些重要的词，因为它们对你来说并不普通。这就是他们打扰你的原因。但是有没有其他方法可以找出重要的词呢？是否有任何指向它们的积极迹象？

So far we have been proceeding negatively by eliminating the ordinary words. You discover some of the important words by the fact that they are not ordinary for you. That is why they bother you. But is there any other way of spotting the important words? Are there any positive signs that point to them?

有几个。第一个也是最明显的标志是作者明确强调某些词而不是其他词。他可以通过多种方式做到这一点。他可能会使用诸如引号或斜体之类的印刷设备来为您标记单词。他可能会通过明确讨论它的各种含义并指出他将在这里和那里使用它的方式来引起你对这个词的注意。或者他可以通过定义这个词用来命名的事物来强调这个词。

There are several. The first and most obvious sign is the explicit stress an author places upon certain words and not others. He may do this in many ways. He may use such typographical devices as quotation marks or italics to mark the word for you. He may call your attention to the word by explicitly discussing its various senses and indicating the way he is going to use it here and there. Or he may emphasize the word by defining the thing that the word is used to name.

没有人会不知道“点”、“线”、“平面”、“角”、“平行”等词是最重要的。这些是 Euclid 定义的命名几何实体的词。还有其他一些重要的词，例如“等于”、“整体”和“部分”，但这些词并未命名任何已定义的词。你知道它们很重要，因为它们出现在公理中。欧几里德通过在一开始就明确他的主要命题来帮助你。你可以猜测构成这些命题的术语是基本的，并且为你强调表达这些术语的词。你可能对这些词没有困难，因为它们是普通话，而 Euclid 似乎就是这样使用它们的。

No one can read Euclid without knowing that such words as “point,” “line,” “plane,” “angle,” “parallel,” and so forth are of the first importance. These are the words that name geometrical entities defined by Euclid. There are other important words, such as “equals,” “whole,” and “part,” but these do not name anything that is defined. You know they are important from the fact that they occur in the axioms. Euclid helps you here by making his primary propositions explicit at the very beginning. You can guess that the terms composing such propositions are basic, and that underlines for you the words that express these terms. You may have no difficulty with these words, because they are words of common speech, and Euclid appears to be using them that way.

如果所有的作者都像欧几里得那样写作，你可能会说，阅读这件事会容易得多。但这当然是这是不可能的，尽管事实上有人认为任何主题都可以用几何方式来阐述。适用于数学的程序——说明和证明的方法——并不适用于所有知识领域。无论如何，为了我们的目的，注意到每种说明的共同点就足够了。每个知识领域都有自己的技术词汇。欧几里得一开始就说得很清楚。这同样适用于任何以几何方式写作的作家，例如伽利略或牛顿。在不同编写的书籍或其他领域中，技术词汇必须由读者发现。

If all authors wrote as Euclid did, you may say, this business of reading would be much easier. But that of course is not possible, although there have in fact been men who thought that any subject matter could be expounded in the geometrical manner. The procedure—the method of exposition and proof—that works in mathematics is not applicable in every field of knowledge. In any event, for our purposes it is sufficient to note what is common to every sort of exposition. Every field of knowledge has its own technical vocabulary. Euclid makes his plain right at the beginning. The same is true of any writer, such as Galileo or Newton, who writes in the geometrical manner. In books differently written or in other fields, the technical vocabulary must be discovered by the reader.

如果作者没有亲自指出这些词，读者可以通过对主题的一些先验知识来定位它们。如果他在开始阅读达尔文或亚当·斯密之前对生物学或经济学有所了解，那么他肯定有一些线索可以辨别技术词汇。分析书籍结构的规则在这里可能会有所帮助。如果你知道这本书是什么类型，它整体上讲的是什么，它的主要部分是什么，那么你就可以将技术词汇与普通词汇区分开来。作者的标题、章节标题和前言在这方面可能会有用。

If the author has not pointed out the words himself, the reader may locate them through having some prior knowledge of the subject matter. If he knows something about biology or economics before he begins to read Darwin or Adam Smith, he certainly has some leads toward discerning the technical words. The rules of analyzing a book’s structure may help here. If you know what kind of book it is, what it is about as a whole, and what its major parts are, you are greatly aided in separating the technical vocabulary from the ordinary words. The author’s title, chapter headings, and preface may be useful in this connection.

从这里你知道，例如，“财富”是亚当·斯密的专业术语，“物种”是达尔文的专业术语。由于一个技术词会导致另一个技术词，因此您会情不自禁地以类似的方式发现其他技术词。你很快就能列出亚当·斯密使用的重要词汇：劳动力、资本、土地、工资、利润、租金、商品、价格、交换、生产性、非生产性、货币等等。这里有一些你在达尔文不能错过的东西：多样性、属、选择、生存、适应、杂交、适者生存、创造。

From this you know, for example, that “wealth” is a technical word for Adam Smith, and “species” for Darwin. Since one technical word leads to another, you cannot help but discover other technical words in a similar fashion. You can soon make a list of the important words used by Adam Smith: labor, capital, land, wages, profits, rent, commodity, price, exchange, productive, unproductive, money, and so forth. And here are some you cannot miss in Darwin: variety, genus, selection, survival, adaptation, hybrid, fittest, creation.

如果某个知识领域具有完善的技术词汇，那么在处理该主题的书中定位重要词汇的任务就相对容易了。你可以通过认识一些人来积极地发现他们领域，或消极地知道什么词必须是技术性的，因为它们不是普通的。不幸的是，有许多领域的技术词汇还没有很好地建立起来。

Where a field of knowledge has a well-established technical vocabulary, the task of locating the important words in a book treating that subject matter is relatively easy. You can spot them positively through having some acquaintance with the field, or negatively by knowing what words must be technical, because they are not ordinary. Unfortunately, there are many fields in which a technical vocabulary is not well established.

哲学家因拥有私人词汇而臭名昭著。当然，有些词在哲学上具有传统地位。尽管它们可能不会被所有作者以相同的意义使用，但它们仍然是讨论某些问题时的技术用语。但是哲学家们经常发现有必要创造新词，或者从普通话中提取一些词并将其变成一个技术词。最后一个过程可能最容易误导读者，他们认为自己知道这个词的意思，因此把它当作一个普通词来对待。然而，大多数优秀的作者都预料到这种混乱，因此在他们采用该程序时会给出非常明确的警告。

Philosophers are notorious for having private vocabularies. There are some words, of course, that have a traditional standing in philosophy. Though they may not be used by all writers in the same sense, they are nevertheless technical words in the discussion of certain problems. But philosophers often find it necessary to coin new words, or to take some word from common speech and make it a technical word. This last procedure is likely to be most misleading to the reader who supposes that he knows what the word means, and therefore treats it as an ordinary word. Most good authors, however, anticipating just this confusion, give very explicit warning whenever they adopt the procedure.

在这方面，一个重要词的线索是作者与其他作家就此争吵。当你发现一位作者告诉你某个特定的词是如何被其他人使用的，以及他为什么选择以其他方式使用它时，你可以肯定这个词对他有很大的影响。

In this connection, one clue to an important word is that the author quarrels with other writers about it. When you find an author telling you how a particular word has been used by others, and why he chooses to use it otherwise, you can be sure that word makes a great difference to him.

我们在这里强调了技术词汇的概念，但你不能把它看得太狭隘。表达作者主要思想、主要概念的相对较小的词组构成了他的专用词汇。这些话承载着他的分析，他的论点。如果他正在进行原创交流，他可能会以非常特殊的方式使用其中一些词，尽管他可能会以该领域已经成为传统的方式使用其他词。无论哪种情况，这些都是对他来说最重要的词。作为读者，它们对您也很重要，但除此之外，任何其他含义不明确的词对您也很重要。

We have here emphasized the notion of technical vocabulary, but you must not take this too narrowly. The relatively small set of words that express an author’s main ideas, his leading concepts, constitutes his special vocabulary. They are the words that carry his analysis, his argument. If he is making an original communication, some of these words are likely to be used by him in a very special way, although he may use others in a fashion that has become traditional in the field. In either case, these are the words that are most important for him. They should be important for you as a reader also, but in addition any other word whose meaning is not clear is important for you.

大多数读者的问题在于他们根本没有足够注意单词来定位他们的困难。他们无法区分他们不充分理解的词从他们所做的。我们建议的所有帮助您在书中找到重要单词的方法都将无济于事，除非您刻意努力记下您必须努力找到它们所传达的术语的单词。未能思考或至少标记出他不理解的词语的读者将走向灾难。

The trouble with most readers is that they simply do not pay enough attention to words to locate their difficulties. They fail to distinguish the words that they do not understand sufficiently from those they do. All the things we have suggested to help you find the important words in a book will be of no avail unless you make a deliberate effort to note the words you must work on to find the terms they convey. The reader who fails to ponder, or at least to mark, the words he does not understand is headed for disaster.

如果你正在阅读一本可以增加你理解力的书，那么按理说，并不是所有的文字你都能完全理解。如果你把它们当成普通的词，都和报纸文章的词一样具有一般的可理解性，那么你将无法在解释这本书方面取得任何进展。你还不如看报纸，因为如果你不试着去理解这本书，它就无法启发你。

If you are reading a book that can increase your understanding, it stands to reason that not all of its words will be completely intelligible to you. If you proceed as if they were all ordinary words, all on the same level of general intelligibility as the words of a newspaper article, you will make no headway toward interpretation of the book. You might just as well be reading a newspaper, for the book cannot enlighten you if you do not try to understand it.

我们大多数人都沉迷于非主动阅读。不积极或要求不高的读者的突出错误是他对文字的注意力不集中，因此他无法与作者达成和解。

Most of us are addicted to non-active reading. The outstanding fault of the non-active or undemanding reader is his inattention to words, and his consequent failure to come to terms with the author.

寻找意义

Finding the Meanings

 

找出重要的词只是任务的开始。它只是在文本中定位你必须去工作的地方。这第五条阅读规则还有另一部分。现在让我们转向那个。让我们假设你已经标记了困扰你的词。接下来是什么？

Spotting the important words is only the beginning of the task. It merely locates the places in the text where you have to go to work. There is another part of this fifth rule of reading. Let us turn to that now. Let us suppose you have marked the words that trouble you. What next?

主要有两种可能性。作者要么自始至终在单一意义上使用这些词，要么在两种或多种意义上使用它们，将他的意思从一个地方转移到另一个地方。在第一个备选方案中，该词代表一个词项。Euclid 中有一个很好的例子，使用重要的词以将它们限制为单一的含义。在第二种选择中，这个词代表几个术语。

There are two main possibilities. Either the author is using these words in a single sense throughout or he is using them in two or more senses, shifting his meaning from place to place. In the first alternative, the word stands for a single term. A good example of the use of important words so that they are restricted to a single meaning is found in Euclid. In the second alternative, the word stands for several terms.

鉴于这些备选方案，您的程序应如下所示。首先，尝试判断这个词是否有一种或多种含义。如果有很多，请尝试查看它们之间的关系。最后，注意在某种意义上使用该词的地方，看看上下文是否为您提供了意义转变原因的任何线索。这最后将使您能够以与作者用法相同的灵活性来理解单词的含义变化。

In the light of these alternatives, your procedure should be as follows. First, try to determine whether the word has one or many meanings. If it has many, try to see how they are related. Finally, note the places where the word is used in one sense or another, and see if the context gives you any clue to the reason for the shift in meaning. This last will enable you to follow the word in its change of meanings with the same flexibility that characterizes the author’s usage.

但是，你可能会抱怨，除了主要的事情之外，一切都清楚了。人们如何找出这些含义是什么？答案虽然简单，但似乎并不令人满意。但耐心和实践会告诉你并非如此。答案是你必须通过在你理解的上下文中使用所有其他词的含义来发现你不理解的词的含义。这条路一定是这样的，不管一开始看起来多么旋转木马。

But, you may complain, everything is clear except the main thing. How does one find out what the meanings are? The answer, though simple, may appear unsatisfactory. But patience and practice will show you otherwise. The answer is that you have to discover the meaning of a word you do not understand by using the meanings of all the other words in the context that you do understand. This must be the way, no matter how merry-go-roundish it may seem at first.

说明这一点的最简单方法是考虑一个定义。定义用文字说明。如果您不理解定义中使用的任何词语，您显然无法理解为所定义事物命名的词语的含义。“点”这个词是几何学中的一个基本词。您可能认为您知道它的含义（在几何中），但 Euclid 想要确保您只以一种方式使用它。他通过首先定义他稍后将要用这个词来命名的事物来告诉你他的意思。他说：“一点就是没有部分的东西。”

The easiest way to illustrate this is to consider a definition. A definition is stated in words. If you do not understand any of the words used in the definition, you obviously cannot understand the meaning of the word that names the thing defined. The word “point” is a basic word in geometry. You may think you know what it means (in geometry), but Euclid wants to be sure you use it in only one way. He tells you what he means by first defining the thing he is later going to use the word to name. He says: “A point is that which has no part.”

这如何帮助你与他和解？你知道，他假设，句子中每个其他词的意思都足够精确。你知道任何有部分的东西都是一个复杂的整体。你知道复杂的反面是简单。简单就等于缺少零件。你知道使用“is”和“that which”这两个词意味着所指的事物必须是某种实体。顺便说一句，从这一切可以得出结论，如果没有没有部分的物理事物，那么欧几里德所说的点就不可能是物理的。

How does that help to bring you to terms with him? You know, he assumes, what every other word in the sentence means with sufficient precision. You know that whatever has parts is a complex whole. You know that the opposite of complex is simple. To be simple is the same as to lack parts. You know that the use of the words “is” and “that which” means that the thing referred to must be an entity of some sort. Incidentally, it follows from all this that, if there are no physical things without parts, a point, as Euclid speaks of it, cannot be physical.

这个例子是你获得意义的典型过程。你以你已经拥有的意义运作。如果定义中使用的每个词都有自己要定义，什么都不能定义。如果你正在阅读的一本书中的每一个字对你来说都是陌生的，就像一本完全是外语的书，你就无法取得任何进步。

This illustration is typical of the process by which you acquire meanings. You operate with meanings you already possess. If every word that was used in a definition had itself to be defined, nothing could ever be defined. If every word in a book you were reading was entirely strange to you, as in the case of a book in a totally foreign language, you could make no progress at all.

这就是人们说一本书对他们来说全是希腊语时的意思。他们只是没有尝试去理解它，如果它真的是希腊语，那将是合理的。但是任何英文书上的大多数单词都是熟悉的单词。这些词围绕着奇怪的词，技术词，可能会给读者带来一些麻烦的词。周围的词是要解释的词的上下文。读者拥有完成这项工作所需的所有材料。

That is what people mean when they say of a book that it is all Greek to them. They simply have not tried to understand it, which would be justifiable if it were really in Greek. But most of the words in any English book are familiar words. These words surround the strange words, the technical words, the words that may cause the reader some trouble. The surrounding words are the context for the words to be interpreted. The reader has all the materials he needs to do the job.

我们并没有假装这份工作很容易。我们只是坚持认为这不是不可能的。如果是这样，没有人可以通过阅读一本书来获得理解。一本书能给你新的见解或启发你这一事实表明它可能包含你可能不太容易理解的单词。如果你不能通过自己的努力去理解那些话，那么我们所说的那种阅读是不可能的。靠自己对一本书的操作，不可能从懂的少到懂的多。

We are not pretending the job is an easy one. We are only insisting that it is not an impossible one. If it were, no one could read a book to gain in understanding. The fact that a book can give you new insights or enlighten you indicates that it probably contains words you may not readily understand. If you could not come to understand those words by your own efforts, then the kind of reading we are talking about would be impossible. It would be impossible to pass from understanding less to understanding more by your own operations on a book.

这样做没有经验法则。这个过程有点像拼拼图的试错法。你放在一起的部分越多，就越容易找到放置剩余部分的地方，即使只是因为它们的数量更少。一本书来到你身边，里面已经有大量的单词。一个地方的词是一个术语。它绝对位于您和作者在使用它时共享的含义。其余的话必须到位。您可以通过尝试使它们适合这种或那种方式来做到这一点。你对目前为止已经出现的词语已经部分揭示的画面理解得越好，就越容易通过对剩余词语的表述来完成画面。每一个词到位都会让下一次调整变得更容易。

There is no rule of thumb for doing this. The process is something like the trial-and-error method of putting a jigsaw puzzle together. The more parts you put together, the easier it is to find places for the remaining parts, if only because there are fewer of them. A book comes to you with a large number of words already in place. A word in place is a term. It is definitely located by the meaning that you and the author share in using it. The remaining words must be put in place. You do this by trying to make them fit this way or that. The better you understand the picture that the words so far in place already partially reveal, the easier it is to complete the picture by making terms of the remaining words. Each word put into place makes the next adjustment easier.

当然，在这个过程中你会犯错误。你会认为您已经设法找到一个词的所属位置以及它如何适合，后来才发现另一个词的位置需要您进行一系列的重新调整。错误会得到纠正，因为只要错误不被发现，画面就无法完成。一旦你在这个达成协议的工作中有了任何经验，你很快就能检查自己。你会知道你是否成功了。当你不理解时，你不会轻率地认为你理解了。

You will make errors, of course, in the process. You will think you have managed to find where a word belongs and how it fits, only to discover later that the placement of another word requires you to make a whole series of readjustments. The errors will get corrected because, so long as they are not found out, the picture cannot be completed. Once you have had any experience at all in this work of coming to terms, you will soon be able to check yourself. You will know whether you have succeeded or not. You will not blithely think you understand when you do not.

在将一本书与拼图游戏进行比较时，我们做出了一个不正确的假设。当然，一个好的拼图是所有部分都适合的。图片可以完美完成。理想中的好书也是如此，但是没有这样的书。书籍越好，作者的措词和组合就越出色，读者就可以卓有成效地进行解读。在这里，就像其他所有阅读规则一样，坏书的可读性不如好书。规则对他们不起作用，除非向你展示他们有多糟糕。如果作者含糊不清地使用词语，你就无法找出他想表达的意思。你只能发现他没有精确。

In comparing a book to a jigsaw puzzle, we have made one assumption that is not true. A good puzzle is, of course, one all of whose parts fit. The picture can be perfectly completed. The same is true of the ideally good book, but there is no such book. In proportion as books are good, their terms will be so well made and put together by the author that the reader can do the work of interpretation fruitfully. Here, as in the case of every other rule of reading, bad books are less readable than good ones. The rules do not work on them, except to show you how bad they are. If the author uses words ambiguously you cannot find out what he is trying to say. You can only find out that he has not been precise.

但是，您可能会问，一个作者在不止一种意义上使用一个词，难道不会含糊不清吗？作者在多种意义上使用词语，尤其是最重要的词语，这不是通常的做法吗？

But, you may ask, does not an author who uses a word in more than a single sense use it ambiguously? And is it not the usual practice for authors to use words in several senses, especially their most important words?

第一个问题的答案是否定的；第二个，是的。模棱两可地使用一个词就是在不区分或关联它们的含义的情况下在多种意义上使用它。（例如，我们可能在本章中模棱两可地使用了“重要”一词，因为我们并不总是清楚我们的意思是对作者重要还是对你重要。）读者可以来。但是，区分他使用关键词的几种含义并使读者能够做出回应性区分的作者是在提供术语。

The answer to the first question is No; to the second, Yes. To use a word ambiguously is to use it in several senses without distinguishing or relating their meanings. (For example, we have probably used the word “important” ambiguously in this chapter, for we were not always clear as to whether we meant important for the author or important for you.) The author who does that has not made terms that the reader can come to. But the author who distinguishes the several senses in which he is using a critical word and enables the reader to make a responsive discrimination is offering terms.

你不应该忘记一个词可以代表多个条款。记住这一点的一种方法是区分作者的词汇和他的术语。如果你在重要单词的一栏中列出一个列表，在重要单词的另一栏中列出它们的重要含义，你将看到词汇和术语之间的关系。

You should not forget that one word can represent several terms. One way to remember this is to distinguish between the author’s vocabulary and his terminology. If you make a list in one column of the important words, and in another of their important meanings, you will see the relation between the vocabulary and the terminology.

还有一些进一步的并发症。首先，具有多种不同含义的词既可以用于单一含义，也可以用于多种含义的组合。我们再以“读书”这个词为例。在某些地方，我们用它来表示阅读任何一种书籍。在其他情况下，我们用它来代表阅读指导性而非娱乐性的书籍。在另外一些例子中，我们用它来代表启迪而非告知的阅读。

There are several further complications. In the first place, a word that has several distinct meanings can be used either in a single sense or in a combination of senses. Let us take the word “reading” again as an example. In some places, we have used it to stand for reading any kind of book. In others, we have used it to stand for reading books that instruct rather than entertain. In still others, we have used it to stand for reading that enlightens rather than informs.

现在，如果我们像之前一样在这里用Xa、Xb和Xc 来表示这三种不同的“阅读”含义，那么刚才提到的第一个用法是Xabc，第二个是Xbc ，第三个是Xc。换句话说，如果几个意思是相关的，一个人可以用一个词来代表所有的意思，也可以代表其中的一些意思，或者一次只代表其中的一个意思。只要每个用法都是明确的，那么这样使用的词就是一个术语。

Now if we symbolize here, as we did before, these three distinct meanings of “reading” by Xa, Xb, and Xc, then the first usage just mentioned is Xabc, the second is Xbc, and the third Xc. In other words, if several meanings are related, one can use a word to stand for all of them, for some of them, or for only one of them at a time. So long as each usage is definite, the word so used is a term.

其次，是同义词的问题。一遍又一遍地重复一个词是尴尬和无聊的，除了在数学写作中，所以优秀的作者经常用具有相同或非常相似含义的不同词来代替他们文本中的重要词。这与一个词可以代表多个术语的情况正好相反；在这里，一个和相同的术语由两个或多个同义词表示。

In the second place, there is the problem of synonyms. The repetition of a single word over and over is awkward and boring, except in mathematical writing, and so good authors often substitute different words having the same or very similar meanings for important words in their text. This is just the opposite of the situation where one word can stand for several terms; here, one and the same term is represented by two or more words used synonymously.

我们可以如下象征性地表达这一点。设X和Y是两个不同的词，例如“启蒙”和“洞察力”。让字母a代表每个人都可以表达的相同含义，即理解的收获。那么Xa和Ya代表相同的术语，尽管它们作为单词是不同的。当我们说阅读“为了洞察力”和阅读“为了”启蒙”时，我们指的是同一种阅读，因为这两个短语的含义相同。这些词各不相同，但只有一个术语供读者理解。

We can express this symbolically as follows. Let X and Y be two different words, such as “enlightenment” and “insight.” Let the letter a stand for the same meaning that each can express, namely, a gain in understanding. Then Xa and Ya represent the same term, though they are distinct as words. When we speak of reading “for insight” and reading “for “enlightenment,” we are referring to the same kind of reading, because the two phrases are being used with the same meaning. The words are different, but there is only one term for you as a reader to grasp.

这当然很重要。如果你假设每次作者改变他的用词，他都在改变他的术语，那么你就犯了一个与假设他每次使用相同的词，术语保持不变一样大的错误。当您在单独的栏中列出作者的词汇和术语时，请记住这一点。你会发现两种关系。一方面，一个单词可能与多个术语相关。另一方面，单个术语可能与多个单词相关。

This is important, of course. If you supposed that every time an author changed his words, he was shifting his terms, you would make as great an error as to suppose that every time he used the same words, the terms remained the same. Keep this in mind when you list the author’s vocabulary and terminology in separate columns. You will find two relationships. On the one hand, a single word may be related to several terms. On the other hand, a single term may be related to several words.

第三，也是最后一点，是词组的问题。如果一个词组是一个单位，也就是说，如果它是一个整体，可以作为句子的主语或谓语，那么它就像一个词。就像一个词一样，它可以指代以某种方式谈论的事情。

In the third place, and finally, there is the matter of phrases. If a phrase is a unit, that is, if it is a whole that can be the subject or predicate of a sentence, it is like a single word. Like a single word, it can refer to something being talked about in some way.

因此，一个术语既可以用一个短语来表达，也可以用一个词来表达。单词和术语之间存在的所有关系也适用于术语和短语。两个短语可以表示同一个词，一个词可以表示多个词，这取决于其组成词的使用方式。

It follows, therefore, that a term can be expressed by a phrase as well as by a word. And all the relations that exist between words and terms hold also between terms and phrases. Two phrases may express the same term, and one phrase may express several terms, according to the way its constituent words are used.

一般来说，短语比单词更不容易产生歧义。因为它是一组词，每个词都在其他词的上下文中，所以单个词更可能具有受限的含义。这就是为什么一个作家如果想确保你明白他的意思，他可能会用一个相当复杂的短语来代替一个词。

In general, a phrase is less likely to be ambiguous than a word. Because it is a group of words, each of which is in the context of the others, the single words are more likely to have restricted meanings. That is why a writer is likely to substitute a fairly elaborate phrase for a single word if he wants to be sure that you get his meaning.

一个例子就足够了。为了确保您接受我们关于阅读的看法，我们用“阅读启蒙”等短语代替“阅读”这个词。为了加倍确定，我们可以用一个更详尽的短语来代替，例如“通过你的思想在一本书上的运作，从理解更少到理解更多的过程”。这里只有一个术语，这个术语指的是本书主要讲述的那种阅读方式。但是那个术语已经用一个词、一个短短语和一个较长的短语来表达。

One illustration should suffice. To be sure that you come to terms with us about reading, we substitute phrases like “reading for enlightenment” for the single word “reading.” To make doubly sure, we may substitute a more elaborate phrase, such as “the process of passing from understanding less to understanding more by the operation of your mind upon a book.” There is only one term here, a term referring to the kind of reading that this book is mostly about. But that one term has been expressed by a single word, a short phrase, and a longer one.

这一章很难写，也可能很难读。原因很清楚。如果不对单词和术语进行各种语法和逻辑解释，就无法完全理解我们一直在讨论的阅读规则。

This has been a hard chapter to write, and probably a hard one to read. The reason is clear. The rule of reading we have been discussing cannot be made fully intelligible without going into all sorts of grammatical and logical explanations about words and terms.

事实上，我们实际上做了很少的解释。要充分说明这些问题需要很多章节。我们只是触及了最基本的要点。我们希望我们已经说得够多了，可以使该规则在实践中成为有用的指南。您将其付诸实践的次数越多，您就越会体会到问题的复杂性。你会想知道一些关于单词的字面和隐喻用法的知识。您将想知道抽象词和具体词之间的区别，以及专有名词和普通名称之间的区别。您将对整个定义业务感兴趣：定义单词和定义事物之间的区别；为什么有些词无法定义，但具有明确的含义，等等。你将寻求对所谓“语言的情感使用”的理解，也就是说，使用语言来唤起情绪，促使人们采取行动或改变他们的想法，这与知识的交流截然不同。你甚至可能会对普通的“理性”言论与“怪诞”或“疯狂”谈话之间的关系产生兴趣——精神失常者的言论，其中几乎每个词都带有奇怪和意想不到但仍可识别的含义。

In fact, we have actually done very little explaining. To give an adequate account of these matters would take many chapters. We have merely touched upon the most essential points. We hope we have said enough to make the rule a useful guide in practice. The more you put it into practice, the more you will appreciate the intricacies of the problem. You will want to know something about the literal and metaphorical use of words. You will want to know about the distinction between abstract and concrete words, and between proper and common names. You will become interested in the whole business of definition: the difference between defining words and defining things; why some words are indefinable, and yet have definite meanings, and so forth. You will seek light on what is called “the emotive use of words,” that is, the use of words to arouse emotions, to move men to action or change their minds, as distinct from the communication of knowledge. And you may even become interested in the relation between ordinary “rational” speech and “bizarre” or “crazy” talk—the speech of the mentally disturbed, where almost every word carries weird and unexpected but nevertheless identifiable connotations.

如果分析阅读的实践引发了这些进一步的兴趣，你将能够通过阅读这些特殊主题的书籍来满足他们。而且你会从阅读这些书中获益更多，因为你会带着你自己阅读体验中产生的问题去找他们。语法和逻辑的研究，这些规则背后的科学，只有在你能将其与实践联系起来的情况下才是实用的。

If the practice of analytical reading elicits these further interests, you will be in a position to satisfy them by reading books on these special subjects. And you will profit more from reading such books, because you will go to them with questions born of your own experience in reading. The study of grammar and logic, the sciences that underlie these rules, is practical only to the extent you can relate it to practice.

您可能永远不想走得更远。但即使你不这样做，你会发现，只要你不厌其烦地找出书中的重要词汇，识别它们不断变化的含义，并达成共识，你对任何一本书的理解都会大大提高。很少有如此小的习惯改变会产生如此大的影响。

You may never wish to go further. But even if you do not, you will find that your comprehension of any book will be enormously increased if you only go to the trouble of finding its important words, identifying their shifting meanings, and coming to terms. Seldom does such a small change in a habit have such a large effect.

9

确定作者的信息

9DETERMINING AN AUTHOR’S MESSAGE

 

交易者和书籍世界不仅会达成协议，还会提出建议。买方或卖方所说的提议是指某种建议、某种要约或接受。在诚实的交易中，在这种意义上提出建议的人是在宣告他打算以某种方式行事。成功的谈判需要的不仅仅是诚实。提案应该清晰明了，当然也应该有吸引力。然后交易者可以达成协议。

Not only coming to terms but also making propositions occurs among traders as well as in the world of books. What a buyer or seller means by a proposition is some sort of proposal, some sort of offer or acceptance. In honest dealings, the person who makes a proposition in this sense is declaring his intention to act in a certain way. More than honesty is required for successful negotiations. The proposition should be clear and, of course, attractive. Then the traders can come to terms.

书中的命题也是宣言。表达作者对某事的判断。他肯定他认为是真的东西，或者否认他认为是假的东西。他断言这个或那个是事实。这类命题是知识声明，而不是意图。作者可能会在序言中一开始就告诉我们他的意图。在一本说明书中，他通常承诺会指导我们一些事情。要弄清楚他是否信守诺言，我们必须寻找他的主张。

A proposition in a book is also a declaration. It is an expression of the author’s judgment about something. He affirms something he thinks to be true, or denies something he judges to be false. He asserts this or that to be a fact. A proposition of this sort is a declaration of knowledge, not intentions. The author may tell us his intentions at the beginning in a preface. In an expository book, he usually promises to instruct us about something. To find out whether he keeps those promises, we must look for his propositions.

通常，阅读的顺序与业务的顺序相反。商人通常在发现提议是什么后达成协议。但读者通常必须首先与作者达成和解，然后才能了解作者在提出什么建议，在宣告什么判断。这就是为什么分析阅读的第五条规则涉及单词和术语，第六个，我们将要讨论的，涉及句子和命题。

Generally, the order of reading reverses the order of business. Businessmen usually come to terms after they find out what the proposition is. But the reader must usually come to terms with an author first, before he can find out what the author is proposing, what judgment he is declaring. That is why the fifth rule of analytical reading concerns words and terms, and the sixth, which we are about to discuss, concerns sentences and propositions.

第七条规则与第六条规则密切相关。作者可能诚实地就事实或知识发表自己的看法。我们通常在这种信任下进行。但是除非我们只对作者的个性感兴趣，否则我们不应该满足于知道他的观点是什么。除非有理由支持，否则他的主张只不过是个人意见的表达。如果我们感兴趣的是这本书及其所涉及的主题，而不仅仅是作者，那么我们不仅想知道他的主张是什么，还想知道他为什么认为应该说服我们接受这些主张。

There is a seventh rule that is closely related to the sixth. The author may be honest in declaring himself on matters of fact or knowledge. We usually proceed in that trust. But unless we are exclusively interested in the author’s personality, we should not be satisfied with knowing what his opinions are. His propositions are nothing but expressions of personal opinion unless they are supported by reasons. If it is the book and the subject with which it deals that we are interested in, and not just the author, we want to know not merely what his propositions are, but also why he thinks we should be persuaded to accept them.

因此，第七条规则涉及各种论点。有很多种推理，有很多种支持一个人所说的话的方法。有时可以争辩说某件事是真的；有时只能为一个概率辩护。但是每一种论证都由许多以某种方式相关的陈述组成。之所以这样说。 _ 这里的“因为”一词表示给出的理由。

The seventh rule, therefore, deals with arguments of all sorts. There are many kinds of reasoning, many ways of supporting what one says. Sometimes it is possible to argue that something is true; sometimes no more than a probability can be defended. But every sort of argument consists of a number of statements related in a certain way. This is said because of that. The word “because” here signifies a reason being given.

参数的存在由与陈述相关的其他词表示，例如：如果是这样，那么就是；或者，因为这个，所以那个；或者，由此可知，情况确实如此。在本书前面几章的过程中，出现了这样的序列。我们观察到，对于我们这些不再上学的人来说，如果我们想继续学习和发现，就必须知道如何让书本更好地教我们。在那种情况下，我们要想继续学习，就必须懂得从书本上学习，而书本是没有老师的。

The presence of arguments is indicated by other words that relate statements, such as: if this is so, then that; or, since this, therefore that; or, it follows from this, that that is the case. In the course of earlier chapters in this book, such sequences occurred. For those of us who are no longer in school, we observed, it is necessary, if we want to go on learning and discovering, to know how to make books teach us well. In that situation, if we want to go on learning, then we must know how to learn from books, which are absent teachers.

一个论点总是一组或一系列陈述，其中一些陈述为要得出的结论提供依据或理由。因此，需要一个段落或至少一组句子来表达一个论点。论证的前提或原则可能并不总是首先陈述，但它们却是结论的来源。如果论证有效，则结论从前提得出。这并不一定意味着结论是正确的，因为支持它的一个或所有前提可能是错误的。

An argument is always a set or series of statements of which some provide the grounds or reasons for what is to be concluded. A paragraph, therefore, or at least a collection of sentences, is required to express an argument. The premises or principles of an argument may not always be stated first, but they are the source of the conclusion, nevertheless. If the argument is valid, the conclusion follows from the premises. That does not necessarily mean that the conclusion is true, since one or all of the premises that support it may be false.

这些解释规则的顺序既有语法方面的，也有逻辑方面的。我们从术语到命题再到论点，从单词（和短语）到句子再到句子集（或段落）。我们正在从更简单的单元构建到更复杂的单元。一本书中最小的重要元素当然是一个单词。说一本书是由文字组成的，这是对的，但还不够。它还由作为单位的词组和类似的作为单位的句子组组成。积极的读者不仅要注意单词，还要注意句子和段落。没有其他方法可以发现作者的术语、命题和论点。

There is a grammatical as well as a logical aspect to the order of these rules of interpretation. We go from terms to propositions to arguments, by going from words (and phrases) to sentences to collections of sentences (or paragraphs). We are building up from simpler to more complex units. The smallest significant element in a book is, of course, a single word. It would be true but not adequate to say that a book consists of words. It also consists of groups of words, taken as units, and similarly of groups of sentences, taken as units. The active reader is attentive not only to the words but also to the sentences and paragraphs. There is no other way of discovering the author’s terms, propositions, and arguments.

分析阅读这一阶段的运动——当解释是我们的目标时——似乎与第一阶段的运动方向相反——当目标是结构大纲时。我们从整本书到主要部分，再到它们的下属部分。正如您所怀疑的那样，这两个运动在某个地方相遇。一本书的主要部分及其主要部分包含许多命题，通常还有几个论点。但如果你继续把这本书分成几个部分，最后你不得不说：“在这一部分中，有以下几点。” 现在，这些观点中的每一个都可能是一个命题，其中一些可能会形成一个论点。

The movement at this stage of analytical reading—when interpretation is our goal—seems to be in the opposite direction from the movement in the first stage—when the goal was a structural outline. There we went from the book as a whole to its major parts, and then to their subordinate divisions. As you might suspect, the two movements meet somewhere. The major parts of a book and their principal divisions contain many propositions and usually several arguments. But if you keep on dividing the book into its parts, at last you have to say: “In this part, the following points are made.” Now each of these points is likely to be a proposition, and some of them taken together probably form an argument.

因此，概述和解释这两个过程在命题和论证的层面上相遇。你通过将书分成几个部分来研究命题和论点。你通过观察论点是如何由命题和最终的术语组成来处理论点的。当你完成了这两个过程之后，你就可以真正说你知道一本书的内容了。

Thus, the two processes, outlining and interpretation, meet at the level of propositions and arguments. You work down to propositions and arguments by dividing the book into its parts. You work up to arguments by seeing how they are composed of propositions and ultimately of terms. When you have completed the two processes, you can really say that you know the contents of a book.

句子与命题

Sentences vs. Propositions

 

我们已经注意到关于我们将在本章中讨论的规则的另一件事。就像关于词和术语的规则一样，我们在这里也处理语言和思想的关系。句子和段落是语法单位。它们是语言单位。命题和论证是逻辑单位，或思想和知识的单位。

We have already noticed another thing about the rules we are going to discuss in this chapter. As in the case of the rule about words and terms, we are here also dealing with the relation of language and thought. Sentences and paragraphs are grammatical units. They are units of language. Propositions and arguments are logical units, or units of thought and knowledge.

我们必须在这里面对一个类似于我们在上一章中遇到的问题。因为语言不是表达思想的完美媒介，因为一个词可以有多种含义，两个或多个词可以有相同的含义，我们看到作者的词汇和他的术语之间的关系是多么复杂。一个词可以代表几个term，一个term可以由多个词代表。

We have to face here a problem similar to the one we faced in the last chapter. Because language is not a perfect medium for the expression of thought, because one word can have many meanings and two or more words can have the same meaning, we saw how complicated was the relation between an author’s vocabulary and his terminology. One word may represent several terms, and one term may be represented by several words.

数学家将一件做工精良的外套上的纽扣和扣眼之间的关系描述为一对一的关系。每个钮孔都有一个钮扣，每个钮扣都有一个孔。好吧，关键是单词和术语不是一对一的关系。在应用这些规则时可能犯的最大错误是假设语言元素与思想或知识元素之间存在一对一的关系。

Mathematicians describe the relation between the buttons and the buttonholes on a well-made coat as a one-to-one relationship. There is a button for every buttonhole, and a hole for every button. Well, the point is that words and terms do not stand in a one-to-one relation. The greatest error you can make in applying these rules is to suppose that a one-to-one relationship exists between the elements of language and those of thought or knowledge.

事实上，明智的做法是不要对纽扣和扣眼做出过于简单的假设。大多数男士西装外套的袖子上都有纽扣，但没有相应的扣眼。如果你穿了一段时间的外套，它可能有一个洞，没有相应的纽扣。

As a matter of fact, it would be wise not to make too easy assumptions even about buttons and buttonholes. The sleeves of most men’s suit jackets bear buttons that have no corresponding buttonholes. And if you have worn the coat for a while, it may have a hole with no corresponding button.

让我们用句子和命题来说明这一点。并非书中的每句话都表达了一个命题。一方面，一些句子表达了问题。他们陈述问题而不是答案。命题是问题的答案。它们是知识或意见的声明。那这就是为什么我们将表达它们的句子称为陈述句，并将提出问题的句子区分为疑问句。其他句子表达愿望或意图。它们可能使我们对作者的目的有所了解，但并没有传达他试图阐述的知识。

Let us illustrate this in the case of sentences and propositions. Not every sentence in a book expresses a proposition. For one thing, some sentences express questions. They state problems rather than answers. Propositions are the answers to questions. They are declarations of knowledge or opinion. That is why we call sentences that express them declarative, and distinguish sentences that ask questions as interrogative. Other sentences express wishes or intentions. They may give us some knowledge of the author’s purpose, but they do not convey the knowledge he is trying to expound.

此外，并不是所有的陈述句都可以读成好像每个陈述句都表达了一个命题。这至少有两个原因。首先是单词有歧义，可以用在各种句子中。因此，如果单词所表达的术语发生变化，则同一个句子有可能表达不同的命题。“阅读就是学习”是一句简单的话；但是，如果在一个地方我们指的是“学习”获取信息，而在另一个地方我们指的是理解力的发展，那么命题就不一样了，因为术语不同。然而句子是一样的。

Moreover, not all the declarative sentences can be read as if each expressed one proposition. There are at least two reasons for this. The first is the fact that words are ambiguous and can be used in various sentences. Thus, it is possible for the same sentence to express different propositions if there is a shift in the terms the words express. “Reading is learning” is a simple sentence; but if at one place we mean by “learning” the acquisition of information, and at another we mean the development of understanding, the proposition is not the same, because the terms are different. Yet the sentence is the same.

第二个原因是所有的句子都不是“阅读就是学习”那么简单。当它的词被明确使用时，一个简单的句子通常表达一个单一的命题。但即使它的词被明确使用，复合句也表达了两个或多个命题。复合句实际上是句子的集合，由“and”或“if … then”或“not only … but also”等词连接起来。您可能会正确地得出结论，长复合句和短段落之间的界限可能很难划清。复合句可以表达以论证形式相关的若干命题。

The second reason is that all sentences are not as simple as “Reading is learning.” When its words are used unambiguously, a simple sentence usually expresses a single proposition. But even when its words are used unambiguously, a compound sentence expresses two or more propositions. A compound sentence is really a collection of sentences, connected by such words as “and,” or “if … then,” or “not only … but also.” You may rightly conclude that the line between a long compound sentence and a short paragraph may be difficult to draw. A compound sentence can express a number of propositions related in the form of an argument.

这样的句子可能很难解释。让我们用马基雅维利的《君主论》中一段有趣的句子来说明我们的意思：

Such sentences can be very difficult to interpret. Let us take an interesting sentence from Machiavelli’s The Prince to show what we mean:

一位王子应该以这样一种方式来激起恐惧：如果他得不到爱，他就会避免仇恨；因为他可以很好地忍受被恐惧而不被憎恨，只要他放弃公民的财产和他们的女人，这种情况就会永远存在。

A prince ought to inspire fear in such a way that, if he does not win love, he avoids hatred; because he can endure very well being feared whilst he is not hated, which will always be as long as he abstains from the property of his citizens and from their women.

这在语法上是一个句子，尽管它非常复杂。分号和“因为”表示主要打破它。第一个命题是王子应该以某种方式激起恐惧。

This is grammatically a single sentence, though it is extremely complex. The semicolon and the “because” indicate the major break in it. The first proposition is that a prince ought to inspire fear in a certain way.

从“因为”这个词开始，我们实际上得到了另一个句子。（可以单独说：“之所以如此，是因为他能忍受”等等）而这句话至少表达了两个命题：（1）王子为什么应该在某个地方激起恐惧的原因方法是，只要不被讨厌，他就可以忍受被恐惧；(2) 只有让他的手远离他的公民和他们的女人的财产，他才能避免被仇恨。

Beginning with the word “because,” we have what is in effect another sentence. (It could be made independent by saying: “The reason for this is that he can endure,” and so forth.) And this sentence expresses two propositions at least: (1) the reason why the prince ought to inspire fear in a certain way is that he can endure being feared so long as he is not hated; (2) he can avoid being hated only by keeping his hands off the property of his citizens and their women.

区分长而复杂的句子包含的各种命题很重要。为了同意或不同意马基雅维利，你必须首先理解他在说什么。但他在这句话中说了三件事。你可以不同意其中的一个而同意其他的。你可能认为马基雅维利以任何理由向王子推荐恐怖主义都是错误的；但你可能会承认他的精明，他说王子最好不要在恐惧的同时引起仇恨，你也可能会同意，让他的手远离臣民的财产和女人是不被仇恨的必不可少的条件。除非你能识别复杂句子中的不同命题，否则你无法对作者所说的内容做出有区别的判断。

It is important to distinguish the various propositions that a long, complex sentence contains. In order to agree or disagree with Machiavelli, you must first understand what he is saying. But he is saying three things in this one sentence. You may disagree with one of them and agree with the others. You may think Machiavelli is wrong in recommending terrorism to a prince on any grounds; but you may acknowledge his shrewdness in saying that the prince had better not arouse hatred along with fear, and you may also agree that keeping his hands off his subjects’ property and women is an indispensable condition of not being hated. Unless you recognize the distinct propositions in a complicated sentence, you cannot make a discriminating judgment on what the writer is saying.

律师们非常了解这个事实。他们必须仔细审查判决，以了解原告指控或被告否认的内容。“John Doe 于 3 月 24 日签署了租约”这一句话看起来很简单，但它仍然说明了几件事，其中一些可能是真的，而另一些可能是假的。John Doe 可能已经签署了租约，但不是在 3 月 24 日，这个事实可能很重要。简而言之，即使是一个语法简单的句子有时也会表达两个或更多的命题。

Lawyers know this fact very well. They have to examine sentences carefully to see what is being alleged by the plaintiff or denied by the defendant. The single sentence, “John Doe signed the lease on March 24,” looks simple enough, but still it says several things, some of which may be true and the others false. John Doe may have signed the lease, but not on March 24, and that fact may be important. In short, even a grammatically simple sentence sometimes expresses two or more propositions.

我们已经说得够多了，足以表明我们所说的句子和命题之间的区别是什么意思。它们没有一对一的关系。不仅一个句子可以通过歧义或复杂性表达多个命题，而且同一个命题也可以由两个表达或更多不同的句子。如果你通过我们使用的同义词和短语来理解我们的术语，你就会知道当我们说“教导和被教导是相关的功能”和“发起和接受交流是相关的过程”时，我们在说同一件事。

We have said enough to indicate what we mean by the difference between sentences and propositions. They are not related as one to one. Not only can a single sentence express several propositions, either through ambiguity or complexity, but one and the same proposition can also be expressed by two or more different sentences. If you grasp our terms through the words and phrases we use synonymously, you will know that we are saying the same thing when we say, “Teaching and being taught are correlative functions,” and “Initiating and receiving communication are related processes.”

我们将停止解释所涉及的语法和逻辑点，而转向规则。与上一章一样，本章的困难在于停止解释。相反，我们会假设您知道一些语法。我们并不一定意味着您必须了解有关语法的所有内容，但您应该关注句子中单词的顺序以及它们之间的关系。一些语法知识对读者来说是必不可少的。你不能开始处理术语、命题和论点——思想的要素——直到你能穿透语言的表面。只要单词、句子和段落是不透明的和未经分析的，它们就是交流的障碍，而不是交流的媒介。你会阅读文字，但不会获得知识。

We are going to stop explaining the grammatical and logical points involved and turn to the rules. The difficulty in this chapter, as in the last, is to stop explaining. Instead, we will assume that you know some grammar. We do not necessarily mean that you must understand everything about syntax, but you should be concerned about the ordering of words in sentences and their relation to one another. Some knowledge of grammar is indispensable to a reader. You cannot begin to deal with terms, propositions, and arguments—the elements of thought—until you can penetrate beneath the surface of language. So long as words, sentences, and paragraphs are opaque and unanalyzed, they are a barrier to, rather than a medium of, communication. You will read words but not receive knowledge.

这是规则。阅读上一章的第五条规则是： 规则5.找到重要的词并达成共识。第六条规则可以这样表述： 规则6.标记一本书中最重要的句子并发现它们包含的命题。第七条规则是这样的： 规则7.通过在句子 S的连接中找到书中的基本论点来定位或构建它们。稍后你会看到为什么我们在这条规则的表述中没有说“段落”。

Here are the rules. The fifth rule of reading, as you will recall from the last chapter, was: RULE 5. FIND THE IMPORTANT WORDS AND COME TO TERMS. The sixth rule can be expressed thus: RULE 6. MARK THE MOST IMPORTANT SENTENCES IN A BOOK AND DISCOVER THE PROPOSITIONS THEY CONTAIN. The seventh rule is this: RULE 7. LOCATE OR CONSTRUCT THE BASIC ARGUMENTS IN THE BOOK BY FINDING THEM IN THE CONNECTION OF SENTENCES. You will see later why we did not say “paragraphs” in the formulation of this rule.

顺便说一句，这些新规则与它们主要适用于说明性作品的达成条款的规则一样真实。当你阅读诗歌作品——小说、戏剧或诗歌时，关于命题和论证的规则是完全不同的。稍后我们将讨论将它们应用于此类作品所需的更改。

Incidentally, it is just as true of these new rules as it was of the rule about coming to terms that they apply primarily to expository works. The rules about propositions and arguments are quite different when you are reading a poetical work—a novel, play, or poem. We will discuss the changes that are required in applying them to such works later.

寻找关键句子

Finding the Key Sentences

 

如何找到一本书中最重要的句子？那么，如何解释这些句子以发现它们包含的一个或多个命题呢？

How does one locate the most important sentences in a book? How, then, does one interpret these sentences to discover the one or more propositions they contain?

同样，我们强调重要的事情。说一本书的重点句子比较少，并不代表其他的都可以不用管。显然，你必须理解每一个句子。但大多数句子，就像大多数单词一样，不会给你带来任何困难。正如我们在讨论阅读速度时指出的那样，您会相对快速地阅读它们。从你作为读者的角度来看，对你来说重要的句子是那些需要努力解释的句子，因为乍一看，它们并不是完全可以理解的。您对它们的理解足够好，知道还有更多内容需要理解。与其他句子相比，它们是您阅读得更慢、更仔细的句子。这些可能不是最重要的句子对作者来说，但他们很可能是，因为你可能对作者必须说的最重要的事情有最大的困难。无需多言，这些是您最应该仔细阅读的内容。

Again, we are placing emphasis on what is important. To say that there is only a relatively small number of key sentences in a book does not mean that you need pay no attention to all the rest. Obviously, you have to understand every sentence. But most of the sentences, like most of the words, will cause you no difficulty. As we pointed out in our discussion of reading speeds, you will read them relatively quickly. From your point of view as a reader, the sentences important for you are those that require an effort of interpretation because, at first sight, they are not perfectly intelligible. You understand them just well enough to know there is more to understand. They are the sentences that you read much more slowly and carefully than the rest. These may not be the sentences that are most important for the author, but they are likely to be, because you are likely to have the greatest difficulty with the most important things the author has to say. And it hardly needs remarking that those are the things you should read most carefully.

从作者的角度来看，重要的句子是表达他整个论点所依据的判断的句子。一本书通常包含的不仅仅是一个论点或一系列论点的简单陈述。作者可能会解释他是如何得出他现在持有的观点的，或者为什么他认为他的立场会产生严重的后果。他可能会讨论他必须使用的词。他可能会评论其他人的工作。他可能沉迷于各种支持和周围的讨论。但他交流的核心在于他所做的主要肯定和否认，以及他这样做的理由。因此，为了掌握，您必须看到主要句子，就好像它们是从页面上浮雕出来的一样。

From the author’s point of view, the important sentences are the ones that express the judgments on which his whole argument rests. A book usually contains much more than the bare statement of an argument, or a series of arguments. The author may explain how he came to the point of view he now holds, or why he thinks his position has serious consequences. He may discuss the words he has to use. He may comment on the work of others. He may indulge in all sorts of supporting and surrounding discussion. But the heart of his communication lies in the major affirmations and denials he is making, and the reasons he gives for so doing. To come to grips, therefore, you have to see the main sentences as if they were raised from the page in high relief.

一些作者可以帮助您做到这一点。他们为你在句子下划线。他们要么告诉你这是他们制作的重点，要么他们使用一种或另一种印刷设备使他们的主要句子脱颖而出。当然，对于那些在阅读时不会保持清醒的人来说，没有任何帮助。我们遇到过许多读者和学生，他们甚至没有注意到如此明显的标志。他们更愿意继续阅读而不是停下来仔细检查重要的句子。

Some authors help you do this. They underline the sentences for you. They either tell you that this is an important point when they make it, or they use one or another typographical device to make their leading sentences stand out. Of course, nothing helps those who will not keep awake while reading. We have met many readers and students who paid no attention even to such clear signs. They preferred to read on rather than stop and examine the important sentences carefully.

有几本书的主要命题是用在阐述的顺序和风格中占据特殊位置的句子来阐述的。欧几里德再次给了我们最明显的例子。他不仅在开头陈述了他的定义、他的假设和他的公理——他的主要命题，而且他还给每个命题贴上了要证明的标签。您可能无法理解他的所有陈述。你可能不会理解他的所有论点。但是你不能错过证明陈述的重要句子或句子组合。

There are a few books in which the leading propositions are set forth in sentences that occupy a special place in the order and style of the exposition. Euclid, again, gives us the most obvious example of this. He not only states his definitions, his postulates, and his axioms—his principal propositions—at the beginning, but he also labels every proposition to be proved. You may not understand all of his statements. You may not follow all of his arguments. But you cannot miss the important sentences or the grouping of sentences for the statement of the proofs.

圣托马斯阿奎那的神学大全是另一本书，其阐述风格使主要句子浮雕。它通过提出问题来进行。每个部分都以一个问题开头。有许多迹象表明阿奎那正试图捍卫答案。陈述了反对答案的一系列反对意见。阿奎那开始论证自己观点的地方标有“我回答那个”这句话。在这样一本书中，没有理由找不到重要的句子——那些表达原因和结论的句子——但即使在这里，对于那些把所读的一切都视为同等重要的读者来说，它仍然是一片模糊——阅读这一切都以相同的速度，或快或慢。这通常意味着一切都同样不重要。

The Summa Theologica of St. Thomas Aquinas is another book whose style of exposition puts the leading sentences into high relief. It proceeds by raising questions. Each section is headed by a question. There are many indications of the answer that Aquinas is trying to defend. A whole series of objections opposing the answer is stated. The place where Aquinas begins to argue his own point is marked by the words, “I answer that.” There is no excuse for not being able to locate the important sentences in such a book—those expressing the reasons as well as the conclusions—yet even here it remains all a blur for those readers who treat everything they read as equally important—and read it all at the same speed, either fast or slow. That usually means that everything is equally unimportant.

除了其风格或格式引起读者对最需要解释的内容的关注的书籍外，发现重要的句子是读者必须自己完成的工作。他可以做几件事。我们已经提到了一个。如果他对他容易理解的段落和他不能理解的段落之间的区别很敏感，他就可能能够找到承载主要意义的句子。也许你开始明白阅读的一部分是困惑和了解它是多么重要。惊奇是向书本和向自然学习的智慧的开端。如果你从不问自己关于一段话的意思的任何问题，你就不能指望这本书能给你任何你还不具备的洞察力。

Apart from books whose style or format calls attention to what most needs interpretation by the reader, the spotting of the important sentences is a job the reader must perform for himself. There are several things he can do. We have already mentioned one. If he is sensitive to the difference between passages he can understand readily and those he cannot, he will probably be able to locate the sentences that carry the main burden of meaning. Perhaps you are beginning to see how essential a part of reading it is to be perplexed and know it. Wonder is the beginning of wisdom in learning from books as well as from nature. If you never ask yourself any questions about the meaning of a passage, you cannot expect the book to give you any insight you do not already possess.

重要句子的另一个线索是组成它们的单词。如果您已经标记了重要的单词，它们应该会引导您找到值得进一步关注的句子。因此，解释性阅读的第一步是为第二步做准备。但反过来也可能如此。可能只有当你对一个句子的意思感到困惑时，你才会标记某些词。我们以固定顺序陈述这些规则的事实并不意味着您必须按该顺序遵守它们。术语构成命题。命题包含术语。如果你知道单词表达的术语，你就抓住了句子中的命题。如果你理解了一个句子所传达的命题，那么你也已经掌握了术语。

Another clue to the important sentences is found in the words that compose them. If you have already marked the important words, they should lead you to the sentences that deserve further attention. Thus the first step in interpretive reading prepares for the second. But the reverse may also be the case. It may be that you will mark certain words only after you have become puzzled by the meaning of a sentence. The fact that we have stated these rules in a fixed order does not mean that you have to follow them in that order. Terms constitute propositions. Propositions contain terms. If you know the terms the words express, you have caught the proposition in the sentence. If you understand the proposition conveyed by a sentence, you have arrived at the terms also.

这为主要命题的位置提供了一条进一步的线索。它们必须属于本书的主要论点。它们必须是前提或结论。因此，如果你能检测到那些似乎形成一个序列的句子，一个有开始和结束的序列，你可能已经把手指放在了重要的句子上。

This suggests one further clue to the location of the principal propositions. They must belong to the main argument of the book. They must be either premises or conclusions. Hence, if you can detect those sentences that seem to form a sequence, a sequence in which there is a beginning and an end, you probably have put your finger on the sentences that are important.

我们说了一个序列，其中有开始也有结束。人们可以用语言表达的每一个论点都需要时间来陈述。你可以一口气说出一句话，但在争论中会有停顿。你必须先说一件事，然后再说另一件事，然后再说另一件事。争论从某处开始，去某处，到达某处。这是一种思想运动。它可以从真正的结论开始，然后继续给出它的理由。或者它可以从证据和原因开始，然后让您得出由此得出的结论。

We said a sequence in which there is a beginning and an end. Every argument that men can express in words takes time to state. You may speak a sentence in one breath, but there are pauses in an argument. You have to say one thing first, then another, and then another. An argument begins somewhere, goes somewhere, gets somewhere. It is a movement of thought. It may begin with what is really the conclusion and then proceed to give the reasons for it. Or it may start with the evidence and the reasons and bring you to the conclusion that follows therefrom.

当然，在这里和其他地方一样，除非您知道如何使用它，否则这条线索是行不通的。当你看到一个论点时，你必须认出一个论点。然而，尽管有一些令人失望的经历，我们仍然坚持我们的观点，即人类的思想对争论的敏感度与眼睛对颜色的敏感度一样。（可能有些人对争论视而不见！）但是眼睛不睁开就看不见，头脑不清醒就不会跟从争论。

Of course, here as elsewhere, the clue will not work unless you know how to use it. You have to recognize an argument when you see one. Despite some disappointing experiences, however, we persist in our opinion that the human mind is as naturally sensitive to arguments as the eye is to colors. (There may be some people who are argument-blind!) But the eye will not see if it is not kept open, and the mind will not follow an argument if it is not awake.

许多人认为他们知道如何阅读，因为他们以不同的速度阅读。但是他们在错误的句子上停下来并放慢速度。他们停在他们感兴趣的句子上，而不是那些令人困惑的句子上他们。事实上，这是阅读一本不完全当代的书的最大障碍之一。任何旧书都包含一些令人惊讶的事实，因为它们与我们所知道的不同。但是当你为了理解而阅读时，你所寻求的并不是那种新奇事物。你对作者本人、对他的语言或对他写作的世界的兴趣是一回事；你对理解他的想法的关注是另一回事。我们在这里讨论的规则能帮助你满足的正是这种担忧，而不是你对其他事物的好奇心。

Many persons believe that they know how to read because they read at different speeds. But they pause and go slow over the wrong sentences. They pause over the sentences that interest them rather than the ones that puzzle them. Indeed, this is one of the greatest obstacles to reading a book that is not completely contemporary. Any old book contains facts that are somewhat surprising because they are different from what we know. But when you are reading for understanding it is not that kind of novelty that you are seeking. Your interest in the author himself, or in his language, or in the world in which he wrote, is one thing; your concern to understand his ideas is quite another. It is this concern that the rules we are discussing here can help you to satisfy, not your curiosity about other matters.

寻找命题

Finding the Propositions

 

假设您找到了主要句子。规则 6 还需要一个步骤。你必须发现每个句子包含的一个或多个命题。这只是另一种说法，你必须知道这句话的意思。您通过发现来发现术语一个词在给定用法中的含义。通过解释构成句子的所有单词，尤其是它的主要单词，您可以类似地发现命题。

Let us suppose that you have located the leading sentences. Another step is required by Rule 6. You must discover the proposition or propositions that each of these sentences contains. This is just another way of saying that you must know what the sentence means. You discover terms by discovering what a word means in a given usage. You discover propositions similarly by interpreting all the words that make up the sentence, and especially its principal words.

再一次，除非你懂一点语法，否则你不能很好地做到这一点。你必须知道形容词和副词所起的作用，动词如何与名词相关，修饰词和从句如何限制或扩大它们修饰词的含义，等等。理想情况下，您应该能够根据句法规则剖析一个句子，尽管您不一定必须以正式的方式进行。尽管目前学校不再强调语法教学，但我们必须假设你知道这么多。我们无法相信您没有，尽管您可能由于缺乏阅读艺术基础方面的练习而变得有点生疏。

Once more, you cannot do this very well unless you know a little grammar. You must know the role that adjectives and adverbs play, how verbs function in relation to nouns, how modifying words and clauses restrict or amplify the meaning of the words they modify, and so forth. Ideally, you should be able to dissect a sentence according to the rules of syntax, although you do not necessarily have to do it in a formal way. Despite the current de-emphasis on teaching grammar in school, we have to assume that you know this much of it. We cannot believe you do not, though you may have grown a little rusty from lack of practice in the rudiments of the art of reading.

找到单词表达的术语和句子表达的命题之间只有两个区别。一个是你在后一种情况下使用了更大的上下文。你把所有周围的句子都放在问题的句子上，就像你用周围的词来解释一个特定的词一样。在这两种情况下，您都是从您确实理解的内容开始，逐渐阐明最初相对难以理解的内容。

There are only two differences between finding the terms that words express and the propositions that sentences express. One is that you employ a larger context in the latter case. You bring all the surrounding sentences to bear on the sentence in question, just as you used the surrounding words to interpret a particular word. In both cases, you proceed from what you do understand to the gradual elucidation of what is at first relatively unintelligible.

另一个区别在于复杂的句子通常表达不止一个命题。在你从一个重要的句子中分离出所有不同但可能相关的命题之前，你还没有完成对它的解释。这样做的技巧来自实践。拿本书中一些复杂的句子，试着用你自己的话来陈述每一个被断言的事情。编号并关联它们。

The other difference lies in the fact that complicated sentences usually express more than one proposition. You have not completed your interpretation of an important sentence until you have separated out of it all the different, though perhaps related, propositions. Skill in doing this comes with practice. Take some of the complicated sentences in this book and try to state in your own words each of the things that is being asserted. Number them and relate them.

“用你自己的话说！” 这表明我们知道最好的测试来判断你是否理解了句子中的一个或多个命题。如果，当你被要求解释作者用一个特定句子的意思时，你所能做的就是重复他的话，做一些小的改动按照他们的顺序，你最好怀疑你不知道他的意思。理想情况下，您应该能够用完全不同的词说同一件事。当然，可以在不同程度上近似这个想法。但是，如果你根本无法摆脱作者的话，那就表明从他那里传给你的只是文字，而不是思想或知识。你知道他的话，而不是他的想法。他试图传达知识，而你收到的只是文字。

“State in your own words!” That suggests the best test we know for telling whether you have understood the proposition or propositions in the sentence. If, when you are asked to explain what the author means by a particular sentence, all you can do is repeat his very words, with some minor alterations in their order, you had better suspect that you do not know what he means. Ideally, you should be able to say the same thing in totally different words. The idea can, of course, be approximated in varying degrees. But if you cannot get away at all from the author’s words, it shows that only words have passed from him to you, not thought or knowledge. You know his words, not his mind. He was trying to communicate knowledge, and all you received was words.

从外语到英语的翻译过程与我们建议的测试相关。如果你不能用英语句子表达法语句子的意思，你就知道你不明白法语的意思。但即使你可以，你的翻译也可能只停留在口头层面；因为即使你已经形成了一个忠实的英语副本，你仍然可能不知道法语句子的作者试图传达什么。

The process of translation from a foreign language to English is relevant to the test we have suggested. If you cannot state in an English sentence what a French sentence says, you know you do not understand the meaning of the French. But even if you can, your translation may remain only on the verbal level; for even when you have formed a faithful English replica, you still may not know what the writer of the French sentence was trying to convey.

然而，将一个英语句子翻译成另一个句子不仅仅是口头上的。你形成的新句子不是原句的口头复制品。如果准确的话，它只忠实于思想。这就是为什么进行此类翻译是您可以对自己进行的最佳测试，如果您想确定自己已经消化了命题，而不仅仅是吞下了单词。如果你没有通过测试，你就发现了理解的失败。如果你说你知道作者的意思，但只能重复作者的句子来表明你知道，那么换句话说，你就无法识别作者的命题。

The translation of one English sentence into another, however, is not merely verbal. The new sentence you have formed is not a verbal replica of the original. If accurate, it is faithful to the thought alone. That is why making such translations is the best test you can apply to yourself, if you want to be sure you have digested the proposition, not merely swallowed the words. If you fail the test, you have uncovered a failure of understanding. If you say that you know what the author means, but can only repeat the author’s sentence to show that you do, then you would not be able to recognize the author’s proposition if it were presented to you in other words.

作者自己在写作过程中可能会用不同的文字表达同一个命题。没有看透文字所表达的命题的读者可能会将等价的句子当作不同命题的陈述来对待。想象一下，一个人不知道“2 + 2 = 4”和“4 – 2 = 2”是同一个算术关系的不同表示法——四的关系是二的两倍，或者二是四的一半。

The author may himself express the same proposition in different words in the course of his writing. The reader who has not seen through the words to the proposition they convey is likely to treat the equivalent sentences as if they were statements of different propositions. Imagine a person who did not know that “2 + 2 = 4” and “4 – 2 = 2” were different notations for the same arithmetic relationship—the relationship of four as the double of two, or two as the half of four.

你将不得不得出结论，那个人只是做了不明白等式。对于你自己或任何其他人，如果你无法分辨同一命题的等价陈述何时被作出，或者当他声称理解一个句子包含的命题时，他自己不能提供等价陈述，你就会被迫得出同样的结论。

You would have to conclude that that person simply did not understand the equation. The same conclusion is forced on you concerning yourself or anybody else who cannot tell when equivalent statements of the same proposition are being made, or who cannot himself offer an equivalent statement when he claims to understand the proposition a sentence contains.

这些评论与主题阅读有关——阅读几本关于同一主题的书。不同的作者经常用不同的词说同样的事情，或者用几乎相同的词说不同的事情。看不透语言中的术语和命题的读者永远无法比较此类相关著作。由于他们的语言差异，他可能会误读作者不同意，或者因为他们陈述中的语言相似而忽略他们真正的差异。

These remarks have a bearing on syntopical reading—the reading of several books about the same subject matter. Different authors frequently say the same thing in different words, or different things using almost the same words. The reader who cannot see through the language to the terms and propositions will never be able to compare such related works. Because of their verbal differences, he is likely to misread the authors as disagreeing, or to ignore their real differences because of verbal resemblances in their statements.

还有一个测试你是否理解你读过的句子中的命题。您能否指出命题所描述的或与命题有任何相关性的一些经验？你能通过引用它的特定实例来举例说明已阐明的普遍真理吗？想象一个可能的案例通常和引用一个实际案例一样好。如果你根本无法通过想象或参考实际经验来举例说明或说明该命题，你应该怀疑你不知道在说什么。

There is one other test of whether you understand the proposition in a sentence you have read. Can you point to some experience you have had that the proposition describes or to which the proposition is in any way relevant? Can you exemplify the general truth that has been enunciated by referring to a particular instance of it? To imagine a possible case is often as good as citing an actual one. If you cannot do anything at all to exemplify or illustrate the proposition, either imaginatively or by reference to actual experiences, you should suspect that you do not know what is being said.

并非所有命题都同样容易受到此测试的影响。可能需要有只有实验室才能负担得起的特殊经历，以确保你已经掌握了某些科学命题。但要点很明确。命题不存在于真空中。它们指的是我们生活的世界。除非你能表现出对命题所指或以某种方式相关的实际或可能事实的一些了解，否则你是在玩文字游戏，而不是在处理思想和知识。

Not all propositions are equally susceptible to this test. It may be necessary to have the special experience that only a laboratory can afford to be sure you have grasped certain scientific propositions. But the main point is clear. Propositions do not exist in a vacuum. They refer to the world in which we live. Unless you can show some acquaintance with actual or possible facts to which the proposition refers or is relevant somehow, you are playing with words, not dealing with thought and knowledge.

让我们考虑一个这样的例子。形而上学的一个基本命题可以用下面的话来表达：“除了实际之外，没有任何行为。” 我们听到很多学生重复这些话带着一种满足的智慧对我们说。他们认为通过如此完美的口头重复，他们正在履行对我们和作者的责任。但是，当我们要求他们换句话说这个命题时，虚假就很明显了。例如，他们很少会说，如果某物不存在，它就无能为力。然而，这是一个显而易见的翻译——至少对于任何在原始意义上理解该命题的人来说是显而易见的。

Let us consider one example of this. A basic proposition in metaphysics is expressed by the following words: “Nothing acts except what is actual.” We have heard many students repeat those words to us with an air of satisfied wisdom. They have thought they were discharging their duty to us and to the author by so perfect a verbal repetition. But the sham was obvious as soon as we asked them to state the proposition in other words. Seldom could they say, for instance, that if someting does not exist, it cannot do anything. Yet this is an immediately apparent translation—apparent, at least, to anyone who understood the proposition in the original sense.

如果找不到翻译，我们会要求对该命题进行举例说明。如果他们中的任何一个人告诉我们草不是仅仅因为可能的阵雨而生长——一个人的银行账户不会因为仅仅可能的加薪而增加——我们就会知道这个命题已经被抓住了。

Failing to get a translation, we would then ask for an exemplification of the proposition. If any one of them told us that grass is not made to grow by merely possible showers—that one’s bank account does not increase on account of a merely possible raise—we would know that the proposition had been grasped.

“语言主义”的恶习可以被定义为使用词语而不考虑它们应该传达的思想并且没有意识到它们应该指代的经验的坏习惯。这是在玩文字游戏。正如我们建议的两项测试所表明的那样，“口头表达”是那些未能进行分析性阅读的人的罪过。这样的读者永远不会超越文字。他们将阅读的内容作为口头记忆，可以空口地背诵。某些现代教育家对文科的指责之一是文科倾向于口头表达，但事实似乎恰恰相反。那些没有接受过语法和逻辑艺术训练的人在阅读方面的失败——无处不在的口头表达——表明缺乏这种纪律是如何导致对文字的奴役而不是对文字的掌握。

The vice of “verbalism” can be defined as the bad habit of using words without regard for the thoughts they should convey and without awareness of the experiences to which they should refer. It is playing with words. As the two tests we have suggested indicate, “verbalism” is the besetting sin of those who fail to read analytically. Such readers never get beyond the words. They possess what they read as a verbal memory that they can recite emptily. One of the charges made by certain modern educators against the liberal arts is that they tend to verbalism, but just the opposite seems to be the case. The failure in reading—the omnipresent verbalism—of those who have not been trained in the arts of grammar and logic shows how lack of such discipline results in slavery to words rather than mastery of them.

寻找论据

Finding the Arguments

 

我们已经在提案上花费了足够多的时间。现在让我们转向分析阅读的第七条规则，它要求读者处理句子的集合。我们之前说过，不制定这条解释规则是有原因的通过说读者应该找到最重要的段落。原因是作家之间没有关于如何构建段落的固定惯例。一些伟大的作家，如蒙田、洛克或普鲁斯特，会写出非常长的段落；其他人，如马基雅维利、霍布斯或托尔斯泰，写的相对较短。近年来，在报纸和杂志风格的影响下，大多数作家倾向于削减段落以方便快速阅读。例如，这一段可能太长了。如果我们想宠爱我们的读者，我们应该用“一些伟大的作家”这样的话来开始一个新的读者。

We have spent enough time on propositions. Let us now turn to the seventh rule of analytical reading, which requires the reader to deal with collections of sentences. We said before that there was a reason for not formulating this rule of interpretation by saying that the reader should find the most important paragraphs. The reason is that there are no settled conventions among writers about how to construct paragraphs. Some great writers, such as Montaigne, Locke, or Proust, write extremely long paragraphs; others, such as Machiavelli, Hobbes, or Tolstoy, write relatively short ones. In recent times, under the influence of newspaper and magazine style, most writers tend to cut their paragraphs to fit quick and easy reading. This paragraph, for instance, is probably too long. If we had wanted to coddle our readers, we should have started a new one with the words, “Some great writers.”

这不仅仅是长度的问题。这里麻烦的一点与语言和思想之间的关系有关。第七条规则指导我们阅读的逻辑单元是论证——一系列命题，其中一些给出了另一个命题的理由。这个逻辑单位并不与任何可识别的写作单位唯一相关，因为术语与单词和短语相关，命题与句子相关。一个论点可以用一个复杂的句子来表达。或者它可以用多个句子来表达，这些句子只是一个段落的一部分。有时一个论点可能与一个段落重合，但也可能发生一个论点贯穿几个或多个段落。

It is not merely a matter of length. The point that is troublesome here has to do with the relation between language and thought. The logical unit to which the seventh rule directs our reading is the argument—a sequence of propositions, some of which give reasons for another. This logical unit is not uniquely related to any recognizable unit of writing, as terms are related to words and phrases, and propositions to sentences. An argument may be expressed in a single complicated sentence. Or it may be expressed in a number of sentences that are only part of one paragraph. Sometimes an argument may coincide with a paragraph, but it may also happen that an argument runs through several or many paragraphs.

还有一个困难。任何一本书中都有许多段落根本没有表达论点——甚至可能不是一本书的一部分。它们可能包含详细说明证据或报告证据收集方式的句子集。正如有一些次要的句子，因为它们只是题外话或旁白，所以也可以有这样的段落。几乎不需要说它们应该被快速阅读。

There is one further difficulty. There are many paragraphs in any book that do not express an argument at all— perhaps not even part of one. They may consist of collections of sentences that detail evidence or report how the evidence has been gathered. As there are sentences that are of secondary importance, because they are merely digressions or side remarks, so also can there be paragraphs of this sort. It hardly needs to be said that they should be read rather quickly.

正因为如此，我们建议规则 7 的另一种表述方式如下：找出书中的段落是否能说明其重要论点；但是，如果论点没有这样表达，你的任务就是通过从这一段中摘录一个句子来构建它们，并且从那开始，直到你收集到陈述构成论点的命题的句子序列。

Because of all this, we suggest another formulation of RULE 7, as follows: FIND IF YOU CAN THE PARAGRAPHS IN A BOOK THAT STATE ITS IMPORTANT ARGUMENTS; BUT IF THE ARGUMENTS ARE NOT THUS EXPRESSED, YOUR TASK IS TO CONSTRUCT THEM, BY TAKING A SENTENCE FROM THIS PARAGRAPH, AND ONE FROM THAT, UNTIL YOU HAVE GATHERED TOGETHER THE SEQUENCE OF SENTENCES THAT STATE THE PROPOSITIONS THAT COMPOSE THE ARGUMENT.

在你发现了前导句之后，段落的构建应该相对容易。有多种方法可以做到这一点。你可以通过在一张纸上写下共同构成一个论点的命题来做到这一点。但通常更好的方法，正如我们已经建议的那样，是在空白处加上数字和其他标记，以指示句子出现的位置，这些句子应该按顺序连接在一起。

After you have discovered the leading sentences, the construction of paragraphs should be relatively easy. There are various ways of doing this. You can do it by actually writing out on a piece of paper the propositions that together form an argument. But usually a better way, as we have already suggested, is to put numbers in the margin, together with other marks, to indicate the places where the sentences occur that should be tied together in a sequence.

在阐明论点这一点上，作者或多或少对他们的读者有所帮助。优秀的说明性作者试图揭示而不是隐藏他们的思想。然而，并非所有优秀的作家都以同样的方式做到这一点。有些人，例如欧几里德、伽利略、牛顿（以几何或数学风格写作的作家），接近于将单个段落作为论证单元的理想。大多数非数学领域的写作风格倾向于在一个段落中提出两个或多个论点，或者一个论点贯穿多个。

Authors are more or less helpful to their readers in this matter of making the arguments plain. Good expository authors try to reveal, not conceal, their thought. Yet not even all good authors do this in the same way. Some, such as Euclid, Galileo, Newton (authors who write in a geometrical or mathematical style), come close to the ideal of making a single paragraph an argumentative unit. The style of most writing in non-mathematical fields tends to present two or more arguments in a single paragraph or to have an argument run through several.

随着一本书的结构更加松散，段落往往变得更加分散。您通常必须搜索一章的所有段落，才能找到可以构造成单个论点陈述的句子。有些书让你徒劳地寻找，有些甚至不鼓励你去寻找。

In proportion as a book is more loosely constructed, the paragraphs tend to become more diffuse. You often have to search through all the paragraphs of a chapter to find the sentences you can construct into a statement of a single argument. Some books make you search in vain, and some do not even encourage the search.

一本好书通常会随着论点的发展而自我总结。如果作者在章节末尾或详细章节末尾为您总结了他的论点，您应该能够回顾前面的页面并找到他在摘要中汇集的材料。在《物种起源》中，达尔文在题为“重述与结论”的最后一章中为读者总结了他的整个论点。读过这本书的读者应该得到帮助。没有的人不能使用它。

A good book usually summarizes itself as its arguments develop.
