If the author summarizes his arguments for you at the end of a chapter, or at the end of an elaborate section, you should be able to look back over the preceding pages and find the materials he has brought together in the summary. In The Origin of Species, Darwin summarizes his whole argument for the reader in a last chapter, entitled “Recapitulation and Conclusion.” The reader who has worked through the book deserves that help. The one who has not cannot use it.

顺便说一句，如果你在开始分析阅读这本书之前已经仔细检查过这本书，你就会知道存在摘要段落，如果存在，它们在哪里。然后，您可以在解释本书时充分利用它们。

Incidentally, if you have inspected the book well before beginning to read it analytically, you will know whether the summary passages exist and if they do, where they are. You can then make the best possible use of them when interpreting the book.

糟糕或结构松散的书的另一个标志是论点中省略了步骤。有时它们可​​以省略而不会造成损害或不便，因为省略的命题通常可以从读者的常识中得到补充。但有时他们的遗漏会产生误导，甚至可能有意误导。演说家或宣传者最熟悉的技巧之一是不说某些与论点高度相关的事情，但如果将它们明确化，可能会受到质疑。虽然我们不指望一位以指导我们为目的的诚实作者会使用这种技巧，但仔细阅读以明确论证中的每一步仍然是一条可靠的准则。

Another sign of a bad or loosely constructed book is the omission of steps in an argument. Sometimes they can be omitted without damage or inconvenience, because the propositions left out can be generally supplied from the common knowledge of readers. But sometimes their omission is misleading, and may even be intended to mislead. One of the most familiar tricks of the orator or propagandist is to leave certain things unsaid, things that are highly relevant to the argument, but that might be challenged if they were made explicit. While we do not expect such devices in an honest author whose aim is to instruct us, it is nevertheless a sound maxim of careful reading to make every step in an argument explicit.

无论是什么类型的书，您作为读者的义务都是一样的。如果书中包含论点，您必须知道它们是什么，并且能够将它们概括为简明扼要。任何好的论点都可以简而言之。当然，也有建立在论据之上的论据。在详尽的分析过程中，可以证明一件事以证明另一件事，而这又可以用来说明更进一步的观点。然而，推理的单位是单个论点。如果你能在你正在阅读的任何一本书中找到这些，你就不太可能错过更大的序列。

Whatever kind of book it is, your obligation as a reader remains the same. If the book contains arguments, you must know what they are, and be able to put them into a nutshell. Any good argument can be put into a nutshell. There are, of course, arguments built upon arguments. In the course of an elaborate analysis, one thing may be proved in order to prove another, and this may be used in turn to make a still further point. The units of reasoning, however, are single arguments. If you can find these in any book you are reading, you are not likely to miss the larger sequences.

说得很好，你可能会反对，但除非一个人像逻辑学家那样了解论证的结构，否则怎么能指望在书中找到它们，或者更糟的是，当作者没有陈述它们时如何构建它们紧凑地放在一个段落中？

This is all very well to say, you may object, but unless one knows the structure of arguments as a logician does, how can one be expected to find them in a book, or worse, to construct them when the author does not state them compactly in a single paragraph?

答案是很明显，你不必“像逻辑学家那样”了解论证。世界上逻辑学家相对较少，无论好坏。大多数传达知识和指导我们的书籍都包含论据。它们是为普通读者准备的，而不是为逻辑专家准备的。

The answer is that it must be obvious that you do not have to know about arguments “as a logician does.” There are relatively few logicians in the world, for better or for worse. Most of the books that convey knowledge and can instruct us contain arguments. They are intended for the general reader, not for specialists in logic.

阅读这些书不需要很强的逻辑能力。重复我们之前说过的，人类思维的本质是这样的，如果它在阅读过程中起作用，如果它与作者达成协议并达到他的命题，它也会看到他的论点。

No great logical competence is needed to read these books. To repeat what we said before, the nature of the human mind is such that if it works at all during the process of reading, if it comes to terms with the author and reaches his propositions, it will see his arguments as well.

但是，我们可以说一些可能对您执行此阅读规则有所帮助的事情。首先，请记住每个论点都必须包含多个陈述。其中，有些给出了你应该接受作者提出的结论的理由。先找到结论，再找原因。如果您首先找到原因，请查看它们的导向。

There are, however, a few things we can say that may be helpful to you in carrying out this rule of reading. In the first place, remember that every argument must involve a number of statements. Of these, some give the reasons why you should accept a conclusion the author is proposing. If you find the conclusion first, then look for the reasons. If you find the reasons first, see where they lead.

其次，区分指出一个或多个特定事实作为某些概括的证据的论证类型和提供一系列一般性陈述以证明某些进一步概括的论证类型。前一种推理通常称为归纳推理，后者称为演绎推理；但名字并不重要。重要的是区分两者的能力。

In the second place, discriminate between the kind of argument that points to one or more particular facts as evidence for some generalization and the kind that offers a series of general statements to prove some further generalizations. The former kind of reasoning is usually referred to as inductive, the latter as deductive; but the names are not what is important. What is important is the ability to discriminate between the two.

在科学文献中，每当强调通过推理证明命题与通过实验建立命题之间的差异时，就会观察到这种区别。伽利略在他的两门新科学中谈到用实验来说明数学证明已经得出的结论。伟大的生理学家威廉·哈维 (William Harvey) 在其著作《论心脏的运动》(On the Motion of the Heart)的最后一章中写道：“理性和实验表明，心室搏动下的血液流经肺部和心脏，并被泵送到全身。” 有时可以通过从其他普遍真理进行推理和提供实验证据来支持一个命题。有时只有一种论证方法可用。

In the literature of science, this distinction is observed whenever the difference is emphasized between the proof of a proposition by reasoning and its establishment by experiment. Galileo, in his Two New Sciences, speaks of illustrating by experiment conclusions that have already been reached by mathematical demonstration. And in a concluding chapter of his book On the Motion of the Heart, the great physiologist William Harvey writes: “It has been shown by reason and experiment that blood by the beat of the ventricles flows through the lungs and heart and is pumped to the whole body.” Sometimes it is possible to support a proposition both by reasoning from other general truths and by offering experimental evidence. Sometimes only one method of argument is available.

第三，观察作者所说的他必须假定的东西，他所说的可以证明或以其他方式证明的东西，以及不需要证明的东西，因为它是不言而喻的。他可能会诚实地告诉你他所有的假设是什么，或者他可能会诚实地让您自己去寻找它们。显然，并不是所有的事情都可以被证明，就像不是所有的事情都可以被定义一样。如果每个命题都必须被证明，那么任何证明都没有开始。证明其他命题需要诸如公理和假设或公设之类的东西。如果这些其他命题得到证明，它们当然可以用作进一步证明的前提。

In the third place, observe what things the author says he must assume, what he says can be proved or otherwise evidenced, and what need not be proved because it is self-evident. He may honestly try to tell you what all his assumptions are, or he may just as honestly leave you to find them out for yourself. Obviously, not everything can be proved, just as not everything can be defined. If every proposition had to be proved, there would be no beginning to any proof. Such things as axioms and assumptions or postulates are needed for the proof of other propositions. If these other propositions are proved, they can, of course, be used as premises in further proofs.

换句话说，每一行论点都必须从某个地方开始。基本上，它可以从两种方式或地方开始：作者和读者之间达成一致的假设，或者作者和读者都不能否认的所谓不言自明的命题。在第一种情况下，假设可以是任何东西，只要达成一致即可。第二种情况需要在这里做一些进一步的评论。

Every line of argument, in other words, must start somewhere. Basically, there are two ways or places in which it can start: with assumptions agreed on between writer and reader, or with what are called self-evident propositions, which neither the writer nor reader can deny. In the first case, the assumptions can be anything, so long as agreement exists. The second case requires some further comment here.

近来，将不言而喻的命题称为“重言式”已经司空见惯；这个词背后的感觉有时是对琐碎事物的蔑视，或者是对骗术的怀疑。兔子被从帽子里拉出来。你通过定义你的词来把真相放进去，然后把它拉出来，就好像你很惊讶地发现它在那里一样。然而，情况并非总是如此。

In recent times, it has become commonplace to refer to self-evident propositions as “tautologies”; the feeling behind the term is sometimes one of contempt for the trivial, or a suspicion of legerdemain. Rabbits are being pulled out of a hat. You put the truth in by defining your words, and then pull it out as if you were surprised to find it there. That, however, is not always the case.

例如，“父亲的父亲是祖父”这样的命题与“整体大于部分”这样的命题有很大的区别。前一个陈述是同义反复；该命题包含在词语的定义中；它只是略微隐藏了口头规定，“让我们称父母的父母为‘祖父母’。”但第二个命题远非如此。让我们试着看看为什么。

For example, there is a considerable difference between a proposition such as “a father of a father is a grandfather,” and a proposition such as “the whole is greater than its parts.” The former statement is a tautology; the proposition is contained in the definition of the words; it only thinly conceals the verbal stipulation, “Let us call the parent of a parent a ‘grandparent.’” But that is far from being the case with the second proposition. Let us try to see why.

“整体大于部分”这句话表达了我们对事物本来面目及其关系的理解，无论我们使用什么词或我们如何建立我们的语言惯例，这些都是一样的。有限数量的整体存在，它们有确定的有限部分；例如，此页面可以切成两半或四分之一。现在，正如我们理解一个有限整体（即任何有限整体）以及我们理解一个有限整体的确定部分一样，我们理解整体大于部分，或者部分小于整体。到目前为止，这不仅仅是一个口头上的问题，我们无法定义“整体”和“部分”这两个词的含义；这些词表达了原始的或无法定义的概念。由于我们无法分别定义它们，我们所能做的就是通过陈述整体和部分之间的关​​系来表达我们对整体和部分的理解。

The statement, “The whole is greater than its parts,” expresses our understanding of things as they are and of their relationships, which would be the same no matter what words we used or how we set up our linguistic conventions. Finite quantitative wholes exist and they have definite finite parts; for example, this page can be cut in half or in quarters. Now, as we understand a finite whole (that is, any finite whole) and as we understand a definite part of a finite whole, we understand the whole to be greater than the part, or the part to be less than the whole. So far is this from being a mere verbal matter that we cannot define the meaning of the words “whole” and “part”; these words express primitive or indefinable notions. As we are unable to define them separately, all we can do is express our understanding of whole and part by a statement of how wholes and parts are related.

该陈述是公理化的或不言而喻的，因为它的反面立即被认为是错误的。我们可以把这一页用“部分”这个词，把它一分为二后的一半用“整个”这个词，但是我们不能认为它被切割之前的页面比我们所看到的少一半。剪完后拿在手里。无论我们如何使用语言，我们对有限整体及其确定部分的理解是这样的，以至于我们不得不说我们知道整体大于部分，我们所知道的是存在的整体与其部分之间的关​​系，而不是某种东西关于单词的使用或它们的含义。

The statement is axiomatic or self-evident in the sense that its opposite is immediately seen to be false. We can use the word “part” for this page, and the word “whole” for a half of this page after cutting it in two, but we cannot think that the page before it is cut is less than the half of it that we have in our hand after we have cut it. However we use language, our understanding of finite wholes and their definite parts is such that we are compelled to say that we know that the whole is greater than the part, and what we know is the relation between existent wholes and their parts, not something about the use of words or their meanings.

那么，这种不证自明的命题具有无法证明但又不可否认的真理地位。它们仅基于共同经验，是常识知识的一部分，因为它们不属于任何有组织的知识体系；它们既不属于哲学或数学，也不属于科学或历史。这就是为什么，顺便说一下，欧几里得称它们为“共同概念”。它们也很有启发性，尽管例如洛克并不认为它们具有启发性。他看不出一个真正没有指导意义的命题，比如关于祖父母的命题，和一个真正有指导意义的命题——一个教导我们一些我们本来不会知道的东西——比如关于部分和整体的命题之间没有区别。那些把所有这些命题都称为重言式的现代人犯了同样的错误。

Such self-evident propositions, then, have the status of indemonstrable but also undeniable truths. They are based on common experience alone and are part of common-sense knowledge, for they belong to no organized body of knowledge; they do not belong to philosophy or mathematics any more than they belong to science or history. That is why, incidentally, Euclid called them “common notions.” They are also instructive, despite the fact that Locke, for example, did not think they were. He could see no difference between a proposition that really does not instruct, such as the one about the grandparent, and one that does—one that teaches us something we would not otherwise know—such as the one about parts and wholes. And those moderns who refer to all such propositions as tautologies make the same mistake. They do not see that some of the propositions they call “tautologies” really add to our knowledge, while others, of course, do not.

寻找解决方案

Finding the Solutions

 

分析阅读的这三个规则——关于术语、命题和论点——可以在第八条规则中得到体现，它支配着解释一本书内容的最后一步。不仅如此，它将分析阅读的第一阶段（概述结构）和第二阶段（解释内容）联系在一起。

These three rules of analytical reading—about terms, propositions, and arguments—can be brought to a head in an eighth rule, which governs the last step in the interpretation of a book’s content. More than that, it ties together the first stage of analytical reading (outlining the structure) and the second stage (interpreting the contents).

你试图发现一本书是关于什么的最后一步是发现作者在他的书的过程中试图解决的主要问题。（你会记得，规则 4 涵盖了这一点。）现在，在你与他达成协议并掌握了他的主张和论点之后，你应该通过向自己提出一些进一步的问题来检查你发现了什么。作者试图解决的哪些问题他成功解决了？在解决这些的过程中，他有没有提出新的问题？在他未能解决的新旧问题中，作者自己知道他在哪些问题上失败了？一个好的作家，就像一个好的读者，应该知道一个问题是否已经解决，当然，承认这种情况可能会减少读者的痛苦。

The last step in your attempt to discover what a book is about was the discovery of the major problems that the author tried to solve in the course of his book. (As you will recall, this was covered by Rule 4.) Now, after you have come to terms with him and grasped his propositions and arguments, you should check what you have found by addressing yourself to some further questions. Which of the problems that the author tried to solve did he succeed in solving? In the course of solving these, did he raise any new ones? Of the problems that he failed to solve, old or new, which did the author himself know he had failed on? A good writer, like a good reader, should know whether a problem has been solved or not, although of course it is likely to cost the reader less pain to acknowledge the situation.

解释性阅读的最后一步包含在规则8中。找出作者的解决方案是什么。当你在解释性阅读中应用了这条规则以及它之前的三个规则时，你可以合理地确信你已经成功地理解了这本书。如果你从一本你无法理解的书开始——因此，一本能够教给你一些东西的书——你已经走了很长一段路。更重要的是，您现在可以完成对本书的分析阅读。工作的第三个也是最后一个阶段将相对容易。你一直保持你的眼睛和你的思想开放，你的嘴巴闭上。到目前为止，您一直在关注作者。从这一点开始，你将有机会与作者争论并表达你自己。

This final step in interpretive reading is covered by RULE 8. FIND OUT WHAT THE AUTHOR’S SOLUTIONS ARE. When you have applied this rule, and the three that precede it in interpretive reading, you can feel reasonably sure that you have managed to understand the book. If you started with a book that was over your head—one, therefore, that was able to teach you something—you have come a long way. More than that, you are now able to complete your analytical reading of the book. The third and last stage of the job will be relatively easy. You have been keeping your eyes and your mind open and your mouth shut. Up to this point, you have been following the author. From this point on, you are going to have a chance to argue with the author and express yourself.

分析阅读第二阶段

The Second Stage of Analytical Reading

 

我们现在已经描述了分析阅读的第二阶段。另一种说法是，我们现在已经列出了回答第二个基本问题的材料，你必须就一本书，或者你读过的任何东西提出这个问题。您会记得第二个问题是详细说了什么，以及如何说？应用规则 5 到 8 显然可以帮助您回答这个问题。当你和作者达成共识，找到他的主要命题和论点，找出他对他所面临问题的解决办法，你就会知道他在书中说的是什么，从而准备继续追问关于它的最后两个基本问题。

We have now described the second stage of analytical reading. Another way to say this is that we have now set forth the materials for answering the second basic question that you must ask about a book, or indeed anything that you read. You will recall that that second question is What is being said in detail, and how? Applying Rules 5 through 8 clearly helps you to answer this question. When you have come to terms with the author, found his key propositions and arguments, and identified his solutions of the problems that he faced, you will know what he is saying in his book, and you are thus prepared to go on to ask the final two basic questions about it.

既然我们已经完成了分析阅读过程的另一个阶段，那么让我们像以前一样暂停一下，写下这个阶段的规则以供回顾。

Since we have now completed another stage in the analytical reading process, let us, as before, pause a moment to write out the rules of this stage for review.

分析阅读的第二阶段，或查找书籍内容的规则（解释其内容）

The Second Stage of Analytical Reading, or Rules for Finding What a Book Says (Interpreting Its Contents)

 

5. 通过解读作者的关键词与作者达成共识。

5. Come to terms with the author by interpreting his key words.

6. 通过处理作者最重要的句子来把握作者的主要命题。

6. Grasp the author’s leading propositions by dealing with his most important sentences.

7. 了解作者的论点，通过在句子序列中找到它们或从中构造它们。

7. Know the author’s arguments, by finding them in, or constructing them out of, sequences of sentences.

8. 确定作者解决了他的哪些问题，哪些没有解决；至于后者，决定作者知道他没有解决的问题。

8. Determine which of his problems the author has solved, and which he has not; and as to the latter, decide which the author knew he had failed to solve.

10

公平地批评一本书

10CRITICIZING A BOOK FAIRLY

 

我们在上一章的结尾说过，我们已经取得了长足的进步。我们已经学会了如何勾勒一本书的大纲。我们已经学习了解释一本书内容的四个规则。我们现在已经准备好进入分析阅读的最后阶段。在这里你将收获之前所有努力的回报。

We said at the end of the last chapter that we had come a long way. We have learned how to outline a book. We have learned the four rules for interpreting a book’s contents. We are now ready for the last stage of analytical reading. Here you will reap the reward of all your previous efforts.

读书是一种对话。你可能认为这根本不是对话，因为作者在说话，你无话可说。如果你这么想，你就没有意识到你作为读者的全部义务——你也没有抓住你的机会。

Reading a book is a kind of conversation. You may think it is not conversation at all, because the author does all the talking and you have nothing to say. If you think that, you do not realize your full obligation as a reader—and you are not grasping your opportunities.

事实上，读者才是最有发言权的人。作者说完了，接下来就轮到读者了。一本书和它的读者之间的对话似乎是有条不紊的，每一方轮流交谈，没有中断，等等。但是，如果读者不守纪律且不礼貌，则可能不会有秩序。可怜的作者无法为自己辩护。他不能说，“在这里，等我说完，再开始反对。” 他无法抗议读者误解了他，没有理解他的观点。

As a matter of fact, the reader is the one who has the last word. The author has had his say, and then it is the reader’s turn. The conversation between a book and its reader would appear to be an orderly one, each party talking in turn, no interruptions, and so forth. If, however, the reader is undisciplined and impolite, it may be anything but orderly. The poor author cannot defend himself. He cannot say, “Here, wait till I’ve finished, before you start disagreeing.” He cannot protest that the reader has misunderstood him, has missed his point.

面对面的人之间的普通谈话只有在礼貌地进行时才是好的。我们考虑的不仅仅是约定俗成的礼貌的社会礼貌。这样的约定并不重要。重要的是要遵守知识礼仪。没有它，谈话就是争吵而不是有益的交流。当然，我们在这里假设谈话是关于一个男人可以同意或不同意的严肃问题。然后，他们做好自己就变得很重要。否则，企业就没有利润。良好谈话的好处是可以学到的东西。

Ordinary conversations between persons who confront each other are good only when they are carried on civilly. We are not thinking merely of the civilities according to conventions of social politeness. Such conventions are not really important. What is important is that there is an intellectual etiquette to be observed. Without it, conversation is bickering rather than profitable communication. We are assuming here, of course, that the conversation is about a serious matter on which men can agree or disagree. Then it becomes important that they conduct themselves well. Otherwise, there is no profit in the enterprise. The profit in good conversation is something learned.

普通对话的真实情况在一本书与读者交谈而读者回应的相当特殊的情况下更是如此。作者纪律严明，我们暂时认为是理所当然的。在好书的情况下，可以假设他很好地进行了他的谈话。读者可以做些什么来回报？他必须做些什么才能很好地坚持自己的目标？

What is true of ordinary conversation is even more true of the rather special situation in which a book has talked to a reader and the reader talks back. That the author is well disciplined, we will take for granted temporarily. That he has conducted his part of the conversation well can be assumed in the case of good books. What can the reader do to reciprocate? What must he do to hold up his end well?

读者有义务也有机会反驳。机会很明显。没有什么能阻止读者发表判断。然而，义务的根源在于书籍与读者之间关系的本质。

The reader has an obligation as well as an opportunity to talk back. The opportunity is clear. Nothing can stop a reader from pronouncing judgment. The roots of the obligation, however, lie a little deeper in the nature of the relation between books and readers.

如果这本书是那种传授知识的书，那么作者的目的就是提供指导。他试过教书。他试图说服或劝说他的读者相信某事。只有当读者最终说：“我受教了。你让我相信某某是真的，或者让我相信这是可能的。” 但即使读者不服、不服，也应该尊重作者的意图和努力。读者欠他一个深思熟虑的判断。如果他不能说“我同意”，他至少应该有不同意甚至暂停对这个问题作出判断的理由。

If the book is of the sort that conveys knowledge, the author’s aim was to instruct. He has tried to teach. He has tried to convince or persuade his reader about something. His effort is crowned with success only if the reader finally says, “I am taught. You have convinced me that such and such is true, or persuaded me that it is probable.” But even if the reader is not convinced or persuaded, the author’s intention and effort should be respected. The reader owes him a considered judgment. If he cannot say, “I agree,” he should at least have grounds for disagreeing or even for suspending judgment on the question.

我们实际上只是在说我们已经说过很多次的话。一本好书值得积极阅读。阅读活动并不止于理解一本书所说的内容。它必须由以下工作完成 批评、评判工作。要求不高的读者无法满足这一要求，甚至可能比他无法分析和解释更多。他不仅不努力去理解；他还简单地把一本书放在一边忘记了，就把它丢掉了。比微弱地赞美它更糟糕的是，他通过不给予任何批判性考虑来诅咒它。

We are really saying no more than what we have already said many times. A good book deserves an active reading. The activity of reading does not stop with the work of understanding what a book says. It must be completed by the work of criticism, the work of judging. The undemanding reader fails to satisfy this requirement, probably even more than he fails to analyze and interpret. He not only makes no effort to understand; he also dismisses a book simply by putting it aside and forgetting it. Worse than faintly praising it, he damns it by giving it no critical consideration whatever.

可教性是一种美德

Teachability as a Virtue

 

我们所说的顶嘴，不是阅读之外的东西。这是分析阅读一本书的第三阶段；和前两个阶段一样，这里也有规则。其中一些规则是知识分子礼仪的一般准则。我们将在本章中处理它们。其他的是定义批评点的更具体的标准。它们将在下一章中讨论。

What we mean by talking back is not something apart from reading. It is the third stage in the analytical reading of a book; and there are rules here as in the case of the first two stages. Some of these rules are general maxims of intellectual etiquette. We will deal with them in this chapter. Others are more specific criteria for defining points of criticism. They will be discussed in the next chapter.

人们倾向于认为一本好书可以超越普通读者的批评。读者和作者不是同行。根据这种观点，提交人应该只接受由他的同龄人组成的陪审团的审判。记住培根给读者的建议：也不相信和认为理所当然；也找不到谈话和话语；但要权衡考虑。沃尔特斯科特爵士对那些“阅读怀疑或阅读蔑视”的人进行了更可怕的诽谤。

There is a tendency to think that a good book is above the criticism of the average reader. The reader and the author are not peers. The author, according to this view, should be subjected to a trial only by a jury of his peers. Remember Bacon’s recommendation to the reader: “Read not to contradict and confute; nor to believe and take for granted; nor to find talk and discourse; but to weigh and consider.” Sir Walter Scott casts even more dire aspersions on those “who read to doubt or read to scorn.”

当然，这里有一定的道理，但也有很多关于书籍如此被完美包围的光环以及由此产生的虚假虔诚的胡说八道。读者可能就像孩子一样，伟大的作家可以教他们，但这并不意味着他们不能被听到。塞万提斯说：“没有比这本书更糟糕的东西，但其中可能会发现一些好东西。”这句话可能是对的，也可能是错的。更可以肯定的是，没有一本好到挑不出毛病的书。

There is a certain truth here, of course, but there is also a good deal of nonsense about the aura of impeccability with which books are thus surrounded, and the false piety it produces. Readers may be like children, in the sense that great authors can teach them, but that does not mean they must not be heard from. Cervantes may or not have been right in saying, “There is no book so bad but something good may be found in it.” It is more certain that there is no book so good that no fault can be found with it.

诚然，一本能启迪读者并在这个意义上优于他们的书，在他们理解之前不应该受到他们的批评。当他们这样做时，他们已经将自己提升到几乎与作者平等的地位。现在他们可以行使新职位的权利和特权。除非他们现在运用他们的批判能力，否则他们就是在冤枉作者。他已尽其所能使他们与他平等。他值得他们像他的同龄人一样行事，他们与他交谈，他们顶嘴。

It is true that a book that can enlighten its readers, and is in this sense superior to them, should not be criticized by them until they understand it. When they do, they have elevated themselves almost to equality with the author. Now they are fit to exercise the rights and privileges of their new position. Unless they exercise their critical faculties now, they are doing the author an injustice. He has done what he could to make them his equal. He deserves that they act like his peers, that they engage in conversation with him, that they talk back.

我们在这里讨论的是可教性的美德——一种几乎总是被误解的美德。可教性常常与服从相混淆。一个人如果被动和顺从，就会被错误地认为是可以受教的。相反，可教性是一种极其积极的美德。不自由地行使独立判断力的人是真正可教的。也许可以训练他，但不能教他。因此，最受教的读者也是最挑剔的。他是最终对一本书作出回应的读者，他以最大的努力对作者所讨论的问题做出自己的决定。

We are discussing here the virtue of teachability—a virtue that is almost always misunderstood. Teachability is often confused with subservience. A person is wrongly thought to be teachable if he is passive and pliable. On the contrary, teachability is an extremely active virtue. No one is really teachable who does not freely exercise his power of independent judgment. He can be trained, perhaps, but not taught. The most teachable reader is, therefore, the most critical. He is the reader who finally responds to a book by the greatest effort to make up his own mind on the matters the author has discussed.

我们说“最后”是因为可教性要求教师在被评判之前被充分倾听，更重要的是，被理解。我们还应该补充一点，单纯的努力量并不是可教性的充分标准。读者必须知道如何判断一本书，就像他必须知道如何理解其内容一样。那么，这第三组阅读规则是可教性训练最后阶段的指南。

We say “finally” because teachability requires that a teacher be fully heard and, more than that, understood before he is judged. We should add also that sheer amount of effort is not an adequate criterion of teachability. The reader must know how to judge a book, just as he must know how to arrive at an understanding of its contents. This third group of rules for reading, then, is a guide to the last stage in the disciplined exercise of teachability.

修辞的作用

The Role of Rhetoric

 

我们到处都发现了教学艺术与受教艺术之间的某种互惠性，作者的技巧使他成为一个体贴的作家，而读者的技巧使他深思熟虑地阅读一本书。我们已经看到相同的语法和逻辑原则是如何构成良好写作规则和良好阅读规则的基础的。到目前为止，我们讨论的规则涉及作者方面的可理解性和读者方面的理解。这最后一组规则超越了对批判性判断的理解。这就是修辞的用武之地。

We have everywhere found a certain reciprocity between the art of teaching and the art of being taught, between the skill of the author that makes him a considerate writer and the skill of the reader that makes him handle a book with consideration. We have seen how the same principles of grammar and logic underlie rules of good writing as well as rules of good reading. The rules we have so far discussed concern the achievement of intelligibility on the part of the writer and the achievement of understanding on the part of the reader. This last set of rules goes beyond understanding to critical judgment. Here is where rhetoric comes in.

当然，修辞学有很多用途。我们通常将其与演说家或宣传家联系起来。但就其最普遍的意义而言，修辞涉及到人类之间进行交流的每一种情况。如果我们是谈话者，我们不仅希望被理解，而且希望在某种意义上得到同意。如果我们试图交流的目的是严肃的，我们希望说服或说服——更准确地说，说服理论问题并说服最终影响行动或感觉的事情。

There are, of course, many uses of rhetoric. We usually think of it in connection with the orator or the propagandist. But in its most general significance, rhetoric is involved in every situation in which communication takes place among human beings. If we are the talkers, we wish not only to be understood but also to be agreed with in some sense. If our purpose in trying to communicate is serious, we wish to convince or persuade—more precisely, to convince about theoretical matters and to persuade about matters that ultimately affect action or feeling.

要同样认真地接受这样的交流，一个人不仅必须是一个回应者，而且是一个负责任的倾听者。你的反应取决于你遵循所说的内容并注意提示它的意图。但你也有责任采取立场。当你拿走它时，它就是你的，而不是作者的。认为除了你自己之外的任何人都对你的判断负责就是成为一个奴隶，而不是一个自由人。文科正是由此而得名。

To be equally serious in receiving such communication, one must be not only a responsive but also a responsible listener. You are responsive to the extent that you follow what has been said and note the intention that prompts it. But you also have the responsibility of taking a position. When you take it, it is yours, not the author’s. To regard anyone except yourself as responsible for your judgment is to be a slave, not a free man. It is from this fact that the liberal arts acquire their name.

就演讲者或作家而言，修辞技巧就是知道如何说服或劝说。由于这是最终目的，沟通的所有其他方面都必须为它服务。清晰易懂的写作中的语法和逻辑技巧本身是有价值的，但它也是达到目的的一种手段。反过来，就读者或听众而言，修辞技巧是知道如何对任何试图说服或说服我们的人做出反应。在这里，语法和逻辑技能也使我们能够理解所说的内容，为批判性反应做好准备。

On the part of the speaker or writer, rhetorical skill is knowing how to convince or persuade. Since this is the ultimate end in view, all the other aspects of communication must serve it. Grammatical and logical skill in writing clearly and intelligibly has merit in itself, but it is also a means to an end. Reciprocally, on the part of the reader or listener, rhetorical skill is knowing how to react to anyone who tries to convince or persuade us. Here, too, grammatical and logical skill, which enables us to understand what is being said, prepares the way for a critical reaction.

暂停判决的重要性

The Importance of Suspending Judgment

 

因此，您会看到语法、逻辑和修辞这三种艺术如何合作调节写作和阅读的复杂过程。分析阅读前两个阶段的技能来自对语法和逻辑的掌握。第三阶段的技巧取决于剩下的艺术。这个阅读阶段的规则基于最广泛意义上的修辞原则。我们会将它们视为一种礼仪准则，使读者在回嘴时不仅有礼貌，而且有效。（虽然没有得到普遍认可，但礼仪总是服务于这两个目的，而不仅仅是前者。）

Thus you see how the three arts of grammar, logic, and rhetoric cooperate in regulating the elaborate processes of writing and reading. Skill in the first two stages of analytical reading comes from a mastery of grammar and logic. Skill in the third stage depends on the remaining art. The rules of this stage of reading rest on the principles of rhetoric, conceived in the broadest sense. We will consider them as a code of etiquette to make the reader not only polite, but also effective, in talking back. (Although it is not generally recognized, etiquette always serves these two purposes, not just the former.)

您可能还会看到阅读的第九条规则是什么。它已经被暗示了好几次了。在您仔细聆听并确定您理解之前，不要开始顶嘴。直到你真的对完成前两个阅读阶段感到满意时，你才可以自由地表达自己。当您拥有时，您不仅获得了成为批评家的权利；你也有义务这样做。

You probably also see what the ninth rule of reading is going to be. It has been intimated several times already. Do not begin to talk back until you have listened carefully and are sure you understand. Not until you are honestly satisfied that you have accomplished the first two stages of reading should you feel free to express yourself. When you have, you not only have earned the right to turn critic; you also have the duty to do so.

这实际上意味着分析阅读的第三阶段必须始终及时跟在其他两个阶段之后。前两个阶段相互渗透。即使是初级读者也可以将它们结合起来，而专家几乎可以将它们完全结合起来。他可以通过将整体分解成部分，同时从思想和知识的要素、术语、命题和论证中构建整体来发现一本书的内容。此外，即使是初学者，也可以在良好的检视阅读中完成这两个阶段所需的一定量的工作。但是专家和初学者一样，必须等到他理解了之后才开始批评。

This means, in effect, that the third stage of analytical reading must always follow the other two in time. The first two stages interpenetrate each other. Even the beginning reader can combine them somewhat, and the expert combines them almost completely. He can discover the contents of a book by breaking down the whole into its parts and at the same time constructing the whole out of its elements of thought and knowledge, its terms, propositions, and arguments. Furthermore, even for the beginner, a certain amount of the work required at those two stages can be performed during a good inspectional reading. But the expert no less than the beginner must wait until he understands before he starts to criticize.

让我们用以下形式重申这第九条阅读规则：规则9。你必须能够说，用合理的确定性， “我理解”，然后才能说出以下任何一项： “我同意”或“我不同意”或“我暂停判断”。这三句话用尽了你可以采取的所有关键立场。我们希望您没有错误地认为批评总是不同意。这是一个普遍的误解。同意与不同意一样，都是对你的批判性判断的运用。你同意和不同意都可能是错误的。同意而不理解是愚蠢的。在不理解的情况下不同意是无礼的。

Let us restate this ninth rule of reading in the following form: RULE 9. YOU MUST BE ABLE TO SAY, WITH REASONABLE CERTAINTY, “I UNDERSTAND,” BEFORE YOU CAN SAY ANY ONE OF THE FOLLOWING THINGS: “I AGREE,” OR “I DISAGREE,” OR “I SUSPEND JUDGMENT.” These three remarks exhaust all the critical positions you can take. We hope you have not made the error of supposing that to criticize is always to disagree. That is a popular misconception. To agree is just as much an exercise of critical judgment on your part as to disagree. You can be just as wrong in agreeing as in disagreeing. To agree without understanding is inane. To disagree without understanding is impudent.

虽然一开始可能不那么明显，但暂停判断也是一种批评行为。它采取的立场是，有些东西还没有被展示出来。你是说你没有以一种或另一种方式被说服或说服。

Though it may not be so obvious at first, suspending judgment is also an act of criticism. It is taking the position that something has not been shown. You are saying that you are not convinced or persuaded one way or the other.

该规则似乎是显而易见的常识，您可能想知道我们为什么费心如此明确地陈述它。有两个原因。首先，许多人犯了前面提到的将批评与不同意等同的错误。（即使是“建设性”的批评也是不同意。）其次，虽然这条规则看起来很合理，但根据我们的经验，很少有人在实践中遵守它。就像黄金法则一样，它引发的更多是口头上的服务，而不是明智的服从。

The rule seems to be such obvious common sense that you may wonder why we have bothered to state it so explicitly. There are two reasons. In the first place, many people make the error already mentioned of identifying criticism with disagreement. (Even “constructive” criticism is disagreement.) In the second place, though this rule seems obviously sound, our experience has been that few people observe it in practice. Like the golden rule, it elicits more lip service than intelligent obedience.

每个作者都有过遭受书评家批评的经历，他们觉得自己没有义务先完成前两个阶段的工作。评论家常常认为他不必既是读者又是法官。每个讲师也有过被问到批评性问题的经历，而这些问题并不是基于对他所说内容的任何理解。你自己可能记得有一次，有人一口气或最多两口气对演讲者说：“我不明白你的意思，但我认为你错了。”

Every author has had the experience of suffering book reviews by critics who did not feel obliged to do the work of the first two stages first. The critic too often thinks he does not have to be a reader as well as a judge. Every lecturer has also had the experience of having critical questions asked that were not based on any understanding of what he had said. You yourself may remember an occasion where someone said to a speaker, in one breath or at most two, “I don’t know what you mean, but I think you’re wrong.”

回答这种批评实际上没有意义。唯一有礼貌的做法是请他们为你陈述你的立场，他们声称这个立场具有挑战性。如果他们不能令人满意地完成，如果他们不能重复你用他们自己的话说，你知道他们不明白，你完全有理由无视他们的批评。它们是无关紧要的，因为所有批评都必须不是基于理解。当你发现很少有人表现出像你一样理解你所说的内容时，你可以为他的同意而高兴，也可以为他的异议而深感不安。

There is actually no point in answering critics of this sort. The only polite thing to do is to ask them to state your position for you, the position they claim to be challenging. If they cannot do it satisfactorily, if they cannot repeat what you have said in their own words, you know that they do not understand, and you are entirely justified in ignoring their criticisms. They are irrelevant, as all criticism must be that is not based on understanding. When you find the rare person who shows that he understands what you are saying as well as you do, then you can delight in his agreement or be seriously disturbed by his dissent.

多年来与各种各样的学生一起阅读书籍，我们发现违反这条规则比遵守这条规则更受尊重。显然不知道作者在说什么的学生似乎毫不犹豫地自命为他的评委。他们不仅不同意他们不理解的事情，而且同样糟糕的是，他们还经常同意他们无法用自己的话清楚地表达的立场。他们的讨论，就像他们的阅读一样，全是文字。在不存在理解的情况下，肯定和否定同样毫无意义且难以理解。对于一个不知道自己在暂停判断什么的读者来说，怀疑或超然的立场也不会更明智。

In years of reading books with students of one kind and another, we have found this rule more honored in the breach than in the observance. Students who plainly do not know what the author is saying seem to have no hesitation in setting themselves up as his judges. They not only disagree with something they do not understand but, what is equally bad, they also often agree to a position they cannot express intelligibly in their own words. Their discussion, like their reading, is all words. Where understanding is not present, affirmations and denials are equally meaningless and unintelligible. Nor is a position of doubt or detachment any more intelligent in a reader who does not know what he is suspending judgment about.

关于遵守这条规则，还有几点需要注意。如果你正在读一本好书，你应该在说“我明白”之前犹豫一下。假设当然是您有很多工作要做，然后才能诚实和有把握地作出声明。当然，在这件事上你必须自己判断，这使得责任更加重大。

There are several further points to note concerning the observance of this rule. If you are reading a good book, you ought to hesitate before you say, “I understand.” The presumption certainly is that you have a lot of work to do before you can make that declaration honestly and with assurance. You must, of course, be a judge of yourself in this matter, and that makes the responsibility even more severe.

说“我不懂”当然也是一种批判性的判断，但只有在你尽力之后，才会反映在书本上，而不是反映在你自己身上。如果你已经做了所有可以指望你的事情，还是不明白，那可能是因为书看不懂。然而，推定有利于这本书，特别是如果它是一本好书。读好书，看不懂通常是读者的错。因此，他有义务完成分析阅读前两个阶段强加的任务很久才进入第三。当你说“我不明白”时，注意你的语气。确保它承认这可能不是作者的错。

To say “I don’t understand” is, of course, also a critical judgment, but only after you have tried your hardest does it reflect on the book rather than yourself. If you have done everything that can be expected of you and still do not understand, it may be because the book is unintelligible. The presumption, however, is in favor of the book, especially if it is a good one. In reading good books, failure to understand is usually the reader’s fault. Hence he is obligated to stay with the task imposed by the first two stages of analytical reading a long time before entering on the third. When you say “I don’t understand,” watch your tone of voice. Be sure it concedes the possibility that it may not be the author’s fault.

在其他两种情况下，该规则需要特别注意。如果你只读了一本书的一部分，就更难确定你理解了，因此你应该更加犹豫是否要批评。有时一本书与同一作者的其他书相关，并且其全部意义取决于它们。在这种情况下，你在说“我明白”时也应该更加谨慎，并且更慢地举起批评的长矛。

There are two other conditions under which the rule requires special care. If you are reading only part of a book, it is more difficult to be sure that you understand, and hence you should be more hesitant to criticize. And sometimes a book is related to other books by the same author, and depends upon them for its full significance. In this situation, also, you should be more circumspect about saying “I understand,” and slower to raise your critical lance.

在最后这方面，一个鲁莽的好例子是由文学评论家提供的，他们同意或不同意亚里士多德的《诗学》，却没有意识到亚里士多德诗歌分析的主要原则部分取决于他的其他作品、他关于心理学和心理学的论文中提出的观点。逻辑学和形而上学。他们在不了解事情的全部内容的情况下同意或不同意。

A good example of brashness in this last respect is furnished by literary critics who have agreed or disagreed with Aristotle’s Poetics without realizing that the main principles in Aristotle’s analysis of poetry depend in part on points made in other of his works, his treatises on psychology and logic and metaphysics. They have agreed or disagreed without understanding what it is all about.

其他作家也是如此，例如柏拉图和康德、亚当·斯密和卡尔·马克思，他们无法在一部作品中说出他们所知道或所想的一切。那些不读康德的《实践理性批判》而评判康德的《纯粹理性批判》，或不读亚当·斯密的《道德情操论》或《没有马克思的资本论的共产党宣言》的国富论的人，很可能同意或不同意他们不完全理解的东西。

The same is true of other writers, such as Plato and Kant, Adam Smith and Karl Marx, who have not been able to say everything they knew or thought in a single work. Those who judge Kant’s Critique of Pure Reason without reading his Critique of Practical Reason, or Adam Smith’s Wealth of Nations without reading his Theory of the Moral Sentiments, or The Communist Manifesto without Marx’s Capital, are more likely than not to be agreeing or disagreeing with something they do not fully understand.

避免争议的重要性

The Importance of Avoiding Contentiousness

 

批判性阅读的第二条一般准则与第一条一样明显，但出于同样的原因，它仍然需要明确的说明。这是规则10，可以这样表达：当您不同意时，请合理地这样做，而不是有争议或有争议的。赢得比赛没有意义如果您知道或怀疑自己错了，请争论。实际上，当然，它可能会让你在短时间内领先于世界。但从稍长期来看，诚实是更好的政策。

The second general maxim of critical reading is as obvious as the first, but it needs explicit statement, nevertheless, and for the same reason. It is RULE 10, and it can be expressed thus: WHEN YOU DISAGREE, DO SO REASONABLY, AND NOT DISPUTATIOUSLY OR CONTENTIOUSLY. There is no point in winning an argument if you know or suspect you are wrong. Practically, of course, it may get you ahead in the world for a short time. But honesty is the better policy in the slightly longer run.

我们首先从柏拉图和亚里士多德那里学到了这条格言。在《会饮》的一段话中，发生了这种交换：

We learned this maxim first from Plato and Aristotle. In a passage in the Symposium, this interchange occurs:

我无法反驳你，苏格拉底，阿伽通说：让我们假设你说的是真的。

I cannot refute you, Socrates, said Agathon: Let us assume that what you say is true.

相反，阿伽通，你不能反驳事实；因为苏格拉底很容易被驳倒。

Say rather, Agathon, that you cannot refute the truth; for Socrates is easily refuted.

这段话与亚里士多德在《伦理学》中的评论相呼应。“这会被认为更好，”他说，

The passage is echoed in a remark of Aristotle’s in the Ethics.“It would be thought to be better,” he says,

确实是我们的责任，为了维护真理甚至摧毁与我们密切相关的东西，尤其是当我们是哲学家或智慧爱好者时；因为，虽然两者都很可爱，但虔诚要求我们尊重真理胜过我们的朋友。

indeed to be our duty, for the sake of maintaining the truth even to destroy what touches us closely, especially as we are philosophers or lovers of wisdom; for, while both are dear, piety requires us to honor truth above our friends.

柏拉图和亚里士多德在这里给了我们大多数人都忽略的建议。大多数人认为赢得争论才是最重要的，而不是了解真相。

Plato and Aristotle here give us advice that most people ignore. Most people think that winning the argument is what matters, not learning the truth.

把谈话当作一场战斗的人，只有当对手，只有成功地反对，他才能获胜，无论他是对还是错。以这种精神接近一本书的读者阅读它只是为了找到他可以不同意的东西。对于好争辩的人，总能找到一根骨头来挑起争吵。骨头是否真的是你自己肩膀上的碎片都没有关系。

He who regards conversation as a battle can win only by being an antagonist, only by disagreeing successfully, whether he is right or wrong. The reader who approaches a book in this spirit reads it only to find something he can disagree with. For the disputatious and the contentious, a bone can always be found to pick a quarrel over. It makes no difference whether the bone is really a chip on your own shoulder.

读者在自己的书房私下与一本书进行对话时，没有什么能阻止读者似乎赢得了争论。他可以主宰局面。作者不是在那里为自己辩护。如果他想要的只是似乎让作者露面的空洞满足感，那么读者可以很容易地得到它。他几乎不需要通读这本书就可以理解。浏览前几页就足够了。

In a conversation that a reader has with a book in the privacy of his own study, there is nothing to prevent the reader from seeming to win the argument. He can dominate the situation. The author is not there to defend himself. If all he wants is the empty satisfaction of seeming to show the author up, the reader can get it readily. He scarcely has to read the book through to get it. Glancing at the first few pages will suffice.

但如果他意识到谈话的唯一好处，活着的或死去的老师，是一个人可以从他们身上学到的东西，如果他意识到你只有通过获得知识才能获胜，而不是通过击倒另一个人，他可能会看到单纯的争论是徒劳的。我们并不是说读者不应该最终不同意并试图表明作者错在哪里。我们只是说他应该准备好同意和不同意。无论他做什么，都应该仅出于一个考虑因素——事实，案件的真相。

But if he realizes that the only profit in conversation, with living or dead teachers, is what one can learn from them, if he realizes that you win only by gaining knowledge, not by knocking the other fellow down, he may see the futility of mere contentiousness. We are not saying that a reader should not ultimately disagree and try to show where the author is wrong. We are saying only that he should be as prepared to agree as to disagree. Whichever he does should be motivated by one consideration alone—the facts, the truth about the case.

这里需要的不仅仅是诚实。不言而喻，读者看到一个观点就应该承认。但他也不应该因为不得不同意作者而不是反对而感到被鞭打。如果他有这种感觉，那么他就是好辩的。根据这第二条格言，他的问题被认为是情感上的而不是智力上的。

More than honesty is required here. It goes without saying that a reader should admit a point when he sees it. But he also should not feel whipped by having to agree with an author, instead of dissenting. If he feels that way, he is inveterately disputatious. In the light of this second maxim, his problem is seen to be emotional rather than intellectual.

关于分歧的解决

On the Resolution of Disagreements

 

第三条格言与第二条格言密切相关。它陈述了进行批评之前的另一个条件。它建议您将分歧视为可以解决的。第二条格言敦促你不要有争议地反对，这一条警告你不要无可救药地反对。如果一个人不承认所有有理性的人都会同意，那么他对讨论的成果毫无希望。请注意，我们说的是“可以同意”。我们并没有说所有理性的人都同意。即使他们不同意，他们也可以。我们试图表明的观点是，除非怀着可能导致问题解决的希望进行分歧，否则争论是徒劳的。

The third maxim is closely related to the second. It states another condition prior to the undertaking of criticism. It recommends that you regard disagreements as capable of being resolved. Where the second maxim urged you not to disagree disputatiously, this one warns you against disagreeing hopelessly. One is hopeless about the fruitfulness of discussion if he does not recognize that all rational men can agree. Note that we said “can agree.” We did not say all rational men do agree. Even when they do not agree, they can. The point we are trying to make is that disagreement is futile agitation unless it is undertaken with the hope that it may lead to the resolution of an issue.

这两个人们可以不同意也可以同意的事实，源于人性的复杂性。男人是理性的动物。他们的理性是他们同意的力量源泉。他们的动物性，以及由此带来的理性缺陷，是大多数分歧的起因。男人是充满激情和偏见的生物。语言他们必须用来交流的是一种不完美的媒介，被情感所笼罩，被兴趣所着色，而且思想不够透明。然而，只要人是理性的，这些阻碍他们理解的障碍是可以克服的。那种只是表面上的分歧，那种由误解引起的分歧，当然是可以治愈的。

These two facts, that people do disagree and can agree, arise from the complexity of human nature. Men are rational animals. Their rationality is the source of their power to agree. Their animality, and the imperfections of their reason that it entails, is the cause of most of the disagreements that occur. Men are creatures of passion and prejudice. The language they must use to communicate is an imperfect medium, clouded by emotion and colored by interest, as well as inadequately transparent for thought. Yet to the extent that men are rational, these obstacles to their understanding can be overcome. The sort of disagreement that is only apparent, the sort that results from misunderstanding, is certainly curable.

当然，还有另一种分歧，这仅仅是由于知识的不平等。相对无知的人常常错误地不同意相对博学的人关于超出他们知识范围的事情。然而，更有学问的人有权批评那些缺乏相关知识的人所犯的错误。这种分歧也可以得到纠正。知识的不平等总是可以通过指导来解决的。

There is, of course, another sort of disagreement, which is owing merely to inequalities of knowledge. The relatively ignorant often wrongly disagree with the relatively learned about matters exceeding their knowledge. The more learned, however, have a right to be critical of errors made by those who lack relevant knowledge. Disagreement of this sort can also be corrected. Inequality of knowledge is always curable by instruction.

可能还有其他更深层次的分歧，并且可能存在于理性本身。很难确定这些，而且几乎不可能用理性来描述它们。无论如何，我们刚才所说的适用于绝大多数分歧。它们可以通过消除误解或无知来解决。两种治疗方法通常都是可能的，但通常很困难。因此，在谈话的任何阶段不同意的人，至少应该希望最终达成一致。他应该准备好改变自己的想法，就像准备改变别人的想法一样。他应该始终将自己误解或在某些点上无知的可能性摆在面前。

There may still be other disagreements that are more deeply buried, and that may subsist in the body of reason itself. It is hard to be sure about these, and almost impossible for reason to describe them. In any event, what we have just said applies to the great majority of disagreements. They can be resolved by the removal of misunderstanding or of ignorance. Both cures are usually possible, though often difficult. Hence the person who, at any stage of a conversation, disagrees, should at least hope to reach agreement in the end. He should be as much prepared to have his own mind changed as seek to change the mind of another. He should always keep before him the possibility that he misunderstands or that he is ignorant on some point. No one who looks upon disagreement as an occasion for teaching another should forget that it is also an occasion for being taught.

问题在于，许多人认为分歧与教导或被教导无关。他们认为一切都只是见仁见智。我有我的，你也有你的；我们发表意见的权利与我们对私有财产的权利一样不可侵犯。按照这样的观点，如果要获得的利润是知识的增加，那么交流就不可能是有利可图的。谈话并不比乒乓球好反对意见的游戏，一场没有人记分的游戏，没有人赢，每个人都满意，因为他没有输——也就是说，他最终持有与开始时相同的观点。

The trouble is that many people regard disagreement as unrelated to either teaching or being taught. They think that everything is just a matter of opinion. I have mine, and you have yours; and our right to our opinions is as inviolable as our right to private property. On such a view, communication cannot be profitable if the profit to be gained is an increase in knowledge. Conversation is hardly better than a ping-pong game of opposed opinions, a game in which no one keeps score, no one wins, and everyone is satisfied because he does not lose—that is, he ends up holding the same opinions he started with.

如果我们持有这种观点，我们就不会——也不能——写这本书。相反，我们认为知识可以交流，讨论可以导致学习。如果真正的知识，而不仅仅是个人意见，受到威胁，那么，在大多数情况下，任何一种分歧都只是表面上的——可以通过达成协议和达成共识来消除；或者它们是真实的，而真正的问题可以通过诉诸事实和理性来解决——当然，从长远来看。关于分歧的理性格言是从长远来看要有耐心。简而言之，我们是说，分歧是有争议的事情。除非基于这样一种假设，即当根据所有相关证据通过理性获得理解时，该理解可以解决原始问题，否则论证是空洞的。

We would not—and could not—write this book if we held this view. Instead, we hold that knowledge can be communicated and that discussion can result in learning. If genuine knowledge, not mere personal opinion, is at stake, then, for the most part, either disagreements are apparent only—to be removed by coming to terms and a meeting of minds; or they are real, and the genuine issues can be resolved—in the long run, of course—by appeals to fact and reason. The maxim of rationality concerning disagreements is to be patient for the long run. We are saying, in short, that disagreements are arguable matters. And argument is empty unless it is undertaken on the supposition that there is attainable an understanding that, when attained by reason in the light of all the relevant evidence, resolves the original issues.

这第三个格言如何应用于读者和作者之间的对话？怎么能说成读书的规律呢？它处理读者发现自己不同意书中某些内容的情况。这要求他首先确定分歧不是由于误解造成的。假设读者仔细遵守了在理解之前不得做出批判性判断的规则，因此确信这里没有误解。然后怎样呢？

How does this third maxim apply to the conversation between reader and writer? How can it be stated as a rule of reading? It deals with the situation in which the reader finds himself disagreeing with something in the book. It requires him first to be sure that the disagreement is not owing to misunderstanding. Suppose that the reader has been careful to observe the rule that he must not render a critical judgment until he understands, and is therefore satisfied that there is no misunderstanding here. What then?

这个准则要求他区分真正的知识和纯粹的意见，并将知识所涉及的问题视为可以解决的问题。如果他进一步追究这件事，作者可能会在一些会改变他想法的地方给予他指导。如果那没有发生，他的批评可能是有道理的，并且至少可以比喻地指导作者。他至少可以希望，如果作者还活着并且在场，他的想法可以改变。

This maxim then requires him to distinguish between genuine knowledge and mere opinion, and to regard an issue where knowledge is concerned as one that can be resolved. If he pursues the matter further, he may be instructed by the author on points that will change his mind. If that does not happen, he may be justified in his criticism, and, metaphorically at least, be able to instruct the author. He can at least hope that were the author alive and present, his mind could be changed.

你可能还记得上一章关于这个主题所说的话。作者如果不说明理由，只能视为作者个人观点的表达。不区分理性的知识陈述和平淡的观点表达的读者不是为了学习而阅读。他至多对作者的个性感兴趣，并且将这本书用作案例历史。这样的读者当然不会同意也不会反对。他不评判书，而是评判人。

You may remember something that was said on this subject in the last chapter. If an author does not give reasons for his propositions, they can be treated only as expressions of personal opinions on his part. The reader who does not distinguish between the reasoned statement of knowledge and the flat expression of opinion is not reading to learn. He is at most interested in the author’s personality and is using the book as a case history. Such a reader will, of course, neither agree nor disagree. He does not judge the book but the man.

然而，如果读者主要对这本书感兴趣，而不是对这个人感兴趣，那么他应该认真对待他的批评义务。这些包括将真正的知识和纯粹的意见之间的区别应用到他自己和作者身上。因此，读者必须做的不仅仅是做出同意或不同意的判断。他必须给出理由。当然，在前一种情况下，如果他积极分享作者对他们同意的观点的理由就足够了。但当他不同意时，他必须给出自己的理由。否则，他就是把知识问题当作意见来对待。

If, however, the reader is primarily interested in the book and not the man, he should take his critical obligations seriously. These involve applying the distinction between real knowledge and mere opinion to himself as well as to the author. Thus the reader must do more than make judgments of agreement or disagreement. He must give reasons for them. In the former case, of course, it suffices if he actively shares the author’s reasons for the point on which they agree. But when he disagrees, he must give his own grounds for doing so. Otherwise, he is treating a matter of knowledge as if it were opinion.

因此，规则11 可以表述如下：通过给出您做出的任何批判性判断的理由，尊重知识与纯个人意见之间的差异。

RULE 11, therefore, can be stated as follows: RESPECT THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN KNOWLEDGE AND MERE PERSONAL OPINION, BY GIVING REASONS FOR ANY CRITICAL JUDGMENT YOU MAKE.

顺便说一下，我们不希望被理解为声称人类可以获得大量“绝对”知识。不证自明的命题，就我们在前一章中定义的意义而言，在我们看来似乎是既无法证明又不可否认的真理。然而，大多数知识都缺乏那种程度的绝对性。我们所知道的，我们所知道的需要更正；我们知道它是因为所有证据，或者至少是大量证据都支持它，但我们不能也不能确定新证据有时不会使我们现在相信的事实无效。

Incidentally, we would not want to be understood as claiming that there is a great deal of “absolute” knowledge available to men. Self-evident propositions, in the sense in which we defined them in the previous chapter, seem to us to be both indemonstrable and undeniable truths. Most knowledge, however, lacks that degree of absoluteness. What we know, we know subject to correction; we know it because all, or at least the weight, of the evidence supports it, but we are not and cannot be certain that new evidence will not sometime invalidate what we now believe is true.

然而，这并没有消除我们一直强调的知识和意见之间的重要区别。知识，如果你愿意的话，包括那些可以辩护的意见，有一种证据的意见或其他。如果我们真的知道某事，从这个意义上说，我们必须相信我们可以说服别人相信我们所知道的。意见，在我们一直使用这个词的意义上，是没有根据的判断。这就是为什么我们将修饰词“仅仅”或“个人的”与它结合使用。当我们除了个人感觉或偏见之外没有任何证据或理由支持该陈述时，我们只能认为某件事是真实的。当我们有其他理性的人可能会接受的客观证据时，我们可以说它是真实的并且我们知道它。

This, however, does not remove the important distinction between knowledge and opinion that we have been stressing. Knowledge, if you please, consists in those opinions that can he defended, opinions for which there is evidence of one kind or another. If we really know something, in this sense, we must believe that we can convince others of what we know. Opinion, in the sense in which we have been employing the word, is unsupported judgment. That is why we have employed the modifiers “mere” or “personal” in conjunction with it. We can do no more than opine that something is true when we have no evidence or reason for the statement other than our personal feeling or prejudice. We can say that it is true and that we know it when we have objective evidence that other reasonable men are likely to accept.

现在让我们总结一下我们在本章中讨论的三个一般准则。这三者一起说明了批判性阅读的条件以及读者应该继续与作者“顶嘴”的方式。

Let us now summarize the three general maxims we have discussed in this chapter. The three together state the conditions of a critical reading and the manner in which the reader should proceed to “talk back” to the author.

第一个要求读者在冲进去之前完成理解任务。第二个要求他不要争论或争论。第三个要求他将关于知识问题的分歧视为通常可以补救的。这条规则更进一步：它还要求他为他的分歧给出理由，这样问题不仅要陈述，还要定义。这就是解决问题的全部希望。

The first requires the reader to complete the task of understanding before rushing in. The second adjures him not to be disputatious or contentious. The third asks him to view disagreement about matters of knowledge as being generally remediable. This rule goes further: It also commands him to give reasons for his disagreements so that issues are not merely stated but also defined. In that lies all hope for resolution.

11

同意或不同意作者的观点

11AGREEING OR DISAGREEING WITH AN AUTHOR

 

读者可以说的第一件事是他理解或不理解。事实上，他必须说他明白，才能说得更多。如果他不明白，他应该保持安静并回去写书。

The first thing a reader can say is that he understands or that he does not. In fact, he must say he understands, in order to say more. If he does not understand, he should keep his peace and go back to work on the book.

第二种选择的严厉性有一个例外。“我不明白”本身可能就是一个批评性的评论。为此，读者必须能够支持它。如果错在书而不是自己，读者必须找出问题的根源。他应该能够证明这本书的结构是混乱的，它的各个部分没有连在一起，其中一些缺乏相关性，或者，也许，作者在使用重要词语时模棱两可，整个系列随之而来的困惑。只要读者能够支持他关于这本书难以理解的指控，他就没有进一步的批评义务。

There is one exception to the harshness of the second alternative. “I don’t understand” may itself be a critical remark. To make it so, the reader must be able to support it. If the fault is with the book rather than himself, the reader must locate the sources of trouble. He should be able to show that the structure of the book is disorderly, that its parts do not hang together, that some of it lacks relevance, or, perhaps, that the author equivocates in the use of important words, with a whole train of consequent confusions. To the extent that a reader can support his charge that the book is unintelligible, he has no further critical obligations.

然而，让我们假设您正在读一本好书。这意味着它是一个相对可理解的。让我们假设你终于可以说“我明白了”。如果除了理解本书之外，您还完全同意作者所说的话，那么工作就结束了。分析阅读完全完成。你被开悟了，被说服了。很明显，只有在存在分歧或暂停判断的情况下，我们才需要考虑额外的步骤。前者是更常见的情况。

Let us suppose, however, that you are reading a good book. That means it is a relatively intelligible one. And let us suppose that you are finally able to say “I understand.” If, in addition to understanding the book, you agree thoroughly with what the author says, the work is over. The analytical reading is completely done. You have been enlightened, and convinced or persuaded. It is clear that we have additional steps to consider only in the case of disagreement or suspended judgment. The former is the more usual case.

就作者与读者争论的程度而言——并期望他们的读者反驳——好的读者必须熟悉争论的原则。他必须能够进行文明的、聪明的辩论。这就是为什么在一本关于阅读的书中需要这样一章的原因。读者不仅要遵循作者的论点，而且还要满足他们的论点，才能最终与他的作者达成重要的同意或不同意。

To the extent that authors argue with their readers—and expect their readers to argue back—the good reader must be acquainted with the principles of argument. He must be able to carry on civil, as well as intelligent, controversy. That is why there is need for a chapter of this sort in a book on reading. Not simply by following an author’s arguments, but only by meeting them as well, can the reader ultimately reach significant agreement or disagreement with his author.

同意和不同意的含义值得进一步考虑一下。与作者达成协议并掌握他的命题和推理的读者分享作者的思想。事实上，整个解释过程都是通过语言媒介来达到思想交流的目的。读懂一本书，可以说是作者和读者之间的一种约定。他们同意使用语言来表达想法。由于这种一致，读者能够透过作者的语言看到他试图表达的思想。

The meaning of agreement and disagreement deserves a moment’s further consideration. The reader who comes to terms with an author and grasps his propositions and reasoning shares the author’s mind. In fact, the whole process of interpretation is directed toward a meeting of minds through the medium of language. Understanding a book can be described as a kind of agreement between writer and reader. They agree about the use of language to express ideas. Because of that agreement, the reader is able to see through the author’s language to the ideas he is trying to express.

读者看懂一本书，怎么会不同意呢？批判性阅读要求他自己下定决心。但由于他成功地理解了这本书，他的思想和作者的思想已经合而为一。他还有什么心思可以独立下定决心？

If the reader understands a book, how can he disagree with it? Critical reading demands that he make up his own mind. But his mind and the author’s have become as one through his success in understanding the book. What mind has he left to make up independently?

有些人犯了导致这种明显困难的错误：他们无法区分“同意”的两种含义。结果，他们错误地认为只要人与人之间存在理解，就不可能出现分歧。他们说，所有的分歧都只是由于误解。

There are some people who make the error that causes this apparent difficulty: they fail to distinguish between two senses of “agreement.” In consequence, they wrongly suppose that where there is understanding between men, disagreement is impossible. They say that all disagreement is simply owing to misunderstanding.

一旦我们想起作者是在对我们生活的世界做出判断，这个错误就变得很明显了。他声称要给我们关于事物存在和行为方式的理论知识，或者关于应该做什么的实践知识。显然，他可以是对的，也可以是错的。他的主张只有在他说的是真实的范围内，在他所说的根据证据可能的范围内才是合理的。否则，他的说法是没有根据的。

The error in this becomes obvious as soon as we remember that the author is making judgments about the world in which we live. He claims to be giving us theoretical knowledge about the way things exist and behave, or practical knowledge about what should be done. Obviously, he can be either right or wrong. His claim is justified only to the extent that he speaks truly, to the extent that he says what is probable in the light of evidence. Otherwise, his claim is unfounded.

例如，如果你说“人人平等”，我们可能会认为你的意思是所有的人在出生时就具有同等的智力、力量和其他能力。鉴于我们所了解的事实，我们不同意你的看法。我们认为你错了。但是假设我们误解了你。假设你说这些话的意思是所有人都应该享有平等的政治权利。因为我们误解了你的意思，所以我们的分歧无关紧要。现在假设错误得到纠正。仍然存在两种选择。我们可以同意或不同意，但现在如果我们不同意，我们之间就会出现真正的问题。我们理解你的政治立场，但持有相反的立场。

If you say, for instance, that “all men are equal,” we may take you to mean that all men are equally endowed at birth with intelligence, strength, and other abilities. In the light of the facts as we know them, we disagree with you. We think you are wrong. But suppose we have misunderstood you. Suppose you meant by these words that all men should have equal political rights. Because we misapprehended your meaning, our disagreement was irrelevant. Now suppose the mistake corrected. Two alternatives still remain. We can agree or disagree, but now if we disagree, there is a real issue between us. We understand your political position, but hold a contrary one.

关于事实或政策的问题——关于事情的现状或应该如何的问题——只有当它们基于对所说内容的共同理解时，才在这个意义上是真实的。就所讨论的事实达成真正一致或不一致的必要条件是就用词达成一致。这是因为，而不是尽管如此，你通过对他的书的合理解释与作者的思想相遇，你才能下定决心同意或反对他所采取的立场。

Issues about matters of fact or policy—issues about the way things are or should be—are real in this sense only when they are based on a common understanding of what is being said. Agreement about the use of words is the indispensable condition for genuine agreement or disagreement about the facts being discussed. It is because of, not in spite of, your meeting the author’s mind through a sound interpretation of his book that you are able to make up your own mind as concurring in or dissenting from the position he has taken.

偏见与判断

Prejudice and Judgment

 

现在让我们考虑一下这样一种情况，在这种情况下，你说你理解了，但你却不同意。如果你曾试图遵守前一章所述的格言，你会不同意，因为你认为作者在某些点上可能被证明是错误的。你不仅仅是在表达你的偏见或表达你的情绪。正因为如此，那么，从理想的角度来看，要进行好争论，就必须具备三个条件。

Now let us consider the situation in which, having said you understand, you proceed to disagree. If you have tried to abide by the maxims stated in the previous chapter, you disagree because you think the author can be shown to be wrong on some point. You are not simply voicing your prejudice or expressing your emotions. Because this is true, then, from an ideal point of view, there are three conditions that must be satisfied if controversy is to be well conducted.

第一个是这个。由于人既是动物又是理性的，因此有必要承认您在争端中带来的情绪，或在争端过程中产生的情绪。否则你很可能是在发泄情绪，而不是在陈述理由。你当你只有强烈的感情时，甚至可能认为你有理由。

The first is this. Since men are animals as well as rational, it is necessary to acknowledge the emotions you bring to a dispute, or those that arise in the course of it. Otherwise you are likely to be giving vent to feelings, not stating reasons. You may even think you have reasons, when all you have are strong feelings.

其次，你必须明确自己的假设。你必须知道你的偏见——也就是你的偏见——是什么。否则你不太可能承认你的对手可能同样有权做出不同的假设。好的争论不应该是关于假设的争吵。例如，如果一位作者明确要求您将某些事情视为理所当然，那么相反的事情也可以视为理所当然这一事实不应阻止您尊重他的要求。如果您的偏见恰恰相反，并且您不承认它们是偏见，那么您就无法公平审理提交人的案子。

Second, you must make your own assumptions explicit. You must know what your prejudices—that is, your prejudgments—are. Otherwise you are not likely to admit that your opponent may be equally entitled to different assumptions. Good controversy should not be a quarrel about assumptions. If an author, for example, explicitly asks you to take something for granted, the fact that the opposite can also be taken for granted should not prevent you from honoring his request. If your prejudices lie on the opposite side, and if you do not acknowledge them to be prejudices, you cannot give the author’s case a fair hearing.

第三，也是最后一点，公正的尝试是消除党派偏见中几乎不可避免的盲目性的良药。没有党派之争的争论当然是不可能的。但是为了确保其中有更多的光，更少的热，每个争论者至少应该尝试采取另一个人的观点。如果你不能以同情的心阅读一本书，那么你对它的不同意见可能更多的是争论而不是民事。

Third and finally, an attempt at impartiality is a good antidote for the blindness that is almost inevitable in partisanship. Controversy without partisanship is, of course, impossible. But to be sure that there is more light in it, and less heat, each of the disputants should at least try to take the other fellow’s point of view. If you have not been able to read a book sympathetically, your disagreement with it is probably more contentious than civil.

理想情况下，这三个条件是进行明智且有益的对话的必要条件。它们显然适用于阅读，因为阅读是读者与作者之间的一种对话。对于愿意尊重不同意见的读者，他们每个人都包含合理的建议。

These three conditions are, ideally, the sine qua non of intelligent and profitable conversation. They are obviously applicable to reading, insofar as that is a kind of conversation between reader and author. Each of them contains sound advice for readers who are willing to respect the civilities of disagreement.

但与其他地方一样，这里的理想只能是近似的。永远不应该期望人类有理想。我们自己，我们不得不承认，充分意识到我们自己的缺陷。我们在争论中违反了自己关于良好知识分子举止的规则。我们发现自己攻击一本书而不是批评它，把稻草人打倒，谴责我们无法支持否认的地方，宣称我们的偏见好像我们的偏见比作者的更好。

But the ideal here, as elsewhere, can only be approximated. The ideal should never be expected from human beings. We ourselves, we hasten to admit, are sufficiently conscious of our own defects. We have violated our own rules about good intellectual manners in controversy. We have caught ourselves attacking a book rather than criticizing it, knocking straw men over, denouncing where we could not support denials, proclaiming our prejudices as if ours were any better than the author’s.

然而，我们仍然相信，对话和批判性阅读可以得到很好的训练。因此，我们将用一组更容易遵循的处方来替代这三个理想条件。它们指出了可以对一本书进行负面批评的四种方式。我们希望，如果读者将自己局限于提出这些观点，他就不太可能沉迷于表达情感或偏见。

We continue to believe, however, that conversation and critical reading can be well disciplined. We are therefore going to substitute for those three ideal conditions, a set of prescriptions that may be easier to follow. They indicate the four ways in which a book can be adversely criticized. Our hope is that if a reader confines himself to making these points, he will be less likely to indulge in expressions of emotion or prejudice.

将读者想象成与作者的对话，作为回话，可以简要概括这四点。在他说完“我理解但我不同意”之后，他可以对作者做出如下评论：（1）“你不知情”；(2) “你被误导了”；(3) “你不合逻辑——你的推理没有说服力”；(4) “你的分析不完整。”

The four points can be briefly summarized by conceiving the reader as conversing with the author, as talking back. After he has said, “I understand but I disagree,” he can make the following remarks to the author: (1) “You are uninformed”; (2) “You are misinformed”; (3) “You are illogical—your reasoning is not cogent”; (4) “Your analysis is incomplete.”

这些可能并不详尽，但我们认为它们是详尽无遗的。无论如何，它们肯定是不同意的读者可以提出的主要观点。他们有些独立。做出这些评论中的任何一个都不会阻止您做出另一个评论。每一个都可以制造，因为它们所指的缺陷并不相互排斥。

These may not be exhaustive, though we think they are. In any event, they are certainly the principal points a reader who disagrees can make. They are somewhat independent. Making one of these remarks does not prevent you from making another. Each and all can be made, because the defects they refer to are not mutually exclusive.

但是，我们应该补充说，如果不明确和准确地指出作者在哪些方面是无知、被误导或不合逻辑，读者就不能发表任何这些评论。一本书不可能对所有事情都一无所知或被误导。这不可能完全不合逻辑。此外，发表任何这些评论的读者不仅必须明确表达尊重，而且还必须支持他的观点。他必须说明他所做的事的理由。

But, we should add, the reader cannot make any of these remarks without being definite and precise about the respect in which the author is uninformed or misinformed or illogical. A book cannot be uninformed or misinformed about everything. It cannot be totally illogical. Furthermore, the reader who makes any of these remarks must not only make it definitely, by specifying the respect, but he must also support his point. He must give reasons for saying what he does.

判断作者的合理性

Judging the Author’s Soundness

 

前三点与第四点有些不同，我们马上就会看到。让我们简要地考虑一下它们中的每一个，然后转向第四个。

The first three remarks are somewhat different from the fourth, as we will presently see. Let us consider each of them briefly, and then turn to the fourth.

 

1. 说作者无知就是说他缺乏与他试图解决的问题相关的一些知识。请注意，除非作者拥有的知识是相关的，否则发表此评论是没有意义的。为了支持这个评论，你必须能够自己陈述作者缺乏的知识，并展示它是如何相关的，它如何影响他的结论。

1. To say that an author is uninformed is to say that he lacks some piece of knowledge that is relevant to the problem he is trying to solve. Notice here that unless the knowledge, if possessed by the author, would have been relevant, there is no point in making this remark. To support the remark, you must be able yourself to state the knowledge that the author lacks and show how it is relevant, how it makes a difference to his conclusions.

这里的一些插图就足够了。达尔文缺乏孟德尔和后来的实验学家的工作所提供的遗传学知识。他对遗传机制的无知是《物种起源》的主要缺陷之一。吉本缺乏后来的历史研究表明对罗马没落有影响的某些事实。通常，在科学和历史中，缺乏信息是在后来的研究中发现的。改进的观察技术和长期的调查使事情在大多数情况下都是这样发生的。但在哲学中，情况可能并非如此。随着时间的流逝，损失与收益一样多。例如，古人就清楚地区分了人们能够感知和想象的事物以及他们能够理解的事物。然而，在 18 世纪，大卫·休谟 (David Hume) 揭示了他对意象和观念之间的这种区别的无知，尽管早期哲学家的著作已经很好地确立了这种区别。

A few illustrations here must suffice. Darwin lacked the knowledge of genetics that the work of Mendel and later experimentalists now provides. His ignorance of the mechanism of inheritance is one of the major defects in The Origin of Species. Gibbon lacked certain facts that later historical research has shown to have a bearing on the fall of Rome. Usually, in science and history, the lack of information is discovered by later researches. Improved techniques of observation and prolonged investigation make this the way things happen for the most part. But in philosophy, it may happen otherwise. There is just as likely to be loss as gain with the passage of time. The ancients, for example, clearly distinguished between what men can sense and imagine and what they can understand. Yet, in the eighteenth century, David Hume revealed his ignorance of this distinction between images and ideas, even though it had been so well established by the work of earlier philosophers.

 

2. 说作者被误导就是说他断言事实并非如此。他在这里的错误可能是由于缺乏知识，但错误不止于此。无论其原因是什么，它都在于做出与事实相反的断言。作者提出的是真实的或更有可能实际上是错误的或不太可能的东西。他声称拥有他不具备的知识。这种缺陷当然应该指出，但前提是它与作者的结论相关。并且为了支持该评论，您必须能够论证与作者相反的立场的真实性或更大可能性。

2. To say that an author is misinformed is to say that he asserts what is not the case. His error here may be owing to lack of knowledge, but the error is more than that. Whatever its cause, it consists in making assertions contrary to fact. The author is proposing as true or more probable what is in fact false or less probable. He is claiming to have knowledge he does not possess. This kind of defect should be pointed out, of course, only if it is relevant to the author’s conclusions. And to support the remark you must be able to argue the truth or greater probability of a position contrary to the author’s.

例如，在他的一篇政治论文中，斯宾诺莎似乎说民主是一种比君主制更原始的政府类型。这与政治史上公认的事实相悖。斯宾诺莎在这方面的错误对他的论点有影响。亚里士多德被误导了雌性因素在动物繁殖中所起的作用，因此得出了关于繁殖过程的无法支持的结论。阿奎那错误地认为天体的物质与地体的物质在本质上是不同的，因为他认为前者仅在位置上发生变化，而在其他方面是不可改变的。现代天体物理学纠正了这个错误，从而改进了古代和中世纪的天文学。但这是一个相关性有限的错误。

For example, in one of his political treatises, Spinoza appears to say that democracy is a more primitive type of government than monarchy. This is contrary to well-ascertained facts of political history. Spinoza’s error in this respect has a bearing on his argument. Aristotle was misinformed about the role that the female factor plays in animal reproduction, and consequently came to unsupportable conclusions about the processes of procreation. Aquinas erroneously supposed that the matter of the heavenly bodies is essentially different from that of terrestrial bodies, because he supposed that the former change only in position, and are otherwise unalterable. Modern astrophysics corrects this error and thereby improves on ancient and medieval astronomy. But here is an error that has limited relevance. Making it does not affect Aquinas’ metaphysical account of the nature of all sensible things as composed of matter and form.

前两点批评可能是相关的。正如我们所见，缺乏信息可能是错误断言的原因。此外，每当一个人在某一方面被误导时，他在同一方面也是无知的。但是，缺陷是简单的消极还是积极的也会有所不同。缺乏相关知识导致无法解决某些问题或支持某些结论。然而，错误的假设会导致错误的结论和站不住脚的解决方案。综上所述，这两点指控作者的前提存在缺陷。他需要比他拥有的更多的知识。他的证据和理由在数量和质量上都不够好。

These first two points of criticism may be related. Lack of information, as we have seen, may be the cause of erroneous assertions. Further, whenever a man is misinformed in a certain respect, he is also uninformed in the same respect. But it makes a difference whether the defect is simply negative or positive as well. Lack of relevant knowledge makes it impossible to solve certain problems or support certain conclusions. Erroneous suppositions, however, lead to wrong conclusions and untenable solutions. Taken together, these two points charge an author with defects in his premises. He needs more knowledge than he possesses. His evidences and reasons are not good enough in quantity or quality.

 

3.说一个作者不合逻辑就是说他在推理上犯了谬误。一般来说，谬误有两种。有一个不合逻辑的结论，这意味着得出的结论根本不是从所提供的理由中得出的。并且出现了不一致的情况，就是作者试图说的两件事是不相容的。要做出这些批评，读者必须是能够准确地表明作者的论点缺乏说服力。人们仅在主要结论受其影响的情况下才关注这一缺陷。一本书可能在无关紧要的方面缺乏说服力。

3. To say that an author is illogical is to say that he has committed a fallacy in reasoning. In general, fallacies are of two sorts. There is the non sequitur, which means that what is drawn as a conclusion simply does not follow from the reasons offered. And there is the occurrence of inconsistency, which means that two things the author has tried to say are incompatible. To make either of these criticisms, the reader must be able to show the precise respect in which the author’s argument lacks cogency. One is concerned with this defect only to the extent that the major conclusions are affected by it. A book may safely lack cogency in irrelevant respects.

第三点更难说明，因为很少有真正好的书会在推理上出现明显的失误。当它们确实出现时，它们通常被精心隐藏，需要非常敏锐的读者才能发现它们。但我们可以向您展示马基雅维利的《君主论》中的明显谬误。马基雅维利写道：

It is more difficult to illustrate this third point, because few really good books make obvious slips in reasoning. When they do occur, they are usually elaborately concealed, and it requires a very penetrating reader to discover them. But we can show you a patent fallacy in Machiavelli’s The Prince. Machiavelli writes:

所有国家的主要基础，无论新旧，都是良好的法律。由于国家没有装备精良的地方不可能有好的法律，因此，在他们装备精良的地方就有好的法律。

The chief foundations of all states, new as well as old, are good laws. As there cannot be good laws where the state is not well armed, it follows that where they are well armed they have good laws.

现在，这根本不能从好的法律取决于足够的警察力量这一事实得出结论，即在警察力量充足的地方，法律就一定是好的。我们忽略了第一个争论的高度可疑特征。我们只对这里的不合逻辑感兴趣。说幸福取决于健康比好的法律取决于有效的警察部队更真实，但这并不意味着所有健康的人都会幸福。

Now it simply does not follow from the fact that good laws depend on an adequate police force, that where the police force is adequate, the laws will necessarily be good. We are ignoring the highly questionable character of the first contention. We are only interested in the non sequitur here. It is truer to say that happiness depends on health than that good laws depend on an effective police force, but it does not follow that all who are healthy are happy.

在他的Elements of Law 中，霍布斯在一处论证说，所有的物体只不过是运动中的物质的数量。他说，身体的世界没有任何品质。然后，在另一个地方，他争辩说人本身不过是一个身体，或者是运动中的原子体的集合。然而，承认感官品质（颜色、气味、味道等）的存在，他得出结论，它们只不过是大脑中原子的运动。结论与最初采取的立场不一致，即运动物体的世界是没有性质的。关于所有运动物体的说法必须适用于它们的任何特定群体，包括大脑的原子。

In his Elements of Law, Hobbes argues in one place that all bodies are nothing but quantities of matter in motion. The world of bodies, he says, has no qualities whatsoever. Then, in another place, he argues that man is himself nothing but a body, or a collection of atomic bodies in motion. Yet, admitting the existence of sensory qualities—colors, odors, tastes, and so forth—he concludes that they are nothing but the motions of atoms in the brain. The conclusion is inconsistent with the position first taken, namely, that the world of bodies in motion is without qualities. What is said of all bodies in motion must apply to any particular group of them, including the atoms of the brain.

这第三点批评与其他两点有关。当然，作者可能无法得出他的证据或原则所暗示的结论。因此，他的推理是不完整的。但我们在这里主要关注的是他从良好的理由进行错误推理的情况。有趣但不太重要的是，发现从本身不真实的前提或不充分的证据进行推理时缺乏说服力。

This third point of criticism is related to the other two. An author may, of course, fail to draw the conclusions that his evidences or principles imply. Thus his reasoning is incomplete. But we are here concerned primarily with the case in which he reasons poorly from good grounds. It is interesting, but less important, to discover lack of cogency in reasoning from premises that are themselves untrue, or from evidences that are inadequate.

从某种意义上说，从可靠的前提得出无效结论的人是被误导了。但值得区分的是，由于推理不当而导致的错误陈述与前面讨论的那种由于其他缺陷，尤其是对相关细节的了解不足而导致的错误陈述。

A person who from sound premises reaches a conclusion invalidly is, in a sense, misinformed. But it is worthwhile to distinguish the kind of erroneous statement that is owing to bad reasoning from the kind previously discussed, which is owing to other defects, especially insufficient knowledge of relevant details.

判断作者的完整性

Judging the Author’s Completeness

 

我们刚刚考虑过的前三点批评涉及作者陈述和推理的合理性。现在让我们转向读者可能提出的第四个负面评论。它涉及作者执行他的计划的完整性——他完成他选择的任务的充分性。

The first three points of criticism, which we have just considered, deal with the soundness of the author’s statements and reasoning. Let us turn now to the fourth adverse remark a reader can make. It deals with the completeness of the author’s execution of his plan—the adequacy with which he discharges the task he has chosen.

在我们进行第四个评论之前，应该注意一件事。既然你已经说你明白了，你不支持前三个评论中的任何一个，你就有义务同意作者的观点。你对此没有意志自由。决定同意或不同意并不是你的神圣特权。

Before we proceed to this fourth remark, one thing should be observed. Since you have said you understand, your failure to support any of these first three remarks obligates you to agree with the author as far as he has gone. You have no freedom of will about this. It is not your sacred privilege to decide whether you are going to agree or disagree.

如果你不能证明作者在相关问题上不知情、被误导或不合逻辑，你就不能不同意。你必须同意。你不能像很多学生和其他人那样说，“我发现你的前提没有错，推理也没有错误，但我不同意你的结论。” 所有你可能通过说某事来表达的意思喜欢那是你不喜欢的结论。你没有反对。你在表达你的情绪或偏见。如果你被说服了，你就应该承认。（如果，尽管你无法支持这三个关键点中的一个或多个，但你仍然诚实地感到不服气，也许你一开始就不应该说你理解了。）

If you have not been able to show that the author is uninformed, misinformed, or illogical on relevant matters, you simply cannot disagree. You must agree. You cannot say, as so many students and others do, “I find nothing wrong with your premises, and no errors in reasoning, but I don’t agree with your conclusions.” All you can possibly mean by saying something like that is that you do not like the conclusions. You are not disagreeing. You are expressing your emotions or prejudices. If you have been convinced, you should admit it. (If, despite your failure to support one or more of these three critical points, you still honestly feel unconvinced, perhaps you should not have said you understood in the first place.)

前三个评论与作者的术语、命题和论点有关。这些是他用来解决引发他努力的问题的要素。第四个评论——这本书是不完整的——与整体结构有关。

The first three remarks are related to the author’s terms, propositions, and arguments. These are the elements he used to solve the problems that initiated his efforts. The fourth remark —that the book is incomplete—bears on the structure of the whole.

 

4. 说一个作者的分析不完整就是说他没有解决他开始时遇到的所有问题，或者他没有尽可能好地利用他的材料，他没有看到它们的所有含义和后果，或者他未能做出与他的事业相关的区分。说一本书不完整是不够的。任何人都可以这样说任何一本书。人是有限的，他们的作品也是有限的，每一个最后的作品。因此，除非读者能够通过自己作为知识者的努力或通过其他书籍的帮助，准确地定义不足之处，否则发表这种评论是没有意义的。

4. To say that an author’s analysis is incomplete is to say that he has not solved all the problems he started with, or that he has not made as good a use of his materials as possible, that he did not see all their implications and ramifications, or that he has failed to make distinctions that are relevant to his undertaking. It is not enough to say that a book is incomplete. Anyone can say that of any book. Men are finite, and so are their works, every last one. There is no point in making this remark, therefore, unless the reader can define the inadequacy precisely, either by his own efforts as a knower or through the help of other books.

让我们简要地说明这一点。亚里士多德的政治学对政府类型的分析是不完整的。由于他所处时代的局限和他对奴隶制的错误接受，亚里士多德没有考虑，甚至没有构思建立在普选基础上的真正民主宪法；他也无法想象代议制政府或现代联邦制国家。他的分析必须扩展到适用于这些政治现实。欧几里德的几何原本是一个不完整的帐户，因为欧几里德没有考虑其他关于平行线关系的假设。做出这些其他假设的现代几何著作弥补了不足。杜威的《我们如何思考》是对思维的不完整分析，因为它未能除了在调查和发现中出现的思维之外，还要处理在阅读或通过指导学习时出现的思维。对于相信个人永生的基督徒来说，爱比克泰德或马库斯·奥勒留 (Marcus Aurelius) 的著作是对人类幸福的不完整描述。

Let us illustrate this point briefly. The analysis of types of government in Aristotle’s Politics is incomplete. Because of the limitations of his time and his erroneous acceptance of slavery, Aristotle fails to consider, or for that matter even to conceive, the truly democratic constitution that is based on universal suffrage; nor can he imagine either representative government or the modern kind of federated state. His analysis would have to be extended to apply to these political realities. Euclid’s Elements of Geometry is an incomplete account because Euclid failed to consider other postulates about the relation of parallel lines. Modern geometrical works, making these other assumptions, supply the deficiencies. Dewey’s How We Think is an incomplete analysis of thinking because it fails to treat the sort of thinking that occurs in reading or learning by instruction in addition to the sort that occurs in investigation and discovery. To a Christian who believes in personal immortality, the writings of Epictetus or Marcus Aurelius are an incomplete account of human happiness.

第四点严格来说不是反对意见的基础。只有在它标志着作者成就的局限性时，它才是批判性的不利因素。部分同意一本书的读者——因为他发现没有理由对其他任何观点提出反对意见——尽管如此，根据这本书的不完整性的第四点，可以暂时搁置对整体的判断。读者的悬而未决的判断是对作者未能完美解决他的问题的回应。

This fourth point is strictly not a basis for disagreement. It is critically adverse only to the extent that it marks the limitations of the author’s achievement. A reader who agrees with a book in part—because he finds no reason to make any of the other points of adverse criticism—may, nevertheless, suspend judgment on the whole, in the light of this fourth point about the book’s incompleteness. Suspended judgment on the reader’s part responds to an author’s failure to solve his problems perfectly.

参考这四个标准，可以对同一领域的相关书籍进行批判性比较。一个人比另一个人更好，因为它说的是更多的真理并且犯的错误更少。如果我们是为了知识而读书，那本书显然是最好的，它最充分地处理了给定的主题。一位作者可能缺少另一位作者拥有的信息；一个人可能会做出错误的假设，而另一个人却没有；从类似的理由进行推理时，一个人可能不如另一个人有说服力。但最深刻的比较是针对每个人所呈现的分析的完整性进行的。这种完整性的衡量标准是在被比较的账户中包含的有效和重要区别的数量。您现在可能会明白掌握作者的术语是多么有用。

Related books in the same field can be critically compared by reference to these four criteria. One is better than another in proportion as it speaks more truth and makes fewer errors. If we are reading for knowledge, that book is best, obviously, which most adequately treats a given subject matter. One author may lack information that another possesses; one may make erroneous suppositions from which another is free; one may be less cogent than another in reasoning from similar grounds. But the profoundest comparison is made with respect to the completeness of the analysis that each presents. The measure of such completeness is to be found in the number of valid and significant distinctions that the accounts being compared contain. You may see now how useful it is to have a grasp of the author’s terms. The number of distinct terms is correlative with the number of distinctions.

你可能还会看到第四条评论是如何将任何一本书的分析阅读的三个阶段联系在一起的。结构概述的最后一步是了解作者试图解决的问题。解释的最后一步是了解作者解决了哪些问题，哪些没有解决。批评的最后一步是关于完整性的观点。它涉及结构概述，因为它考虑作者陈述问题的充分程度，以及衡量他解决问题的圆满程度的解释。

You may also see how the fourth critical remark ties together the three stages of analytical reading of any book. The last step of structural outlining is to know the problems that the author is trying to solve. The last step of interpretation is to know which of these problems the author solved and which he did not. The final step of criticism is the point about completeness. It touches structural outlining insofar as it considers how adequately the author has stated his problems, and interpretation insofar as it measures how satisfactorily he has solved them.

分析阅读第三阶段

The Third Stage of Analytical Reading

 

至此，我们已经大体上完成了对分析阅读规则的列举和讨论。我们现在可以在适当的标题下以适当的顺序列出所有规则。
