We have now completed, in a general way, the enumeration and discussion of the rules of analytical reading. We can now set forth all the rules in their proper order and under appropriate headings.

一、分析阅读的第一阶段：寻找一本书的内容的规则

I. The First Stage of Analytical Reading: Rules for Finding What a Book Is About

 

1.按种类和题材对书进行分类。

1. Classify the book according to kind and subject matter.

2. 尽可能简洁地陈述整本书的内容。

2. State what the whole book is about with the utmost brevity.

3. 按顺序和关系列举主要部分，并像概述整体一样概述这些部分。

3. Enumerate its major parts in their order and relation, and outline these parts as you have outlined the whole.

4. 定义作者试图解决的一个或多个问题。

4. Define the problem or problems the author has tried to solve.

二。分析阅读的第二阶段：解释书籍内容的规则

II. The Second Stage of Analytical Reading: Rules for Interpreting a Book’s Contents

 

5. 通过解读作者的关键词与作者达成共识。

5. Come to terms with the author by interpreting his key words.

6. 通过处理作者最重要的句子来把握作者的主要命题。

6. Grasp the author’s leading propositions by dealing with his most important sentences.

7. 了解作者的论点，通过在句子序列中找到它们或从中构造它们。

7. Know the author’s arguments, by finding them in, or constructing them out of, sequences of sentences.

8. 确定作者解决了他的哪些问题，哪些没有解决；对于后者，确定作者知道他未能解决的问题。

8. Determine which of his problems the author has solved, and which he has not; and of the latter, decide which the author knew he had failed to solve.

三、分析阅读的第三阶段：批评一本书作为知识交流的规则

III. The Third Stage of Analytical Reading: Rules for Criticizing a Book as a Communication of Knowledge

 

A.知识分子礼仪的一般准则

A. General Maxims of Intellectual Etiquette

9. 在完成大纲和对本书的解释之前，不要开始批评。（不要说你同意、不同意或暂停判断，直到你能说“我理解”。）

9. Do not begin criticism until you have completed your outline and your interpretation of the book. (Do not say you agree, disagree, or suspend judgment, until you can say “I understand.”)

10. 不争辩不同意或争论不休。

10. Do not disagree disputatiously or contentiously.

11. 通过为您做出的任何批判性判断提出充分的理由，证明您认识到知识与个人意见之间的区别。

11. Demonstrate that you recognize the difference between knowledge and mere personal opinion by presenting good reasons for any critical judgment you make.

B.批评点的特殊标准

B. Special Criteria for Points of Criticism

 

12. 显示作者不知情的地方。

12. Show wherein the author is uninformed.

13. 指出作者被误导的地方。

13. Show wherein the author is misinformed.

14. 指出作者不合逻辑的地方。

14. Show wherein the author is illogical.

15. 指出作者的分析或叙述不完整的地方。

15. Show wherein the author’s analysis or account is incomplete.

注：在后四项中，前三项是不同意的标准。如果所有这些都失败了，您必须同意，至少部分同意，尽管您可以根据最后一点暂停对整体的判断。

Note: Of these last four, the first three are criteria for disagreement. Failing in all of these, you must agree, at least in part, although you may suspend judgment on the whole, in the light of the last point.

我们在第 7 章末观察到，应用分析阅读的前四个规则可以帮助你回答关于一本书必须问的第一个基本问题，即这本书整体上讲的是什么？同样，在第 9 章的末尾，我们指出应用解释的四个规则可以帮助您回答必须问的第二个问题，即详细说了什么，以及如何说？很可能很明显，阅读的最后七条规则——知识分子礼仪的格言和批评观点的标准——可以帮助你回答你必须问的第三和第四个基本问题。你会记得那些问题是：这是真的吗？那是什么？

We observed at the end of Chapter 7 that applying the first four rules of analytical reading helps you to answer the first basic question you must ask about a book, namely, What is the book about as a whole? Similarly, at the end of Chapter 9, we pointed out that applying the four rules for interpretation helps you to answer the second question you must ask, namely, What is being said in detail, and how? It is probably clear that the last seven rules of reading—the maxims of intellectual etiquette and the criteria for points of criticism—help you to answer the third and fourth basic questions you must ask. You will recall that those questions are: Is it true? and What of it?

问题是，这是真的吗？可以询问我们阅读的任何内容。它适用于任何一种写作，无论是在一种或另一种意义上的“真理”——数学的、科学的、哲学的、历史的和诗歌的。对人类思想的任何工作，没有比赞美它所达到的真理程度更高的赞扬了；出于同样的原因，对它在这方面的失败进行不利的批评就是以严肃的工作应有的严肃态度对待它。然而，奇怪的是，近年来，在西方历史上，人们对这一卓越标准的关注首次减少。书籍赢得了评论家的喝彩，获得了广泛的关注，几乎达到了藐视事实的地步——越是离谱越好。许多读者，尤其是那些审阅当前出版物的读者，使用其他标准来评判、赞扬或谴责他们读过的书——它们的新颖性、它们的轰动效应、它们的诱惑力、它们的力量，甚至它们使人困惑或困惑的力量，但不是它们的真实性、它们的清晰度或它们的力量启发。或许，他们之所以走到这一步，是因为现在有那么多精确科学领域之外的著作表现出对真理的关注如此之少。人们可能会冒险猜测，如果说的是真实的话，无论从那个术语的任何意义上说，再次成为它应该成为的主要关注点，那么就会有更少的书被编写、出版和阅读。但不是他们的真理，他们的清晰度，或者他们的启蒙力量。或许，他们之所以走到这一步，是因为现在有那么多精确科学领域之外的著作表现出对真理的关注如此之少。人们可能会冒险猜测，如果说的是真实的话，无论从那个术语的任何意义上说，再次成为它应该成为的主要关注点，那么就会有更少的书被编写、出版和阅读。但不是他们的真理，他们的清晰度，或者他们的启蒙力量。或许，他们之所以走到这一步，是因为现在有那么多精确科学领域之外的著作表现出对真理的关注如此之少。人们可能会冒险猜测，如果说的是真实的话，无论从那个术语的任何意义上说，再次成为它应该成为的主要关注点，那么就会有更少的书被编写、出版和阅读。

The question, Is it true? can be asked of anything we read. It is applicable to every kind of writing, in one or another sense of “truth”—mathematical, scientific, philosophical, historical, and poetical. No higher commendation can be given any work of the human mind than to praise it for the measure of truth it has achieved; by the same token, to criticize it adversely for its failure in this respect is to treat it with the seriousness that a serious work deserves. Yet, strangely enough, in recent years, for the first time in Western history, there is a dwindling concern with this criterion of excellence. Books win the plaudits of the critics and gain widespread popular attention almost to the extent that they flout the truth—the more outrageously they do so, the better. Many readers, and most particularly those who review current publications, employ other standards for judging, and praising or condemning, the books they read—their novelty, their sensationalism, their seductiveness, their force, and even their power to bemuse or befuddle the mind, but not their truth, their clarity, or their power to enlighten. They have, perhaps, been brought to this pass by the fact that so much of current writing outside the sphere of the exact sciences manifests so little concern with truth. One might hazard the guess that if saying something that is true, in any sense of that term, were ever again to become the primary concern it should be, fewer books would be written, published, and read.

除非您所读的内容在某种意义上是正确的，否则您无需再往前走。但如果是，就必须面对最后一个问题。如果不确定所呈现的事实有什么意义，或者应该有什么意义，你就无法智能地阅读信息。事实很少在没有一些解释的情况下出现，无论是明示的还是暗示的。如果您阅读的信息摘要必须根据对其重要性的某些评估和某些解释原则来选择事实，则尤其如此。如果你是为了开悟而读书，在学习的每一个阶段，都会不断地问这个问题，它是什么？

Unless what you have read is true in some sense, you need go no further. But if it is, you must face the last question. You cannot read for information intelligently without determining what significance is, or should be, attached to the facts presented. Facts seldom come to us without some interpretation, explicit or implied. This is especially true if you are reading digests of information that necessarily select the facts according to some evaluation of their significance, some principle of interpretation. And if you are reading for enlightenment, there is really no end to the inquiry that, at every stage of learning, is renewed by the question, What of it?

正如我们已经指出的，这四个问题概括了读者的所有义务。此外，前三个对应于人类话语的本质。如果通信不复杂，则不需要结构大纲。如果语言是一种完美的媒介而不是一种相对不透明的媒介，那么就不需要解释了。如果错误和无知没有限制真理和知识，我们就不必批判。第四个问题开启了信息和理解之间的区别。当您阅读的材料本身主要是信息性的时，您将面临进一步探索和寻求启发的挑战。即使您已从阅读的内容中获得一些启发，您仍被要求继续寻找意义。

These four questions, as we have already pointed out, summarize all the obligations of a reader. The first three, moreover, correspond to something in the very nature of human discourse. If communications were not complex, structural outlining would be unnecessary. If language were a perfect medium instead of a relatively opaque one, there would be no need for interpretation. If error and ignorance did not circumscribe truth and knowledge, we should not have to be critical. The fourth question turns on the distinction between information and understanding. When the material you have read is itself primarily informational, you are challenged to go further and seek enlightenment. Even when you have been somewhat enlightened by what you have read, you are called upon to continue the search for significance.

在继续第三部分之前，也许我们应该再次强调，这些分析阅读的规则描述了一种理想的表现。很少有人以这种理想的方式读过任何书，而那些以这种方式读过的书可能也很少。然而，理想仍然是成就的衡量标准。在你接近它的程度上，你是一个很好的读者。

Before proceeding to Part Three, perhaps we should stress, once again, that these rules of analytical reading describe an ideal performance. Few people have ever read any book in this ideal manner, and those who have, probably read very few books this way. The ideal remains, however, the measure of achievement. You are a good reader to the degree in which you approximate it.

当我们说某人“博览群书”时，我们应该牢记这一理想。很多时候，我们用这个短语来表示阅读的数量而不是阅读的质量。一个博览群书却不博览群书的人，与其说是表扬不如说是值得同情。正如托马斯·霍布斯所说：“如果我像大多数人一样读那么多书，我也会像他们一样愚蠢。”

When we speak of someone as “well-read,” we should have this ideal in mind. Too often, we use that phrase to mean the quantity rather than the quality of reading. A person who has read widely but not well deserves to be pitied rather than praised. As Thomas Hobbes said, “If I read as many books as most men do, I would be as dull-witted as they are.”

伟大的作家总是伟大的读者，但这并不意味着他们阅读了所有在他们那个时代被列为不可或缺的书籍。在许多情况下，他们读的书比我们大多数大学现在所要求的要少，但他们读过的书，他们读得很好。因为他们掌握了这些书，他们成为了他们的同龄人作者。他们有权凭借自己的权利成为权威。在事件的自然过程中，好学生经常成为老师，因此，好读者也成为作者。

The great writers have always been great readers, but that does not mean that they read all the books that, in their day, were listed as the indispensable ones. In many cases, they read fewer books than are now required in most of our colleges, but what they did read, they read well. Because they had mastered these books, they became peers with their authors. They were entitled to become authorities in their own right. In the natural course of events, a good student frequently becomes a teacher, and so, too, a good reader becomes an author.

我们在这里的目的不是引导您从阅读到写作。而是要提醒你，一个人通过应用我们在阅读一本书时描述的规则来接近良好阅读的理想，而不是通过试图肤浅地了解更多的书。当然，有很多书值得好好读一读。有一个更大的数字应该只被检查。要想成为博览群书的人，无论在任何意义上，都必须知道如何有辨别地使用自己拥有的任何技能——根据每本书的优点来阅读每一本书。

Our intention here is not to lead you from reading to writing. It is rather to remind you that one approaches the ideal of good reading by applying the rules we have described in the reading of a single book, and not by trying to become superficially acquainted with a larger number. There are, of course, many books worth reading well. There is a much larger number that should be only inspected. To become well-read, in every sense of the word, one must know how to use whatever skill one possesses with discrimination—by reading every book according to its merits.

12

阅读辅助

12AIDS TO READING

 

任何阅读书籍之外的阅读帮助我们都可以称之为外在的。所谓“内在阅读”，我们指的是阅读一本书本身，与其他所有书籍截然不同。“外部阅读”是指根据其他书籍阅读一本书。到目前为止，我们有意避免提及任何阅读的外在辅助工具。我们制定的阅读规则是内在阅读的规则——它们不包括走出书本去发现它的意思。到目前为止，我们一直坚持你作为读者的首要任务是有充分理由的——将这本书带入你的书房，并用你自己的思想的力量，在没有其他帮助的情况下，独自完成它。但继续坚持这一点是错误的。外部援助可以提供帮助。有时它们对于充分理解是必要的。

Any aid to reading that lies outside the book being read we may speak of as extrinsic. By “intrinsic reading” we mean reading a book in itself, quite apart from all other books. By “extrinsic reading” we mean reading a book in the light of other books. So far we have intentionally avoided mentioning any extrinsic aids to reading. The rules of reading we have set forth are rules of intrinsic reading—they do not include going outside the book to discover what it means. There are good reasons for our having insisted up to now on your primary task as a reader—taking the book into your study and working on it by yourself, with the power of your own mind, and with no other aids. But it would be wrong to continue insisting on this. Extrinsic aids can help. And sometimes they are necessary for full understanding.

外在阅读我们至今只字未提的一个原因是内在阅读和外在阅读在实际理解和批评一本书的过程中往往会融合在一起。我们实在忍不住要用我们的经验来承担阐释和批评甚至提纲的任务。在这本书之前我们一定读过其他书；没有人通过分析阅读开始他的阅读生涯。我们可能不会像我们应该的那样系统地运用我们在其他书籍和生活中的经验，但我们仍然衡量作者根据来自许多不同来源的我们所知道的其他事物的陈述和结论。因此，常识说任何一本书都不应该，因为任何一本书都不能完全孤立地阅读。

One reason why we have said nothing about extrinsic reading up to now is that intrinsic and extrinsic reading tend to fuse in the actual process of understanding and criticizing a book. We really cannot help bringing our experience to bear on the tasks of interpretation and criticism and even outlining. We must have read other books before this one; no one starts his reading career by reading analytically. We may not bring to bear our experience both of other books and of life as systematically as we should, but we nevertheless measure the statements and conclusions of a writer against other things that we know, from many different sources. Thus it is common sense to say that no book should be, because no book can be, read entirely and completely in isolation.

但到目前为止避免外在帮助的主要原因是许多读者过于依赖它们，我们想让你意识到这是不必要的。另一方面，拿着字典看书是个坏主意，尽管这并不意味着您永远不应该去查字典来了解您不熟悉的单词的含义。在评论中寻找让您感到困惑的书的含义通常是不明智的。总的来说，最好自己做自己能做的，再寻求外界的帮助；因为如果你始终如一地按照这个原则行事，你会发现你对外界帮助的需求会越来越少。

But the main reason for avoiding extrinsic aids up to this point is that many readers depend on them too slavishly, and we wanted you to realize that this is unnecessary. Reading a book with a dictionary in the other hand is a bad idea, although this does not mean you should never go to a dictionary for the meanings of words that are strange to you. And seeking the meaning of a book that puzzles you in a commentary is often ill-advised. On the whole, it is best to do all that you can by yourself before seeking outside help; for if you act consistently on this principle, you will find that you need less and less outside help.

阅读的外在帮助分为四类。按照我们在本章中讨论它们的顺序，它们是： 第一，相关经验；二、其他书籍；三、评论与摘要；第四，参考书。

The extrinsic aids to reading fall into four categories. In the order in which we will discuss them in this chapter, they are: first, relevant experiences; second, other books; third, commentaries and abstracts; fourth, reference books.

无法针对每种特定情况说明如何以及何时使用任何这些类型的外部辅助工具。但是，可以提出一些一般性建议。阅读的一条常识性格言是，当你按照内在阅读的规则尽最大努力阅读一本书后，如果你仍然无法理解一本书的全部或部分内容，就应该寻求外部帮助。

How and when to use any of these types of extrinsic aids cannot be stated for every particular case. Some’ general suggestions can be made, however. It is a common-sense maxim of reading that outside help should be sought whenever a book remains unintelligible to you, either in whole or part, after you have done your best to read it according to the rules of intrinsic reading.

相关经验的作用

The Role of Relevant Experience

 

有两种类型的相关经验可以用来帮助理解难懂的书。当我们在第 6 章谈到普通经验和特殊经验之间的区别时，我们已经提到了所涉及的区别。所有人都有共同的经验女人只是因为她们还活着。必须积极寻求特殊经验，并且只有那些不厌其烦地获得它的人才能获得。特殊经历的最好例子是实验室的实验，但并不总是需要实验室。人类学家可能会通过前往亚马逊流域获得特殊经验，例如，研究尚未探索过的地区的土著居民。因此，他获得了其他人通常无法获得的经验，而且许多人永远也无法获得这种经验；因为如果大量科学家入侵该地区，它将不再是独一无二的。同样，宇航员在月球上的经历也非常特殊，尽管月球并不是通常意义上的实验室。大多数人没有机会知道生活在一个没有空气的星球上是什么感觉，而且这将成为一种普遍体验，如果真的发生的话，还需要几个世纪的时间。木星也一样，由于其引力大得多，在未来很长一段时间内，在这个意义上仍将是一个“实验室”，而且可能永远都是这样。

There are two types of relevant experience that may be referred to for help in understanding difficult books. We have already mentioned the distinction involved, when we spoke in Chapter 6 of the difference between common experience and special experience. Common experience is available to all men and women just because they are alive. Special experience must be actively sought and is available only to those who go to the trouble of acquiring it. The best example of special experience is an experiment in a laboratory, but a laboratory is not always required. An anthropologist may acquire special experience by traveling to the Amazon basin, for example, to study the aboriginal inhabitants of a region that has not yet been explored. He thereby gains experience that is not ordinarily available to others, and that will never be available to many; for if large numbers of scientists invade the region, it will cease to be unique. Similarly, the experience of the astronauts on the moon is highly special, although the moon is not a laboratory in the ordinary sense of the term. Most men do not have the opportunity of knowing what it is like to live on an airless planet, and it will be centuries before this becomes a common experience, if it ever does. Jupiter, too, with its enormously greater gravity, will remain a “laboratory” in this sense for a long time to come, and may always be such.

共同的经验不必为了共同而被每个人分享。通用不等于通用。例如，作为父母的孩子的经历并不是每个人都有，因为有些人是天生的孤儿。然而，家庭生活仍然是普遍的经历，因为大多数男人和女人在他们的日常生活中都有这种经历。性爱也不是一种普遍的体验，尽管它很常见，但就我们赋予“常见”一词的意义而言。有些男人和女人从未经历过它，但这种经历被如此高比例的人分享，以至于它不能被称为特殊。（这并不意味着不能在实验室研究性活动，事实上它一直如此。）被教导的经历也不是普遍的，因为有些男人和女人从未上过学。但它也很常见。

Common experience does not have to be shared by everyone in order to be common. Common is not the same as universal. The experience of being a child of parents, for example, is not shared by every human being, for some are orphans from birth. However, family life is nevertheless common experience, because most men and women, in the ordinary course of their lives, share it. Nor is sexual love a universal experience, although it is common, in the sense we are giving the word common. Some men and women never experience it, but the experience is shared by such a high proportion of humans that it cannot be called special. (This does not mean that sexual activity cannot be studied in the laboratory, as in fact it has been.) The experience of being taught is not universal, either, for some men and women never go to school. But it, too, is common.

这两种体验主要与不同种类的书籍有关。一方面，共同经验与阅读小说最相关，另一方面与阅读另一方面，哲学。关于小说的真实性的判断几乎完全基于共同的经验；我们说，这本书对我们的生活体验要么真实，要么不真实，因为它是由大多数人领导的，包括我们自己。哲学家和诗人一样，诉诸人类的共同经验。他不在实验室工作或在该领域进行研究。因此，要理解和检验哲学家的主要原则，你不需要特殊经验的外在帮助。他指的是你自己的常识和你对生活的世界的日常观察。

The two kinds of experience are mainly relevant to different kinds of books. Common experience is most relevant to the reading of fiction, on the one hand, and to the reading of philosophy, on the other. Judgments concerning the verisimilitude of a novel are almost wholly based on common experience; the book, we say, is either true or not true to our experience of life as it is led by most people, ourselves included. The philosopher, like the poet, appeals to the common experience of mankind. He does no work in laboratories or research in the field. Hence to understand and test a philosopher’s leading principles you do not need the extrinsic aid of special experience. He refers you to your own common sense and your daily observation of the world in which you live.

特殊经历主要与阅读科学著作有关。要理解和判断科学书籍中的归纳论点，您必须能够遵循科学家报告的证据作为其基础。有时科学家对实验的描述是如此生动清晰，以至于您没有任何困难。有时插图和图表有助于您熟悉所描述的现象。

Special experience is mainly relevant to the reading of scientific works. To understand and judge the inductive arguments in a scientific book, you must be able to follow the evidence that the scientist reports as their basis. Sometimes the scientist’s description of an experiment is so vivid and clear that you have no trouble. Sometimes illustrations and diagrams help to acquaint you with the phenomena described.

普通经验和特殊经验都与历史书籍的阅读有关。这是因为历史既有虚构的，也有科学的。一方面，叙事历史是一个故事，有情节和人物、插曲、复杂的动作、高潮和余波。与阅读小说和戏剧相关的共同经验也适用于此。但历史也像科学，至少在某种意义上，历史学家作为其工作基础的经验是相当特殊的。他可能已经阅读了读者不费吹灰之力就无法阅读的一份或多份文件。他可能做过广泛的研究，要么是对过去文明的遗迹，要么是以采访遥远地方的活人的形式。

Both common and special experience are relevant to the reading of history books. This is because history partakes both of the fictional and the scientific. On the one hand, a narrative history is a story, having a plot and characters, episodes, complications of action, a climax, an aftermath. The common experience that is relevant to reading novels and plays is relevant here, too. But history is also like science, in the sense that at least some of the experience on which the historian bases his work is quite special. He may have read a document or many documents that the reader could not manage to see without great trouble. He may have done extensive research, either into the remains of past civilizations or in the form of interviews with living persons in faraway places.

你怎么知道你是否正确地利用你的经验来帮助你理解一本书？最可靠的测试是我们已经推荐的一种理解测试：问问自己是否可以举一个你认为自己理解的要点的具体例子。我们曾多次要求学生这样做，结果发现他们可以不是。学生们似乎明白了这一点，但当被要求提供一个例子时，他们完全不知所措。显然，他们并没有真正理解这本书。当你不太确定你是否掌握了一本书时，用这种方式来测试你自己。以亚里士多德在《伦理学》中对美德的讨论为例。他一遍又一遍地说，美德是介于缺陷和过剩这两个极端之间的中庸之道。他举了一些具体的例子；你能供应其他人吗？如果是这样，你已经理解了他的一般观点。如果没有，你应该回去再读一遍他的讨论。

How do you know whether you are making proper use of your experience to help you understand a book? The surest test is one we have already recommended as a test of understanding: ask yourself whether you can give a concrete example of a point that you feel you understand. We have many times asked students to do this, only to find that they could not. The students appeared to have understood the point, but they were completely at a loss when called upon to supply an example. Obviously, they had not really understood the book. Test yourself in this way when you are not quite sure whether you have grasped a book. Take Aristotle’s discussion of virtue in the Ethics, for example. He says over and over that virtue is a mean between the extremes of defect and excess. He gives some concrete examples; can you supply others? If so, you have understood his general point. If not, you should go back and read his discussion again.

其他作为阅读辅助工具的书籍

Other Books as Extrinsic Aids to Reading

 

稍后我们将更多地讨论主题阅读，即在一个主题上阅读不止一本书。目前，我们想谈谈阅读其他书籍作为阅读特定作品的外在辅助工具的可取性。

We will have more to say later about syntopical reading, where more than one book is read on a single subject. For the moment, we want to say a few things about the desirability of reading other books as extrinsic aids to the reading of a particular work.

我们的建议尤其适用于阅读所谓的好书。人们开始阅读名著的热情往往很快就会让位于绝望的无能感。当然，一个原因是许多读者不知道如何读好一本书。但这还不是全部。还有另一个原因：即他们认为他们应该能够理解他们拿起的第一本书，而无需阅读与其密切相关的其他书籍。他们可能会在没有先阅读《邦联条例》和《宪法》的情况下尝试阅读《联邦党人文集》。或者他们可以在没有读过孟德斯鸠的《法律精神》、卢梭的《社会契约论》和洛克的第二篇论文的情况下尝试所有这些民政府。

Our advice applies particularly to the reading of so-called great books. The enthusiasm with which people embark on a course of reading great books often gives way, fairly soon, to a feeling of hopeless inadequacy. One reason, of course, is that many readers do not know how to read a single book very well. But that is not all. There is another reason: namely, that they think they should be able to understand the first book they pick up, without having read the others to which it is closely related. They may try to read The Federalist Papers without having first read the Articles of Confederation and the Constitution. Or they may try all these without having read Montesquieu’s The Spirit of Laws, Rousseau’s The Social Contract, and Locke’s second treatise Of Civil Government.

许多名著不仅相互关联，而且它们的写作顺序也不容忽视。一位后来的作家受到了一位较早作家的影响。如果你先读前面的作者，他可能会帮助你理解后面的。相互阅读相关书籍并按照使后面的书籍更容易理解的顺序阅读是外在阅读的基本常识性格言。

Not only are many of the great books related, but also they were written in a certain order that should not be ignored. A later writer has been influenced by an earlier one. If you read the earlier writer first, he may help you to understand the later one. Reading related books in relation to one another and in an order that renders the later ones more intelligible is a basic common-sense maxim of extrinsic reading.

这种外在阅读的效用只是阅读一本书本身的上下文价值的延伸。我们已经看到必须如何使用上下文来解释单词和句子以找到术语和命题。正如整本书是其任何部分的上下文一样，相关书籍提供了更大的上下文，可以帮助您解释正在阅读的书。

The utility of this kind of extrinsic reading is simply an extension of the value of context in reading a book by itself. We have seen how the context must be used to interpret words and sentences to find terms and propositions. Just as the whole book is the context for any of its parts, so related books provide an even larger context that helps you interpret the book you are reading.

人们经常观察到，伟大的书籍都包含在长时间的对话中。伟大的作家都是伟大的读者，理解他们的一种方法是阅读他们读过的书。作为读者，他们与其他作者进行对话，就像我们每个人都与我们阅读的书进行对话一样，尽管我们可能不会写其他书。

It has often been observed that the great books are involved in a prolonged conversation. The great authors were great readers, and one way to understand them is to read the books they read. As readers, they carried on a conversation with other authors, just as each of us carries on a conversation with the books we read, though we may not write other books.

要加入这场对话，我们必须阅读彼此相关的伟大书籍，并以某种尊重时间顺序的顺序阅读。书籍的对话及时发生。时间在这里至关重要，不应被忽视。这些书可以从现在读到过去，也可以从过去读到现在。尽管从过去到现在的顺序由于更自然而具有某些优势，但无论哪种方式都可以观察到时间顺序的事实。

To join this conversation, we must read the great books in relation to one another, and in an order that somehow respects chronology. The conversation of the books takes place in time. Time is of the essence here and should not be disregarded. The books can be read from the present into the past or from the past into the present. Though the order from past to present has certain advantages through being more natural, the fact of chronology can be observed in either way.

顺便说一句，应该注意的是，阅读书籍的必要性更多地适用于历史和哲学，而不是科学和小说。这在哲学的案例中最为重要，因为哲学家们是彼此的伟大读者。对于小说或戏剧来说，这可能是最不重要的，如果它们真的很好，可以单独阅读，尽管文学评论家当然不想局限于这样做。

It should be noted, incidentally, that the need to read books in relation to one another applies more to history and philosophy than to science and fiction. It is most important in the case of philosophy, because philosophers are great readers of each other. It is probably least important in the case of novels or plays, which, if they are really good, can be read in isolation, although of course the literary critic will not want to confine himself to doing so.

如何使用评论和摘要

How to Use Commentaries and Abstracts

 

第三类外部阅读辅助工具包括评论和摘要。这里要强调的是，这样的作品应该明智地使用，也就是谨慎使用。有两个原因。

A third category of extrinsic aids to reading includes commentaries and abstracts. The thing to emphasize here is that such works should be used wisely, which is to say sparingly. There are two reasons for this.

首先是评论员对一本书的评论并不总是正确的。当然，有时他们的作品非常有用，但事实并非如此。在大学书店和高中生经常光顾的商店里随处可见的手册和手册往往特别具有误导性。这些作品旨在告诉学生关于他的一位老师布置的一本书他必须知道的一切，但它们有时在解释上大错特错，此外，作为一个实际问题，它们激怒了一些老师和教授。

The first is that commentators are not always right in their comments on a book. Sometimes, of course, their works are enormously useful, but this is true less often than one could wish. The handbooks and manuals that are widely available in college bookstores and in stores frequented by high school students are often particularly misleading. These works purport to tell the student everything he has to know about a book that has been assigned by one of his teachers, but they are sometimes woefully wrong in their interpretations, and besides, as a practical matter, they irritate some teachers and professors.

为了捍卫手册，必须承认它们对于通过考试通常是无价的。此外，为了平衡一些教师对手册的错误感到恼火的事实，其他教师在教学中自己使用它们。

In defense of handbooks, it must be conceded that they are often invaluable for passing examinations. Furthermore, to balance the fact that some teachers are irritated by the errors of handbooks, other teachers use them themselves in their teaching.

谨慎使用评论的第二个原因是，即使它们是正确的，也可能并不详尽。也就是说，您可能会在一本书中发现评论作者没有发现的重要含义。阅读评论，尤其是看起来非常自信的评论，往往会限制你对一本书的理解，即使你的理解就目前而言是正确的。

The second reason for using commentaries sparingly is that, even if they are right, they may not be exhaustive. That is, you may be able to discover important meanings in a book that the author of a commentary about it has not discovered. Reading a commentary, particularly one that seems very self-assured, thus tends to limit your understanding of a book, even if your understanding, as far as it goes, is correct.

因此，我们想给您一条关于使用评论的建议。事实上，这几乎是外在阅读的基本准则。内在阅读的规则之一是在阅读作者的书之前阅读作者的序言和介绍，而外在阅读的规则是您不应该阅读作者的书。别人的评论，直到你读完这本书。这尤其适用于学术和批判性的介绍。只有当你尽最大努力先阅读这本书，然后再应用它们来回答你仍然困惑的问题时，它们才是正确的使用。如果您先阅读它们，它们很可能会扭曲您对本书的阅读。您将倾向于只看到学者或评论家提出的观点，而看不到其他可能同样重要的观点。

Hence, there is one piece of advice that we want to give you about using commentaries. Indeed, this comes close to being a basic maxim of extrinsic reading. Whereas it is one of the rules of intrinsic reading that you should read an author’s preface and introduction before reading his book, the rule in the case of extrinsic reading is that you should not read a commentary by someone else until after you have read the book. This applies particularly to scholarly and critical introductions. They are properly used only if you do your best to read the book first, and then and only then apply to them for answers to questions that still puzzle you. If you read them first they are likely to distort your reading of the book. You will tend to see only the points made by the scholar or critic, and fail to see other points that may be just as important.

以这种方式阅读此类介绍会带来相当大的乐趣。你已经阅读了这本书并理解了它。介绍的作者也看过，也许看过很多遍，对它有自己的理解。因此，您以基本平等的条件接近他。但是，如果您在阅读本书之前先阅读了他的介绍，那么您就任凭他摆布了。

There is considerable pleasure associated with the reading of such introductions when it is done in this way. You have read the book and understood it. The writer of the introduction has also read it, perhaps many times, and has his own understanding of it. You approach him, therefore, on essentially equal terms. If you read his introduction before reading the book, however, you are at his mercy.

注意这条规则，评论应该在你读过他们阐述的书之后而不是之前阅读，这也适用于手册。如果你已经读过这本书并且知道手册哪里错了，那么这些作品就不会伤害你。但是，如果您完全依赖手册，而从不阅读原书，您可能会遇到大麻烦。

Heeding this rule, that commentaries should be read after you have read the book that they expound and not before, applies also to handbooks. Such works cannot hurt you if you have already read the book and know where the handbook is wrong, if it is. But if you depend wholly on the handbook, and never read the original book, you may be in bad trouble.

还有一点。如果你养成了依赖评论和手册的习惯，那么如果找不到，你就会完全迷失方向。借助评论，您也许能够理解某本书，但总的来说，您的阅读能力会更差。

And there is this further point. If you get into the habit of depending on commentaries and handbooks, you will be totally lost if you cannot find one. You may be able to understand a particular book with the help of a commentary, but in general you will be a worse reader.

这里给出的外部阅读规则也适用于摘要和情节摘要。它们在两个连接中有用，但仅在这两个连接中有用。首先，如果您已经读过一本书，它们可以帮助您唤起您对本书内容的记忆。理想情况下，您在分析阅读本书时自己制作了这样的摘要，但如果您还没有这样做，摘要或摘要可能是一个重要的帮助。其次，当您从事主题阅读并希望了解某项工作是否可能与您的项目密切相关时，摘要很有用。摘要永远不能代替书的阅读，但它可以有时会告诉您是否想要或需要阅读这本书。

The rule of extrinsic reading given here applies also to abstracts and plot digests. They are useful in two connections, but in those two only. First, they can help to jog your memory of a book’s contents, if you have already read it. Ideally, you made such an abstract yourself, in reading the book analytically, but if you have not done so, an abstract or digest can be an important aid. Second, abstracts are useful when you are engaged in syntopical reading, and wish to know whether a certain work is likely to be germane to your project. An abstract can never replace the reading of a book, but it can sometimes tell you whether you want or need to read the book or not.

如何使用参考书

How to Use Reference Books

 

参考书有很多种。在下一节中，我们将主要讨论两种最常用的类型：词典和百科全书。然而，我们不得不说的许多事情也适用于其他类型的参考书。

There are many kinds of reference books. In the following section we will confine ourselves mainly to the two most used kinds, dictionaries and encyclopedias. However, many of the things we will have to say apply to other kinds of reference books as well.

人们并不总是意识到，但确实需要大量的知识才能很好地使用参考书。具体来说，需要四种知识。因此，参考书只能以有限的方式消除无知。它不能治愈完全的无知。它不能替你思考。

It is not always realized, yet it is nevertheless true, that a good deal of knowledge is required before you can use a reference book well. Specifically, four kinds of knowledge are required. Thus a reference book is an antidote to ignorance in only a limited way. It cannot cure total ignorance. It cannot do your thinking for you.

要想用好一本参考书，你必须首先对你想知道的东西有一些想法，不管它有多模糊。你的无知一定就像一圈被光包围的黑暗。你想给黑眼圈带来光明。除非光明包围黑暗，否则你无法做到这一点。另一种说法是，您必须能够向参考书提出一个易于理解的问题。如果你在无知的迷雾中徘徊、迷失，那对你毫无帮助。

To use a reference book well, you must, first, have some idea, however vague it may be, of what you want to know. Your ignorance must be like a circle of darkness surrounded by light. You want to bring light to the dark circle. You cannot do that unless light surrounds the darkness. Another way to say this is that you must be able to ask a reference book an intelligible question. It will be no help to you if you are wandering, lost, in a fog of ignorance.

其次，你必须知道在哪里可以找到你想知道的东西。你必须知道你在问什么样的问题，什么样的参考书可以回答那种问题。没有可以回答所有问题的参考书；可以说，所有这些作品都是专家。实际上，这归结为这样一个事实，即您必须对所有主要类型的参考书有一个全面的了解，然后才能有效地使用任何一种类型。

Second, you must know where to find out what you want to know. You must know what kind of question you are asking, and which kinds of reference books answer that kind of question. There is no reference book that answers all questions; all such works are specialists, as it were. Practically, this comes down to the fact that you must have a fair overall knowledge of all of the major types of reference books before you can use any one type effectively.

在一本参考书对你有用之前，还需要第三种相关的知识。您必须知道特定工作的组织方式。它会做如果你不知道如何使用特定的工作，那么知道你想知道什么，知道使用哪种参考书是没有用的。因此，阅读参考书是一门艺术，就像阅读其他任何东西都是一门艺术一样。顺便说一句，制作参考书有相关的艺术。作者或编者应该知道读者会寻找什么样的信息，并根据他们的需要安排他的书。然而，他可能并不总是能够预料到这些，这就是为什么在阅读本书本身之前应该先阅读本书的介绍和序言的规则在这里特别适用。在得到编辑关于如何使用参考书的建议之前，不要尝试使用参考书。

There is a third, and correlative, kind of knowledge that is required before a reference book can be useful to you. You must know how the particular work is organized. It will do you no good to know what you want to know, and to know the kind of reference book to use, if you do not know how to use the particular work. Thus there is an art of reading reference books, just as there is an art to reading anything else. There is a correlative art to making reference books, by the way. The author or compiler should know what kind of information readers will seek, and arrange his book to fit their needs. He may not always be able to anticipate these, however, which is why the rule that you should read the introduction and preface to a book before reading the book itself applies particularly here. Do not try to use a reference book before getting the editor’s advice on how to use it.

当然，并不是所有的问题都可以通过参考书来解答。你不会在任何参考书中找到上帝在托尔斯泰的故事中向天使提出的三个问题的答案，男人活着通过——也就是说，“人的内心是什么？” “什么不是给人类的？” 和“男人靠什么生活？” 你也找不到另一个问题的答案，这个问题也被用作托尔斯泰故事的标题：“一个人需要多少土地？” 还有很多这样的问题。参考书只有在你知道它们可以回答哪些问题、哪些问题不能回答时才有用。这归结为了解男人通常同意的事情。只有那些人们通常和习惯上同意的东西才能在参考书中找到。不受支持的意见在那里没有业务，尽管它们有时会悄悄出现。

Of course, not all kinds of questions can be answered by reference books. You will not find in any reference book the answers to the three questions that God asks the angel in Tolstoy’s story, What Men Live By—namely, “What dwells in man?” “What is not given to man?” and “What do men live by?” Nor will you find the answers to another question that is also used as the title of a Tolstoy story: “How much land does a man need?” And there are many such questions. Reference books are only useful when you know which kinds of questions can be answered by them, and which cannot. This comes down to knowing the sorts of things that men generally agree on. Only those things about which men generally and conventionally agree are to be found in reference books. Unsupported opinions have no business there, though they sometimes creep in.

我们同意，有可能知道一个人何时出生、何时死亡以及有关类似事件的事实。我们同意可以定义词语和事物，并且可以勾勒出几乎任何事物的历史。我们在道德问题或关于未来的问题上意见不一，所以这些东西在参考书中是找不到的。在我们这个时代，我们假设物理世界是可排序的，因此几乎所有关于它的东西都可以在参考书中找到。并非总是如此。因此，参考历史书籍本身很有趣，因为它可以告诉我们很多关于人们对可知事物的看法的变化。

We agree that it is possible to know when a man was born, when he died, and facts about similar matters. We agree that it is possible to define words and things, and that it is possible to sketch the history of almost anything. We do not agree on moral questions or on questions about the future, and so these sorts of things are not to be found in reference books. We assume in our time that the physical world is orderable, and thus almost everything about it is to be found in reference books. This was not always so; as a result, the history of reference books is interesting in itself, for it can tell us much about changes in men’s opinions as to what is knowable.

如您所见，我们刚才一直建议智能使用参考书还有第四个要求。你必须知道你想知道什么；您必须知道在什么参考文献中可以找到它；你必须知道如何在参考书中找到它；并且您必须知道它被本书的作者或编译者认为是可知的。所有这些都表明，在使用参考书之前，您必须了解很多。参考书对于一无所知的人是没有用的。他们不是困惑者的向导。

As you can see, we have just been suggesting that there is a fourth requirement for the intelligent use of reference books. You must know what you want to know; you must know in what reference work to find it; you must know how to find it in the reference work; and you must know that it is considered knowable by the authors or compilers of the book. All this indicates that you must know a good deal before you can use a work of reference. Reference books are useless to people who know nothing. They are not guides to the perplexed.

如何使用字典

How to Use a Dictionary

 

作为参考书，该词典受制于上述所有考虑因素。但是这本词典也能带来有趣的阅读体验。它挑战任何人在闲暇时坐下来阅读它。还有更糟糕的消磨时间的方法。

As a reference book, the dictionary is subject to all the considerations outlined above. But the dictionary also invites a playful reading. It challenges anyone to sit down with it in an idle moment. There are worse ways to kill time.

字典里充满了神秘的知识和诙谐的怪癖。当然，除此之外，他们还有更清醒的工作。要充分利用这些，就必须知道如何阅读字典这种特殊的书籍。

Dictionaries are full of arcane knowledge and witty oddments. Over and above that, of course, they have their more sober employments. To make the most of these, one has to know how to read the special kind of book a dictionary is.

桑塔亚纳关于希腊人的评论——他们是欧洲历史上唯一未受过教育的民族——具有双重意义。大众当然是没有受过教育的，但即使是少数有学识的人——有闲阶级——也没有受过教育，因为他们必须拜访外国大师的脚下。从这个意义上说，教育始于罗马人，他们上学时师从希腊教师，并通过与他们征服的希腊文化的接触而变得有教养。

Santayana’s remark about the Greeks—that they were the only uneducated people in European history—has a double significance. The masses were, of course, uneducated, but even the learned few—the leisure class—were not educated in the sense that they had to sit at the feet of foreign masters. Education, in that sense, begins with the Romans, who went to school to Greek pedagogues, and became cultivated through contact with the Greek culture they had conquered.

因此，第一本词典是荷马词汇表也就不足为奇了，旨在帮助罗马人阅读伊利亚特和奥德赛以及其他使用“古老”荷马词汇的希腊文学。在相同的方式，我们今天的许多人需要一个词汇表来阅读莎士比亚，或者如果不是莎士​​比亚，乔叟。

It is not surprising, therefore, that the first dictionaries were glossaries of Homeric words, intended to help Romans read the Iliad and Odyssey as well as other Greek literature employing the “archaic” Homeric vocabulary. In the same way, many of us today need a glossary to read Shakespeare, or if not Shakespeare, Chaucer.

中世纪有字典，但它们通常是世俗知识的百科全书，包括对学术话语中最重要的技术术语的讨论。文艺复兴时期有外语词典（希腊语和拉丁语），由于主导该时期教育的作品是古代语言，因此很有必要。即使当所谓的粗俗语言——意大利语、法语、英语——逐渐取代拉丁语成为学习语言时，追求学习仍然是少数人的特权。在这种情况下，字典的目标受众是有限的，主要是作为阅读和写作有价值的文学作品的辅助工具。

There were dictionaries in the Middle Ages, but they were usually encyclopedias of worldly knowledge comprised of discussions of the most important technical terms employed in learned discourse. There were foreign-language dictionaries in the Renaissance (both Greek and Latin), made necessary by the fact that the works that dominated the education of the period were in the ancient languages. Even when the so-called vulgar tongues—Italian, French, English—gradually replaced Latin as the language of learning, the pursuit of learning was still the privilege of the few. Under such circumstances, dictionaries were intended for a limited audience, mainly as an aid to reading and writing worthy literature.

因此我们看到，从一开始教育的动机就主导了词典的制作，尽管也有兴趣保持语言的纯洁性和秩序。与后一个目的相比，1857 年开始的牛津英语词典（通常称为 OED）是一个新的出发点，因为它没有试图规定用法，而是提供每种用法的准确历史记录——最坏的和最好的，取自通俗和优雅的作品。但是，作为自封的仲裁者的词典编纂者与作为历史学家的词典编纂者之间的这种冲突可以被视为一个附带问题，因为字典，无论其构造如何，主要是一种教育工具。

Thus we see that from the beginning the educational motive dominated the making of dictionaries, although there was also an interest in preserving the purity and order of the language. As contrasted with the latter purpose, the Oxford English Dictionary (known familiarly as the OED), begun in 1857, was a new departure, in that it did not try to dictate usage but instead to present an accurate historical record of every type of usage—the worst as well as the best, taken from popular as well as elegant writing. But this conflict between the lexicographer as self-appointed arbiter and the lexicographer as historian can be regarded as a side-issue, for the dictionary, however constructed, is primarily an educational instrument.

这个事实与使用字典作为阅读的外在辅助工具的规则有关。阅读任何一本书的第一条规则是要知道它是什么类型的书。这意味着了解作者的意图是什么以及您可以期望在他的作品中找到什么样的东西。如果你仅仅把字典看成拼写书或发音指南，你会相应地使用它，也就是说不太好。如果你意识到它包含了丰富的历史信息，在语言的成长和发展中得到了结晶，你就会注意，不仅是每个词下所列含义的多样性，还包括它们的顺序和关系。

This fact is relevant to the rules for using a dictionary well, as an extrinsic aid to reading. The first rule of reading any book is to know what kind of book it is. That means knowing what the author’s intention was and what sort of thing you can expect to find in his work. If you look upon a dictionary merely as a spelling book or guide to pronunciation, you will use it accordingly, which is to say not well. If you realize that it contains a wealth of historical information, crystallized in the growth and development of language, you will pay attention, not merely to the variety of meanings listed under each word, but also to their order and relation.

最重要的是，如果你有兴趣提高自己的教育水平，你将根据其主要目的使用字典——作为阅读书籍的帮助，否则这些书籍可能会太难，因为它们的词汇包括技术词汇、古语、文学典故，或甚至在过时的意义上使用熟悉的词。

Above all, if you are interested in advancing your own education, you will use a dictionary according to its primary intention—as a help in reading books that might otherwise be too difficult because their vocabulary includes technical words, archaic words, literary allusions, or even familiar words used in obsolete senses.

当然，要读好一本书，除了作者的词汇之外，还有很多问题需要解决。我们已经警告过——尤其是在第一次阅读一本难读的书时——一手拿着书，另一只手拿着字典。如果一开始就查太多的话，肯定会搞不清全书的条理和条理。词典的主要服务是在您遇到技术性词汇或对您来说是全新的词汇时。即便如此，我们也不建议您在第一次阅读一本好书时查阅这些内容，除非它们似乎对作者的一般含义很重要。

Of course, there are many problems to be solved in reading a book well other than those arising from an author’s vocabulary. And we have warned against—particularly on the first reading of a difficult book—sitting with the book in one hand and the dictionary in the other. If you have to look up too many words at the beginning, you will certainly lose track of the book’s unity and order. The dictionary’s primary service is on those occasions when you are confronted with a technical word or with a word that is wholly new to you. Even then, we would not recommend looking up even these during your first reading of a good book unless they seem to be important to the author’s general meaning.

这暗示了其他几个负面禁令。没有比试图通过引用字典来解决关于共产主义、正义或自由的争论的人更令人恼火的了。词典编纂者可能被尊为词语使用方面的权威，但他们并不是智慧的终极源泉。另一个负面规则是：不要吞下字典。不要试图通过记住意义与任何实际经验无关的花哨的单词列表来快速获取单词丰富的单词。简而言之，不要忘记字典是一本关于单词的书，而不是关于事物的书。

This suggests several other negative injunctions. There is no more irritating fellow than the one who tries to settle an argument about communism, or justice, or freedom, by quoting from the dictionary. Lexicographers may be respected as authorities on word usage, but they are not the ultimate founts of wisdom. Another negative rule is: Don’t swallow the dictionary. Don’t try to get word-rich quick by memorizing a fancy list of words whose meanings are unconnected with any actual experience. In short, do not forget that the dictionary is a book about words, not about things.

如果我们记住这一点，我们就可以从这个事实中推导出智能使用字典的所有规则。可以从四个方面来看待单词。

If we remember this, we can derive from that fact all the rules for using a dictionary intelligently. Words can be looked at in four ways.

 

1.文字是有形的东西——可写的文字和可说的声音。因此，必须有统一的拼写方式并发音，虽然一致性经常被变化破坏，无论如何并不像你的一些老师所指出的那样永远重要。

1. WORDS ARE PHYSICAL THINGS—writable words and speak-able sounds. There must, therefore, be uniform ways of spelling and pronouncing them, though the uniformity is often spoiled by variations, and in any event is not as eternally important as some of your teachers may have indicated.

2.单词是语音的一部分。每个单词在短语或句子的更复杂结构中都扮演着语法角色。同一个词在不同的用法中可能会有所不同，从一个词性转变为另一个词性，尤其是在像英语这样的非屈折变化语言中。

2. WORDS ARE PARTS OF SPEECH. Each single word plays a grammatical role in the more complicated structure of a phrase or sentence. The same word can vary in different usages, shifting from one part of speech to another, especially in a non-inflected language like English.

3.文字就是符号。它们具有意义，不是一个而是多个。这些含义以各种方式相关。有时它们会从一个变成另一个；有时一个词会有两组或更多组完全不相关的含义。通过它们的含义，不同的词彼此相关——作为同义词共享相同的含义，即使它们在阴影上不同；或通过意义的对立或对比作为反义词。此外，正是根据它们作为符号的能力，我们将单词区分为专有名称或普通名称（根据它们仅命名一个事物或在某些方面相似的许多事物）；以及作为具体或抽象的名称（根据它们指向我们可以感知的事物，或者指代我们可以通过思想理解但不能通过我们的感官观察到的事物的某些方面）。

3. WORDS ARE SIGNS. They have meanings, not one but many. These meanings are related in various ways. Sometimes they shade from one into another; sometimes a word will have two or more sets of totally unrelated meanings. Through their meanings, different words are related to one another—as synonyms sharing in the same meaning even though they differ in shading; or as antonyms through opposition or contrast of meanings. Furthermore, it is in their capacity as signs that we distinguish words as proper or common names (according as they name just one thing or many that are alike in some respect); and as concrete or abstract names (according as they point to something we can sense, or refer to some aspect of things that we can understand by thought but not observe through our senses).

最后，4 .单词是约定俗成的。它们是人造的标志。这就是为什么每个词都有一段历史，一段文化历程，在这个过程中它经历了某些转变。单词的历史是由它们从原始词根、前缀和后缀的词源派生而来的；它包括对他们身体变化的描述，包括拼写和发音；它讲述了不断变化的含义，其中哪些是古老的和过时的，哪些是流行的和常规的，哪些是惯用语、口语或俚语。

Finally, 4. WORDS ARE CONVENTIONAL. They are man-made signs. That is why every word has a history, a cultural career in the course of which it goes through certain transformations. The history of words is given by their etymological derivation from original word-roots, prefixes, and suffixes; it includes the account of their physical changes, both in spelling and pronunciation; it tells of the shifting meanings, and which among them are archaic and obsolete, which are current and regular, which are idiomatic, colloquial, or slang.

一本好的词典会回答所有这四种关于单词的不同问题。使用字典的艺术在于知道要问什么关于单词的问题以及如何找到答案。我们提出了问题。字典本身会告诉您如何找到答案。

A good dictionary will answer all of these four different kinds of questions about words. The art of using a dictionary consists in knowing what questions to ask about words and how to find the answers. We have suggested the questions. The dictionary itself tells you how to find the answers.

因此，它是一本完美的自助书，因为它告诉您要注意什么以及如何解释它使用的各种缩写和符号，为您提供有关单词的四种信息。任何人如果不查阅词典开头的注释和缩略语列表，如果不能很好地使用它，只能怪自己。

As such, it is a perfect self-help book, because it tells you what to pay attention to and how to interpret the various abbreviations and symbols it uses in giving you the four varieties of information about words. Anyone who fails to consult the explanatory notes and the list of abbreviations at the beginning of a dictionary has only himself to blame if he is not able to use it well.

如何使用百科全书

How to Use an Encyclopedia

 

我们所说的关于字典的许多事情也适用于百科全书。就像字典一样，百科全书也能带来有趣的阅读体验。它也很有趣，很有趣，而且对某些人来说，还可以抚慰人心。但是，试图通读百科全书和通读字典一样是徒劳的。熟记百科全书的人极有可能被冠以 idiot savant的称号—— “博学的傻瓜”。

Many of the things we have said about dictionaries apply to encyclopedias also. Like the dictionary, the encyclopedia invites a playful reading. It too is diverting, entertaining, and, for some people, soothing. But it is just as vain to try to read an encyclopedia through as a dictionary. The man who knew an encyclopedia by heart would be in grave danger of incurring the title idiot savant—”learned fool.”

许多人使用字典来查找单词的拼写和发音。百科全书的类似用途是仅用它来查找日期和地点以及其他类似的简单事实。但这是对百科全书的使用不足或滥用。与字典一样，此类作品既是教育工具，也是信息工具。看一眼他们的历史就会证实这一点。

Many people use a dictionary to find out how to spell and pronounce words. The analogous employment of an encyclopedia is to use it only to look up dates and places and other such simple facts. But this is to under-use, or misuse, an encyclopedia. Like dictionaries, such works are educational as well as informational tools. A glance at their history will confirm this.

尽管“百科全书”一词是希腊语，但希腊人没有百科全书，原因与他们没有字典的原因相同。对他们来说，这个词的意思不是一本关于知识的书，一本承载知识的书，而是知识本身——一个受过教育的人应该拥有的所有知识。再次是罗马人首先发现了百科全书的必要性。现存最古老的例子是普林尼。

Though the word “encyclopedia” is Greek, the Greeks had no encyclopedia, and for the same reason that they had no dictionary. The word meant to them not a book about knowledge, a book in which knowledge reposed, but knowledge itself—all the knowledge that an educated man should have. It was again the Romans who first found encyclopedias necessary; the oldest extant example is that of Pliny.

有趣的是，第一个按字母顺序排列的 en直到大约 1700 年，百科全书才出现。从那时起，大多数伟大的百科全书都是按字母顺序排列的。这是所有安排中最简单的，它使百科全书的制作取得了长足的进步。

Interestingly enough, the first alphabetically-arranged en cyclopedia did not appear until about 1700. Most of the great encyclopedias since then have been alphabetical. It is the easiest of all arrangements, and it made possible great strides in encyclopedia-making.

百科全书提出了一个与生词本不同的问题。字典按字母顺序排列是很自然的。但是作为百科全书主题的世界是按字母顺序排列的吗？明显不是。那么，这个世界是如何安排和安排的呢？这归结为询问知识是如何排序的。

Encyclopedias present a different problem from wordbooks. An alphabetical arrangement is natural for a dictionary. But is the world, which is the subject matter of an encyclopedia, arranged alphabetically? Obviously not. Well then, how is the world arranged and ordered? This comes down to asking how knowledge is ordered.

知识的顺序随着世纪而改变。曾经，所有知识都与七门文科有关——语法、修辞和逻辑，三门学科；算术、几何、天文学和音乐，quadrivium。中世纪的百科全书反映了这种安排。由于大学是按照同样的制度安排的，学生也是按照这种制度来学习的，所以这种安排在教育上是有用的。

The ordering of knowledge has changed with the centuries. All knowledge was once ordered in relation to the seven liberal arts—grammar, rhetoric, and logic, the trivium; arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, and music, the quadrivium. Medieval encylopedias reflected this arrangement. Since the universities were arranged according to the same system, and students studied according to it also, the arrangement was useful in education.

现代大学与中世纪大学有很大不同，这种变化反映在现代百科全书中。他们报告的知识被划分为封地或专业，大致相当于大学的各个部门。但是，这种排列方式虽然构成了百科全书的主干结构，但却被材料的字母顺序排列所掩盖。

The modern university is very different from the medieval one, and the change is reflected in modern encyclopedias. The knowledge that they report is divided up in fiefs, or specialties, that are roughly equivalent to the various departments of the university. But this arrangement, although it forms the backbone structure of an encyclopedia, is masked by the alphabetical arrangement of the material.

正是这种基础结构——借用社会学家的术语——百科全书的优秀读者和用户将寻求发现。的确，他想要从他的集合中获得的主要是事实信息。但他不应该满足于孤立的事实。百科全书向他展示了一系列事实——与其他事实相关的事实。与单纯的信息相比，百科全书能够提供的理解取决于对这种关系的认识。

It is this infra-structure—to take a term from the sociologists —that the good reader and user of an encyclopedia will seek to discover. It is true that it is primarily factual information that he wants from his set. But he should not be content with facts in isolation. The encyclopedia presents him with an arrangement of facts—facts in relation to other facts. The understanding, as contrasted with the mere information, that an encylopedia can provide depends on the recognition of such relations.

在按字母顺序排列的百科全书中，这些关系在很大程度上是模糊的。在按主题排列的百科全书中，当然，它们是突出显示的。但是专题百科全书有很多缺点，其中之一是大多数读者不习惯使用它们。理想情况下，最好的百科全书应该是既有主题又有字母顺序排列的百科全书。它以单独文章的形式呈现材料将按字母顺序排列，但它也会包含某种主题重点或大纲——本质上是目录。（目录是一本书的主题排列，与索引相反，索引是按字母顺序排列的。）据我们所知，目前市场上没有这样的百科全书，但值得付出努力试着做一个。

In an alphabetically-arranged encyclopedia, these relations are to a large extent obscured. In a topically-arranged encyclopedia, they are, of course, highlighted. But topical encyclopedias have many disadvantages, among them the fact that most readers are not accustomed to using them. Ideally, the best encyclopedia would be one that had both a topical and an alphabetical arrangement. Its presentation of material in the form of separate articles would be alphabetical, but it would also contain some kind of topical key or outline—essentially, a table of contents. (A table of contents is a topical arrangement of a book, as opposed to an index, which is an alphabetical arrangement.) As far as we know, there is no such encyclopedia on the market today, but it would be worth the effort to try to make one.

如果没有理想，读者必须求助于百科全书编辑提供的帮助和建议。任何好的百科全书都包含有关如何有效使用它的说明，应该阅读并遵循这些说明。通常，这些说明要求用户先转到集合的索引，然后再转到按字母顺序排列的其中一卷。在这里，索引起到了目录的作用，虽然不是很好；因为它在同一个标​​题下汇集了百科全书中的讨论，这些讨论在空间上可能相距甚远，但仍然是关于同一主题的。这反映了一个事实，即虽然索引当然是按字母顺序排列的，但其所谓的分析——即主要条目下的细分——是按主题排列的。但主题本身必须按字母顺序排列，这不一定是最好的安排。因此，真正优秀的百科全书（如大英百科全书）的索引部分地揭示了作品所反映的知识安排。出于这个原因，任何未能使用索引的读者如果作品不能满足他的需要，只能怪他自己。

In default of the ideal, the reader must fall back on the help and advice provided him by an encyclopedia’s editors. Any good encyclopedia includes directions about how to use it effectively, and these should be read and followed. Often, these directions require that the user go first to the set’s index, before turning to one of the alphabetically-arranged volumes. Here, the index is serving the function of a table of contents, though not very well; for it gathers together, under one heading, references to discussions in the encyclopedia that may be widely separated in space but that are nevertheless about the same general subject. This reflects the fact that although an index is of course alphabetically arranged, its so-called analyticals—that is, the breakdowns under a main entry—are topically arranged. But the topics themselves must be in alphabetical order, which is not necessarily the best arrangement. Thus the index of a really good encyclopedia such as Britannica goes part of the way toward revealing the arrangement of knowledge that the work reflects. For this reason, any reader who fails to use the index has only himself to blame if the work does not serve his needs.

有与使用百科全书相关的负面禁令，就像字典一样。百科全书和字典一样，是阅读好书的宝贵辅助工具——坏书通常不需要它们存在；但，和以前一样，明智的做法是不要让自己成为百科全书的奴隶。同样，与字典一样，百科全书不能用于解决基于意见分歧的争论。尽管如此，他们应该用于尽快和永久地结束关于事实问题的争论。事实永远不应该首先争论。百科全书使这种徒劳的努力变得不必要，因为百科全书充满了事实。理想情况下，它们没有其他任何东西。最后，虽然词典通常对单词的描述一致，但百科全书对事实的描述往往不一致。因此，如果您真的对某个主题感兴趣并且依赖于百科全书式的处理，请不要将自己局限于一本百科全书。多读一本，最好是不同时期写的。

There are negative injunctions associated with the use of encyclopedias, just as there are for dictionaries. Encyclopedias, like dictionaries, are valuable adjuncts to the reading of good books—bad books do not ordinarily require their presence; but, as before, it is wise not to enslave yourself to an encyclopedia. Again, as with dictionaries, encyclopedias are not to be used for the settling of arguments where these are based on differences of opinion. Nevertheless, they should be used to end disputes about matters of fact as quickly and permanently as possible. Facts should never be argued about in the first place. An encyclopedia makes this vain effort unnecessary, because encyclopedias are full of facts. Ideally, they are filled with nothing else. Finally, although dictionaries usually agree in their accounts of words, encyclopedias often do not agree in their accounts of facts. Hence, if you are really interested in a subject and are depending on encyclopedic treatments of it, do not restrict yourself to just one encylopedia. Read more than one, and preferably ones written at different times.

我们指出了用户在查阅字典时应牢记的有关单词的几点要点。就百科全书而言，类似的点是关于事实的，因为百科全书是关于事实的，就像字典是关于单词的一样。

We noted several points about words that the user should keep in mind when he consults a dictionary. In the case of encyclopedias, the analogous points are about facts, for an encyclopedia is about facts as a dictionary is about words.

1.事实就是命题。事实陈述使用组合词，例如“亚伯拉罕·林肯出生于 1809 年 2 月 12 日”或“黄金的原子序数是 79”。事实不像文字那样是物理事物，但它们确实需要解释。为了获得透彻的知识，为了理解，你还必须知道一个事实的意义是什么——它如何影响你正在寻找的真理。如果你只知道事实是什么，那你就知道的不多。

1. FACTS ARE PROPOSITIONS. Statements of fact employ words in combination, such as “Abraham Lincoln was born on February 12, 1809,” or “the atomic number of gold is 79.” Facts are not physical things, as words are, but they do require to be explained. For thorough knowledge, for understanding, you must also know what the significance of a fact is—how it affects the truth you are seeking. You do not know much if all you know is what the fact is.

2.事实是“真实”的命题。事实不是意见。当有人说“这是事实”时，他的意思是人们普遍认为情况就是如此。他从不意味着，也不应该意味着，他一个人，或者他与少数观察者一起，相信情况如此这般。正是事实的这种特征赋予了百科全书以其基调和风格。包含其编辑未经证实的意见的百科全书是不诚实的；尽管百科全书可能报告意见（例如，在“某些人认为情况如此，其他人认为情况如此”这样的短语中），必须清楚地标记它们。百科全书报告案件事实而不是对案件发表意见的要求（除上述情况外）也限制了作品的覆盖范围。它无法妥善处理没有达成共识的问题——例如道德问题。如果它确实处​​理这样的问题，它只能适当地报道人们对此的分歧。

2. FACTS ARE “TRUE” PROPOSITIONS. Facts are not opinions. When someone says “it is a fact that,” he means that it is generally agreed that such is the case. He never means, or never should mean, that he alone, or he together with a minority of observers, believes such and such to be the case. It is this characteristic of facts that gives the encyclopedia its tone and style. An encyclopedia that contains the unsupported opinions of its editors is dishonest; and although an encyclopedia may report opinions (for example, in a phrase like “it is held by some that this is the case, by others that that is the case”), it must clearly label them. The requirement that an encyclopedia report the facts of the case and not opinions about it (except as noted above) also limits the work’s coverage. It cannot properly deal with matters about which there is no consensus—with moral questions, for example. If it does deal with such questions, it can only properly report the disagreements among men about them.

3.事实是现实的反映。事实可能是 (a) 信息单数或 (b) 相对无可置疑的概括，但在任何一种情况下，它们都被认为代表了事物的真实面目。（林肯的生日是一个信息单数；黄金的原子序数暗示了对物质的相对无可置疑的概括。）因此，事实不是思想或概念，也不是纯粹对现实的推测意义上的理论。同样，对现实（或现实的一部分）的解释不是事实，除非人们普遍同意它是正确的。

3. FACTS ARE REFLECTIONS OF REALITY. Facts may be either (a) informational singulars or (b) relatively unquestioned generalizations, but in either case they are held to represent the way things really are. (The birthdate of Lincoln is an informational singular; the atomic number of gold implies a relatively unquestioned generalization about matter.) Thus facts are not ideas or concepts, nor are they theories in the sense of being mere speculations about reality. Similarly, an explanation of reality (or of part of it) is not a fact until and unless there is general agreement that it is correct.

最后一条声明有一个例外。当百科全书与作为文章主题的主题、个人或学校相关联时，百科全书可以恰当地描述不再被认为是全部或部分正确的理论，或者尚未完全验证的理论. 因此，例如，亚里士多德关于天体本质的观点可以在一篇关于亚里士多德主义的文章中得到阐述，即使我们不再相信它们是真实的。

There is one exception to the last statement. An encyclopedia can properly describe a theory that is no longer held to be correct, in whole or in part, or one that has not yet been fully validated, when it is associated with a topic, person or school that is the subject of an article. Thus, for example, Aristotle’s views on the nature of celestial matter could be expounded in an article on Aristotelianism even though we no longer believe them to be true.

最后，4 . 事实在某种程度上是约定俗成的。我们说，事实会改变。我们的意思是，一些在一个时代被认为是事实的命题在另一个时代不再被认为是事实。只要事实是“真实的”并代表现实，它们当然就不会改变，因为严格来说，真理不会改变，现实也不会改变。但并非所有我们认为为真的命题都是真的；和我们必须承认，几乎任何我们认为正确的给定命题都可以通过更耐心或更准确的观察和调查来证伪。这尤其适用于科学事实。

Finally, 4. FACTS ARE TO SOME EXTENT CONVENTIONAL. Facts change, we say. We mean that some propositions that are considered to be facts in one epoch are no longer considered to be facts in another. Insofar as facts are “true” and represent reality, they cannot change, of course, because truth, strictly speaking, does not change, nor does reality. But not all propositions that we take to be true are really true; and we must concede that almost any given proposition that we take to be true can be falsified by more patient or more accurate observation and investigation. This applies particularly to the facts of science.

事实也是——同样在某种程度上——由文化决定。例如，一位原子科学家在他的头脑中保持着一个复杂的、假设的现实结构，这个结构为他决定了某些事实，这些事实不同于原始人所确定和接受的事实。这并不意味着科学家和原始人不能就任何事实达成一致；例如，他们必须同意二加二等于四，或者一个物理整体大于它的任何部分。但是原始人可能不同意科学家关于核粒子的事实，就像科学家可能不同意原始人关于仪式魔法的事实一样（这是一个很难写的句子，因为，在文化上决定了我们自己，我们倾向于同意科学家而不是原始人，因此很想把第二个“事实”放在引号中。但这正是重点。）

Facts are also—again to some extent—culturally determined. An atomic scientist, for example, maintains a complicated, hypothetical structure of reality in his mind that determines—for him—certain facts that are different from the facts that are determined for and accepted by a primitive. This does not mean that the scientist and the primitive cannot agree on any facts; they must agree, for instance, that two plus two is four, or that a physical whole is greater than any of its parts. But the primitive may not agree with the scientist’s facts about nuclear particles, just as the scientist may not agree with the primitive’s facts about ritual magic (That was a hard sentence to write, because, being culturally determined ourselves, we tend to agree with the scientist rather than the primitive and were thus tempted to put the second “fact” in quotation marks. But that is precisely the point.)

如果您记得我们上面概述的关于事实的要点，那么一本好的百科全书将回答您关于事实的问题。使用百科全书作为阅读辅助工具的艺术就是就事实提出适当问题的艺术。与字典一样，我们只是提出了问题；百科全书将提供答案。

A good encyclopedia will answer your questions about facts if you remember the points about facts that we have outlined above. The art of using an encyclopedia as an aid to reading is the art of asking the proper questions about facts. As with the dictionary, we have merely suggested the questions; the encyclopedia will supply the answers.

您还应该记住，百科全书并不是追求理解的最佳场所。可以从中获得关于知识的顺序和安排的见解；但这虽然是一个重要的主题，但却是一个有限的主题。有许多知识是您在百科全书中找不到的。

You should also remember that an encyclopedia is not the best place to pursue understanding. Insights may be gained from it about the order and arrangement of knowledge; but that, although an important subject, is nonetheless a limited one. There are many matters required for understanding that you will not find in an encyclopedia.

有两个特别明显的遗漏。准确地说，百科全书不包含任何论点，除非它报告了现在被广泛接受为正确或至少具有历史意义的论点过程。因此一个缺乏说明文写作的主要元素。百科全书也不包含诗歌或想象文学，尽管它可能包含有关诗歌和诗人的事实。由于理解需要想象力和理性，这意味着百科全书在追求它的过程中一定是一个相对不令人满意的工具。

There are two particularly striking omissions. An encyclopedia, properly speaking, contains no arguments, except insofar as it reports the course of arguments that are now widely accepted as correct or at least as of historical interest. Thus a major element in expository writing is lacking. An encylopedia also contains no poetry or imaginative literature, although it may contain facts about poetry and poets. Since both the imagination and the reason are required for understanding, this means that the encyclopedia must be a relatively unsatisfying tool in the pursuit of it.

第三部分

PART THREE

 

处理不同类型阅读材料的方法

Approaches to Different Kinds of Reading Matter

 

13

如何阅读实用书籍

13HOW TO READ PRACTICAL BOOKS

 

在任何艺术或实践领域，规则都有一种令人失望的过于笼统的方式。越通用，当然越少，这就是优势。越笼统，也越容易理解——更容易理解规则本身。但同样真实的是，规则越普遍，它们与您试图遵循它们的实际情况的复杂性就越遥远。

In any art or field of practice, rules have a disappointing way of being too general. The more general, of course, the fewer, and that is an advantage. The more general, too, the more intelligible—it is easier to understand the rules in and by themselves. But it is also true that the more general the rules, the more remote they are from the intricacies of the actual situation in which you try to follow them.

我们已经阐述了分析阅读的一般规则，以便它们适用于任何说明性书籍——任何传达知识的书籍，在我们一直使用该术语的意义上。但是你不能一般地阅读一本书。你读过这本书或那本书，每本书都是特定类型的。它可以是历史或数学书籍、政治小册子或自然科学著作，也可以是哲学或神学论文。因此，您在遵守规则时必须具有一定的灵活性和适应性。幸运的是，当你应用它们时，你会逐渐感受到它们是如何在不同种类的书籍上发挥作用的。

We have stated the rules of analytical reading generally so that they apply to any expository book—any book that conveys knowledge, in the sense in which we have been using that term. But you cannot read a book in general. You read this book or that, and every particular book is of a particular sort. It may be a history or a book in mathematics, a political tract or a work in natural science, or a philosophical or theological treatise. Hence, you must have some flexibility and adaptability in following the rules. Fortunately, you will gradually get the feeling of how they work on different kinds of books as you apply them.

重要的是要注意，在第 11 章末尾介绍的十五条阅读规则不适用于小说和诗歌的阅读。想象作品的结构大纲与说明性书籍的大纲不同。小说戏剧和诗歌不是用词、命题和论证来进行的——它们的基本内容，换句话说，是不合逻辑的，对这些作品的批评是基于不同的前提。然而，如果认为没有任何规则适用于阅读富有想象力的文学作品，那就错了。事实上，我们将在下一章描述阅读此类书籍的一组平行规则。这些本身就很有用；但是，对它们的考察以及它们与阅读说明性作品规则的差异，也有助于阐明后者的规则。

It is important to note here that the fifteen rules of reading, in the form in which they were presented toward the end of Chapter 11, do not apply to the reading of fiction and poetry. The outlining of the structure of an imaginative work is a different matter from the outlining of an expository book. Novels and plays and poems do not proceed by terms, propositions, and arguments—their fundamental content, in other words, is not logical, and the criticism of such works is based on different premises. Nevertheless, it would be a mistake to think that no rules at all apply to reading imaginative literature. In fact, there is a parallel set of rules for reading such books that we will describe in the next chapter. These are useful in themselves; but the examination of them and their differences from the rules for reading expository works also throws light on the latter rules.

你不必担心你将不得不学习一整套全新的阅读小说和诗歌的十五条或更多规则。两种规则之间的联系很容易看出和说明。它包含一个我们一再强调的基本事实，即你在阅读时必须提出问题，特别是无论你正在阅读什么，你都必须提出四个特定的问题。这四个问题与任何书籍都相关，无论是小说还是非行动，无论是诗歌、历史、科学还是哲学。我们已经看到阅读说明性作品的规则是如何与这四个问题联系起来并从中发展而来的。同样，想象文学的阅读规则也是由它们发展而来的，只是阅读材料的性质不同，导致发展上存在一定的差异。

You need not fear that you will have to learn a whole new set of fifteen or more rules for reading fiction and poetry. The connection between the two kinds of rules is easy to see and state. It consists in the underlying fact, which we have emphasized over and over, that you must ask questions when you read, and specifically that you must ask four particular questions of whatever you are reading. These four questions are relevant to any book, whether fiction or nonaction, whether poetry or history or science or philosophy. We have seen how the rules of reading expository works connect with and are developed from these four questions. Similarly, the rules of reading imaginative literature are also developed from them, although the difference in the nature of the materials read causes some dissimilarities in the development.

既然如此，在本书的这一部分，我们将更多地讨论这些问题，而不是阅读规则。我们偶尔会提及新规则，或对旧规则的修订或改编。但大多数时候，当我们继续建议阅读不同类型的书籍和其他材料的方法时，我们会强调必须首先提出的不同问题，以及可以预期的不同类型的答案。

That being the case, in this part of the book we will have more to say about these questions than about the rules for reading. We will occasionally refer to a new rule, or to a revision or adaptation of an old one. But most of the time, as we proceed to suggest approaches to the reading of different kinds of books and other materials, we will emphasize the different questions that must be primarily asked, and the different kinds of answers that can be expected.

在说明领域，我们注意到基本分为实践和理论——关注行动问题的书籍，以及只关注已知事物的书籍。理论上是正如我们已经注意到的，它可以进一步分为历史、科学（和数学）和哲学。实用的划分跨越了所有界限，因此我们建议进一步检查此类书籍的性质，并在您阅读它们时提出一些指导方针和预防措施。

In the expository realm, we have noted that the basic division is into the practical and the theoretical—books that are concerned with the problems of action, and books that are concerned only with something to be known. The theoretical is further divisible, as we have noted, into history, science (and mathematics), and philosophy. The practical division cuts across all boundaries, and we therefore propose to examine the nature of such books a little further, and to suggest some guidelines and precautions when you read them.

两种实用书籍

The Two Kinds of Practical Books

 

关于任何一本实用的书，最重要的是要记住它永远无法解决它所关注的实际问题。一本理论书可以解决它自己的问题。但是一个实际的问题只能通过行动本身来解决。当你的实际问题是如何谋生时，一本关于如何交朋友和影响他人的书无法解决它，尽管它可能会建议你去做一些事情。没有什么比做更能解决问题的了。只有靠谋生才能解决。

The most imporant thing to remember about any practical book is that it can never solve the practical problems with which it is concerned. A theoretical book can solve its own problems. But a practical problem can only be solved by action itself. When your practical problem is how to earn a living, a book on how to make friends and influence people cannot solve it, though it may suggest things to do. Nothing short of the doing solves the problem. It is solved only by earning a living.

以这本书为例。这是一本实用的书。如果你对它的兴趣是实际的（当然，它可能只是理论上的），你想解决学习阅读的问题。在你真正学习之前，你不会认为那个问题已经解决和消除了。这本书不能为你解决问题。它只能提供帮助。你必须真正经历阅读活动，不仅是这本书，还有许多其他书。这就是所谓只有行动才能解决实际问题，而行动只发生在世界上，而不是发生在书本上。

Take this book, for example. It is a practical book. If your interest in it is practical (it might, of course, be only theoretical), you want to solve the problem of learning to read. You would not regard that problem as solved and done away with until you did learn. This book cannot solve the problem for you. It can only help. You must actually go through the activity of reading, not only this book but many others. That is what it means to say that nothing but action solves practical problems, and action occurs only in the world, not in books.

每个动作都发生在特定的情况下，总是在此时此地，在特定的情况下发生。你不能笼统地行动。紧接在行动之前的那种实际判断必须是非常特殊的。它可以用语言来表达，但很少。它几乎从未出现在书籍中，因为一本实用书籍的作者无法设想他的读者可能不得不采取行动的具体实际情况。尽管他会尽力提供帮助，但他无法给他们具体实用的建议。只有处于完全相同情况下的另一个人才能做到这一点。

Every action takes place in a particular situation, always in the here and now and under a particular set of circumstances. You cannot act in general. The kind of practical judgment that immediately precedes action must be highly particular. It can be expressed in words, but it seldom is. It is almost never found in books, because the author of, a practical book cannot envisage the concrete practical situations in which his readers may have to act. Try as he will to be helpful, he cannot give them concrete practical advice. Only another person in exactly the same situation could do that.

然而，实用书籍可以或多或少地陈述适用于许多同类特定情况的一般规则。任何试图使用此类书籍的人都必须将这些规则应用于特定案例，因此，在这样做时必须运用实际判断。换句话说，读者自己必须对本书进行一些补充，以使其适用于实践。他必须补充他对特定情况的了解以及他对规则如何适用于案件的判断。

Practical books can, however, state more or less general rules that apply to a lot of particular situations of the same sort. Whoever tries to use such books must apply the rules to particular cases and, therefore, must exercise practical judgment in doing so. In other words, the reader himself must add something to the book to make it applicable in practice. He must add his knowledge of the particular situation and his judgment of how the rule applies to the case.

任何包含规则的书——处方、格言或任何类型的一般指导——你都会很容易地认出是一本实用的书。但是一本实用的书可能包含的不仅仅是规则。它可能会尝试陈述规则背后的原则并使它们易于理解。例如，在这本关于阅读的实用书籍中，我们试图通过对语法、修辞和逻辑原则的简要说明来解释规则。作为规则基础的原则本身通常是科学的，也就是说，它们是理论知识。合在一起，它们就是事物的理论。于是，我们就谈起造桥理论或者契约桥理论。我们指的是使良好程序规则成为现实的理论原则。

Any book that contains rules—prescriptions, maxims, or any sort of general directions—you will readily recognize as a practical book. But a practical book may contain more than rules. It may try to state the principles that underlie the rules and make them intelligible. For example, in this practical book about reading, we have tried here and there to explain the rules by brief expositions of grammatical, rhetorical, and logical principles. The principles that underlie rules are usually in themselves scientific, that is, they are items of theoretical knowledge. Taken together, they are the theory of the thing. Thus, we talk about the theory of bridge building or the theory of contract bridge. We mean the theoretical principles that make the rules of good procedure what they are.

因此，实用书籍分为两大类。有些，比如这本，或者一本食谱，或者一本驾驶手册，主要是规则的介绍。他们包含的任何其他讨论都是为了规则。很少有这类好书。另一种实用书籍主要关注生成规则的原理。大多数经济学、政治学和道德方面的伟大著作都属于这种类型。

Practical books thus fall into two main groups. Some, like this one, or a cookbook, or a driver’s manual, are primarily presentations of rules. Whatever other discussion they contain is for the sake of the rules. There are few great books of this sort. The other kind of practical book is primarily concerned with the principles that generate rules. Most of the great books in economics, politics, and morals are of this sort.

这种区别不是尖锐和绝对的。原则和规则可以在同一本书中找到。重点是相对强调之一。将书籍分类到这两堆中不会有任何困难。任何领域的规则书总是可以立即识别为实用的。实用原则​​这本书乍一看可能像一本理论书。从某种意义上说，正如我们所见。它涉及一种特定实践的理论。你总能说它很实用，然而。它的问题的性质暴露了它。它总是关于人类行为的一个领域，在这个领域中，人们可以做得更好或更差。

This distinction is not sharp and absolute. Both principles and rules may be found in the same book. The point is one of relative emphasis. You will have no difficulty in sorting books into these two piles. The book of rules in any field will always be immediately recognizable as practical. The book of practical principles may look at first like a theoretical book. In a sense it is, as we have seen. It deals with the theory of a particular kind of practice. You can always tell it is practical, however. The nature of its problems gives it away. It is always about a field of human behavior in which men can do better or worse.

在阅读一本主要是规则书的书时，要寻找的主要命题当然是规则。规则最直接地用祈使句而不是陈述句来表达。这是一个命令。上面写着：“及时缝一针，省九针。” 该规则也可以用声明的方式表达，就像我们说的那样，“及时缝一针可以节省九针”。两种形式的陈述都表明——命令式更强调一点，但不一定更令人难忘——及时行事是值得的。

In reading a book that is primarily a rule-book, the major propositions to look for, of course, are the rules. A rule is most directly expressed by an imperative rather than a declarative sentence. It is a command. It says: “Save nine stitches by taking a stitch in time.” That rule can also be expressed declaratively, as when we say, “A stitch in time saves nine.” Both forms of statement suggest—the imperative a little more emphatically, but not necessarily more memorably—that it is worth while to be prompt.

无论是以声明的形式还是以命令的形式陈述，您总能认出一条规则，因为它推荐了一些值得为达到特定目的而去做的事情。因此，命令你达成共识的阅读规则也可以作为建议陈述：良好的阅读涉及达成共识。“好”这个词是赠品。暗示这样的阅读是值得的。

Whether it is stated declaratively or in the form of a command, you can always recognize a rule because it recommends something as worth doing to gain a certain end. Thus, the rule of reading that commands you to come to terms can also be stated as a recommendation: good reading involves coming to terms. The word “good” is the giveaway. That such reading is worth doing is implied.

这类实用书籍中的论点将试图向您表明规则是合理的。作者可能不得不诉诸原则来说服你，或者他可能只是通过向你展示它们在具体案例中的工作原理来说明它们的合理性。寻找这两种论点。诉诸原则通常缺乏说服力，但它有一个优势。它比规则的使用示例更能解释规则的原因。

The arguments in a practical book of this sort will be attempts to show you that the rules are sound. The writer may have to appeal to principles to persuade you that they are, or he may simply illustrate their soundness by showing you how they work in concrete cases. Look for both sorts of arguments. The appeal to principles is usually less persuasive, but it has one advantage. It can explain the reason for the rules better than examples of their use.

在另一类实用书籍中，那种主要涉及规则背后的原则、主要命题和论点的书籍，当然看起来与纯理论书籍中的完全一样。命题会说事情是这样的，而论证会试图表明事情是这样的。

In the other kind of practical books, the kind dealing mainly with the principles underlying rules, the major propositions and arguments will, of course, look exactly like those in a purely theoretical book. The propositions will say that something is the case, and the arguments will try to show that it is so.

但是读这样一本书和读一本纯理论书有一个重要的区别。由于要解决的最终问题是实际问题——行动问题，在人们可以做得更好或更差的领域——这些关于“实用原则”的书籍的聪明读者总是在字里行间或空白处阅读。他试图看到可能无法表达但可以从原则中推导出来的规则。他走得更远。他试图弄清楚这些规则在实践中应该如何应用。

But there is an important difference between reading such a book and reading a purely theoretical one. Since the ultimate problems to be solved are practical—problems of action, in fields where men can do better or worse—an intelligent reader of such books about “practical principles” always reads between the lines or in the margins. He tries to see the rules that may not be expressed but that can, nevertheless, be derived from the principles. He goes further. He tries to figure out how the rules should be applied in practice.

除非这样阅读，否则一本实用的书就不会被当作实用的来阅读。不把一本实用的书当作实用来读，就是读得很差。你真的不明白，你肯定不能用其他任何方式正确地批评它。如果规则的可理解性可以在原则中找到，那么实践原则的意义也可以在它们所导致的规则和它们所推荐的行动中找到。

Unless it is so read, a practical book is not read as practical. To fail to read a practical book as practical is to read it poorly. You really do not understand it, and you certainly cannot criticize it properly in any other way. If the intelligibility of rules is to be found in principles, it is no less true that the significance of practical principles is to be found in the rules they lead to, the actions they recommend.

这表明您必须做些什么才能理解任何一种实用书籍。它还指出了批判性判断的最终标准。在纯理论书籍的情况下，同意或不同意的标准与所讲内容的真实性有关。但实践真理不同于理论真理。一项行为准则在两个条件下实际上是正确的：一个是它有效；另一个是它的运作会把你带到正确的终点，一个你正确渴望的终点。

This indicates what you must do to understand either sort of practical book. It also indicates the ultimate criteria for critical judgment. In the case of purely theoretical books, the criteria for agreement or disagreement relate to the truth of what is being said. But practical truth is different from theoretical truth. A rule of conduct is practically true on two conditions: one is that it works; the other is that its working leads you to the right end, an end you rightly desire.

假设一位作者认为你应该追求的目标对你来说似乎并不正确。尽管他的建议实际上可能是合理的，但从让你达到那个目的的意义上说，你最终不会同意他的看法。你对他的书实际上是正确的还是实际上是错误的判断将相应地做出。如果您认为仔细和明智的阅读不值得，那么无论它的规则多么合理，这本书对您来说都没有什么实用的道理。

Suppose that the end an author thinks you should seek does not seem like the right one to you. Even though his recommendations may be practically sound, in the sense of getting you to that end, you will not agree with him ultimately. And your judgment of his book as practically true or practically false will be made accordingly. If you do not think careful and intelligent reading is worth doing, this book has little practical truth for you, however sound its rules may be.

注意这意味着什么。在判断一本理论书籍时，读者必须观察自己的基本原理或假设与作者的一致性或差异。在判断一本实用的书时，一切都取决于目的或目标。如果你不认同卡尔马克思对经济正义的热情，他的经济学说和它所建议的改革在你看来可能实际上是错误的或无关紧要的。例如，您可能会像埃德蒙·伯克（Edmund Burke）那样认为，维持现状是最理想的目标；考虑到所有因素，您认为这比消除资本主义的不平等现象更重要。在这种情况下，您可能会认为像《共产党宣言》这样的书是荒谬的错误。你的主要判断总是基于目的，而不是手段。我们对达到我们不赞成或不关心的目的，即使是最合理的方法也没有实际兴趣。

Notice what this means. In judging a theoretical book, the reader must observe the identity of, or the discrepancy between, his own basic principles or assumptions and those of the author. In judging a practical book, everything turns on the ends or goals. If you do not share Karl Marx’s fervor about economic justice, his economic doctrine and the reforms it suggests are likely to seem to you practically false or irrelevant. You may think, as Edmund Burke did, for example, that preserving the status quo is the most desirable objective; everything considered, you believe that to be more important than removing the inequities of capitalism. In that case, you are likely to think that a book like The Communist Manifesto is preposterously false. Your main judgment will always be in terms of the ends, not the means. We have no practical interest in even the soundest means to reach ends we disapprove of or do not care about.

说服的作用

The Role of Persuasion

 

这个简短的讨论为您提供了阅读任何实用书籍时必须问自己的两个主要问题的线索。第一个是：作者的目标是什么？第二个是：他提出的实现这些目标的方法是什么？在一本关于原则的书中回答这些问题可能比在一本关于规则的书中更难。目的和手段可能不太明显。然而，在任何一种情况下回答它们对于理解和批评一本实用的书都是必要的。

This brief discussion gives you a clue to the two major questions you must ask yourself in reading any sort of practical book. The first is: What are the author’s objectives? The second is: What means for achieving them is he proposing? It may be more difficult to answer these questions in the case of a book about principles than in the case of one about rules. The ends and means are likely to be less obvious. Yet answering them in either case is necessary for the understanding and criticism of a practical book.

它还使您想起我们之前提到的实用写作的一个方面。每本实用书籍中都夹杂着雄辩或宣传。我们从来没有读过一本政治哲学书——无论它看起来多么理论化，无论它所涉及的原则多么“抽象”——没有试图说服读者相信“最好的政府形式”。同样，道德论文试图说服读者相信“美好的生活”，并推荐过这种生活的方式。我们一直试图说服你以某种方式阅读书籍，以达到你可能获得的理解。

It also reminds you of one aspect of practical writing that we noted earlier. There is an admixture of oratory or propaganda in every practical book. We have never read a book of political philosophy—however theoretical it may have appeared, however “abstract” the principles with which it dealt —that did not try to persuade the reader about “the best form of government.” Similarly, moral treatises try to persuade the reader about “the good life” as well as recommend ways of leading it. And we have tried continuously to persuade you to read books in a certain way, for the sake of the understanding that you may attain.

你会明白为什么实用的作者必须始终是演说家或宣传家。因为你对他的作品的最终判断将取决于你对他作品的接受程度 他提出的目标意味着，他要赢得你达到他的目的。要做到这一点，他必须以一种既能打动你的心又能打动你的思想的方式进行辩论。他可能不得不利用你的情绪来获得你意志的方向。

You can see why the practical author must always be something of an orator or propagandist. Since your ultimate judgment of his work is going to turn on your acceptance of the goal for which he is proposing means, it is up to him to win you to his ends. To do this, he has to argue in a way that appeals to your heart as well as your mind. He may have to play on your emotions and gain direction of your will.

这没有任何错误或恶意。必须说服人们以某种​​方式思考和行动，这是实际事务的本质。实际思考和行动都不仅仅是头脑的事情。情绪不能被排除在外。没有人在不从脖子以下以某种方式移动的情况下做出严肃的实际判断或参与行动。如果我们这样做，世界可能会变得更美好，但它肯定会是一个不同的世界。没有意识到这一点的实用书籍的作者将是无效的。他们的读者如果不这样做，很可能会在他不知情的情况下被卖掉一张货单。

There is nothing wrong or vicious about this. It is of the very nature of practical affairs that men have to be persuaded to think and act in a certain way. Neither practical thinking nor action is an affair of the mind alone. The emotions cannot be left out. No one makes serious practical judgments or engages in action without being moved somehow from below the neck. The world might be a better place if we did, but it would certainly be a different world. The writer of practical books who does not realize this will be ineffective. The reader of them who does not is likely to be sold a bill of goods without his knowing it.

防止任何形式的宣传的最好方法是认清它的本来面目。只有隐藏和不被发现的雄辩才是真正的阴险。没有经过大脑就到达心脏的东西很可能会反弹并使大脑无法正常工作。以这种方式进行的宣传就像一种你不知道自己正在吞咽的毒品。效果很神秘；事后你不知道为什么你会有这样的感觉或想法。
