The best protection against propaganda of any sort is the recognition of it for what it is. Only hidden and undetected oratory is really insidious. What reaches the heart without going through the mind is likely to bounce back and put the mind out of business. Propaganda taken in that way is like a drug you do not know you are swallowing. The effect is mysterious; you do not know afterwards why you feel or think the way you do.

聪明地阅读一本实用书籍的人，知道它的基本术语、命题和论点的人，总能发现它的言辞。他会找出“用词表达感情”的段落。意识到他必须服从劝说，他可以做一些事情来权衡上诉。他有销售阻力；但这不必是百分之一百。当销售阻力可以防止您仓促和轻率地购买时，它是好的。但是那些认为自己应该对所有呼吁完全充耳不闻的读者最好不要读实用的书。

The person who reads a practical book intelligently, who knows its basic terms, propositions, and arguments, will always be able to detect its oratory. He will spot the passages that make an “emotive use of words.” Aware that he must be subject to persuasion, he can do something about weighing the appeals. He has sales resistance; but this need not be one hundred percent. Sales resistance is good when it prevents you from buying hastily and thoughtlessly. But the reader who supposes he should be totally deaf to all appeals might just as well not read practical books.

这里还有一点。由于实际问题的性质以及所有实际写作中的演讲的混合，作者的“个性”更实用书籍比理论书籍重要。你不需要对数学论文的作者一无所知；他的推理要么好，要么不好，不管他是什么样的人。但是，为了理解和判断一篇道德论文、一篇政治文章或一篇经济讨论，你应该对作者的性格、他的生活和时代有所了解。例如，在阅读亚里士多德的《政治学》时，知道希腊社会是建立在奴隶制基础上的是非常相关的。同样，通过了解马基雅维利时代的意大利政治局势以及他与美第奇家族的关系，可以大大了解亲王；或者，就霍布斯的利维坦而言，霍布斯生活在英国内战期间，社会暴力和混乱几乎让他痛苦不堪。

There is a further point here. Because of the nature of practical problems and because of the admixture of oratory in all practical writing, the “personality” of the author is more important in the case of practical books than theoretical. You need know nothing whatever about the author of a mathematical treatise; his reasoning is either good or not, and it makes no difference what kind of man he is. But in order to understand and judge a moral treatise, a political tract, or an economic discussion, you should know something about the character of the writer, something about his life and times. In reading Aristotle’s Politics, for example, it is highly relevant to know that Greek society was based on slavery. Similarly, much light is thrown on The Prince by knowing the Italian political situation at the time of Machiavelli, and his relation to the Medicis; or, in the case of Hobbes’ Leviathan, that Hobbes lived during the English civil wars and was almost pathologically distressed by social violence and disorder.

在实用书籍的情况下，协议意味着什么？

What Does Agreement Entail in the Case of a Practical Book?

 

我们确信您可以看到，在阅读一本实用书籍的情况下，您必须问任何一本书的四个问题都会有所改变。让我们试着阐明这些变化。

We are sure that you can see that the four questions you must ask about any book are somewhat changed in the case of reading a practical book. Let us try to spell out these changes.

第一个问题，这本书讲的是什么？，变化不大。由于实用书是说明性的，所以在回答第一个问题的过程中，还是有必要勾勒一下本书的结构。

The first question, What is the book about?, does not change very much. Since a practical book is an expository one, it is still necessary, in the course of answering this first question, to make an outline of the book’s structure.

然而，虽然你必须总是试图找出（规则 4 涵盖了这一点）作者的问题是什么，但在这里，在实用书籍的情况下，这一要求成为主要要求。我们说过，你必须试着辨别作者的目标。这是另一种说法，你必须知道他试图解决什么问题。你必须知道他想做什么——因为在实际工作中，知道他想做什么归结为知道他想让你做什么。这显然非常重要。

However, although you must always try to find out (Rule 4 covers this) what an author’s problems were, here, in the case of practical books, this requirement becomes the dominant one. We have said that you must try to discern the author’s objectives. That is another way of saying you must know what problems he was trying to solve. You must know what he wanted to do—because, in the case of a practical work, knowing what he wants to do comes down to knowing what he wants you to do. And that is obviously of considerable importance.

第二个问题也没有太大变化。为了回答有关本书的含义或内容的问题，您还必须发现作者的术语、命题和论点。但这里又是该任务的最后一个方面（由规则 8 涵盖）现在显得最为重要。你会记得，规则 8 要求你说出作者解决了哪些问题，哪些没有解决。适用于实用书籍的此规则的改编已经说明。你必须发现并理解作者为实现他的建议而推荐的方法。换句话说，如果适用于实用书籍的规则 4 是“找出作者想要你做什么”，那么同样适用的规则 8 就是“找出作者如何建议你这样做”。

The second question does not change very much, either. You must still, in order to answer the question about the book’s meaning or contents, discover the author’s terms, propositions, and arguments. But here again it is the last aspect of that task (covered by Rule 8) that now looms most important. Rule 8, you will recall, required you to say which of the author’s problems he solved and which he did not. The adaptation of this rule that applies in the case of practical books has already been stated. You must discover and understand the means the author recommends for achieving what he is proposing. In other words, if Rule 4 as adapted for practical books is FIND OUT WHAT THE AUTHOR WANTS YOU TO DO, then Rule 8, as similarly adapted, is FIND OUT HOW HE PROPOSES THAT YOU DO THIS.

第三个问题，Is it true?，比前两个问题有所改变。如果是一本理论书，当你将作者对世界上正在发生的事情的描述和解释与你自己的知识进行比较时，问题就得到了回答。如果这本书大体上符合你自己对事物现状的体验，那么你必须至少部分承认它的真实性。如果是一本实用的书，虽然会有一些书与现实的比较，但主要考虑的是作者的目标——即他所寻求的目的，以及他提出的达到目的的手段——是否符合现实。您对寻求什么是正确的以及寻求它的最佳方式的看法。

The third question, Is it true?, is changed somewhat more than the first two. In the case of a theoretical book, the question is answered when you have compared the author’s description and explanation of what is or happens in the world with your own knowledge thereof. If the book accords generally with your own experience of the way things are, then you must concede its truthfulness, at least in part. In the case of a practical book, although there is some such comparison of the book and reality, the main consideration is whether the author’s objectives—that is, the ends that he seeks, together with the means he proposes to reach them—accord with your conception of what it is right to seek, and of what is the best way of seeking it.

第四个问题，What of it?，变化最大。如果在读完一本理论书籍后，你对它的主题的看法或多或少地发生了变化，那么你就需要对你对事物的总体看法进行一些调整。（如果不需要调整，那么你不可能从这本书中学到很多，如果有的话。）但这些调整不一定是翻天覆地的，最重要的是，它们并不一定意味着你要采取行动。

The fourth question, What of it?, is changed most of all. If, after reading a theoretical book, your view of its subject matter is altered more or less, then you are required to make some adjustments in your general view of things. (If no adjustments are called for, then you cannot have learned much, if anything, from the book.) But these adjustments need not be earth-shaking, and above all they do not necessarily imply action on your part.

然而，同意一本实用的书确实意味着你要采取行动。如果你被作者说服或说服他所提出的目标是值得的，如果你进一步相信或说服他所推荐的方法可能达到这些目的，那么你就很难拒绝采取行动作者希望你这样做的方式。

Agreement with a practical book, however, does imply action on your part. If you are convinced or persuaded by the author that the ends he proposes are worthy, and if you are further convinced or persuaded that the means he recommends are likely to achieve those ends, then it is hard to see how you can refuse to act in the way the author wishes you to.

当然，我们承认这并不总是会发生。但我们希望您了解它在不存在时的含义。这意味着尽管他表面上同意作者的目的并接受他的手段，但读者实际上并不同意或接受。如果他两者都做了，他就不可能不采取行动。

We recognize, of course, that this does not always happen. But we want you to realize what it means when it does not. It means that despite his apparent agreement with the author’s ends and acceptance of his means, the reader really does not agree or accept. If he did both, he could not reasonably fail to act.

让我们举例说明我们的意思。如果在读完本书的第二部分后，你（1）同意分析式阅读是值得的，并且（2）接受阅读规则从本质上支持这一目标，那么你一定已经开始尝试以我们的方式阅读有描述。如果你没有，那不仅仅是因为你懒惰或累了。这是因为您并不是真正的意思 (1) 或 (2)。

Let us give an example of what we mean. If, after completing Part Two of this book, you (1) agreed that reading analytically is worthwhile, and (2) accepted the rules of reading as essentially supportive of that aim, then you must have begun to try to read in the manner we have described. If you did not, it is not just because you were lazy or tired. It is because you did not really mean either (1) or (2).

这一论点有一个明显的例外。例如，假设您阅读了一篇关于如何制作巧克力慕斯的文章。你喜欢巧克力慕斯，所以你同意文章作者的看法，结局是好的。您还接受作者提出的达到目的的方法——他的秘诀。但你是一个从不下厨房的男性读者，所以你不会做慕斯。这是否使我们的观点无效？

There is one apparent exception to this contention. Suppose, for example, that you read an article about how to make a chocolate mousse. You like chocolate mousse, and so you agree with the author of the article that the end in view is good. You also accept the author’s proposed means for attaining the end—his recipe. But you are a male reader who never goes into the kitchen, and so you do not make a mousse. Does this invalidate our point?

它没有，尽管它确实表明了应该提及的实用书籍类型之间的重要区别。就此类作品的作者提出的目标而言，这些目标有时是普遍的或普遍的——适用于所有人类——有时仅适用于人类的某一部分。如果目的是普遍的——例如本书就是这样，它认为所有人都应该阅读得更好，而不仅仅是某些人——那么本节讨论的含义适用于所有读者。如果目的是有选择的，只适用于某一类人，那么读者必须决定他是否属于那个类别。如果他这样做了，那么暗示适用于他，他或多或少有义务按照作者指定的方式行事。如果他不这样做，那么他可能没有那么大的义务。

It does not, although it does indicate an important distinction between types of practical books that should be mentioned. With regard to the ends proposed by the authors of such works, these are sometimes general or universal—applicable to all human beings—and sometimes applicable only to a certain portion of human beings. If the end is universal—as it is, for example, with this book, which maintains that all persons should read better, not just some—then the implication discussed in this section applies to every reader. If the end is selective, applying only to a certain class of human beings, then the reader must decide whether or not he belongs to that class. If he does, then the implication applies to him, and he is more or less obligated to act in the ways specified by the author. If he does not, then he may not be so obligated.

我们说“可能不那么有义务”，因为读者很可能在自欺欺人，或者误解了自己的动机，决定他不属于与目的相关的类别。就巧克力慕斯文章的读者而言，他可能是在无所事事地表达自己的观点，即虽然慕斯固然美味，但其他人——也许是他的妻子——应该是制作它的人。在许多情况下，我们承认目的的可取性和手段的可行性，但以某种方式表达了我们不愿意自己执行该操作。我们或多或少明确地说，让别人来做吧。

We say “may not be so obligated” because there is a strong possibility that the reader may be fooling himself, or misunderstanding his own motives, in deciding that he does not belong to the class to which the end is relevant. In the case of the reader of the article about chocolate mousse, he is probably, by his inaction, expressing his view that, although mousse is admittedly delicious, someone else—perhaps his wife—should be the one to make it. And in many cases, we concede the desirability of an end and the feasibility of the means, but in one way or another express our reluctance to perform the action ourselves. Let someone else do it, we say, more or less explicitly.

当然，这主要不是阅读问题，而是心理问题。然而，心理事实与我们阅读实用书籍的效率有关，因此我们在这里讨论了这个问题。

This, of course, is not primarily a reading problem but rather a psychological one. Nevertheless, the psychological fact has bearing on how effectively we read a practical book, and so we have discussed the matter here.

14

如何阅读富有想象力的文学作品

14HOW TO READ IMAGINATIVE LITERATURE

 

到目前为止，这本书只涉及大多数人阅读的一半。即使这样的估计也过于宽松。可能任何人的大部分阅读时间都花在了报纸和杂志上，以及与工作有关的必须阅读的东西上。就书籍而言，我们大多数人阅读的小说多于非小说类书籍。此外，在非小说类书籍中，最受欢迎的是那些像报纸和杂志一样以新闻方式处理当代热点问题的书籍。

So far, this book has been concerned with only half the reading that most people do. Even that is too liberal an estimate. Probably the greater part of anybody’s reading time is spent on newspapers and magazines, and on things that have to be read in connection with one’s job. And so far as books are concerned, most of us read more fiction than nonfiction. Furthermore, of the nonfiction books, the most popular are those that, like newspapers and magazines, deal journalistically with matters of contemporary interest.

关于前面章节中规定的规则，我们没有欺骗您。在着手详细讨论它们之前，我们解释说我们必须将自己限制在阅读严肃的非小说类书籍上。同时阐述阅读想象力和说明性文学的规则会让人感到困惑。但是现在我们不能再忽视其他类型的阅读了。

We have not deceived you about the rules set forth in the preceding chapters. Before undertaking to discuss them in detail, we explained that we would have to limit ourselves to the business of reading serious nonfiction books. To have expounded the rules for reading imaginative and expository literature at the same time would have been confusing. But now we cannot ignore the other types of reading any longer.

在开始这项任务之前，我们想强调一个相当奇怪的悖论。知道如何阅读富有想象力的文学作品的问题本质上比知道如何阅读说明性书籍的问题要困难得多。然而，事实似乎是，这种技能比阅读科学和哲学、政治、经济和历史的艺术更为广泛。这怎么可能是真的？

Before embarking on the task, we want to emphasize one rather strange paradox. The problem of knowing how to read imaginative literature is inherently much more difficult than the problem of knowing how to read expository books. Nevertheless, it seems to be a fact that such skill is more widely possessed than the art of reading science and philosophy, politics, economics, and history. How can this be true?

当然，这可能是人们自欺欺人地相信自己阅读小说的能力。根据我们的教学经验，我们知道当被要求说出他们喜欢一部小说的哪些方面时，人们会变得舌头打结。他们很清楚自己很喜欢这本书，但他们无法过多地描述自己的享受，也无法说出这本书中包含哪些内容让他们感到高兴。这可能表明人们可以成为优秀的小说读者而不是优秀的评论家。我们怀疑这充其量只是半真半假。对任何事物的批判性阅读都取决于一个人的理解是否充分。那些不能说出自己喜欢一本小说的人可能没有在最明显的表面下阅读过它。然而，悖论远不止于此。富有想象力的文学主要是取悦而不是教导。为什么一个人高兴。美比真理更难分析。

It may be, of course, that people deceive themselves about their ability to read novels intelligently. From our teaching experience, we know how tongue-tied people become when asked to say what they liked about a novel. That they enjoyed it is perfectly clear to them, but they cannot give much of an account of their enjoyment or tell what the book contained that caused them pleasure. This might indicate that people can be good readers of fiction without being good critics. We suspect this is, at best, a half-truth. A critical reading of anything depends upon the fullness of one’s apprehension. Those who cannot say what they like about a novel probably have not read it below its most obvious surfaces. However, there is more to the paradox than that. Imaginative literature primarily pleases rather than teaches. It is much easier to be pleased than taught, but much harder to know why one is pleased. Beauty is harder to analyze than truth.

要弄清楚这一点，需要对审美欣赏进行广泛的分析。我们不能在这里进行。然而，我们可以给你一些关于如何阅读富有想象力的文学作品的建议。我们将首先以否定的方式进行，陈述明显的“不应该”而不是建设性的规则。接下来，我们将通过类比的方式进行，将阅读非小说类的规则简要地翻译成阅读小说的等价物。最后，在下一章中，我们将着手研究阅读特定类型的想象文学的问题，即小说、戏剧和抒情诗。

To make this point clear would require an extensive analysis of esthetic appreciation. We cannot undertake that here. We can, however, give you some advice about how to read imaginative literature. We will proceed, first, by the way of negation, stating the obvious “don’ts” instead of the constructive rules. Next, we will proceed by the way of analogy, briefly translating the rules for reading nonfiction into their equivalents for reading fiction. Finally, in the next chapter, we will proceed to examine the problems of reading specific types of imaginative literature, namely, novels, plays, and lyric poems.

如何不阅读想象文学

How Not to Read Imaginative Literature

 

要想从否定的方式入手，首先必须把握说明文学与想象文学的基本区别。这些差异将解释为什么我们不能把小说当作哲学论证来阅读，或者将抒情诗当作数学证明来阅读。

In order to proceed by the way of negation, it is first of all necessary to grasp the basic differences between expository and imaginative literature. These differences will explain why we cannot read a novel as if it were a philosophical argument, or a lyric as if it were a mathematical demonstration.

已经提到的最明显的区别与两种写作的目的有关。说明性书籍试图传达知识——关于读者已经拥有或可能拥有的经历的知识。富有想象力的人试图传达一种体验本身——读者只有通过阅读才能拥有或分享的体验——如果他们成功了，他们就会给读者一些可以享受的东西。由于其不同的意图，这两种工作对智力和想象力的吸引力不同。

The most obvious difference, already mentioned, relates to the purposes of the two kinds of writing. Expository books try to convey knowledge— knowledge about experiences that the reader has had or could have. Imaginative ones try to communicate an experience itself— one that the reader can have or share only by reading—and if they succeed, they give the reader something to be enjoyed. Because of their diverse intentions, the two sorts of work appeal differently to the intellect and the imagination.

我们通过运用我们的感官和想象力来体验事物。要想知道任何事情，我们都必须运用我们的判断力和推理力，这是理智的。这并不意味着我们可以不使用我们的想象力来思考，或者说感官体验完全脱离了理性的洞察力或反思。这件事只是重点之一。小说主要吸引想象力。这就是将其称为富有想象力的文学的原因之一，与知识分子的科学和哲学形成对比。

We experience things through the exercise of our senses and imagination. To know anything we must use our powers of judgment and reasoning, which are intellectual. This does not mean that we can think without using our imagination, or that sense experience is ever wholly divorced from rational insight or reflection. The matter is only one of emphasis. Fiction appeals primarily to the imagination. That is one reason for calling it imaginative literature, in contrast to science and philosophy which are intellectual.

关于想象力文学的这一事实导致了我们想要提出的可能是最重要的负面禁令。不要试图抗拒富有想象力的文学作品对你的影响。

This fact about imaginative literature leads to what is probably the most important of the negative injunctions we want to suggest. Don’t try to resist the effect that a work of imaginative literature has on you.

我们已经详细讨论了积极阅读的重要性。所有书籍都是如此，但在说明性作品和诗歌中却以完全不同的方式出现。前者的读者应该像一只猛禽，时刻保持警惕，时刻准备着猛扑。适合阅读诗歌和小说的那种活动是不一样的。这是一种被动的行为，如果我们可以表达，或者更好的是，积极的热情的话。在阅读故事时，我们必须以这样的方式行动，让它对我们起作用。我们必须让它感动我们，我们必须让它做它想对我们做的任何工作。我们必须以某种方式让自己对它敞开心扉。

We have discussed at length the importance of reading actively. This is true of all books, but it is true in quite different ways of expository works and of poetry. The reader of the former should be like a bird of prey, constantly alert, always ready to pounce. The kind of activity that is appropriate in reading poetry and fiction is not the same. It is a sort of passive action, if we may be allowed the expression, or, better, active passion. We must act in such a way, when reading a story, that we let it act on us. We must allow it to move us, we must let it do whatever work it wants to do on us. We must somehow make ourselves open to it.

我们很大程度上要归功于解释性文学——哲学、科学、数学——它们塑造了我们生活的现实世界。但如果我们不这样做，我们就无法生活在这个世界上能够不时地摆脱它。我们并不是说富有想象力的文学总是或本质上是逃避现实的。在这个词的通常意义上，这个想法是可鄙的。如果我们必须逃避现实，那应该是更深层次或更大的现实。这是我们内心生活的现实，是我们对世界的独特看法。发现这个现实使我们快乐；这种体验让我们自己通常不会触及的某些部分深感满足。无论如何，阅读一部伟大的文学艺术作品的规则应该以这种深刻的体验为目的或目标。规则应该清除所有阻止我们尽可能深入感受的因素。

We owe much to the expository literature—the philosophy, science, mathematics—that has shaped the real world in which we live. But we could not live in this world if we were not able, from time to time, to get away from it. We do not mean that imaginative literature is always, or essentially, escapist. In the ordinary sense of that term, the idea is contemptible. If we must escape from reality, it should be to a deeper, or greater, reality. This is the reality of our inner life, of our own unique vision of the world. To discover this reality makes us happy; the experience is deeply satisfying to some part of ourselves we do not ordinarily touch. In any event, the rules of reading a great work of literary art should have as an end or goal just such a profound experience. The rules should clear away all that stops us from feeling as deeply as we possibly can.

说明文学和想象文学之间的基本区别导致了另一个区别。由于其根本不同的目标，这两种写作必然会使用不同的语言。富有想象力的作家试图最大限度地利用词语的潜在歧义，从而获得其多重含义中固有的所有丰富性和力量。他使用隐喻作为他的结构的单位，就像逻辑作家使用锐化为单一含义的词语一样。但丁对神曲的评价，它必须被理解为具有几个不同但相关的含义，通常适用于诗歌和小说。说明文的逻辑旨在明确明确的理想。两行之间不应留下任何内容。一切相关和可陈述的内容都应尽可能明确和清楚地说明。相比之下，富有想象力的写作既依赖于暗示的内容，也依赖于所说的内容。比喻的倍增在字里行间添加的内容几乎比构成字里行间的内容还要多。整首诗或故事说的是它的文字没有说或不能说的话。

The basic difference between expository and imaginative literature leads to another difference. Because of their radically diverse aims, these two kinds of writing necessarily use language differently. The imaginative writer tries to maximize the latent ambiguities of words, in order thereby to gain all the richness and force that is inherent in their multiple meanings. He uses metaphors as the units of his construction just as the logical writer uses words sharpened to a single meaning. What Dante said of The Divine Comedy, that it must be read as having several distinct though related meanings, generally applies to poetry and fiction. The logic of expository writing aims at an ideal of unambiguous explicitness. Nothing should be left between the lines. Everything that is relevant and statable should be said as explicitly and clearly as possible. In contrast, imaginative writing relies as much upon what is implied as upon what is said. The multiplication of metaphors puts almost more content between the lines than in the words that compose them. The whole poem or story says something that none of its words say or can say.

从这个事实我们得到另一个否定禁令。不要在富有想象力的文学作品中寻找术语、命题和论据。这些事情是合乎逻辑的，而不是诗意的，设备。“在诗歌和戏剧中，”诗人马克·范·多伦 (Mark Van Doren) 曾评论道，“陈述是一种模糊的媒介。” 什么例如，抒情诗“状态”在它的任何句子中都找不到。整体，包括所有词语之间的关系和对彼此的反应，说了一些永远不能局限于命题紧身衣中的东西。（然而，想象文学包含类似于术语、命题和论证的元素，我们稍后将讨论它们。）

From this fact we obtain another negative injunction. Don’t look for terms, propositions, and arguments in imaginative literature. Such things are logical, not poetic, devices. “In poetry and in drama,” the poet Mark Van Doren once observed, “statement is one of the obscurer mediums.” What a lyric poem “states,” for instance, cannot be found in any of its sentences. And the whole, comprising all its words in their relations to and reactions upon each other, says something that can never be confined within the straitjacket of propositions. (However, imaginative literature contains elements that are analogous to terms, propositions, and arguments, and we will discuss them in a moment.)

当然，我们可以从富有想象力的文学、诗歌和故事，尤其是戏剧中学习——但与我们从科学和哲学书籍中学习的方式不同。我们从经验中学习——我们在日常生活中的经验。因此，我们也可以从小说在我们的想象中产生的替代或艺术创造的体验中学习。从这个意义上说，诗歌和故事既能教人又能取悦人。但是科学和哲学教给我们的意义是不同的。说明性作品不会为我们提供新奇的体验。他们评论我们已经拥有或可以获得的体验。这就是为什么说说明性书籍主要是教学，而富有想象力的书籍只是衍生性教学，即通过创造我们可以从中学习的经验来进行教学似乎是正确的。为了从这些书中学习，我们必须对经验进行自己的思考；为了向科学家和哲学家学习，我们必须首先尝试理解他们所做的思考。

Of course, we can learn from imaginative literature, from poems and stories and especially, perhaps, plays—but not in the same way as we are taught by scientific and philosophical books. We learn from experience—the experience that we have in the course of our daily lives. So, too, we can learn from the vicarious, or artistically created, experiences that fiction produces in our imagination. In this sense, poems and stories teach as well as please. But the sense in which science and philosophy teach us is different. Expository works do not provide us with novel experiences. They comment on such experiences as we already have or can get. That is why it seems right to say that expository books teach primarily, while imaginative books teach only derivatively, by creating experiences from which we can learn. In order to learn from such books, we have to do our own thinking about experience; in order to learn from scientists and philosophers, we must first try to understand the thinking they have done.

最后，最后一条否定规则。不要以正确适用于知识交流的真实性和一致性标准来批评小说。一个好故事的“真实性”是它的真实性，它的内在概率或似是而非。它必须是一个可能的故事，但它不需要以可通过实验或研究验证的方式描述生活或社会的事实。几个世纪前，亚里士多德曾说过“诗歌中的正确性标准与政治中的正确性标准不同”，或者在物理学或心理学中。关于解剖学的技术错误或地理或历史上的错误应该受到批评，因为它们出现的书本身是关于这些主题的论文。但事实的错误陈述不会损害一个故事，如果它的出纳员成功地围绕着他们的话。当我们阅读历史时，我们想要某种意义上的真相，如果我们没有得到真相，我们有权抱怨。当我们阅读一本小说时，我们想要的故事必须是真实的，只有在小说家创造的人物和事件的世界中可能发生，并在我们身上重新创造的意义上，它才可能是真实的。

Finally, one last negative rule. Don’t criticize fiction by the standards of truth and consistency that properly apply to communication of knowledge. The “truth” of a good story is its verisimilitude, its intrinsic probability or plausibility. It must be a likely story, but it need not describe the facts of life or society in a manner that is verifiable by experiment or research. Centuries ago, Aristotle remarked that “the standard of correctness is not the same in poetry as in politics,” or in physics or psychology for that matter. Technical inaccuracies about anatomy or errors in geography or history should be criticized when the book in which they occur offers itself as a treatise on those subjects. But misstatements of fact do not mar a story if its teller succeeds in surrounding them with plausibility. When we read history, we want the truth in some sense, and we have a right to complain if we do not get it. When we read a novel we want a story that must be true only in the sense that it could have happened in the world of characters and events that the novelist has created, and re-created in us.

一旦我们阅读并理解了一本哲学书，我们将如何处理它？我们测试它——根据作为它最初灵感的共同经验，这是它存在的唯一借口。我们说，这是真的吗？我们感受到了吗？我们是否一直这样想而不自知？现在这很明显吗，尽管以前不明显？尽管作者的理论或解释可能很复杂，但它是否真的比我们之前对这个主题的混乱想法和观点更简单？

What do we do with a philosophical book, once we have read it and understood it? We test it—against the common experience that was its original inspiration, and that is its only excuse for being. We say, is this true? Have we felt this? Have we always thought this without realizing it? Is this obvious now, though it was not previously? Complicated as the author’s theory or explanation may be, is it actually simpler than the chaotic ideas and opinions we had about this subject before?

如果我们可以肯定地回答这些问题中的大部分，那么我们就会受到我们自己和作者之间的理解共同体的约束。当我们理解并且不反对时，我们必须说：“这是我们对这件事的常识。我们测试了你的理论，发现它是正确的。”

If we can answer most of these questions in the affirmative, then we are bound by the community of understanding that is between ourselves and the author. When we understand and do not disagree, we must say, “This is our common sense of the matter. We have tested your theory and found it correct.”

诗歌不是这样。例如，我们不能根据自己的经验来检验奥赛罗，除非我们也是摩尔人，并且嫁给了我们怀疑有背叛行为的威尼斯女士。但即便如此，奥赛罗也不是每个摩尔人，苔丝狄蒙娜也不是每个威尼斯女士；大多数这样的夫妻都幸运地不认识伊阿古。事实上，除了一个人之外，所有人都会如此幸运；奥赛罗，无论是人物还是戏剧，都是独一无二的。

Not so with poetry. We cannot test Othello, say, against our own experience, unless we too are Moors and wedded to Venetian ladies whom we suspect of treachery. But even if this were so, Othello is not every Moor, and Desdemona is not every Venetian lady; and most such couples would have the good fortune not to know an Iago. In fact, all but one would be so fortunate; Othello, the character as well as the play, is unique.

阅读想象文学的一般规则

General Rules for Reading Imaginative Literature

 

为了使上一节中讨论的“不要做的事”更有帮助，必须辅之以建设性的建议。这些建议可以从阅读说明性作品的规则中类推得出。

To make the “don’ts” discussed in the last section more helpful, they must be supplemented by constructive suggestions. These suggestions can be developed by analogy from the rules of reading expository works.

正如我们所见，有三组这样的规则。第一组包括发现统一和部分-整体结构的规则；第二部分包括识别和解释本书的组成术语、命题和论点的规则；第三部分包括批评作者学说的规则，以便我们可以明智地同意或反对他。我们将这三组规则称为结构性、解释性和批判性。以此类推，我们可以找到类似的规则来指导我们阅读诗歌、小说和戏剧。

There are, as we have seen, three groups of such rules. The first group consists of rules for discovering the unity and part-whole structure; the second consists of rules for identifying and interpreting the book’s component terms, propositions, and arguments; the third consists of rules for criticizing the author’s doctrine so that we can reach intelligent agreement or disagreement with him. We called these three groups of rules structural, interpretive, and critical. By analogy, we can find similar sets of rules to guide us in reading poems, novels, and plays.

首先，我们可以将结构规则——大纲规则——翻译成它们虚构的类似物，如下所示。

First, we can translate the structural rules—the rules of outlining—into their fictional analogues as follows.

(1) 你必须根据其种类对想象文学作品进行分类。歌词主要根据单一的情感体验来讲述故事，而小说和戏剧的情节要复杂得多，涉及许多人物、他们的行为和他们对彼此的反应，以及他们在这个过程中所遭受的情感。此外，每个人都知道，戏剧与小说的不同之处在于它完全通过动作和言语来叙述。（对此有一些有趣的例外，我们稍后会提到。）剧作家永远不能像小说家那样，并且经常在小说的过程中以自己的身份说话。所有这些写作方式上的差异都会引起读者接受能力的差异。因此，您应该立即识别您正在阅读的小说类型。

(1) You must classify a work of imaginative literature according to its kind. A lyric tells its story primarily in terms of a single emotional experience, whereas novels and plays have much more complicated plots, involving many characters, their actions and their reactions upon one another, as well as the emotions they suffer in the process. Everyone knows, furthermore, that a play differs from a novel by reason of the fact that it narrates entirely by means of actions and speeches. (There are some interesting exceptions to this, which we will mention later.) The playwright can never speak in his own person, as the novelist can, and frequently does, in the course of a novel. All of these differences in manner of writing call for differences in the reader’s receptivity. Therefore, you should recognize at once the kind of fiction you are reading.

（二）要把握整个工作的统一性。你是否做到了这一点，可以通过你是否能够用一两句话表达那种团结来检验。说明性作品的统一性最终在于它试图解决的主要问题。因此，它的统一性可以通过这个问题的表述，或者通过回答它的命题来说明。虚构的统一性也与作者所面临的问题有关，但我们看到，那个问题是试图传达具体的经验，所以故事的统一性总是在情节上。你还没有掌握全部故事直到你能用简短的叙述来总结它的情节——而不是一个命题或一个论点。它的统一性就在于此。

(2) You must grasp the unity of the whole work. Whether you have done this or not can be tested by whether you are able to express that unity in a sentence or two. The unity of an expository work resides ultimately in the main problem that it tries to solve. Hence its unity can be stated by the formulation of this question, or by the propositions that answer it. The unity of fiction is also connected with the problem the author has faced, but we have seen that that problem is the attempt to convey a concrete experience, and so the unity of a story is always in its plot. You have not grasped the whole story until you can summarize its plot in a brief narration—not a proposition or an argument. Therein lies its unity.

请注意，我们刚才所说的情节的统一性与我们所说的虚构作品语言的独特性之间并没有真正的矛盾。就我们在​​这里使用的术语而言，即使是歌词也有一个“情节”。但是情节并不是作品在读者心中重新创造的具体体验，无论是抒情的、戏剧的还是小说的；它只是它的框架，或者可能是它的场合。它代表着作品的统一性，这种统一性恰如其分地存在于经验本身中，就像一部说明性作品意义的逻辑总结代表了整体的论证一样。

Note that there is no real contradiction here between what we have just said about the unity of plot and what we said about the uniqueness of the language of a fictional work. Even a lyric has a “plot” in the sense in which we are using the term here. But the plot is not the concrete experience that is re-created in the reader by the work, be it lyric, play, or novel; it is only the framework of it, or perhaps the occasion of it. It stands for the unity of the work, which is properly in the experience itself, just as the logical summation of the meaning of an expository work stands for the argument of the whole.

(3) 你不仅必须将整体简化为最简单的整体，而且你还必须发现整体是如何由其所有部分构成的。说明性书籍的各个部分与整个问题的各个部分有关，部分解决方案有助于解决整体问题。小说的各个部分是作者展开情节所采取的不同步骤——人物塑造和事件的细节。在这两种情况下，零件的排列方式不同。在科学和哲学中，它们必须按逻辑排列。在一个故事中，各个部分必须以某种方式符合时间安排，即从开始到中间再到结尾的过程。要了解叙述的结构，您必须知道它从哪里开始——当然不一定在第一页——它经历了什么，以及它从哪里出来。你必须知道导致高潮的各种危机，高潮发生的地点和方式，以及之后会发生什么。（我们所说的“后果”并不是指故事结束后发生的事情。没有人知道这一点。我们指的只是故事中高潮发生后发生的事情。）

(3) You must not only reduce the whole to its simplest unity, but you must also discover how that whole is constructed out of all its parts. The parts of an expository book are concerned with parts of the whole problem, the partial solutions contributing to the solution of the whole. The parts of fiction are the various steps that the author takes to develop his plot—the details of characterization and incident. The way in which the parts are arranged differs in the two cases. In science and philosophy, they must be ordered logically. In a story, the parts must somehow fit into a temporal scheme, a progress from a beginning through the middle to its end. To know the structure of a narrative, you must know where it begins—which is not necessarily on the first page, of course—what it goes through, and where it comes out at. You must know the various crises that lead up to the climax, where and how the climax occurs, and what happens in the aftermath. (By “aftermath” we do not mean what happens after the story is over. Nobody can know that. We mean only what happens, within the narrative, after the climax has occurred.)

从我们刚才提出的观点可以得出一个重要的结论。说明性书籍的部分或子整体比小说的部分更容易独立阅读。欧几里德出版了他的几何原本，分为十三部分，或者他称之为书籍，其中第一部分可以阅读本身。每本组织良好的说明性书籍或多或少都是这种情况。它的部分或章节，单独或分组，是有意义的。但是，当从整体中抽离出来时，小说的章节、戏剧的行为或歌词的诗句往往变得相对毫无意义。

An important consequence follows from the points we have just made. The parts or sub-wholes of an expository book are more likely to be independently readable than the parts of fiction. Euclid published his Elements in thirteen parts, or books, as he called them, and the first of them can be read by itself. That is more or less the case with every well-organized expository book. Its sections or chapters, taken separately or in subgroups, make sense. But the chapters of a novel, the acts of a play, or the verses of a lyric often become relatively meaningless when wrenched from the whole.

第二，阅读小说的解读规则是什么？我们事先考虑了语言的诗意用法和逻辑用法之间的区别，这使我们准备好翻译指导我们找到术语、命题和论点的规则。我们知道我们不应该那样做，但我们必须做类似的事情。

Second, what are the interpretive rules for reading fiction? Our prior consideration of the difference between a poetic and a logical use of language prepares us to make a translation of the rules that direct us to find the terms, the propositions, and the arguments. We know we should not do that, but we must do something analogous to it.

(1) 小说的要素是情节和事件、人物以及他们的思想、言论、感受和行动。每一个都是作者创造的世界中的一个元素。通过操纵这些元素，作者讲述了他的故事。它们就像逻辑话语中的术语。正如你必须与说明文作家达成协议一样，在这里你必须熟悉事件和人物刻画的细节。除非你熟悉故事中的人物，直到你经历了故事中的事件，你才算是理解了一个故事。

(1) The elements of fiction are its episodes and incidents, its characters, and their thoughts, speeches, feelings, and actions. Each of these is an element in the world the author creates. By manipulating these elements, the author tells his story. They are like the terms in logical discourse. Just as you must come to terms with an expository writer, so here you must become acquainted with the details of incident and characterization. You have not grasped a story until you are familiar with its characters, until you have lived through its events.

(2) 命题中的词项相连。虚构的元素由整个场景或背景联系在一起，它们在浮雕中脱颖而出。我们已经看到，富有想象力的作家创造了一个世界，在这个世界中，他的人物“生活、移动并拥有他们的存在”。因此，引导您找到作者命题的规则的虚构类比可以表述如下：在这个想象的世界中变得自在；就好像你是现场的观察者一样了解它；成为它的人口中的一员，愿意与它的角色交朋友，并且能够通过同情的洞察力参与它的发生，就像你在朋友的行为和痛苦中所做的那样。如果你能做到这一点，小说的元素将不再是棋盘上机械地移动的孤立棋子。

(2) Terms are connected in propositions. The elements of fiction are connected by the total scene or background against which they stand out in relief. The imaginative writer, we have seen, creates a world in which his characters “live, move, and have their being.” The fictional analogue of the rule that directs you to find the author’s propositions can, therefore, be stated as follows: become at home in this imaginary world; know it as if you were an observer on the scene; become a member of its population, willing to befriend its characters, and able to participate in its happenings by sympathetic insight, as you would do in the actions and sufferings of a friend. If you can do this, the elements of fiction will cease to be so many isolated pawns moved about mechanically on a chessboard. You will have found the connections that vitalize them into members of a living society.

(3) 如果说明书中有动议，则为论证的运动，从证据和理由到他们支持的结论的逻辑过渡。在阅读此类书籍时，必须遵循论点。因此，在你发现它的术语和命题之后，你被要求分析它的推理。在小说的解释性阅读中有一个类似的最后一步。你已经熟悉了角色。你已经加入了他们居住的想象世界，同意他们社会的法律，呼吸它的空气，品尝它的食物，在它的高速公路上行驶。现在你必须跟随他们经历他们的冒险。场景或背景，社会环境，（如命题）是一种静态的小说元素的联系。情节的展开（如论证或推理）是动态联系。亚里士多德说，情节是故事的灵魂。这是它的生命。要想读好一个故事，你必须把手指放在叙述的脉搏上，对它的节拍保持敏感。

(3) If there is any motion in an expository book, it is the movement of the argument, a logical transition from evidences and reasons to the conclusions they support. In the reading of such books, it is necessary to follow the argument. Hence, after you have discovered its terms and propositions, you are called upon to analyze its reasoning. There is an analogous last step in the interpretive reading of fiction. You have become acquainted with the characters. You have joined them in the imaginary world wherein they dwell, consented to the laws of their society, breathed its air, tasted its food, traveled its highways. Now you must follow them through their adventures. The scene or background, the social setting, is (like the proposition) a kind of static connection of the elements of fiction. The unraveling of the plot (like the arguments or reasoning) is the dynamic connection. Aristotle said that plot is the soul of a story. It is its life. To read a story well you must have your finger on the pulse of the narrative, be sensitive to its very beat.

在将这些虚构的等价物留给阅读的解释规则之前，我们必须提醒您不要过于仔细地检查类比。这种类比就像一个比喻，如果你用力过猛，它就会瓦解。我们建议的三个步骤概述了人们逐渐意识到一位富有想象力的作家的艺术成就的方式。它们绝不会破坏您对小说或戏剧的享受，它们应该能让您通过深入了解快乐的来源来丰富您的快乐。你不仅会知道自己喜欢什么，还会知道为什么喜欢它。

Before leaving these fictional equivalents for the interpretive rules of reading, we must caution you not to examine the analogy too closely. An analogy of this sort is like a metaphor that will disintegrate if you press it too hard. The three steps we have suggested outline the way in which one becomes progressively aware of the artistic achievement of an imaginative writer. Far from spoiling your enjoyment of a novel or play, they should enable you to enrich your pleasure by knowing intimately the sources of your delight. You will not only know what you like but also why you like it.

另一个警告：上述规则主要适用于小说和戏剧。就抒情诗有一些叙事线而言，它们也适用于歌词。但这些规则并没有停止适用于非叙事歌词，尽管这种联系远没有那么紧密。歌词是具体体验的表现，就像一个长篇故事，它试图在读者中重新创造那种体验。即使是最短的歌词也有开头、中间和结尾，就像任何经历中都有时间顺序一样，无论多么短暂和转瞬即逝。尽管在一首简短的歌词中，人物角色可能很少，但总是至少有一个人物——即这首诗的说话者。

One other caution: the foregoing rules apply mainly to novels and plays. To the extent that lyric poems have some narrative line, they apply to lyrics also. But the rules do not cease to apply to non-narrative lyrics, although the connection is much less close. A lyric is the representation of a concrete experience, just like a long story, and it attempts to re-create that experience in the reader. There is a beginning, middle, and end of even the shortest lyric, just as there is a temporal sequence in any experience, no matter how brief and fleeting. And though the cast of characters may be very small in a short lyric, there is always at least one character—namely, the speaker of the poem.

第三，也是最后一点，阅读小说的关键规则是什么？你可能还记得，在说明性作品的情况下，我们区分了管理批评的一般准则和一些特定的要点——具体的批评评论。关于一般格言，可以通过一种翻译充分地得出类比。就说明性作品而言，建议是不要批评一本书——不要说你同意或不同意——直到你能先说你理解，所以这里的格言是：在你完全理解之前不要批评富有想象力的写作作者试图让你体验到什么。

Third, and last, what are the critical rules for reading fiction? You may remember that we distinguished, in the case of expository works, between the general maxims governing criticism and a number of particular points—specific critical remarks. With respect to the general maxims, the analogy can be sufficiently drawn by one translation. Where, in the case of expository works, the advice was not to criticize a book—not to say you agree or disagree—until you can first say you understand, so here the maxim is: don’t criticize imaginative writing until you fully appreciate what the author has tried to make you experience.

这有一个重要的推论。一个故事的好读者不会质疑作者创造的世界——在他身上重新创造的世界。“我们必须赋予艺术家他的主题、他的想法、他的女主人，”亨利·詹姆斯在小说的艺术中说；“我们的批评只针对他的看法。” 也就是说，我们必须仅仅欣赏这样一个事实，即作家将他的故事设定在巴黎，而不是反对将其设定在明尼阿波利斯会更好；但我们有权批评他对他的巴黎人和这座城市本身所做的事情。

There is an important corollary to this. The good reader of a story does not question the world that the author creates—the world that is re-created in himself. “We must grant the artist his subject, his idea, his donné,” said Henry James in The Art of Fiction;“our criticism is applied only to what he makes of it.” That is, we must merely appreciate the fact that a writer sets his story in, say, Paris, and not object that it would have been better to set it in Minneapolis; but we have a right to criticize what he does with his Parisians and with the city itself.

换句话说，我们必须记住一个明显的事实，即我们不同意或不同意小说。我们要么喜欢，要么不喜欢。我们对说明性书籍的批评判断关注的是它们的真实性，而在批评 belles-letres 时，正如这个词本身所暗示的那样，我们主要考虑的是它们的美。任何艺术作品的美都与我们熟知它时带给我们的愉悦有关。

In other words, we must remember the obvious fact that we do not agree or disagree with fiction. We either like it or we do not. Our critical judgment in the case of expository books concerns their truth, whereas in criticizing belles-lettres, as the word itself suggests, we consider chiefly their beauty. The beauty of any work of art is related to the pleasure it gives us when we know it well.

那么，让我们以下列方式重述这些准则。在你表达你的好恶之前，你必须首先确定你已经做出了诚实的努力来欣赏这部作品。通过欣赏，我们的意思是拥有作者试图通过处理你的情绪为你创造的体验和想象力。因此，你无法通过被动阅读来欣赏小说（事实上，正如我们所说，你必须热情地阅读它），就像你无法通过这种方式理解一本哲学书籍一样。为了获得欣赏，就像获得理解一样，你必须积极阅读，这意味着执行我们简要概述的所有分析阅读行为。

Let us restate the maxims, then, in the following manner. Before you express your likes and dislikes, you must first be sure that you have made an honest effort to appreciate the work. By appreciation, we mean having the experience that the author tried to produce for you by working on your emotions and imagination. Thus, you cannot appreciate a novel by reading it passively (indeed, as we have remarked, you must read it passionately) any more than you can understand a philosophical book that way. To achieve appreciation, as to achieve understanding, you must read actively, and that means performing all the acts of analytical reading that we have briefly outlined.

当你完成这样的阅读之后，你就有能力去判断了。您的第一个判断自然是品味。你不仅会说你喜欢或不喜欢这本书，还会说为什么。当然，你给出的理由与这本书本身有一些关键的相关性，但在他们的第一个表达中，他们更有可能是关于你——你的偏好和偏见——而不是关于这本书。因此，要完成批评的任务，您必须通过指出引起反应的书中的那些事情来客观化您的反应。你必须从说你喜欢或不喜欢什么以及为什么，过渡到说这本书的好坏以及原因。

After you have completed such a reading, you are competent to judge. Your first judgment will naturally be one of taste. You will say not only that you like or dislike the book, but also why. The reasons you give will, of course, have some critical relevance to the book itself, but in their first expression they are more likely to be about you—your preferences and prejudices—than about the book. Hence, to complete the task of criticism, you must objectify your reactions by pointing to those things in the book that caused them. You must pass from saying what you like or dislike and why, to saying what is good or bad about the book and why.

你越能反省地辨别阅读小说或诗歌的乐趣的原因，你就越接近于了解文学作品本身的艺术美德。这样你就会逐渐形成一种批评的标准。你可能会发现一大群志同道合的人来分享你的批判性判断。您甚至可能会发现，我们认为是真实的，任何学习阅读的人都会获得良好的文学品味。

The better you can reflectively discern the causes of your pleasure in reading fiction or poetry, the nearer you will come to knowing the artistic virtues in the literary work itself. You will thus gradually develop a standard of criticism. And you will probably find a large company of men and women of similar taste to share your critical judgments. You may even discover, what we think is true, that good taste in literature is acquired by anyone who learns to read.



阅读故事、戏剧和诗歌的15条建议

15SUGGESTIONS FOR READING STORIES, PLAYS, AND POEMS

 

上一章讨论的阅读想象文学的平行规则是一般规则，适用于所有类型的想象文学——小说和故事，无论是散文还是诗歌（包括史诗）；戏剧，无论是悲剧还是喜剧或介于两者之间的东西；和抒情诗，无论长度或复杂程度如何。

The parallel rules for reading imaginative literature that were discussed in the last chapter were general ones, applying across the board to all kinds of imaginative literature—novels and stories, whether in prose or verse (including epics); plays, whether tragedies or comedies or something in between; and lyric poems, of whatever length or complexity.

这些规则是通用的，在应用于不同类型的想象文学时必须有所调整。在本章中，我们想建议所需的调整。关于阅读故事、戏剧和抒情诗，我们将有一些特别要说的，我们还将包括关于阅读史诗和伟大的希腊悲剧所带来的特殊问题的注释。

These rules, being general, must be adapted somewhat when they are applied to the different kinds of imaginative literature. In this chapter we want to suggest the adaptations that are required. We will have something particular to say about the reading of stories, plays, and lyric poems, and we will also include notes on the special problems presented by the reading of epic poems and the great Greek tragedies.

然而，在继续讨论这些问题之前，最好对积极和苛刻的读者必须向任何一本书提出的四个问题中的最后一个做一些评论，当这个问题被问到一部富有想象力的文学作品时。

Before proceeding to those matters, however, it is desirable to make some remarks about the last of the four questions that the active and demanding reader must ask of any book, when that question is asked of a work of imaginative literature.

你会记得前三个问题是：第一，整本书讲的是什么？第二，详细说了什么，怎么说的？第三，这本书是全部还是部分真实的？上一章介绍了这三个问题在想象文学中的应用。当你能够描述一个故事、戏剧或诗歌的情节的统一性时，第一个问题就得到了回答——“情节”正在被解释广泛地包括一首抒情诗和一个故事的动作或运动。当你能够辨别出不同角色所扮演的角色，并用你自己的话讲述他们所涉及的关键事件和事件时，第二个问题就得到了回答。当你能够对作品的诗意真实性做出合理判断时，第三个问题就得到了回答。这是一个可能的故事吗？工作是否满足你的心灵和思想？你欣赏作品的美吗？在每种情况下，你能说出为什么吗？

You will recall that the first three questions are: first, What is the book about as a whole?; second, What is being said in detail, and how?; and third, Is the book true, in whole or part? The application of these three questions to imaginative literature was covered in the last chapter. The first question is answered when you are able to describe the unity of the plot of a story, play, or poem—“plot” being construed broadly to include the action or movement of a lyric poem as well as of a story. The second question is answered when you are able to discern the role that the various characters play, and recount, in your own words, the key incidents and events in which they are involved. And the third question is answered when you are able to give a reasoned judgment about the poetical truth of the work. Is it a likely story? Does the work satisfy your heart and your mind? Do you appreciate the beauty of the work? In each case, can you say why?

第四个问题是，它是什么？对于说明性书籍，回答这个问题意味着您要采取某种行动。这里的“行动”并不总是意味着出去做某事。我们已经提出，当读者同意一项实际工作——即同意所提出的目的——并适当地接受作者所说的可以达到目的的手段时，这种行为是读者的义务。当说明性工作是理论性的时，这个意义上的行动不是强制性的。在那里，只需要心理活动。但是，如果你确信这样一本书的全部或部分内容是真实的，那么你必须同意它的结论，如果它们暗示你对这个主题的看法有所调整，那么你或多或少需要进行这些调整。

The fourth question is, What of it? In the case of expository books, an answer to this question implies some kind of action on your part. “Action,” here, does not always mean going out and doing something. We have suggested that that kind of action is an obligation for the reader when he agrees with a practical work—that is, agrees with the ends proposed —and accepts as appropriate the means by which the author says they can be attained. Action in this sense is not obligatory when the expository work is theoretical. There, mental action alone is required. But if you are convinced that such a book is true, in whole or part, then you must agree with its conclusions, and if they imply some adjustment of your views of the subject, then you are more or less required to make those adjustments.

现在重要的是要认识到，在想象文学作品的情况下，第四个也是最后一个问题必须有完全不同的解释。从某种意义上说，这个问题与阅读故事和诗歌无关。严格来说，当你读好小说、戏剧或诗歌时，不需要你采取任何行动——也就是说，分析性的。当您将分析阅读的平行规则应用于此类作品并回答了前三个问题时，您就履行了作为读者的所有责任。

Now it is important to recognize that, in the case of a work of imaginative literature, this fourth and final question must be interpreted quite differently. In a sense, the question is irrelevant to the reading of stories and poems. Strictly speaking, no action whatever is called for on your part when you have read a novel, play, or poem well—that is, analytically. You have discharged all of your responsibilities as a reader when you have applied the parallel rules of analytical reading to such works, and answered the first three questions.

我们说“严格来说”，因为很明显，富有想象力的作品往往会导致读者以各种方式行动。有时，一个故事比阐述相同观点的说明性作品更能表达观点——无论是政治、经济还是道德观点。乔治奥威尔的动物 农场和他的1984 年都是对极权主义的有力攻击。奥尔德斯·赫胥黎 (Aldous Huxley) 的《美丽新世界》( Brave New World ) 雄辩地抨击了技术进步的暴政。亚历山大·索尔仁尼琴 (Alexander Solzhenitsyn) 的《第一圈》( The First Circle ) 比一百份事实研究和报告更能告诉我们苏联官僚机构的残忍和不人道。这样的作品在人类历史上曾多次被查禁和审查，其原因不言而喻。正如 EB White 曾经说过的那样，“一个暴君不害怕雄辩的作家鼓吹自由——他害怕一个醉酒的诗人，他可能会讲一个会站稳脚跟的笑话。”

We say “strictly speaking,” because it is obvious that imaginative works have often led readers to act in various ways. Sometimes a story is a better way of getting a point across—be it a political, economic, or moral point—than an expository work making the same point. George Orwell’s Animal Farm and his 1984 are both powerful attacks on totalitarianism. Aldous Huxley’s Brave New World is an eloquent diatribe against the tyranny of technological progress. Alexander Solzhenitsyn’s The First Circle tells us more about the petty cruelty and inhumanity of the Soviet bureaucracy than a hundred factual studies and reports. Such works have been banned and censored many times in the history of mankind, and the reason for that is clear. As E. B. White once remarked, “A despot doesn’t fear eloquent writers preaching freedom-he fears a drunken poet who may crack a joke that will take hold.”

然而，阅读故事和诗歌的这种实际后果并不是问题的本质。富有想象力的作品可以导致行动，但它们不是必须的。它们属于美术领域。

Nevertheless, such practical consequences of the reading of stories and poems are not of the essence of the matter. Imaginative writings can lead to action, but they do not have to. They belong in the realm of fine art.

一件美术作品之所以“好”，并不是因为它“精致”或“完成”，而是因为它本身就是一个目的（finis，拉丁语，意思是结束）。它不会朝着超越自身的结果前进。正如爱默生所说的美，它是它自己存在的借口。

A work of fine art is “fine” not because it is “refined” or “finished,” but because it is an end (finis, Latin, means end) in itself. It does not move toward some result beyond itself. It is, as Emerson said of beauty, its own excuse for being.

因此，在将最后一个问题应用于想象力文学作品时，您应该谨慎行事。如果您因为读过的一本书而感到有冲动去做某事，请问问自己，该作品是否包含产生这种感觉的隐含陈述。诗歌，严格来说，不是陈述的领域，尽管许多故事和诗歌中都有陈述，或多或少地埋藏在其中。留意它们并对它们做出反应是完全正确的。但是你应该记住，你正在注意故事或诗歌本身以外的事物并对其做出反应。这本身就存在。要读好它，您所要做的就是体验它。

Therefore, when it comes to applying this last question to works of imaginative literature, you should do so with caution. If you feel impelled because of a book you have read to go out and do something, ask yourself whether the work contains some implied statement that has produced this feeling. Poetry, properly speaking, is not the realm of statement, although many stories and poems have statements in them, more or less deeply buried. And it is quite right to take heed of them, and to react to them. But you should remember that you are then taking heed of and reacting to something other than the story or poem itself. That subsists in its own right. To read it well, all you have to do is experience it.

如何阅读故事

How to Read Stories

 

我们想给你阅读故事的第一条建议是：快速阅读并全神贯注。理想情况下，一个故事应该一口气读完，尽管这对于忙于阅读长篇小说的人来说几乎是不可能的。然而，应该通过将好故事的阅读时间压缩到尽可能短的时间来接近理想状态。否则你会忘记发生了什么，情节的统一性会逃避你，你会迷失方向。

The first piece of advice we would like to give you for reading a story is this: Read it quickly and with total immersion. Ideally, a story should be read at one sitting, although this is rarely possible for busy people with long novels. Nevertheless, the ideal should be approximated by compressing the reading of a good story into as short a time as feasible. Otherwise you will forget what happened, the unity of the plot will escape you, and you will be lost.

一些读者，当他们真正喜欢一本小说时，想要细细品味，驻足阅读，尽可能多地阅读。但在这种情况下，与其说他们在读这本书，不如说是在满足他们对事件和人物或多或少的无意识感受。我们稍后会回到这一点。

Some readers, when they really like a novel, want to savor it, to pause over it, to draw out the reading of it for as long as they can. But in this case they are probably not so much reading the book as satisfying their more or less unconscious feelings about the events and the characters. We will return to that in a moment.

我们建议快速阅读，并完全沉浸其中。我们已经指出了让一本富有想象力的书对您产生影响的重要性。这就是我们所说的后一个短语的意思。让人物走进你的头脑和心灵；暂停你对事件的怀疑，如果是的话。在你理解角色为什么这样做之前，不要反对他所做的事情——如果是的话。尽可能努力地生活在他的世界里，而不是你的世界里；在那里，他所做的事情可能是可以理解的。在你确定你已经在你的能力范围内“生活”在其中之前，不要将世界作为一个整体来评判。

Read quickly, we suggest, and with total immersion. We have indicated the importance of letting an imaginative book work on you. That is what we mean by the latter phrase. Let the characters into your mind and heart; suspend your disbelief, if such it is, about the events. Do not disapprove of something a character does before you understand why he does it—if then. Try as hard as you can to live in his world, not in yours; there, the things he does may be quite understandable. And do not judge the world as a whole until you are sure that you have “lived” in it to the extent of your ability.

遵循这条规则可以让你回答关于任何一本书应该问的第一个问题——它是关于什么的，作为一个整体？除非你快速阅读它，否则你将看不到故事的统一性。除非你认真阅读，否则你将看不到细节。

Following this rule will allow you to answer the first question you should ask about any book—What is it about, as a whole? Unless you read it quickly you will fail to see the unity of the story. Unless you read intensely you will fail to see the details.

正如我们所观察到的，一个故事的术语是它的人物和事件。您必须熟悉它们，并能够将它们分类。但这里有一个警告。以《战争与和平》为例，许多读者在开始阅读这部伟大的小说时，被大量的人物介绍所淹没，尤其是他们的名字都听起来很奇怪。他们很快就放弃了这本书，因为他们相信自己永远无法解决所有问题错综复杂的关系，分不清谁是谁。任何一部大小说都是如此——如果一部小说真的很棒，我们希望它尽可能大。

The terms of a story, as we have observed, are its characters and incidents. You must become acquainted with them, and be able to sort them out. But here a word of warning. To take War and Peace as an example, many readers start this great novel and are overwhelmed by the vast number of characters to whom they are introduced, especially since they all have strange-sounding names. They soon give up on the book in the belief that they will never be able to sort out all the complicated relationships, to know who is who. This is true of any big novel—and if a novel is really good, we want it to be as big as possible.

这些胆小的读者并不总是会想到，当他们搬到一个新城镇或城镇的一部分时，当他们去新学校或工作时，甚至当他们到达聚会时，他们也会发生完全相同的事情。在这种情况下，他们不会放弃；他们知道，过不了多久，个人就会开始在人群中出现，朋友们就会从同事、学生或客人的无名人群中出现。我们可能不记得我们在聚会上遇到的每个人的名字，但我们会记得我们交谈了一个小时的男人的名字，或者我们第二天晚上约会的女孩的名字，或者孩子去的母亲的名字和我们同一所学校。同样的事情也发生在小说中。我们不应该期望记住每个字符；他们中的许多人只是背景人物，谁在那里只是为了衬托主角的行动。然而，当我们完成时战争与和平或任何伟大的小说，我们知道谁是重要的，我们不会忘记。皮埃尔、安德鲁、娜塔莎、玛丽公主、尼古拉斯——这些名字可能会立即浮现在脑海中，尽管我们可能已经多年没有读过托尔斯泰的书了。

It does not always occur to such fainthearted readers that exactly the same thing happens to them when they move to a new town or part of a town, when they go to a new school or job, or even when they arrive at a party. They do not give up in those circumstances; they know that after a short while individuals will begin to be visible in the mass, friends will emerge from the faceless crowd of fellow-workers, fellow-students, or fellow-guests. We may not remember the names of everyone we met at a party, but we will recall the name of the man we talked to for an hour, or the girl with whom we made a date for the next evening, or the mother whose child goes to the same school as ours. The same thing happens in a novel. We should not expect to remember every character; many of them are merely background persons, who are there only to set off the actions of the main characters. However, by the time we have finished War and Peace or any big novel, we know who is important, and we do not forget. Pierre, Andrew, Natasha, Princess Mary, Nicholas—the names are likely to come immediately to memory, although it may have been years since we read Tolstoy’s book.

尽管发生了过多的事件，我们也很快就会知道什么是重要的。作者通常在这方面提供很多帮助；他们不想让读者错过情节展开的关键内容，因此他们以各种方式标记它。但我们的观点是，如果一开始一切都不清楚，您不应该着急。其实那时候应该还不清楚。故事就像生活本身。在生活中，我们不期望在事件发生时就理解它们，至少是完全清楚地理解它们，但回顾它们，我们确实理解了。因此，一个故事的读者，在他读完之后回顾它，就会明白事件的关系和行动的顺序。

We also, despite the plethora of incidents, soon learn what is important. Authors generally give a good deal of help in this respect; they do not want the reader to miss what is essential to the unfolding of the plot, so they flag it in various ways. But our point is that you should not be anxious if all is not clear from the beginning. Actually, it should not be clear then. A story is like life itself; in life, we do not expect to understand events as they occur, at least with total clarity, but looking back on them, we do understand. So the reader of a story, looking back on it after he has finished it, understands the relation of events and the order of actions.

所有这一切都归结为同一点：你必须完成一个故事才能说你读得很好。然而，矛盾的是，故事在最后一页就不再像生活了。生活要继续，但故事不会。它的人物在书外没有生命力，你对他们在第一页之前和最后一页之后发生的事情的想象只能与下一位读者的想象一样好。其实，这样的猜测都是毫无意义的。哈姆雷特的前奏已经写好了，但它们很荒谬。我们不应该问《战争与和平》结束后皮埃尔和娜塔莎会怎样。我们对莎士比亚和托尔斯泰的创作感到满意，部分原因是它们的时间有限。我们不需要更多了。

All of this comes down to the same point: you must finish a story in order to be able to say that you have read it well. Paradoxically, however, a story ceases to be like life on its last page. Life goes on, but the story does not. Its characters have no vitality outside the book, and your imagination of what happens to them before the first page and after the last is only as good as the next reader’s. Actually, all such speculations are meaningless. Preludes to Hamlet have been written, but they are ridiculous. We should not ask what happens to Pierre and Natasha after War and Peace ends. We are satisfied with Shakespeare’s and Tolstoy’s creations partly because they are limited in time. We need no more.

绝大多数被阅读的书都是这样或那样的故事。不识字的人听故事。我们甚至自己弥补。小说似乎是人类的必需品。为什么是这样？

The great majority of books that are read are stories of one kind or another. People who cannot read listen to stories. We even make them up for ourselves. Fiction seems to be a necessity for human beings. Why is this?

小说之所以成为人类必需品的原因之一是它满足了许多无意识和有意识的需求。如果它像说明文一样只触及有意识的头脑，那将是很重要的。但小说也很重要，因为它也触及无意识。

One reason why fiction is a human necessity is that it satisfies many unconscious as well as conscious needs. It would be important if it only touched the conscious mind, as expository writing does. But fiction is important, too, because it also touches the unconscious.

在最简单的层面上——关于这个主题的讨论可能非常复杂——我们喜欢或不喜欢某些类型的人胜过其他类型的人，并不总是确定原因。如果在一部小说中，这些人受到奖励或惩罚，我们可能会对这本书产生比其艺术价值更强烈的感受，无论是赞成还是反对。

On the simplest level—and a discussion of this subject could be very complex—we like or dislike certain kinds of people more than others, without always being sure why. If, in a novel, such people are rewarded or punished, we may have stronger feelings, either pro or con, about the book than it merits artistically.

例如，当小说中的人物继承了金钱或以其他方式获得好运时，我们常常会感到高兴。然而，只有当这个角色“富有同情心”——这意味着我们可以认同他或她时，这往往才是正确的。我们不承认我们想继承这笔钱，我们只是说我们喜欢这本书。

For example, we are often pleased when a character in a novel inherits money, or otherwise comes into good fortune. However, this tends to be true only if the character is “sympathetic”—meaning that we can identify with him or her. We do not admit to ourselves that we would like to inherit the money, we merely say that we like the book.

或许我们都想去爱得比我们做的更丰富。许多小说都是关于爱情的——也许大部分都是——而与这些充满爱意的人物产生共鸣让我们很高兴。他们是免费的，而我们不是。但我们可能不想承认这一点；为了这样做可能会让我们有意识地觉得我们自己的爱是不够的。

Perhaps we would all like to love more richly than we do. Many novels are about love—most are, perhaps—and it gives us pleasure to identify with the loving characters. They are free, and we are not. But we may not want to admit this; for to do so might make us feel, consciously, that our own loves are inadequate.

同样，几乎每个人的性格中都带有某种无意识的虐待狂和受虐狂。这些通常在小说中得到满足，在小说中我们可以认同征服者或受害者，甚至两者。在每一种情况下，我们都倾向于简单地说我们喜欢“那种书”——没有具体说明或真的不知道为什么。

Again, almost everyone has some unconscious sadism and masochism in his makeup. These are often satisfied in novels, where we can identify with either the conqueror or victim, or even with both. In each case, we are prone to say simply that we like “that kind of book”—without specifying or really knowing why.

最后，我们怀疑我们所知道的生活是不公正的。为什么好人受苦，坏人好？我们不知道，我们也不能知道，但事实让每个人都非常焦虑。在故事中，这种混乱和不愉快的情况得到了调整，这让我们非常满意。

Finally, we suspect that life as we know it is unjust. Why do good people suffer, and bad ones prosper? We do not know, we cannot know, but the fact causes great anxiety in everyone. In stories, this chaotic and unpleasant situation is adjusted, and that is extremely satisfying to us.

在故事中——在小说、叙事诗和戏剧中——正义通常确实存在。人们得到他们应得的；作者对他笔下的人物就像神一样，确保根据他们的真正功绩对他们进行奖赏或惩罚。在一个好故事中，在一个令人满意的故事中，至少通常是这样。一个糟糕的故事最令人恼火的事情之一是，故事中的人物似乎毫无缘由地受到了惩罚或奖励。伟大的讲故事的人不会犯错。他能够使我们相信正义——我们称之为诗意的正义——已经实现。

In stories—in novels and narrative poems and plays-justice usually does exist. People get what they deserve; the author, who is like a god to his characters, sees to it that they are rewarded or punished according to their true merit. In a good story, in a satisfying one, this is usually so, at least. One of the most irritating things about a bad story is that the people in it seem to be punished or rewarded with no rhyme or reason. The great storyteller makes no mistakes. He is able to convince us that justice—poetic justice, we call it—has been done.

即使是高尚的悲剧也是如此。在那里，好人遭遇了可怕的事情，但我们看到英雄，即使他不完全配得上他的命运，至少也明白了这一点。我们非常希望分享他的理解。如果我们只知道——那么我们就能承受世界为我们准备的一切。“我想知道为什么”是舍伍德·安德森 (Sherwood Anderson) 的一篇小说的标题。它可能是许多故事的标题。悲剧英雄确实知道为什么，当然，通常是在他的生活毁了之后。我们可以分享他的洞察力，但不必分担他的痛苦。

This is true even of high tragedy. There, terrible things happen to good men, but we see that the hero, even if he does not wholly deserve his fate, at least comes to understand it. And we have a profound desire to share his understanding. If we only knew— then we could withstand whatever the world has in store for us. “I Want to Know Why” is the title of a story by Sherwood Anderson. It could be the title of many stories. The tragic hero does learn why, though often, of course, only after the ruin of his life. We can share his insight without sharing his suffering.

因此，在批评小说时，我们必须小心区分那些满足我们自己特殊的无意识需求的书——那些让我们说，“我喜欢这本书，虽然我真的不知道为什么”——来自那些满足几乎每个人的深层无意识需求的人。后者无疑是伟大的故事，那些世世代代流传千古的故事。只要人还是人，他们就会继续满足他，给他一些他需要的东西——对正义和理解的信念以及对焦虑的减轻。我们不知道，也不能确定现实世界是好的。但一个伟大故事的世界在某种程度上是美好的。我们希望尽可能多地住在那里。

Thus, in criticizing fiction we must be careful to distinguish those books that satisfy our own particular unconscious needs—the ones that make us say, “I like this book, although I don’t really know why”—from those that satisfy the deep unconscious needs of almost everybody. The latter are undoubtedly the great stories, the ones that live on and on for generations and centuries. As long as man is man, they will go on satisfying him, giving him something that he needs to have—a belief in justice and understanding and the allaying of anxiety. We do not know, we cannot be sure, that the real world is good. But the world of a great story is somehow good. We want to live there as often and as long as we can.

关于史诗的注释

A Note About Epics

 

在西方世界的伟大传统中，最受尊敬但阅读最少的书籍可能是主要的史诗，尤其是荷马的《伊利亚特》和《奥德赛》、维吉尔的《埃涅阿斯纪》、但丁的《神曲》和弥尔顿的《失乐园》。这个悖论需要一些评论。

Perhaps the most honored but probably the least read books in the great tradition of the Western World are the major epic poems, particularly the Iliad and Odyssey of Homer, Virgil’s Aeneid, Dante’s Divine Comedy, and Milton’s Paradise Lost. This paradox requires some comment.

从过去2500年来成功完成的极少数作品来看，一首长篇史诗显然是一个人所能写出的最难的东西。这不是因为不想尝试；数以百计的史诗已经开始，有些——例如，华兹华斯的前奏曲和拜伦的唐璜——已经发展到广泛的规模而从未真正完成。因此，荣誉归于坚持并完成任务的诗人。如果他创作出具有上述五种品质的作品，他将获得更大的荣誉。但它们肯定不容易阅读。

Judging by the very small number that have been completed successfully in the past 2,500 years, a long epic poem is apparently the most difficult thing a man can write. This is not for want of trying; hundreds of epics have been begun, and some—for example, Wordsworth’s Prelude and Byron’s Don Juan—have grown to extensive proportions without ever really being finished. So honor is due the poet who sticks to the task and completes it. Greater honor is due him if he produces a work that has the qualities of the five just mentioned. But they are certainly not easy to read.

这不仅是因为它们是用诗歌写成的——因为除了《失乐园》以外，我们都可以找到散文译本。困难似乎在于他们的提升，在于他们处理主题的方法。这些主要史诗中的任何一部都对读者提出了巨大的要求——需要关注、参与和想象力。阅读它们所需的努力确实非常大。

This is not only because they are written in verse—for in every case except that of Paradise Lost, prose translations are available to us. The difficulty seems rather to lie in their elevation, in their approach to their subject matter. Any of these major epics exerts enormous demands on the reader—demands of attention, of involvement, and of imagination. The effort required to read them is very great indeed.

我们大多数人都没有意识到我们遭受的损失做出这样的努力。从对这些史诗的良好阅读——正如我们应该说的分析性阅读——中获得的回报，至少与阅读任何其他书籍，当然是任何其他小说作品所获得的回报一样大。然而不幸的是，那些在这些书中做得不够好的读者并没有获得这些回报。

Most of us are not aware of the loss we suffer by not making that effort. For the rewards to be gained from a good reading—an analytical reading, as we should say—of these epics are at least as great as those to be gained from the reading of any other books, certainly any other works of fiction. Unfortunately, however, these rewards are not gained by readers who do less than a good job on these books.

我们希望您尝试阅读这五首伟大的史诗，并设法通读所有这些。如果您这样做，我们相信您不会失望。您将能够享受到进一步的满足感。荷马、维吉尔、但丁和弥尔顿——他们是每一位优秀的诗人都读过的作家，更不用说其他作家了。它们与圣经一起构成了任何严肃阅读计划的支柱。

We hope that you will take a stab at reading these five great epic poems, and that you will manage to get through all of them. We are certain you will not be disappointed if you do. And you will be able to enjoy a further satisfaction. Homer, Virgil, Dante, and Milton—they are the authors that every good poet, to say nothing of other writers, has read. Along with the Bible, they constitute the backbone of any serious reading program.

如何阅读剧本

How to Read Plays

 

戏剧是虚构的，是故事，只要这是真的，它就应该像故事一样被阅读。也许读者必须更积极地创造背景，创造人物生活和活动的世界，因为戏剧中没有像小说那样大量的描写。但问题本质上是相似的。

A play is fiction, a story, and insofar as that is true, it should be read like a story. Perhaps the reader has to be more active in creating the background, the world in which the characters live and move, for there is no description in plays such as abounds in novels. But the problems are essentially similar.

但是，有一个重要的区别。当你阅读一部戏剧时，你并不是在阅读一部完整的作品。完整的剧本（作者想让你理解的作品）只有在舞台上表演时才能理解。就像必须听到的音乐一样，当我们在书中阅读戏剧时，它缺乏物理维度。读者必须提供该维度。

However, there is one important difference. When you read a play, you are not reading a complete work. The complete play (the work that the author intended you to apprehend) is only apprehended when it is acted on a stage. Like music, which must be heard, a play lacks a physical dimension when we read it in a book. The reader must supply that dimension.

做到这一点的唯一方法是假装看到它在行动。因此，一旦你从整体上和细节上发现了该剧的内容，并且回答了其他问题后，你必须就任何故事提出疑问，然后再尝试导演该剧。想象一下，你有六个好在你面前的演员，等待你的命令。告诉他们这句台词怎么说，那场戏怎么演。解释这几句话的重要性，以及该动作如何成为作品的高潮。你会玩得很开心，你会学到很多关于这个游戏的知识。

The only way to do that is to make a pretense of seeing it acted. Therefore, once you have discovered what the play is about, as a whole and in detail, and once you have answered the other questions you must ask about any story, then try directing the play. Imagine that you have half a dozen good actors before you, awaiting your commands. Tell them how to say this line, how to play that scene. Explain the importance of these few words, and how that action is the climax of the work. You will have a lot of fun, and you will learn a lot about the play.

一个例子将说明我们的意思。在《哈姆雷特》中，第二幕第二场，波洛纽斯向国王和王后宣布哈姆雷特疯了，因为他爱上了奥菲莉亚，奥菲莉亚拒绝了王子的求爱。国王和王后心存疑虑，于是波洛纽斯建议国王和他躲在阿拉斯后面，以便偷听哈姆雷特和奥菲莉亚之间的谈话。该提议出现在第二幕第二场第 160-170 行；紧接着，哈姆雷特进来了，正在读书。他对 Polonius 的演讲令人费解。正如 Polonius 所说，“虽然这很疯狂，但其中有方法！” 后来，在第三幕的早期，哈姆雷特进入并发表了著名的独白，开始是“生存还是毁灭”，然后被奥菲莉亚的视线打断了。他和她说了一阵子，突然就叫道：“哈，哈！你诚实吗？（III，i，第 103 行）。现在的问题是，哈姆雷特之前是否听到波洛涅斯说他和国王计划监视他？或许他也听到波洛纽斯说他会“把我的女儿交给他”？如果是这样的话，哈姆雷特与波洛涅斯和奥菲莉亚的谈话就意味着一回事；如果他没有无意中听到阴谋，他们就会另有打算。莎士比亚没有留下舞台指导；读者（或导演）必须自己决定。你自己的决定将是你理解这出戏的核心。

An example will show what we mean. In Hamlet, Act II, Scene ii, Polonius announces to the king and queen that Hamlet is insane because of his love for Ophelia, who has spurned the prince’s advances. The king and queen are doubtful, whereupon Polonius proposes that the king and he hide behind an arras, in order to overhear a conversation between Hamlet and Ophelia. This proposal occurs in Act II, Scene ii, at lines 160-170; immediately thereafter Hamlet enters, reading. His speeches to Polonius are enigmatic; as Polonius says, “though this be madness, yet there is method in’t!” Later on, early in Act III, Hamlet enters and delivers the famous soliloquy, beginning “To be or not to be,” and then is interrupted by catching sight of Ophelia. He speaks to her quite reasonably for a time, but suddenly he cries: “Ha, ha! are you honest?” (III, i, line 103). Now the question is, has Hamlet overheard Polonius say earlier that he and the king planned to spy on him? And did he perhaps also hear Polonius say that he would “loose my daughter to him”? If so Hamlet’s conversations with both Polonius and Ophelia would mean one thing; if he did not overhear the plotting, they would mean another. Shakespeare left no stage directions; the reader (or director) must decide for himself. Your own decision will be central to your understanding of the play.

莎士比亚的许多戏剧都要求读者进行这种活动。我们的观点是，无论剧作家在告诉我们应该期待看到什么时多么明确，它总是令人向往的。（我们无法质疑我们将要听到的内容，因为剧本的台词就在我们面前。）在你假装以这种方式将剧本搬上舞台之前，你可能还没有真正读好剧本。充其量，你只给了它部分阅读。

Many of Shakespeare’s plays require this kind of activity on the part of the reader. Our point is that it is always desirable, no matter how explicit the playwright was in telling us exactly what we should expect to see. (We cannot question what we are to hear, since the play’s words are before us.) Probably you have not read a play really well until you have pretended to put it on the stage in this way. At best, you have given it only a partial reading.

早些时候，我们建议剧作家不能像小说作者那样直接与读者对话这一规则有一些有趣的例外。（菲尔丁，在汤姆琼斯，是在一部伟大的小说中直接称呼读者的一个例子。）其中两个例外相隔近 25 个世纪的时间。古希腊喜剧剧作家阿里斯托芬 (Aristophanes) 写下了唯一幸存下来的所谓古喜剧 (Old Comedy) 的例子。在阿里斯托芬式的戏剧中，男主角有时会走出角色，也许会走向观众，发表与戏剧情节毫无关系的政治演讲。感觉这些话是作者个人感情的表达。现在偶尔会这样做——有用的艺术手段从来没有真正丢失过——但也许不如阿里斯托芬那样有效。

Earlier, we suggested that there were interesting exceptions to the rule that the playwright cannot speak directly to the reader as the author of a novel can and often does. (Fielding, in Tom Jones, is an example of this direct addressing of the reader in one great novel.) Two of these exceptions are separated by nearly twenty-five centuries of time. Aristophanes, the ancient Greek comic playwright, wrote the only examples of what is called Old Comedy that survive. From time to time in an Aristophanic play, and always at least once, the leading actor would step out of character, perhaps move forward toward the audience, and deliver a political speech that had nothing whatever to do with the action of the drama. It is felt that these speeches were expressions of the author’s personal feelings. This is occasionally done nowadays—no useful artistic device is ever really lost—but perhaps not as effectively as Aristophanes did it.

另一个例子是萧伯纳，他不仅希望自己的剧本被演出，还希望它们能被阅读。他把所有的剧本都出版了，至少有一部（《心碎之家》）在演出之前出版，并在出版后附上长长的序言，在序言中他解释了剧本的意义，并告诉读者如何理解它们。（他还在已出版的版本中包含了非常详尽的舞台指导。）如果不阅读萧伯纳为该剧写的序言而阅读萧伯纳戏剧，就是故意背弃对理解的重要帮助。同样，其他现代剧作家也曾在这一技巧上模仿过萧伯纳，但从未像他那样有效。

The other example is that of Shaw, who not only expected his plays to be acted but also hoped that they would be read. He published them all, at least one (Heartbreak House) before it was ever acted, and accompanied the publication with long prefaces in which he explained the meaning of the plays and told his readers how to understand them. (He also included very extensive stage directions in the published versions.) To read a Shavian play without reading the preface Shaw wrote for it is to turn one’s back intentionally on an important aid to understanding. Again, other modern playwrights have imitated Shaw in this device, but never as effectively as he did.

另一点建议可能会有所帮助，尤其是在阅读莎士比亚时。我们已经提出了通读剧本的重要性，尽可能一口气读完，以便对整体有一个感觉。但是，由于戏剧大多是韵文，而且由于 1600 年以来语言发生的变化，诗句在某些地方或多或少是不透明的，因此通常需要大声朗读一段令人费解的段落。慢慢读，好像有听众在听，并带有“表达”——也就是说，当你阅读它们时，试着让这些词对你有意义。这个简单的装置将解决许多困难。只有在它失败后，你才应该转向词汇表或注释。

One other bit of advice may be helpful, particularly in reading Shakespeare. We have already suggested the importance of reading the plays through, as nearly as possible at one sitting, in order to get a feel for the whole. But, since the plays are mostly in verse, and since the verse is more or less opaque in places because of changes in the language that have occurred since 1600, it is often desirable to read a puzzling passage out loud. Read slowly, as if an audience were listening, and with “expression”—that is, try to make the words meaningful to you as you read them. This simple device will clear up many difficulties. Only after it has failed should you turn to the glossary or notes.

关于悲剧的注释

A Note About Tragedy

 

大多数戏剧不值得一读。我们认为，这是因为它们不完整。它们不是用来阅读的——它们是用来表演的。伟大的说明著作很多，伟大的小说、故事、抒情诗也很多，但伟大的戏剧却寥寥无几。然而，那几部——埃斯库罗斯、索福克勒斯和欧里庇得斯的悲剧，莎士比亚的戏剧，莫里哀的喜剧，极少数现代人的作品——确实非常伟大，因为它们包含了人类所拥有的一些最深刻和最丰富的见解。曾经用言语表达过。

Most plays are not worth reading. This, we think, is because they are incomplete. They were not meant to be read—they were meant to be acted. There are many great expository works, and many great novels, stories, and lyric poems, but there are only a few great plays. However, those few—the tragedies of Aeschylus, Sophocles, and Euripedes, the plays of Shakespeare, Molière’s comedies, the works of a very few moderns—are very great indeed, for they contain within them some of the deepest and richest insights men have ever expressed in words.

其中，对于初学者来说，希腊悲剧可能是最难破解的。一方面，在古代世界，同时出现了三部悲剧，这三部悲剧往往涉及一个共同的主题，但除了一部（埃斯库罗斯的奥瑞斯忒亚）之外，只有一部戏剧（或幕）幸存下来。另一方面，几乎不可能在头脑中安排剧本，因为我们对希腊导演是如何做到的几乎一无所知。再者，戏剧通常是基于观众熟知但我们只能通过戏剧了解的故事。例如，了解俄狄浦斯的故事，以及我们了解乔治华盛顿和樱桃树的故事，从而将索福克勒斯的杰作视为对一个熟悉的故事的评论是一回事；这是另一回事俄狄浦斯王作为主要故事，并尝试想象提供背景的熟悉故事。

Among these, Greek tragedy is probably the toughest nut to crack for beginning readers. For one thing, in the ancient world three tragedies were presented at one time, the three often dealing with a common theme, but except in one case (the Oresteia of Aeschylus) only single plays (or acts) survive. For another, it is almost impossible to stage the plays mentally, since we know almost nothing about how the Greek directors did it. For still another, the plays often are based on stories that were well known to their audiences but are known to us only through the plays. It is one thing to know the story of Oedipus, for example, as well as we know the story of George Washington and the Cherry Tree, and thus to view Sophocles’ masterpiece as a commentary on a familiar tale; and it is quite another to see Oedipus Rex as the primary story and try to imagine the familiar tale that provided the background.

然而，戏剧是如此强大，以至于它们甚至战胜了这些障碍以及其他障碍。好好阅读它们很重要，因为它们不仅可以告诉我们很多关于生活的事情因为我们仍然生活在其中，但它们也为后来写的许多其他戏剧——例如，拉辛和奥尼尔的——形成了一种文学框架。我们有两条建议可能会有所帮助。

Nevertheless, the plays are so powerful that they triumph over even these obstacles, as well as others. It is important to read them well, for they not only can tell us much about life as we still live it, but they also form a kind of literary framework for many other plays written much later—for example, Racine’s and O’Neill’s. We have two bits of advice that may help.

首先是要记住悲剧的本质是时间，或者更确切地说是时间的缺乏。如果有足够的时间，任何希腊悲剧中都没有问题是无法解决的，但时间永远不够。决定、选择必须在一瞬间做出，没有时间思考和权衡后果；而且，由于即使是悲剧英雄也容易犯错——尤其是容易犯错——这些决定是错误的。我们很容易看到应该做什么，但我们是否能够及时看到？这是你在阅读任何希腊悲剧时应该经常问的问题。

The first is to remember that the essence of tragedy is time, or rather the lack of it. There is no problem in any Greek tragedy that could not have been solved if there had been enough time, but there is never enough. Decisions, choices have to be made in a moment, there is no time to think and weigh the consequences; and, since even tragic heroes are fallible—especially fallible, perhaps—the decisions are wrong. It is easy for us to see what should have been done, but would we have been able to see in time? That is the question that you should always ask in reading any Greek tragedy.

第二点建议是这样的。关于希腊戏剧的演出，我们确实知道的一件事是悲剧演员脚上穿着公共汽车皮，使他们高出地面几英寸。（他们也戴着面具。）但是合唱团的成员没有穿公共汽车，尽管他们有时戴着面具。因此，一方面是悲剧主角的身材，另一方面是合唱团成员之间的比较非常重要。因此，当你读合唱词时，你应该总是想象这些词是由你这样的人说的；而主角所说的话则出自巨人之口，出自那些不仅看起来而且实际上比生命更伟大的人物。

The second bit of advice is this. One thing we do know about the staging of Greek plays is that the tragic actors wore buskins on their feet that elevated them several inches above the ground. (They also wore masks.) But the members of the chorus did not wear buskins, though they sometimes wore masks. The comparison between the size of the tragic protagonists, on the one hand, and the members of the chorus, on the other hand, was thus highly significant. Therefore you should always imagine, when you read the words of the chorus, that the words are spoken by persons of your own stature; while the words spoken by the protagonists proceed from the mouths of giants, from personages who did not only seem, but actually were, larger than life.

如何阅读抒情诗

How to Read Lyric Poetry

 

诗歌最简单的定义（在本节标题所暗示的某种有限意义上）是诗人所写的。这似乎很明显，但有些人会对定义提出异议。他们认为，诗歌是一种个性的自然流露，可以表达出来以书面形式，但也可以采取身体行动的形式，或或多或少的音乐声音，甚至只是感觉。当然，这是有原因的，诗人总是认识到这一点。这是一个非常古老的观念，即诗人深入自己创作他的诗歌，他们的起源地是思想或灵魂中神秘的“创造之井”。从这个意义上说，任何人都可以在任何时候，在一种孤独的敏感性会议中创作诗歌。但是，尽管我们承认这个定义中有一定的道理，但我们将在下文中使用的术语的含义要窄得多。无论诗歌冲动的起源是什么，对我们来说，诗歌都是由词组成的，而且更重要的是，由以或多或少有序和有纪律的方式排列的词组成。

The simplest definition of poetry (in the somewhat limited sense implied by the title of this section) is that it is what poets write. That seems obvious enough, and yet there are those who would dispute the definition. Poetry, they hold, is a kind of spontaneous overflowing of the personality, which may be expressed in written words but may also take the form of physical action, or more or less musical sound, or even just feeling. There is something to this, of course, and poets have always recognized it. It is a very old notion that the poet reaches down deep into himself to produce his poems, that their place of origin is a mysterious “well of creation” within the mind or soul. In this sense of the term, poetry can be made by anyone at any time, in a kind of solitary sensitivity session. But although we admit that there is a kernel of truth in this definition, the meaning of the term that we will be employing in what follows is much narrower. Whatever may be the origin of the poetic impulse, poetry, for us, consists of words, and what is more, of words that are arranged in a more or less orderly and disciplined way.

同样包含真理核心的术语的其他定义是诗歌（同样，主要是抒情诗）不是真正的诗歌，除非它赞美，或者除非它激起行动（通常是革命性的），或者除非它是用押韵写的，或者除非它使用一种叫做“诗意的措辞”的专门语言。在那句话中，我们有意将一些非常现代和一些非常陈旧的概念混合在一起。我们的观点是，所有这些定义以及我们可能提到的十几个定义都太狭窄了，就像上一段中讨论的定义太宽泛（对我们而言）一样。

Other definitions of the term that similarly contain a kernel of truth are that poetry (again, primarily lyric poetry) is not truly poetry unless it praises, or unless it rouses to action (usually revolutionary), or unless it is written in rhyme, or unless it employs a specialized language that is called “poetic diction.” In that sentence we have intentionally mixed together some very modern and some very antiquated notions. Our point is that all of these definitions, and a dozen more that we might mention, are too narrow, just as the definition discussed in the last paragraph was too broad (for us).

在如此宽泛和如此狭隘的定义之间存在一个中心核心，大多数人，如果他们对此事感觉合理，都会承认这是诗歌。如果我们试图准确地说出中心核心是什么，我们可能会遇到麻烦，所以我们不去尝试。尽管如此，我们确信您明白我们的意思。我们可以肯定，十次有九次，甚至一百次有九十九次，您会同意我们的观点，即 X 是一首诗而 Y 不是。这足以满足我们在以下几页中的目的。

Between such very broad and such very narrow definitions lies a central core that most people, if they were feeling reasonable about the matter, would admit was poetry. If we tried to state precisely what the central core consisted in, we would probably get into trouble, and so we will not try. Nevertheless, we are certain that you know what we mean. We are certain that nine times out of ten, or perhaps even ninety-nine times out of a hundred, you would agree with us that X was a poem and Y was not. And that is fully sufficient for our purposes in the following pages.

许多人认为他们看不懂抒情诗——尤其是现代诗歌。他们认为这通常很困难，晦涩、复杂，而且需要如此多的关注，他们需要付出如此多的努力，以至于不值得。我们会说两件事。首先，如果你以正确的方式阅读抒情诗，即使是现代诗歌，并不总是像你想象的那样需要大量的工作。其次，无论您愿意付出什么努力，通常都是值得的。

Many people believe that they cannot read lyric poetry—especially modern poetry. They think that it is often difficult, obscure, complex, and that it demands so much attention, so much work on their part, that it is not worthwhile. We would say two things. First, lyric poetry, even modern poetry, does not always demand as much work as you may think if you go about reading it in the right way. Second, it is often worth whatever effort you are willing to spend.

我们并不是说你不应该写一首诗。一首好诗可以在你的余生中一遍又一遍地研究、重读和思考。你将永远不会停止在其中寻找新事物、新的乐趣和喜悦，以及关于你自己和世界的新想法。我们的意思是，将一首诗带到足够近的地方来进行创作的最初任务并不像您想象的那么难。

We do not mean that you should not work on a poem. A good poem can be worked at, re-read, and thought about over and over for the rest of your life. You will never stop finding new things in it, new pleasures and delights, and also new ideas about yourself and the world. We mean that the initial task of bringing a poem close enough to you to work on it is not as hard as you may have believed.

阅读歌词要遵循的第一条规则是不停地通读它，不管你认为你是否理解它。这与我们为许多不同类型的书籍建议的规则相同，但它对一首诗比对哲学或科学论文更重要，甚至比小说或戏剧更重要。

The first rule to follow in reading a lyric is to read it through without stopping, whether you think you understand it or not. This is the same rule that we have suggested for many different kinds of books, but it is more important for a poem than it is for a philosophical or scientific treatise, and even for a novel or play.

事实上，很多人在读诗，尤其是难读的现代诗时遇到的问题，正是因为他们没有意识到读诗的第一条规则。当面对 TS Eliot 或 Dylan Thomas 或其他一些“晦涩难懂”的现代诗歌时，他们会一头扎进去，但被第一行或第一节打断了。他们无法立即完整地理解它，但他们认为自己应该理解。他们对单词感到困惑，试图解开复杂的句法，很快就放弃了，得出的结论是，正如他们所怀疑的那样，现代诗歌对他们来说太难了。

In fact, the trouble so many people seem to have in reading poems, especially the difficult modern ones, stems from their unawareness of this first rule of reading them. When faced by a poem of T. S. Eliot or Dylan Thomas or some other “obscure” modern, they plunge in with a will, but are brought up short by the first line or stanza. They do not understand it immediately and in its entirety, and they think they should. They puzzle over the words, try to unwind the complicated skein of the syntax, and soon give up, concluding that, as they suspected, modern poetry is just too difficult for them.

困难的不仅是现代歌词。许多最好的语言诗歌都是复杂的，涉及他们的语言和思想。此外，许多看似简单的诗歌在表面之下却有着巨大的复杂性。

It is not only modern lyrics that are difficult. Many of the best poems in the language are complicated and involved in their language and thought. Besides, many apparently simple poems have immense complexity under the surface.

但任何好的抒情诗都有一个统一性。除非我们阅读所有内容，并且一次全部阅读，否则我们无法理解它的统一性。我们不能发现，除非可能是偶然的，基本的感觉或经验是它的基础。特别是，一首诗的精髓几乎永远不会出现在它的第一行，甚至是它的第一节。它只能在整体中找到，而不是在任何部分中最终找到。
