But any good lyric poem has a unity. Unless we read all of it, and all at once, we cannot comprehend its unity. We cannot discover, except possibly by accident, the basic feeling or experience that underlies it. In particular, the essence of a poem is almost never to be found in its first line, or even in its first stanza. It is to be found only in the whole, and not conclusively in any part.

读歌词的第二条规则是：再读一遍这首诗——但要大声读出来。我们之前曾就莎士比亚的诗剧提出过这一建议。这很有帮助；这是必不可少的。当你大声朗读这首诗时，你会发现，说出这些词的行为本身就会迫使你更好地理解它们。如果你正在说，你不能轻易地滑过一个被误解的短语或线条。眼睛可能会错过的错误强调会冒犯您的耳朵。这首诗的节奏和韵律，如果有的话，会帮助你理解，让你把重点放在它所属的地方。最后，你将能够对这首诗敞开心扉，让它对你产生影响，就像它应该的那样。

The second rule for reading lyrics is this: Read the poem through again—but read it out loud. We have suggested this before, in the case of poetic dramas like Shakespeare’s. There it was helpful; here it is essential. You will find, as you read the poem out loud, that the very act of speaking the words forces you to understand them better. You cannot glide over a misunderstood phrase or line quite so easily if you are speaking it. Your ear is offended by a misplaced emphasis that your eyes might miss. And the rhythm of the poem, and its rhymes, if it has them, will help you to understand by making you place the emphasis where it belongs. Finally, you will be able to open yourself to the poem, and let it work on you, as it should.

在歌词的阅读上，前两条建议比什么都重要。我们认为，如果认为自己不会读诗的读者能先遵守这些规则，那么他们之后就不会有什么困难了。一旦你理解了一首诗的整体，即使这种理解是模糊的，你也可以开始问它问题。和说明性作品一样，这就是理解的秘诀。

In the reading of lyrics, these first two suggestions are more important than anything else. We think that if readers who believe they cannot read poems would obey these rules first, they would have little difficulty afterwards. For once you have apprehended a poem in its unity, even if this apprehension is vague, you can begin to ask it questions. And as with expository works, that is the secret of understanding.

您对说明性作品提出的问题是语法和逻辑问题。你对歌词提出的问题通常是修辞性的，尽管它们也可能是句法性的。你不会接受一首诗；但你必须找到关键词。然而，你发现它们主要不是通过语法辨别力，而是通过修辞辨别力。为什么某些词会从诗中跳出来，直勾勾地盯着你看？是因为节奏标记了他们吗？还是押韵？还是重复的话？几节似乎是关于相同的想法；如果是这样，这些想法是否形成某种顺序？您发现的任何此类内容都将有助于您的理解。

The questions you ask of an expository work are grammatical and logical. The questions you ask of a lyric are usually rhetorical, though they may also be syntactical. You do not come to terms with a poem; but you must discover the key words. You discover them not primarily by an act of grammatical discernment, however, but by an act of rhetorical discernment. Why do certain words pop out of the poem and stare you in the face? Is it because the rhythm marks them? Or the rhyme? Or are the words repeated? Do several stanzas seem to be about the same ideas; if so, do these ideas form any kind of sequence? Anything of this sort that you can discover will help your understanding.

大多数好的歌词中都存在某种冲突。一些有时两个对立的人——个人、图像或想法——被命名，然后描述他们之间的冲突。如果是这样，这很容易发现。但冲突通常只是暗示而不是明示。例如，大量伟大的抒情诗——也许甚至是其中的大部分——都是关于爱情与时间、生与死、短暂事物的美丽与永恒的胜利之间的冲突。但这些词在诗中可能没有提到。

In most good lyrics there is some kind of conflict. Some times two antagonists—either individual people, or images, or ideas—are named, and then the conflict between them is described. If so, this is easy to discover. But often the conflict is only implied and not stated. For example, a large number of great lyric poems—perhaps even the majority of them—are about the conflict between love and time, between life and death, between the beauty of transient things and the triumph of eternity. But these words may not be mentioned in the poem itself.

据说几乎所有莎士比亚的十四行诗都是关于他所谓的“吞噬时间”的蹂躏。很明显，其中一些是，因为他一再明确地说。

It has been said that almost all of Shakespeare’s sonnets are about the ravages of what he calls “Devouring time.” It is clear that some of them are, for he explicitly says so again and again.

当我看到被时间的手弄脏

了陈旧的埋葬年龄的富有骄傲的代价

When I have seen by Time’s fell hand defacedThe rich-proud cost of outworn buried age

 

他在第 64 首十四行诗中写道，并列出了时间战胜一切的其他胜利，人类希望证明这一点。然后他说：

he writes in the 64th sonnet and lists other victories that time gains over all that man wishes were proof against it. Then he says:

毁灭教会我如此反省，

那个时候会到来，带走我的爱。

Ruin hath taught me thus to ruminate,That Time will come and take my love away.

 

毫无疑问，那首十四行诗是关于什么的。与著名的第 116 首十四行诗类似，其中包含以下几行：

There is no question what that sonnet is about. Similarly with the famous 116th sonnet, which contains these lines:

爱情不是时间的傻瓜，虽然玫瑰色的嘴唇和脸颊

在他弯曲的镰刀的罗盘中；

爱情不会随着他短暂的几个小时和几个星期而改变，

但甚至会在厄运的边缘证明它。

Love’s not Time’s fool, though rosy lips and cheeksWithin his bending sickle’s compass come;Love alters not with his brief hours and weeks,But bears it out even to the edge of doom.

 

但是几乎同样著名的第 138 首十四行诗，它的开头是：

But the almost equally famous 138th sonnet, which begins with the lines:

当我的爱人发誓说她是真实的

我相信她，尽管我知道她在撒谎，

When my love swears that she is made of truthI do believe her, though I know she lies,

 

同样是关于爱情与时间的冲突，虽然诗中没有出现“时间”这个词。

is also about the conflict between love and time, although the word “time” appears nowhere in the poem.

你会毫不费力地看到。也不难看出 Marvell 著名的抒情诗“To His Coy Mistress”也是关于同一主题的，因为他在开头就明确指出了这一点：

That you will see without much difficulty. Nor is there any difficulty in seeing that Marvell’s celebrated lyric “To His Coy Mistress” is about the same subject, for he makes this clear right at the beginning:

如果我们的世界和时间够

多， 女士，这种羞怯就不是犯罪。

Had we but world enough, and time,This coyness, lady, were no crime.

 

Marvell 说，我们并没有拥有世界上所有的时间——因为

We do not have all the time in the world, Marvell says—for

......在我的背后，我总是听到

时间的有翼战车急匆匆地靠近；

在我们面前

的是广袤无垠的沙漠。

… at my back I always hearTime’s wingèd chariot hurrying near;And yonder all before us lieDeserts of vast eternity.

 

因此，他恳求他的情妇，

Therefore, he adjures his mistress,

让我们把我们所有的力量和我们所有

的甜蜜都揉成一团，

用粗暴的斗争撕裂我们的快乐穿过

生命的铁门。

因此，虽然我们不能让我们的太阳

静止不动，但我们会让他运行。

Let us roll all our strength and allOur sweetness up into one ball,And tear our pleasures with rough strifeThorough the iron gates of life.Thus, though we cannot make our sunStand still, yet we will make him run.

 

或许很难看出阿奇博尔德·麦克利什 (Archibald MacLeish) 的“你，安德鲁·马维尔 (You, Andrew Marvell)”的主题完全相同。诗开头：

It is perhaps a bit harder to see that the subject of “You, Andrew Marvell,” by Archibald MacLeish, is exactly the same. The poem begins:

在这里面朝下在太阳下在

这里在地球正午的高度

感受总是来临

的夜晚总是升起

And here face down beneath the sunAnd here upon earth’s noonward heightTo feel the always coming onThe always rising of the night

 

因此，麦克利什让我们想象某个人（诗人？演讲者？读者？）躺在正午的阳光下——但所有的同样，在那明亮和温暖之中，意识到“黄昏的尘世寒冷”。他想象着落日的影子——历史上所有累积的连续落日——穿过世界，穿过波斯和巴格达……他觉得“黎巴嫩消失了，克里特岛消失了”，“西班牙沉没了，海岸/非洲的镀金沙滩”和……“现在海上长长的灯光”也消失了。他总结道：

Thus MacLeish asks us to imagine someone (the poet? the speaker? the reader?) as lying in the noonday sun—but all the same, in the midst of that brightness and warmth, aware of “the earthly chill of dusk.” He imagines the line of the shadow of the setting sun—of all the cumulative successive setting suns of history—moving across the world, across Persia, and Baghdad … he feels “Lebanon fade out and Crete,” “And Spain go under and the shore / Of Africa the gilded sand,” and … “now the long light on the sea” vanishes, too. And he concludes:

在阳光下脸朝下

感受夜的阴影来得多么迅速、多么隐秘

……

And here face downward in the sunTo feel how swift, how secretly,The shadow of the night comes on….

 

诗中没有“时间”二字，也没有提到情人。然而，标题让我们想起了 Marvell 的抒情诗，其主题是“如果我们只有足够的世界和时间”，因此这首诗本身及其标题的组合引发了爱（或生命）与时间之间的同样冲突，即我们在这里考虑的其他诗歌的主题。

The word “time” is not used in the poem, nor is there any mention of a lover. Nevertheless, the title reminds us of Marvell’s lyric with its theme of “Had we but world enough and time,” and thus the combination of the poem itself and its title invokes the same conflict, between love (or life) and time, that was the subject of the other poems we have considered here.

关于阅读抒情诗的最后一条建议。一般来说，此类作品的读者觉得他们必须比实际需要更多地了解作者及其时代。我们非常相信评论、批评、传记——但这可能只是因为我们怀疑自己的阅读能力。几乎每个人都能读懂任何一首诗，只要他肯下功夫。您发现的有关作者生平或时代的任何内容都是有效的，并且可能会有所帮助。但是，对一首诗的上下文有广泛的了解并不能保证这首诗本身会被理解。要理解它必须阅读——一遍又一遍。阅读任何伟大的抒情诗都是一生的工作——当然，并不是说它应该终生继续阅读，而是作为一首伟大的诗歌，它值得多次回访。在一首给定的诗的假期里，

One final piece of advice about reading lyric poems. In general, readers of such works feel that they must know more about the authors and their times than they really have to. We put much faith in commentaries, criticism, biographies—but this may be only because we doubt our own ability to read. Almost everyone can read any poem, if he will go to work on it. Anything you discover about an author’s life or times is valid and may be helpful. But a vast knowledge of the context of a poem is no guarantee that the poem itself will be understood. To be understood it must be read—over and over. Reading any great lyric poem is a lifetime job—not, of course, in the sense that it should go on and on throughout a lifetime, but rather that as a great poem, it deserves many return visits. And during vacations from a given poem, we may learn more about it than we realize.

16

如何阅读历史

16HOW TO READ HISTORY

 

“历史”和“诗歌”一样，是一个具有多种含义的词。为了使本章对你有用，我们必须就这个词与你达成共识——也就是说，解释我们将如何使用它。

“History,” like “poetry,” is a word of many meanings. In order for this chapter to be useful to you, we must come to terms with you about the word—that is, explain how we will be using it.

首先，作为事实的历史与作为对事实的书面记录的历史是有区别的。在这里，我们显然是在后一种意义上使用该术语，因为在我们的“阅读”意义上，您无法阅读事实。但是有许多种被称为历史的书面记录。与某个事件或时期有关的一系列文件可以称为它的历史。与参与者的口头访谈记录或此类记录的集合，可以类似地称为他或他们参与的事件的历史。具有完全不同意图的作品，例如个人日记或信件集，可以被解释为当时的历史。这个词可以适用，而且确实已经适用于几乎所有起源于某个时期的文字，

First of all, there is the difference between history as fact and history as a written record of the facts. We are obviously, here, employing the term in the latter sense, since in our sense of “read” you cannot read facts. But there are many kinds of written record that are called historical. A collection of documents pertaining to a certain event or period could be called a history of it. A transcription of an oral interview with a participant, or a collection of such transcriptions, could similarly be called a history of the event in which he or they participated. A work having quite a different intention, such as a personal diary or collection of letters, could be construed as being a history of the time. The word could be applied, and indeed has been applied, to almost every kind of writing that originated in a time period, or in the context of an event, in which the reader was interested.

我们在下文中使用“历史”一词的含义比其中任何一个都更狭义和更广泛。它之所以狭窄，是因为我们想将自己限制在以或多或少正式的方式呈现的本质上的叙述性叙述中，过去的一个时期或事件或一系列事件。这是该术语的传统用法，我们不会为此道歉。同样，正如我们对抒情诗的定义一样，我们认为您会同意我们的看法，即这是该术语的普通含义，我们在这里要坚持普通。

The sense in which we use the word “history” in what follows is both narrower and broader than any of those. It is narrower because we want to restrict ourselves to essentially narrative accounts, presented in a more or less formal manner, of a period or event or series of events in the past. This is a traditional use of the term, and we do not apologize for it. Again, as with our definition of lyric poetry, we think you will agree with us that this is the ordinary meaning of the term, and we want to stick to the ordinary here.

但我们的含义也比当今流行的该术语的许多定义更广泛。我们认为，尽管并非所有历史学家都同意我们的看法，但历史的本质是叙述，“故事”这个词的最后五个字母有助于我们理解其基本含义。即使是文档集，作为一个集合，也会讲述一个故事。这个故事可能并不明确——也就是说，历史学家可能会尽量不以任何“有意义的”顺序排列文件。但无论它们是否有序，它都隐含在它们之中。否则，我们认为，该系列不会被称为其时代的历史。

But our meaning is also broader than many of the definitions of the term that are current today. We think, although not all historians agree with us, that the essence of history is narration, that the last five letters of the word—“story”—help us to understand the basic meaning. Even a collection of documents, as a collection, tells a story. That story may not be explicit—that is, the historian may try not to arrange the documents in any “meaningful” order. But it is implicit in them, whether they are ordered or not. Otherwise, we think, the collection would not be called a history of its time.

然而，是否所有历史学家都同意我们关于历史是什么的概念并不重要。我们正在讨论的这类历史有很多，您将希望或必须至少阅读其中的一部分。我们将尽力帮助您完成这项任务。

It is not important, however, whether all historians agree with us in our notion of what history is. There is a great deal of history of the kind we are discussing, and you will want to or have to read at least some of it. We will try to aid you in that task.

历史事实的难以捉摸

The Elusiveness of Historical Facts

 

可能你曾经是陪审团的成员，听过关于一个简单事实的证词，比如一场车祸。或者，您可能曾在最高荣誉的陪审团中任职，必须决定一个人是否杀了另一个人。如果你做过任何一件事情，你就会知道从亲眼目睹的人的记忆中重建过去是多么困难，即使是过去的单一事件。

Probably you have been a member of a jury, listening to the testimony about a simple matter of fact, such as an automobile accident. Or you may have been on a blue ribbon jury, and have had to decide whether one person killed another or not. If you have done either, you know how difficult it is to reconstruct the past, even a single event in the past, from the memories of persons who actually saw it happen.

法院关注的是最近发生的事件，并且有在场证人在场。此外，还有严格的证据规则。证人不能假设任何事情，他不能猜测、假设或估计（除非在非常小心控制的条件下）。当然，他不应该撒谎。

A court concerns itself with events that have happened fairly recently and in the presence of living witnesses. In addition, there are stringent rules of evidence. A witness cannot suppose anything, he cannot guess or hypothecate or estimate (except under very carefully controlled conditions). And of course he is not supposed to lie.

有了所有仔细的证据规则，再加上交叉询问，作为陪审团的一员，你是否绝对确定你真的知道发生了什么？

With all the careful rules of evidence, and cross-examination besides, have you ever been absolutely sure, as a member of a jury, that you really knew what happened?

法律假定您不会绝对确定。它假设陪审员心中总会有一些疑问。作为一个实践问题，为了以一种或另一种方式决定审判，它说怀疑必须是“合理的”，如果它被允许影响你的判断。换句话说，怀疑必须足以困扰你的良心。

The law assumes that you will not be absolutely sure. It assumes that there will always be some doubt in a juror’s mind. As a matter of practice, in order that trials may be decided one way or the other, it says that the doubt must be “reasonable” if it is to be allowed to affect your judgment. The doubt must be, in other words, sufficient to trouble your conscience.

历史学家关心的是发生在很久以前的事件，其中大部分发生在很久以前。事件的所有目击者通常都已经死了。他们提供的证据不是在法庭上提供的——也就是说，它不受严格和谨慎的规则约束。这样的证人通常有猜测、假设、估计、假设和假设。我们无法通过看他们的脸来判断他们是否在撒谎（如果我们真的能了解任何人的话）。他们没有经过盘问。并且不能保证他们知道他们在说什么。

A historian is concerned with events that occurred, most of them, a long time ago. All the witnesses to the events are usually dead. What evidence they give is not given in a courtroom—that is, it is not governed by stringent and careful rules. Such witnesses as there are often guess, hypothecate, estimate, assume, and suppose. We cannot see their faces in order to judge whether they are lying (if we ever really can know that about anybody). They are not cross-examined. And there is no guarantee whatever that they know what they are talking about.

那么，如果很难确定一个人是否知道一件相对简单的事情的真相，例如法庭上由陪审团决定的事情，那么了解历史上真正发生的事情就更难了。历史事实，尽管我们可能对这个词有一种信任和坚定的感觉，但却是世界上最难以捉摸的事物之一。

If, then, it is difficult to be sure that one knows about the truth of a relatively simple matter, such as is decided by a jury in a court of law, how much more difficult it is to know what really happened in history. A historical fact, though we may have a feeling of trust and solidity about the word, is one of the most elusive things in the world.

当然，对于某些历史事实，我们是可以相当确定的。美国卷入了一场内战，这场内战始于 1861 年 4 月 12 日对萨姆特堡的射击，结束于 1865 年 4 月 9 日李将军在阿波马托克斯法院大楼向格兰特将军投降。每个人都同意这些日期。当时不太可能（尽管并非完全不可能）每个美国日历都不正确。

Of course, about some kinds of historical fact we can be pretty certain. America was involved in a Civil War that began with the firing on Fort Sumter, on April 12, 1861, and ended with the surrender of General Lee to General Grant at Appomattox Court House, on April 9, 1865. Everyone agrees about those dates. It is not likely (though it is not totally impossible) that every American calendar was incorrect at that time.

但是如果我们确切地知道什么时候我们学到了多少内战开始，何时结束？的确，这些日期是有争议的 - 不是为了日历是错误的，而是战争确实始于1860年秋天林肯的选举，并在李投降后五天以他的暗杀结束。其他人声称这场战争甚至更早开始——在 1861 年之前的五年、十年或二十年——我们知道它实际上仍在美国的边远地区进行，北方的消息还没有传来胜利，迟至 1865 年 5 月、6 月和 7 月。还有一些人认为内战还没有结束，直到美国黑人完全自由和平等，或者直到南方设法脱离联盟，

But how much have we learned if we know exactly when the Civil War started and when it ended? Indeed, those dates have been disputed—not on the grounds that the calendars were wrong, but that the war really started with the election of Lincoln in the fall of 1860 and ended with his assassination five days after Lee’s surrender. Others have claimed that the war started even earlier—as much as five or ten or twenty years before 1861—and we know that it was still actually being fought in outlying parts of the United States, to which word had not yet come of the Northern triumph, as late as May, June, and July, 1865. And there are those, too, who feel that the Civil War is not over yet, that it will never be over until black Americans are completely free and equal, or until the South manages to secede from the Union, or until the right of the federal government to control all the states is finally established and accepted by every American everywhere.

至少我们确实知道，有人可能会说，无论对萨姆特堡的射击是否引发了内战，它确实发生在 1861 年 4 月 12 日。这是真的——在我们之前提到的可能性范围内。但为什么萨姆特被解雇了？这是一个显而易见的下一个问题。袭击发生后还能避免战争吗？如果是的话，我们会在意一个多世纪前的某个春日发生了这样那样的袭击吗？如果我们不关心——而且我们不关心许多对堡垒的袭击，这些袭击无疑已经发生，但我们对此一无所知——向萨姆特开火还会是一个重要的历史事实吗？

At least we do know, one might say, that whether or not the firing on Fort Sumter started the Civil War, it did occur on April 12, 1861. That is true—within the limits of possibility we referred to before. But why was Sumter fired on? That is an obvious next question. And could war still have been avoided after the attack? If it had been, would we care that such and such an assault occurred on such and such a spring day more than a century ago? If we did not care—and we do not care about many attacks on forts that have doubtless occurred, but about which we know nothing whatever—would the firing on Sumter still be a significant historical fact?

历史理论

Theories of History

 

我们将历史、过去的故事归类为虚构而非科学——如果它必须与其中一个或另一个相关联的话。如果不是，如果允许历史介于这两类书籍的主要部分之间，那么人们通常会承认，历史更接近小说而不是科学。

We class history, the story of the past, more often under fiction than under science—if it must be affiliated with one or the other. If not, if history, that is, is allowed to rest somewhere in between the two main divisions of the kinds of books, then it is usually admitted that history is closer to fiction than to science.

这并不意味着历史学家编造他的事实，就像诗人或讲故事的人。但是，如果我们过分坚持认为小说家捏造事实，我们可能会遇到麻烦。正如我们所说，他创造了一个世界。但是这个新世界与我们自己的世界并没有完全不同——事实上，最好不要完全不同——诗人是一个普通人，他拥有普通的感官，并通过这些普通的感官来学习。他看不到我们看不到的东西（他可能看得更清楚或以稍微不同的方式）。他的角色使用我们使用的词（否则我们无法相信他们）。只有在梦中，人类才能创造出真正奇特的新世界——但即使在最奇幻的梦中，想象中的事件和生物也是由日常经验的元素构成的。它们只是以奇怪的新方式组合在一起。

This does not mean that a historian makes up his facts, like a poet or story teller. However, we might get into trouble if we insisted too strongly that a writer of fiction makes up his facts. He creates a world, as we have said. But this new world is not totally different from our own—indeed, it had better not be—and a poet is an ordinary man, with ordinary senses by and through which he has learned. He does not see things that we cannot see (he may see better or in a slightly different way). His characters use words that we use (otherwise we could not believe in them). It is only in dreams that human beings create really strange new worlds—yet even in the most fantastic dream the events and creatures of the imagination are made up out of elements of everyday experience. They are merely put together in strange new ways.

当然，好的历史学家不会编造过去。他认为自己有责任受某些概念或准确性或事实标准的约束。然而，重要的是要记住，历史学家必须总是编造一些东西。他必须要么在事件中找到一种普遍模式，要么将一种模式强加于事件；或者他必须假设他知道为什么他故事中的人会做他们所做的事情。他可能有一个普遍的理论或哲学，例如普罗维登斯统治人类事务，并使他的历史符合这一点。或者，他可能会放弃任何此类似乎是从外部或上面强加的模式，而是坚持认为他只是在报告已经发生的真实事件。但在那种情况下，他很可能被迫为事件分配原因和行动动机。必须认识到您正在阅读的历史学家的运作方式。

A good historian does not, of course, make up the past. He considers himself responsibly bound by some concept or criterion of accuracy or facts. Nevertheless, it is important to remember that the historian must always make up something. He must either find a general pattern in, or impose one on, events; or he must suppose that he knows why the persons in his story did the things they did. He may have a general theory or philosophy, such as that Providence rules human affairs, and make his history fit that. Or he may abjure any such pattern, imposed as it were from the outside or above, and instead insist that he is merely reporting the real events that have occurred. But in that case he is likely to be forced to assign causes for events and motivations for actions. It is essential to recognize which way the historian you are reading is operating.

避免采取一种或另一种立场的唯一方法是假设人们做事不是为了某种目的，或者这种目的，如果存在的话，是无法被发现的——换句话说，历史根本没有模式.

The only way to avoid taking either one or the other position is to assume that men do not do things for a purpose, or that the purpose, if it exists, is undiscoverable—in other words, that there is no pattern to history at all.

托尔斯泰有这样一个历史学说。当然，他不是历史学家。他是个小说家。但许多历史学家持有相同的观点，尤其是在现代。这托尔斯泰认为，每一个人类行为的原因是如此多方面、如此复杂，并且如此深藏在无意识的动机中，以至于不可能知道为什么会发生任何事情。

Tolstoy had such a theory about history. He was not a historian, of course; he was a novelist. But many historians have held the same view, particularly in modern times. The causes of every human action, Tolstoy thought, were so manifold, so complex, and so deeply hidden in unconscious motivations that it is impossible to know why anything ever happened.

因为历史理论各不相同，也因为历史学家的理论会影响他对事件的描述，所以如果我们想理解一个事件或时期的历史，就必须阅读不止一种。的确，这是读史的第一条法则。如果我们感兴趣的事件对我们有实际意义，那就更重要了。对于所有美国人来说，了解一些内战的历史可能具有实际意义。我们仍然生活在那场巨大而令人遗憾的冲突的回波中；我们生活在一个它帮助创造的世界里。但是，如果我们只从一个人、一个方面、一个派系的现代学院派历史学家的角度来看，我们是不可能理解它的。前几天，我们打开了一本新的内战史，并注意到它的作者将其描述为“一部公正的、从南方的角度看内战的客观历史。” 作者似乎是认真的。也许他是；也许这样的事情是可能的。无论如何，我们承认每一个叙事历史都必​​须从一些观点。但要了解真相，我们应该从多个角度来看。

Because theories of history differ, and because a historian’s theory affects his account of events, it is necessary to read more than one account of the history of an event or period if we want to understand it. Indeed, this is the first rule of reading history. And it is all the more important if the event in which we are interested has practical significance for us. It is probably of practical significance to all Americans that they know something about the history of the Civil War. We still live in the backwash of that great and sorry conflict; we live in a world it helped to make. But we cannot hope to understand it if we look at it through the eyes of only one man, or one side, or one faction of modern academic historians. The other day we opened a new Civil War history and noted that its author offered it as “an impartial, objective history of the Civil War from the point of view of the South.” The author appeared to be serious. Maybe he was; maybe such a thing is possible. At any rate, we would admit that every narrative history has to be written from some point of view. But to get at the truth, we ought to look at it from more than one viewpoint.

历史上的普遍性

The Universal in History

 

我们并不总是能够阅读多个事件的历史。如果不是，我们必须承认我们没有多少机会了解所讨论事情的真相——了解真正发生的事情。然而，这并不是阅读历史的唯一原因。可能有人会说，只有专业的历史学家，也就是自己写历史的人，才需要通过详尽地核对来源来交叉检验他的资料来源。如果他想知道关于他的主题他应该知道什么，他必须千方百计。作为历史的外行读者，我们站在两者之间一方面是专业的历史学家，另一方面是不负责任的业余爱好者，他们阅读历史只是为了消遣。

We are not always able to read more than one history of an event. When we are not, we must admit that we do not have much chance of learning the truth of the matter in question—of learning what really happened. However, that is not the only reason to read history. It might be claimed that only the professional historian, the man who is writing a history himself, is required to cross-examine his sources by exhaustively checking one against the other. He must leave no stone unturned if he is to know what he ought to know about his subject. We, as lay readers of history, stand somewhere between the professional historian, on the one hand, and the irresponsible amateur, on the other hand, who reads history only for amusement.

让我们以修昔底德为例。您可能知道，他在公元前五世纪末写下了伯罗奔尼撒战争唯一一部重要的当代史。从某种意义上说，没有什么可以检查他的工作。那么，我们可以期望从中学到什么？

Let us take the example of Thucydides. You may be aware that he wrote the only major contemporary history of the Peloponnesian War at the end of the fifth century B.C. In a sense, there is nothing to check his work against. What, then, can we expect to learn from it?

希腊现在是一个小国；二十五个世纪前在那里发生的一场战争对我们今天的生活几乎没有实际影响。在其中战斗的人都早已死去，他们为之战斗的具体事物也早已死去。胜利现在毫无意义，失败也没有痛苦。被占领和丢失的城市已经化为尘土。事实上，如果我们停下来想一想，几乎所有伯罗奔尼撒战争的遗迹都是修昔底德对它的描述。

Greece is now a tiny country; a war that occurred there twenty-five centuries ago can have little real effect on our life today. Everyone who fought in it is long dead, and the specific things for which they fought are long dead, too. The victories are now meaningless, and the defeats without pain. The cities that were taken and lost have crumbled into dust. Indeed, if we stop to think of it, almost all that remains of the Peloponnesian War is Thucydides’ account of it.

然而，该帐户仍然很重要。因为修昔底德的故事——我们不妨使用这个词——对后来的人类历史产生了影响。后来时代的领导者阅读修昔底德。当他们发现自己所处的处境甚至与悲惨分裂的希腊城邦的处境有几分相似时，他们便将自己的处境与雅典或斯巴达相提并论。他们把修昔底德当作借口和理由，甚至当作一种行为模式。结果是，在公元前五世纪，修昔底德 (Thucydides) 对世界历史的一小部分持有的观点改变了世界历史，也许是微乎其微，但可以察觉. 因此，我们读修昔底德并不是因为他完美地描述了他写书之前发生的事情，而是因为他在一定程度上决定了之后发生的事情。我们读他，虽然这看起来很奇怪，但知道现在发生了什么。

Yet that account is still important. For Thucydides’ story —we might as well use that word—has had an influence on the subsequent history of man. Leaders in later eras read Thucydides. When they found themselves in situations that even faintly approximated that of the tragically divided Greek city-states, they compared their own position to that of Athens or Sparta. They used Thucydides as an excuse and a justification, and even as a pattern of conduct. The result was that by ever so little, perhaps, but perceptibly, the history of the world was changed by the view held of a small portion of it by Thucydides in the fifth century B.C. Thus we read Thucydides not because he described perfectly what happened before he wrote his book, but because he to a certain extent determined what happened after. And we read him, strange as this may seem, to know what is happening now.

“诗歌比历史更具哲学性，”亚里士多德写道。他的意思是诗歌更普遍，更普遍。一首好诗不仅在它自己的时间和地点是真实的，而且在所有的时间和地点都是真实的。它对所有人都有意义和力量。历史并不像那样普遍。它以诗歌所没有的方式与事件联系在一起。但任何好的历史也是普遍的。

“Poetry is more philosophical than history,” wrote Aristotle. By this he meant that poetry is more general, more universal. A good poem is true not only in its own time and place, but in all times and places. It has meaning and force for all men. History is not quite so universal as that. It is tied to events in a way that poetry is not. But any good history is also universal.

修昔底德自己说，他正在写他的历史，这样未来的人就不必重蹈他亲眼所见的错误，以及他个人和他的国家所遭受的痛苦。他描述了人类错误的种类，这些错误对他以外的人，对希腊人以外的人都有意义。然而，雅典人和斯巴达人在 2500 年前所犯的一些错误，或者至少是非常相似的错误，现在正在犯，因为自修昔底德时代以来，这些错误一再犯。

Thucydides himself said that he was writing his history so that men of the future would not have to repeat the mistakes he had seen made and from which he had suffered personally and through the agony of his country. He described the kinds of human mistakes that would have meaning to men other than himself, to men other than Greeks. Yet some of the very same errors that the Athenians and the Spartans made 2,500 years ago, or at least very similar ones, are being made now, as they have been made over and over again since Thucydides’ time.

如果你对历史的看法是有限的，如果你只是为了发现真正发生的事情而去看它，你就不会学到修昔底德，或者任何一位优秀的历史学家必须教授的主要内容。如果你读得好修昔底德，你甚至可能会决定放弃尝试发现过去真正发生的事情。

If your view of history is limited, if you go to it to discover only what really happened, you will not learn the main thing that Thucydides, or indeed any good historian, has to teach. If you read Thucydides well, you may even decide to give up trying to discover what really happened in the past.

历史是导致现在发生的事情的故事。我们感兴趣的是现在——那个和未来。未来将部分由现在决定。因此，你也可以从历史学家那里了解一些关于未来的事情，甚至可以从像修昔底德这样生活在两千多年前的人那里了解到。

History is the story of what led up to now. It is the present that interests us—that and the future. The future will be partly determined by the present. Thus, you can learn something about the future, too, from a historian, even from one who like Thucydides lived more than two thousand years ago.

让我们总结这两条阅读历史的建议。第一个是：如果可以的话，多读一本你感兴趣的事件或时期的历史。二是：读历史不仅要了解过去特定时间和地点的真实情况，还要了解古今中外的人的行为方式。

Let us sum up these two suggestions for reading history. The first is: if you can, read more than one history of an event or period that interests you. The second is: read a history not only to learn what really happened at a particular time and place in the past, but also to learn the way men act in all times and places, especially now.

历史书要问的问题

Questions to Ask of a Historical Book

 

尽管大多数历史更接近虚构而不是科学，但它们可以作为说明性作品来阅读，因此它们应该如此。因此，我们必须向历史书提出我们向任何说明性书籍提出的相同问题。由于历史的特殊性，我们必须以不同的方式提出这些问题，并且必须期望得到略有不同的答案。

Despite the fact that most histories are closer to fiction than to science, they can be read as expository works, and therefore they should be. Hence, we must ask the same questions of a historical book that we ask of any expository book. Because of the special nature of history, we must ask those questions a little differently and must expect to receive slightly different kinds of answers.

就第一个问题而言，每一部历史都有一个特定的、有限的主题。令人惊讶的是，读者经常不费心去找出这是什么。特别是，他们并不总是仔细注意作者为自己设置的限制。内战史不是 19 世纪的世界史。它可能不会成为 1860 年代美国西部的历史。它可以，尽管也许不应该，忽视那十年美国教育的状况，或者美国边境的运动，或者美国自由的进步。因此，如果我们要读好一部历史，就必须准确地知道它是关于什么的，它不是关于什么的。当然，如果我们要批评它，我们必须知道后者。不能因为作者没有做他没有尝试做的事而受到指责。

As far as the first question is concerned, every history has a particular and limited subject. It is surprising, then, how often readers do not trouble to find out what this is. In particular, they do not always note carefully what limitations the author sets for himself. A history of the Civil War is not a history of the world in the nineteenth century. It probably will not be a history of the American West in the 1860’s. It could, though perhaps it should not, ignore the state of American education in that decade, or the movement of the American frontier, or the progress of American freedom. Hence, if we are to read a history well, it is necessary to know precisely what it is about and what it is not about. Certainly, if we are to criticize it, we must know the latter. An author cannot be blamed for not doing what he did not try to do.

关于第二个问题，历史学家讲了一个故事，这个故事当然是及时发生的。它的大体轮廓就这样确定了，我们不必去寻找它们。但是讲故事的方式不止一种，我们必须知道历史学家选择了怎样的方式来讲述他的故事。他是否将自己的作品分成与几年、几十年或几代人相对应的章节？还是他根据自己选择的其他标准来划分？他是否在一章中讨论了他那个时期的经济史，而在其他章节中涵盖了战争、宗教运动和文学作品？其中哪一个对他来说最重要？如果我们发现这一点，如果我们能说出他所讲述的故事的哪个方面对他来说是最基本的，我们就能更好地理解他。我们可能不同意他关于什么是基本的判断，

With regard to the second question, the historian tells a story, and that story, of course, occurred in time. Its general outlines are thus determined, and we do not have to search for them. But there is more than one way to tell a story, and we must know how the historian has chosen to tell his. Does he divide his work into chapters that correspond to years or decades or generations? Or does he divide it according to other rubrics of his own choosing? Does he discuss, in one chapter, the economic history of his period, and cover its wars and religious movements and literary productions in others? Which of these is most important to him? If we discover that, if we can say which aspect of the story he is telling seems to him most fundamental, we can understand him better. We may not agree with his judgment about what is basic, but we can still learn from him.

对历史的批判有两种形式。我们可以判断——但一如既往，只有在我们理解了所说的内容之后——历史学家的作品缺乏真实性。人们只是不那样做，我们可能会觉得。即使历史学家通过让我们接触他的资料来记录他的陈述，即使据我们所知它们是相关的，我们仍然可以感觉到他误解了它们，他对它们的判断是错误的方式，也许是由于他对人性或人类事务的把握存在某种缺陷。例如，我们倾向于对许多年长的历史学家有这种感觉，他们在他们的著作中没有过多地讨论经济问题。我们现在可能倾向于认为，人们的行为是出于自身利益；过分高贵地赋予历史的“英雄”可能会让我们产生怀疑。

Criticism of history takes two forms. We can judge—but only, as always, after we understand what is being said—that a historian’s work lacks verisimilitude. People just do not act that way, we may feel. Even if the historian documents his statements by giving us access to his sources, and even if to our knowledge they are relevant, we can still feel that he has misunderstood them, that he has judged them in the wrong way, perhaps through some deficiency in his grasp of human nature or human affairs. We tend to feel this, for example, about many older historians who do not include much discussion of economic matters in their work. People, we may be inclined to think now, act out of self-interest; too much nobility ascribed to the “hero” of a history may make us suspicious.

另一方面，我们可能会认为，特别是如果我们对这个主题有一些特殊的了解，历史学家滥用了他的资料来源。我们可能会气愤地发现他没有读过我们读过的某本书。并且他可能对事情的真相有错误的了解。那样的话，他不可能写出一部好的历史。我们希望历史学家被告知。

On the other hand, we may think, especially if we have some special knowledge of the subject, that the historian has misused his sources. We may be indignant to discover that he has not read a certain book that we have read. And he may be misinformed about the facts of the matter. In that case, he cannot have written a good history of it. We expect a historian to be informed.

然而，第一个批评更为重要。一个好的历史学家必须结合讲故事的人和科学家的才能。他必须知道可能发生的事情以及一些目击者或作家所说的实际发生的事情。

The first criticism is, however, more important. A good historian must combine the talents of the storyteller and the scientist. He must know what is likely to have happened as well as what some witnesses or writers said actually did happen.

关于最后一个问题“它是什么？”，可能没有一种文学比历史对人类行为的影响更大。讽刺和哲学乌托邦的图画收效甚微；我们都希望世界变得更美好，但我们很少会受到作者们的建议的启发，他们只是描述（通常是痛苦地）现实与理想之间的差异。历史告诉我们过去的人的行为，经常会引导我们做出改变，努力改善我们的命运。总的来说，政治家在历史上的博学多于在其他学科上的博学。历史表明了可能性，因为它描述了已经完成的事情。如果它们已经完成，也许它们可以再做一次——或者它们可以避免。

With regard to the last question, What of it?, it is possible that no kind of literature has a greater effect on the actions of men than history. Satires and pictures of philosophical utopias have little effect; we would all like the world to be better, but we are seldom inspired by the recommendations of authors who do no more than describe, often bitterly, the difference between the real and the ideal. History, which tells us of the actions of men of the past, often does lead us to make changes, to try to better our lot. In general, statesmen have been more learned in history than in other disciplines. History suggests the possible, for it describes things that have already been done. If they have been done, perhaps they can be done again —or perhaps they can be avoided.

因此，对“它是什么？”这个问题的主要回答在于实际的政治行动的方向。因此，读好历史非常重要。不幸的是，领导人的行动往往带有一些历史知识，但还不够。世界小而危险现在，我们所有人开始更好地阅读历史将是一个好主意。

The main answer to the question, What of it?, therefore, lies in the direction of practical, political action. For this reason it is of great importance that history be read well. Unfortunately, leaders have often acted with some knowledge of history but not enough. With the world as small and dangerous as it has become, it would be a good idea for all of us to start reading history better.

如何阅读传记和自传

How to Read Biography and Autobiography

 

传记是关于一个真实人物的故事。这种混合的遗产使它具有混合的特征。

A biography is a story about a real person. This mixed patrimony causes it to have a mixed character.

一些传记作家会反对这种描述。但通常至少，传记是对一个男人或女人或一群人的生活、历史的叙述；因此，传记提出了许多与历史相同的问题。读者必须问同样的问题——作者的目的是什么？他的真理标准是什么？——当然，也包括我们对任何一本书都必须提出的问题。

Some biographers would object to this description. But ordinarily, at least, a biography is a narrative account of the life, the history, of a man or woman or of a group of people; thus, a biography poses many of the same problems as a history. The reader must ask the same sort of questions—what is the author’s purpose? What are his criteria of truth?—as well, of course, as asking the questions we must ask of any book.

有几种传记。权威传记旨在成为关于某个重要人物生平的最终、详尽的学术著作，值得一部权威传记。权威的传记不能写在活人身上。在几本非权威传记首次出现之前，它们很少被写出来，所有这些传记往往都有些不足。查阅了所有资料来源，阅读了所有信件，并且作者审查了大量当代历史。由于收集材料的能力与将它们塑造成一本好书的才能有些不同，因此权威的传记并不总是容易阅读。这太糟糕了。一本学术著作不必枯燥乏味。最伟大的传记之一是博斯韦尔的约翰逊传，它一直令人着迷。它当然是权威的（尽管后来出现了约翰逊博士的其他传记），但它也非常有趣。

There are several kinds of biographies. The definitive biography is intended to be the final, exhaustive, scholarly work on the life of someone important enough to deserve a definitive biography. Definitive biographies cannot be written about living persons. They are seldom written until several non-definitive biographies have first appeared, all of them often somewhat inadequate. All sources are gone through, all letters read, and a great deal of contemporary history examined by the author. Since the ability to gather the materials is somewhat different from the talent for shaping them into a good book, definitive biographies are not always easy reading. This is too bad. A scholarly book does not have to be dull. One of the greatest of all biographies is Boswell’s Life of Johnson, and it is continuously fascinating. It is certainly definitive (though other biographies of Dr. Johnson have since appeared), but it is also uniquely interesting.

权威的传记是历史的一部分——通过他的眼睛看到的一个人和他所处时代的历史。它应该作为历史来阅读。授权传记根本不是一回事。此类作品通常由继承人委托或一些重要人物的朋友，他们被仔细地写下来，以便以最好的方式看到这个人所犯的错误和他取得的胜利。它们有时确实非常好，因为作者有优势——不是其他作家通常享有的优势——被控制它的人允许访问所有相关材料。但是，当然，授权传记不能像权威传记那样值得信赖。读者不应将其简单地当作历史来阅读，而应理解它可能有偏见——这是读者对本书主题的看法；这是他的朋友和同事希望他为世人所知的方式。

A definitive biography is a slice of history—the history of a man and of his times, as seen through his eyes. It should be read as history. An authorized biography is not the same thing at all. Such works are usually commissioned by the heirs or friends of some important person, and they are carefully written so that the errors the person made and the triumphs he achieved are seen in the best light possible. They can sometimes be very good indeed, because the author has the advantage—not as a rule accorded to other writers—of being allowed access to all pertinent material by those who control it. But, of course, an authorized biography cannot be trusted in the same way that a definitive biography can be. Instead of reading it simply as history, the reader should understand that it may be biased—that this is the way the reader is expected to think of the book’s subject; this is the way his friends and associates want him to be known to the world.

正传是一种历史，但又是有区别的历史。我们可能很想知道感兴趣的人希望公众了解某人的私人生活，但我们不应该期望知道私人生活到底是什么。因此，一本授权传记的阅读通常会告诉我们很多关于它的写作时间、它的习俗和举止、那些可以接受的行为和态度——以及，通过暗示和一点推断，关于那些是不是。但是，如果我们只阅读一方的公报，我们就不应该希望发现一个人的真实生活，就像我们不希望了解一场战争的真实故事一样。要弄清真相，我们必须阅读所有的公报，询问当时在场的人，并用我们自己的头脑从混乱中理清头绪。一本权威的传记已经完成了这项工作；在授权传记的情况下（大多数在世人的传记都是这种类型的），还有很多工作要做。

The authorized biography is a kind of history, but it is history with a difference. We may be curious to know what interested persons want the public to know about someone’s private life, but we should not expect to know what the private life really was. The reading of an authorized biography will thus often tell us much about the time in which it was written, about its customs and manners, about those actions and attitudes that were acceptable—and, by implication and with a little extrapolation, about those that were not. But we should not hope to discover the real life of a human being any more than we would hope to know the real story of a war if we read the communiqués of only one side. To get at the truth we must read all the communiqués, ask people who were there, and use our own minds to make sense out of the muddle. A definitive biography has already done this work; in the case of an authorized biography (and most biographies of living persons are of this sort), there is still much to do.

仍然有那些传记既不是权威的也不是授权的。也许我们可以称它们为普通的传记。在这样的作品中，我们期望作者是准确的，了解他的事实。最重要的是，我们希望有一种感觉，那就是我们正在另一个时空观看一个真实人物的生活。人类是好奇的，尤其是对其他人好奇。

There remain those biographies that are neither definitive nor authorized. Perhaps we may call them ordinary biographies. In such works, we expect the author to be accurate, to know his facts. We want above all to be given the feeling that we are viewing the life of a real person in another time and place. Human beings are curious, and especially curious about other human beings.

这些书虽然不像权威传记那样值得信赖，但通常是非常好的读物。如果没有艾萨克·沃尔顿 (Izaak Walton) 的朋友，例如诗人约翰·多恩 (John Donne) 和乔治·赫伯特 (George Herbert)的生活，世界将变得更加贫穷（沃尔顿当然以他的 The Compleat Angler 而闻名）；或约翰·廷德尔在《发现者法拉第》中对他的朋友迈克尔·法拉第的记述。

Such books, although not trustworthy in the way definitive biographies are, are often very good reading. The world would be the poorer without Izaak Walton’s Lives of his friends, the poets John Donne and George Herbert, for example (Walton is of course better known for his The Compleat Angler); or John Tyndall’s account of his friend Michael Faraday in Faraday the Discoverer.

有些传记是说教的。他们有一个道德目的。这种类型的文章已经不多了，但它们曾经很常见。（当然，它们仍然是为儿童写的。）普鲁塔克的《贵族希腊人和罗马人的生活》就是这样一部作品。普鲁塔克 (Plutarch) 讲述了过去希腊和罗马伟人的故事，以帮助他的同时代人也变得伟大，并帮助他们避免伟人经常犯的错误——或者他是这么认为的。生活_是一本了不起的书；但是，尽管许多记述是我们所掌握的关于他们主题的唯一记述，但我们阅读它的次数与其说是为了了解其传记信息，不如说是为了了解它对一般生活的看法。它的主题是有趣的人，有好有坏，但绝不会无动于衷。普鲁塔克自己意识到了这一点。他说，他写作的初衷是指导别人，但在工作过程中，他发现越来越多的是他自己从“将这些人一个接一个地安置在他的房子里”中获得利益和刺激。 ”

Some biographies are didactic. They have a moral purpose. Not many of this sort are written any more, but they used to be common. (They are still written for children, of course.) Plutarch’s Lives of the Noble Grecians and Romans is such a work. Plutarch told the stories of great men of the Greek and Roman past in order to help his contemporaries to be great also, and to help them avoid the errors into which the great so often fall—or so he felt. The Lives is a marvelous book; but, although many of the accounts are the only ones we have of their subjects, we do not read it so much for its biographical information as for its view of life in general. Its subjects are interesting people, good and bad, but never indifferent. Plutarch realized this himself. His original intention in writing had been to instruct others, he said, but in the course of the work he discovered that more and more it was he himself who was deriving profit and stimulation from “lodging these men one after the other in his house.”

顺便说一下，普鲁塔克的这部历史著作是另一部对后来的历史产生了深远影响的著作。例如，正如普鲁塔克展示亚历山大大帝以阿喀琉斯（他从荷马那里学到的生活）为榜样自己的生活一样，许多后来的征服者也试图以普鲁塔克笔下的亚历山大为榜样。

Incidentally, Plutarch’s is another historical work that has exercised a profound influence on subsequent history. For example, just as Plutarch shows Alexander the Great modeling his own life on that of Achilles (whose life he learned about from Homer), so many later conquerors have tried to model their lives on that of Plutarch’s Alexander.

自传提出了一些不同的和有趣的问题。首先，是否有人写过真正的自传值得怀疑。如果了解别人的生活很难，了解自己的生活就更难了。而且，当然，所有自传都必须写关于尚未完成的生活。

Autobiographies present some different and interesting problems. First of all, it is questionable whether anyone has ever written a true autobiography. If it is difficult to know the life of anyone else, it is even more difficult to know one’s own. And, of course, all autobiographies have to be written about lives that are not yet complete.

当没有人反驳你时，你几乎无法抗拒说出比真相少或多的诱惑（后者可能更常见）。每个人都有一些不忍心泄露的秘密；每个人对自己也有一些幻想，他几乎不可能认为是幻想。然而，虽然不可能写出一部完全真实的自传，但也不可能写出完全不真实的自传。就像没有人是完美的说谎者一样，每本自传都会告诉我们关于作者的一些事情，只要他想隐瞒一些事情。

The temptation to tell either less or more than the truth (the latter may be more common), when there is no one to contradict you, is almost irresistible. Everybody has some secrets he cannot bear to divulge; everybody also has some illusions about himself, which it is almost impossible for him to regard as illusions. However, although it is not possible to write a wholly true autobiography, neither is it possible to write one that contains no truth at all. Just as no man can be a perfect liar, so every autobiography tells us something about its author, if only that there are things that he wants to conceal.

习惯上说，卢梭的《忏悔录》，或大约在同一时间（大约十八世纪中叶）写成的其他书籍，是第一本真正的自传。这是为了忽略例如奥古斯丁的忏悔录和蒙田的随笔；但错误比这更严重。事实上，任何人就任何主题所写的大部分内容都是自传体的。《理想国》中有大量柏拉图，《失乐园》中有弥尔顿， 《浮士德》中有歌德——尽管我们可能无法准确指出。如果我们对人性感兴趣，在合理的范围内，我们会倾向于阅读任何一本书，部分目的是为了发现其作者的性格。

It is customary to say that the Confessions of Rousseau, or some other book written about the same time (about the middle of the eighteenth century), is the first real autobiography. This is to overlook Augustine’s Confessions, for example, and Montaigne’s Essays; but the error is more serious than that. In fact, much of what anyone writes on any subject is autobiographical. There is a great deal of Plato in the Republic, of Milton in Paradise Lost, of Goethe in Faust— though we may not be able to put our finger on it exactly. If we are interested in humanity, we will tend, within reasonable limits, to read any book partly with an eye to discovering the character of its author.

这绝不应该是首要考虑因素，如果过度考虑，就会导致所谓的可悲谬误。但我们应该记住，文字不会自己写下来——我们读到的文字是由一个活着的人发现并写下来的。柏拉图和亚里士多德说了一些相似的东西，也说了一些不相似的东西；但即使他们完全同意，他们也不可能写出相同的书，因为他们是不同的人。我们甚至可以在《神学大全》这样一本看似不显眼的著作中发现圣托马斯·阿奎那的某些东西。

This should never be the primary consideration, and it leads, when it is overdone, to the so-called pathetic fallacy. But we should remember that words do not write themselves —the ones we read have been found and written down by a living man. Plato and Aristotle said some similar, and some dissimilar, things; but even if they had agreed completely, they could not have written the same books, for they were different men. We may even discover something of St. Thomas Aquinas in such an apparently unrevealing work as the Summa Theologica.

因此，正式的自传是一种相对较新的文学体裁并不重要。没有人能够将自己完全置身于书本之外。“我没有创造我的书，”蒙田说，“正如我的书没有创造我；一本与其作者同质的书，关注我自己自我，是我生命中不可或缺的一部分。” 他补充说，“每个人都在我的书中认出了我，而我的书也认出了我。” 这是真的，而且不仅仅是蒙田。“这不是书，”惠特曼谈到他的《草叶集》时说。“谁碰了这个，谁就碰了一个人。”

Thus it matters very little that formal autobiography is a relatively new literary genre. No one has ever been able to keep himself entirely out of his book. “I have no more made my book,” said Montaigne, “than my book has made me; a book co-substantial with its author, concerned with my own self, an integral part of my life.” And he added, “Everyone recognizes me in my book, and my book in me.” This is true, and not only of Montaigne. “This is no book,” says Whitman of his Leaves of Grass.“Who touches this touches a man.”

阅读传记和自传是否有任何额外的提示？这是一个重要的。尽管这样的书，尤其是自传，揭示了他们作者的很多信息，但我们不应该花太多时间试图发现一个作家的秘密，以至于我们没有发现他清楚地说了什么。除此之外，考虑到这类书籍往往更富有诗意，而不是散漫或哲学，而且它们是特殊的历史类型，也许没有什么可以补充的了。当然，你应该记住，如果你想了解一个人生平的真相，你应该尽可能多地阅读他的传记，包括他自己的传记，如果他写过传记的话。把传记当作历史和历史的原因来读；对所有自传持保留态度；永远不要忘记，在你完全理解它在说什么之前，你不能与一本书争论。至于“那是什么？”这个问题，我们只会这样说：传记，就像历史一样，可以成为实际的、道德的行动的原因。传记可以鼓舞人心。这是一个生活的故事，通常是一个或多或少成功的生活——我们也有生活要过。

Are there any additional hints for reading biographies and autobiographies? Here is one that is important. Despite the fact that such books, and especially the autobiographies, reveal much about their authors, we should not spend so much time trying to discover a writer’s secrets that we do not find out what he says plainly. Apart from this, given the fact that such books are often more poetical than discursive or philosophical, and that they are special kinds of history, there is perhaps little more to add. You should remember, of course, that if you wish to know the truth about a person’s life, you should read as many biographies of him as you can find, including his own account of his life, if he wrote one. Read biography as history and as the cause of history; take all autobiographies with a grain of salt; and never forget that you must not argue with a book until you fully understand what it is saying. As to the question, What of it?, we would only say this: biography, like history, can be a cause of practical, moral action. A biography can be inspiring. It is the story of a life, usually a more or less successful one—and we too have lives to lead.

如何阅读时事

How to Read About Current Events

 

我们已经说过，我们对分析阅读艺术的阐述适用于你必须阅读的一切，而不仅仅是书籍。现在我们想稍微限定一下这个陈述。分析阅读并不总是必要的。我们阅读的许多内容并不需要第三级阅读能力所需的那种努力和技巧。尽管如此，虽然阅读的规则并不总是必须应用，但任何事情都必须始终提出四个问题你读。当然，这意味着当你面对我们大多数人花费大量阅读时间的事物时，必须问他们：报纸、杂志、时事书籍等。

We have said that our exposition of the art of analytical reading applies to everything you have to read, not just to books. Now we want to qualify that statement a little. Analytical reading is not always necessary. There are many things that we read that do not require the kind of effort and skill that is called for at this third level of reading ability. Nevertheless, although the rules of reading do not all always have to be applied, the four questions must always be asked of anything you read. That means, of course, that they must be asked when you are faced with the kind of things to which most of us devote much of our reading time: newspapers, magazines, books about current events, and the like.

毕竟，历史并没有停留在一千年前，或者一百年前。世界在继续，男人和女人继续写下正在发生的事情以及事情是如何变化的。也许没有哪部现代史像修昔底德的著作那样伟大；后代将不得不对此做出判断。但作为人类和公民，我们确实有义务尝试了解我们周围的世界。

After all, history did not stop a thousand years ago, or a hundred. The world goes on, and men and women continue to write about what is happening and how things are changing. Perhaps no modern history is as great as Thucydides’ work; posterity will have to be the judge of that. But we do have an obligation, as human beings and as citizens, to try to understand the world around us.

问题归结为了解现在实际发生的事情。我们在最后一句话中故意选择了“实际上”这个词。新闻片的法语单词是actualités；时事文学的整个概念在某种程度上与“新闻”的概念相同。我们如何获得新闻，我们如何知道我们得到的是真的？

The problem comes down to knowing what is actually happening now. We have chosen the word “actually” in the last sentence intentionally. The French word for newsreel is actualités; the whole concept of current events literature is somehow the same as that of the “news.” How do we get the news, and how do we know that what we get is true?

您可以立即看到，我们面临着历史本身提出的相同问题。我们不能确定我们是否了解事实——我们不能确定我们是否知道现在发生的事情，正如我们不能确定过去发生的事情一样。然而，我们必须尽可能地尝试去了解。

You can see at once that we are faced with the same problem that is posed by history itself. We cannot be sure that we are getting at the facts—we cannot be sure that we know what is happening now any more than we can be sure about what happened in the past. And yet we must try to know, so far as that is possible.

如果我们能同时出现在任何地方，偷听地球上所有的谈话，观察每个活着的人的内心，我们或许就能一探时事的真相。人是有限的，我们必须求助于记者的服务。记者是应该知道小范围内发生的事情的人。他们在报纸故事、杂志或书籍中报道。我们能知道什么取决于他们。

If we could be everywhere at once, overhear all conversations on earth, look into the heart of every living person, we might be able to make a stab at the truth of current events. Being human and hence limited, we must fall back on the services of reporters. Reporters are persons who are supposed to know what is happening in a small area. They report it in newspaper stories, in magazines, or in books. What we can know depends on them.

理想情况下，无论何种类型的记者，都是一面透明的镜子，现实在其中被反映出来——或者通过它闪耀。但是人的头脑不是一块透明的玻璃。它不是一个好的反射镜，当现实通过它闪耀时，头脑就不是一个很好的过滤器。它分离出它认为不真实、不真实的东西。那当然是对的；记者不应该报道他认为是假的。但他可能错了。

Ideally, a reporter, of whatever kind, is a clear glass in which reality is reflected—or through which it shines. But the human mind is not a clear glass. It is not a good reflector, and when reality shines through it, the mind is not a very good filter. It separates out what it considers to be unreality, untruth. That is proper, of course; a reporter should not report what he thinks is false. But he may be mistaken.

因此，在阅读任何有关当前事件的报告时，最重要的是要知道是谁在撰写报告。这里涉及的与其说是对记者本人的认识，不如说是对他所拥有的那种思想的认识。各种类型的过滤报告者分为几类。要了解我们记者的思维是怎样的过滤器，我们必须提出一系列相关问题。这相当于就处理时事的任何材料提出一系列问题。问题是：

Thus the most important thing to know, when reading any report of current happenings, is who is writing the report. What is involved here is not so much an acquaintance with the reporter himself as with the kind of mind he has. The various sorts of filter-reporters fall into groups. To understand what kind of filter our reporter’s mind is, we must ask a series of questions about it. This amounts to asking a series of questions about any material dealing with current events. The questions are these:

 

1.作者想证明什么？

1. What does the author want to prove?

2.他想说服谁？

2. Whom does he want to convince?

3. 他具备哪些特殊知识？

3. What special knowledge does he assume?

4. 他使用什么特殊语言？

4. What special language does he use?

5. 他真的知道他在说什么吗？

5. Does he really know what he is talking about?

在大多数情况下，可以安全地假设所有时事书籍都想证明一些事情。通常很容易发现这是什么。简介通常会陈述此类书籍的主要论点或论点。如果那里没有出现，作者可能会在序言中说明。

For the most part it is safe to assume that all current events books want to prove something. Often it is easy enough to discover what this is. The blurb often states the main contention or thesis of such books. If it does not appear there, it may be stated by the author in a preface.

问完这本书试图证明什么，接下来你应该问作者试图说服谁。这本书是为那些“内行”的人准备的——你属于那个类别吗？是针对能够针对作者描述的情况快速采取行动的一小群人吗？还是适合所有人？如果您不属于本书的目标受众，您可能不想阅读它。

Having asked what the book is trying to prove, you should next ask whom the author is trying to convince. Is the book intended for those “in the know”—and are you in that category? Is it for that small group of persons who can do something, and quickly, about the situation the author describes? Or is it for everyone? If you do not belong to the audience for which the book is intended, you may not want to read it.

接下来你必须发现作者假设你拥有哪些特殊知识。“知识”一词在这里意在涵盖很多领域。“意见”或“偏见”可能是更好的选择。许多作者只为同意他们的读者写作。如果你强烈反对记者的假设，你可能只会在尝试阅读他的书时感到恼怒。

You must next discover what special knowledge the author assumes that you have. The word “knowledge” is intended here to cover a lot of ground. “Opinion” or “prejudice” might have been a better choice. Many authors write only for readers who agree with them. If you disagree sharply with a reporter’s assumptions, you may only be irritated if you try to read his book.

作者做出的假设，以及他假设你分享的假设，有时很难发现。在The Seventeenth Century Background 中， Basil Willey 是这样说的：

The assumptions that an author makes, and that he assumes you share, are sometimes very difficult to discover. In The Seventeenth Century Background, Basil Willey has this to say:

……批判性地意识到自己的习惯性假设几乎是难以克服的；“教义感觉为事实”只能被看作是教义，而不是事实，经过大量的思考，而且通常只有一流的玄学家的帮助。

… it is almost insuperably difficult to become critically conscious of one’s own habitual assumptions; “doctrines felt as facts” can only be seen to be doctrines, and not facts, after great efforts of thought, and usually only with the aid of a first-rate metaphysician.

他接着表示，发现一个与我们时代不同的时代的“被认为是事实的教义”更容易，这就是他在书中试图做的事情。然而，在阅读关于我们自己时代的书籍​​时，我们没有距离的优势。因此，我们不仅要努力看穿作者兼记者思想的过滤器，还要看透我们自己的思想。

He goes on to suggest that it is easier to discover the “doctrines felt as facts” of an age different from our own, and that is what he attempts to do in his book. In reading books about our own time, however, we do not have the advantage of distance. Thus we must try to see through the filter not only of the author-reporter’s mind, but also of our own.

接下来，您必须询问是否有作者使用的特殊语言。这在阅读杂志和报纸时尤为重要，但它也适用于所有有关现代历史的书籍。某些词会激起我们的特殊反应，一个世纪后它们可能不会激起其他读者的反应。这样一个词的一个例子是“共产主义”或“共产主义”。我们应该尝试控制这些反应，或者至少知道它们何时发生。

Next, you must ask if there is a special language that the author uses. This is particularly important in reading magazines and newspapers, but it also applies to all books about current history. Certain words provoke special responses from us, responses that they might not provoke from other readers a century hence. An example of such a word is “Communism” or “Communist.” We should try to control these responses, or at least know when they occur.

最后，您必须考虑五个问题中的最后一个，这可能是最难回答的。您正在阅读其作品的记者本人是否知道事实？他是否知道他所写的人的秘密想法和决定？为了公平公正地说明情况，他是否知道他应该知道的一切？

Finally, you must consider the last of the five questions, which is probably the hardest to answer. Does the reporter whose work you are reading himself know the facts? Is he privy to the perhaps secret thoughts and decisions of the persons about whom he is writing? Does he know all that he should know in order to give a fair and balanced account of the situation?

换句话说，我们的意思是，作者-记者可能存在的偏见并不是唯一需要考虑的事情。我们最近听到很多关于“新闻管理”的说法；重要的是要认识到，这不仅适用于我们作为公众成员，也适用于本应“知情”的记者。他们可能不会是。带着世界上最好的善意，尽一切努力向我们提供事情的真相，记者可能仍然对秘密行动、条约等“不知情”。他自己可能知道这一点，也可能不知道。当然，在后一种情况下，情况对他的读者来说尤其危险。

What we are suggesting, in other words, is that the possible bias of the author-reporter is not the only thing that has to be considered. We have heard a good deal lately about the “management of the news”; it is important to realize that this applies not only to us, as members of the public, but also to reporters who are supposed to be “in the know.” They may not be. With the best good will in the world, with every intention of providing us with the truth of the matter, a reporter may still be “uninformed” with regard to secret actions, treaties, and so forth. He himself may be aware of this, or he may not. In the latter case, of course, the situation is especially perilous for his reader.

你会注意到这五个问题实际上只是我们所说的你必须向任何说明性书籍提出的问题的变体。例如，了解作者的特殊语言无非是与他达成和解。但是因为关于当代世界的最新书籍和其他材料给我们作为读者提出了特殊的问题，所以我们以不同的方式陈述了这些问题。

You will note that these five questions are really only variations on the questions we have said you must ask of any expository book. Knowing an author’s special language, for example, is nothing more than coming to terms with him. But because current books and other material about the contemporary world pose special problems for us as readers, we have stated the questions in a different way.

也许最有用的是总结警告中的差异而不是一套阅读此类书籍的规则。警告是这样的：Caveat lector——“让读者当心。” 读者在阅读亚里士多德、但丁或莎士比亚时不必警惕。但是任何当代书籍的作者都可能——尽管他不一定有——对你以某种方式理解它感兴趣。或者，如果他不这样做，他的信息来源可能会有这样的兴趣。你应该知道这种兴趣，并在阅读任何内容时将其考虑在内。

Perhaps it is most useful to sum up the difference in a warning rather than a set of rules for reading books of this kind. The warning is this: Caveat lector—“Let the reader beware.” Readers do not have to be wary when reading Aristotle, or Dante, or Shakespeare. But the author of any contemporary book may have—though he does not necessarily have—an interest in your understanding it in a certain way. Or if he does not, the sources of his information may have such an interest. You should know that interest, and take it into account in whatever you read.

关于摘要的注释

A Note on Digests

 

我们的基本区分还有另一个结果——为获取信息而阅读和为理解而阅读之间的区分——这是我们所说的关于阅读的一切内容的基础。这就是有时我们必须阅读有关理解的信息——找出其他人如何解释事实。让我们试着解释一下这意味着什么。

There is another consequence of our basic distinction—the distinction between reading for information and reading for understanding—that underlies everything we have said about reading. And this is that sometimes we have to read for information about understanding—to find out how others have interpreted the facts. Let us try to explain what this means.

大多数情况下，我们阅读报纸和杂志，甚至是广告，都是为了了解其中包含的信息。这种材料的数量是巨大的，大到今天没有人有时间阅读其中的一小部分。在这种阅读领域，需求一直是许多优秀发明的源泉。新闻杂志，例如《时代》杂志和《新闻周刊》，通过阅读新闻并将其简化为信息的基本要素，对我们大多数人来说发挥着无价的作用。撰写这些杂志的人主要是读者。他们将阅读信息的艺术发展到远远超出普通读者能力的地步。

For the most part, we read newspapers and magazines, and even advertising matter, for the information they contain. The amount of such material is vast, so vast that no one today has time to read more than a small fraction of it. Necessity has been the mother of a number of good inventions in the field of such reading. The news magazines, for instance, such as Time and Newsweek, perform an invaluable function for most of us by reading the news and reducing it to its essential elements of information. The men who write these magazines are primarily readers. They have developed the art of reading for information to a point far beyond the average reader’s competence.

像《读者文摘》这样的出版物也是如此，它声称以浓缩的形式为我们带来许多在当前的普通杂志中值得我们关注的内容，使其成为一个小卷的紧凑范围。当然，最好的文章和最好的书一样，不可能没有损失地浓缩。例如，如果蒙田的文章出现在当前的期刊上，我们几乎不会满足于阅读它们的摘要。在这种情况下，摘要只有在促使我们阅读原文时才会发挥良好作用。然而，对于一般的文章，浓缩通常就足够了，而且往往比原来的更好，因为一般的文章主要是信息性的。读者文摘的制作技巧而同类期刊的评分，首先是一种阅读技巧，其次才是写作的简单明了。它为我们做了我们中很少有人有技术——即使我们有时间——为自己做的事情。它从页面和次要内容的页面中删除了可靠信息的核心。

The same is true of a publication like Reader’s Digest, which professes to bring us in condensed form much that is worth our attention in current general magazines to the compact scope of a single, small volume. Of course, the very best articles, like the best books, cannot be condensed without loss. If the essays of Montaigne, for example, were appearing in a current periodical, we would scarcely be satisfied to read a digest of them. A summary, in this case, would function well only if it impelled us to read the original. For the average article, however, a condensation is usually adequate, and often even better than the original, because the average article is mainly informational. The skill that produces Reader’s Digest and the scores of similar periodicals is, first of all, a skill in reading, and only then one of writing simply and clearly. It does for us what few of us have the technique—even if we had the time—to do for ourselves. It cuts the core of solid information out of pages and pages of less substantial stuff.

但是，毕竟，我们仍然必须阅读完成这些当前新闻和信息摘要的期刊。如果我们希望获得信息，就无法避免阅读任务，无论摘要有多好。归根结底，阅读它们的任务与这些杂志的编辑对他们以更紧凑的形式提供的原始材料执行的任务相同。就我们阅读的程度而言，它们节省了我们的劳力，但它们并没有节省我们，也不可能完全节省我们阅读的麻烦。从某种意义上说，它们执行的功能只有当我们能够阅读他们的信息摘要并且他们已经完成了预先阅读以便为我们提供摘要时，才对我们有利。

But, after all, we still have to read the periodicals that accomplish these digests of current news and information. If we wish to be informed, we cannot avoid the task of reading, no matter how good the digests are. And the task of reading them is, in the last analysis, the same task as that which is performed by the editors of these magazines on the original material that they make available in more compact form. They have saved us labor, so far as the extent of our reading is concerned, but they have not saved us and cannot entirely save us the trouble of reading. In a sense, the function they perform profits us only if we can read their digests of information as well as they have done the prior reading in order to give us the digests.

这涉及阅读理解和信息。显然，摘要越浓缩，发生的选择就越多。如果将 1,000 页减少到 900 页，我们可能不必太担心这一点；但是，如果将 1,000 页裁减为十页，甚至一页，那么遗漏什么的问题就变得很关键了。因此，冷凝越大，了解冷凝器的特性就越重要；同样的警告我们之前提到的在这里更适用。最终，也许，这归结为阅读专家凝聚的字里行间。您无法参考原件来找出遗漏的内容；您必须以某种方式从凝结本身推断出这一点。因此，阅读文摘有时是您能做的最苛刻和最困难的阅读。

And that involves reading for understanding as well as information. Obviously, the more condensed a digest is, the more selection has occurred. We may not have to worry about this very much if 1,000 pages are cut down to 900, say; but if 1,000 pages are cut to ten, or even one, then the question of what has been left out becomes critical. Hence the greater the condensation, the more important it is that we know something of the character of the condensor; the same caveat we mentioned before applies here with even greater force. Ultimately, perhaps, this comes down to reading between the lines of an expert condensation. You cannot refer to the original to find out what was left out; you must somehow infer this from the condensation itself. Reading digests, therefore, is sometimes the most demanding and difficult reading that you can do.

17

如何阅读科学和数学

17HOW TO READ SCIENCE AND MATHEMATICS

 

本章的标题可能会产生误导。我们不打算为您提供有关如何阅读各种科学和数学的建议。我们将只讨论两种：一种是我们传统的伟大科学和数学经典，另一种是现代科普。我们所说的，往往适用于专业专着的阅读，内容比较深奥，题材有限，但我们不能帮你看。有两个原因。一是，简单地说，我们没有资格去做。

The title of this chapter may be misleading. We do not propose to give you advice about how to read every kind of science and mathematics. We will confine ourselves to discussing only two kinds: the great scientific and mathematical classics of our tradition, on the one hand, and modern scientific popularizations, on the other hand. What we say will often be applicable to the reading of specialized monographs on abstruse and limited subjects, but we cannot help you to read those. There are two reasons for this. One is, simply, that we are not qualified to do it.

另一个是这个。直到大约 19 世纪末，主要的科学书籍都是为普通读者编写的。他们的作者——像伽利略、牛顿和达尔文这样的人——并不反对被他们领域的专家阅读。事实上，他们想要接触到这样的读者。但当时还没有制度化的专业化，阿尔伯特·爱因斯坦称之为“科学的快乐童年”。聪明且博览群书的人应该阅读科学书籍以及历史和哲学；没有硬性规定，没有不能逾越的界限。也没有当代科学中明显的对普通读者或外行读者的漠视写作。大多数现代科学家不关心外行读者的想法，因此他们甚至不去接触他们。

The other is this. Until approximately the end of the nineteenth century, the major scientific books were written for a lay audience. Their authors—men like Galileo, and Newton, and Darwin—were not averse to being read by specialists in their fields; indeed, they wanted to reach such readers. But there was as yet no institutionalized specialization in those days, days which Albert Einstein called “the happy childhood of science.” Intelligent and well-read persons were expected to read scientific books as well as history and philosophy; there were no hard and fast distinctions, no boundaries that could not be crossed. There was also none of the disregard for the general or lay reader that is manifest in contemporary scientific writing. Most modern scientists do not care what lay readers think, and so they do not even try to reach them.

今天，科学往往是由专家为专家撰写的。关于科学主题的严肃交流需要读者具备如此多的专业知识，以至于任何不了解该领域的人通常根本无法阅读。这种方法有明显的优势，尤其是它有助于更​​快地推进科学。专家们互相谈论他们的专业知识可以很快到达它的前沿——他们可以立即看到问题并开始尝试解决它们。但代价同样显而易见。你——我们在本书中针对的普通聪明读者——完全被排除在外。

Today, science tends to be written by experts for experts. A serious communication on a scientific subject assumes so much specialized knowledge on the part of the reader that it usually cannot be read at all by anyone not learned in the field. There are obvious advantages to this approach, not least that it serves to advance science more quickly. Experts talking to each other about their expertise can arrive very quickly at the frontiers of it—they can see the problems at once and begin to try to solve them. But the cost is equally obvious. You—the ordinary intelligent reader whom we are addressing in this book—are left quite out of the picture.

事实上，这种情况虽然在科学上比在其他地方更为极端，但在许多其他领域也同样存在。如今，除了其他哲学家之外，哲学家很少为任何人写作；经济学家为经济学家写作；甚至历史学家也开始发现，与为每个人编写的更传统的叙述作品相比，长期以来在科学领域占主导地位的与其他专家进行速记、专题交流是一种更方便的交流思想的方式。

In fact, this situation, although it is more extreme in science than elsewhere, obtains in many other fields as well. Nowadays, philosophers seldom write for anyone except other philosophers; economists write for economists; and even historians are beginning to find that the kind of shorthand, monographic communication to other experts that has long been dominant in science is a more convenient way of getting ideas across than the more traditional narrative work written for everyone.

在这种情况下，一般读者会怎么做？他不可能成为所有领域的专家。因此，他必须求助于科学普及。其中一些是好的，一些是坏的。但是，了解其中的区别不仅很重要，而且很重要。能够理解地阅读好书也很重要。

What does the general reader do in these circumstances? He cannot become expert in all fields. He must fall back, therefore, on scientific popularizations. Some of these are good, and some are bad. But it is not only important to know the difference; it is also important to be able to read the good ones with understanding.

了解科学企业

Understanding the Scientific Enterprise

 

发展最快的学科之一是科学史。在过去几年中，我们看到了该领域的显着变化。就在不久之前，“严肃的”科学家还看不起科学史学家。后者被认为是研究某一学科历史的人，因为他们没有能力扩展其边界。科学家对科学史学家的态度可以用萧伯纳的那句名言来概括：那些不会的人，教书。”

One of the fastest growing academic disciplines is the history of science. We have seen marked changes in this area within the past few years. It was not so long ago that “serious” scientists looked down upon historians of science. The latter were thought of as men who studied the history of a subject because they were not capable of expanding its frontiers. The attitude of scientists to historians of science could be summed up in that famous remark of George Bernard Shaw’s: “Those who can, do; those who can’t, teach.”

现在很少听到这种态度的表达。科学史部门变得受人尊敬，优秀的科学家研究和撰写他们学科的历史。一个例子就是所谓的“牛顿产业”。目前，许多国家正在对艾萨克·牛顿爵士的工作和奇怪的性格进行深入而广泛的研究。最近出版或宣布了六本书。原因是科学家比以往任何时候都更加关注科学事业本身的性质。

Expressions of this attitude are seldom heard nowadays. Departments of the history of science have become respectable, and excellent scientists study and write about the history of their subject. An example is what has been called the “Newton industry.” At the present time, intensive and extensive research is being undertaken in many countries on the work and strange personality of Sir Isaac Newton. Half a dozen books have been recently published or announced. The reason is that scientists are more concerned than ever before about the nature of the scientific enterprise itself.

因此，我们会毫不犹豫地建议您至少尝试阅读我们传统中的一些伟大科学经典。事实上，真的没有理由不去阅读它们。如果你愿意付出努力，它们都不是不可能的困难，即使是像牛顿的《自然哲学的数学原理》这样的书。

Thus we have no hesitation in recommending that you try to read at least some of the great scientific classics of our tradition. In fact, there is really no excuse for not trying to read them. None of them is impossibly difficult, not even a book like Newton’s Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy, if you are willing to make the effort.

我们可以给你的最有用的建议就是这个。阅读说明性作品的规则之一要求您尽可能清楚地陈述作者试图解决的问题。这条分析阅读的规则适用于所有的说明性作品，但它尤其适用于科学和数学领域的作品。

The most helpful advice we can give you is this. You are required by one of the rules for reading expository works to state, as clearly as you can, the problem that the author has tried to solve. This rule of analytical reading is relevant to all expository works, but it is particularly relevant to works in the fields of science and mathematics.

还有另一种说法。作为外行，您不会阅读经典科学书籍以了解当代意义上的主题知识。相反，您阅读它们是为了了解科学的历史和哲学。这确实是外行人对科学的责任。释放它的主要方式是意识到伟大的科学家们试图解决的问题——意识到这些问题，同时也意识到这些问题的背景。

There is another way of saying this. As a layman, you do not read the classical scientific books to become knowledgeable in their subject matters in a contemporary sense. Instead, you read them to understand the history and philosophy of science. That, indeed, is the layman’s responsibility with regard to science. The major way in which you can discharge it is to become aware of the problems that the great scientists were trying to solve—aware of the problems, and aware, also, of the background of the problems.

追随科学发展的潮流，追溯事实、假设、原则和证明相互关联的方式，就是从事人类理性可能最成功运作的活动。或许，这本身就足以证明科学的历史研究是正当的。此外，这种研究在某种程度上将有助于消除科学表面上的不可理解性。最重要的是，它是一种对教育至关重要的思想活动，从苏格拉底时代到我们现在，教育的中心目标一直被认为是通过对奇迹的训练来解放思想。

To follow the strands of scientific development, to trace the ways in which facts, assumptions, principles, and proofs are interrelated, is to engage in the activity of the human reason where it has probably operated with the most success. That is enough by itself, perhaps, to justify the historical study of science. In addition, such study will serve to dispel, in some measure, the apparent unintelligibility of science. Most important of all, it is an activity of the mind that is essential to education, the central aim of which has always been recognized, from Socrates’ day down to our own, as the freeing of the mind through the discipline of wonder.

经典科学书籍阅读建议

Suggestions for Reading Classical Scientific Books

 

所谓科学书籍，我们指的是某个研究领域的发现或结论报告，无论是在实验室中进行实验还是通过原始自然观察进行。科学的问题总是尽可能准确地描述现象，并追溯不同现象之间的相互联系。

By a scientific book, we mean the report of findings or conclusions in some field of research, whether carried on experimentally in a laboratory or by observations of nature in the raw. The scientific problem is always to describe the phenomena as accurately as possible, and to trace the interconnections between different kinds of phenomena.

在伟大的科学著作中，没有雄辩或宣传，尽管在最初的预设意义上可能存在偏见。通过区分作者的假设和他通过论证建立的内容，您可以发现并考虑到这一点。一个科学作者越“客观”，他就越会明确要求你把这个或那个视为理所当然。科学的客观性并不是没有最初的偏见。它是通过坦白承认而获得的。

In the great works of science, there is no oratory or propaganda, though there may be bias in the sense of initial presuppositions. You detect this, and take account of it, by distinguishing what the author assumes from what he establishes through argument. The more “objective” a scientific author is, the more he will explicitly ask you to take this or that for granted. Scientific objectivity is not the absence of initial bias. It is attained by frank confession of it.

科学著作中的主要术语通常用不常用的或技术性的词来表达。它们相对容易被发现，通过它们你可以很容易地掌握命题。主要命题总是一般性命题。因此，科学不是时空的。恰好相反; 与历史学家不同，科学家试图在时间和地点上摆脱局限性。他试图说出事情的一般情况，事情的一般表现。

The leading terms in a scientific work are usually expressed by uncommon or technical words. They are relatively easy to spot, and through them you can readily grasp the propositions. The main propositions are always general ones. Science thus is not chronotopic. Just the opposite; a scientist, unlike a historian, tries to get away from locality in time and place. He tries to say how things are generally, how things generally behave.

阅读科学书籍可能有两个主要困难。一是关于论点。科学主要是归纳的；也就是说，它的主要论点是那些通过参考可观察到的证据来建立一般命题的论点——一个由实验产生的单个案例，或通过患者调查收集的大量案例。还有其他论证，属于演绎论证。在这些论证中，一个命题被其他已经以某种方式建立的命题所证明。就证明而言，科学与哲学并无太大区别。但归纳论证是科学的特点。

There are likely to be two main difficulties in reading a scientific book. One is with respect to the arguments. Science is primarily inductive; that is, its primary arguments are those that establish a general proposition by reference to observable evidence—a single case created by an experiment, or a vast array of cases collected by patient investigation. There are other arguments, of the sort that are called deductive. These are arguments in which a proposition is proved by other propositions already somehow established. So far as proof is concerned, science does not differ much from philosophy. But the inductive argument is characteristic of science.

出现第一个困难是因为，为了理解科学书籍中的归纳论证，您必须能够遵循科学家报告的证据作为其基础。不幸的是，除了手头的书，这并不总是可能的。如果这本书本身不能启发他，读者只有一个办法，那就是亲身获得必要的特殊体验。他可能不得不亲眼目睹实验室演示。他可能需要查看和操作与书中提到的设备类似的设备。他可能不得不去博物馆观察标本或模型。

This first difficulty arises because, in order to understand the inductive arguments in a scientific book, you must be able to follow the evidence that the scientist reports as their basis. Unfortunately, this is not always possible with nothing but the book in hand. If the book itself fails to enlighten him, the reader has only one recourse, which is to get the necessary special experience for himself at first hand. He may have to witness a laboratory demonstration. He may have to look at and handle pieces of apparatus similar to those referred to in the book. He may have to go to a museum and observe specimens or models.

任何想了解科学史的人，不仅必须阅读经典著作，而且还必须通过直接体验来熟悉那段历史中的重要实验。有经典实验，也有经典书籍。对于那些亲眼所见并亲手完成伟大科学家所描述的获得见解的程序的人来说，科学经典变得更容易理解。

Anyone who desires to acquire an understanding of the history of science must not only read the classical texts, but must also become acquainted, through direct experience, with the crucial experiments in that history. There are classical experiments as well as classical books. The scientific classics become more intelligible to those who have seen with their own eyes and done with their own hands what a great scientist describes as the procedure by which he reached his insights.

这并不意味着您不完成所描述的所有步骤就不能开始。以拉瓦锡的​​《化学原理》为例。这部作品于 1789 年出版，不再被认为是有用的化学教科书，事实上，学生为了通过这门学科的高中考试而学习它是不明智的。然而，它的方法在当时是革命性的时间，其化学元素的概念，大体上还是我们现代的那个。现在的重点是，你不必通读和详细地阅读这本书，就能获得对它的这些印象。例如，序言强调了方法在科学中的重要性，很有启发性。“物理科学的每一个分支，”拉瓦锡写道，必须由三样东西组成：作为科学对象的一系列事实，代表这些事实的观念，以及表达这些事实的词语……。而且，由于思想是通过文字来保存和交流的，因此必然会得出这样的结论，即我们不能在不改进科学本身的情况下改进任何科学的语言；另一方面，我们也不能，

This does not mean that you cannot make a start without going through all the steps described. Take a book like Lavoisier’s Elements of Chemistry, for instance. Published in 1789, the work is no longer considered to be useful as a textbook in chemistry, and indeed a student would be unwise to study it for the purpose of passing even a high school examination in the subject. Nevertheless, its method was revolutionary at the time, and its conception of a chemical element is still, on the whole, the one that we have in modern times. Now the point is that you do not have to read the book through, and in detail, to receive these impressions of it. The Preface, for example, with its emphasis on the importance of method in science, is enlightening. “Every branch of physical science,” wrote Lavoisier, must consist of three things: the series of facts which are the objects of the science, the ideas which represent these facts, and the words by which these facts are expressed…. And, as ideas are preserved and communicated by means of words, it necessarily follows that we cannot improve the language of any science without at the same time improving the science itself; neither can we, on the other hand, improve a science without improving the language or nomenclature which belongs to it.

这正是拉瓦锡所做的。他通过改进语言来改进化学，就像一个世纪前的牛顿通过系统化和整理语言来改进物理学一样——在这个过程中，你可能还记得，发展了微积分和积分学。

This was exactly what Lavoisier did. He improved chemistry by improving its language, just as Newton, a century before, had improved physics by systematizing and ordering its language—in the process, as you may recall, developing the differential and integral calculus.

提到微积分，我们会想到阅读科学书籍的第二个主要困难。这就是数学的问题。

Mention of the calculus leads us to consider the second main difficulty in reading scientific books. And that is the problem of mathematics.

面对数学问题

Facing the Problem of Mathematics

 

许多人对数学感到恐惧，认为自己根本看不懂数学。没有人十分清楚为什么会这样。一些心理学家认为存在“符号失明”这样的事情——无法摆脱对具体事物的依赖，无法跟随符号的控制移动。这可能是有原因的，除了，当然，文字也会发生变化，而它们的变化，或多或少是不受控制的，可能更难理解。其他人认为麻烦出在数学教学上。如果是这样，我们可以感到欣慰的是，最近的许多研究都致力于解决如何更好地教授它的问题。

Many people are frightened of mathematics and think they cannot read it at all. No one is quite sure why this is so. Some psychologists think there is such a thing as “symbol blindness”—the inability to set aside one’s dependence on the concrete and to follow the controlled shifting of symbols. There may be something to this, except, of course, that words shift, too, and their shifts, being more or less uncontrolled, are perhaps even more difficult to follow. Others believe that the trouble lies in the teaching of mathematics. If so, we can be gratified that much recent research has been devoted to the question of how to teach it better.

问题部分在于此。我们没有被告知，或者没有及早被告知，以至于我们无法理解数学是一种语言，我们可以像学习其他任何语言一样学习它，包括我们自己的语言。我们必须两次学习自己的语言，第一次是学习说，第二次是学习阅读。幸运的是，数学只需学习一次，因为它几乎完全是一种书面语言。

The problem is partly this. We are not told, or not told early enough so that it sinks in, that mathematics is a language, and that we can learn it like any other, including our own. We have to learn our own language twice, first when we learn to speak it, second when we learn to read it. Fortunately, mathematics has to be learned only once, since it is almost wholly a written language.

正如我们已经观察到的，学习一门新的书面语言总是让我们陷入初级阅读的问题。当我们在小学接受最初的阅读指导时，我们的问题是学会识别页面上出现的某些任意符号，并记住这些符号之间的某些关系。即使是最好的读者也会继续阅读，至少偶尔会阅读初级水平的内容：例如，每当我们遇到一个我们不认识的单词并且不得不查字典时。如果我们对一个句子的句法感到困惑，那我们也是在初级水平上工作。只有解决了这些问题，我们才能进行更高层次的阅读。

As we have already observed, learning a new written language always involves us in problems of elementary reading. When we underwent our initial reading instruction in elementary school, our problem was to learn to recognize certain arbitrary symbols when they appeared on a page, and to memorize certain relations among these symbols. Even the best readers continue to read, at least occasionally, at the elementary level: for example, whenever we come upon a word that we do not know and have to look up in the dictionary. If we are puzzled by the syntax of a sentence, we are also working at the elementary level. Only when we have solved these problems can we go on to read at higher levels.

由于数学是一种语言，它有自己的词汇、语法和句法，初学者必须学习这些。必须记住某些符号和符号之间的关系。问题是不同的，因为语言不同，但从理论上讲，这并不比学习阅读英语、法语或德语更难。事实上，在初级阶段，它甚至可能更容易。

Since mathematics is a language, it has its own vocabulary, grammar, and syntax, and these have to be learned by the beginning reader. Certain symbols and relationships between symbols have to be memorized. The problem is different, because the language is different, but it is no more difficult, theoretically, than learning to read English or French or German. At the elementary level, in fact, it may even be easier.

任何语言都是人们就交流者可以相互理解的主题进行交流的媒介。日常话语的主题主要是情感事实和关系。任何两个不同的人都不能完全理解这些主题。但是两个不同的人可以理解第三种东西，这种东西在他们之外并且在情感上与他们分开，例如电路，等腰三角形，或三段论。主要是当我们将这些事物赋予情感内涵时，我们才难以理解它们。数学让我们避免了这一点。如果使用得当，数学术语、命题和方程式是没有情感内涵的。

Any language is a medium of communication among men on subjects that the communicants can mutually comprehend. The subjects of ordinary discourse are mainly emotional facts and relations. Such subjects are not entirely comprehensible by any two different persons. But two different persons can comprehend a third thing that is outside of and emotionally separated from both of them, such as an electrical circuit, an isosceles triangle, or a syllogism. It is mainly when we invest these things with emotional connotations that we have trouble understanding them. Mathematics allows us to avoid this. There are no emotional connotations of mathematical terms, propositions, and equations when these are properly used.

我们也没有被告知，至少还不够早，数学可以多么美丽，在智力上是多么令人满意。如果他愿意去惹一点麻烦，任何人看到这一点恐怕都不晚。你可以从欧几里德开始，他的《几何原本》是有史以来最清晰、最优美的作品之一。

We are also not told, at least not early enough, how beautiful and how intellectually satisfying mathematics can be. It is probably not too late for anyone to see this if he will go to a little trouble. You might start with Euclid, whose Elements of Geometry is one of the most lucid and beautiful works of any kind that has ever been written.

例如，让我们考虑一下《几何原本》第一卷中的前五个命题。（如果有这本书的副本，你应该看看它。）初等几何中的命题有两种：（1）图形构造中的问题陈述，和（2）关于图形或图形之间关系的定理他们的部分。构造问题需要做一些事情，定理需要证明一些事情。在欧几里德构造问题的末尾，您会看到字母 QEF，它代表Quod erat faciendum， “（存在）它被要求做的事情。” 在欧几里德定理的末尾，您会看到字母 QED，它代表Quod erat demonstrandum， “（存在）需要证明的东西。”

Let us consider, for example, the first five propositions in Book I of the Elements. (If a copy of the book is available, you should look at it.)
