Propositions in elementary geometry are of two kinds: (1) the statement of problems in the construction of figures, and (2) theorems about the relations between figures or their parts. Construction problems require that something be done, theorems require that something be proved. At the end of a Euclidean construction problem, you will find the letters Q.E.F., which stand for Quod erat faciendum,“(Being) what it was required to do.” At the end of a Euclidean theorem, you will find the letters Q.E.D., which stand for Quod erat demonstrandum,“(Being) what it was required to prove.”

《几何原本》第一卷中的前三个命题都是构造问题。为什么是这样？一个答案是在定理的证明中需要构造。这在前四个命题中并不明显，但我们可以在第五个命题中看到它，这是一个定理。它指出在等腰三角形（两条边相等的三角形）中，底角相等。这涉及命题 3 的使用，因为较短的线从较长的线中分离出来。由于命题 3 又依赖于命题 2 中结构的使用，而命题 2 涉及命题 1，我们看到为了命题 5 需要这三个结构。

The first three propositions in Book I of the Elements are all problems of construction. Why is this? One answer is that the constructions are needed in the proofs of the theorems. This is not apparent in the first four propositions, but we can see it in the fifth proposition, which is a theorem. It states that in an isosceles triangle (a triangle with two equal sides) the base angles are equal. This involves the use of Proposition 3, for a shorter line is cut off from a longer line. Since Proposition 3, in turn, depends on the use of the construction in Proposition 2, while Proposition 2 involves Proposition 1, we see that these three constructions are needed for the sake of Proposition 5.

结构也可以被解释为服务于另一个目的。它们与公设有明显的相似之处；构造和假设都断言可以执行几何运算。在假设的情况下，假设了可能性；在命题的情况下，它被证明了。当然，证明涉及假设的使用。因此，我们可能想知道，例如，是否真的存在定义 20 中定义的等边三角形这样的东西。在这里不用担心数学对象存在的棘手问题，我们至少可以看到命题1 表明，从假设存在直线和圆这样的东西，可以得出存在诸如等边三角形之类的东西。

Constructions can also be interpreted as serving another purpose. They bear an obvious similarity to postulates; both constructions and postulates assert that geometrical operations can be performed. In the case of the postulates, the possibility is assumed; in the case of the propositions, it is proved. The proof, of course, involves the use of the postulates. Thus, we might wonder, for example, whether there is really any such thing as an equilateral triangle, which is defined in Definition 20. Without troubling ourselves here about the thorny question of the existence of mathematical objects, we can at least see that Proposition 1 shows that, from the assumption that there are such things as straight lines and circles, it follows that there are such things as equilateral triangles.

让我们回到命题5，等腰三角形底角相等的定理。当得出结论时，在涉及参考先前命题和假设的一系列步骤中，该命题已被证明。然后证明，如果某件事是真的（即我们有一个等腰三角形的假设），并且如果一些额外的事情是有效的（定义、假设和先验命题），那么其他事情也是真的，即，结论。该命题断言此if-then关系。它不断言假设为真，也不断言结论为真，除非假设为真。在命题得到证明之前，假设和结论之间的这种联系也不会被视为真实。证明的正是这种联系的真实性，而不是别的。

Let us return to Proposition 5, the theorem about the equality of the base angles of an isosceles triangle. When the conclusion has been reached, in a series of steps involving reference to previous propositions and to the postulates, the proposition has been proved. It has then been shown that if something is true (namely, the hypothesis that we have an isosceles triangle), and if some additional things are valid (the definitions, postulates, and prior propositions), then something else is also true, namely, the conclusion. The proposition asserts this if-then relationship. It does not assert the truth of the hypothesis, nor does it assert the truth of the conclusion, except when the hypothesis is true. Nor is this connection between hypothesis and conclusion seen to be true until the proposition is proved. It is precisely the truth of this connection that is proved, and nothing else.

说这很美是不是有点夸张？我们不这么认为。我们这里所拥有的是对一个非常有限的问题的真正合乎逻辑的阐述。阐述的清晰性和问题的有限性都有一些非常吸引人的地方。普通的话语，即使是非常好的哲学话语，也很难用这种方式来限制它的问题。在哲学问题的情况下使用逻辑几乎从来没有像这样清楚。

Is it an exaggeration to say that this is beautiful? We do not think so. What we have here is a really logical exposition of a really limited problem. There is something very attractive about both the clarity of the exposition and the limited nature of the problem. Ordinary discourse, even very good philosophical discourse, finds it difficult to limit its problems in this way. And the use of logic in the case of philosophical problems is hardly ever as clear as this.

考虑此处概述的命题 5 的论证与最简单的三段论之间的区别，例如：

Consider the difference between the argument of Proposition 5, as outlined here, and even the simplest of syllogisms, such as the following:

所有的动物都会死；

所有人都是动物；

因此，所有的人都会死。

All animals are mortal;All men are animals;Therefore, all men are mortal.

 

这也有一些令人满意的地方。我们可以把它当作一段数学推理。假设有动物和人这样的东西，并且动物是终有一死的，那么结论就和关于三角形的角的结论一样肯定。但麻烦的是，真的有动物和人；我们正在假设一些关于真实事物的东西，一些可能是真的也可能不是真的。我们必须以一种我们在数学中不必做的方式来检验我们的假设。欧几里德的命题不受此影响。是否存在诸如等腰三角形之类的东西对他来说并不重要。如果有，他说，如果它们以这样那样的方式定义，那么绝对可以得出它们的底角相等。这一点毫无疑问——从现在到永远。

There is something satisfying about that, too. We can treat it as though it were a piece of mathematical reasoning. Assuming that there are such things as animals and men, and that animals are mortal, then the conclusion follows with the same certainty as the one about the angles of the triangle. But the trouble is that there really are animals and men; we are assuming something about real things, something that may or may not be true. We have to examine our assumptions in a way that we do not have to do in mathematics. Euclid’s proposition does not suffer from this. It does not really matter to him whether there are such things as isosceles triangles. If there are, he is saying, and if they are defined in such and such a way, then it follows absolutely that their base angles are equal. There can be no doubt about this whatever—now and forever.

处理科学书籍中的数学

Handling the Mathematics in Scientific Books

 

关于欧几里德的题外话让我们有点偏离了正题。我们观察到科学书籍中出现数学是阅读它们的主要障碍之一。有几件事要说。

This digression on Euclid has led us a little out of our way. We were observing that the presence of mathematics in scientific books is one of the main obstacles to reading them. There are a couple of things to say about that.

首先，你至少可以比你想象的更好地阅读初等数学。我们已经建议你应该从 Euclid 开始，我们相信，如果你花几个晚上学习几何原本，你就会克服对这门学科的大部分恐惧。做了一些工作欧几里德，你可能会继续浏览其他古典希腊数学家的作品——阿基米德、阿波罗尼乌斯、尼科马科斯。它们并不是真的很难，而且你可以跳过。

First, you can probably read at least elementary mathematics better than you think. We have already suggested that you should begin with Euclid, and we are confident that if you spent several evenings with the Elements you would overcome much of your fear of the subject. Having done some work on Euclid, you might proceed to glance at the works of other classical Greek mathematicians—Archimedes, Apollonius, Nicomachus. They are not really very difficult, and besides, you can skip.

这就引出了我们要说的第二点。如果你的目的是阅读一本数学书本身，你必须阅读它，当然，从头到尾 - 并且手里拿着铅笔，因为在这里在页边空白处甚至在草稿本上写字更有必要比任何其他类型的书都要多。但你的意图可能不是那样，而是阅读一本包含数学的科学著作。在这种情况下，跳绳通常是勇气的更好部分。

That leads to the second point we want to make. If your intention is to read a mathematical book in and for itself, you must read it, of course, from beginning to end—and with a pencil in your hand, for writing in the margins and even on a scratch pad is more necessary here than in the case of any other kinds of books. But your intention may not be that, but instead to read a scientific work that has mathematics in it. In this case, skipping is often the better part of valor.

以牛顿原理为例举个例子。书中包含很多命题，既有构造题，也有定理，但没有必要全部通读一遍，尤其是第一次读完。阅读命题的陈述，并浏览证明以了解它是如何完成的；阅读所谓的引理和推论的陈述；并阅读所谓的学术论文，这些论文本质上是对命题之间的关系及其与整个作品的关系的讨论。如果你这样做，你将开始看到那个整体，从而发现牛顿正在构建的系统是如何构建的——什么是第一位的，什么是第二位的，以及各个部分是如何组合在一起的。以这种方式通读整个作品，如果图表对您造成困扰（就像许多读者一样），请避免使用图表，只需浏览一下大部分间隙内容，但一定要找到并阅读牛顿阐述其主要观点的段落。其中之一出现在作品的最后，在第三本书的结尾，书名为“世界体系”。这个General Scholium，正如牛顿所说，不仅总结了以前发生的事情，而且陈述了几乎所有后来的物理学的重大问题。

Take Newton’s Principia for an example. The book contains many propositions, both construction problems and theorems, but it is not necessary to read all of them in detail, especially the first time through. Read the statement of the proposition, and glance down the proof to get an idea of how it is done; read the statements of the so-called lemmas and corollaries; and read the so-called scholiums, which are essentially discussions of the relations between propositions and of their relations to the work as a whole. You will begin to see that whole if you do this, and so to discover how the system that Newton is constructing is built—what comes first and what second, and how the parts fit together. Go through the whole work in this way, avoiding the diagrams if they trouble you (as they do many readers), merely glancing at much of the interstitial matter, but being sure to find and read the passages where Newton is making his main points. One of these comes at the very end of the work, at the close of Book III, which is titled “The System of the World.” This General Scholium, as Newton called it, not only sums up what has gone before but also states the great problem of almost all subsequent physics.

牛顿光学是您可能想尝试阅读的另一本科学经典。实际上其中的数学内容很少，虽然乍一看似乎并非如此，因为页面上散布着图表。但是这些图这些只是描述牛顿实验的插图，其中有孔让太阳照进黑暗的房间，有棱镜来拦截阳光，还有几张白纸，让光束的各种颜色可以照在上面。你可以很容易地自己重复其中的一些实验，这样做很有趣，因为颜色很漂亮，描述也非常清楚。除了实验的描述之外，您还需要阅读各种定理或命题的陈述，以及三本书中每一本书结尾处的讨论，其中牛顿总结了他的发现并提出了这些发现的结论。第三卷的结尾很有名，因为它包含牛顿关于科学事业本身的一些陈述，非常值得一读。

Newton’s Optics is another scientific classic that you might want to try to read. There is actually very little mathematics in it, although at first glance that does not appear to be so because the pages are sprinkled with diagrams. But these diagrams are merely illustrations describing Newton’s experiments with holes for the sun to shine through into a dark room, with prisms to intercept the sunbeam, and with pieces of white paper placed so that the various colors of the beam can shine on them. You can quite easily repeat some of these experiments yourself, and this is fun to do, for the colors are beautiful, and the descriptions are eminently clear. You will want to read, in addition to the descriptions of the experiments, the statements of the various theorems or propositions, and the discussions that occur at the end of each of the three Books, where Newton sums up his discoveries and suggests their consequences. The end of Book III is famous, for it contains some statements by Newton about the scientific enterprise itself that are well worth reading.

数学经常被科学作家使用，主要是因为它具有我们所描述的精确、清晰和有限的品质。通常你不需要深入数学就可以了解一些事情，就像牛顿的情况一样。然而，奇怪的是，即使数学对你来说绝对是可怕的，它在某些作品中的缺失可能会给你带来更多麻烦。一个典型的例子是伽利略的两门新科学，他关于材料强度和运动的著名论文。这部作品对现代读者来说特别困难，因为它不是主要是数学；相反，它以对话的形式呈现。对话形式虽然适合舞台，并且在被柏拉图这样的大师使用时在哲学中很有用，但实际上并不适合科学。因此很难发现伽利略在说什么，尽管当你这样做时你会发现他在陈述一些革命性的事情。

Mathematics is very often employed by scientific writers, mainly because it has the qualities of preciseness, clarity, and limitedness that we have described. Usually you can understand something of the matter without going very deeply into the mathematics, as in the case of Newton. Oddly enough, however, even if mathematics is absolutely terrifying to you, its absence from certain works may cause you even more trouble. A case in point is Galileo’s Two New Sciences, his famous treatise on the strength of materials and on motion. This work is particularly difficult for modern readers because it is not primarily mathematical; instead, it is presented in the form of a dialogue. The dialogue form, though appropriate to the stage and useful in philosophy when employed by such a master as Plato, is not really appropriate to science. It is therefore hard to discover what Galileo is saying, although when you do you will discover that he is stating some revolutionary things.

当然，并非所有的科学经典都使用数学，甚至不需要使用数学。希腊医学的创始人希波克拉底的著作不是数学的。您可能会通过阅读它们来发现希波克拉底的医学观点——即，医学是使人保持健康的艺术，而不是在他们生病时治愈他们的艺术。那是不幸的现在一个不常见的想法。威廉哈维关于血液循环的论述也不是数学的，或者威廉吉尔伯特关于磁铁的书。如果您始终牢记您的主要职责不是胜任主题而是理解问题，那么阅读它们不会有太大困难。

Not all of the scientific classics, of course, employ mathematics or even need to employ it. The works of Hippocrates, the founder of Greek medicine, are not mathematical. You might well read them to discover Hippocrates’ view of medicine—namely, that it is the art of keeping people well, rather than that of curing them when they are sick. That is unfortunately an uncommon idea nowadays. Nor is William Harvey’s discourse on the circulation of the blood mathematical, or William Gilbert’s book on magnets. They can be read without too much difficulty if you always keep in mind that your primary obligation is not to become competent in the subject matter but instead to understand the problem.

科普笔记

A Note on Popular Science

 

从某种意义上说，读科普没什么好说的。根据定义，这些作品——无论是书籍还是文章——都是为广大读者而不仅仅是为专家而写的。因此，如果你设法阅读了一些科学传统的经典著作，你应该不会有太大的困难。这是因为，尽管它们是关于科学的，但它们通常会回避或避免读者在阅读科学原创作品时遇到的两个主要问题。首先，它们包含的实验描述相对较少（相反，它们仅报告实验结果）。其次，它们包含的数学内容相对较少（除非它们是关于数学本身的通俗书籍）。

In a sense, there is little more to say about reading scientific popularizations. By definition, these are works—either books or articles—written for a wide audience, not just for specialists. Thus, if you have managed to read some of the classics of the scientific tradition, you should not have much trouble with them. This is because, although they are about science, they generally skirt or avoid the two main problems that confront the reader of an original contribution in science. First, they contain relatively few descriptions of experiments (instead, they merely report the results of experiments). Second, they contain relatively little mathematics (unless they are popular books about mathematics itself).

通俗的科学文章通常比通俗的科学书籍更容易阅读，尽管并非总是如此。有时这样的文章非常好——例如，在《科学美国人》月刊或《科学》（一种更具技术性的周刊）中找到的文章。当然，这些出版物，无论它们多么好，或者编辑多么仔细和负责任，都会带来上一章末尾讨论的问题。在阅读它们时，我们任由为我们过滤信息的记者摆布。如果他们是好记者，我们很幸运。如果他们不是，我们几乎没有追索权。

Popular scientific articles are usually easier to read than popular scientific books, although not always. Sometimes such articles are very good—for example, articles found in Scientific American, a monthly magazine, or Science, a somewhat more technical weekly publication. Of course, these publications, no matter how good they are or how carefully and responsibly edited, pose the problem that was discussed at the end of the last chapter. In reading them, we are at the mercy of reporters who filter the information for us. If they are good reporters, we are fortunate. If they are not, we have almost no recourse.

就故事本身或看似故事的意义而言，科普从来都不是易读的。即使是一篇关于 DNA 的三页文章，没有实验报告，也没有图表或数学公式，也需要相当大的努力读者的一部分。如果不保持头脑清醒，就无法阅读它来理解它。因此，积极阅读的要求在这里比其他任何地方都更为重要。确定主题。发现整体与部分之间的关​​系。达成共识并绘制命题和论点。在你开始批评或评估重要性之前，努力获得理解。到目前为止，这些规则都很熟悉。但它们在这里特别适用。

Scientific popularizations are never easy reading in the sense that a story is or seems to be. Even a three-page article on DNA containing no reports of experiments and no diagrams or mathematical formulas demands considerable effort on the part of the reader. You cannot read it for understanding without keeping your mind awake. Thus, the requirement that you read actively is more important here than almost anywhere else. Identify the subject matter. Discover the relation between the whole and its parts. Come to terms and plot the propositions and arguments. Work at achieving understanding before you begin to criticize or to assess significance. These rules, by now, are all familiar. But they apply here with particular force.

短文通常主要是信息性的，因此它们不需要您积极思考。你必须努力去理解，遵循作者提供的叙述，但你通常不必超越这一点。就怀特海的《数学导论》、林肯·巴奈特的《宇宙与爱因斯坦博士》、巴里·科蒙纳的《封闭的圆》等优秀的畅销书而言，还需要更多东西。对于像 Commoner 这样的书来说尤其如此，主题是环境危机，这对我们今天的所有人都特别感兴趣和重要。写作紧凑，需要经常注意。但整本书所蕴含的含义是细心的读者不会错过的。虽然它不是实际工作，但在第 13 章中描述的意义上, 其理论结论具有重要的后果。仅仅提到本书的主题——环境危机——就说明了这一点。所讨论的环境是我们自己的；如果它正在经历某种危机，那么它就不可避免地会出现，即使作者没有这么说——尽管他实际上已经说过了——我们也卷入了这场危机。在危机中要做的事情（通常）是以某种方式行事，或者停止以某种方式行事。因此，布蒙纳的书虽然本质上是理论性的，但具有超越理论而进入实践领域的意义。

Short articles are usually primarily informational, and as such they require less active thinking on your part. You must make an effort to understand, to follow the account provided by the author, but you often do not have to go beyond that. In the case of such excellent popular books as Whitehead’s Introduction to Mathematics, Lincoln Barnett’s The Universe and Dr. Einstein, and Barry Commoner’s The Closing Circle, something more is required. This is particularly true of a book like Commoner’s, on a subject—the environmental crisis—of special interest and importance to all of us today. The writing is compact and requires constant attention. But the book as a whole has implications that the careful reader will not miss. Although it is not a practical work, in the sense described above in Chapter 13, its theoretical conclusions have important consequences. The mere mention of the book’s subject matter —the environmental crisis—suggests this. The environment in question is our own; if it is undergoing a crisis of some sort, then it inevitably follows, even if the author had not said so—though in fact he has—that we are also involved in the crisis. The thing to do in a crisis is (usually) to act in a certain way, or to stop acting in a certain way. Thus Commoner’s book, though essentially theoretical, has a significance that goes beyond the theoretical and into the realm of the practical.

这并不是说 Commoner 的著作很重要而 Whitehead 和 Barnett 的著作不重要。当《宇宙与爱因斯坦博士》作为原子研究史的理论说明（为大众读者而写）时，人们广泛意识到原子物理学中固有的危险，主要但不完全是最近发现的原子弹所代表的。因此，这本理论书也产生了实际影响。但是，即使今天人们并不那么担心原子战争或核战争的迫在眉睫，阅读这本理论书籍或类似书籍的所谓实际必要性仍然存在。原因是原子和核物理学是我们这个时代的伟大成就之一。它为人类带来了美好的希望，同时也带来了巨大的危险。一个知情和关心的读者应该知道他能知道的关于这个主题的一切。

This is not to suggest that Commoner’s work is important and the books by Whitehead and Barnett unimportant. When The Universe and Dr. Einstein was written, as a theoretical account (written for a popular audience) of the history of researches into the atom, people were widely aware of the perils inherent in atomic physics, as represented mainly but not exclusively by the recently discovered atomic bomb. Thus that theoretical book also had practical consequences. But even if people are today not so worried about the imminence of an atomic or nuclear war, there is still what may be called a practical necessity to read this theoretical book, or one like it. The reason is that atomic and nuclear physics is one of the great achievements of our age. It promises great things for man, at the same time that it poses great perils. An informed and concerned reader should know everything he can about the subject.

怀特海的《数学导论》表现出一种略有不同的紧迫感。数学是现代主要的谜团之一。也许它是主导者，在我们的社会中占有一席之地，类似于另一个时代的宗教奥秘。如果我们想知道我们这个时代的全部内容，我们应该对数学是什么，以及数学家是如何运作和思考的有所了解。怀特海的书虽然没有深入探讨该主题的更深奥的分支，但对数学推理的原理非常有说服力。如果它什么都不做，它向细心的读者表明数学家是一个普通人，而不是魔术师。对于任何希望将视野扩展到当下的思想和经验之外的读者来说，这一发现也很重要。

A slightly different urgency is exerted by Whitehead’s Introduction to Mathematics. Mathematics is one of the major modern mysteries. Perhaps it is the leading one, occupying a place in our society similar to the religious mysteries of another age. If we want to know something about what our age is all about, we should have some understanding of what mathematics is, and of how the mathematician operates and thinks. Whitehead’s book, although it does not go very deeply into the more abstruse branches of the subject, is remarkably eloquent about the principles of mathematical reasoning. If it does nothing else, it shows the attentive reader that the mathematician is an ordinary man, not a magician. And that discovery, too, is important for any reader who desires to expand his horizons beyond the immediate here and now of thought and experience.

18

如何阅读哲学

18HOW TO READ PHILOSOPHY

 

孩子们提出了宏伟的问题。“为什么是人？” “是什么让猫滴答作响？” “世界第一名是什么？” “上帝创造地球有什么理由吗？” 从婴儿的嘴里出来的，如果不是智慧，至少是对它的探索。根据亚里士多德的说法，哲学始于惊奇。它肯定从童年开始，即使对我们大多数人来说它也止步于此。

Children ask magnificent questions. “Why are people?” “What makes the cat tick?” “What’s the world’s first name?” “Did God have a reason for creating the earth?” Out of the mouths of babes comes, if not wisdom, at least the search for it. Philosophy, according to Aristotle, begins in wonder. It certainly begins in childhood, even if for most of us it stops there, too.

孩子是天生的提问者。他与成年人的区别不是他提出的问题的数量，而是他们的性格。成年人并没有失去似乎是人类与生俱来的好奇心，但他们的好奇心在质量上退化了。他们想知道事情是否如此，而不是为什么。但是孩子们的问题并不局限于百科全书可以回答的那种。

The child is a natural questioner. It is not the number of questions he asks but their character that distinguishes him from the adult. Adults do not lose the curiosity that seems to be a native human trait, but their curiosity deteriorates in quality. They want to know whether something is so, not why. But children’s questions are not limited to the sort that can be answered by an encyclopedia.

托儿所和大学之间发生了什么来关闭问题的流动，或者更确切地说，将其变成成年人对事实的好奇心的沉闷渠道？一个不被好的问题所激怒的头脑，即使是最好的答案也无法理解其重要性。学习答案很容易。但是要培养积极好奇的头脑，带着真正的问题、深刻的问题活着——那就是另一回事了。

What happens between the nursery and college to turn the flow of questions off, or, rather, to turn it into the duller channels of adult curiosity about matters of fact? A mind not agitated by good questions cannot appreciate the significance of even the best answers. It is easy enough to learn the answers. But to develop actively inquisitive minds, alive with real questions, profound questions—that is another story.

既然孩子天生就有这样的头脑，我们为什么还要努力培养这样的头脑呢？沿着这条线的某个地方，成人一定无法以某种方式维持婴儿对原始事物的好奇心。深度。学校本身，也许，通过死记硬背的沉重负担使头脑变得迟钝，其中大部分可能是必要的。失败可能更多是父母的错。我们经常告诉孩子没有答案，即使有答案，或者要求他不要再问问题。当我们对这个显然无法回答的问题感到困惑时，我们会勉强掩饰自己的愤怒。这一切都让孩子气馁。他可能会觉得太好奇是不礼貌的。人类的好奇心永远不会被扼杀；但它很快就被贬低为大多数大学生提出的问题，他们就像他们即将成为的成年人一样，只询问信息。

Why should we have to try to develop such minds, when children are born with them? Somewhere along the line, adults must fail somehow to sustain the infant’s curiosity at its original depth. School itself, perhaps, dulls the mind—by the dead weight of rote learning, much of which may be necessary. The failure is probably even more the parents’ fault. We so often tell a child there is no answer, even when one is available, or demand that he ask no more questions. We thinly conceal our irritation when baffled by the apparently unanswerable query. All this discourages the child. He may get the impression that it is impolite to be too inquisitive. Human inquisitiveness is never killed; but it is soon debased to the sort of questions asked by most college students, who, like the adults they are soon to become, ask only for information.

我们没有办法解决这个问题；我们当然不会轻率地认为我们可以告诉您如何回答孩子们提出的深刻而奇妙的问题。但我们确实希望你认识到，伟大的哲学书籍最引人注目的事情之一就是它们提出了与孩子们相同的深刻问题。能够保留孩子的世界观，同时对保留它意味着什么有成熟的理解，是极其罕见的——具有这些品质的人很可能能够为我们的孩子做出真正重要的贡献思维。

We have no solution for this problem; we are certainly not so brash as to think we can tell you how to answer the profound and wondrous questions that children put. But we do want you to recognize that one of the most remarkable things about the great philosophical books is that they ask the same sort of profound questions that children ask. The ability to retain the child’s view of the world, with at the same time a mature understanding of what it means to retain it, is extremely rare—and a person who has these qualities is likely to be able to contribute something really important to our thinking.

为了理解存在，我们不需要像孩子一样思考。孩子们当然不会，也不能理解它——如果确实有人能理解的话。但我们必须能够像孩子一样看东西，像他们想的那样想，像他们问的那样问。成人生活的复杂性阻碍了真相。伟大的哲学家总是能够拨开复杂的话题，看到简单的区别——说起来很简单，说起来却很困难。如果我们要遵循它们，我们也必须在我们的问题上像孩子一样简单——在我们的回答中成熟而明智。

We are not required to think as children in order to understand existence. Children certainly do not, and cannot, understand it—if, indeed, anyone can. But we must be able to see as children see, to wonder as they wonder, to ask as they ask. The complexities of adult life get in the way of the truth. The great philosophers have always been able to clear away the complexities and see simple distinctions—simple once they are stated, vastly difficult before. If we are to follow them we too must be childishly simple in our questions—and maturely wise in our replies.

哲学家提出的问题

The Questions Philosophers Ask

 

哲学家提出的这些“幼稚简单”的问题是什么？当我们把它们写下来时，它们似乎并不很简单，因为回答这些问题太难了。然而，从基本或基础的意义上说，它们最初是简单的。

What are these “childishly simple” questions that philosophers ask? When we write them down, they do not seem simple, because to answer them is so difficult. Nevertheless, they are initially simple in the sense of being basic or fundamental.

提出以下关于存在或存在的问题，例如：存在和不存在有什么区别？所有确实存在的事物的共同点是什么，以及所有确实存在的事物的属性是什么？事物存在的方式是否不同——存在或存在的不同方式？是否有些事物只存在于头脑中或为头脑而存在，而另一些则存在于头脑之外，它们是否为我们所知，甚至为我们所知？存在的一切都是物理存在的，还是有一些东西是脱离物质体现而存在的？万物皆变，还是有什么东西是不变的？有没有必然存在的东西，或者我们必须说所有存在的东西都可能不存在？可能存在的范围是否大于实际存在的范围？

Take the following questions about being or existence, for example: What is the difference between existing and not existing? What is common to all the things that do exist, and what are the properties of everything that does exist? Are there different ways in which things can exist—different modes of being or existence? Do some things exist only in the mind or for the mind, whereas others exist outside the mind, and whether or not they are known to us, or even knowable by us? Does everything that exists exist physically, or are there some things that exist apart from material embodiment? Do all things change, or is there anything that is immutable? Does anything exist necessarily, or must we say that everything that does exist might not have existed? Is the realm of possible existence larger than the realm of what actually does exist?

这些通常是哲学家在探索存在本身的本质和存在领域时提出的典型问题。作为问题，它们并不难陈述或理解，但它们却极其难以回答——事实上是如此困难，以至于有些哲学家，尤其是近代的哲学家，认为它们无法以任何令人满意的方式得到回答。

These are typically the kind of questions that a philosopher asks when he is concerned to explore the nature of being itself and the realms of being. As questions, they are not difficult to state or understand, but they are enormously difficult to answer—so difficult, in fact, that there are philosophers, especially in recent times, who have held that they cannot be answered in any satisfactory manner.

另一组哲学问题关注的是变化或成为而不是存在。在我们的经验中，我们会毫不犹豫地归因于存在的事物，我们也会说它们都可能发生变化。它们生起又消逝；在存在的时候，他们中的大多数人从一个地方移动到另一个地方；其中许多在数量或质量上发生变化：它们变大或变小，变重或变轻；或者，就像成熟的苹果和老化的牛排一样，它们会变色。

Another set of philosophical questions concerns change or becoming rather than being. Of the things in our experience to which we would unhesitatingly attribute existence, we would also say that all of them are subject to change. They come into being and pass away; while in being, most of them move from one place to another; and many of them change in quantity or in quality: they become larger or smaller, heavier or lighter; or, like the ripening apple and the aging beefsteak, they change in color.

任何变化涉及什么？在每一个变化的过程中，是否有什么东西是永恒不变的，以及那件经久不衰的东西的某些方面或方面改变？当你学习到一些你以前不知道的东西时，你所获得的知识当然发生了变化，但你还是原来的那个人；如果不是这样，你不能说是通过学习改变的。所有的变化都是这样吗？例如，对于像生和死这样显着的变化——产生和消逝——或仅对不那么根本的变化，如局部运动、生长或质量变化，是否如此？有多少种不同的变化？是否相同的基本要素或条件进入了所有变化过程，是否相同的原因在所有变化过程中起作用？改变的原因是什么意思？是否有不同类型的原因导致变化？变化的原因——成为的原因——与存在或存在的原因相同吗？

What is involved in any change? In every process of change, is there something that endures unchanged as well as some respect or aspect of that enduring thing which undergoes change? When you learn something that you did not know before, you have certainly changed with respect to the knowledge you have acquired, but you are also the same individual that you were before; if that were not the case, you could not be said to have changed through learning. Is this true of all change? For example, is it true of such remarkable changes as birth and death—of coming to be and passing away—or only of less fundamental changes, such as local motion, growth, or alteration in quality? How many different kinds of change are there? Do the same fundamental elements or conditions enter into all processes of change, and are the same causes operative in all? What do we mean by a cause of change? Are there different types of causes responsible for change? Are the causes of change—of becoming—the same as the causes of being, or existence?

这些问题是由将注意力从存在转向生成并试图将生成与存在联系起来的哲学家提出的。再说一次，它们不是很难陈述或理解的问题，尽管要清楚地很好地回答它们是极其困难的。无论如何，你可以看到他们是如何从对世界和我们对世界的体验的幼稚简单态度开始的。

Such questions are asked by the philosopher who turns his attention from being to becoming and also tries to relate becoming to being. Once again, they are not difficult questions to state or understand, though they are extremely difficult to answer clearly and well. In any case, you can see how they begin with a childishly simple attitude toward the world and our experience of it.

不幸的是，我们没有篇幅来更深入地探讨整个问题范围。我们只能列举一些哲学家提出并试图回答的其他问题。不仅有关于存在和成为的问题，还有关于必然性和偶然性的问题；关于物质和非物质；关于物质的和非物质的；关于自由和不确定性；关于人类思想的力量；关于人类知识的性质和范围；关于意志的自由。

Unfortunately, we do not have space to go into the whole range of questions more deeply. We can only list some other questions that philosophers ask and try to answer. There are questions not only about being and becoming, but also about necessity and contingency; about the material and the immaterial; about the physical and the non-physical; about freedom and indeterminacy; about the powers of the human mind; about the nature and extent of human knowledge; about the freedom of the will.

从我们用来区分理论和实践领域的那些术语的意义上来说，所有这些问题都是推测性的或理论性的。但是，如您所知，哲学并不仅限于理论问题。

All these questions are speculative or theoretical in the sense of those terms that we have employed in distinguishing between the theoretical and practical realms. But philosophy, as you know, is not restricted to theoretical questions only.

以善与恶为例。孩子们很关心好与坏的区别；如果他们在这方面犯了错误，他们的背后很可能会受到影响。但是，当我们长大后，我们不会停止思考其中的差异。善恶之间是否存在普遍有效的区别？无论情况如何，是否总有某些事情总是好的，而另一些事情总是坏的？或者哈姆雷特是正确的，他呼应了蒙田，他说：“没有什么是好是坏，而是思想使然。”

Take good and evil, for instance. Children are much concerned with the difference between good and bad; their behinds are likely to suffer if they make mistakes about it. But we do not stop wondering about the difference when we grow up. Is there a universally valid distinction between good and evil? Are there certain things that are always good, others that are always bad, whatever the circumstances? Or was Hamlet right when, echoing Montaigne, he said: “There is nothing either good or bad but thinking makes it so.”

当然，善与恶并不等同于对与错。这两对术语似乎指的是不同类别的事物。特别是，即使我们觉得对的就是好的，我们可能不会觉得错的就是恶的。但是我们如何使这种区分精确呢？

Good and evil, of course, are not the same as right and wrong; the two pairs of terms seem to refer to different classes of things. In particular, even if we feel that whatever is right is good, we probably do not feel that whatever is wrong is evil. But how do we make this distinction precise?

“好”是一个重要的哲学词，但它也是我们日常词汇中的一个重要词。试图说出它的意思是一项令人兴奋的练习；它会让你在不知不觉中非常深入地了解哲学。有很多东西是好的，或者像我们更喜欢说的那样，有很多商品。可以订货吗？有些比其他的更重要吗？有些人依赖其他人吗？是否存在商品冲突的情况，以至于您不得不选择一种商品而放弃另一种商品？

“Good” is an important philosophical word, but it is an important word in our everyday vocabulary, too. Trying to say what it means is a heady exercise; it will involve you very deeply in philosophy before you know it. There are many things that are good, or, as we would prefer to say, there are many goods. Is it possible to order the goods? Are some more important than others? Do some depend on others? Are there circumstances in which goods conflict, so that you have to choose one good at the expense of forgoing another?

同样，我们没有空间更广泛地探讨这些问题。我们只能列举一些实际领域的其他问题。不仅有善恶、对错、物品次序的问题，也有责任和义务的问题；关于美德和恶习；关于幸福、生活的目的或目标；关于人际关系和社会互动领域的正义和权利；关于国家及其与个人的关系；关于美好的社会、公正的政体和公正的经济；关于战争与和平。

Again, we do not have space to go more extensively into these questions. We can only list some other questions in the practical realm. There are questions not only about good and evil, right and wrong, and the order of goods, but also about duties and obligations; about virtues and vices; about happiness, life’s purpose or goal; about justice and rights in the sphere of human relations and social interaction; about the state and its relation to the individual; about the good society, the just polity, and the just economy; about war and peace.

我们讨论过的两组问题决定或确定了哲学的两个主要分支。第一组中的问题，关于存在和成为的问题，与世界上正在发生的事情有关。这样的问题属于被称为理论或思辨的哲学分支。第二组的问题，关于善与恶，或对与错的问题，与应该做什么或寻求什么有关，它们属于哲学的分支，有时被称为实践，更准确地说是规范的。告诉你如何做某事的书，如食谱，或如何做某事的书，如驾驶手册，不需要试图争辩说你应该成为一名好厨师，或学好驾驶汽车；他们可以假设你想做某事或做某事，而只是告诉你如何在你的努力中取得成功。相比之下，规范哲学书籍主要关注的是所有人都应该实现的目标寻求——过上美好生活或建立美好社会等目标——而且，与食谱和驾驶手册不同，它们只是以最普遍的术语规定了实现这些目标应该采用的方法。

The two groups of questions that we have discussed determine or identify two main divisions of philosophy. The questions in the first group, the questions about being and becoming, have to do with what is or happens in the world. Such questions belong to the division of philosophy that is called theoretical or speculative. The questions in the second group, the questions concerning good and evil, or right and wrong, have to do with what ought to be done or sought, and they belong to the division of philosophy that is sometimes called practical, and is more accurately called normative. Books that tell you how to make something, such as a cookbook, or how to do something, such as a driver’s manual, need not try to argue that you ought to become a good cook, or learn to drive a car well; they can assume that you want to make or do something and merely tell you how to succeed in your efforts. In contrast, books of normative philosophy concern themselves primarily with the goals all men ought to seek—goals such as leading a good life or instituting a good society—and, unlike cookbooks and driving manuals, they go no further than prescribing in the most universal terms the means that ought to be employed in order to achieve these goals.

哲学家提出的问题也有助于区分哲学的两个主要分支的从属分支。如果思辨或理论哲学的著作主要关注关于存在或存在的问题，那么它就是形而上学的。如果它关注生成——关注变化的性质和种类、它们的条件和原因，那么它就是自然哲学方面的著作。如果它主要关注的是知识——关于我们知道任何事情所涉及的问题，人类知识的起因、范围和局限性，以及它的确定性和不确定性——那么它就是一部认识论的著作，它只是另一部知识论的名称。从理论哲学转向规范哲学，主要区别在于关于美好生活的问题与个人行为的对错问题，

The questions that philosophers ask also serve to distinguish subordinate branches of the two main divisions of philosophy. A work of speculative or theoretical philosophy is metaphysical if it is mainly concerned with questions about being or existence. It is a work in the philosophy of nature if it is concerned with becoming—with the nature and kinds of changes, their conditions and causes. If its primary concern is with knowledge—with questions about what is involved in our knowing anything, with the causes, extent, and limits of human knowledge, and with its certainties and uncertainties—then it is a work in epistemology, which is just another name for theory of knowledge. Turning from theoretical to normative philosophy, the main distinction is between questions about the good life and what is right or wrong in the conduct of the individual, all of which fall within the sphere of ethics, and questions about the good society and the conduct of the individual in relation to the community—the sphere of politics or political philosophy.

现代哲学与伟大传统

Modern Philosophy and the Great Tradition

 

为了下文简洁起见，让我们将关于世界上正在发生的事情，或者关于人们应该做什么或寻求什么的问题称为“一阶问题”。那么，我们应该认识到，还可以提出“二阶问题”：关于我们的一阶知识的问题，关于我们在尝试回答一阶问题时思考的内容的问题，关于方法的问题我们用语言表达这样的想法。

For the sake of brevity in what follows, let us call questions about what is and happens in the world, or about what men ought to do or seek, “first-order questions.” We should recognize, then, that there are also “second-order questions” that can be asked: questions about our first-order knowledge, questions about the content of our thinking when we try to answer first-order questions, questions about the ways in which we express such thoughts in language.

一阶问题和二阶问题之间的区别很有用，因为它有助于解释近年来哲学发生的变化。当今大多数职业哲学家不再相信哲学家可以回答一阶问题。今天，大多数职业哲学家都将注意力完全集中在二阶问题上，通常是与表达思想的语言有关的问题。

This distinction between first-order and second-order questions is useful, because it helps to explain what has happened to philosophy in recent years. The majority of professional philosophers at the present day no longer believe that first-order questions can be answered by philosophers. Most professional philosophers today devote their attention exclusively to second-order questions, very often to questions having to do with the language in which thought is expressed.

这一切都是好的，因为批评永远不会有害。问题在于完全放弃了最有可能引起外行读者兴趣的一阶哲学问题。事实上，今天的哲学，就像当代科学或数学一样，不再是为外行读者而写的。几乎根据定义，二阶问题是具有狭隘吸引力的问题；职业哲学家和科学家一样，除了其他专家之外，对任何人的观点都不感兴趣。

That is all to the good, for it is never harmful to be critical. The trouble is the wholesale giving up of first-order philosophical questions, which are the ones that are most likely to interest lay readers. In fact, philosophy today, like contemporary science or mathematics, is no longer being written for lay readers. Second-order questions are, almost by definition, ones of narrow appeal; and professional philosophers, like scientists, are not interested in the views of anyone but other experts.

这使得现代哲学对于非哲学家来说非常难读——事实上，就像科学对于非科学家一样难读。我们不能在这本书中给你任何关于如何阅读现代哲学的建议，只要它只涉及二阶问题。但是，有些哲学书籍您可以阅读，我们认为您应该阅读。这些书提出了我们称之为一阶问题的各种问题。它们也主要是为外​​行读者而不是专门为其他哲学家而写的，这并非偶然。

This makes modern philosophy very hard to read for non-philosophers—as difficult, indeed, as science for non-scientists. We cannot in this book give you any advice about how to read modern philosophy as long as it is concerned exclusively with second-order questions. However, there are philosophical books that you can read, and that we believe you should read. These books ask the kinds of questions that we have called first-order ones. It is not accidental that they were also written primarily for a lay audience rather than exclusively for other philosophers.

直到大约 1930 年，或者更晚一些，哲学书籍都是为普通读者编写的。哲学家希望被他们的同龄人阅读，但他们也希望被普通的、聪明的男人和女人阅读。由于他们提出和试图回答的问题是每个人都关心的问题，他们认为每个人都应该知道他们的想法。

Up to about 1930, or perhaps even a little later, philosophical books were written for the general reader. Philosophers hoped to be read by their peers, but they also wanted to be read by ordinary, intelligent men and women. Since the questions that they asked and tried to answer were of concern to everyone, they thought that everyone should know what they thought.

从柏拉图开始，所有伟大的哲学经典著作都是从这个角度写成的。外行读者可以阅读这些书籍；如果你愿意，你可以成功地阅读它们。我们在本章中所说的一切都是为了帮助您做到这一点。

All of the great classical works in philosophy, from Plato onward, were written from this point of view. These books are accessible to the lay reader; you can succeed in reading them if you wish to. Everything that we have to say in this chapter is intended to help you do that.

论哲学方法

On Philosophical Method

 

理解什么是哲学方法很重要——至少在哲学被认为是提出并试图回答一阶问题的范围内。假设你是一位哲学家，被我们提到的一个幼稚的简单问题所困扰——例如，关于存在的一切事物的属性的问题，或者关于变化的性质和原因的问题。你如何进行？

It is important to understand what philosophical method consists in—at least insofar as philosophy is conceived as asking and trying to answer first-order questions. Suppose that you are a philosopher who is troubled by one of the childishly simple questions we have mentioned—the question, for instance, about the properties of everything that exists, or the question about the nature and causes of change. How do you proceed?

如果你的问题是科学的，你就会知道要回答它你必须进行某种特殊的研究，要么通过开发实验来检验你的答案，要么通过观察广泛的现象。如果您的问题是历史性的，您就会知道您还必须进行研究，尽管是不同类型的研究。但是没有实验可以告诉你所有现存事物的共同点是什么，确切地说是关于存在。您无法观察到任何特殊类型的现象，也没有您可以查找和阅读的文件来找出什么是变化或为什么会发生变化。你所能做的就是反思这个问题。简而言之，除了思考，别无他法。

If your question were scientific, you would know that to answer it you would have to perform some kind of special research, either by way of developing an experiment to test your answer, or by way of observing a wide range of phenomena. If your question were historical, you would know that you would also have to perform research, although of a different kind. But there is no experiment that will tell you what all existing things have in common, precisely in respect to having existence. There are no special kinds of phenomena that you can observe, no documents that you can seek out and read, in order to find out what change is or why things change. All you can do is reflect upon the question. There is, in short, nothing to do but think.

当然，你并不是在完全真空中思考。哲学，当它好的时候，就不是“纯粹的”推测——脱离经验的思考。想法不能随便放在一起。对哲学问题的答案的有效性有严格的测试。但是这样的测试仅仅基于共同的经验——基于你已经拥有的经验，因为你是一个人，而不是哲学家。通过对变化现象的共同体验，你和其他人一样熟悉；世界上关于你的一切都表现出可变性。就单纯的变化体验而言，你可以像最伟大的哲学家一样思考变化的本质和原因。他们的不同之处在于他们对它的思考非常好：他们提出了可能被问到的最尖锐的问题，并着手制定仔细而清晰的答案。怎么做？不是通过调查。不是通过拥有或试图获得比我们其他人更多的经验。相反，通过比我们其他人更深刻地思考经验。

You are not thinking in a total vacuum, of course. Philosophy, when it is good, is not “pure” speculation—thinking divorced from experience. Ideas cannot be put together just anyway. There are stringent tests of the validity of answers to philosophical questions. But such tests are based on common experience alone—on the experience that you already have because you are a human being, not a philosopher. You are as well acquainted through common experience with the phenomena of change as anybody else; everything in the world about you manifests mutability. As far as the mere experience of change goes, you are in as good a position to think about its nature and causes as the greatest philosophers. What distinguishes them is that they thought about it extremely well: they formulated the most penetrating questions that could be asked about it, and they undertook to develop carefully and clearly worked-out answers. By what means? Not by investigation. Not by having or trying to get more experience than the rest of us have. Rather, by thinking more profoundly about the experience than the rest of us have.

了解这一点是不够的。我们还必须认识到，并非所有哲学家提出并试图回答的问题都是真正的哲学问题。他们自己并不总是意识到这一点，他们在这一关键方面的无知或错误会给不敏感的读者带来相当大的困难。为了避免这些困难，有必要能够将真正的哲学问题与哲学家可能处理的其他问题区分开来，但他应该放弃并留给以后的科学研究来回答。这位哲学家被误导了，因为他没有看到这些问题可以通过科学研究来回答，尽管他在写作时可能不知道这一点。

Understanding this is not enough. We must also realize that not all of the questions that philosophers have asked and tried to answer are truly philosophical. They themselves were not always aware of this, and their ignorance or mistake in this crucial respect can cause unperceptive readers considerable difficulty. To avoid such difficulties, it is necessary to be able to distinguish the truly philosophical questions from the other questions that a philosopher may deal with, but that he should have waived and left for later scientific investigation to answer. The philosopher was misled by failing to see that such questions can be answered by scientific investigation, though he probably could not have known this at the time of his writing.

这方面的一个例子是古代哲学家提出的关于地球和天体物质之间区别的问题。根据他们的观察，在没有望远镜帮助的情况下，天体似乎只是在原地发生变化；它们似乎不像植物和动物那样产生或消逝；他们也没有出现改变大小或质量。因为天体只会发生一种变化——局部运动——而所有的地体在其他方面也会发生变化，所以古人得出结论，它们必须由另一种物质组成。他们没有猜到，也可能猜不到，随着望远镜的发明，天体会让我们知道它们的易变性，这超出了我们通过普通经验所能知道的任何事情。因此，他们把一个他们认为应该由哲学家来回答的问题作为一个问题，这个问题本应留待以后的科学研究使用。这种调查始于伽利略使用望远镜和他发现木星的卫星；这导致了开普勒的革命性断言，即天体的物质与地球上物体的物质完全相同；这反过来又为牛顿提出天体力学奠定了基础，在该力学中，相同的运动定律无限制地适用于物理宇宙中的所有物体。

An example of this is the question that ancient philosophers asked about the difference between the matter of terrestrial and celestial bodies. To their observation, unaided by telescopes, it appeared to be the case that the heavenly bodies changed only in place; they did not appear to come into being or to pass away, like plants and animals; nor did they appear to change in size or quality. Because celestial bodies were subject to one kind of change only—local motion—whereas all terrestrial bodies change in other respects as well, the ancients concluded that they had to be composed of a different kind of matter. They did not surmise, nor could they probably have surmised, that with the invention of the telescope, the heavenly bodies would give us knowledge of their mutability beyond anything we can know through common experience. Hence they took as a question that they thought it proper for philosophers to answer one that should have been reserved for later scientific investigation. Such investigation began with Galileo’s use of the telescope and his discovery of the moons of Jupiter; this led to the revolutionary assertion by Kepler that the matter of the heavenly bodies is exactly the same as the matter of bodies on earth; and this in turn laid the groundwork for Newton’s formulation of a celestial mechanics in which the same laws of motion apply without qualification to all bodies wherever they are in the physical universe.

总的来说，除了可能导致的混乱之外，关于科学问题的错误信息或信息缺乏对古典哲学家的工作造成损害是无关紧要的。原因是我们在阅读哲学著作时感兴趣的是哲学问题，而不是科学或历史问题。而且，冒着重复自己的风险，我们必须强调，除了思考之外别无他法来回答这些问题。如果我们可以建造望远镜或显微镜来检查存在的特性，我们当然应该这样做。但是这样的仪器是不可能的。

On the whole, apart from the confusions that may result, the misinformation or lack of information about scientific matters that mars the work of the classical philosophers is irrelevant. The reason is that it is philosophical questions, not scientific or historical ones, that we are interested in when we read a philosophical work. And, at the risk of repeating ourselves, we must emphasize that there is no other way than thinking to answer such questions. If we could build a telescope or microscope to examine the properties of existence, we should do so, of course. But no such instruments are possible.

我们不想给人这样的印象，即只有哲学家才会犯我们在这里讨论的那种错误。假设一位科学家对一个人应该过什么样的生活的问题感到困扰。这是规范哲学的问题，只有通过思考才能回答。但科学家可能没有意识到这一点，而是假设某种实验或研究会给他一个答案。他可能决定问 1000 个人什么他们想过什么样的生活，并根据他们的回答来回答问题。但很明显，在那种情况下，他的回答将与亚里士多德对天体问题的推测一样无关紧要。

We do not want to give the impression that it is only philosophers who make mistakes of the sort we are discussing here. Suppose a scientist becomes troubled by the question about the kind of life a man ought to lead. This is a question in normative philosophy, and the only way to answer it is by thinking about it. But the scientist may not realize that, and instead suppose that some kind of experiment or research will give him an answer. He may decide to ask 1,000 persons what kind of life they would like to lead, and base his answer to the question on their answers. But it should be obvious that his answer, in that case, would be as irrelevant as Aristotle’s speculations about the matter of the celestial bodies.

论哲学风格

On Philosophical Styles

 

尽管只有一种哲学方法，但西方传统的伟大哲学家至少采用了五种阐述方式。哲学的学生或读者应该能够区分它们并知道各自的优点和缺点。

Although there is only one philosophical method, there are at least five styles of exposition that have been employed by the great philosophers of the Western tradition. The student or reader of philosophy should be able to distinguish between them and know the advantages and disadvantages of each.

1.哲学对话：柏拉图在他的《对话录》中采用的第一种哲学阐述方式，如果不是有效的话，也是时间最早的。风格是对话式的，甚至是口语化的；许多人与苏格拉底讨论一个主题（或者，在后来的对话中，与一位被称为雅典陌生人的演讲者讨论）；通常，经过一定程度的摸索之后，苏格拉底开始提出一系列有助于阐明主题的问题和评论。在柏拉图这样的大师手中，这种风格是启发式的，也就是说，它允许读者，实际上是引导他，自己发现事物。当苏格拉底故事的高雅戏剧——有人会说是高雅喜剧——丰富了这种风格时，它就会变得非常强大。

1. THE PHILOSOPHICAL DIALOGUE: The first philosophical style of exposition, first in time if not in effectiveness, is the one adopted by Plato in his Dialogues. The style is conversational, even colloquial; a number of men discuss a subject with Socrates (or, in the later dialogues, with a speaker known as The Athenian Stranger); often, after a certain amount of fumbling, Socrates embarks on a series of questions and comments that help to elucidate the subject. In the hands of a master like Plato, this style is heuristic, that is, it allows the reader, indeed leads him, to discover things for himself. When the style is enriched by the high drama—some would say the high comedy—of the story of Socrates, it becomes enormously powerful.

“像柏拉图这样的大师，”我们说——但没有人“像”柏拉图。其他哲学家尝试过对话——例如，西塞罗和贝克莱——但收效甚微。他们的对话单调乏味，几乎不可读。衡量柏拉图的伟大之处在于，他能够写出哲学对话，其智慧、魅力和深刻程度可与任何人创作的任何主题的任何书籍相提并论。然而，除了柏拉图之外，没有人能够有效地处理它，这可能是这种哲学思考方式不恰当的一个迹象。

“A master like Plato,” we said—but there is no one “like” Plato. Other philosophers have attempted dialogues—for example, Cicero and Berkeley—but with little success. Their dialogues are flat, dull, almost unreadable. It is a measure of the greatness of Plato that he was able to write philosophical dialogues that, for wit, charm, and profundity are the equal of any books ever produced by anyone, on any subject. Yet it may be a sign of the inappropriateness of this style of philosophizing that no one except Plato has ever been able to handle it effectively.

柏拉图就是这样做的，这是不言而喻的。怀特海曾评论说，所有西方哲学都不过是“柏拉图的注脚”；后来的希腊人自己也有一句话：“无论我走到哪里，我都会遇到柏拉图回来。” 然而，不应误解这些声明。柏拉图本人显然没有哲学体系，没有学说——除非没有学说，我们应该继续谈论。并提出问题。因为柏拉图和他之前的苏格拉底确实设法提出了后来的哲学家认为有必要处理的大部分重要问题。

That Plato did so, goes without saying. All Western philosophy, Whitehead once remarked, is but “a footnote to Plato”; and the later Greeks themselves had a saying: “Everywhere I go in my head, I meet Plato coming back.” Those statements, however, should not be misunderstood. Plato himself had apparently no philosophical system, no doctrine—unless it was that there is no doctrine, that we should simply keep talking. And asking questions. For Plato, and Socrates before him, did indeed manage to raise most of the important questions that subsequent philosophers have felt it necessary to deal with.

2.哲学论文或随笔：亚里士多德是柏拉图最好的学生；师从他二十年。据说他也写过对话，但这些对话都没有完整地保存下来。幸存下来的是关于许多不同主题的异常困难的论文或论文。亚里士多德显然是一位思想清晰的人，但幸存作品的难度使学者们认为它们最初是讲课或书籍的笔记——要么是亚里士多德自己的笔记，要么是听大师讲话的学生记下的笔记。我们可能永远不会知道事情的真相，但无论如何，亚里士多德的论文是一种新的哲学风格。

2. THE PHILOSOPHICAL TREATISE OR ESSAY: Aristotle was Plato’s best pupil; he studied under him for twenty years. He is said to have also written dialogues, but none of these survives entirely. What does survive are curiously difficult essays or treatises on a number of different subjects. Aristotle was obviously a clear thinker, but the difficulty of the surviving works has led scholars to suggest that they were originally notes for lectures or books—either Aristotle’s own notes, or notes taken down by a student who heard the master speak. We may never know the truth of the matter, but in any event the Aristotelean treatise was a new style in philosophy.

亚里士多德在他的论文中所涵盖的主题，以及他在介绍他的发现时所采用的各种风格，也有助于在随后的几个世纪中建立哲学的分支和方法。首先是所谓的通俗作品——主要是对白，流传下来的只有片断。然后是纪录片收藏。我们所知道的主要宪法是希腊各州 158 部独立宪法的集合。其中只有一部幸存下来，即 1890 年从纸莎草纸上复原的雅典宪法。最后，还有主要的论文，其中一些，如物理学和形而上学，或伦理学、政治学和诗学，纯粹是哲学著作，无论是理论性的还是规范性的；其中一些，如《论灵魂》一书，是哲学理论和早期科学研究的混合体；其中一些，如生物学论文，主要是博物学领域的科学著作。

The subjects covered by Aristotle in his treatises, and the various styles adopted by him in presenting his findings, also helped to establish the branches and approaches of philosophy in the succeeding centuries. There are, first of all, the so-called popular works—mostly dialogues, of which only fragments have come down to us. Then there are the documentary collections. The major one that we know about was a collection of 158 separate constitutions of Greek states. Only one of these survives, the constitution of Athens, which was recovered from a papyrus in 1890. Finally, there are the major treatises, some of which, like the Physics and Metaphysics, or the Ethics, Politics, and Poetics, are purely philosophical works, theoretical or normative; some of which, like the book On the Soul, are mixtures of philosophical theory and early scientific investigation; and some of which, like the biological treatises, are mainly scientific works in the field of natural history.

伊曼纽尔康德，虽然他在哲学意义上可能更受柏拉图的影响，但他采用了亚里士多德的阐述风格。他的论文是完成的艺术作品，在这方面与亚里士多德不同。他们首先陈述主要问题，然后以有条不紊的方式深入讨论主题，然后顺便或最后处理特殊问题。可以说康德和亚里士多德的清晰性在于他们强加给一个主题的顺序。我们看到哲学的开始、中间和结束。我们也，特别是在亚里士多德的例子中，提供了对其他人（包括哲学家和普通人）的观点和反对意见的描述。因此，在某种意义上，论文的风格类似于对话的风格。但是康德或亚里士多德的论文中缺少戏剧元素；

Immanuel Kant, although he was probably more influenced by Plato in a philosophical sense, adopted Aristotle’s style of exposition. His treatises are finished works of art, unlike Aristotle’s in this respect. They state the main problem first, go through the subject matter in a thorough and businesslike way, and treat special problems by the way or at the last. The clarity of both Kant and Aristotle may be said to consist in the order that they impose on a subject. We see a philosophical beginning, middle, and end. We also, particularly in the case of Aristotle, are provided with accounts of the views and objections of others, both philosophers and ordinary men. Thus, in one sense the style of the treatise is similar to the style of the dialogue. But the element of drama is missing from the Kantian or Aristotelean treatise; a philosophical view is developed through straightforward exposition rather than through the conflict of positions and opinions, as in Plato.

3.异议的会面：中世纪发展起来并由圣托马斯·阿奎那在他的《神学大全》中完善的哲学风格与已经讨论过的两种哲学风格有相似之处。我们已经指出，柏拉图提出了大部分持续存在的哲学问题；正如我们可能观察到的那样，苏格拉底在对话过程中提出了儿童提出的那种简单但深刻的问题。正如我们也指出的，亚里士多德承认其他哲学家的反对意见并予以答复。

3. THE MEETING OF OBJECTIONS: The philosophical style developed in the Middle Ages and perfected by St. Thomas Aquinas in his Summa Theologica has likenesses to both of those already discussed. Plato, we have pointed out, raises most of the persistent philosophical problems; and Socrates, as we might have observed, asks in the course of the dialogues the kind of simple but profound questions that children ask. And Aristotle, as we have also pointed out, recognizes the objections of other philosophers and replies to them.

阿奎那的风格是提出问题和反对意见的结合。Summa分为部分、论文、问题和文章。所有文章的形式都是一样的。提出一个问题；给出了相反（错误）的答案；引出论据来支持那个错误的答案；这些首先被权威文本（通常是圣经中的引文）所反驳；最后，阿奎那用“我回答那个”这句话介绍了他自己的答案或解决方案。有鉴于他自己对此事的看法，他随后对错误答案的每个论点进行了答复。

Aquinas’ style is a combination of question-raising and objection-meeting. The Summa is divided into parts, treatises, questions, and articles. The form of all the articles is the same. A question is posed; the opposite (wrong) answer to it is given; arguments are educed in support of that wrong answer; these are countered first by an authoritative text (often a quotation from Scripture); and finally, Aquinas introduces his own answer or solution with the words “I answer that.” Having given his own view of the matter, he then replies to each of the arguments for the wrong answer.

这种风格的整洁和秩序对头脑井井有条的人很有吸引力，但这并不是托马斯主义哲学思考方式的最重要特征。相反，这是阿奎那对冲突的明确认识，他对不同观点的报告，以及他试图满足所有可能反对他自己的解决方案的反对意见。真理以某种方式从对立和冲突中演化而来的观点是中世纪的一个普遍观点。阿奎那时代的哲学家理所当然地认为，他们应该准备好在公开的、公开的辩论中捍卫自己的观点，这些辩论经常有成群结队的学生和其他感兴趣的人参加。中世纪的文明基本上是口头的，部分原因是书籍很少而且很难获得。除非能够通过公开讨论的检验，否则一个命题不会被接受为真实的；哲学家不是一个孤独的思想家，而是在知识市场上面对他的对手（正如苏格拉底所说）。就这样Summa Theologica充满了辩论和讨论的精神。

The neatness and order of this style are appealing to men with orderly minds, but that is not the most important feature of the Thomistic way of philosophizing. Rather, it is Aquinas’ explicit recognition of conflicts, his reporting of different views, and his attempt to meet all possible objections to his own solutions. The idea that the truth somehow evolves out of opposition and conflict was a common medieval one. Philosophers in Aquinas’ time accepted as a matter of course that they should be prepared to defend their views in open, public disputes, which were often attended by crowds of students and other interested persons. The civilization of the Middle Ages was essentially oral, partly because books were few and hard to come by. A proposition was not accepted as true unless it could meet the test of open discussion; the philosopher was not a solitary thinker, but instead faced his oponents in the intellectual market place (as Socrates might have said). Thus, the Summa Theologica is imbued with the spirit of debate and discussion.

4.哲学的系统化：在 17 世纪，哲学阐述的第四种风格是由两位著名的哲学家笛卡尔和斯宾诺莎发展起来的。着迷于数学在组织人类自然知识方面有望取得的成功，他们试图以类似于数学组织的方式来组织哲学本身。

4. THE SYSTEMIZATION OF PHILOSOPHY: In the seventeenth century, a fourth style of philosophical exposition was developed by two notable philosophers, Descartes and Spinoza. Fascinated by the promised success of mathematics in organizing man’s knowledge of nature, they attempted to organize philosophy itself in a way akin to the organization of mathematics.

笛卡尔是一位伟大的数学家，虽然在某些方面可能是错误的，但他是一位令人敬畏的哲学家。从本质上讲，他试图做的是给哲学披上数学的外衣——赋予它两千多年前欧几里德赋予几何的确定性和形式结构。笛卡尔在这方面并非完全失败，他对思维清晰和清晰的要求在他那个时代混乱的知识氛围中在某种程度上是合理的。他还写道或多或少传统形式的哲学论文，包括一系列对反对他观点的答复。

Descartes was a great mathematician and, although perhaps wrong on some points, a redoubtable philosopher. What he tried to do, essentially, was to clothe philosophy in mathematical dress—to give it the certainty and formal structure that Euclid, two thousand years before, had given geometry. Descartes was not wholly unsuccessful in this, and his demand for clarity and distinctness in thinking was to some extent justified in the chaotic intellectual climate of his time. He also wrote philosophical treatises in a more or less traditional form, including a set of replies to objections to his views.

斯宾诺莎将这个概念推得更远。他的《伦理学》以严格的数学形式写成，包括命题、证明、推论、引理、论据等。然而，形而上学和道德的主题并没有以这种方式得到令人满意的处理，这种方式更适合于几何学和其他数学学科而不是哲学学科。一个迹象是，在阅读斯宾诺莎时，你可以跳过很多内容，就像你在阅读牛顿时可以跳过的一样。你不能跳过康德或亚里士多德的任何内容，因为推理是连续的；你不能跳过柏拉图的任何东西，就像你不能跳过戏剧或诗歌的一部分一样。

Spinoza carried the conception even farther. His Ethics is written in strict mathematical form, with propositions, proofs, corollaries, lemmas, scholiums, and the like. However, the subject matter of metaphysics and of morals is not very satisfactorily handled in this manner, which is more appropriate for geometry and other mathematical subjects than for philosophical ones. A sign of this is that when reading Spinoza you can skip a great deal, in exactly the same way that you can skip in Newton. You cannot skip anything in Kant or Aristotle, because the line of reasoning is continuous; and you cannot skip anything in Plato, any more than you would skip a part of a play or poem.

可能没有绝对的修辞规则。然而，是否有可能像斯宾诺莎试图做的那样以数学形式写出令人满意的哲学著作，或者像伽利略试图做的那样以对话形式写出令人满意的科学著作，这是值得怀疑的。事实上，这两个人都在某种程度上未能传达他们希望传达的信息，他们选择的形式似乎是失败的主要原因。

Probably there are no absolute rules of rhetoric. Nevertheless, it is questionable whether it is possible to write a satisfactory philosophical work in mathematical form, as Spinoza tried to do, or a satisfactory scientific work in dialogue form, as Galileo tried to do. The fact is that both of these men failed to some extent to communicate what they wished to communicate, and it seems likely that the form they chose was a major reason for the failure.

5.哲学家的风格：还有另一种哲学阐述风格值得一提，尽管它可能不如其他四种重要。这是尼采在《查拉图斯特拉如是说》等著作中以及某些现代法国哲学家所采用的格言风格。这种风格在上个世纪的流行可能是由于西方读者对以格言风格写成的东方智慧书籍的浓厚兴趣。这种风格也可能归功于帕斯卡的Pensées 的例子。但是，帕斯卡当然不打算以简短、神秘的陈述的形式离开他的伟大作品；他还没来得及以论文的形式写完这本书就去世了。

5. THE APHORISTIC STYLE: There is one other style of philosophical exposition that deserves mention, although it is probably not as important as the other four. This is the aphoristic style adopted by Nietzsche in such works as Thus Spake Zarathustra and by certain modern French philosophers. The popularity of this style during the past century is perhaps owing to the great interest, among Western readers, in the wisdom books of the East, which are written in an aphoristic style. This style may also owe something to the example of Pascal’s Pensées. But of course Pascal did not intend to leave his great work in the form of short, enigmatic statements; he died before he could finish writing out the book in essay form.

哲学格言形式的最大优点在于它是启发式的；读者有更多的印象说的比实际说的要多，因为他自己做了很多思考工作——在陈述之间建立联系和为立场构建论据。然而，与此同时，这也是这种风格的一大缺点，它实际上根本不是说明性的。作者就像一个肇事逃逸的司机；他触及一个主题，他提出了关于它的真理或见解，然后在没有适当捍卫他所说的话的情况下跑到另一个主题。因此，虽然格言式的风格对于那些有诗意倾向的人来说是令人愉快的，但对于那些宁愿尝试遵循和批评作者的思想路线的严肃哲学家来说，它是令人恼火的。

The great advantage of the aphoristic form in philosophy is that it is heuristic; the reader has the impression that more is being said than is actually said, for he does much of the work of thinking—of making connections between statements and of constructing arguments for positions—himself. At the same time, however, this is the great disadvantage of the style, which is really not expositional at all. The author is like a hit-and-run driver; he touches on a subject, he suggests a truth or insight about it, and then runs off to another subject without properly defending what he has said. Thus, although the aphoristic style is enjoyable for those who are poetically inclined, it is irritating for serious philosophers who would rather try to follow and criticize an author’s line of thought.

据我们所知，在我们的西方传统中没有采用其他重要的哲学阐述方式。（卢克莱修的《论事物的本质》等作品也不例外。它最初是诗歌；但就其风格而言，它与其他哲学论文没有什么不同；无论如何，我们现在通常在散文翻译中阅读它。）这意味着所有伟大的哲学家都采用了这五种风格中的一种；当然，有时候一位哲学家会尝试不止一种。论文或散文可能是最常见的形式，无论是在过去还是在现在。它的范围从高度正式和困难的作品（如康德的作品）到流行的哲学论文或信件。对话是出了名的难写，几何风格的写作和阅读都非常困难。从哲学的角度来看，格言式的风格是非常不能令人满意的。最近，Thomistic 风格并没有被广泛使用。

As far as we know, there is no other important style of philosophical exposition that has been employed in our Western tradition. (A work like Lucretius’ On the Nature of Things is not an exception. It was originally in verse; but as far as its style goes, it is no different from other philosophical essays; and in any event we ordinarily read it nowadays in prose translations.) This means that all of the great philosophers have employed one or the other of these five styles; sometimes, of course, a philosopher tries more than one. The treatise or essay is probably the most common form, both in the past and in the present. It can range all the way from highly formal and difficult works like those of Kant, to popular philosophical essays or letters. Dialogues are notoriously hard to write, and the geometrical style is enormously difficult both to write and to read. The aphoristic style is highly unsatisfactory from a philosophical point of view. The Thomistic style has not been used very much in recent times. Perhaps it would not be acceptable to modern readers, but that seems a shame, considering all its advantages.

阅读哲学的提示

Hints for Reading Philosophy

 

从迄今为止的讨论中或许可以清楚地看出，在阅读任何哲学著作时要发现的最重要的事情是它试图回答的一个或多个问题。问题可以明确说明，也可以在一定程度上隐含。无论哪种情况，您都必须尝试找出它们是什么。

It is perhaps clear from the discussion so far that the most important thing to discover in reading any philosophical work is the question or questions it tries to answer. The questions may be stated explicitly, or they may be implicit to a certain extent. In either case, you must try to find out what they are.

作者如何回答这些问题，将深受其控制原则的影响。这些也可能被陈述，但情况并非总是如此。我们已经引用了巴兹尔·威利 (Basil Willey) 关于发现作者隐藏和未陈述的假设的困难和重要性，更不用说我们自己的假设了。这适用于任何一本书。它适用于具有特殊影响力的哲学著作。

How the author answers these questions will be deeply affected by his controlling principles. These may be stated, too, but that is not always the case. We have already quoted Basil Willey on the difficulty—and the importance—of discovering the hidden and unstated assumptions of an author, to say nothing of our own. This goes for any book. It applies to works in philosophy with particular force.

不能指责伟大的哲学家试图不诚实地隐藏他们的假设，或者他们的定义和假设不明确。一个伟大哲学家的标志恰恰是他比其他作家更清楚地阐述了这些事情。然而，每一位伟大的哲学家都有某些作为其工作基础的控制原则。这些很容易看出他是否在您正在阅读的书中提到了它们。但他可能没有这样做，将他们的待遇留给另一本书。或者他可能永远不会明确对待它们，而是让它们渗透到他的每一部作品中。

The great philosophers cannot be charged with having tried to hide their assumptions dishonestly, or with having been unclear in their definitions and postulations. It is precisely the mark of a great philosopher that he makes these things clearer than other writers can. Nevertheless, every great philosopher has certain controlling principles that underlie his work. These are easy enough to see if he states them in the book you are reading. But he may not have done so, reserving their treatment for another book. Or he may never treat them explicitly, but instead allow them to pervade every one of his works.

很难举出这种控制原则的例子。我们可能提供的任何东西都可能会受到哲学家的质疑，我们在这里没有空间来捍卫我们的选择。然而，我们可以提及柏拉图的主导思想，即关于哲学主题的对话可能是所有人类活动中最重要的。现在这个想法很少在对话中明确表达，尽管苏格拉底在道歉中断言未经审视的生活不值得过，柏拉图在第七封信中也提到了这一点。关键是柏拉图在许多其他地方表达了这种观点，尽管用词不多——例如，在《普罗泰戈拉》中，观众表示不赞成普罗泰戈拉不愿意继续与苏格拉底交谈。另一个例子是共和国第一卷中的 Cephalus，他恰好有其他事务要处理，因此离开了。柏拉图在这里似乎是在说，虽然不是很明确，无论出于何种原因，拒绝加入对真理的探索是对人类最深层本性的背叛。但是，正如我们已经注意到的，这通常不被引用为柏拉图的“思想”之一，因为它在他的作品中很少被明确讨论。

It is difficult to give examples of such controlling principles. Any that we might proffer would probably be disputed by philosophers, and we do not here have space to defend our choices. Nevertheless, we could mention the controlling idea of Plato that conversation about philosophical subjects is perhaps the most important of all human activities. Now this idea is seldom explicitly stated in the dialogues, although Socrates may be saying it when, in the Apology, he asserts that the unexamined life is not worth living, and Plato mentions it in the Seventh Letter. The point is that Plato expresses this view in a number of other places, though not in so many words—for example, in the Protagoras, where the audience is shown as disapproving of Protagoras’ unwillingness to continue talking to Socrates. Another example is that of Cephalus, in Book I of the Republic, who happens to have other business to attend to and so departs. Plato seems to be saying here, though not explicitly, that it is a betrayal of man’s deepest nature to refuse to join, for whatever reason, in the search for truth. But, as we have noted, this is not ordinarily cited as one of Plato’s “ideas,” because it is seldom explicitly discussed in his works.

我们可以在亚里士多德那里找到其他例子。首先，在阅读任何亚里士多德的作品时，始终要认识到其他作品中所说的内容与讨论相关。因此，在Organon中阐述的逻辑基本原理在Physics中被假定。其次，部分由于这些论文不是完成的艺术作品，它们的控制原则并不总是令人满意地清楚地陈述。道德规范涉及很多方面：幸福、习惯、美德、快乐等等——这个清单可能会很长。但只有非常细心的读者才能发现控制性洞察力。这是幸福是善的全部，而不是最高的洞见好，因为在那种情况下，它只是其他好处中的一个。认识到这一点，我们就会看到幸福并不在于自我完善或自我完善的善，即使这些是部分善中最高的。幸福，正如亚里士多德所说，是整个生命的品质，他的“完整”不仅是时间意义上的，而且是从所有可以看待生命的方面来看的。幸福的人，正如我们现在所说的那样，是一个把一切都放在一起的人——并在他的一生中保持它。这种洞察力在影响伦理学中几乎所有其他想法和洞察力的意义上是控制性的，但它并没有像它可能的那样明确地陈述。

We can find other examples in Aristotle. In the first place, it is always important to recognize, in reading any Aristotelean work, that things said in other works are relevant to the discussion. Thus the basic principles of logic, expounded in the Organon, are assumed in the Physics. In the second place, owing partly to the fact that the treatises are not finished works of art, their controlling principles are not always stated with satisfactory clarity. The Ethics is about many things: happiness, habit, virtue, pleasure, and so forth—the list could be very long. But the controlling insight is discovered only by the very careful reader. This is the insight that happiness is the whole of the good, not the highest good, for in that case it would be only one good among others. Recognizing this, we see that happiness does not consist in self-perfection, or the goods of self-improvement, even though these constitute the highest among partial goods. Happiness, as Aristotle says, is the quality of a whole life, and he means “whole” not only in a temporal sense but also in terms of all the aspects from which a life can be viewed. The happy man is one, as we might say nowadays, who puts it all together—and keeps it there throughout his life. This insight is controlling in the sense that it affects almost all of the other ideas and insights in the Ethics, but it is not stated nearly as explicitly as it might be.

再举一个例子。康德的成熟思想通常被称为批判哲学。他自己将“批判”与“教条主义”进行了对比，他将“教条主义”归咎于许多以前的哲学家。他所说的“教条主义”指的是这样一种假设，即人类智力可以通过纯粹的思考得出最重要的真理，而不会意识到自己的局限性。根据康德的说法，首先需要的是对头脑的资源和力量进行批判性的调查和评估。因此，思想的局限性是康德的一个控制原则，在某种程度上它在时间上先于他的任何哲学家都没有。但是，尽管这一点非常清楚，因为它在《纯粹理性批判》中有明确说明，但并未说明，因为它被假设为康德在美学方面的主要著作《判断力批判》中。尽管如此，它也控制着那里。

One more example. Kant’s mature thought is often known as critical philosophy. He himself contrasted “criticism” to “dogmatism,” which he imputed to many previous philosophers. By “dogmatism” he meant the presumption that the human intellect can arrive at the most important truths by pure thinking, without being aware of its own limitations. What is first required, according to Kant, is a critical survey and assessment of the mind’s resources and powers. Thus, the limitation of the mind is a controlling principle in Kant in a way that it is not in any philosopher who precedes him in time. But while this is perfectly clear because explicitly stated in the Critique of Pure Reason, it is not stated, because it is assumed, in the Critique of Judgment, Kant’s major work in esthetics. Nevertheless, it is controlling there as well.

关于在一本哲学书中找到控制原则，我们只能说这些，因为我们不确定我们是否可以告诉您如何发现它们。有时需要数年才能做到这一点，并且需要多次阅读和重读。然而，这是良好而透彻的阅读的理想目标，你应该记住，如果你想理解你的作者，这最终是你必须尝试做的。尽管发现这些控制原则很困难，但是，我们不建议您走捷径阅读有关哲学家及其生平和观点的书籍。你自己的发现将比别人的想法更有价值。

This is all we can say about finding the controlling principles in a philosophical book, because we are not sure that we can tell you how to discover them. Sometimes it takes years to do this, and many readings and rereadings. Nevertheless, it is the ideal goal of a good and thorough reading, and you should keep in mind that it is ultimately what you must try to do if you are to understand your author. Despite the difficulty of discovering these controlling principles, however, we do not recommend that you take the shortcut of reading books about the philosophers, their lives and opinions. The discovery you come to on your own will be much more valuable than someone else’s ideas.

一旦你找到了作者的控制原则，你就会想决定他是否在整个作品中都坚持这些原则。不幸的是，哲学家，即使是最优秀的哲学家，也常常不这样做。爱默生说，一致性“是小脑袋妖怪。” 这是一个非常无忧无虑的陈述，但尽管记住它可能是明智的，但毫无疑问，哲学家的前后矛盾是一个严重的问题。如果一位哲学家前后矛盾，你必须确定他真正指的是两组命题中的哪一组——第一原则，如他所说；或结论，这些结论实际上并不遵循所陈述的原则。或者您可能会认为两者都无效。

Once you have found an author’s controlling principles, you will want to decide whether he adheres to them throughout his work. Unfortunately, philosophers, even the best of them, often do not do so. Consistency, Emerson said, “is the hobgoblin of little minds.” That is a very carefree statement, but although it is probably wise to remember it, there is no doubt, either, that inconsistency in a philosopher is a serious problem. If a philosopher is inconsistent, you have to decide which of two sets of propositions he really means—the first principles, as he states them; or the conclusions, which do not in fact follow from the principles as stated. Or you may decide that neither is valid.

哲学著作的阅读具有与哲学和科学之间的差异相关的特殊方面。我们在这里只考虑哲学方面的理论著作，例如形而上学论文或关于自然哲学的书籍。

The reading of philosophical works has special aspects that relate to the difference between philosophy and science. We are here considering only theoretical works in philosophy, such as metaphysical treatises or books about the philosophy of nature.

哲学问题是解释，而不是像科学那样描述事物的本质。哲学询问的不仅仅是现象之间的联系。它试图渗透到它们背后的究竟因和缘。只有当这些问题的答案得到明确论据和分析的支持时，这些问题才能得到令人满意的探索。

The philosophical problem is to explain, not to describe, as science does, the nature of things. Philosophy asks about more than the connections of phenomena. It seeks to penetrate to the ultimate causes and conditions that underlie them. Such problems are satisfactorily explored only when the answers to them are supported by clear arguments and analysis.

因此，读者的主要努力必须是关于术语和最初的命题。虽然哲学家和科学家一样，有专门的术语，但表达他的术语的词通常取自普通话，但在非常特殊的意义上使用。这需要读者特别注意。如果他不克服以熟悉的方式使用熟悉的词语的倾向，他很可能会把这本书弄得乱七八糟。

The major effort of the reader, therefore, must be with respect to the terms and the initial propositions. Although the philosopher, like the scientist, has a technical terminology, the words that express his terms are usually taken from common speech, but used in a very special sense. This demands special care from the reader. If he does not overcome the tendency to use familiar words in a familiar way, he will probably make gibberish and nonsense of the book.

哲学讨论的基本术语当然是抽象的。但科学也是如此。除了抽象术语外，没有任何一般知识是可以表达的。抽象没有什么特别困难的。我们在生活的每一天和各种谈话中都使用它们。然而，“抽象”和“具体”这两个词似乎困扰着很多人。

The basic terms of philosophical discussions are, of course, abstract. But so are those of science. No general knowledge is expressible except in abstract terms. There is nothing particularly difficult about abstractions. We use them every day of our lives and in every sort of conversation. However, the words “abstract” and “concrete” seem to trouble many persons.

每当您笼统地谈论任何事情时，您都在使用抽象。你通过感官感知到的东西总是具体而具体的。你用头脑想的总是抽象的和笼统的。理解一个“抽象词”就是理解它所表达的意思。“有一个想法”只是另一种说法，表示您了解您具体经历的事物的某些一般方面。您无法看到或触摸甚至想象因此提到的一般方面。如果可以的话，感官和头脑之间就没有区别了。那些试图想象想法所指的人会迷惑自己，并最终对所有抽象事物产生绝望的感觉。

Whenever you talk generally about anything, you are using abstractions. What you perceive through your senses is always concrete and particular. What you think with your mind is always abstract and general. To understand an “abstract word” is to have the idea it expresses. “Having an idea” is just another way of saying that you understand some general aspect of the things you experience concretely. You cannot see or touch or even imagine the general aspect thus referred to. If you could, there would be no difference between the senses and the mind. People who try to imagine what ideas refer to befuddle themselves, and end up with a hopeless feeling about all abstractions.

正如在科学书籍中归纳论证应该是读者的主要关注点一样，在哲学方面，你必须密切关注哲学家的原则。它们可能是他要求你与他一起承担的事情，或者是他认为不言而喻的事情。假设没有问题。让他们看看接下来会发生什么，即使你自己有相反的假设。假装你相信你相信的事情是一种很好的心理锻炼真的不相信。你对自己的预判越清楚，你就越有可能不误判别人的预判。

Just as inductive arguments should be the reader’s main focus in the case of scientific books, so here, in the case of philosophy, you must pay closest attention to the philosophers principles. They may be either things he asks you to assume with him, or matters that he calls self-evident. There is no trouble about assumptions. Make them to see what follows, even if you yourself have contrary presuppositions. It is a good mental exercise to pretend that you believe something you really do not believe. And the clearer you are about your own prejudgments, the more likely you will be not to misjudge those made by others.

可能引起麻烦的是另一种原则。很少有哲学书籍不陈述作者认为不言而喻的某些命题。这些命题是直接从经验中得出的，而不是由其他命题证明的。

It is the other sort of principles that may cause trouble. Few philosophical books fail to state some propositions that the author regards as self-evident. Such propositions are drawn directly from experience rather than proved by other propositions.

需要记住的是，正如我们不止一次指出的那样，它们所依据的经验与科学家的特殊经验不同，是人类的共同经验。哲学家不在实验室工作，不在实地进行研究。因此，要理解和检验哲学家的主要原则，你不需要通过有条不紊的调查获得的特殊经验的外在帮助。他指的是你自己的常识和对你所生活的世界的日常观察。

The thing to remember is that the experience from which they are drawn, as we have noted more than once, is, unlike the scientist’s special experience, the common experience of mankind. The philosopher does no work in laboratories, no research in the field. Hence to understand and test a philosopher’s leading principles you do not need the extrinsic aid of special experience, obtained by methodical investigation. He refers you to your own common sense and daily observation of the world in which you live.

换句话说，你阅读一本哲学书的方法与它的写作方法非常相似。一个哲学家，面对一个问题，除了思考它什么也做不了。读者面对一本哲学书籍，只能阅读它——正如我们所知，这意味着思考它。除了头脑本身，没有其他的帮助。

In other words, the method according to which you should read a philosophical book is very similar to the method according to which it is written. A philosopher, faced with a problem, can do nothing but think about it. A reader, faced with a philosophical book, can do nothing but read it—which means, as we know, thinking about it. There are no other aids except the mind itself.

但这种读者和书本质上的孤独，恰恰是我们在分析阅读规则的长篇讨论之初所想象的情形。因此你可以明白为什么我们说阅读规则，正如我们已经陈述和解释的那样，更直接地适用于哲学书籍的阅读而不是任何其他类型的阅读。

But this essential loneliness of reader and book is precisely the situation that we imagined at the beginning of our long discussion of the rules of analytical reading. Thus you can see why we say that the rules of reading, as we have stated and explained them, apply more directly to the reading of philosophical books than to the reading of any other kind.

关于自己做主

On Making Up Your Own Mind

 

优秀的哲学理论著作与优秀的科学论文一样没有雄辩和宣传。你不不得不关心作者的“人格”，或者调查他的社会和经济背景。然而，阅读与你的作者处理过相同问题的其他伟大哲学家的著作是有用的。哲学家们在思想史上进行过长时间的对话。在你对他们所说的内容做出决定之前，你最好先听一听。

A good theoretical work in philosophy is as free from oratory and propaganda as a good scientific treatise. You do not have to be concerned about the “personality” of the author, or investigate his social and economic background. There is utility, however, in reading the works of other great philosophers who have dealt with the same problems as your author. The philosophers have carried on a long conversation with each other in the history of thought. You had better listen in on it before you make up your mind about what any of them says.

哲学家意见不一致的事实不应该困扰你，原因有二。首先，分歧的事实，如果持续存在，可能表明存在重大未解决的问题，也许是无法解决的问题。很高兴知道真正的奥秘在哪里。其次，其他人的分歧相对不重要。你的责任只是做出你自己的决定。面对哲学家们通过他们的书进行的长篇对话，你必须判断什么是真的什么是假的。当你读好一本哲学书——这意味着你也阅读了关于同一主题的其他哲学家——你就可以做出判断了。

The fact that philosophers disagree should not trouble you, for two reasons. First, the fact of disagreement, if it is persistent, may point to a great unsolved and, perhaps, insoluble problem. It is good to know where the true mysteries are. Second, the disagreements of others are relatively unimportant. Your responsibility is only to make up your own mind. In the presence of the long conversation that the philosophers have carried on through their books, you must judge what is true and what is false. When you have read a philosophical book well—and that means reading other philosophers on the same subject, too—you are in a position to judge.

确实，每个人都必须自己回答这些哲学问题，这是最显着的标志。采纳别人的意见，不是解决问题，而是逃避问题。你的答案必须有坚实的基础，并有论据支持。这意味着，最重要的是，你不能依赖专家的证词，而在科学的情况下你可能不得不这样做。

It is, indeed, the most distinctive mark of philosophical questions that everyone must answer them for himself. Taking the opinions of others is not solving them, but evading them. And your answers must be solidly grounded, with arguments to back them up. This means, above all, that you cannot depend on the testimony of experts, as you may have to do in the case of science.

原因是哲学家提出的问题比其他人提出的问题更重要。除了孩子。

The reason is that the questions philosophers ask are simply more important than the questions asked by anyone else. Except children.

神学注记

A Note on Theology

 

有两种神学，自然神学和教义神学。自然神学是哲学的一个分支。它可以说是形而上学的最后一章。如果你问，为了例如，因果关系是否是一个无穷无尽的过程，是否一切都是因果，如果你的回答是肯定的，你可能会发现自己陷入了无限倒退。因此，您可能不得不假设一些并非其本身引起的原始原因。亚里士多德称这种无原因的原因为不动的推动者。你可以给它起其他名字——你甚至可以说它只是上帝的另一个名字——但关键是你会通过你的头脑的独立努力——自然的工作——来达到这个概念。

There are two kinds of theology, natural theology and dogmatic theology. Natural theology is a branch of philosophy; it is the last chapter, as it were, in metaphysics. If you ask, for example, whether causation is an endless process, whether everything is caused, you may find yourself, if you answer in the affirmative, involved in an infinite regress. Therefore you may have to posit some originating cause that is not itself caused. Aristotle called this uncaused cause an unmoved mover. You could give it other names—you could even say that it was merely another name for God—but the point is that you would have arrived at the conception by the unaided effort-the natural working—of your mind.

教义神学与哲学的不同之处在于，它的首要原则是某些宗教的信徒所遵守的信仰条款。教义神学的著作总是依赖于教义和宣扬这些教义的教会的权威。

Dogmatic theology differs from philosophy in that its first principles are articles of faith adhered to by the communicants of some religion. A work of dogmatic theology always depends upon dogmas and the authority of a church that proclaims them.

如果你没有信仰，如果你不属于教会，你仍然可以通过像对待数学家的假设一样尊重它的教义来读好这样一本神学书籍。但是您必须始终牢记，信条不是信徒们假设的东西。对于拥有信仰的人来说，信仰是最确定的知识形式，而不是暂时的意见。

If you are not of the faith, if you do not belong to the church, you can nevertheless read such a theological book well by treating its dogmas with the same respect you treat the assumptions of a mathematician. But you must always keep in mind that an article of faith is not something that the faithful assume. Faith, for those who have it, is the most certain form of knowledge, not a tentative opinion.

对于今天的许多读者来说，理解这一点似乎很困难。通常，他们在处理教义神学时犯了两个错误中的一个或两个。第一个错误是拒绝接受，即使是暂时的，作为作者首要原则的信条。结果，读者继续与这些首要原则作斗争，从未真正关注过这本书本身。第二个错误是认为，因为第一原则是教条的，所以基于它们的论证、它们所支持的推理以及它们得出的结论都是同样的教条。当然，如果某些原则被接受，并且基于这些原则的推理是有说服力的，那么结论也必须被接受——至少在原则被接受的范围内。

Understanding this seems to be difficult for many readers today. Typically, they make either or both of two mistakes in dealing with dogmatic theology. The first mistake is to refuse to accept, even temporarily, the articles of faith that are the first principles of the author. As a result, the reader continues to struggle with these first principles, never really paying attention to the book itself. The second mistake is to assume that, because the first principles are dogmatic, the arguments based on them, the reasoning that they support, and the conclusions to which they lead are all dogmatic in the same way. It is true enough, of course, if certain principles are accepted, and the reasoning that is based on them is cogent, that the conclusions must then be accepted too—at least to the extent that the principles are. But if the reasoning is defective, the most acceptable first principles will lead to invalid conclusions.

正如你所看到的，我们在这里谈论的是神学著作的非信徒读者所面临的困难。他的任务是在阅读本书时接受第一原则为真，然后以任何优秀的说明性作品应有的谨慎来阅读它。对信仰必不可少的作品的忠实读者还有其他困难要面对。然而，这些问题并不局限于阅读神学。

We are speaking here, as you can see, of the difficulties that face a non-believing reader of a theological work. His task is to accept the first principles as true while he is reading the book, and then to read it with all the care that any good expository work deserves. The faithful reader of a work that is essential to his faith has other difficulties to face. However, these problems are not confined to reading theology.

如何阅读“规范”书籍

How to Read “Canonical” Books

 

有一种非常有趣的书，一种阅读，尚未讨论。我们使用“规范”一词来指代此类书籍；在更古老的传统中，我们可能称它们为“神圣的”或“圣洁的”，但这些词不再适用于所有此类作品，尽管它们仍然适用于其中一些作品。

There is one very interesting kind of book, one kind of reading, that has not yet been discussed.
