We use the term “canonical” to refer to such books; in an older tradition we might have called them “sacred” or “holy,” but those words no longer apply to all such works, though they still apply to some of them.

一个典型的例子是圣经，当它不是作为文学而是作为上帝启示的话语来阅读时。然而，对于正统的马克思主义者来说，马克思的著作必须以与正统的犹太人或基督徒必须阅读圣经的方式大致相同的方式来阅读。毛泽东的红宝书对于“忠实的”中国共产党人来说具有同样的典型特征。

A prime example is the Holy Bible, when it is read not as literature but instead as the revealed Word of God. For orthodox Marxists, however, the works of Marx must be read in much the same way as the Bible must be read by orthodox Jews or Christians. And Mao Tse-tung’s Little Red Book has an equally canonical character for a “faithful” Chinese Communist.

经典书籍的概念可以扩展到这些明显的例子之外。考虑任何机构——一个教会、一个政党、一个社会——除其他外 (1) 是一个教学机构，(2) 有一套教义要教授，并且 (3) 有忠实和服从的成员。任何此类组织的成员都会虔诚地阅读。他们不会——甚至不能——质疑对他们来说是经典的书籍的授权或正确阅读。信徒被他们的信仰禁止在“神圣”文本中发现错误，更不用说在那里发现胡说八道了。

The notion of a canonical book can be extended beyond these obvious examples. Consider any institution—a church, a political party, a society—that among other things (1) is a teaching institution, (2) has a body of doctrine to teach, and (3) has a faithful and obedient membership. The members of any such organization read reverentially. They do not—even cannot—question the authorized or right reading of the books that to them are canonical. The faithful are debarred by their faith from finding error in the “sacred” text, to say nothing of finding nonsense there.

正统犹太人以这种方式阅读旧约；基督徒，新约；穆斯林，古兰经；正统的马克思主义者，马克思和列宁的著作，并根据政治气氛，斯大林的；正统的弗洛伊德精神分析学家，弗洛伊德的著作；美国陆军军官，步兵手册。你可以自己想出更多的例子。

Orthodox Jews read the old Testament in this way; Christians, the New Testament; Muslims, the Koran; orthodox Marxists, the works of Marx and Lenin and, depending on the political climate, those of Stalin; orthodox Freudian psychoanalysts, the works of Freud; U.S. Army officers, the infantry manual. And you can think of many more examples by yourself.

事实上，我们几乎所有人，即使我们还没有完全达到它，都已经接近了我们必须按规范阅读的情况。一个初出茅庐的律师，一心要通过律师考试，必须以特定的方式阅读特定的文本才能获得满分。医生和其他专业人士也是如此；当我们作为学生时，确实如此，当我们被要求冒着“失败”的危险按照我们教授对它的解释来阅读文本时。（当然，并不是所有的教授都因为不同意他们的学生而让他们不及格！）

In fact, almost all of us, even if we have not quite reached it, have approached the situation in which we must read canonically. A fledgling lawyer, intent on passing the bar exams, must read certain texts in a certain way in order to attain a perfect score. So with doctors and other professionals; and indeed so with all of us when, as students, we were required at the peril of “failure” to read a text according to our professor’s interpretation of it. (Of course, not all professors fail their students for disagreeing with them!)

这种阅读的特点，或许可以用“正统”二字来概括，几乎无处不在。这个词来自两个希腊词根，意思是“正确的意见”。这些书只有一种正确的阅读方式；任何其他的阅读或解释都充满了危险，从失去一个“A”到一个人的灵魂被诅咒。这种特性带有一种义务。经典书籍的忠实读者有义务理解它，并在一种或另一种“真实”的意义上发现它是真实的。如果他自己不能做到这一点，他就不得不去找能做到的人。这可能是牧师或拉比，也可能是他在党内等级制度中的上级，也可能是他的教授。在任何情况下，他都必须接受提供给他的问题的解决方案。他基本上没有自由地读书；但作为回报，他获得了一种阅读其他书籍时可能永远无法获得的满足感。

The characteristics of this kind of reading are perhaps summed up in the word “orthodox,” which is almost always applicable. The word comes from two Greek roots, meaning “right opinion.” These are books for which there is one and only one right reading; any other reading or interpretation is fraught with peril, from the loss of an “A” to the damnation of one’s soul. This characteristic carries with it an obligation. The faithful reader of a canonical book is obliged to make sense out of it and to find it true in one or another sense of “true.” If he cannot do this by himself, he is obliged to go to someone who can. This may be a priest or a rabbi, or it may be his superior in the party hierarchy, or it may be his professor. In any case, he is obliged to accept the resolution of his problem that is offered him. He reads essentially without freedom; but in return for this he gains a kind of satisfaction that is possibly never obtained when reading other books.

事实上，我们必须在这里停下来。阅读圣书的问题——如果你相信它是神的话——是整个阅读领域中最困难的问题。关于如何阅读圣经的书籍比关于一起阅读艺术的所有其他方面的书籍还要多。神的话显然是人所能读懂的最难的文字；但它也是，如果你相信它是神的话，最重要的是阅读。信徒们的努力与任务的难度成正比。可以这样说，至少在欧洲传统中，圣经是一本多义的书。它不仅是阅读最广泛的书，也是阅读最仔细的书。

Here, in fact, we must stop. The problem of reading the Holy Book—if you have faith that it is the Word of God—is the most difficult problem in the whole field of reading. There have been more books written about how to read Scripture than about all other aspects of the art of reading together. The Word of God is obviously the most difficult writing men can read; but it is also, if you believe it is the Word of God, the most important to read. The effort of the faithful has been duly proportionate to the difficulty of the task. It would be true to say that, in the European tradition at least, the Bible is the book in more senses than one. It has been not only the most widely read, but also the most carefully read, book of all.

19

如何阅读社会科学

19HOW TO READ SOCIAL SCIENCE

 

社会科学的概念和术语几乎遍及我们今天阅读的所有内容。

The concepts and terminology of the social sciences pervade almost everything we read today.

例如，现代新闻业并不局限于报道事实，除了人们在报纸头版上发现的那种速记“谁-什么-为什么-何时-何地”的新闻故事。更常见的是，记者将事实融入新闻的解释、评论和分析中。这些解释和评论借鉴了社会科学的概念和术语。

Modern journalism, for example, does not limit itself to reporting facts, except in the kind of shorthand, “who-what-why-when-where” news story that one finds on the front page of a newspaper. Journalists, much more commonly, enmesh the facts in interpretation, commentary, analysis of the news. These interpretations and comments draw on the concepts and terminology of the social sciences.

这些概念和术语也反映在大量当前的书籍和文章中，这些书籍和文章可以归为社会批评的标题。我们面临着关于种族问题、犯罪、执法、贫困、教育、福利、战争与和平、好政府和坏政府等主题的源源不断的文献。这些文献中的大部分都借鉴了社会科学的意识形态和语言。

These concepts and this terminology are also reflected in the vast number of current books and articles that may be grouped together under the heading of social criticism. We are confronted with a continuous flow of literature on such subjects as race problems, crime, law enforcement, poverty, education, welfare, war and peace, good and bad government. Much of this literature borrows its ideology and language from the social sciences.

社会科学文学并不局限于非虚构类作品。还有一大类重要的当代作品可以称为社会科幻小说。这里的目标是创建人造社会模型，例如，让我们能够探索技术创新的社会后果。社会权力的组织，种类财产和所有权以及财富的分配在小说、戏剧、故事、电影和电视节目中有不同的描述、谴责或赞美。只要它们这样做，就可以说它们具有社会意义或包含“相关信息”。同时，他们利用和传播社会科学的元素。

The literature of social science is not confined to non-fiction. There is also a large and important category of contemporary writing that might be termed social-science fiction. Here the aim is to create artificial models of society that allow us, for example, to explore the social consequences of technological innovation. The organization of social power, the kinds of property and ownership, and the distribution of wealth are variously described, deplored, or lauded in novels, plays, stories, moving pictures, television shows. Insofar as they do this they may be said to have social significance or to contain “relevant messages.” At the same time they draw on and disseminate elements of the social sciences.

此外，几乎没有任何社会、经济或政治问题不是由这些领域的专家解决的，无论是他们自己还是应积极处理这些问题的官员的邀请。社会科学专家帮助阐明问题，并被要求帮助解决这些问题。

Furthermore, there is hardly any social, economic, or political problem that has not been tackled by specialists in these fields, either on their own or by invitation from officials who are actively coping with these problems. Specialists in the social sciences help to formulate the problems and are called upon to help in dealing with them.

在社会科学日益普及的过程中，最不重要的因素远非它们在高中阶段、大专和社区大学的引入。事实上，社会科学课程的学生入学人数远远超过更传统的文学和语言课程的入学人数。社会科学课程的注册人数大大超过了“纯”科学课程的注册人数。

Far from the least important factor in the growing pervasiveness of the social sciences is their introduction at the high school level and in the junior and community colleges. In fact, student enrollments in social science courses are running far ahead of enrollments in the more traditional literature and language courses. And enrollments in social science courses greatly exceed those in courses dealing with the “pure” sciences.

什么是社会科学？

What Is Social Science?

 

我们一直在谈论社会科学，就好像它是一个单一的实体。事实并非如此。

We have been talking of social science as if it were a single entity. That is hardly the case.

事实上，哪些是社会科学？回答这个问题的一种方法是查看大学在这个名称下有哪些部门和学科。社会科学部门通常包括人类学、经济学、政治学和社会学系。为什么它们通常不包括法学院、教育学院、商业学院、社会服务学院和公共管理学院，所有这些学院的发展都借鉴了社会科学的概念和方法？将这些学校与社会科学系分开的普遍理由是，这些学校的主要目的是是为大学以外的专业工作进行培训，而前面提到的部门更专门致力于追求人类社会的系统知识，这是一种通常在大学内进行的活动。

Which, in fact, are the social sciences? One way to answer the question is to see what departments and disciplines universities group under this name. Social science divisions usually include departments of anthropology, economics, politics, and sociology. Why do they not ordinarily include as well schools of law, education, business, social service, and public administration, all of which draw on the concepts and methods of the social sciences for their development? The reason commonly given for the separation of these schools from the social science divisions is that the main purpose of such schools is to train for professional work outside of the university, while the previously mentioned departments are more exclusively dedicated to the pursuit of systematic knowledge of human society, an activity that usually goes on within the university.

目前，大学中有建立跨学科研究中心和研究所的趋势。这些中心跨越传统的社会科学系和专业学校，包括统计理论和方法、人口学、心理学（选举和民意调查的科学）、政策和决策、人员招聘和待遇、公共管理学、人类生态学等等。这些中心正在制作研究和报告，其中包含十几个或更多这些专业的发现。即使要辨别这些努力的各个方面都需要相当复杂的知识，更不用说判断调查结果和结论的有效性了。

There is presently a trend in universities toward the establishment of centers and institutes for interdisciplinary studies. These centers cut across the conventional social science departments and professional schools, and include studies in the theories and methods of statistics, demography, psephology (the science of elections and polling), policy- and decision-making, recruitment and treatment of personnel, public administration, human ecology, and many more. Such centers are producing studies and reports that incorporate findings of a dozen or more of these specialties. Considerable sophistication is required even to discern the various strands of these efforts, let alone judge the validity of the findings and conclusions.

心理学呢？那些严格解释其领域的社会科学家倾向于将心理学排除在外，因为它关注个人和个人特征，而社会科学则适当地关注文化、制度和环境因素。那些不那么严格的人，虽然承认生理心理学应该归入生物科学，但认为正常和异常的心理学都应该被视为一门社会科学，因为个人与其社会环境不可分割。

What about psychology? Those social scientists who interpret their field strictly tend to exclude psychology on the grounds that it concerns itself with individual and personal characteristics, while the social sciences proper focus on cultural, institutional, and environmental factors. Those who are less strict, while conceding that physiological psychology should be subsumed under the biological sciences, hold that psychology, both normal and abnormal, should be regarded as a social science on the grounds of the inseparability of the individual from his social environment.

顺便说一句，心理学是目前在学生中非常受欢迎的社会科学领域的一个典型例子。全国范围内心理学的入学人数可能比任何其他学科都多。心理学文献，从最技术性的到最流行的，在各个层面都是巨大的。

Psychology, incidentally, is a prime example of a social science area that is currently enjoying great popularity among students. It is possible that enrollments in psychology across the country are larger than in any other subject. And the literature of psychology, at every level from the most technical to the most popular, is enormous.

行为科学呢？它们在社会科学图景中处于什么位置？正如最初使用的那样，术语行为科学包括社会学和人类学以及生物学、经济学、地理学、法律、心理学和精神病学以及政治学的行为方面。对行为的强调有助于强调能够被系统地调查并产生可验证结果的可观察、可测量的行为。最近，行为科学一词几乎被用作社会科学一词的同义词，但许多纯粹主义者反对这种用法。

What of the behavioral sciences? Where do they fit into the social science picture? As originally used, the term behavioral science included sociology and anthropology and the behavioral aspects of biology, economics, geography, law, psychology and psychiatry, and political science. The accent on behavior served to emphasize observable, measurable behavior capable of being systematically investigated and of producing verifiable findings. Recently, the term behavioral sciences has come to be used almost as a synonym of the term social sciences, but many purists object to this usage.

最后，历史呢？众所周知，社会科学利用历史研究来获取数据及其概括的例证。然而，尽管历史被视为对特定事件和人物的描述，从构成系统知识的最低限度意义上讲，它可能是科学的，但就其本身产生关于行为和发展的模式或规律的系统知识而言，它并不是一门科学。

Finally, what about history? It is acknowledged that the social sciences draw on the study of history for data and for exemplifications of their generalizations. However, although history, viewed as accounts of particular events and persons, may be scientific in the minimal sense of constituting systematic knowledge, it is not a science in the sense that of itself it yields systematic knowledge of patterns or laws of behavior and development.

那么，是否有可能定义我们所指的社会科学？我们认为是这样，至少就本章而言是这样。人类学、经济学、政治学和社会学等领域构成了社会科学的一种中心核心，几乎所有社会科学家都会将其包含在任何定义中。此外，我们认为大多数社会科学家都会承认，法律、教育和公共管理等领域的大部分（尽管不是全部）文献，以及商业和社会服务等领域的一些文献，加在一起与相当一部分心理学文献一样，属于合理定义的范围。我们将假设这样的定义，尽管公认的不精确，但在下文中您会很清楚。

Is it possible, then, to define what we mean by social science? We think so, at least for the purposes of this chapter. Such fields as anthropology, economics, politics, and sociology constitute a kind of central core of social science, which almost all social scientists would include in any definition. In addition, we think it would be conceded by most social scientists that much, though not all, of the literature of such fields as law, education, and public administration, and some of the literature of such fields as business and social service, together with a considerable portion of psychological literature, falls within the confines of a reasonable definition. We will assume that such a definition, although admittedly imprecise, is clear to you in what follows.

阅读社会科学的明显轻松

The Apparent Ease of Reading Social Science

 

大量的社会科学著作似乎是最容易阅读的材料。数据通常来自读者熟悉的经验——在这方面，社会科学就像诗歌或哲学——阐述的风格通常是叙述性的，读者通过阅读小说和历史已经很熟悉了。

A great deal of social science writing seems like the easiest possible material to read. The data are often drawn from experiences familiar to the reader—in this respect, social science is like poetry or philosophy—and the style of exposition is usually narrative, already familiar to the reader through his reading of fiction and history.

此外，我们都熟悉并经常使用社会科学的行话。诸如文化（交叉、反面和次要）、群体内、异化、地位、输入/输出、基础结构、种族、行为、共识以及类似的分数之类的术语，往往会出现在几乎每一次谈话中，几乎我们读到的一切。

In addition, we have all become familiar with the jargon of social science and use it often. Such terms as culture (cross, counter, and sub), in-group, alienation, status, input/output, infra-structure, ethnic, behavioral, consensus, and scores like them, tend to appear in almost every conversation and in almost everything we read.

想想“社会”这个词本身。这是一个多么像变色龙的词，多么多的形容词可以放在它的前面，同时它始终传达着人们生活在一起而不是孤立的广泛概念。我们听说过异常社会、流产社会、顺从社会、贪得无厌的社会、富裕社会，我们可以继续通过字母表，直到我们到达发酵社会，这是一个处于持续发酵状态的社会，与我们自己的不同。

Consider the word “society” itself. What a chameleon-like word it is, what a host of adjectives can be placed in front of it, while throughout it continues to convey the broad notion of people living together rather than in isolation. We hear of the aberrant society, the abortive society, the acquiescent society, the acquisitive society, the affluent society, and we can continue on through the alphabet until we arrive at the zymotic society, which is one that is in a continuous state of ferment, not unlike our own.

“社会”作为形容词，也是一个具有许多熟悉含义的词。有社会权力、社会压力和社会承诺——当然，还有无处不在的社会问题。最后一句话确实是社会科学文献阅读和写作中似是而非的轻松的一个很好的例子。我们愿意打赌，在过去的几个月里，如果不是最近几周，你已经读过甚至可能写过“政治、经济和社会问题”这个短语。当你阅读或撰写它时，你可能很清楚政治和经济问题的含义。但是，您或作者所说的社会问题是什么意思？

“Social,” as an adjective, is also a word of many and familiar meanings. There is social power, social pressure, and social promise—and then, of course, there are the ubiquitous social problems. The last phrase, indeed, is a fine example of the specious ease that is involved in both the reading and the writing of social science literature. We would be willing to wager that in the last few months, if not the last few weeks, you have read and even possibly written the phrase “political, economic, and social problems.” When you read or wrote it, you were probably clear as to what was meant by political and economic problems. But what did you, or the author, mean by social problems?

许多社会科学著作中的行话和隐喻，加上常常充斥其中的深刻情感，使得阅读起来看似容易。参考文献是指读者很容易熟悉的事物；事实上，他几乎每天都读到或听到它们。此外，他对他们的态度和感受通常是坚定的。哲学也一样，处理我们通常所知的世界，但我们通常不会“致力于”哲学问题。但在社会科学处理的问题上，我们可能会有强烈的意见。

The jargon and metaphors of much social science writing, together with the deep feeling that often imbues it, make for deceptively easy reading. The references are to matters that are readily familiar to the reader; indeed, he reads or hears about them almost daily. Furthermore, his attitudes and feelings regarding them are usually firmly developed. Philosophy, too, deals with the world as we commonly know it, but we are not ordinarily “committed” on philosophical questions. But on matters with which social science deals, we are likely to have strong opinions.

阅读社会科学的难点

Difficulties of Reading Social Science

 

矛盾的是，正是我们所讨论的因素，使社会科学看起来容易阅读的因素，也使它难以阅读。例如，考虑提到的最后一个因素——您作为读者可能对您的作者正在考虑的问题有某种看法的承诺。许多读者担心，如果他们站在一边并客观地质疑他们正在阅读的内容，那将是对他们承诺的背叛。然而，每当您进行分析性阅读时，这都是必要的。这种立场是阅读规则所暗示的，至少是结构概述和解释的规则所暗示的。如果你要回答你读到的任何东西都应该问的前两个问题，你必须，可以说，在门口检查你的意见。如果你拒绝听一本书在说什么，你就无法理解一本书。

Paradoxically, the very factors we have discussed, the factors which make social science seem easy to read, also make it difficult to read. Consider the last factor mentioned, for instance—the commitment that you as a reader are likely to have to some view of the matter your author is considering. Many readers fear that it would be disloyal to their commitment to stand apart and impersonally question what they are reading. Yet this is necessary whenever you read analytically. Such a stance is implied by the rules of reading, at least by the rules of structural outlining and interpretation. If you are going to answer the first two questions that should be asked of anything you read, you must, as it were, check your opinions at the door. You cannot understand a book if you refuse to hear what it is saying.

社会科学写作中的术语和命题非常熟悉也是理解的障碍。许多社会科学家自己也认识到这一点。他们强烈反对在通俗新闻和其他著作中使用或多或少的技术术语和概念。这种概念的一个例子是国民生产总值 (GNP)。在严肃的经济著作中，这个概念的使用意义相对有限。但许多记者和专栏作家，一些社会科学家说，让这个概念做了太多的工作。他们用得太广泛了，却没有真正理解它的意思。显然，如果您正在阅读的某物的作者对他对关键术语的使用感到困惑，那么作为读者的您一定也是如此。

The very familiarity of the terms and propositions in social science writing is also an obstacle to understanding. Many social scientists recognize this themselves. They object vigorously to the use of more or less technical terms and concepts in popular journalism and other writings. An example of such a concept is that of the Gross National Product (GNP). In serious economic writing, the concept is employed in a relatively limited sense. But many reporters and columnists, some social scientists say, make the concept do too much work. They use it too widely, without really understanding what it means. Obviously, if the writer of something you are reading is confused about his use of a key term, you, as reader, must be so, too.

让我们试着通过区分来阐明这一点一方面是社会科学，另一方面是所谓的硬科学——物理学、化学等。我们已经观察到，一本科学书籍（在后一种意义上使用“科学”）的作者清楚地表明了他的假设和他想要证明的东西，并确保他的术语和命题很容易被发现。由于达成共识并找到命题是阅读任何说明性作品的主要部分，这意味着就此类书籍而言，大部分工作都是为您完成的。您可能仍然难以理解数学表示形式；如果你没有牢牢把握论点和结论的实验或观察基础，你会发现很难批评这本书——也就是说，很难回答问题，这是真的吗？那是什么？尽管如此，

Let us try to make this point clear by drawing a distinction between the social sciences, on the one hand, and the so-called hard sciences—physics, chemistry, and the like—on the other hand. We have observed that the author of a scientific book (taking “scientific” in the latter sense) makes clear what he assumes and what he desires to prove, and also makes sure that his terms and propositions are easy to spot. Since coming to terms and finding the propositions is a main part of reading any expository work, this means that much of the work is done for you in the case of such books. You may still have difficulty with the mathematical form of presentation; and if you do not have a firm grasp of the arguments and of the experimental or observational basis of the conclusions, you will find it hard to criticize the book—that is, to answer the questions, Is it true? and What of it? Nevertheless, there is an important sense in which the reading of this kind of scientific books is easier than the reading of most other kinds of expository works.

另一种表达硬科学家所做的事情的方式是说他“规定了他的用法”——也就是说，他告诉你哪些术语对他的论点是必不可少的，以及他将如何使用它们。这些规定通常出现在本书的开头，以定义、假设、公理等形式出现。由于使用规定是这些领域的特征，因此有人说它们就像游戏或具有“游戏结构”。规定使用就像制定游戏规则一样。如果你想玩扑克，你不会质疑三对牌比两对牌更好的规则；如果你想玩桥牌，你不会与女王拿 J 的惯例争论（在同一花色中），或者最大的王牌拿任何其他牌（在花色合同中）。相似地，你不会质疑一位科学家在阅读他的书时的规定。你接受它们，然后从那里继续。

Another way to say what it is that the hard scientist does is to say that he “stipulates his usage”—that is, he informs you what terms are essential to his argument and how he is going to use them. Such stipulations usually occur at the beginning of the book, in the form of definitions, postulates, axioms, and so forth. Since stipulation of usage is characteristic of these fields, it has been said that they are like games or have a “game structure.” Stipulation of usage is like establishing the rules of a game. If you want to play poker, you do not dispute the rule that three of a kind is a better hand than two pairs; if you want to play bridge, you do not argue with the convention that a queen takes a jack (in the same suit), or that the highest trump takes any other card (in a suit contract). Similarly, you do not dispute a hard scientist’s stipulations in reading his book. You accept them, and go on from there.

至少直到最近，对用法的规定在社会科学中并不像在硬科学中那样普遍。原因之一是社会科学通常没有数学化。另一个是社会或行为科学中的用法规定更难做到。这是一回事定义一个圆或一个等腰三角形；定义经济萧条或心理健康是另一回事。即使社会科学家试图定义这些术语，他的读者也倾向于质疑他的用法。结果，社会科学家必须在他的整个工作中继续与他自己的术语作斗争——而他的斗争给他的读者带来了问题。

Until quite recently, at least, stipulation of usage was not as common in the social sciences as it is in the hard sciences. One reason for this is that the social sciences were typically not mathematicized. Another is that stipulation of usage in the social or behavioral sciences is harder to do. It is one thing to define a circle or an isosceles triangle; it is quite another to define an economic depression or mental health. Even if a social scientist attempts to define such terms, his readers are inclined to question his usage. As a result, the social scientist must continue to struggle with his own terms throughout his work—and his struggle creates problems for his reader.

阅读社会科学最重要的困难来自于这样一个事实，即这个文学领域是一种混合的，而不是纯粹的说明性写作。我们已经看到历史如何是虚构和科学的混合体，以及我们如何必须牢记这一点来阅读它。我们熟悉这种混合物；我们对此有很多经验。社会科学的情况则大不相同。许多社会科学是科学、哲学和历史的混合体，通常会加入一些虚构的内容。

The most important source of difficulty in reading social science derives from the fact that this field of literature is a mixed, rather than a pure, kind of expository writing. We have seen how history is a mixture of fiction and science, and how we must read it with that in mind. We are familiar with this kind of mixture; we have had a great deal of experience with it. The situation in social science is quite different. Much social science is a mixture of science, philosophy, and history, often with some fiction thrown in for good measure.

如果社会科学总是同一种混合物，我们就会像熟悉历史一样熟悉它。但事实远非如此。混合本身从一本书转移到另一本书，读者面临着识别构成他正在阅读的内容的各种线索的任务。这些线索可能会在一本书的过程中发生变化，也可能会在不同的书中发生变化。将它们分开并不是一件容易的事。

If social science were always the same kind of mixture, we could become familiar with it as we have with history. But this is far from the case. The mixture itself shifts from book to book, and the reader is confronted with the task of identifying the various strands that go to make up what he is reading. These strands may change in the course of a single book as well as in different books. It is no easy job to separate them out.

你会记得，分析型读者必须采取的第一步是回答这个问题，这是什么类型的书？就小说而言，这个问题相对容易回答。就科学和哲学而言，这也相对容易；即使历史是混合形式，至少读者通常知道他在读历史。但是构成社会科学的各种线索——有时以这种模式交织在一起，有时以那种模式交织在一起，有时又以另一种模式交织在一起——使我们在阅读涉及任何领域的著作时都很难回答这个问题。事实上，这个问题和定义社会科学的问题一样困难。

You will recall that the first step the analytical reader has to take is to answer the question, What kind of book is this? In the case of fiction, that question is relatively easy to answer. In the case of science and philosophy, it is also relatively easy; and even if history is a mixed form, at least the reader ordinarily knows that he is reading history. But the various strands that go to make up social science—sometimes interwoven in this pattern, sometimes in that, sometimes in still another—make the question very hard to answer when we are reading a work in any of the fields involved. The problem, in fact, is precisely as difficult as the problem of defining social science.

然而，分析型读者必须以某种方式设法回答这个问题。这不仅是他的首要任务，也是他最重要的任务。如果他能说出要做什么阅读他正在阅读的书，他将在理解这本书方面迈进了一个很好的途径。

Nevertheless, the analytical reader must somehow manage to answer the question. It is not only his first task, but also his most important. If he is able to say what strands go to make up the book he is reading, he will have moved a good way toward understanding it.

概述社会科学著作的大纲并没有什么特别的问题，但是正如我们已经建议的那样，与作者达成协议可能会非常困难，因为作者相对无法规定他的用法。尽管如此，对关键术语的一些共同理解通常是可能的。我们从术语转向命题和论证，如果这本书是一本好书，这里也没有特别的问题。但最后一个问题，“它是什么？”，需要读者有相当大的克制。正是在这里，我们前面描述的情况可能会发生——即读者说“我不能批评作者的结论，但我仍然不同意它们”的情况。当然，这是因为读者可能对作者的方法和结论有先入为主的判断。

Outlining a work in social science poses no special problems, but coming to terms with the author, as we have already suggested, may be extremely difficult, owing to the relative inability of the author to stipulate his usage. Nevertheless, some common understanding of the key terms is usually possible. From terms we move to propositions and arguments, and here again there is no special problem if the book is a good one. But the last question, What of it?, requires considerable restraint on the part of the reader. It is here that the situation we described earlier may occur—namely, the situation in which the reader says, “I cannot fault the author’s conclusions, but I nevertheless disagree with them.” This comes about, of course, because of the prejudgments that the reader is likely to have concerning the author’s approach and his conclusions.

阅读社会科学文献

Reading Social Science Literature

 

在本章中，我们不止一次使用了“社会科学文献”这个短语而不是“社会科学书籍”。原因是在社会科学中习惯于阅读关于一个主题的几本书，而不是为了阅读一本书本身。这不仅是因为社会科学是一个相对较新的领域，经典著作还很少。这也是因为在阅读社会科学时，我们往往主要关注特定的事物或问题，而不是特定的作者或书籍。例如，我们对执法很感兴趣，我们阅读了六本关于这个主题的著作。或者我们的兴趣可能涉及种族关系、教育、税收或地方政府的问题。通常，关于这些主题的任何一个都没有单一的权威著作，因此我们必须阅读几本。一个迹象是社会科学作者自己为了与时俱进，必须不断推出新的修订版本他们的作品；新作品取代旧作品并迅速使它们过时。

More than once in the course of this chapter we have employed the phrase “social science literature” instead of “social science book.” The reason is that it is customary in social science to read several books about a subject rather than one book for its own sake. This is not only because social science is a relatively new field with as yet but few classic texts. It is also because when reading social science, we often have our eye primarily on a particular matter or problem, rather than on a particular author or book. We are interested in law enforcement, for example, and we read half a dozen works on the subject. Or our interest may concern race relations, or education, or taxation, or the problems of local government. Typically, there is no single, authoritative work on any of these subjects, and we must therefore read several. One sign of this is that social science authors themselves, in order to keep up with the times, must constantly bring out new, revised editions of their works; and new works supersede older ones and rapidly render them obsolete.

正如我们已经观察到的，在某种程度上，哲学中也出现了类似的情况。要完全理解一个哲学家，你应该尝试阅读你的作者自己读过的哲学家，那些对他有影响的哲学家。在某种程度上，历史也是如此，我们建议，如果你想发现过去的真相，你最好多读几本书，而不是一本。但在那些情况下，你找到一本重要的、权威的著作的可能性要大得多。在社会科学中，这种情况并不常见，因此阅读多本著作而不是一本的必要性更为迫切。

To some extent, a similar situation obtains in philosophy, as we have already observed. Fully to understand a philosopher, you should make some attempt to read the philosophers your author himself has read, the philosophers who have influenced him. To some extent it is also true in history, where we suggested that, if you want to discover the truth of the past, you had better read several books about it rather than one. But in those cases the likelihood that you would find one major, authoritative work was much greater. In social science that is not so common, and so the necessity of reading several works rather than one is much more urgent.

分析阅读的规则本身并不适用于阅读同一主题的多部作品。当然，它们适用于阅读的每一部作品，如果你想读好其中任何一部，你就必须观察它们。但是，当我们从第三级阅读（分析阅读）过渡到第四级（主题阅读）时，需要新的阅读规则。由于社会科学的这一特点，我们现在已经准备好应对第四个层次，我们已经认识到它的必要性。

The rules of analytical reading are not in themselves applicable to the reading of several works on the same subject. They apply to each of the works that is read, of course, and if you want to read any of them well you have to observe them. But new rules of reading are required as we pass from the third level of reading (analytical reading), to the fourth (syntopical reading). We are now prepared to tackle that fourth level, having come to see, because of this characteristic of social science, the need for it.

指出这一点可以清楚地说明为什么我们将社会科学的讨论放到第三部分的最后一章。现在应该清楚为什么我们以我们的方式组织讨论了。我们从阅读实用书籍开始，实用书籍与其他书籍不同，因为如果读者同意并接受他正在阅读的内容，他就有特殊的行动义务。然后我们处理了小说和诗歌，它们提出了与说明性书籍不同的特殊问题。最后，我们处理了三种类型的理论说明性写作——科学和数学、哲学和社会科学。社会科学排在最后，因为需要按主题阅读。因此，本章既是第三部分的结尾，也是第四部分的导言。

Pointing this out makes it clear why we relegated the discussion of the social sciences to the last chapter in Part Three. It should now be clear why we organized the discussion in the way we did. We began with the reading of practical books, which are different from all others because of the special obligation to act that the reader is under if he agrees with and accepts what he is reading. We then treated fiction and poetry, which pose special problems that are unlike those of expository books. Finally, we dealt with three types of theoretical, expository writing—science and mathematics, philosophy, and social science. Social science came last because of the need to read it syntopically. Thus the present chapter serves as both the end of Part Three and an introduction to Part Four.

第四部分

PART FOUR

 

阅读的终极目标

The Ultimate Goals of Reading

 

20

阅读的第四个层次：主题阅读

20THE FOURTH LEVEL OF READING: SYNTOPICAL READING

 

到目前为止，我们还没有具体说明如何阅读同一主题的两本或更多书籍。我们试图建议在讨论某些主题时，不止一本书是相关的，而且我们还不时以非常非正式的方式提到各个领域的某些相关书籍和作者。知道不止一本书与特定问题相关是任何专题阅读项目的首要要求。第二个要求是知道应该阅读哪些书。第二个要求比第一个更难满足。

So far we have not said anything specific about how to read two or more books on the same subject. We have tried to suggest that when certain subjects are discussed, more than one book is relevant, and we have also from time to time mentioned, in a very informal way, certain related books and authors in various fields. Knowing that more than one book is relevant to a particular question is the first requirement in any project of syntopical reading. Knowing which books should be read, in a general way, is the second requirement. The second requirement is a great deal harder to satisfy than the first.

当我们检查“关于同一主题的两本或更多书”这个短语时，困难就变得很明显了。“同一主题”是什么意思？当主题是一个单一的历史时期或事件时，这也许就足够清楚了，但在几乎任何其他领域都找不到如此清晰的地方。《乱世佳人》和《战争与和平》都是关于一场伟大战争的小说——但在大多数情况下，相似之处就此止步。司汤达的《帕尔马修道院》是“关于”同一个冲突——即拿破仑战争——托尔斯泰的小说是“关于”的。但当然，这两者都与战争无关，或者实际上与战争本身无关。战争为这两个故事提供了背景或背景——就像它对人类生活的大部分内容一样——但正是这些故事吸引了作者的注意力。我们可以学习关于战争的一些事情——事实上，托尔斯泰曾经说过，他从司汤达对滑铁卢战役的描述中学到了很多关于战争的知识——但如果我们的主要目的是研究战争，我们就不会去看这些小说或任何其他小说.

The difficulty becomes evident as soon as we examine the phrase “two or more books on the same subject.” What do we mean by “same subject”? Perhaps this is clear enough when the subject is a single historical period or event, but in hardly any other sphere is there much clarity to be found. Gone With the Wind and War and Peace are both novels about a great war—but there, for the most part, the resemblance stops. Stendhal’s The Charterhouse of Parma is “about” the same conflict-that is, the Napoleonic Wars—that Tolstoy’s novel is “about.” But of course neither is about the war, or indeed about war in general, as such. War provides the context or background of both stories—as it does for much of human life—but it is the stories on which the authors rivet our attention. We may learn something about the war—in fact, Tolstoy once said that he had learned much of what he knew about battles from Stendhal’s account of the Battle of Waterloo—but we do not go to these novels or any others if our primary intention is to study war.

您可能已经预料到小说会出现这种情况。小说家与说明性作家不同的交流方式是固有的事实。但在说明性作品的情况下也会出现这种情况。

You could have anticipated that this situation would obtain in the case of fiction. It is inherent in the fact that the novelist does not communicate in the same way that an expository writer does. But the situation obtains in the case of expository works, as well.

例如，假设您有兴趣阅读有关爱的概念。由于爱情文学浩瀚无边，因此创建书籍参考书目以供阅读的难度相对较小。假设你已经这样做了，通过询问顾问，通过搜索一个好的图书馆的卡片目录，并通过检查关于这个主题的一个好的学术论文的参考书目。此外，假设你将自己局限于说明性作品，尽管小说家和诗人无疑对这个主题感兴趣。（稍后我们将解释为什么建议这样做。）现在您开始检查参考书目中的书籍。你发现了什么？

Suppose, for example, that you are interested in reading about the idea of love. Since the literature of love is vast, you would have relatively little difficulty in creating a bibliography of books to read. Suppose that you have done that, by asking advisors, by searching through the card catalogue of a good library, and by examining the bibliography in a good scholarly treatise on the subject. And suppose in addition that you have confined yourself to expository works, despite the undoubted interest of novelists and poets in the subject. (We will explain why it would be advisable to do this later.) You now begin to examine the books in your bibliography. What do you find?

即使是粗略的阅读，也会发现非常广泛的参考范围。几乎没有任何一种人类行为不被称为——以这样或那样的方式——爱的行为。范围也不限于人类领域。如果你阅读得足够深入，你会发现宇宙中几乎所有事物都被赋予了爱；也就是说，存在的一切都被某人说过爱或被爱——或两者兼而有之。

Even a cursory perusal reveals a very great range of reference. There is hardly a single human action that has not been called—in one way or another—an act of love. Nor is the range confined to the human sphere. If you proceed far enough in your reading, you will find that love has been attributed to almost everything in the universe; that is, everything that exists has been said by someone either to love or to be loved—or both.

据说石头喜欢地球的中心。火的向上运动被称为它的爱的功能。铁屑对磁铁的吸引力被描述为爱的效果。关于变形虫、草履虫、蜗牛和蚂蚁的爱情生活的小册子已经写成，更不用说大多数所谓的高等动物了，据说它们既爱主人又爱彼此。当我们谈到人类时，我们发现作家们谈论和写下他们对男人、女人、女人、男人、孩子、他们自己、人类、金钱、艺术、家庭生活、原则、事业、职业或职业的爱，冒险，安全，想法，乡村生活，自爱，牛排或葡萄酒。在某些博学的论文中，据说天体的运动是由爱所激发的；在另一些情况下，天使和魔鬼的区别在于他们的爱的质量。当然，据说上帝就是爱。

Stones are said to love the center of the earth. The upward motion of fire is called a function of its love. The attraction of iron filings to a magnet is described as an effect of love. Tracts have been written on the love life of amoebae, paramecia, snails, and ants, to say nothing of most of the so-called higher animals, who are said to love their masters as well as one another. When we come to human beings, we discover that authors speak and write of their love for men, women, a woman, a man, children, themselves, mankind, money, art, domesticity, principles, a cause, an occupation or profession, adventure, security, ideas, a country life, loving itself, a beefsteak, or wine. In certain learned treatises, the motions of the heavenly bodies are said to be inspired by love; in others, angels and devils are differentiated by the quality of their love. And of course God is said to be Love.

面对如此巨大的参考范围，我们如何说明我们正在研究的主题是什么？我们甚至可以确定只有一个主题吗？当一个人说“我爱奶酪”，另一个人说“我爱足球”，第三个人说“我爱人类”时，他们三个都在使用这个词吗？毕竟，吃奶酪不吃足球不吃人类，踢足球不吃奶酪也不吃人类，无论“我爱人类”是什么意思，这个意思似乎都不适用于奶酪或足球。然而这三个人确实使用同一个词。实际上是否有一些深层原因，一些表面上并不明显的原因？尽管这个问题很难，但在我们回答之前，我们是否可以说我们已经确定了“同一主题”？

Confronted with this enormous range of reference, how are we to state what the subject is that we are investigating? Can we even be sure that there is a single subject? When one person says “I love cheese,” and another says “I love football,” and a third says “I love mankind,” are they all three using the word in any sense that is common? After all, one eats cheese but not football or mankind, one plays football but not cheese or mankind, and whatever “I love mankind” means, that meaning does not seem to be applicable to cheese or football. And yet all three do use the same word. Is there in fact some deep reason for that, some reason that is not immediately apparent on the surface? Difficult as that question is, can we say that we have identified the “same subject” until we have answered it?

面对这种混乱的情况，你可能会决定将探究限制在人类的爱上——人类之间的爱，同性或异性，同龄或不同年龄等等。这将排除我们刚才讨论的三个陈述。但是，即使您只阅读了有关该主题的可用书籍的一小部分，您仍然会发现非常广泛的参考资料。例如，你会发现一些作家说爱情完全在于占有欲，通常是性欲；也就是说，爱只是几乎所有动物对异性成员的吸引力的一个名称。但你也会发现其他作者认为，爱，严格地说，不包含任何占有欲，而在于纯粹的仁爱。为自己，而仁意味着要为别人好？

Faced with this chaotic situation, you may decide to limit the enquiry to human love—to love between human beings, of the same sex or different sexes, of the same age or different ages, and so forth. That would rule out the three statements we have just discussed. But you would still find, even if you read only a small portion of the available books about the subject, a very great range of reference. You would find, for instance, that love is said by some writers to consist wholly in acquisitive desire, usually sexual desire; that is, love is merely a name for the attraction that almost all animals feel toward members of the opposite sex. But you would also find other authors who maintain that love, properly speaking, contains no acquisitive desire whatever, and consists in pure benevolence. Do acquisitive desire and benevolence have anything in common, considering that acquisitive desire always implies wanting some good for oneself, while benevolence implies wanting a good for someone else?

至少贪欲和仁爱是有共同点的趋势的记录，在这个词的某种非常抽象的意义上的欲望。但是你对这个主题的文学研究很快就会发现那些认为爱的本质是认知而非欲望的作家。这些作家认为，爱是一种智力行为，而不是情感行为。换句话说，知道另一个人是令人钦佩的总是在两种欲望的任何一种意义上对他或她产生欲望。这些作者并不否认欲望进入画面，但他们确实否认欲望应该被称为爱。

At least acquisitive desire and benevolence share a common note of tendency, of desire in some very abstract sense of the term. But your investigation of the literature of the subject would soon uncover writers who conceive of the essence of love as being cognitive rather than appetitive. Love, these writers maintain, is an intellectual act, not an emotional one. In other words, knowing that another person is admirable always proceeds desiring him or her, in either of the two senses of desire. Such authors do not deny that desire enters into the picture, but they do deny that desire should be called love.

让我们假设——事实上，我们认为这是可以做到的——你能够在这些不同的人类爱情概念中识别出一些共同的含义。即使那样，也不是所有的问题都得到解决。考虑一下爱在人与人之间表现出来的方式。男人和女人对彼此的爱，在恋爱时和结婚时是一样的，在二十多岁和七十多岁时是一样的吗？女人对丈夫的爱和对孩子的爱一样吗？母亲对孩子的爱会随着孩子的成长而改变吗？兄弟对妹妹的爱和对父亲的爱一样吗？孩子对父母的爱会随着他或她的成长而改变吗？男人对女人的爱，无论是他的妻子还是其他人，就像他对另一个男人的友谊一样，他和这个人的关系有什么不同——比如和他一起打保龄球的人，和他一起工作的人，以及他喜欢和他一起智力的人？“爱”和“友谊”是不同的词这一事实是否意味着他们命名的情感（如果这实际上是他们命名的）不同？两个不同年龄的男人能成为朋友吗？如果他们在某些其他方面（例如拥有的财富或智力水平）明显不同，他们可以成为朋友吗？女人真的可以做朋友吗？兄弟姐妹能不能做朋友，或者兄弟姐妹，或者姐妹姐妹？你能与借钱或借钱的人保持友谊吗？不是，为什么不呢？一个男孩可以爱他的老师吗？是否有区别 他和这个人的关系有什么不同——比如和他一起打保龄球的人，和他一起工作的人，以及他喜欢和他一起知识分子的人？“爱”和“友谊”是不同的词这一事实是否意味着他们命名的情感（如果这实际上是他们命名的）不同？两个不同年龄的男人能成为朋友吗？如果他们在某些其他方面（例如拥有的财富或智力水平）明显不同，他们可以成为朋友吗？女人真的可以做朋友吗？兄弟姐妹能不能做朋友，或者兄弟姐妹，或者姐妹姐妹？你能与借钱或借钱的人保持友谊吗？不是，为什么不呢？一个男孩可以爱他的老师吗？是否有区别 他和这个人的关系有什么不同——比如和他一起打保龄球的人，和他一起工作的人，以及他喜欢和他一起知识分子的人？“爱”和“友谊”是不同的词这一事实是否意味着他们命名的情感（如果这实际上是他们命名的）不同？两个不同年龄的男人能成为朋友吗？如果他们在某些其他方面（例如拥有的财富或智力水平）明显不同，他们可以成为朋友吗？女人真的可以做朋友吗？兄弟姐妹能不能做朋友，或者兄弟姐妹，或者姐妹姐妹？你能与借钱或借钱的人保持友谊吗？不是，为什么不呢？一个男孩可以爱他的老师吗？是否有区别 一个与他一起工作的人，一个他喜欢与谁一起工作的人？“爱”和“友谊”是不同的词这一事实是否意味着他们命名的情感（如果这实际上是他们命名的）不同？两个不同年龄的男人能成为朋友吗？如果他们在某些其他方面（例如拥有的财富或智力水平）明显不同，他们可以成为朋友吗？女人真的可以做朋友吗？兄弟姐妹能不能做朋友，或者兄弟姐妹，或者姐妹姐妹？你能与借钱或借钱的人保持友谊吗？不是，为什么不呢？一个男孩可以爱他的老师吗？是否有区别 一个与他一起工作的人，一个他喜欢与谁一起工作的人？“爱”和“友谊”是不同的词这一事实是否意味着他们命名的情感（如果这实际上是他们命名的）不同？两个不同年龄的男人能成为朋友吗？如果他们在某些其他方面（例如拥有的财富或智力水平）明显不同，他们可以成为朋友吗？女人真的可以做朋友吗？兄弟姐妹能不能做朋友，或者兄弟姐妹，或者姐妹姐妹？你能与借钱或借钱的人保持友谊吗？不是，为什么不呢？一个男孩可以爱他的老师吗？是否有区别 和一个他喜欢谁的智力公司？“爱”和“友谊”是不同的词这一事实是否意味着他们命名的情感（如果这实际上是他们命名的）不同？两个不同年龄的男人能成为朋友吗？如果他们在某些其他方面（例如拥有的财富或智力水平）明显不同，他们可以成为朋友吗？女人真的可以做朋友吗？兄弟姐妹能不能做朋友，或者兄弟姐妹，或者姐妹姐妹？你能与借钱或借钱的人保持友谊吗？不是，为什么不呢？一个男孩可以爱他的老师吗？是否有区别 和一个他喜欢谁的智力公司？“爱”和“友谊”是不同的词这一事实是否意味着他们命名的情感（如果这实际上是他们命名的）不同？两个不同年龄的男人能成为朋友吗？如果他们在某些其他方面（例如拥有的财富或智力水平）明显不同，他们可以成为朋友吗？女人真的可以做朋友吗？兄弟姐妹能不能做朋友，或者兄弟姐妹，或者姐妹姐妹？你能与借钱或借钱的人保持友谊吗？不是，为什么不呢？一个男孩可以爱他的老师吗？是否有区别 例如拥有财富或智力程度？女人真的可以做朋友吗？兄弟姐妹能不能做朋友，或者兄弟姐妹，或者姐妹姐妹？你能与借钱或借钱的人保持友谊吗？不是，为什么不呢？一个男孩可以爱他的老师吗？是否有区别 例如拥有财富或智力程度？女人真的可以做朋友吗？兄弟姐妹能不能做朋友，或者兄弟姐妹，或者姐妹姐妹？你能与借钱或借钱的人保持友谊吗？不是，为什么不呢？一个男孩可以爱他的老师吗？是否有区别老师是男是女？如果人形机器人存在，人类会喜欢它们吗？如果我们在火星或其他星球上发现了智慧生物，我们会爱他们吗？我们可以爱一个素未谋面的人，比如电影明星或总统吗？如果我们觉得我们恨某人，那真的是爱的表达吗？

Let us suppose—in fact, we think it can be done—that you are able to identify some common meaning in these various conceptions of human love. Even then not all of your problems are solved. Consider the ways in which love manifests itself between and among human beings. Is the love that a man and woman have for each other the same when they are courting as when they are married, the same when they are in their twenties as when they are in their seventies? Is the love that a woman has for her husband the same as that she has for her children? Does a mother’s love for her children change as they grow up? Is the love of a brother for his sister the same as his love for his father? Does a child’s love for its parents change as he or she grows? Is the love that a man has for a woman, either his wife or some other, the same as the friendship he feels for another man, and does it make a difference what relationship he has with the man—such as one with whom he goes bowling, one with whom he works, and one whose intellectual company he enjoys? Does the fact that “love” and “friendship” are different words mean that the emotions they name (if that is in fact what they name) differ? Can two men of different ages be friends? Can they be friends if they are markedly different in some other respect, such as possession of wealth or degree of intelligence? Can women be friends at all? Can brothers and sisters be friends, or brother and brother, or sister and sister? Can you retain a friendship with someone you either borrow money from or lend it to? It not, why not? Can a boy love his teacher? Does it make a difference whether the teacher is male or female? If humanoid robots existed, could human beings love them? If we discovered intelligent beings on Mars or some other planet, could we love them? Can we love someone we have never met, like a movie star or the President? If we feel that we hate someone, is that really an expression of love?

这些只是你阅读标准爱情说明文学的一部分时会提出的几个问题。还有很多其他问题可以问。但是，我们认为我们已经说明了这一点。任何主题阅读项目都涉及一个奇怪的悖论。尽管这种阅读水平被定义为阅读同一主题的两本或更多书籍，这意味着对主题的识别发生在阅读开始之前，但从某种意义上说，对主题的识别必须遵循阅读，而不是在它之前。就爱情而言，你可能必须阅读十几本或一百本作品才能决定你在读什么。当你这样做时，你可能不得不得出结论，你读过的作品中有一半根本不是关于这个主题的。

These are just a few of the questions that would be raised by your reading of even a part of the standard expository literature of love. There are many other questions that could be asked. However, we think we have made the point. A curious paradox is involved in any project of syntopical reading. Although this level of reading is defined as the reading of two or more books on the same subject, which implies that the identification of the subject matter occurs before the reading begins, it is in a sense true that the identification of the subject matter must follow the reading, not precede it. In the case of love, you might have to read a dozen or a hundred works before you could decide what you were reading about. And when you had done that, you might have to conclude that half of the works you had read were not on the subject at all.

检查在主题阅读中的作用

The Role of Inspection in Syntopical Reading

 

我们不止一次说过，阅读的层次是累积的，更高的层次包括它之前或之下的所有阅读层次。现在是时候解释这在主题阅读的情况下意味着什么了。

We have stated more than once that the levels of reading are cumulative, that a higher level includes all of those that precede or lie below it. It is now time to explain what that means in the case of syntopical reading.

你会记得，在解释检视阅读和分析阅读的关系时，我们指出了检视阅读的两个步骤——一是略读；二是略读。第二，浅读——预料到分析阅读的前两步, 并概述其结构。浅阅读虽然对分析阅读的第一步也有帮助，但主要是为第二步做准备，当你被要求通过与作者达成共识、陈述他的主张并遵循他的论点来解释一本书的内容时.

You will recall that in explaining the relationship between inspectional reading and analytical reading, we pointed out that the two steps in inspectional reading—first, skimming; and second, superficial reading—anticipated the first two steps in analytical reading Skimming helps to prepare you for the first step of analytical reading, in the course of which you identify the subject matter of whatever you are reading, state what kind of book it is, and outline its structure. Superficial reading, while it is also helpful in that first step of analytical reading, is primarily a preparation for the second step, when you are called upon to interpret a book’s contents by coming to terms with the author, stating his propositions, and following his arguments.

以某种类似的方式，检查阅读和分析阅读都可以被视为主题阅读的预期或准备。事实上，正是在这里，检视阅读作为读者的主要工具或工具发挥了作用。

In a somewhat analogous fashion, both inspectional and analytical reading can be considered as anticipations or preparations for syntopical reading. It is here, in fact, that inspectional reading comes into its own as a major tool or instrument for the reader.

让我们再次假设您有一本大约有一百本书的书目，所有这些书目似乎都与爱情有关。如果你分析地阅读它们中的每一个，你最终不仅会对你正在研究的主题有一个相当清晰的想法——主题阅读项目的“同一主题”——而且你还会知道哪一个，如果有的话，您读过的书与该主题无关，因此与您的需求无关。但是阅读一百本分析性的书可能会花费你十年的时间。如果你能够全身心投入到这个项目中，它仍然需要几个月的时间。面对我们提到的关于主题阅读的悖论，一些捷径显然是必要的。

Let us suppose once more that you have a bibliography of a hundred or so titles, all of which appear to be on the subject of love. If you read every one of them analytically, you would not only end up with a fairly clear idea of the subject that you were investigating—the “same subject” of the syntopical reading project—but you would also know which, if any, of the books you had read were not on that subject and thus irrelevant to your needs. But to read a hundred books analytically might well take you ten years. If you were able to devote full time to the project, it would still take many months. Some short cut is obviously necessary, in the face of the paradox we have mentioned concerning syntopical reading.

这条捷径是由你的检视阅读技巧提供的。当你积累了你的参考书目后要做的第一件事就是检查你清单上的所有书籍。在检查所有这些之前，你不应该分析地阅读它们中的任何一个。检视阅读不会让你了解主题的所有复杂性，或者你的作者可以提供的所有见解，但它会执行两个基本功能。首先，它会让你对你的主题有一个足够清晰的认识，这样你随后对清单上的一些书籍的分析性阅读就会富有成效。其次，它将允许您将参考书目减少到更易于管理的大小。

That short cut is provided by your skill in inspectional reading. The first thing to do when you have amassed your bibliography is to inspect all of the books on your list. You should not read any of them analytically before inspecting all of them. Inspectional reading will not acquaint you with all of the intricacies of the subject matter, or with all of the insights that your authors can provide, but it will perform two essential functions. First, it will give you a clear enough idea of your subject so that your subsequent analytical reading of some of the books on the list is productive. And second, it will allow you to cut down your bibliography to a more manageable size.

我们几乎想不出还有什么建议比这对学生，尤其是研究生和研究生更有用，只要他们愿意听从。根据我们的经验，一定数量的学生处于这些高级教育水平有一定的积极阅读和分析阅读的能力。他们可能还不够多，他们可能远非完美的读者，但他们至少知道如何抓住一本书的核心，就它做出合理易懂的陈述，并将它融入一个情节或计划中他们的主题。但是他们的努力是非常浪费的，因为他们不明白如何比其他人更快地阅读一些书。他们在阅读的每一本书或文章上花费相同的时间和精力。结果，他们没有读那些真正值得好好读的书，而是把时间浪费在不值得关注的作品上。

We can hardly think of any advice that would be more useful for students, especially graduate and research students, than this, if they would only heed it. In our experience, a certain number of students at those advanced levels of schooling have some capability of reading actively and analytically. There may not be enough of them, and they may be far from perfect readers, but they at least know how to get at the meat of a book, to make reasonably intelligible statements about it, and to fit it into a plot or plan of their subject matter. But their efforts are enormously wasteful because they do not understand how to read some books faster than others. They spend the same amount of time and effort on every book or article they read. As a result, they do not read those books that deserve a really good reading as well as they deserve, and they waste time on works that deserve less attention.

善于检查的读者不只是在他的心理卡片目录中对一本书进行分类，并对其内容有肤浅的了解。他还发现，在他检查它所花的很短的时间内，这本书是否说了一些关于他的主题的重要内容。他可能还不知道那东西到底是什么——这个发现可能需要等待另一次阅读。但他已经学会了两件事之一。要么这本书是他必须返回以寻求启发的一本书，要么是一本书，无论多么有趣或内容丰富，都没有启发，因此不必再次阅读。

The skillful inspectional reader does more than classify a book in his mental card catalogue, and achieve a superficial knowledge of its contents. He also discovers, in the very short time it takes him to inspect it, whether the book says something important about his subject or not. He may not yet know what that something is precisely—that discovery will probably have to wait for another reading. But he has learned one of two things. Either the book is one to which he must return for light, or it is one that, no matter how enjoyable or informative, contains no enlightenment and therefore does not have to be read again.

这个建议经常被忽视是有原因的。在分析阅读的情况下，我们说过熟练的读者会同时执行初学者必须视为分开的步骤。以此类推，这种主题阅读的准备——在开始分析阅读之前检查清单上的所有书籍——似乎可以与分析阅读同时进行。但我们不相信任何读者都能做到这一点，无论多么熟练。这确实是许多年轻研究人员所犯的错误。认为他们可以将这两个步骤合并为一个，他们最终以相同的速度阅读所有内容，这对于特定的作品来说可能太快或太慢，但无论如何对于他们阅读的大多数书籍来说都是错误的。

There is a reason why this advice is often unheeded. In the case of analytical reading, we said that the skillful reader performs concurrently steps that the beginner must treat as separate. By analogy, it might seem that this kind of prepararation for syntopical reading—the inspection of all of the books on your list before starting the analytical reading of any of them—could be done concurrently with analytical reading. But we do not believe that can be done by any reader, no matter how skillful. And this indeed is the mistake that so many younger researchers make. Thinking they can collapse these two steps into one, they end up reading everything at the same rate, which may be either too fast or too slow for a particular work, but in any event is wrong for most of the books they read.

一旦你通过检查确定了这些书是与您的主题相关，然后您可以继续按主题阅读它们。请注意，在最后一句话中，我们并没有像您预期的那样说“继续分析地阅读它们”。当然，从某种意义上说，你确实必须阅读每部单独的作品，这些作品共同构成了你所在学科的文学作品，并使用你通过应用分析阅读规则获得的那些技能。但千万不要忘记，分析阅读的艺术适用于阅读一本书，而理解那本书是我们的目标。正如我们将要看到的，主题阅读的目的是完全不同的。

Once you have identified, by inspection, the books that are relevant to your subject matter, you can then proceed to read them syntopically. Note that in the last sentence we did not say “proceed to read them analytically,” as you might have expected. In a sense, of course, you do have to read each of the individual works that, together, constitute the literature of your subject, with those skills that you acquired by applying the rules of analytical reading. But it must never be forgotten that the art of analytical reading applies to the reading of a single book, when understanding of that book is the aim in view. As we will see, the aim in syntopical reading is quite different.

主题阅读的五个步骤

The Five Steps in Syntopical Reading

 

我们现在准备解释如何按主题阅读。我们假设，通过阅读大量书籍，您对至少其中一些书籍所涉及的主题有一个很好的了解，而且这就是您想要研究的主题。那么，你做什么？

We are now prepared to explain how to read syntopically. We will assume that, by your inspection of a number of books, you have a pretty good idea of the subject that at least some of them are about, and furthermore that this is the subject you want to investigate. What, then, do you do?

主题阅读有五个步骤。我们不会称它们为规则，尽管我们可以称它们为规则，因为如果不采取任何步骤，主题阅读就会变得更加困难，甚至不可能。我们将粗略地按照它们发生的顺序来讨论它们，尽管从某种意义上说，它们必须全部发生才能使它们中的任何一个发生。

There are five steps in syntopical reading. We shall not call them rules, although we might, for if any of the steps is not taken, syntopical reading becomes much more difficult, perhaps impossible. We will discuss them roughly in the order in which they occur, although in a sense all of them have to take place for any of them to.

主题阅读的第1步：找到相关的段落。 _ _ _ 由于我们当然假设您知道如何进行分析阅读，因此我们假设如果您愿意，您可以通读每本相关书籍。但那将是按照你的优先顺序将单本书放在第一位，然后才是你的问题。事实上，顺序是相反的。在主题式阅读中，主要服务的是您和您所关心的问题，而不是您阅读的书籍。

STEP 1 IN SYNTOPICAL READING: FINDING THE RELEVANT PASSAGES. Since we are of course assuming that you know how to read analytically, we are assuming that you could read each of the relevant books thoroughly if you wanted to. But that would be to place the individual books first in the order of your priorities, and your problem second. In fact, the order is reversed. In syntopical reading, it is you and your concerns that are primarily to be served, not the books that you read.

因此，这个阅读水平的第一步是另一个检查您确定为相关的全部作品。您的目标是在书中找到与您的需求最相关的段落。任何一本书的全部内容都不太可能直接针对您选择的主题或困扰您的主题。即使是这样（这种情况很少见），您也应该快速阅读本书。你不想忘记这样一个事实：你正在阅读它是为了一个别有用心的目的——也就是说，为了它可能会揭示你自己的问题——而不是为了它本身。

Hence the first step at this level of reading is another inspection of the whole works that you have identified as relevant. Your aim is to find the passages in the books that are most germane to your needs. It is unlikely that the whole of any of the books is directly on the subject you have chosen or that is troubling you. Even if this is so, as it very rarely is, you should read the book quickly. You do not want to lose sight of the fact that you are reading it for an ulterior purpose-namely, for the light it may throw on your own problem—not for its own sake.

这一步似乎可以与前面描述的书籍检查同时进行，其目的是发现这本书是否与您的关注点完全相关。在许多情况下，情况确实如此。但认为这总是可能的是不明智的。请记住，您第一次阅读本书的目的之一是将主题阅读项目的主题归零。我们已经说过，除非您检查了原始清单上的许多书，否则并不总是可以对问题有充分的了解。因此，在识别相关书籍的同时尝试识别相关段落往往是危险的。除非你非常熟练，或者已经非常熟悉你的主题，否则你最好将这两个步骤分开。

It might seem that this step could be taken concurrently with the previously described inspection of the book, the purpose of which was to discover whether the book was at all relevant to your concerns. In many cases, that is so. But it is unwise to consider that this is always possible. Remember that one of the aims of your first inspection of the book was to zero in on the subejct matter of your syntopical reading project. We have said that an adequate understanding of the problem is not always available until you have inspected many of the books on your original list. Therefore, to try to identify the relevant passages at the same time that you identify the relevant books is often perilous. Unless you are very skillful, or already quite familiar with your subject, you had better treat the two steps as separate.

这里重要的是要认识到你在主题阅读过程中阅读的第一本书与你在阅读许多关于该主题的其他书籍之后阅读的书籍之间的区别。对于后面的书，您可能已经对问题有了相当清晰的认识，在这种情况下，这两个步骤可以合并。但在开始时，它们应该严格分开。否则，您可能会在识别相关段落时犯严重错误，这些错误将在以后不得不更正，从而浪费时间和精力。

What is important here is to recognize the difference between the first books that you read in the course of syntopical reading, and those that you come to after you have read many others on the subject. In the case of the later books, you probably already have a fairly clear idea of your problem, and in that case the two steps can coalesce. But at the beginning, they should be kept rigorously separated. Otherwise, you are likely to make serious mistakes in identifying the relevant passages, mistakes that will have to be corrected later with a consequent waste of time and effort.

最重要的是，请记住，你的任务与其说是对你面前的特定书籍有一个整体的理解，不如说是找出它如何对你有帮助。 这可能与作者自己写作的目的相去甚远。在诉讼的现阶段，这无关紧要。作者可以帮你无意中解决自己的问题。正如我们所指出的，在主题阅读中，所读的书是为你服务的，而不是相反。从这个意义上说，主题阅读是你能做的最积极的阅读。当然，分析阅读也很活跃。但是当你分析地阅读一本书时，你就把自己置于门徒与大师之间的关系中。当你按主题阅读时，你必须是情境的主人。

Above all, remember that your task is not so much to achieve an overall understanding of the particular book before you as to find out how it can be useful to you in a connection that may be very far from the author’s own purpose in writing it. That does not matter at this stage of the proceedings. The author can help you to solve your own problem without having intended to. In syntopical reading, as we have noted, the books that are read serve you, not the other way around. In this sense, syntopical reading is the most active reading you can do. Analytical reading is also active, of course. But when you read a book analytically, you put yourself in a relation to it of disciple to master. When you read syntopically, you must be the master of the situation.

正因为如此，你必须以一种与以前有所不同的方式与你的作者达成和解。

Because this is so, you must go about the business of coming to terms with your authors in a somewhat different way than before.

主题阅读中的第2步：让作者遵守条款。 _ _ 在解释性阅读（分析性阅读的第二阶段）中，第一条规则要求你与作者达成共识，这意味着识别他的关键词并发现他如何使用它们。但是现在你面对的是许多不同的作者，他们不太可能都使用相同的词，甚至是相同的术语。因此，必须由您来建立条款，并将您的作者带到他们那里，而不是相反。

STEP 2 IN SYNTOPICAL READING: BRINGING THE AUTHORS TO TERMS. In interpretive reading (the second stage of analytical reading) the first rule requires you to come to terms with the author, which means identifying his key words and discovering how he uses them. But now you are faced with a number of different authors, and it is unlikely that they will have all used the same words, or even the same terms. Thus it is you who must establish the terms, and bring your authors to them rather than the other way around.

这可能是主题阅读中最困难的一步。真正归结为迫使作者使用您的语言，而不是使用他的语言。我们所有的正常阅读习惯都与此相反。正如我们多次指出的那样，我们假设我们想要分析阅读的一本书的作者是我们更好的，如果这本书是一本好书，尤其如此。我们倾向于接受作者的术语和他对主题的组织，无论我们多么积极地试图理解他。然而，在主题阅读中，如果我们接受任何一位作者的术语，我们很快就会迷失方向。我们可以理解他的书，但我们将无法理解其他书，而且我们会发现对我们感兴趣的主题没有太多启发。

This is probably the most difficult step in syntopical reading. What it really comes down to is forcing an author to use your language, rather than using his. All of our normal reading habits are opposed to this. As we have pointed out several times, we assume that the author of a book we want to read analytically is our better, and this is particularly true if the book is a great one. Our tendency is to accept the author’s terms and his organization of the subject matter, no matter how active we may be in trying to understand him. In syntopical reading, however, we will very quickly be lost if we accept any one author’s terminology. We may understand his book, but we will fail to understand the others, and we will find that not much light is shed on the subject in which we are interested.

我们不仅要坚决拒绝接受任何一位作者的术语；我们还必须愿意面对这样一种可能性，即没有作者的术语对我们有用。换句话说，我们必须接受这样一个事实，即我们与名单上的任何作者之间的术语重合纯属偶然。确实，这种巧合常常会带来不便；因为如果我们使用一个作者的一个术语或一组术语，我们可能会想使用他的术语中的其他术语，而这些可能会妨碍而不是帮助。

Not only must we resolutely refuse to accept the terminology of any one author; we must also be willing to face the possibility that no author’s terminology will be useful to us. In other words, we must accept the fact that coincidence of terminology between us and any of the authors on our list is merely accidental. Often, indeed, such coincidence will be inconvenient; for if we use one term or set of terms of an author, we may be tempted to use others among his terms, and these may get in the way rather than help.

简而言之，主题阅读在很大程度上是一种翻译练习。我们不必从一种自然语言翻译成另一种自然语言，就像从法语翻译成英语那样。但是我们确实对一些作者强加了一个共同的术语，无论他们可能使用共同的自然语言，他们可能并没有特别关注我们试图解决的问题，因此可能没有创造出理想的术语来处理用它。

Syntopical reading, in short, is to a large extent an exercise in translation. We do not have to translate from one natural language to another, as from French to English. But we do impose a common terminology on a number of authors who, whatever natural language they may have shared in common, may not have been specifically concerned with the problem we are trying to solve, and therefore may not have created the ideal terminology for dealing with it.

这意味着当我们继续我们的主题阅读项目时，我们必须开始建立一组术语，首先，帮助我们理解我们所有的作者，而不仅仅是他们中的一个或几个，其次，帮助我们解决我们的问题。这种洞察力导致了第三步。

This means that as we proceed on our project of syntopical reading we must begin to build up a set of terms that first, helps us to understand all of our authors, not just one or a few of them, and second, helps us to solve our problem. That insight leads to the third step.

主题阅读的第3步：把问题弄清楚。 _ _ _ _ 解释性阅读的第二条规则要求我们找到作者的关键句子，并从中发展对他的命题的理解。命题是由术语组成的，当然我们必须对我们正在阅读的作品做类似的工作。但由于我们自己正在建立这种情况下的术语，我们也面临着建立一套中性命题的任务。做到这一点的最好方法是提出一系列问题，这些问题可以阐明我们的问题，并且我们的每位作者都给出了答案。

STEP 3 IN SYNTOPICAL READING: GETTING THE QUESTIONS CLEAR. The second rule of interpretive reading requires us to find the author’s key sentences, and from them to develop an understanding of his propositions. Propositions are made up of terms, and of course we must do a similar job on the works we are reading syntopically. But since we ourselves are establishing the terminology in this case, we are faced with the task of establishing a set of neutral propositions as well. The best way to do this is to frame a set of questions that shed light on our problem, and to which each of our authors gives answers.

这也很难。问题的陈述方式和顺序必须能够帮助我们解决开始时遇到的问题，但它们的构建方式也必须使我们所有或大多数作者都可以被解释为给出对他们的回答。困难在于我们想要回答的问题可能没有被作者视为问题。他们对这个问题的看法可能与我们的完全不同。

This, too, is difficult. The questions must be stated in such a way and in such an order that they help us to solve the problem we started with, but they also must be framed in such a way that all or most of our authors can be interpreted as giving answers to them. The difficulty is that the questions we want answered may not have been seen as questions by the authors. Their view of the subject may have been quite different from ours.

事实上，有时我们不得不接受这样一个事实，即作者没有回答我们的一个或多个问题。在那种情况下，我们必须记录他在这个问题上保持沉默或犹豫不决。但即使他没有明确讨论这个问题，我们有时也能在他的书中找到隐含的答案。如果他考虑过这个问题，我们可以得出结论，他会以这样那样的方式回答。这里需要克制；我们无法将想法放入作者的脑海中，也无法将文字放入他们的口中。但我们也不能完全依赖他们对问题的明确陈述。如果我们能以这种方式依赖其中任何一个，我们可能就没有问题需要解决了。

Sometimes, indeed, we have to accept the fact that an author gives no answer to one or more of our questions. In that case, we must record him as silent or indeterminate on the question. But even if he does not discuss the question explicitly, we can sometimes find an implicit answer in his book. If he had considered the question, we may conclude, he would then have answered it in such and such a way. Restraint is necessary here; we cannot put thoughts into our authors’ minds, or words into their mouths. But we also cannot depend entirely on their explicit statements about the problem. If we could depend on any one of them in that way, we probably would have no problem to solve.

我们说过，提问的顺序一定要有利于我们的调查。当然，顺序取决于主题，但可以建议一些一般性方向。第一个问题通常与我们正在研究的现象或想法的存在或特征有关。如果一位作者说这种现象存在，或者说这个想法具有某种性质，那么我们可能会对他的书提出进一步的问题。这些可能与现象如何为人所知或想法如何表现出来有关。最后一组问题可能与前面问题的答案的后果有关。

We have said that the questions must be put in an order that is helpful to us in our investigation. The order depends on the subject, of course, but some general directions can be suggested. The first questions usually have to do with the existence or character of the phenomenon or idea we are investigating. If an author says that the phenomenon exists or that the idea has a certain character, then we may ask further questions of his book. These may have to do with how the phenomenon is known or how the idea manifests itself. A final set of questions might have to do with the consequences of the answers to the previous questions.

我们不应该期望我们所有的作者都会以同样的方式回答我们的问题。如果他们这样做了，我们将再次没有问题需要解决；它本来可以通过协商一致解决的。由于作者会有所不同，我们面临着必须采取主题阅读的下一步。

We should not expect that all of our authors will answer our questions in the same way. If they did, we would once again have no problem to solve; it would have been solved by consensus. Since the authors will differ, we are faced with having to take the next step in syntopical reading.

主题阅读中的第4步：定义问题。 _ _ 如果一个问题很明确，并且如果我们可以合理地确定作者以不同的方式回答它——可能是赞成的，也可能是反对的——那么一个问题已经被定义。这是以一种方式回答问题的作者与以一种或另一种相反方式回答问题的作者之间的问题。

STEP 4 IN SYNTOPICAL READING: DEFINING THE ISSUES. If a question is clear, and if we can be reasonably certain that authors answer it in different ways—perhaps pro and con—then an issue has been defined. It is the issue between the authors who answer the question in one way, and those who answer it in one or another opposing way.

当所有被审查的作者只给出两个答案时，这个问题是一个相对简单的问题，通常，一个问题会给出两个以上的备选答案。在那种情况下，相反的答案必须相互排序，采用它们的作者根据他们的观点进行分类。

When only two answers are given by all of the authors examined, the issue is a relatively simple one, Often, more than two alternative answers are given to a question. In that case, the opposing answers must be ordered in relation to one another, and the authors who adopt them classified according to their views.

当两位以相同方式理解问题的作者以相反或矛盾的方式回答问题时，问题才真正结合起来。但这并不像人们希望的那样经常发生。通常，答案的差异必须归因于对问题的不同概念，就像对主题的不同观点一样。主题阅读器的任务是以确保它们尽可能紧密地结合在一起的方式来定义问题。有时，这迫使他以任何作者都没有明确采用的方式来构建问题。

An issue is truly joined when two authors who understand a question in the same way answer it in contrary or contradictory ways. But this does not happen as often as one might wish. Usually, differences in answers must be ascribed to different conceptions of the question as often as to different views of the subject. The task of the syntopical reader is to define the issues in such a way as to insure that they are joined as well as may be. Sometimes this forces him to frame the question in a way that is not explicitly employed by any author.

讨论我们正在处理的问题可能会涉及很多问题，但很可能会分门别类。例如，关于正在考虑的想法的特征的问题可能会产生许多相互关联的问题。围绕一组密切相关的问题展开的许多问题可以称为关于该主题的那个方面的争议。这样的争论可能非常复杂，主题读者的任务是将其整理并以有序和清晰的方式排列，即使没有作者设法做到这一点。这种对争议以及构成问题的分类和安排，将我们带到主题阅读的最后一步。

There may be many issues involved in the discussion of the problem we are dealing with, but it is likely that they will fall into groups. Questions about the character of the idea under consideration, for example, may generate a number of issues that are connected. A number of issues revolving around a closely connected set of questions may be termed the controversy about that aspect of the subject. Such a controversy may be very complicated, and it is the task of the syntopical reader to sort it out and arrange it in an orderly and perspicuous fashion, even if no author has managed to do that. This sorting and arranging of the controversies, as well as of the constituent issues, brings us to the final step in syntopical reading.

主题阅读中的第5步：分析讨论。_ _ 到目前为止，我们已经在所检查的作品中找到了相关段落，创建了一个中性术语，适用于所有或大多数作者所检查的、框架和排序的一组问题，其中大多数可以解释为回答，并对问题的不同答案所产生的问题进行界定和安排。那么还有什么要做呢？

STEP 5 IN SYNTOPICAL READING: ANALYZING THE DISCUSSION. SO far we have found the relevant passages in the works examined, created a neutral terminology that applies to all or most of the authors examined, framed and ordered a set of questions that most of them can be interpreted as answering, and defined and arranged the issues produced by differing answers to the questions. What then remains to be done?

前四个步骤对应于分析阅读的前两组规则。当遵循这些规则并将其应用于任何一本书时，我们就可以回答以下问题：它说了什么？它是怎么说的？在我们的主题阅读项目中，我们在这一点上同样能够回答关于我们问题的讨论的相同问题。在对一部作品进行分析阅读的情况下，还有两个问题有待回答，即，这是真的吗？那是什么？在主题阅读的情况下，我们现在准备解决与讨论相关的类似问题。

The first four steps correspond to the first two groups of rules for analytical reading. Those rules, when followed and applied to any book, allowed us to answer the questions, What does it say? and How does it say it? In our syntopical reading project, we are similarly able at this point to answer the same questions about the discussion concerning our problem. In the case of the analytical reading of a single work, two further questions remained to be answered, namely, Is it true? and What of it? In the case of syntopical reading, we are now prepared to address ourselves to similar questions about the discussion.

让我们假设我们开始的问题不是一个简单的问题，而是思想家们为之奋斗了几个世纪的那些长期存在的问题之一，而且好人已经不同意并且可以继续不同意。基于这一假设，我们应该认识到，作为专题读者，我们的任务不仅仅是自己回答问题——我们精心设计和整理的问题既是为了阐明对主题的讨论，也是为了阐明主题本身。这类问题的真相并不那么容易被发现。事实上，我们可能会冒昧地期望可以在任何一组问题答案中找到真相。相反，如果有的话，它会在对立答案的冲突中被发现，许多（如果不是全部的话）可能有有说服力的证据和令人信服的理由来支持它们。

Let us assume that the problem with which we began was not a simple one, but was rather one of those perennial problems with which thinkers have struggled for centuries, and about which good men have disagreed and can continue to disagree. We should recognize, on this assumption, that our task as syntopical readers is not merely to answer the questions ourselves—the questions that we have so carefully framed and ordered both to elucidate the discussion of the subject and the subject itself. The truth about a problem of this sort is not found so easily. In fact, we would probably be presumptuous to expect that the truth could be found in any one set of answers to the questions. Rather, it is to be found, if at all, in the conflict of opposing answers, many if not all of which may have persuasive evidence and convincing reasons to support them.

那么，就可以找到的真理而言——解决问题的方法，只要我们可以获得——宁可存在于有序的讨论本身，而不是存在于关于它的任何命题或断言的集合中。因此，为了将这个真理呈现在我们的头脑中——以及其他人的头脑中——我们必须做的不仅仅是提出和回答问题。我们必须按照一定的顺序询问他们，并且能够捍卫该顺序；我们必须展示如何以不同的方式回答问题，并且试着说出为什么；我们必须能够指出所检查的书中支持我们的答案分类的文本。只有当我们完成所有这些后，我们才能声称已经分析了对我们问题的讨论。只有这样我们才能声称已经理解了它。

The truth, then, insofar as it can be found—the solution to the problem, insofar as that is available to us—consists rather in the ordered discussion itself than in any set of propositions or assertions about it. Thus, in order to present this truth to our minds—and to the minds of others—we have to do more than merely ask and answer the questions. We have to ask them in a certain order, and be able to defend that order; we must show how the questions are answered differently and try to say why; and we must be able to point to the texts in the books examined that support our classification of answers. Only when we have done all of this can we claim to have analyzed the discussion of our problem. And only then can we claim to have understood it.

事实上，我们可能做得更多。对问题讨论的透彻分析可以为其他人对问题的进一步富有成效的工作提供基础。它可以清除枯枝落叶，为有独创性的思想家取得突破铺平道路。如果没有分析工作，这可能是不可能的，因为问题的范围可能不可见。

We may, indeed, have done more than that. A thorough analysis of the discussion of a problem may provide the groundwork for further productive work on the problem by others. It can clear away the deadwood and prepare the way for an original thinker to make a breakthrough. Without the work of analysis, that might not have been possible, for the dimensions of the problem might not have been visible.

客观性的需要

The Need for Objectivity

 

对问题或主题的讨论进行充分分析，确定并报告该讨论中的主要问题或基本的知识反对意见。这并不意味着分歧始终是每次讨论的主要特征。相反，在大多数情况下，同意伴随着分歧；也就是说，在大多数问题上，争论的对立面的意见或观点由几位作者共享，通常是许多作者共享。我们很少能找到一个有争议的立场的孤立指数。

An adequate analysis of the discussion of a problem or subject matter identifies and reports the major issues, or basic intellectual oppositions, in that discussion. This does not imply that disagreement is always the dominant feature of every discussion. On the contrary, agreement in most cases accompanies disagreement; that is, on most issues, the opinions or views that present opposite sides of the dispute are shared by several authors, often by many. Seldom do we find a solitary exponent of a controversial position.

人类在任何研究领域中对事物本质的认同，都建立了对他们共同持有的观点的真实性的某种推定。但他们的分歧建立了反推定——冲突中的任何观点，无论是否同意，都可能是完全正确的。在相互矛盾的意见中，一个当然可能是完全正确的，而其余的都是错误的；但也有可能每个人都表达了全部真相的一部分；并且，除了平坦和孤立的矛盾（这在我们在这里处理的这类问题的任何讨论中都是罕见的），甚至所有相互矛盾的观点都可能是错误的， 正如所有人似乎都同意的观点可能是错误的一样。一些尚未表达的意见可能是事实或更接近事实。

The agreement of human beings about the nature of things in any field of inquiry establishes some presumption of the truth of the opinions they commonly hold. But their disagreement establishes the counter-presumption—that none of the opinions in conflict, whether shared or not, may be wholly true. Among conflicting opinions, one may, of course, be wholly true and all the rest false; but it is also possible that each expresses some portion of the whole truth; and, except for flat and isolated contradictions (which are rare in any discussion of the kind of problems we are dealing with here), it is even possible that all the conflicting opinions may be false, just as it is possible for that opinion to be false on which all seem to agree. Some opinion as yet unexpressed may be the truth or nearer to it.

这是另一种说法，主题阅读项目的目的不是对过程中提出的问题的最终答案，也不是项目开始时问题的最终解决方案。对于我们可能尝试对此类主题阅读进行的报告尤其如此。如果在它确定和分析的任何重要问题上断言或试图证明任何观点的正确性或错误性，那将是教条式的，而不是辩证的。如果那样做，主题分析将不再是主题分析；它只会成为讨论中的另一种声音，从而失去其超然和客观的特征。

This is another way of saying that the aim of a project of syntopical reading is not final answers to the questions that are developed in the course of it, or the final solution of the problem with which the project began. This is particularly true of the report we might try to make of such syntopical reading. It would be dogmatic, not dialectical, if, on any of the important issues that it identified and analyzed, it asserted or tried to prove the truth or falsity of any view. If it did that, the syntopical analysis would cease to be syntopical; it would become simply one more voice in the discussion, thereby losing its detached and objective character.

关键不在于再多一个声音在人类讨论重要问题的论坛上没有任何分量。关键是可以而且应该为追求理解做出不同类型的贡献。这种贡献在于始终保持客观和超然。主题分析试图达到的特殊品质确实可以用“辩证客观性”这两个词来概括。

The point is not that one more voice carries no weight in the forum of human discussion on important issues. The point is that a different type of contribution to the pursuit of understanding can and should be made. And this contribution consists in being resolutely objective and detached throughout. The special quality that a syntopical analysis tries to achieve can, indeed, be summarized in the two words “dialectical objectivity.”

简而言之，主题式读者试图从各个方面进行观察，不偏袒任何一方。当然，他会在这个苛刻的理想中失败。绝对客观性是人类不可能的。他可能会成功地不偏袒任何一方，在不影响任何党派观点的情况下提出问题，并公正地对待反对意见。但是，不偏袒任何一方总比通盘看容易。在后者这方面，主题阅读器无疑会失败。无法详尽列举问题的所有可能方面。尽管如此，他还是得试一试。

The syntopical reader, in short, tries to look at all sides and to take no sides. Of course, he will fail in this exacting ideal. Absolute objectivity is not humanly possible. He may succeed in taking no sides, presenting the issues without prejudice to any partisan point of view, and treating opposing views impartially. But it is easier to take no sides than to look at all sides. In this latter respect, the syntopical reader will undoubtedly fail. All possible sides of an issue cannot be exhaustively enumerated. Nevertheless, he must try.

我们说，不偏袒任何一方比放眼四方容易，但即便如此也仍然困难重重。主题读者必须抵制某些诱惑并了解自己的想法。避免对相互矛盾的观点的真实性作出明确判断，并不能保证完美的辩证客观性。偏袒可以以各种微妙的方式侵入——通过通过强调和忽略的深浅、问题的语气或旁白的颜色，以及对关键问题的各种不同答案的呈现顺序，对论点进行了总结。

Taking no sides is easier than looking at all sides, we say, but it remains difficult even so. The syntopical reader must resist certain temptations and know his own mind. Perfect dialectical objectivity is not guaranteed by avoiding explicit judgments on the truth of conflicting opinions. Partiality can intrude in a variety of subtle ways—by the manner in which arguments are summarized, by shades of emphasis and neglect, by the tone of a question or the color of a passing remark, and by the order in which the various different answers to key questions are presented.

为了避免其中一些危险，认真的主题读者可能会求助于一种显而易见的方法并尽可能多地使用它。也就是说，他必须不断地回顾作者的实际文本，反复阅读相关段落；并且，在向更广泛的观众展示他的工作成果时，他必须用作者自己的语言引用作者的观点或论点。尽管看起来是这样，但这并不与我们之前所说的有必要找到一个中性术语来分析问题的说法相矛盾。这种必要性仍然存在，并且当呈现作者论点的摘要时，它们必须以该语言而不是作者的语言呈现。但作者自己的话，谨慎引用，以免断章取义，必须附在摘要中，以便读者自己判断作者的解释是否正确。

In order to avoid some of these dangers, the conscientious syntopical reader may resort to one obvious device and use it as much as possible. That is, he must constantly refer back to the actual text of his authors, reading the relevant passages over and over; and, in presenting the results of his work to a wider audience, he must quote the opinion or argument of an author in the writer’s own language. Although it may appear to do so, this does not contradict what we said earlier about the necessity of finding a neutral terminology in which to analyze the problem. That necessity remains, and when summaries of an author’s argument are presented, they must be presented in that language and not the author’s. But the author’s own words, carefully quoted so as not to wrench them out of context, must accompany the summary, so that the reader can judge for himself whether the interpretation of the author is correct.

只有主题读者坚决避免它们的意图才能防止其他类型的偏离辩证客观性。这种理想要求刻意努力平衡问题与问题，放弃任何可能有偏见的评论，检查任何过分强调或过分强调的倾向。归根结底，虽然读者可以判断一篇辩证阐述的书面报告的有效性，但只有它的作者——只有主题读者本人——才能知道他是否满足了这些要求。

Only the syntopical reader’s firm intention to avoid them can be relied on to prevent other sorts of departure from dialectical objectivity. That ideal demands a deliberate effort to balance question against question, to forgo any comment that might be prejudicial, to check any tendency toward overemphasis or underemphasis. In the last analysis, although a reader may be the judge of the effectiveness of a written report of a dialectical exposition, only the writer of it—only the syntopical reader himself—can know whether he has satisfied these requirements.

主题阅读练习的一个例子：进步的想法

An Example of an Exercise in Syntopical Reading: The Idea of Progress

 

一个例子可能有助于解释主题阅读的工作原理。让我们考虑一下进步的概念。我们不随机选择这个主题。我们对此进行了广泛的研究。*如果不是这样的话，这个例子就不会对你有用。

An example may be helpful to explain how syntopical reading works. Let us consider the idea of progress. We do not take this subject at random. We have done extensive research on it.* The example would not be so useful to you if that were not so.

对这一重要的历史和哲学思想的研究耗时数年。第一项任务是制作一份要检查相关段落的作品清单——收集一份参考书目（最终超过 450 项）。这项任务是通过一系列阅读数倍于书籍、文章和其他作品的检查性阅读来完成的。重要的是要指出，就进步的想法而言，正如大多数其他重要想法的情况一样，许多最终被判断为相关的项目或多或少是偶然发现的，或者至少是偶然发现的有根据的猜测的帮助。有明显的起点；最近的许多书的标题中都包含“进步”一词。但其他人没有，而且大多数较旧的书籍虽然与该主题相关，但甚至没有使用该术语。

The investigation of this important historical and philosophical idea occupied several years. The first task was to produce a list of works to be examined for relevant passages—to amass a bibliography (it finally ran to more than 450 items). This task was accomplished by a series of inspectional readings of several times that many books, articles, and other pieces. It is important to point out that in the case of the idea of progress, as would be true in the case of most other important ideas, many of the items finally judged to be relevant were found more or less by accident, or at least with the help of educated guesses. There were obvious places to start; many recent books contain the word “progress” in their titles. But others do not, and most of the older books, although relevant to the subject, do not even employ the term.

阅读了一些虚构和诗歌作品，但总体上决定专注于说明性作品。我们已经注意到，将小说、戏剧和诗歌纳入主题阅读项目是很困难的，这有几个原因。首先，一个故事的主干或本质是它的情节，而不是它在问题上的立场。其次，即使是最健谈的角色也很少在某个问题上明确表态——他们往往会在故事中谈论其他事情，主要是情感关系。第三，即使一个角色确实发表了这样的演讲——例如，塞特姆布里尼在托马斯·曼的魔法山中谈到了进步——我们也永远不能确定这是作者的正在表示的视图。作者让他的角色继续谈论这个话题是否具有讽刺意味？他是想让你看到这个职位的愚蠢，而不是它的智慧？一般来说，在将一部虚构作品置于一个问题的某一方面之前，需要进行大量的综合解释。付出的努力如此巨大，而结果本质上如此可疑，通常谨慎的做法是弃权。

A few fictional and poetical works were read, but on the whole it was decided to concentrate on expository works. We have already observed that including novels, plays, and poems in a syntopical reading project is difficult, and this is so for several reasons. First of all, the backbone or essence of a story is its plot, not its positions on issues. Second, even the most talkative characters seldom take clear positions on an issue—they tend to talk, in the story, about other matters, mainly emotional relations. Third, even if a character does make such a speech—as, for example, Settembrini does about progress in Thomas Mann’s Magic Mountain—we can never be sure that it is the author’s view that is being represented. Is the author being ironic in allowing his character to go on about the subject? Is he intending you to see the foolishness of the position, rather than its wisdom? Generally speaking, an intensive effort of synthetic interpretation is required before a fictional work can be placed on one side or another of an issue. The effort is so great, and the results essentially so dubious, that usually it is prudent to abstain.

与通常情况一样，对许多有待审查的作品的进展的讨论显然是混乱的。面对这一事实，正如我们所指出的，任务是开发一个中性术语。这是一项复杂的工作，但一个例子可能有助于解释所做的事情。

The discussion of progress in the many works that remained to be examined was, as is usually the case, apparently chaotic. Faced with this fact, the task was, as we have indicated, to develop a neutral terminology. This was a complex undertaking, but one example may help to explain what was done.

“进步”这个词本身被作者以多种不同的方式使用。大多数这些不同的方式反映的只是意义的深浅，并且可以在分析中处理。但是这个词被一些作者用来表示历史上的某种进步，而不是进步。由于大多数作者使用该词来表示人类状况的历史性变化，即变得更好，并且由于改善是该概念的本质，因此不能将同一个词应用于两种观点。在这种情况下，大多数人占了上风，少数派不得不被称为历史上主张“非改良性进步”的作者。关键是在讨论少数派的观点时，我们不能使用“进步”这个词，即使相关作者自己也使用过它。

The word “progress” itself is used by authors in a number of different ways. Most of these different ways reflect no more than shades of meaning, and they can be handled in the analysis. But the word is used by some authors to denote a certain kind of movement forward in history that is not an improvement. Since most of the authors use the word to denote a historical change in the human condition that is for the better, and since betterment is of the essence of the conception, the same word could not be applied to both views. In this case, the majority gained the day, and the minority faction had to be referred to as authors who assert “non-meliorative advance” in history. The point is that when discussing the views of the minority faction, we could not employ the word “progress,” even though the authors involved had used it themselves.
