如前所述，主题阅读的第三步是弄清楚问题。我们对进步情况下的主要问题的直觉经过检查证明是正确的。要问的第一个问题，作者可以解释为给出各种答案的问题是，历史上是否有进步？历史变革的总进程是朝着改善人类状况的方向发展，这是事实吗？基本上，在该主题的文献中对这个问题提出了三种不同的答案：（1）是，（2）否，以及（3）我们不知道。然而，有许多不同的方式说“是”，有几种不同的方式说不，以及至少三种不同的说法，我们无法知道人类进步是否发生。

The third step in syntopical reading is, as we have noted, getting the questions clear. Our intuition about the primary question in the case of progress turned out to be correct upon examination. The first question to ask, the question to which authors can be interpreted as giving various answers, is, Does progress occur in history? Is it a fact that the general course of historical change is in the direction of improvement in man’s condition? Basically, there are three different answers to this question put forth in the literature of the subject: (1) Yes, (2) No, and (3) We cannot know. However, there are a number of different ways of saying Yes, several different ways of saying No, and at least three different ways of saying that we cannot know whether human progress occurs or not.

对这个主要问题的五花八门和相互关联的答案构成了我们决定称之为关于进步的一般争论。从某种意义上说，这是普遍的，我们研究过的每一位对这个主题有重要意义的作者都会在其中可以识别的各种问题上采取立场。但也有一个关于进步的特殊争议，它由只有进步作者加入的问题组成——那些断言进步发生的作者。这些问题与进步的性质或属性有关，他们都是进步的作者，断言是历史事实。这里只有三个问题，尽管对每个问题的讨论都很复杂。它们可以表述为问题：(1) 进步是必要的，还是取决于其他事件？(2) 进步会无限期地持续下去，还是最终会结束或“停滞不前”？(3) 人性以及人类制度是否有进步——在人类动物本身，还是仅仅在人类生活的外在条件方面？

The multifarious and interrelated answers to this primary question constitute what we decided to call the general controversy about progress. It is general in the sense that every author we studied who has anything significant to say about the subject takes sides on the various issues that can be identified within it. But there is also a special controversy about progress, which is made up of issues that are joined only by progress authors—authors who assert that progress occurs. These issues have to do with the nature or properties of the progress that they all, being progress authors, assert is a fact of history. There are only three issues here, although the discussion of each of them is complex. They can be stated as questions: (1) Is progress necessary, or is it contingent on other occurences? (2) Will progress continue indefinitely, or will it eventually come to an end or “plateau out”? (3) Is there progress in human nature as well as in human institutions —in the human animal itself, or merely in the external conditions of human life?

最后，还有一组从属问题，正如我们所说，同样只在进步作者之间，关于进步发生的方面。我们确定了一些作者所说的六个领域发生了进展，尽管其他作者否认在其中一个或多个领域发生了进展——尽管从未在所有领域发生过（因为根据定义，他们是断言发生某种进展的作者） . 六个是：（一）知识进步，（二）技术进步，（三）经济进步，（四）政治进步，（五）道德进步，（六）艺术进步。最后一点的讨论提出了特殊的问题，因为在我们看来，没有作者真正断言这种审美进步发生了，尽管许多作者否认在这方面取得了进展。

Finally, there is a set of subordinate issues, as we called them, again only among progress authors, about the respects in which progress occurs. We identified six areas in which progress is said by some authors to occur, although other writers deny its occurrence in one or more of these areas—although never in all (since they are by definition authors who assert the occurrence of some kind of progress). The six are: (1) progress in knowledge, (2) technological progress, (3) economic progress, (4) political progress, (5) moral progress, and (6) progress in the fine arts. The discussion of the last point raises special problems, since in our opinion no author genuinely asserts that such aesthetic progress occurs, although a number of writers deny that progress occurs in this respect.

刚刚描述的进展分析的结构举例说明了我们在这个主题的讨论中定义问题并分析讨论本身的努力——在其他方面词，采取主题阅读的第四和第五步。像这样的事情必须始终由主题读者来完成，尽管他当然不必总是写一本长篇大论的书来报告他的研究。*

The structure of the analysis of progress just described exemplifies our effort to define the issues within the discussion of this subject and to analyze the discussion itself—in other words, to take the fourth and fifth steps in syntopical reading. And something like this must always be done by a syntopical reader, although of course he does not always have to write a long book reporting his researches.*

Syntopicon 及其使用方法

The Syntopicon and How to Use It

 

如果你仔细阅读这一章，你会注意到，虽然我们花了一些时间讨论它，但我们并没有真正解决我们所谓的主题阅读悖论。这个悖论可以这样表述：除非你知道要读什么书，否则你无法按主题阅读，但除非你可以按主题阅读，否则你不知道该读什么。另一种表述方式可以称为主题式阅读的基本问题，即如果你不知道从哪里开始，你就无法进行主题式阅读；即使您大致知道从哪里开始，找到相关书籍和这些书籍中的相关段落所需的时间也可能超过采取所有其他步骤所需的时间总和。

If you read this chapter carefully, you will have noticed that, although we spent some time discussing it, we did not really solve what we called the paradox of syntopical reading. That paradox can be stated thus: Unless you know what books to read, you cannot read syntopically, but unless you can read syntopically, you do not know what to read. Another way to state it is in the form of what may be called the fundamental problem of syntopical reading, namely, that if you do not know where to start, you cannot read syntopically; and even if you have a rough idea of where to begin, the time required to find the relevant books and relevant passages in those books may exceed the time required to take all of the other steps combined.

实际上，当然，至少在理论上解决了悖论和问题的解决方案。从理论上讲，您可以非常透彻地了解我们传统的主要文献，以至于您对其中讨论每个想法的位置都有一个可行的概念。但如果你是这样的人，你就不需要任何人的帮助，我们不能告诉你任何你不知道的主题阅读。

Actually, of course, there is at least a theoretical resolution of the paradox and solution of the problem. Theoretically, you could know the major literature of our tradition so thoroughly that you had a working notion of where every idea is discussed in it. But if you are such a person, you need no help from anybody, and we cannot tell you anything you do not know about syntopical reading.

*既然这样一本书已经写成并出版了，我们希望它确实能够实现思想上的突破，就像我们设想的主题阅读的成果一样，并且这本关于进步的书可以促进该领域的进一步工作，因为哲学研究所出版的关于自由、幸福、正义和爱的其他书籍已经在他们的书中完成了——在这些书出现之前，这些工作异常困难。

* Now that such a book has been written and published, we hope that it will indeed make possible a breakthrough in thought such as we envisaged as the fruit of syntopical reading, and that the book on progress may facilitate further work in its field, as other books produced by the Institute for Philosophical Research on the ideas of freedom, happiness, justice, and love have done in theirs—work that was inordinately difficult before these books appeared.

 

另一方面，即使你没有这方面的知识你自己，你也许可以申请给其他做过的人。但是你应该认识到，如果你能够向这样的人提出申请，那么他的建议可能会成为一种障碍，而不是一种帮助。如果主题是他自己做过专门研究的主题，他很难只告诉你相关的段落来阅读而不告诉你如何阅读它们——这很可能会妨碍你。但是，如果他没有对这个主题进行专门研究，他可能不会比你了解更多，尽管对他和你来说可能都是如此。

On the other hand, even if you did not have this knowledge yourself, you might be able to apply to someone else who did. But you should recognize that if you were able to apply to such a person, his advice might turn out to be almost as much a hindrance as a help. If the subject was one on which he had himself done special research, it would be hard for him merely to tell you the relevant passages to read without telling you how to read them—and that might well get in your way. But if he had not done special research on the subject, he might not know a great deal more than yourself, although it might seem so both to him and to you.

因此，我们需要的是一本参考书，它可以告诉您到哪里可以找到与大量感兴趣的主题相关的段落，同时又不会说明应该如何阅读这些段落，也不会预先判断它们的含义或意义。Syntopicon 是此类作品的一个例子。它出版于 1940 年代，是题为“西方世界名著”的丛书的专题索引。在大约 3,000 个主题或主题中的每一个下，它都列出了对讨论该主题的集合中页面的引用。一些参考文献涉及许多页面的段落，另一些参考文献涉及关键段落甚至部分段落。找到它们所需的时间并不比取下指示的卷并翻阅其页面所需的时间更多。

What is needed, therefore, is a reference book that tells you where to go to find the relevant passages on a large number of subjects of interest, without at the same time saying how the passages should be read—without prejudging their meaning or significance. The Syntopicon is an example of such a work. Produced in the 1940’s, it is a topical index to the set of books titled Great Books of the Western World. Under each of some 3,000 topics or subjects, it lists references to pages within the set where that subject is discussed. Some of the references are to passages covering many pages, others are to key paragraphs or even parts of paragraphs. No more time is required to find them than is needed to take down the indicated volume and flip through its pages.

当然，Syntopicon 有一个主要缺陷。它只是一套书籍（虽然很大）的索引，而且它只粗略地指出了在其他书籍中可以找到哪些段落未包含在该系列中的信息。尽管如此，它总能为您提供至少一个主题阅读项目的起点。而且，在任何此类项目的过程中，套装中包含的书籍都是您几乎总是想阅读的书籍。因此，Syntopicon 应该能够为开始研究某个问题的成熟学者或读者节省大量的前期研究工作，并使他迅速进步到可以开始独立思考的程度，因为他知道做了什么思考。

The Syntopicon has one major defect, of course. It is an index of just one set of books (albeit a large one), and it gives only a very rough indication of where passages may be found in other books that are not included in the set. Nevertheless, it always provides you with at least a place to start on any syntopical reading project. And it is also true that the books included in the set are ones that you would almost always want to read anyway, in the course of any such project. Thus the Syntopicon should be able to save the mature scholar or reader who is beginning his research into a certain problem much of the preliminary labor of research, and advance him rapidly to the point where he can begin to think independently about it, because he knows what thinking has been done.

Syntopicon 对这类读者很有用，它对初学者更有用。Syntopicon 可以通过三种方式帮助这样的读者：主动性、暗示性和指导性。

Useful as the Syntopicon is for that kind of reader, it is much more useful for the beginner. The Syntopicon can help such a reader in three ways: initiatively, suggestively, and instructively.

它通过克服任何人在面对我们传统的经典书籍时所面临的最初困难来主动工作。这些作品有点压倒性。我们可能希望我们已经阅读了它们，但我们常常没有这样做。我们发现来自各个方面的建议都让我们自己去阅读它们，并且给我们提供了阅读计划，从较简单的作品开始，然后继续阅读较难的作品。但是所有这些程序都需要阅读整本书，或者至少需要完整阅读其中的大部分内容。根据一般经验，这种解决方案很少能达到预期的效果。

It works initiatively by overcoming the initial difficulty that anyone faces when confronted by the classical books of our tradition. These works are a little overpowering. We may wish that we had read them, but often we do not do so. We find ourselves advised from all sides to read them, and we are given reading programs, beginning with the easier works and proceeding to the more difficult ones. But all such programs require the reading of whole books or, at least, the integral reading of large parts of them. It is a matter of general experience that this kind of solution seldom achieves the desired result.

在 Syntopicon 的帮助下对这些主要作品进行主题阅读提供了一个完全不同的解决方案。Syntopicon 通过让人们阅读他们感兴趣的主题的特定书籍来启动阅读伟大的书籍；在这些主题上，阅读大量作者的相对较短的文章。它可以帮助我们在通读名著之前阅读它们。

A syntopical reading of these major works with the aid of the Syntopicon provides a radically different solution. The Syntopicon initiates the reading of great books by enabling persons to read particular ones on the subjects in which they are interested; and on those subjects, to read relatively short passages from a large number of authors. It helps us to read in the great books before we have read through them.

在 Syntopicon 的帮助下，对名著进行主题阅读也可能具有启发性。从读者对某一特定主题的现有兴趣出发，可能会引起或产生对相关主题的其他兴趣。一旦开始研究一位作者，就很难不去探索其背景。在不知不觉中，您已经阅读了本书的大部分内容。

Syntopical reading in the great books, with the help of the Syntopicon, may also work suggestively. Starting from the reader’s existing interest in a particular subject, it may arouse or create other interests in related subjects. And once started on an author, it is hard not to explore the context. Before you know it, you have read a good portion of the book.

最后，在 Syntopicon 的帮助下进行主题阅读以三种不同的方式发挥指导作用。事实上，这是这种阅读水平的主要好处之一。

Finally, syntopical reading with the aid of the Syntopicon works instructively, in three distinct ways. This, in fact, is one of the major benefits of this level of reading.

首先，与阅读文章相关的主题可以为读者解释文章指明方向。但它并没有告诉他这段话的意思，因为这段话可能以几种或许多不同的方式与主题相关。因此，呼吁读者发现 文章与主题的确切相关性。学会这样做就是获得阅读艺术中的一项主要技能。

First, the topic in connection with which the passage is being read serves to give direction to the reader in interpreting the passage. But it does not tell him what the passage means, since the passage may be relevant to the topic in several or many different ways. Hence the reader is called upon to discover precisely what relevance the passage has to the topic. To learn to do this is to acquire a major skill in the art of reading.

其次，收集关于同一主题但来自不同作品和不同作者的许多段落，有助于加深读者对阅读的每段段落的理解。有时，当依次阅读同一本书的段落并在上下文中相互阅读时，每一个都会变得更加清晰。有时，当将不同书籍中的一系列对比或冲突的段落相互阅读时，它们的含义会更加突出。有时一位作者的段落，通过对另一位作者的段落进行扩充或评论，实质上有助于读者理解第二位作者。

Second, the collection of a number of passages on the same topic, but from different works and different authors, serves to sharpen the reader’s interpretation of each passage read. Sometimes, when passages from the same book are read in sequence and in the context of one another, each becomes clearer. Sometimes the meaning of each of a series of contrasting or conflicting passages from different books is accentuated when they are read against one another. And sometimes the passages from one author, by amplifying or commenting on the passages from another, materially help the reader’s understanding of the second author.

第三，如果对许多不同的主题进行主题阅读，那么在 Syntopicon 中经常会发现在两个或更多主题下引用相同的段落这一事实将具有指导作用。当读者对不同的主题有不同的解释时，他会逐渐理解这段话的含义。这种多重解释不仅是阅读艺术的一项基本练习，而且往往会使头脑习惯性地警惕任何丰富或复杂的段落可能包含的多种含义。

Third, if syntopical reading is done on a number of different subjects, the fact that the same passage will often be found cited in the Syntopicon under two or more subjects will have its instructive effect. The passage has an amplitude of meaning that the reader will come to perceive as he interprets it somewhat differently in relation to different topics. Such multiple interpretation not only is a basic exercise in the art of reading but also tends to make the mind habitually alert to the many strains of meaning that any rich or complex passage can contain.

因为我们相信 Syntopicon 对任何希望以本章描述的方式阅读的读者都有用，无论他是初学者还是成熟的学者和研究人员，我们冒昧地为这一级别的阅读采用它的名字。我们希望读者能原谅我们这看似小小的自我放纵。作为宽恕的回报，我们想指出一个重要的事实。有一个小“s”的主题阅读与主题阅读之间有很大的区别，后者是指在 Syntopicon 的帮助下阅读伟大的书籍。在后一种意义上，主题阅读可以构成任何主题阅读项目的一部分，其中该术语用于以前的感觉，也许从那里开始总是明智的。但是带有小“s”的主题阅读是一个比主题阅读应用更广泛的术语。

Because we believe that the Syntopicon can be useful to any reader wishing to read in the manner described in this chapter, be he a beginner or a mature scholar and researcher, we have taken the liberty of adopting its name for this level of reading. We hope the reader will forgive us what may seem to be a small self-indulgence. In return for that forgiveness, we would like to point out an important fact. There is a considerable difference between syntopical reading, with a small “s,” and Syntopical reading, where the latter phrase refers to reading the great books with the help of the Syntopicon. Syntopical reading, in the latter sense, can constitute a part of any syntopical reading project where the term is used in the former sense, and perhaps it would always be wise to start there. But syntopical reading with a small “s” is a term of much wider application than Syntopical reading.

论主题阅读的原则

On the Principles That Underlie Syntopical Reading

 

有人说主题式阅读（刚才提到的广义上的）是不可能的。他们说，将术语强加于作者是错误的，即使是“中性”术语（如果有的话）。他自己的术语必须被视为神圣不可侵犯的，因为书永远不应该“断章取义”地阅读，此外，从一组术语翻译成另一组术语总是很危险的，因为单词不像数学符号那样是可控的。此外，反对者坚持认为，主题式阅读包括阅读在空间和时间上相距甚远、风格和方法截然不同的作者，就好像他们是同一个话语世界的成员，就好像他们在互相交谈一样——这扭曲了事情的真相。每个作者本身就是一个小宇宙，尽管同一作者在不同时期所写的不同书籍之间可以建立联系（他们警告说，即使这里也存在危险），但一位作者与另一位作者之间并没有明确的联系。最后，他们坚持认为作者讨论的主题本身并不像他们讨论主题的方式那么重要。他们说，风格就是人；如果我们在试图发现作者所说内容的过程中忽略了作者是如何说某事的，我们就会错过这两种理解。

There are those who say that syntopical reading (in the broader sense just mentioned) is impossible. It is wrong, they say, to impose a terminology, even a “neutral” one (if there is any such thing), on an author. His own terminology must be treated as sacrosanct, because books should never be read “out of context,” and besides, translation from one set of terms to another is always dangerous because words are not controllable like mathematical symbols. Further, the objectors maintain, syntopical reading involves reading authors widely separated in space and time, and differing radically in style and approach, as if they were members of the same universe of discourse, as if they were talking to one another—and this distorts the facts of the matter. Each author is a little universe in himself, and although connections can be made between different books written by the same author at different times (even here there are dangers, they warn), there are no clear connections relating one author to another. They maintain, finally, that the subjects that authors discuss, as such, are not as important as the ways in which they discuss them. The style, they say, is the man; and if we ignore how an author says something, in the process of trying to discover what he says, we will miss both kinds of understanding.

很明显，我们不同意所有这些指控，因此对每一项指控的回答都是有序的。让我们一次一个。

It should be apparent that we disagree with all of those charges, and therefore an answer to each of them is in order. Let us take them one at a time.

首先，关于术语。否认一个想法可以用多于一组的术语来表达类似于否认从一种自然语言中翻译是可能的语言到另一个。当然，这种否认是存在的。例如，最近，我们读到一篇新译《古兰经》的介绍，开头就说翻译《古兰经》是不可能的。但既然作者接着解释了他是如何做到的，我们只能假设他的意思是，对于一本被许多人奉为圣书的书，翻译是特别困难的。我们会同意的。但困难并非不可能。

First, to the point about terminology. To deny that an idea can be expressed in more than one set of terms is similar to denying that translation is possible from one natural language to another. That denial is made, of course. Recently, for example, we read an introduction to a new translation of the Koran that began by saying that to translate the Koran is impossible. But since the author then proceeded to explain how he had done it, we could only assume that he meant that translation is particularly difficult in the case of a book held to be holy by large numbers of people. We would agree. But the difficult is not the impossible.

事实上，作者的术语必须被视为神圣不可侵犯的观点可能永远只是另一种说法，即很难将一种术语翻译成另一种术语。我们也会同意这一点。但同样，困难并非不可能。

In fact, the view that an author’s terms must be treated as sacrosanct is probably always merely another way of saying that it is difficult to translate from one terminology to another. We would agree to that, too. But again, the difficult is not the impossible.

第二，关于作者的分离性和独特性。这归根结底是说，如果亚里士多德走进我们的办公室，毫无疑问穿着长袍，并由一位既懂现代英语又懂古典希腊语的翻译陪同，我们将无法理解他或他我们。我们根本不相信。毫无疑问，亚里士多德会对他所看到的某些事物感到惊讶，但我们非常有信心，如果我们愿意，我们可以在十分钟内对我们共有的问题进行哲学讨论。某些概念可能会反复出现困难，但一旦我们认识到它们是这样的，我们就可以解决它们。

Second, to the point about the separateness and uniqueness of authors. This comes down to saying that if Aristotle, for example, walked into our office, attired no doubt in robes and accompanied by an interpreter who knew both modern English and classical Greek, we would not be able to understand him or he us. We simply do not believe it. Doubtless Aristotle would be amazed at some of the things he saw, but we are quite confident that within ten minutes we could, if we wanted to, be engaged in a philosophical discussion of problems that we shared. There might be recurrent difficulties about certain conceptions, but as soon as we recognized them as such, we could resolve them.

如果这是可能的（而且我们真的认为没有人会否认它），那么一本书通过解释者（即你，主题读者）与另一本书“交谈”并非不可能。当然，需要小心谨慎，你应该尽可能地了解两种“语言”——即两本书——。但是这个问题并不是无法克服的，而且认为它是这样的想法简直是愚蠢的。

If that is possible (and we do not really think anyone would deny it), then it is not impossible for one book to “talk” to another through the medium of an interpreter—namely, you, the syntopical reader. Care is required, of course, and you should know both “languages”—that is, both books—as well as you can. But the problem is not insuperable, and it is simply foolish to suggest that it is.

最后，关于方式或风格的观点。我们认为，这相当于说男人之间没有理性的交流，而是所有男人都在情感层面进行交流，这与他们与宠物交流的层次相同。如果你对你的狗说“我爱你”愤怒的语气，他会退缩；但他不了解你。谁能认真地断言，在两个人之间的语音交流中，除了语调或手势之外别无其他？语调很重要，尤其是当情感关系是沟通的主要内容时；如果我们只听（看？），肢体语言可能会告诉我们一些事情。但在人类交流中也有其他东西。如果你问某人如何到达出口，他告诉你走 B 走廊，不管他用什么语气。他要么对要么错，要么说谎要么说真话，但关键是你很快就会沿着走廊 B 发现这一点。你已经明白了什么他一边说，一边毫无疑问地以各种方式对他说话的方式做出反应。

Finally, to the point about the manner or style. This is equivalent, we think, to saying that there is no rational communication among men, but that all men communicate at the emotional level, which is the same level at which they communicate with pets. If you say “I love you” to your dog in an angry tone of voice, he will cower; but he does not understand you. Can anyone seriously assert that there is nothing more than tone of voice or gesture in vocal communications between two human beings? Tone of voice is important, particularly when emotional relations are the primary content of the communication; and body language probably has things to tell us if we will only listen (look?). But there is something else, too, in human communication. If you ask someone how to reach the exit, and he tells you to follow Corridor B, it does not matter what tone of voice he employs. He is either right or wrong, lying or telling the truth, but the point is that you will soon find that out by following Corridor B. You have understood what he said as well as reacting, no doubt in all sorts of ways, to how he said it.

相信，然后，翻译是可能的（因为它一直在进行），书籍可以相互“交谈”（因为人类这样做），并且当人与人之间存在客观，理性的交流内容时他们试图变得理性（因为我们可以并且确实互相学习），我们相信主题阅读是可能的。

Believing, then, that translation is possible (because it is done all the time), that books can “talk” to one another (because human beings do so), and that there is an objective, rational content of communication between human beings when they are trying to be rational (because we can and do learn from each other), we believe that syntopical reading is possible.

主题阅读总结

Summary of Syntopical Reading

 

我们现在已经完成了主题阅读的讨论。因此，让我们以大纲的形式展示在这个阅读层次上必须采取的各种步骤。

We have now completed our discussion of syntopical reading. Let us therefore display the various steps that must be taken at this level of reading in outline form.

正如我们所见，主题阅读有两个主要阶段。一种是预备性的，另一种是主题阅读。让我们写出所有这些步骤以供审查。

As we have seen, there are two main stages of syntopical reading. One is preparatory, and the other is syntopical reading proper. Let us write out all of these steps for review.

一、调查主题阅读的准备工作

I. Surveying the Field Preparatory to Syntopical Reading

 

1. 借助图书馆目录、顾问和书籍中的参考书目，为你的主题创建一个暂定参考书目。

1. Create a tentative bibliography of your subject by recourse to library catalogues, advisors, and bibliographies in books.

2. 检查暂定书目中的所有书籍，以确定哪些与您的主题密切相关，并对主题有更清晰的了解。

2. Inspect all of the books on the tentative bibliography to ascertain which are germane to your subject, and also to acquire a clearer idea of the subject.

注意：严格来说，这两个步骤在时间上并不是截然不同的；也就是说，这两个步骤相互影响，特别是第二个步骤用于修改第一个步骤。

Note: These two steps are not, strictly speaking, chronologically distinct; that is, the two steps have an effect on each other, with the second, in particular, serving to modify the first.

二。第一阶段积累的书目专题阅读

II. Syntopical Reading of the Bibliography Amassed in Stage I

 

1. 检查已在第一阶段确定为与您的主题相关的书籍，以找到最相关的段落。

1. Inspect the books already identified as relevant to your subject in Stage I in order to find the most relevant passages.

2. 通过构建一个主题的中性术语来让作者接受，所有或绝大多数作者都可以被解释为使用，无论他们是否实际使用这些词。

2. Bring the authors to terms by constructing a neutral terminology of the subject that all, or the great majority, of the authors can be interpreted as employing, whether they actually employ the words or not.

3. 通过构建一组问题来为所有作者建立一组中性命题，所有或大多数作者都可以被解释为给出了答案，无论他们是否明确地处理了这些问题。

3. Establish a set of neutral propositions for all of the authors by framing a set of questions to which all or most of the authors can be interpreted as giving answers, whether they actually treat the questions explicitly or not.

4. 定义问​​题，包括主要问题和次要问题，方法是将作者对不同问题的相反答案放在一个问题的一侧或另一侧。你应该记住，一个问题并不总是明确存在于作者之间或作者之间，但有时必须通过解释作者对可能不是他们主要关注的问题的观点来构建。

4. Define the issues, both major and minor ones, by ranging the opposing answers of authors to the various questions on one side of an issue or another. You should remember that an issue does not always exist explicitly between or among authors, but that it sometimes has to be constructed by interpretation of the authors’ views on matters that may not have been their primary concern.

5. 通过对问题进行排序来分析讨论，以便最大限度地阐明主题。较普遍的问题应先于较不普遍的问题，并且应明确指出问题之间的关系。

5. Analyze the discussion by ordering the questions and issues in such a way as to throw maximum light on the subject. More general issues should precede less general ones, and relations among issues should be clearly indicated.

注意：理想情况下，应始终保持辩证的超然或客观性。确保这一点的一种方法是始终伴随着对作者对某个问题的观点的解释以及对他的文本的实际引用。

Note: Dialectical detachment or objectivity should, ideally, be maintained throughout. One way to insure this is always to accompany an interpretation of an author’s views on an issue with an actual quotation from his text.

21

阅读与心智的成长

21READING AND THE GROWTH OF THE MIND

 

我们现在已经完成了本书开头摆在我们面前的任务。我们已经表明，积极阅读是良好阅读的本质，而且阅读越积极越好。

We have now completed the task that lay before us at the beginning of this book. We have shown that activity is the essence of good reading, and that the more active reading is, the better it is.

我们已经将积极阅读定义为提问，并且指出了必须对任何一本书提出什么问题，以及对于不同类型的书必须如何以不同的方式回答这些问题。

We have defined active reading as the asking of questions, and we have indicated what questions must be asked of any book, and how those questions must be answered in different ways for different kinds of books.

我们已经确定并讨论了阅读的四个层次，并展示了它们是如何累积的，较早或较低的层次如何包含在较晚或较高的层次中。根据我们声明的意图，我们更加强调后期和较高层次的阅读，而不是早期和较低层次的阅读，因此我们强调分析和主题阅读。由于分析阅读对于大多数读者来说可能是最陌生的一种，因此我们对它的讨论比任何其他级别都要长，给出了它的规则，并按照必须应用的顺序对其进行了解释。但是几乎所有关于分析阅读的内容，加上上一章提到的某些改编，也适用于主题阅读。

We have identified and discussed the four levels of reading, and shown how these are cumulative, earlier or lower levels being contained in later or higher ones. Consequent upon our stated intention, we have laid more stress upon the later and higher levels of reading than upon the earlier and lower ones, and we have therefore emphasized analytical and syntopical reading. Since analytical reading is probably the most unfamiliar kind for most readers, we have discussed it at greater length than any of the other levels, giving its rules and explaining them in the order in which they must be applied. But almost everything that was said of analytical reading also applies, with certain adaptations that were mentioned in the last chapter, to syntopical reading as well.

我们已经完成了我们的任务，但您可能还没有完成您的任务。我们不需要提醒您这是一个实用的书，也不认为实用书的读者对它有特殊的义务。我们说过，如果一本实用书籍的读者接受它提出的目标，并同意所推荐的方法是适当和有效的，那么他就必须按照所建议的方式行事。您可能不接受我们认可的主要目标——即您应该能够尽可能地阅读——或者我们建议的实现该目标的方法——即检查性阅读、分析性阅读和主题阅读的规则。（然而，在那种情况下，您不太可能阅读此页。）但是，如果您确实接受该目标并同意该方法是适当的，那么您必须努力阅读，因为您可能以前从未阅读过。

We have completed our task, but you may not have completed yours. We do not need to remind you that this is a practical book, nor that the reader of a practical book has a special obligation with respect to it. If, we said, the reader of a practical book accepts the ends it proposes and agrees that the means recommended are appropriate and effective, then he must act in the way proposed. You may not accept the primary aim we have endorsed—namely, that you should be able to read as well as possible—nor the means we have proposed to reach it—namely, the rules of inspectional, analytical, and syntopical reading. (In that case, however, you are not likely to be reading this page.) But if you do accept that aim and agree that the means are appropriate, then you must make the effort to read as you probably have never read before.

这是你的任务和义务。我们能以任何方式帮助您吗？

That is your task and your obligation. Can we help you in it in any way?

我们认为我们可以。任务主要落在你身上——从今以后，你必须做所有的工作（并获得所有的好处）。但关于目的和手段，还有几件事要说。让我们先讨论后者。

We think we can. The task falls mainly on you—it is you who, henceforth, must do all the work (and obtain all the benefits). But there are several things that remain to be said, about the end and the means. Let us discuss the latter first.

好书能为我们做什么

What Good Books Can Do for Us

 

“手段”可以有两种解释。在上一段中，我们将该术语解释为阅读规则，即成为更好阅读者的方法。但是“手段”也可以解释为指的是您阅读的内容。有方法却没有适用的材料，就如同有材料却没有适用的方法一样毫无用处。

“Means” can be interpreted in two ways. In the previous paragraph, we interpreted the term as referring to the rules of reading, that is, the method by which you become a better reader. But “means” can also be interpreted as referring to the things you read. Having a method without materials to which it can be applied is as useless as having the materials with no method to apply to them.

在后一种意义上，为你进一步提高阅读能力服务的方法是你将要阅读的书。我们已经说过，该方法适用于您阅读的任何内容，如果您通过该陈述理解任何类型的书，那么这就是事实——无论是小说还是非小说，想象的还是说明性的，实用的还是理论的。但实际上，该方法，至少在我们对分析的讨论中举例说明和主题阅读，并不适用于每本书。原因是有些书不需要它。

In the latter sense of the term, the means that will serve you in the further improvement of your reading are the books you will read. We have said that the method applies to anything you read, and that is true, if you understand by the statement any kind of book—whether fiction or nonfiction, imaginative or expository, practical or theoretical. But in fact, the method, at least as it is exemplified in our discussion of analytical and syntopical reading, does not apply to every book. The reason is that some books do not require it.

我们之前已经提出过这一点，但我们现在想再次提出来，因为它与摆在你们面前的任务相关。如果您阅读是为了成为更好的读者，那么您不能只阅读任何一本书或一篇文章。如果你读的都是你能力范围内的书，你作为一个读者是不会进步的。你必须处理那些超出你能力范围的书，或者，正如我们所说的，那些你无法理解的书。只有那种书才能让你舒展一下头脑。除非你伸展，否则你不会学习。

We have made this point before, but we want to make it now again because of its relevance to the task that lies before you. If you are reading in order to become a better reader, you cannot read just any book or article. You will not improve as a reader if all you read are books that are well within your capacity. You must tackle books that are beyond you, or, as we have said, books that are over your head. Only books of that sort will make you stretch your mind. And unless you stretch, you will not learn.

因此，对于您来说，不仅要能够阅读，而且要能够识别那些对您提出提高阅读能力所需的各种要求的书，变得至关重要。一本只能消遣或招待你的书可能是一个闲暇时间的愉快消遣，但你绝不能指望从中得到任何乐趣。我们并不反对娱乐本身，但我们确实想强调阅读技能的提高并不伴随它。这同样适用于一本书，它只是告诉你一些你不知道的事实，而没有增加你对这些事实的理解。为获取信息而阅读与为娱乐而阅读一样，不会让你的头脑更加紧张。看起来好像确实如此，但这仅仅是因为你的头脑比读这本书之前更充满了事实。然而，你的头脑基本上处于与以前相同的状态。量变了，但是功力没有提升。

Thus, it becomes of crucial importance for you not only to be able to read well but also to be able to identify those books that make the kinds of demands on you that improvement in reading ability requires. A book that can do no more than amuse or entertain you may be a pleasant diversion for an idle hour, but you must not expect to get anything but amusement from it. We are not against amusement in its own right, but we do want to stress that improvement in reading skill does not accompany it. The same goes for a book that merely informs you of facts that you did not know without adding to your understanding of those facts. Reading for information does not stretch your mind any more than reading for amusement. It may seem as though it does, but that is merely because your mind is fuller of facts than it was before you read the book. However, your mind is essentially in the same condition that it was before. There has been a quantitative change, but no improvement in your skill.

我们说过很多次，好的读者在阅读时对自己提出要求。他积极、努力地阅读。现在我们在说别的。您想要练习阅读的书籍，尤其是分析阅读，也必须对您提出要求。在你看来，它们一定超出了你的能力范围。你不必担心它们确实如此，因为如果你应用我们拥有的阅读规则，就没有一本书是你完全无法掌握的描述。当然，这并不意味着这些规则会立即为您创造奇迹。肯定有一些书会继续扩展你，无论你是一个多么优秀的读者。事实上，这些正是你必须寻找的书，因为它们最能帮助你成为一个更有技巧的读者。

We have said many times that the good reader makes demands on himself when he reads. He reads actively, effort-fully. Now we are saying something else. The books that you will want to practice your reading on, particularly your analytical reading, must also make demands on you. They must seem to you to be beyond your capacity. You need not fear that they really are, because there is no book that is completely out of your grasp if you apply the rules of reading to it that we have described. This does not mean, of course, that these rules will accomplish immediate miracles for you. There are certainly some books that will continue to extend you no matter how good a reader you are. Actually, those are the very books that you must seek out, because they are the ones that can best help you to become an ever more skillful reader.

一些读者错误地认为这些书——那些对他们的技能提供持续和永无止境的挑战的书——总是在相对陌生的领域。实际上，就大多数读者而言，这归结为相信只有科学书籍，也许还有哲学书籍，才符合标准。但事实远非如此。我们已经说过，伟大的科学书籍在很多方面都比非科学书籍更容易阅读，因为科学作者会帮助你达成共识、确定关键命题并陈述主要论点。诗歌作品中没有这些帮助，因此从长远来看，它们很可能是你能读到的最难、要求最高的书。例如，荷马在很多方面都比牛顿更难读懂，尽管你可能第一次从荷马那里得到更多。原因是荷马处理的主题更难写好。

Some readers make the mistake of supposing that such books—the ones that provide a constant and never-ending challenge to their skill—are always ones in relatively unfamiliar fields. In practice, this comes down to believing, in the case of most readers, that only scientific books, and perhaps philosophical ones, satisfy the criterion. But that is far from the case. We have already remarked that the great scientific books are in many ways easier to read than non-scientific ones, because of the care with which scientific authors help you to come to terms, identify the key propositions, and state the main arguments. These helps are absent from poetical works, and so in the long run they are quite likely to be the hardest, the most demanding, books that you can read. Homer, for example, is in many ways harder to read than Newton, despite the fact that you may get more out of Homer the first time through. The reason is that Homer deals with subjects that are harder to write well about.

我们这里所说的困难与一本烂书所呈现的困难是截然不同的。读一本坏书也很困难，因为它无视你努力分析它的努力，每当你认为你已经确定它时，它就会从你的指缝中溜走。事实上，对于一本坏书来说，真的没有什么可以确定的。不值得尝试。你的奋斗不会得到任何回报。

The difficulties that we are talking about here are very different from the difficulties that are presented by a bad book. It is hard to read a bad book, too, for it defies your efforts to analyze it, slipping through your fingers whenever you think you have it pinned down. In fact, in the case of a bad book, there is really nothing to pin down. It is not worth the effort of trying. You receive no reward for your struggle.

一本好书确实会奖励您尝试阅读它。最好的书最能奖励你。当然，奖励有两种。首先，当你成功地完成一项好的、困难的工作时，你的阅读技巧就会得到提高。其次——从长远来看，这一点更为重要——一本好书可以教会你认识世界和认识自己。您学到的不仅仅是如何更好地阅读；你也学到了更多关于生活的知识。你变得更聪明了。不仅知识更丰富——只提供信息的书籍也能产生这样的结果。但更明智的是，你更深刻地意识到人类生活的伟大和永恒的真理。

A good book does reward you for trying to read it. The best books reward you most of all. The reward, of course, is of two kinds. First, there is the improvement in your reading skill that occurs when you successfully tackle a good, difficult work. Second—and this in the long run is much more important —a good book can teach you about the world and about yourself. You learn more than how to read better; you also learn more about life. You become wiser. Not just more knowledgeable—books that provide nothing but information can produce that result. But wiser, in the sense that you are more deeply aware of the great and enduring truths of human life.

毕竟，有些人类问题是无法解决的。有一些关系，人与人之间，人与非人世界之间，没有人能说了算。不仅在科学和哲学等领域如此，很明显，在这些领域，任何人都没有而且永远不会达到对自然及其法则、存在和变化的最终理解；对于诸如男女关系、父母与子女关系、人与上帝关系等熟悉的日常事务也是如此。这些是你不能想得太多，也不能想得太多的事情。最伟大的书可以帮助你更好地思考它们，因为它们是由比其他人更善于思考它们的男人和女人写的。

There are some human problems, after all, that have no solution. There are some relationships, both among human beings and between human beings and the nonhuman world, about which no one can have the last word. This is true not only in such fields as science and philosophy, where it is obvious that final understanding about nature and its laws, and about being and becoming, has not been achieved by anyone and never will be; it is also true of such familiar and everyday matters as the relation between men and women, or parents and children, or man and God. These are matters about which you cannot think too much, or too well. The greatest books can help you to think better about them, because they were written by men and women who thought better than other people about them.

书籍金字塔

The Pyramid of Books

 

仅以西方传统写成的几百万本书中的绝大多数——超过 99%——不会对你提出足够的要求来提高你的阅读技能。这似乎是一个令人沮丧的事实，而且百分比似乎被高估了。但显然，考虑到所涉及的数字，这是真的。这些书只能以娱乐或信息为目的阅读。娱乐可能有很多种，信息可能以各种方式很有趣。但是你不应该期望从他们那里学到任何重要的东西。事实上，你根本不需要——分析地——阅读它们。略读即可。

The great majority of the several million books that have been written in the Western tradition alone—more than 99 per cent of them—will not make sufficient demands on you for you to improve your skill in reading. This may seem like a distressing fact, and the percentages may seem an overestimate. But obviously, considering the numbers involved, it is true. These are the books that can be read only for amusement or information. The amusement may be of many kinds, and the information may be interesting in all sorts of ways. But you should not expect to learn anything of importance from them. In fact, you do not have to read them—analytically—at all. Skimming will do.

还有第二类书，你可以从中学习——如何阅读和如何生活。不到百分之一的书属于这一类——可能更多的是千分之一，甚至万分之一。这些都是好书，是作者精心编写的，向读者传达了对人类持久感兴趣的主题的重要见解。这样的书总共可能不超过几千本。他们对读者提出了苛刻的要求。它们值得分析性地阅读一次。如果你很熟练，你将能够从他们那里得到他们在一次良好的阅读过程中所能给予的一切。它们是你读过一次就放在书架上的书。你知道你永远不必再读它们，尽管您可能会回到他们那里检查某些要点或刷新您对某些想法或情节的记忆。（对于此类书籍，您在页边空白处或本书其他地方所做的注释特别有价值。）

There is a second class of books from which you can learn —both how to read and how to live. Less than one out of every hundred books belongs in this class—probably it is more like one in a thousand, or even one in ten thousand. These are the good books, the ones that were carefully wrought by their authors, the ones that convey to the reader significant insights about subjects of enduring interest to human beings. There are in all probably no more than a few thousand such books. They make severe demands on the reader. They are worth reading analytically—once. If you are skillful, you will be able to get everything out of them that they can give in the course of one good reading. They are books that you read once and then put away on your shelf. You know that you will never have to read them again, although you may return to them to check certain points or to refresh your memory of certain ideas or episodes. (It is in the case of such books that the notes you make in the margin or elsewhere in the volume are particularly valuable.)

你怎么知道你再也不用读这些书了？您可以通过自己对阅读它们的经历的心理反应来了解这一点。这样的书可以拓展你的思维，增加你的理解力。但是随着你的思维扩展和你的理解增加，你会意识到，通过一个或多或少神秘的过程，你将不会再被这本书改变。你意识到你已经完全掌握了这本书。你把它榨干了。你很感激它给了你什么，但你知道它不能再给了。

How do you know that you do not ever have to read such books again? You know it by your own mental reaction to the experience of reading them. Such a book stretches your mind and increases your understanding. But as your mind stretches and your understanding increases, you realize, by a process that is more or less mysterious, that you are not going to be changed any more in the future by this book. You realize that you have grasped the book in its entirety. You have milked it dry. You are grateful to it for what it has given you, but you know it has no more to give.

在这几千本书中，有一小部分——这里的数量可能少于一百本——即使是你所能读到的最好的书也无法读完。你如何认识这一点？同样，它相当神秘，但是当你在尽你最大的能力分析阅读后合上这本书，然后将它放回书架上时，你会偷偷怀疑里面的东西比你得到的要多。我们说“怀疑”是因为现阶段可能就是这样。如果你知道你拥有的是什么错过了，作为一名分析型读者，你的义务会立即带你回到这本书中去寻找它。事实上，您无法用手指触摸它，但您知道它就在那里。你发现你无法忘记这本书，你一直在想它以及你对它的反应。最后，你回到它。然后一件非常了不起的事情发生了。

Of the few thousand such books there is a much smaller number—here the number is probably less than a hundred—that cannot be exhausted by even the very best reading you can manage. How do you recognize this? Again it is rather mysterious, but when you have closed the book after reading it analytically to the best of your ability, and place it back on the shelf, you have a sneaking suspicion that there is more there than you got. We say “suspicion” because that may be all it is at this stage. If you knew what it was that you had missed, your obligation as an analytical reader would take you back to the book immediately to seek it out. In fact, you cannot put your finger on it, but you know it is there. You find that you cannot forget the book, that you keep thinking about it and your reaction to it. Finally, you return to it. And then a very remarkable thing happens.

如果这本书属于我们之前提到的第二类书，你会发现，当你再次阅读它时，里面的书比你记得的要少。当然，原因是你自己也在这期间成长了。你的头脑更充实，你的理解更深刻。书没有变，但你变了。这样的回报难免令人失望。

If the book belongs to the second class of books to which we referred before, you find, on returning to it, that there was less there than you remembered. The reason, of course, is that you yourself have grown in the meantime. Your mind is fuller, your understanding greater. The book has not changed, but you have. Such a return is inevitably disappointing.

但是，如果这本书属于最高级别——极少数取之不尽、用之不竭的书籍——你在返回时会发现这本书似乎与你一起成长。你在其中看到新事物——整套新事物——你以前没有看到。你之前对这本书的理解并没有失效（假设你第一次读得很好）；它和以前一样真实，而且和以前一样真实。但现在在其他方面也是如此。

But if the book belongs to the highest class—the very small number of inexhaustible books—you discover on returning that the book seems to have grown with you. You see new things in it—whole sets of new things—that you did not see before. Your previous understanding of the book is not invalidated (assuming that you read it well the first time); it is just as true as it ever was, and in the same ways that it was true before. But now it is true in still other ways, too.

一本书如何随着你的成长而成长？这当然是不可能的；一本书，一旦写成出版，就不会改变。但你现在才开始意识到，这本书从一开始就远远高于你，它一直高于你，而且可能永远如此。因为它是一本真正的好书——一本伟大的书，正如我们所说的——它可以在不同层次上阅读。您对以前阅读的理解有所增加的印象并非错误。那本书真的让你振作起来。但是现在，即使你变得更聪明、更有知识，它也能再次提升你。它会一直这样做，直到你死去。

How can a book grow as you grow? It is impossible, of course; a book, once it is written and published, does not change. But what you only now begin to realize is that the book was so far above you to begin with that it has remained above you, and probably always will remain so. Since it is a really good book—a great book, as we might say—it is accessible at different levels. Your impression of increased understanding on your previous reading was not false. The book truly lifted you then. But now, even though you have become wiser and more knowledgeable, it can lift you again. And it will go on doing this until you die.

显然没有多少书可以为我们任何人做到这一点。我们的估计是这个数字远少于一百。但这个数字甚至比任何给定读者的数字都要少。除了心智的力量之外，人类在许多方面都存在差异。他们有不同的口味；不同的事物对一个人比对另一个人更有吸引力。你对牛顿的感觉可能永远不会像对莎士比亚的感觉那样，要么是因为你可能能够很好地阅读牛顿，以至于你不必再读他的书，要么是因为世界上的数学系统并没有对你有吸引力. 或者，如果他们这样做了——查尔斯·达尔文就是这样一个人的例子——那么牛顿可能是为数不多的几本书之一，而不是莎士比亚。

There are obviously not many books that can do this for any of us. Our estimate was that the number is considerably less than a hundred. But the number is even less than that for any given reader. Human beings differ in many ways other than in the power of their minds. They have different tastes; different things appeal more to one person than to another. You may never feel about Newton the way you feel about Shakespeare, either because you may be able to read Newton so well that you do not have to read him again, or because mathematical systems of the world just do not have all that appeal to you. Or, if they do—Charles Darwin is an example of such a person—then Newton may be one of the handful of books that are great for you, and not Shakespeare.

从这个意义上说，我们不想权威地声明任何特定的一本书或一组书一定对你很好，尽管在我们的第一个附录中我们确实列出了那些经验表明能够对许多读者具有这种价值的书. 相反，我们的观点是，你应该寻找几本对你有这种价值的书。无论是关于阅读还是关于生活，它们都是最能教给你的书。它们是您会想要一遍又一遍地阅读的书籍。它们是可以帮助您成长的书籍。

We do not want to state authoritatively that any particular book or group of books must be great for you, in this sense, although in our first Appendix we do list those books that experience has shown are capable of having this kind of value for many readers. Our point, instead, is that you should seek out the few books that can have this value for you. They are the books that will teach you the most, both about reading and about life. They are the books to which you will want to return over and over. They are the books that will help you to grow.

心灵的生命与成长

The Life and Growth of the Mind

 

有一个古老的测试——它在一代人之前非常流行——旨在告诉你哪些书可以为你做到这一点。假设，测试进行了，你事先知道你将在你的余生中被困在一个荒岛上，或者至少是很长一段时间。还要假设您有时间为体验做准备。您一定会随身携带某些实用且有用的文章。您还将获得十本书。你会选择哪些？

There is an old test—it was quite popular a generation ago —that was designed to tell you which books are the ones that can do this for you. Suppose, the test went, that you know in advance that you will be marooned on a desert island for the rest of your life, or at least for a long period. Suppose, too, that you have time to prepare for the experience. There are certain practical and useful articles that you would be sure to take with you. You will also be allowed ten books. Which ones would you select?

尝试确定一个列表是有启发性的，不仅因为它可以帮助您确定您最想阅读和重读的书籍。事实上，与你想象如果你是，生活会是什么样子时你对自己的了解相比，这可能是次要的切断通常围绕着你的所有娱乐、信息和理解的来源。请记住，岛上没有收音机或电视，也没有借阅图书馆。只有你和十本书。

Trying to decide on a list is instructive, and not only because it may help you to identify the books that you would most like to read and reread. That, in fact, is probably of minor importance, compared with what you can learn about yourself when you imagine what life would be like if you were cut off from all the sources of amusement, information, and understanding that ordinarily surround you. Remember, there would be no radio or television on the island, and no lending library. There would be just you and ten books.

当您开始考虑时，这种想象的情况似乎很奇怪且不真实。但它真的如此不真实吗？我们不这么认为。在某种程度上，我们都是被困在荒岛上的人。如果我们真的在那里，我们都会面临同样的挑战——寻找我们自身的资源来过上美好的人类生活的挑战。

This imagined situation seems bizarre and unreal when you begin to think about it. But is it actually so unreal? We do not think so. We are all to some extent persons marooned on a desert island. We all face the same challenge that we would face if we really were there—the challenge of finding the resources within ourselves to live a good human life.

有一个关于人类思想的奇怪事实，一个将思想与身体截然不同的事实。身体在某些方面受到限制，而思想却没有。这方面的一个标志是身体不会无限期地继续增强力量并发展技能和优雅。到大多数人三十岁时，他们的身体和以前一样好；事实上，那时很多人的身体已经开始恶化。但是头脑可以维持的成长和发展的数量是没有限制的。思想不会在任何特定年龄停止成长；只有当大脑本身在衰老中失去活力时，头脑才会失去提高技能和理解力的能力。

There is a strange fact about the human mind, a fact that differentiates the mind sharply from the body. The body is limited in ways that the mind is not. One sign of this is that the body does not continue indefinitely to grow in strength and develop in skill and grace. By the time most people are thirty years old, their bodies are as good as they will ever be; in fact, many persons’ bodies have begun to deteriorate by that time. But there is no limit to the amount of growth and development that the mind can sustain. The mind does not stop growing at any particular age; only when the brain itself loses its vigor, in senescence, does the mind lose its power to increase in skill and understanding.

这是人类最了不起的事情之一，它实际上可能是智人与其他动物之间的主要区别，其他动物的智力似乎不会超过其发展的某个阶段。但是，人类拥有的这一巨大优势也伴随着巨大的危险。如果不使用，头脑就会像肌肉一样萎缩。精神肌肉萎缩是我们因不进行脑力锻炼而付出的代价。这是一个可怕的惩罚，因为有证据表明精神萎缩是一种致命的疾病。这么多忙碌的人退休后这么快就死了，似乎没有其他解释。工作的要求使他们保持活力。它们是由外力人为支撑的。但是一旦这些需求停止，就没有资源在他们自己的精神活动方式中，他们完全停止思考，然后死去。

This is one of the most remarkable things about human beings, and it may actually be the major difference between homo sapiens and the others animals, which do not seem to grow mentally beyond a certain stage in their development. But this great advantage that man possesses carries with it a great peril. The mind can atrophy, like the muscles, if it is not used. Atrophy of the mental muscles is the penalty that we pay for not taking mental exercise. And this is a terrible penalty, for there is evidence that atrophy of the mind is a mortal disease. There seems to be no other explanation for the fact that so many busy people die so soon after retirement. They were kept alive by the demands of their work upon their minds; they were propped up artificially, as it were, by external forces. But as soon as those demands cease, having no resources within themselves in the way of mental activity, they cease thinking altogether, and expire.

电视、收音机以及日常生活中围绕在我们身边的所有娱乐和信息来源也都是人造道具。它们会给我们这样的印象，即我们的思维是活跃的，因为我们需要对来自外界的刺激做出反应。但是，那些让我们继续前进的外部刺激的力量是有限的。他们就像毒品一样。我们逐渐习惯了它们，并且我们不断地需要越来越多的它们。最终，它们几乎没有效果。然后，如果我们自身缺乏资源，我们就会停止在智力、道德和精神上成长。当我们停止成长时，我们就开始死亡。

Television, radio, and all the sources of amusement and information that surround us in our daily lives are also artificial props. They can give us the impression that our minds are active, because we are required to react to stimuli from outside. But the power of those external stimuli to keep us going is limited. They are like drugs. We grow used to them, and we continuously need more and more of them. Eventually, they have little or no effect. Then, if we lack resources within ourselves, we cease to grow intellectually, morally, and spiritually. And when we cease to grow, we begin to die.

因此，读好书，即积极阅读，不仅本身是一件好事，也不仅仅是我们工作或事业进步的一种手段。它还有助于保持我们的思想活跃和成长。

Reading well, which means reading actively, is thus not only a good in itself, nor is it merely a means to advancement in our work or career. It also serves to keep our minds alive and growing.

附录

A 推荐阅读清单

APPENDIX AA RECOMMENDED READING LIST

 

在接下来的几页中列出了值得您阅读的书籍。我们非常认真地对待“值得你花时间”这句话。尽管并非所有列出的书籍在任何普遍接受的术语含义中都“伟大”，但所有这些书籍都会奖励您阅读它们所付出的努力。所有这些书都让大多数人难以理解——无论如何，这足以迫使大多数读者展开他们的思想来理解和欣赏它们。如果你想提高阅读技巧，同时发现我们文学传统中思想和言论的最佳内容，那当然是你应该寻找的那种书。

On the following pages appears a list of books that it would be worth your while to read. We mean the phrase “worth your while” quite seriously. Although not all of the books listed are “great” in any of the commonly accepted meanings of the term, all of them will reward you for the effort you make to read them. All of these books are over most people’s heads—sufficiently so, at any rate, to force most readers to stretch their minds to understand and appreciate them. And that, of course, is the kind of book you should seek out if you want to improve your reading skills, and at the same time discover the best that has been thought and said in our literary tradition.

从我们在上一章中使用的术语的特殊意义来看，有些书很棒。回到他们那里，你总会发现一些新的东西，通常是很多东西。它们可以无休止地重读。另一种说法是，有些书——我们不会说具体有多少，也不会试图识别它们，因为在某种程度上这是个人判断——所有读者都无法理解，无论他们多么熟练. 正如我们在上一章所观察到的，这些是每个人都应该特别努力去寻找的作品。它们是真正伟大的书籍；任何人都应该选择将这些书带到他自己的荒岛上。

Some of the books are great in the special sense of the term that we employed in the last chapter. On returning to them, you will always find something new, often many things. They are endlessly re-readable. Another way to say this is that some of the books—we will not say exactly how many, nor will we try to identify them, since to some extent this is an individual judgment—are over the heads of all readers, no matter how skillful. As we observed in the last chapter, these are the works that everyone should make a special effort to seek out. They are the truly great books; they are the books that anyone should choose to take with him to his own desert island.

这份清单很长，看起来有点让人不知所措。我们敦促您不要让自己为此感到羞愧。首先，您可能会认出大多数作者的名字。这里没有什么深奥到深奥的。更重要的是，我们想提醒您，无论出于何种原因，从您最感兴趣的书籍开始阅读是明智的。正如我们多次指出的那样，主要目的是阅读好书，而不是广泛阅读。如果您一年只阅读几本书，您应该不会失望。该列表不是任何时间都可以通过的东西。这不是只有完成每个项目才能迎接的挑战。相反，它是一个邀请，您可以从任何您觉得自在的地方开始，优雅地接受它。

The list is long, and it may seem a little overwhelming. We urge you not to allow yourself to be abashed by it. In the first place, you are likely to recognize the names of most of the authors. There is nothing here that is so recondite as to be esoteric. More important, we want to remind you that it is wise to begin with those books that interest you most, for whatever reason. As we have pointed out several times, the primary aim is to read well, not widely. You should not be disappointed if you read no more than a handful of the books in a year. The list is not something to be gotten through in any amount of time. It is not a challenge that you can meet only by finishing every item on it. Instead, it is an invitation that you can accept graciously by beginning wherever you feel at home.

作者按照已知或假定的出生日期按时间顺序排列。当列出一位作者的几部作品时，这些作品也尽可能按时间顺序排列。学者们并不总是同意一本书的首次出版，但这不需要你担心。要记住的一点是，列表作为一个整体会随着时间向前移动。当然，这并不一定意味着您应该按时间顺序阅读它。你甚至可以从列表的末尾开始，向后阅读荷马和旧约。

The authors are listed chronologically, according to the known or supposed date of their birth. When several works of an author are listed, these too are arranged chronologically, where that is possible. Scholars do not always agree about the first publication of a book, but this need not concern you. The point to remember is that the list as a whole moves forward through time. That does not necessarily mean that you should read it chronologically, of course. You might even start with the end of the list and read backward to Homer and the Old Testament.

我们没有列出每个作者的所有作品。我们通常只引用更重要的书名，在说明性书籍的情况下选择它们，以显示作者对不同学习领域的贡献的多样性。在某些情况下，我们列出了作者的作品，并在括号中指定了那些特别重要或有用的标题。

We have not listed all the works of every author. We have usually cited only the more important titles, selecting them, in the case of expository books, to show the diversity of an author’s contribution to different fields of learning. In some instances, we have listed an author’s Works and specified, in brackets, those titles that are especially important or useful.

在制定此类清单时，最大的困难总是出现在相对现代的项目上。作者离我们的时代越近，就越难对他做出超然的判断。说时间会证明一切都很好，但我们可能不想等待。因此，对于较新的作家和书籍，存在很大的意见分歧空间，我们不会对我们列表中较晚的项目提出我们可以对较早的项目提出的权威程度。

In drawing up a list of this kind, the greatest difficulty always arises with respect to the relatively contemporary items. The closer an author is to our own time, the harder it is to exercise a detached judgment about him. It is all very well to say that time will tell, but we may not want to wait. Thus, with regard to the more recent writers and books, there is much room for differences of opinion, and we would not claim for the later items on our list the degree of authority that we can claim for the earlier ones.

对于一些较早的项目也可能存在意见分歧，我们可能会被指控对一些我们根本没有列出的作者有偏见。在某些情况下，我们愿意承认这可能是正确的。这是我们的清单，在某些方面可能与其他人制定的清单不同。但是，如果每个人都认真地同意制定一个值得花一辈子的阅读计划的目标，那将不会有太大的不同。最终，当然，你应该列出自己的清单，然后着手处理。然而，明智的做法是先阅读大量受到一致好评的书籍，然后再开始自己的研究。这个列表是一个开始的地方。

There may be differences of opinion about some of the earlier items too, and we may be charged with being prejudiced against some authors that we have not listed at all. We are willing to admit that this may be true, in some cases. This is our list, and it may differ in some respects from lists drawn up by others. But it will not differ very significantly if everyone concurs seriously in the aim of making up a reading program that is worth spending a lifetime on. Ultimately, of course, you should make up your own list, and then go to work on it. It is wise, however, to read a fair number of the books that have been unanimously acclaimed before you branch off on your own. This list is a place to begin.

我们想提一个可能会让一些读者感到不幸的遗漏。该列表仅包含西方作者和书籍；没有中国、日本或印度的作品。有几个原因。一是我们对西方文学传统之外的知识并不特别了解，因此我们的建议没有什么分量。另一个是东方不像西方那样有单一的传统，我们必须学习所有东方传统才能做好这项工作。很少有学者能像这样熟悉东方的所有著作。第三，在试图了解世界其他地区的传统之前，了解您自己的传统是有道理的。今天许多人试图阅读《易经》等书籍或《薄伽梵歌》感到困惑，不仅是因为此类作品的内在困难，还因为他们没有通过练习更容易理解的作品来学会阅读——他们更容易理解——他们自己的文化。最后，这个列表已经足够长了。

We want to mention one omission that may strike some readers as unfortunate. The list contains only Western authors and books; there are no Chinese, Japanese, or Indian works. There are several reasons for this. One is that we are not particularly knowledgeable outside of the Western literary tradition, and our recommendations would carry little weight. Another is that there is in the East no single tradition, as there is in the West, and we would have to be learned in all Eastern traditions in order to do the job well. There are very few scholars who have this kind of acquaintance with all the works of the East. Third, there is something to be said for knowing your own tradition before trying to understand that of other parts of the world. Many persons who today attempt to read such books as the I Ching or the Bhagavad-Gita are baffled, not only because of the inherent difficulty of such works, but also because they have not learned to read well by practicing on the more accessible works—more accessible to them—of their own culture. And finally, the list is long enough as it is.

另一个遗漏需要评论。这份名单是一本书，包括少数主要被称为抒情诗人的人的名字。当然，名单上的一些作家写了抒情诗，但他们最著名的是其他更长的作品。这一事实不应被视为反映了我们对抒情诗的偏见。但我们建议从一本好的诗集开始，而不是从单个作者的作品集开始。帕尔格雷夫的黄金宝库和The Oxford Book of English Verse是很好的起点。这些较旧的选集应该由更现代的选集来补充——例如，塞尔登·罗德曼 (Selden Rodman) 的一百首现代诗歌，这是一本广泛使用的平装本合集，以有趣的方式扩展了抒情诗的概念。由于阅读抒情诗需要特殊技巧，我们还会推荐几本有关该主题的可用手册中的任何一本——例如，马克·范多伦 (Mark Van Doren) 的诗歌导论，这是一本选集，其中还包含对如何阅读许多著名歌词的简短讨论。

One other omission requires comment. The list, being one of books, includes the names of few persons known primarily as lyric poets. Some of the writers on the list wrote lyric poems, of course, but they are best known for other, longer works. This fact is not to be taken as reflecting a prejudice on our part against lyric poetry. But we would recommend starting with a good anthology of poetry rather than with the collected works of a single author. Palgrave’s The Golden Treasury and The Oxford Book of English Verse are excellent places to start. These older anthologies should be supplemented by more modern ones—for example, Selden Rodman’s One Hundred Modern Poems, a collection widely available in paperback that extends the notion of a lyric poem in interesting ways. Since reading lyric poetry requires special skill, we would also recommend any of several available handbooks on the subject—for example, Mark Van Doren’s Introduction to Poetry, an anthology that also contains short discussions of how to read many famous lyrics.

 

我们按作者和书名列出了这些书，但我们没有试图指明出版商或特定版本。几乎列表中的每部作品都以某种形式提供，而且许多都有多个版本，包括平装本和精装本。但是，我们已经指出哪些作者和标题包含在我们自己编辑的两组中。西方世界名著中的书名由一个星号标识；Gateway to the Great Books中代表的作者用双星号标识。

We have listed the books by author and title, but we have not attempted to indicate a publisher or a particular edition. Almost every work on the list is available in some form, and many are available in several editions, both paperback and hard cover. However, we have indicated which authors and titles are included in two sets that we ourselves have edited. Titles included in Great Books of the Western World are identified by a single asterisk; authors represented in Gateway to the Great Books are identified by a double asterisk.

 

1.荷马（公元前9世纪。？）

15. 别加的阿波罗尼乌斯（约公元前240年）

16. * *西塞罗（公元前 106-43年。）

16. * *Cicero (106-43 B.C.)

Works (esp. Orations, On Friendship, On Old Age)

17. Lucretius（约公元前 95-55年。）

17. Lucretius (c. 95-55 B.C.)

18. 维吉尔（公元前 70-19年。）

18. Virgil (70-19 B.C.)

19. 贺拉斯（公元前 65-8年。）

19. Horace (65-8 B.C.)

作品（尤其是 Odes and Epodes, The Art of Poetry）

Works (esp. Odes and Epodes, The Art of Poetry)

20. 李维（公元前59年-公元17 年）

20. Livy (59 B.C.-A.D. 17)

罗马史

History of Rome

21. 奥维德（公元前43 年-公元.17 年）

凯撒和克利奥帕特拉，皮格马利翁，圣琼）

Caesar and Cleopatra, Pygmalion, Saint Joan)

122. * *马克斯·普朗克 (1858-1947)

122. * *Max Planck (1858-1947)

 

量子理论的起源与发展 科学何去何从？科学自传

Origin and Development of the Quantum Theory Where Is Science Going? Scientific Autobiography

126. * *乔治·桑塔亚那 (1863-1952)

130. * *托马斯·曼 (1875-1955)

第一圈癌症病房

The First Circle Cancer Ward

附录 B

四个阅读层次的练习和测试

APPENDIX BEXERCISES AND TESTS AT THE FOUR LEVELS OF READING

 

介绍性的

Introductory

 

本附录提供了一个高度简化的示例，说明独立学习或小组学习的阅读练习是什么样的。显然，示例无法提供一套彻底或详尽的练习，例如人们期望在手册或工作簿中找到的练习。然而，它或许可以在某种程度上建议这样的练习是什么，以及如何充分利用它们。

This Appendix offers a highly abbreviated sample of what Reading Exercises for independent study or group study are like. Obviously the sample cannot provide a thorough or exhaustive set of exercises, such as one would expect to find in a manual or workbook. However, it can perhaps go a certain way toward suggesting what such exercises would be, and how to get the most out of them.

附录包含四个阅读级别中每个级别的简短练习和测试问题：

The Appendix contains brief exercises and test questions at each of the four levels of reading:

在第一级阅读——初级阅读——使用的文本是关于西方世界名著中两位作者约翰·斯图尔特·米尔和艾萨克·牛顿爵士的传记。

At the First Level of Reading—Elementary Reading—the texts used are biographical notes about two of the authors included in Great Books of the Western World, John Stuart Mill and Sir Isaac Newton.

第二层次阅读——检视阅读——阅读西方名著中的但丁《神曲》和达尔文《物种起源》两部著作的目录。

At the Second Level of Reading—Inspectional Reading—the texts used are the tables of contents of two works included in Great Books of the Western World, Dante’s Divine Comedy and Darwin’s The Origin of Species.

在阅读的第三个层次——分析阅读——使用的文本是如何阅读一本书本身。

At the Third Level of Reading—Analytical Reading—the text used is How to Read a Book itself.

在阅读的第四个层次——主题阅读——所使用的文本是从另外两篇文章中重印的精选段落作品收录于《西方世界名著•》、亚里士多德的《政治学》和卢梭的《社会契约论》。

At the Fourth Level of Reading—Syntopical Reading—the texts used are selected passages reprinted from two other works included in Great Books• of the Western World, Aristotle’s Politics and Rousseau’s The Social Contract.

读者可能会发现阅读的前两个层次的示例练习比后两个层次的示例练习更熟悉和常规。与更详尽的手册不同，本附录只能加强和阐明不同阅读水平之间的区别以及不同类型书籍之间的区别。它无法尝试提供真正全面和密集的练习手册。

The reader will probably find that the sample exercises at the first two levels of reading are more familiar and conventional than those at the last two levels. This Appendix, unlike a more elaborate manual, can do little more than reinforce and clarify the distinctions between the various levels of reading and the differences between the various kinds of books. It cannot attempt to provide a really comprehensive and intensive exercise workbook.

批评阅读练习和试题已经司空见惯，理由是它们没有科学标准化，它们具有文化歧视性，它们本身不能可靠地预测学业成功或随后的职业发展，问题通常允许不止一个适当或“正确”的答案，并且由于所有这些原因，通过测试评分在一定程度上是任意的。

It has become commonplace to criticize reading exercises and test questions on the grounds that they are not scientifically standardized, that they are culturally discriminatory, that by themselves they are not reliably predictive of success in schooling or in subsequent career progress, that questions often permit of more than one appropriate or “correct” answer, and that for all these reasons, grading by tests is to a certain extent arbitrary.

对考试的大部分批评和类似批评都是正确的，特别是如果有关学校排名或安置或就业机会的重大决定完全基于这些考试的结果。然而，许多测试确实能有效区分或识别能力程度，它们将继续广泛用于对个人进行学术和职业判断。即使没有其他原因，这个原因本身也希望读者对这些练习和试题的机制有一定的了解。

Much of this and similar criticism of the tests is valid, particularly if major decisions about school standing or placement, or about employment opportunities, are based exclusively on results drawn from these tests. However, many of the tests do effectively distinguish or identify degrees of competence, and they will continue to be widely employed in making academic and career judgments about individuals. Even if there were no other reasons, this reason by itself makes it desirable that the reader have some familiarity with the mechanics of these exercises and test questions.

特别要注意的是，大多数此类阅读练习中使用的文本主要是为了基于它们的试题而选择的。因此，文本本身在很大程度上是无关的；通常它们是片段——技术迂腐的点点滴滴或仅仅是琐事。

It is particularly to be noted that the texts used in most such reading exercises are selected primarily for the sake of the test questions that are based on them. Hence the texts themselves are for the most part unrelated; frequently they are fragments—bits and pieces of technical pedantry or mere trivia.

在本附录中，尽管它只是示例性的，但重点却完全不同。用于练习和提供测试材料的文本本身就值得一读。事实上，对于任何愿意阅读的人来说，它们都是不可或缺的读物超越第一级阅读。选择文本并设计基于它们的问题作为学习如何阅读值得阅读的工具。

In this Appendix, merely exemplary though it be, the emphasis is quite otherwise. The texts used for practice and to provide material for testing are themselves worth reading. Indeed, they are indispensable reading for anyone who wishes to advance beyond the first levels of reading. The texts are selected and the questions based on them are designed as tools for learning how to read what is worth reading.

关于出现在以下页面中的测试中使用的问题形式的一个词。在此类测试中通常会采用多种不同类型的问题。有论述题和多项选择题。当然，作文题要求被试回答他在扩展陈述中读到的内容。多项选择题又分很多种；通常它们出现在同类组中。有时阅读练习后会出现一系列陈述，被测者被要求指出哪一个陈述最能表达所读文章的主要思想或观点。在其他情况下，可能会向读者提供有关文本细节的陈述选择，其中只有一个是对文本的有效解释，或者至少比其他的更恰当；或者可能恰恰相反；一个是错误的选择，另一个是正确的。或者可以从文本中逐字引用，以发现读者是否注意到并记住了它。有时，在直接引用或简单地从文本中提取的语句中，读者会发现一个空白，表示省略了一个或多个对语句有意义的词。然后是一个选项列表，字母或数字，被测试的人被要求选择插入空白时最能完成陈述的短语。在直接引用或简单地从文本中提取的陈述中，读者会发现一个空白，表示省略了一个或多个可以理解该陈述的词。然后是一个选项列表，字母或数字，被测试的人被要求选择插入空白时最能完成陈述的短语。在直接引用或简单地从文本中提取的陈述中，读者会发现一个空白，表示省略了一个或多个可以理解该陈述的词。然后是一个选项列表，字母或数字，被测试的人被要求选择插入空白时最能完成陈述的短语。

A word about the form of the questions used in the tests that appear in the following pages. It is customary in such tests to employ a number of different kinds of questions. There are essay questions and multiple-choice questions. An essay question, of course, requires the person being tested to respond to something he has read in an extended statement. Multiple-choice questions are in turn of many kinds; usually they are presented in homogeneous groups. Sometimes a series of statements follows the reading exercise, and the person being tested is asked to indicate which statement best expresses the main idea or ideas of the passage read. In other cases the reader may be offered a choice of statements about a detail in the text, only one of which is a valid interpretation of the text, or at least is more apt than the others; or it may be the other way around; one is an incorrect choice, and the others are correct. Or a verbatim quotation may be given from the text to discover whether the reader has taken note of it and remembered it. Sometimes, in a statement either quoted directly or simply drawn from the text the reader will find a blank indicating that one or more words that will make sense of the statement have been omitted. Then follows a list of choices, lettered or numbered, among which the person being tested is asked to choose the phrase that, when inserted in the blank, best completes the statement.

大多数问题可以直接从阅读的文章中得到回答。但有些问题要求读者跳出文本，寻找假设他知道的材料，正确回答问题所需的材料。还有一些问题是推论性的：也就是说，它们从文本中得出某些推论。要求参加测试的人从一组可能性中选择可以从文本中合理得出的推论；或者他可能会被期望识别并丢弃那些在文本中没有根据的虚假推论。

Most questions may be answered directly from the passage read. But some questions require the reader to go outside the text for material that it is assumed he knows, material required to answer the question correctly. Still other questions are inferential: that is, they draw certain inferences from the text. The person taking the test is asked to select from a group of possibilities the inferences that can reasonably be drawn from the text; or he may be expected to recognize and discard inferences that are spurious and have no foundation in the text.

如果一个人面临着创建一个标准化的任务要在关键的学术和职业情况下广泛使用测试，那么问题类型的选择和问题本身的框架也变得至关重要。幸运的是，我们在本附录中没有面临那种任务。相反，我们只是建议一些可以在旨在提高个人阅读技能的独立学习课程中尝试的方法。我们将在接下来的内容中使用刚刚描述的大多数类型的问题——而不是像通常所做的那样将类型分成组——以及一些其他类型的问题。有些很容易，有些则非常困难；困难的问题可能是最有趣的尝试回答。

If one is faced with the task of creating a standardized test to be used widely in critical academic and career situations, then the choice of the kinds of questions and the framing of the questions themselves become critical as well. Fortunately, we do not face that kind of task in this Appendix. Instead, we are merely suggesting some approaches that may be tried in a course of independent study aimed at improving one’s own reading skills. We will employ in what follows most of the kinds of questions just described—not segregating the types in groups as is usually done—and some other kinds as well. Some are quite easy, others are very difficult; the difficult questions may be the most fun to try to answer.

因为有些问题非常困难，而且因为我们设计这些问题的目的既是为了让你反思你所读的内容，也是为了测试你所阅读的内容，所以在许多情况下，我们给出的比通常的要多对问题的简短而隐晦的回答。对于本附录最后一部分（主题阅读部分）中的问题，情况尤其如此。在那里，我们冒昧地牵着读者的手，以这样一种方式提出问题，以建议对所读文本的整体解释，并尽可能多地回答问题，就好像我们在场一样亲自。

Because some of the questions are very difficult, and because we have framed them with the intention as much of causing you to reflect on what you have read as to test you on what you have read, we have in many cases given more than the customary short and cryptic answers to the questions. This is particularly so in the case of the questions in the last part of this Appendix, the section dealing with syntopical reading. There, we have taken the liberty of leading the reader by the hand, as it were, framing the questions in such a way as to suggest an overall interpretation of the texts read, and answering the questions as much as possible as though we were present in person.

一、阅读一级练习与测试：初级阅读

I. Exercises and Tests at the First Level of Reading: Elementary Reading

 

附录的这一部分出现了两个简短的传记素描。一本概述了约翰·斯图尔特·密尔的生平，另一本概述了艾萨克·牛顿爵士的生平。穆勒的草图首先出现，尽管牛顿当然比穆勒早了将近两个世纪。

Two short biographical sketches appear in this section of the Appendix. One outlines the life of John Stuart Mill, the other that of Sir Isaac Newton. The Mill sketch appears first, although of course Newton predates Mill by nearly two centuries.

这部穆勒的传记素描转载自《西方世界名著》第 43 卷。除了《独立宣言》、《邦联条例》、美国宪法以及汉密尔顿、麦迪逊和杰伊的联邦党人文集——美国的建国文件——卷包含密尔的三部全集：《论自由》、《代议制政府》和《功利主义》。这是密尔最伟大的三部作品，但它们绝不是他所有著作的全部。例如， 《妇女的从属》在当代引起了极大的兴趣，这不仅是因为穆勒是西方历史上最早提倡妇女完全平等的思想家之一，而且还因为这本书尖锐的风格和它表达的许多关于女性平等的见解。随时随地的男女关系。

This biographical sketch of Mill is reprinted from Volume 43 of Great Books of the Western World. Besides the Declaration of Independence, the Articles of Confederation, the U.S. Constitution, and the Federalist Papers of Hamilton, Madison and Jay—the founding documents of America—that volume contains three complete works by Mill: On Liberty, Representative Government and Utilitarianism. These are three of Mill’s greatest works, but they by no means exhaust his writings. The Subjection of Women, for example, is of great contemporary interest, not only because Mill was one of the first thinkers in Western history to advocate complete equality for women, but also because of the book’s trenchant style and the many insights it expresses about the relations of men and women at any time and place.

在第一层次的阅读中，速度并不是最重要的。接下来的密尔生平速写大约有 1,200 字长。我们建议以舒适的速度阅读它——大约六到十分钟。我们还建议您标记文本中您特别感兴趣的短语和句子，或许还可以做一些注释。然后尝试回答我们附加的问题。

At the first level of reading, speed is not of the essence. The sketch of Mill’s life that follows is about 1,200 words long. We suggest that it be read at a comfortable speed—in perhaps six to ten minutes. We also suggest that you mark phrases and sentences in the text that especially interest you and perhaps also make a few notes. Then try to answer the questions we have appended.

约翰·斯图尔特·米尔1806-1873 _

JOHN STUART MILL1806-1873

 

穆勒在他的自传中宣称，他的智力发展主要归功于两个人的影响：他的父亲詹姆斯·穆勒和他的妻子。

Mill, in his Autobiography, declared that his intellectual development was due primarily to the influence of two people: his father, James Mill, and his wife.

詹姆斯·穆勒以爱尔维蒂乌斯和边沁的理论为蓝本，为他的儿子制定了一个全面的教育计划。它的范围堪称百科全书，并在穆勒 13 岁时为他提供了相当于全面大学教育的知识。父亲充当男孩的导师和忠实伙伴，允许穆勒与他在同一个房间工作，甚至在他写印度史或为大英百科全书撰写文章时打断他。密尔后来将这一结果描述为“让我看起来像一个‘人造’或人造的人，我身上烙下了某种我只能复制的观点印象。”

James Mill elaborated for his son a comprehensive educational program, modelled upon the theories of Helvétius and Bentham. It was encyclopedic in scope and equipped Mill by the time he was thirteen with the equivalent of a thorough university education. The father acted as the boy’s tutor and constant companion, allowing Mill to work in the same room with him and even to interrupt him as he was writing his History of India or his articles for the Encyclopaedia Britannica. Mill later described the result as one that “made me appear as a ‘made’ or manufactured man, having had a certain impress of opinion stamped upon me which I could only reproduce.”

三岁开始接受希腊语和算术教育。到他八岁时，密尔已经通读了整部希罗多德、柏拉图的六篇对话和相当多的历史。十二岁之前，他学习过欧几里德和代数、希腊和拉丁诗人以及一些英国诗歌。他对历史的兴趣继续，他甚至试图写一个罗马政府的帐户。十二岁时，他在亚里士多德的《欧加农》和有关该主题的拉丁文学术手册中接触到逻辑学。在他父亲直接监督下的最后一年，也就是他第 13 岁，专攻政治经济学。儿子的笔记后来在他的政治经济学原理中为老穆勒服务。他通过与父亲的朋友一起学习一段时间来进一步接受教育，跟随奥斯汀学习法律，跟随李嘉图学习经济学，并靠自己完成了边沁关于立法的论文，他认为这篇论文给了他“一种信条、一种学说、一种哲学……宗教”，并使“他成为一个不同的人”。

The education began with Greek and arithmetic at the age of three. By the time he was eight Mill had read through the whole of Herodotus, six dialogues of Plato and considerable history. Before he was twelve he had studied Euclid and algebra, the Greek and Latin poets, and some English poetry. His interest in history continued, and he even attempted writing an account of Roman government. At twelve he was introduced to logic in Aristotle’s Organon and the Latin scholastic manuals on the subject. The last year under his father’s direct supervision, his thirteenth, was devoted to political economy; the son’s notes later served the elder Mill in his Elements of Political Economy. He furthered his education by a period of studies with his father’s friends, reading law with Austin and economics with Ricardo, and completed it by himself with Bentham’s treatise on legislation, which he felt gave him “a creed, a doctrine, a philosophy … a religion” and made a “different being of him.”

尽管密尔从未真正与父亲断绝关系，但他在 20 岁那年经历了一场心理“危机”。他突然想到提出这个问题：“假设你生活中的所有目标都实现了；您所期待的所有制度和观点的变化，都可以在这一刻完全生效：这对您来说会是一种极大的快乐和幸福吗？” 他报告说“一种无法抑制的自我意识清楚地回答，'不'”，他被持续数年的抑郁症所克服。在阅读马蒙特尔的回忆录时，他的“忧郁”第一次破灭：“我……来到一段讲述他父亲去世、家庭的悲惨处境，以及他当时还是个孩子的突然灵感，并让他们觉得他将成为他们的一切——将提供一个地方他们失去的一切。” 他被这一幕感动得热泪盈眶，从这一刻起，他的“担子轻了”。

Although Mill never actually severed relations with his father, he experienced, at the age of twenty, a “crisis” in his mental history. It occurred to him to pose the question: “Suppose that all your objects in life were realized; that all the changes in institutions and opinions which you are looking forward to, could be completely effected at this very instant: would this be a great joy and happiness to you?” He reported that “an irrepressible self-consciousness distinctly answered, ‘No,’” and he was overcome by a depression which lasted for several years. The first break in his “gloom” came while reading Marmontel’s Mémoires:“I … came to the passage which relates his father’s death, the distressed position of the family, and the sudden inspiration by which he, then a mere boy, felt and made them feel that he would be everything to them —would supply the place of all that they had lost.” He was moved to tears by the scene, and from this moment his “burden grew lighter.”

从 17 岁起，穆勒就在他父亲担任官员的东印度公司工作以养活自己。虽然他一开始名义上是文员，但很快就晋升为助理审查员，从他父亲 1836 年去世到公司的活动被英国政府接管为止的二十年里，他一直负责与印度的关系。国家，这给了他在政府问题上广泛的实践经验。除了正常工作外，他还参加了许多为立法改革准备公众舆论的活动。他、他的父亲和他们的朋友组成了一个被称为“哲学激进分子”的团体，该团体对导致 1832 年改革法案的辩论做出了重大贡献。密尔积极揭露他认为背离合理的东西议会和法院的原则。他经常为对“激进”事业友好的报纸撰稿，帮助创建和编辑作为“激进”机关的《威斯敏斯特评论》，并参加了多个阅读和辩论社团，致力于讨论当代知识和社会问题。

From the time he was seventeen, Mill supported himself by working for the East India Company, where his father was an official. Although he began nominally as a clerk, he was soon promoted to assistant-examiner, and for twenty years, from his father’s death in 1836, until the Company’s activities were taken over by the British Government, he had charge of the relations with the Indian states, which gave him wide practical experience in the problems of government. In addition to his regular employment, he took part in many activities tending to prepare public opinion for legislative reform. He, his father, and their friends formed the group known as “philosophical radicals,” which made a major contribution to the debates leading to the Reform Bill of 1832. Mill was active in exposing what he considered departures from sound principle in parliament and the courts of justice. He wrote often for the newspapers friendly to the “radical” cause, helped to found and edit the Westminster Review as a “radical” organ, and participated in several reading and debating societies, devoted to the discussion of the contemporary intellectual and social problems.

这些活动并没有阻止他追求自己的知识兴趣。他编辑了边沁的《司法证据原理》。他研究逻辑和科学，旨在将三段论逻辑与归纳科学的方法相协调，并出版了他的《逻辑系统》( System of Logic ) (1843)。与此同时，他将自己的研究推向了经济学领域。这些首先以《政治经济学中一些悬而未决的问题》的形式出现，后来在《政治经济学原理》（1848 年）中得到了系统的处理。

These activities did not prevent him from pursuing his own intellectual interests. He edited Bentham’s Rationale of Judicial Evidence. He studied logic and science with the aim of reconciling syllogistic logic with the methods of inductive science, and published his System of Logic (1843). At the same time he pushed his inquiries in the field of economics. These first took the form of Essays on Some Unsettled Questions in Political Economy and were later given systematic treatment in the Principles of Political Economy (1848).

他将这些年的发展和生产力归功于他与 Harriet Taylor 夫人的关系，她于 1851 年成为他的妻子。密尔认识她已有 20 年，自从他的“危机”后不久，他对她的影响赞不绝口。在他的工作上。尽管他在七年的婚姻生活中发表的作品比他职业生涯中的任何其他时期都少，但他构思并部分完成了他的许多重要作品，包括随笔《论自由》 (1859 年)、《议会改革思想》，后来导致了代议制政府（1861 年）和功利主义（1863 年）。他特别将他对他所倡导的抽象改革的人性方面的理解归功于她。在她死后，他说：“对我来说，对她的记忆是一种信仰，她的认可是我努力规范自己生活的标准，它总结了所有的价值。”

The development and productivity of these years he attributed to his relationship with Mrs. Harriet Taylor, who became his wife in 1851. Mill had known her for twenty years, since shortly after his “crisis,” and he could never praise too highly her influence upon his work. Although he published less during the seven years of his married life than at any other period of his career, he thought out and partly wrote many of his important works, including the essay On Liberty (1859), the Thoughts on Parliamentary Reform, which later led to the Representative Government (1861), and Utilitarianism (1863). He attributed to her especially his understanding of the human side of the abstract reforms he advocated. After her death he stated: “Her memory is to me a religion, and her approbation the standard by which, summing up as it does all worthiness, I endeavour to regulate my life.”

密尔将他最后几年的大部分时间直接用于政治活动。除了他的著作之外，他还是第一个妇女选举权协会的创始人之一，并于 1865 年同意成为国会议员。他与自由党的激进派一起投票，积极参与迪斯雷利改革法案的辩论，并推动他长期倡导的措施，如妇女代表权、伦敦政府改革和土地变更等。在爱尔兰的任期。主要是因为他支持不受欢迎的措施，他未能连任。他退隐到他在阿维尼翁的小屋，这座小屋的建造是为了让他可以靠近他妻子的坟墓，并于 1873 年 5 月 8 日在那里去世。

Mill devoted a large part of his last years directly to political activity. In addition to his writings, he was one of the founders of the first women’s suffrage society and, in 1865, consented to become a member of Parliament. Voting with the radical wing of the Liberal Party, he took an active part in the debates on Disraeli’s Reform Bill and promoted the measures which he had long advocated, such as the representation of women, the reform of London government, and the alteration of land tenure in Ireland. Largely because of his support of unpopular measures, he was defeated for re-election. He retired to his cottage in Avignon, which had been built so that he might be close to the grave of his wife, and died there May 8, 1873.

请注意，这些测试中的问题并不都是同一类型：有多种选择题和一些作文题。有些问题需要你阅读的文章中没有包含的信息——有能力的读者为他所读的任何内容提供的背景信息。选择所有你认为有效的答案，无论它们是在文本中明示或暗示的，还是仅根据逻辑或你的背景信息在你看来是正确的。

Note that the questions in these tests are not all of the same type: there are several kinds of multiple-choice questions and some essay questions as well. Some questions call for information not included in the passage you have read—the background information a capable reader brings to whatever he reads. Select all the answers which seem to you to be valid, whether they are stated or implied in the text, or simply seem to you true on the basis of logic or your background information.

测试 A：关于约翰·斯图尔特·穆勒的传记素描的问题

Test A: Questions about the biographical sketch of John Stuart Mill

 

1. 在密尔生命的后期，英格兰由 (a) 乔治四世 (b) 威廉四世 (c) 维多利亚 (d) 爱德华七世统治。

1. During the latter part of Mill’s life, England was ruled by (a) George IV (b) William IV (c) Victoria (d) Edward VII.

2. Mill 的早期教育主要由 (a) Jeremy Bentham (b) 他的父亲 James Mill (c)大英百科全书 (Encyclopaedia Britannica )设计，他父亲为此撰写了文章 (d) Marmontel's Mémoires。

2. Mill’s early education was largely designed by (a) Jeremy Bentham (b) his father, James Mill (c) the Encyclopaedia Britannica for which his father wrote articles (d) Marmontel’s Mémoires.

3. 到他八岁时，密尔已经阅读了 (a) 希罗多德 (b) 柏拉图的六段对话 (c) 林肯的葛底斯堡演说。

3. By the time he was eight years old, Mill had read (a) Herodotus (b) six dialogues of Plato (c) Lincoln’s Gettysburg Address.

4. Mill 在 (a) 14 (b) 17 (c) 21 (d) 25 岁时去东印度公司工作养活自己。

4. Mill went to work for the East India Company to support himself at the age of (a) 14 (b) 17 (c) 21 (d) 25.

5. 在 20 岁时，密尔经历了 (a) 与父亲的争吵 (b) 心理史的危机 (c) 心理史的“危机” (d) 与已婚妇女的恋情。

5. At the age of twenty, Mill experienced a (a) quarrel with his father (b) crisis in his mental history (c) “crisis” in his mental history (d) love affair with a married woman.

6. 穆勒、他的父亲和他们的朋友称自己为“哲学激进分子”，因为他们相信 (a) 可以通过暴力推翻政府 (b) 应该对议会代表进行改革 (c) 哲学研究应该从大学课程中删除。

6. Mill, his father, and their friends called themselves “philosophical radicals” because they believed (a) in the overthrow of the government by violence (b) that reforms should be made in Parliamentary representation (c) that the study of philosophy should be dropped from college curriculums.

7. 穆勒年轻时读过的、可能影响了他思想的作家有 (a) 亚里士多德 (b) 杜威 (c) 李嘉图 (d) 边沁。

7. Among the authors whom Mill read as a young man, and who probably influenced his thinking, were (a) Aristotle (b) Dewey (c) Ricardo (d) Bentham.

8. 文中没有提到 Mill 的哪些著名作品？(a) 关于自由(b)代议制政府(c)功利主义(d)妇女的屈从。

8. Which of these well known works of Mill is not mentioned in the text? (a) On Liberty (b) Representative Government (c) Utilitarianism (d) The Subjection of Women.

9. 如果他今天还活着，密尔会不会

9. Were he alive today, is it likely or not likely that Mill would be

LIKELY

不见得

10. 从文中可以推断，密尔认为他的妻子（前夫人哈里特·泰勒）在婚内和死后都是 (a) 他最严厉的批评者 (b) 他最好的朋友 (c) 他的最大的敌人 (d) 他的缪斯女神。

10. It can be inferred from the text that Mill considered his wife (the former Mrs. Harriet Taylor), both during their marriage and after her death, to be (a) his severest critic (b) his best friend (c) his greatest enemy (d) his muse.

翻页。413用于测试 A 的答案。

Turn to p. 413 for the answers to Test A.
